review_text: I love how simple the story was told but the meaning of each words leave you think and make you realize. Auggie was indeed the epitome of courage, strength and wisdom. I love how each of the key characters had a chapter to show their own perspective. And each of them lead to one thing, their love and concern for Auggie. I really broke down on the graduation part. It was really a heart breaking scene and I can picture out how people who use to insult him, who use to talk behind his back and who use to scare away from him as if he has a contagious disease.

4.5 stars rounded up to 5. So I had high expectations coming into this book and the beginning was kind of slow but I'd say my expectations were surpassed. 
 I was surprised to find out that this book had multiple povs, not just August (a.k.a. Auggie, our protagonist and main character). Those other povs turned out to be my favorite part of the book. It was a very clever addition that worked out because the other povs give us insight in how other people perceive August's facial deformities. It works so well because the author was spot on in her characterization of the characters. Their thoughts and their actions were 100% accurate/realistic and completely reflect how kids (and even adults) would act or think. Honestly, reading this transported me back to when I was in elementary school and I honestly emphasize so much. I was definitely one of those kids who didn't partake in bullying but I wouldn't stand up for the person either (I'm ashamed to say). 
 Kids and adults alike will enjoy this book and the message resonates no matter how old one may be. Everyone should be reminded of the message of this book and I genuinely think if I ever have a child/children I'm going to give them this book to read. I honestly teared up like twice throughout this book, but I'm a big sap, so. 
 Also, the book I was reading had an extra "Julian" chapter and while I think it was a nice touch it wasn't as resonating or good as the main book imo, but maybe I'm being too harsh.
Nja, inte sa bra som jag vantade mig.

I love love love Wonder; it's wonderfully written, great story, and I enjoyed talking about it with my friends back in the day I first read it 2-3 years ago... Wonder told us about the struggling life of August Pullman (Auggie). The main issue is something we could relate in our daily life; in our interaction with family at home or in the school life to be exact. And the overal issues that Wonder told to us is something really realistic. I cried a bucket in the bullying part when I first read Wonder, since it's one of the issues I concern the most.

Fan-freaking-tastic! Loved it! After Atticus Finch, Isabel and Nate Pullman are my FAVORITE literary parents. I laughed. I cried. JUST READ IT!! (Why not 5 stars you ask? Because I listened to the audiobook and the last 45 minutes are pretty uneventful and I got a tad bored.)

Wonder by R.J. Palacio. (c)2012. 5 Stars. I got this ebook from the library. Engaging from the very start. A heavy subject written with a light touch. A middle grade read which should be mandatory in that it deals with self-image and bullying in young people's lives at school and beyond. Highly recommend!

When you finish this book, you won't help but notice the rising of the hairs at the back of your neck, and the feeling that August Pullman isn't a fictional character, but a real person living in New York City at this very moment. Excellent, excellent read. I await Palacio's next work, which I am sure would be just as endearing.

WONDER is a book you snuggle with when you finish the last page. 
 I knew this was a book about a boy with a facial abnormality, but I didn't really know what else to expect. I was surprised by the several POV's and the wonderful story of a boy and his family. 
 WONDER made me laugh hysterically and cry like a baby and sometimes, both at the same time-- like when Jack told Auggie he should sue his plastic surgeon. 
 I loved that this book doesn't make you feel sorry for Auggie (the MC), it opens your eyes to his world and the world of those who are surrounding him and loving him. 
 The characters in this book were so believable. They each love Auggie, but struggle with their own feelings of peer pressure, insecurity and pride. 
 This is such a beautiful book with a theme to be more kind than necessary. There should be more books like this out there! 
 Thank you RJ Palacio!

"I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 I agree, Auggie. Ms. Palacio, I'm giving you one right now, for this amazing book. 
 In case you've been living under a rock, here's a basic summary of Wonder: August Pullman is the new kid at Beecher Prep- in fact he is new to a standard school setting in general, having previously been home-schooled- but that's not the only thing that makes him an object of curiosity. Because of a genetic disorder, he was born with facial deformities that- despite numerous surgeries and medical procedures- are still quite shocking to behold. His first year of "regular" school is sure to be a challenge, but it might turn out to be a triumph as well. 
 This is an amazing story. Auggie has a touching, authentic voice and his experiences are raw and honest. On one level, Wonder has similarities to your average school story- friendship problems, trouble with bullies, family ups and downs, and more- but the author raises the bar, and makes this story more important than a simple tale for entertainment. Palacio's writing is powerful; full of pure emotion and some really beautiful sentiments. The main thread of the book focuses on how wonderful and necessary it is for a person to be accepted and cherished for who they are inside- a lesson that can never be emphasized enough.

This is such a good book about friendship..Sincerity is the most imporatant things to have in a friendship....Auggie is such a awesome kid that went through difficulties at school... 
 Precept from Mr Browne.... 
 YOUR DEEDS ARE YOUR MONUMENTS 
 "This precept means that we should be remembered for the things we do. The things we do are the most important things of all. They more important than what we say or what we look like. The things we do outlast our mortality. The things we do are like monuments that people do to honor heroes after they've died. They're like the pyramids that the Egyptian build to honor the pharaohs. Only instead of being made out of stone, they're made out of memories people have of you. That's why youe deeds are like your monuments. Build with the memories instead of with stone." 
 I really like this precept.

Since I've become a children's librarian, I've been reading more j fic and I must say Wonder is one of the best I've read in a while, quite a step up from Diary of a Wimpy Kid (although that book has its place and even gets a shout out in this book). 
 The story is told first by August, also know to his family by the name of Auggie, a boy who has a facial deformity that he's had since birth. Life's about to change drastically for August because this year instead of being home schooled he's off to the public school to start 5th grade. August tells us the first part of the story and then the story is taken up by other characters who illuminate their own participation in August's life. I know some reviewers here thought some of these points of view didn't advance the story but I have to disagree. I liked hearing about those other character's opinions and how they viewed August. I thought it gave the story more punch. 
 It's a moving story because we come to realize that even though August is physically different, fundamentally he's the same as every other 5th grader. It's heartening to see people learn this lesson. It's a lesson worth learning for everyone when we come across people who are different from us. 
 I think this is a book that anyone could or should read but especially middle/high schoolers. They'll be able to relate to every character in the book and the situations presented.
Loved it! I simply could not put this book down, I read it in one day. And when I finally finished it, I literally held it up to my chest and hugged it.

A great story of kindness and how it can change the world! I loved getting to know each character as they told the story from their point of view. August is one brave kid and I love his summer precept- "that everyone should have one standing ovation in their lives". I couldn't agree more!

We live a world which revolves a great deal on appearances and materials, because of this I really enjoyed being able to read a book which shows us how insignificant these things should be to us and remind us of what is really important. 
 We tend to criticize those who are different and not classified as 'normal' because we aren't open to what we do not know or understand. 
 Wonder lets us empathise with those we don't understand through the points of views in which the story is written in. This is one of the few books which can't help but inspires you and warm your heart. This novel follows the life of August Pullman, a adorable ten year old boy who lives everyday facing the challenge of difference . August, who was unfortunate enough to be born with a facial deformation , must confront his fears of going to school August and all those in his life are breathtakingly beautiful characters who were highly developed and moving to read about. These characters took the readers on a enjoyable journey that I wish did not end -They made this book impossible to dislike. What drew me to August and made him capture my heart was not that he was different but his courage and bravery. That he was able to face his fears even though it was difficult and never gave up, he doesn't wallow in self-pity or choose the easy way out. 
 R.J. Palacio has successfully written a touching story , more than worth the read.

Really great book that took me way too long to read! I guess that's what comes from this life. 
 Anyway, I thought the idea of looking at a situation from different perspectives was good for this book-I usually find it rather forced and unneeded-but with this it would allow kids to see perspective and how unintended actions can still hurt. 
 I was a bit disappointed about the fact that the antagonist of the novel was put aside so neatly, but it was written for 5th graders, not adults, so I'll cut the author some slack!

4.5 stars 
 I have tears in my eyes.

This is a solid novel that could have used some restraint. Auggie's experience with his appearance is certainly heartbreaking and revealing. The handful of protagonists are far more developed than most middle-grade novels. That being said, this novel can be really, really cheesy, especially towards the ending.

My daughter read this a couple years ago and recommended it to me. I couldn't put it down. They say that sometimes fiction can be more true than non-fiction, and this book is a great example. This book is like scripture for the principle that everyone has difficulties, seen and unseen; that people can change for good reason, bad reason, or no reason; that there's good and bad in everyone; that life is a series of challenges that we thrive by overcoming, or learn by succumbing. Truly a beautiful story, accessible to all.
I absolutely loved this book. It is not easy to write about a young person with physical disabilities and allow his voice to come through as a regular kid. This book succeeded beautifully.

So -- let me say this. 
 There are some complaints in negative reviews that the characters in this book all sound alike, and that real life doesn't allow for such fantastical turn-arounds in the hearts and minds of middle schoolers. Maybe they're right. 
 And yet, this is a book to love. It might help to remember that the intended reading audience for the book is probably not me (late thirties, English degree), and odds are it's not you, either. The former middle school teacher in me wants to make this required reading for all middle schoolers, and then open the floor for community discussion. 
 Augie's facial defects are described as extreme, but really, there's an Augie at each school, and one in each grade, each class. That kid who for one reason or another is different and perceived to be so. The one who is teased and yes, bullied--the one who is chosen last for teams or groups, the one who sits alone at lunch and recess. 
 It is human nature to identify these differences, and maybe it's human nature to compare ourselves (with relief... thank goodness we're not like THAT), to draw a comfortable line of separation between ourselves and whatever that difference might be. 
 Overcoming those instincts and growing in wisdom and compassion is a good thing, and thanks to R.J. Palacio and Wonder for reinforcing that lesson.

Auggie is an endearing boy you'll want in your classroom as a student or classmate. He knows he has a purpose but struggles with the reality that people will judge him before they even get to know him. I loved the way that the author retold the same scenes from the different character's point of view. I would hope my students will all have an ahh haa moment in their own lives when meeting new people as wells as being the new kid. Great addition for the Lone Star list.
Probably the best YA book I've ever read.
The kind of book you hug when you finish

August was born with several problems, including a cleft lip and palate, that left his face severely disfigured. He is entering 5th grade and attending school for the first time outside of his home. I couldn't help thinking that 5th grade is a pretty rough time to be starting school, even in the best of circumstances. August weathers the social storm and makes friends, and we get to experience it all through his eyes, the eyes of a couple of his friends, his sister, her best friend and her boyfriend. The story is tender and inspiring and well worth the quick read.

For about a week before I read this book I was in a reading rut. I had started 4 different books and managed to finish none of them. Nothing appealed to me, nothing made me want to sit down and completely lose track of time while reading. Until Wonder came along. Wonder came across my radar through a NetGalley email. The cover art jumped off the computer screen and then I read the description and was hooked. 
 Each of Palacio's perspectives are so well developed I feel like these are people I actually know. Each character's voice is clear and distinctive. I only wish I could have seen the story through the eyes of one of August's parents (but that would have pulled the book from its middle grades reading level). Palacio does a brilliant job of demonstrating how it isn't always easy to make the right choice. How sometimes we all struggle with making the decision to be kind and empathetic to others. I thought this was going to be a sad, make me cry book but instead it was a joyous, uplifting, make me laugh book(although I did cry once). 
 I appreciated the short chapter formatting of the book. I think that will make it very accessible to reluctant readers. I can't wait to get this book on my library's shelf and start recommending it. 
 Bonus points for quoting Natalie Merchant and great mentions of Diary of a Wimpy Kind, Star Wars, Wizard of Oz, etc.

I loved the lesson this book teaches about having compassion for others. I enjoyed the different perspectives from the characters throughout the book, although I would have liked to have heard from August a little more. Great book for kids (and adults) to read on acceptance/anti-bullying.

My BIL recommended this book and I have to thank him! I laughed; I cried; and now I will strive to "always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary.". I will also recommend this book to everyone.
Words cannot describe how wonderful this book is. Read it. "always try to be a little kinder than necessary."
A MUST read for everyone!!! I will definitely be adding this to my read aloud each year.

Loved the characters in this book, especially Auggie's family. It was thought provoking, funny, and sweet. I gave it only 4 stars because it didn't move me at the end like I was hoping for. Great book nonetheless.

So I cried multiple times reading this book, heck, I cried within the first 60 pages or so. I read this super quickly as the format of the book is very appealing and makes it an easy read. I adored the characters and loved hearing multiple different viewpoints throughout. This book is very inspiring and uplifting in a way, as it teaches the reader many a valuable lesson. I love a good quote and this book contains many great ones which I will take away with me. Touching, beautifully written and an all round great book recommended to people of all ages. Huge thumbs up from me :)
Fantastic! I read this in a day and a half. I loved the variety of perspectives and voices. I would highly recommend it.
Okay, so can I give this book a thousand stars? ABSOLUTELY BRILLIANT. [?]
Awesome book. Highly recommend!

I couldn't wait to finish this book so I could pass it on to my nine year old grandson. What does that say about the value of this book? I can see it as the perfect read aloud for a fifth and sixth grade class.

Wow, *such* a good book! I laughed, I cried, and I absolutely rooted for all the protagonists, especially August, of course. 
 Did not agree with some representations of heaven, but other than that completely and utterly loved this book. Could not recommend it higher.

This book has first-person narrations by Auggie, who has a rare genetic defect that caused severe deformities to his head; his friend Summer, the first person at his new school to befriend him; Via, his older sister; Jack, who was asked to be Auggie's buddy at the beginning of the school year; and Justin, whose family has taught him to look down on those who don't look like they do. Keep a box of tissues handy--the story is by turns insightful, sad, and uplifting. I recommend it as a read-aloud for intermediate grade-school classes, and every school library should have at least one copy of the shelf. Start reading it when you have a lot of free time ahead--you won't want to put it down.

I wanted to give this a four stars but when I got to the very last sentence, a wash of realization hit me. That this book had to be a five star :) 
 This is such an inspiring book and it opens up the heart :') It was a fast pace book, I got really into it. I did tear up, at the same time laughed a LOT :D A great book overall :)

"Wonder" by R.J Palacio is a fantatic read, and I'm glad I picked it up even though it was meant for younger readers, while I am 17 years old. I wish I had the chance to read this book as a child because It could've taught me an important life lesson. 
 "Wonder" is the story of August Pullman, a ten year old who goes to school for the fisrt time after years of being homeschooled. As if that isn't hard enough, August has a very rare facial deformity. August feels like an ordinary kid, and you can certainly agree when you read his thoughts, but his face prevents him from being truly ordianry. 
 I kept wondering what my response would have been had I met a boy like August- smart, kind hearted, brave- could I ignore his appearance and just accept him the way he was? I do know that I will certainly try harder after reading this book. 
 I felt like the characters were very well deveolped and much thought was put into August's character. The story is told through different perspecitves which actually worked great. The only character I didn't like was Via's (August's older sister) boyfriend, but his part didn't ruin it for me. 
 In conculsion, JUST READ IT! No matter how old you are! I'm sure you'll shed a tear at some point while reading this book, and August will find his way to your heart.

Great book for young teens about the struggle to be accepted in life and about being different. 
 Started a little on the boring side, but quickly became interesting and had an ending that will make you smile broadly.
Read this on the recommendation of a fifth grade teacher friend, and I'm so glad I did! Loved it!
I read this book two days ago. I had heard about how amazing it was. And those reviews were absolutely correct Wonder was amazing one of the best books of the year for me.

This is a wonderful story. A quick read that reminded me how much I enjoyed reading young adult novels. Palacio has created a beautiful book--excellent first novel. I would not only recommend it to all young people, but feel any adult would love this book. Congrats to the Vermont Humanities Council for selecting this book for the Vermont Reads program. Get a copy today!

This book was totally worth the hype. I wanted to read it before the movie. I loved it so much I am worried about even seeing the movie for fear it will mess up the story. I really loved that we got various narrators.
This is one book that just blew me away. The writer clearly knows, loves, and understands kids.

This book was beautiful. It was warm, distressing, moving, insightful, and uplifting. Everyone should read it (and that's not something I say about every book that I rate highly). Not only is it well written and engaging, but it has a wonderful perspective. What I really liked was how common the experiences of so many of the characters were in general, including Auggie. Though he is certainly unique among his family and peers, his experiences and reactions to the desire to belong amid both both bullying and kindness were something almost all of us can relate to. I also loved getting the different characters' perspectives. The ways in which most of the characters make assumptions about each other (often incorrect), display their weaknesses as they try to navigate their relationships and understanding of their experience, and allow their strength to develop and come out were all really wonderful, and made the story real, tangible, and incredibly human. I really can't praise this story enough. It was a joy to read. I hope everyone can come away from it with a determination to "act a little kinder than is necessary."
Loved it!

Wonderful! Wonderful! Wonderful! 
 Middle school can be tough, especially is you don't look like the other kids. 
 This little dude suffers from a very rare combination of Genetic Disorders that makes him- special- in every sense of the word. Homeschooled for the first few years of school due to his surgery schedules, August is attending a real middle school- school for the first time in his life. 
 From changing friendships, bullying, to finding yourself, losing other things, and everything in between- A must read for any middle school kid! Highest recommendation! Thoroughly enjoyable and rings totally true.

I really enjoyed this book. I have a ten year old daughter right now about to go into middle school and reading this book took me back to all of the trauma of middle school. Kids that age are so mean anyway, much less if there is something about you that makes you stand out. I disagree with some that said the voice wasn't believable, other than one paragraph, when I was really looking for it, I could totally see a ten year old kid thinking/saying these things. I liked getting the perspective of all the main characters and I liked how it showed how you never really know what is going on in someone else's life or what is making them act the way they do. I especially liked the message on kindness and making a conscious choice in any situation to be "kinder than is necessary." I admit I teared up a bit at the end and when the one sad thing happened 3/4 of the way through but I think that's a sign of a good book. I also think the kids in the story could have been a LOT meaner than they were, but I'm glad the author didn't go that dark. I enjoyed the happy ending and would totally recommend this book to others. Now to get my ten year old to read it...

This book was fantastic. It should be on the required reading lists for all children in the 3rd or 4th grade. I loved it as an adult, and I know others will too. 
 Palacio touched on themes that every teacher, parent and child should know and understand: bullying, family, friends, death, coming of age, growing up, and so on. These overarching parts of our lives are crucial to overcome but important to comprehend. For that reason alone, you have to read this book. I promise you, you won't regret it.
This book was so cute and it just made me so happy. I loved the ending message, "'Shall we make a new rule of life... always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?'"

" When given the choice of being right or being kind, choose kind." Dr Wayne W. Dyer 
 I couldn't agree with the message of this book more. I love that it is written for middle school students. If I were a 5th grade teacher or a parent of a pre-teen I would make this book a priority. There are of course many ways to teach empathy and kindness. This book however seems to have a way of reaching kids. 
 As I was reading I kept thinking about a day when I went to the grocery store with a friend of mine. We were 19 and waiting in line. Someone wanted to go in front of me. I can't even remember the reason. I didn't care. I let them in front of me and continued my conversation with my friend. She cut me off and scolded me, "You're TOO nice." I was confused. I didn't go out of my way to be kind to this person. I simply sacrificed all of 3 minutes to allow them in front of me. I was sad that is TINY act in her eyes was "too nice." 
 "Or maybe everyone could be a little kinder. Its just a line, we'll be out of here soon..." I replied. I couldn't tell you what happened next but now 14 years later she and I are no longer friends. 
 And then all the little bits of kindness I received over the years interrupted my reading.... 
 The first day of first grade my box of crayons spilled all over the floor and immediately with out the teacher prompting the entire class dove on the floor to help me pick up my crayons. 
 The guy at the gym the other day who went out of his way to discuss our workouts and gave me enough encouragement to last the summer. ( He was temporarily disabled...) 
 Or the Santa Clause looking man who bought my breakfast at WAWA before my nanny job one morning. ( He saw me rooting for change) 
 Small conversations, simple gestures.... They are so much bigger than we know. 
 "Choose Kindness"
A wonderful read. Should be required for all middle schoolers to help learn tolerance, empathy and true strength of character.

3,5 stars 
 This book missed something! 
 It was a pretty good read, the characters are well built and you reAlly get to know the experience of those ppl born with a facial deformity but...it missed more dramatic influence.. 
 Its a bk that leaves a tiny impact on u...where it should hve a left a huge one!
Super good read! Half way through I told my 10 year old to start reading it, she is almost finished and is loving it as well.

Wow. Just wow. 
 This book, told from multiple viewpoints, is amazing. The characters are believable and rounded out. There is character development and realism. It was touching and funny and made me cry. Then, the last portion (told from Julian's point of view) turned it all upside down and really made you think! This is a great book to read with your kids (or anyone!) and discuss differences and judgment and how everyone is fighting their own demons. It's a great book to discuss patience and tolerance and love for each other as human beings. Powerful. If you are looking for a book to read to your older elementary/middle school kids to help discuss the ideas of bullying and acceptance and human dignity, I can't recommend this book highly enough.
Both my kid and I loved this book. I highly recommend it for any kids 8 and up.

I listened to the audio version for several chapters and didn't love the narrator's voice. But then I read the book and loved it! I thought this was a thought provoking look at the life of someone with a disability. I enjoyed the different perspectives. There were some parts that I was a little bothered by, but over all I feel like it's a book worth reading. It made me want to be a better person and treat everyone with kindness. I'm making my teens read it and I'm reading it to my boys!
As a parent, this one made me emotional. I cried sad tears, I cried happy tears. We should all be a little kinder than is necessary.
A fabulous read with a great message.
http://www.segredosemlivros.com/2014/...
What a great story. Fifth grade is hard enough if you are a "normal" child. If you are not, it can be the pits! Be kinder than is necessary: just one of The many messages of the book!

This is a gem of a book. Sincere. Honest. Heart-tugging. Full of hope and laced with humor. Auggie -- along with his adoring family and truest friends -- teaches us the importance of acceptance, kindness, and looking past the surface to the true measure of a being's worth.

I loved this sweet book about a disabled 13 year old boy named August learning to navigate his way around his new school, his new friends, and learning to accept himself. I loved his friendships with Summer and Jack, his family dynamics, and the way the perspectives flowed together. It was really interesting for me to read about Auggie's facial deformities, as I'd never read about disabilities like that before. I found myself wishing 10 year old me had had this book in my school library. I would have felt less alone. This is one of my favorite books.

I loved many things about this. The message of kindness cannot be ignored. I'm glad that our local middle school is reading it as its "One Book, One School"this summer. 
 I gave it only four stars, because I thought the author didn't really capture the kids' voices very well. There was no reason they HAD to be ten, and she wrote them more like twelve-year olds anyway.

I loved this book! It should be required reading for fifth graders. It is about August Pullman, who was born with a severe facial deformity. He has been homeschooled his entire life, but now he is starting fifth grade at a real school, and the story is about his adjustment, as well as the adjustment of the other kids at the school. It was heartbreaking at times, but so sweet. I highly recommend it for anyone, children or adults!
I loved how it was written from different perspectives. It gave insight into how it might be to constantly be stared at but also the perspective of being a sibling and a friend.

I saw the trailer for the movie and immediately thought i need to read this book. I wasn't wrong. What a wonderful and inspirational story! I really enjoyed reading about August's life and the way the author used positivity to wrap up everything in the end. I think i needed a book like that this week and this one really delivered. 
 Its for sure one of the better young adult fiction novels out there right now!
DNF . Maybe Later .

This was an amazingly cute book. I learned about it at an English Festival where the speaker brought it up and I purchased it at my school's book fair. It's a great book that exemplifies the don't judge a book by it's cover ideal. It was well written and I loved how it switched views. I really want to hold August, one of my favorite characters. :D

This is the story of Auggie told from the viewpoint of multiple characters. Auggie was born with multiple facial deformities that cause many people to react to him with fear, cruelty, or both, and he is about to enter the 5th grade, his first real school experience. 
 Through the varying viewpoints we get to know Auggie on many levels. This is a warm, thought-provoking look at a child who must endure more than most. 
 Review copy received from Netgalley.com 2/2012.

Junior Fiction 
 Auggie is a 5th grade boy living in New York City. He has been home schooled and is entering a private school for the first time. Along with the normal anxieties associated with this event is the fact that Auggie has a severe physical deformity. He just wants to be accepted as a normal 5th grader but that is not what happens. The book tells the story from Auggie's point of view as well as his family and friends. With all the concern about bullying now this book is a good lesson in learning to accept people who are different than the norm. Looking up the deformity Auggie suffers from will help you appreciate his struggles more. 
 Sue Mooi 
 Library Assistant
Every 5th grader (and beyond) should read this book.
Beautifully written and timely message.

The voice in this book is particularly strong and enjoyable -- especially the characters who admit to not really knowing why they do what they do, which strikes me as more realistic than characters who always make perfect sense. I wish the "villain" had more depth, but the other characters are worth getting to know. The resolution is perhaps a bit too simple and clean, but overall it is better-than-average as far as engaging and thought-provoking children's books go.

I loved this book. The author did a good job with developing her characters. Loved each and every one of them. My favorite line from this book is "always try to be a little kinder than is necessary" So very important in today's world.

So many people recommend this book, all of them with their eyes glossy and their cheeks red, as though they have been moved beyond measure. For a while I just lied and said that I had read it, and wasn't it amazing, and weren't we all so affected by it? But I hadn't read it. 
 Now that I have, I won't be joining their camp. Stylistically I found it kind of a slog (especially when I opened Justin's section, to be met with all lowercase for reasons unknown) but more than that, I just cannot abide the ending. I thought that the rest of the story had at least been treated with some pragmatism and realism in relation to Auggie, but I think he actually says it best when he says "But hey, if they want to give me a medal for being me, that's okay." To dedicate a book to disability awareness, normalisation, the social issues surrounding a physical difference like Auggie's, and then to totally undermine it, just doesn't make sense to me at all. 
 I think I'm teetering on 2 1/2 stars for this one.
A MUST READ for parents & educators, it demonstrates how a bullied child feels & how one member of the family can affect the whole that takes you on a rollercoaster of emotions.
Loved this book! Much more than 5 stars!

I picked this up for my 16 year ok'd daughter, and she told me I should read it. I'm so glad I did! Palacio captures the voices of her characters so precisely, and the message of the book is one we could all stand to hear again: "be kinder than necessary."
What an amazing and moving book - I absolutely loved it and have not been able to get it out of my head. Five stars!!

The book can definitely touch you, it is humorously, uplifting, and clearly illustrates the day-to-day difficulties of being a kid. 
 However, the book also suffers from terrible cliches. There is no "villain" in this book. Almost every character turns out to be a saint. Each character is more likable than the next, everyone so great and loving and understanding and kind. 
 It gives an overly positive out view of the world that makes the book simply too cliche and unrealistic to be great.

August has a facial deformity that has kept him from mainstream school until now. Stepping into the halls of Beecher Prep, August tells his story frankly, as do the other narrators of the story. Auggie's positive attitude changes everyone around him.

http://mariesbookgarden.blogspot.com/... 
 My middle-grade-writer husband read this amazing debut middle-grade novel last week, and he cried and cried and cried. While in the middle of reading the book, he asked me whether people stared at me or made fun of me for the way I looked when I was a child. (I had a cleft lip and palate, in addition to a severe overbite and horribly crooked teeth.) The answer was yes, they did...and sometimes I still find people staring at my cleft lip scar. Sometimes children ask me about it. But what I faced was nothing like what the main character in this book faced. 
 August (Auggie) had a series of birth defects that resulted in a face that is mashed up and unlike any other. The book starts with Auggie saying "I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid...I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 Auggie has been homeschooled for the first ten years of his life because of all the surgeries he had to endure. (Like Auggie, I also had to have jaw surgery and an implant in my chin.) Finally, as he is entering fifth grade, his parents decide to send him to school. And so begins the story. We hear the story from Auggie's perspective, as well as from his older sister Via and a few of his friends. 
 My husband, in his own review (http://middlegrademafioso.blogspot.co...), writes about why this book is different and has value as a middle-grade novel. I'll leave that to the expert to describe. 
 The first part that had me crying was on page 7. When Auggie was born, he was immediately rushed out of the room, and his mom got very upset. Finally, "She says that when she looked down into my tiny mushed-up face for the first time, all she could see was how pretty my eyes were." A similar thing happened at my birth: the nurse would not show me to my mom until she had braced herself...because of my cleft lip and palate. But my mom, too, thought I was beautiful and was just relieved that I was there and my defects could be repaired. I could live a normal life. Auggie's mom, too, only saw the beauty in him, and not the ugliness like the rest of the world did. 
 Auggie makes friends at school, eventually, and he also makes some enemies. People are horribly mean to him everywhere he goes...especially when they see him for the first time. He's a bright, funny, and sensitive kid, as people discover once they get past his face. 
 I loved this story of a boy who finds his place in the world, helped along by people who show him kindness. 
 "Shall we make a new rule of life...always to try to be a little kinder than necessary?" --J.M. Barrie

Everyone has told me I have to read this book. One of the best books they had ever read. Maybe I was expecting too much from it. I thought it was a great story but not as moving as I was expecting. I did finish it in one sitting though!

A really interesting voice. A surprisingly light treatment of what can be a terribly depressing subject--a middle schooler with a severe facial deformity trying to integrate into public schools after being babied and homeschooled. I wish that the ending was less of a perfect, neat one. In fact, it almost ruined the book for me it was so over-the-top. Almost.
"He is the greatest...whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own." love this book :)

"Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness." 
 Why I have been putting off reading this book for so long, I will not understand. I expected this story to be deep, because it does involve a main character with a very rare medical condition, and the imminent negativity from those that don't or can't understand their struggles; a trigger warning for bullying of sorts. This book shows how cruel children can be, the anxiety of the family that leave fate to protect their child(ren) when they can't, even if it's something as remedial as them going to school, and how you should NEVER judge a book by its cover. 
 August, from the get go, was going to be a relatable, engaging character who undergoes his own metamorphosis by the last page. He, like most people, I'm pretty sure-like me-saw "public school" as this unnatural war zone that would make him feel prone to ridiculing. Again, like I said before: kids are cruel, and Palacio does NOT sugarcoat it. 
 There's this one scene-first off, it mentions, time and time that August is a Star Wars fan. (one of)His favorite character is Boba Fett. The main dick, Julian, asked if he also liked Darth Sidious. Darth Sidious has a disfigured face similar to August's. 
 "Oohh...no you did not!" I about threw that book like it was Julian. 
 But, as the book progressed, you do see the random acts of kindness the book, as a whole, weaves together and makes you believe that there is good, and that the smallest act of good and kindness can go a long way. 
 What surprised me was that there were multiple perspectives. Besides Justin's, I loved all of them. It made the story that much raw and rounded. It shows how other people, besides the family are closely affected by how others have treated August. 
 All, in all, this book teaches you that what you put out into the universe, good or bad, the universe gives back to you tenfold. It was such a fun read. I HAD to finish this book because I was literally rooting for August. It literally felt like I went to school with him and became his friend.
An amazing read! So honest and clever. Really enjoyed this YG book.

Auggie has endured surgeries and stares due to his facial deformity, but nothing has prepared him for something even worse: fifth grade. It's Auggie's first time in a real school, and he has to deal with the challenges of harder classes, real teachers and other students -- a lot different than having his mother teach him at home. Compounding this difficulty is dealing with the reactions to those around him, ranging from shock to disgust, at his misshapen face. All Auggie wants is to fit in, have friends, and be ordinary -- even if he is so much more. 
 At first I was distracted by the shifts in perspectives, having chapters in the pov of Auggie's sister, her boyfriend, and the other students in his grade. But ultimately this proves effective to offer insight into their motivations, as it is hard for Auggie to judge who is truly a friend. 
 The shifting perspectives keep the pace of the story moving, and Auggie has relatable experiences with friends, bullies, and family that make the story accessible, especially for middle grade boys. 
 (3 1/2 stars)

**CONTAINS SPOILERS** 
 I don't even know where to start. What a beautiful, emotional, raw, heart-warming book. I think this is the most eye-opening book I have read in my lifetime. I'm at a loss for words. I found myself laughing, smiling, angered and absolutely bawling my eyes from both sadness and happiness. GO AND READ THIS BOOK RIGHT NOW!! 
 RJ Palacio really opens up your eyes to what it would be like to live your life with any deformity or 'special needs'. The novel switches between Auggie's perspective and his friends and sisters perspectives. This book was an emotional roller-coaster. At the beginning, I found it so hard to read about a ten-year-old boy putting himself down so much and thinking he was an ugly freak. Ten-year-olds' shouldn't be thinking like that but Auggie only felt this way because of the way other people reacted to his appearance. 
 Palacio really captured the minds of each character when writing their section. For example, when the story was told from the perspective of Auggie's sisters boyfriend, it was a completely different writing style. Palacio altered the writing style to suit the character which I really loved. 
 Auggie's connection with his dog Daisy really resonated with me. Dogs love you unconditionally. Auggie felt safe and happy when Daisy was around because he knew that she didn't care what he looked like. There is a quote that really hit me after Daisy sadly passed away (absolutely bawled my eyes out at this!!) "I wondered how it would feel to be in heaven someday and not have my face matter anymore. Just like it never, ever mattered to Daisy". That says everything about how dogs are not just dogs. Dogs make us feel safe and loved. I have that same connection with my dog and I felt what Auggie was feeling in that moment. 
 It was really interesting to read how Auggie's condition affected, not only himself, but also his sister, Via. Since the day Auggie was born, their mum and dad made everything about Auggie. Via felt like she was the outsider and that their parents didn't care for her as much as they cared for Auggie. I really like that Palacio covered that aspect. 
 The thing that stood out the most for me was seeing the monumental shift in the way the school kids treated Auggie from his first day ever at school to his final day as a fifth-grader. When he first started school, the other kids stared at him and didn't want to go near him, to the extent where they said if anyone touched Auggie, they would catch "The Plague". That was absolutely horrific. Luckily, Jack and Summer put that aside and treated Auggie as he should be treated - like a human being! Then when they went to the nature camp and ran into some bullies from another school, the bullies who had teased him at his own school were the ones to protect him. Everyone at school started to treat him with respect after that. 
 When Auggie was awarded the award for bravery at his Graduation, I was in tears again. It does take bravery and courage to live with something like that because, not only kids but adults too, can be ruthless and judgemental. 
 Overall, this was a WONDERful book (get it?). I absolutely loved it and I think it's the best book I've read in quite some time. I know I said that about A Man Called Ove but this book has left me with so much emotion in my heart.
Loved the simple message, "Be kinder than is necessary." Great book for kids going into middle school and younger.

Most things about this book are wonderful. It is, essentially, a story of kindness overcoming darkness and cruelty. August and his family and friends are sympathetic and well-rounded characters, the multi-narrator format works well, and even if some of the perspectives feel a bit superfluous and add nothing new to the story itself, they're all likable and interesting enough for that not to bother me. 
 The Booksmugglers' wrote a very good review that highlights my few complaints with the book, the moments that really gave me pause and make it harder for me to love it unquestioningly. 
 Nevertheless it's a great read that I finished in pretty much one sitting, and I highly recommend it, especially for it's intended audience of middle grade kids.

Four and a half stars. Loved this audiobook! Five stars for that. Yes, the plot can be predictable, but it is all so heartwarming. You just can't help but love August and his family. Genuine nice people all around. My only complaint: I wanted more of Summer! She was such a smart, kind, young girl who really liked him from day one, so I wish we could have learned more about her.

I really liked this book. I had a classmate in high school similar to Auggie. I wish I had gotten to know her. 
 I could also relate to Via because having a sister with disabilities, I remember the stares and desire to protect her. I wanted people to look beyond her physical limitations in order to get to know the real Becca. 
 "But the best way to measure how much you've grown...It's what you've done with your time, how you've chosen to spend your days, and whom you have touched this year. That, to me, is the greatest measure of success." (Mr. Tushman) 
 "Shall we make a new rule of life...always try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" J.M. Barrie, The Little White Bird

I really enjoyed reading from the kids' point of view and how they felt about Auggie. Especially Via, Auggie's sister, who is conflicted in so many ways about her brother. Jack, too, has reactions to events that feel really true to the age--including not sitting at Auggie's lunch table because he wants to relax and be with "normal kids." Everything just felt really authentic. This is a good example of a book that can "teach" tolerance, but it's a good book first.

(This is the review from my book/movie club.) 
 Pros: Everyone really enjoyed the book. Some of us shared that there were a few tears shed during the reading. We liked the switching of different points of view. The author did a great job of making you feel strongly one way or another about all the characters. We all liked Auggie, but there were other standout characters, especially Via and Justin. And no one liked Julian of course, but Miranda was another character who the group thought was unlikeable and had questionable motives. 
 Cons: I got distracted a few times by the out-of-date references: Clint Eastwood, Sound of Music, The little Rascals, Close Encounters etc. I think today's 10-year-old (even in 2012) would use a little more current entertainment references. The book was slow at times - there were a lot of every day conversations. 
 Wonder is perfect for all ages. It is touching, humorous at times, and has subtle lessons about the importance of acceptance, friendship, and family. Read it!

"Some things you just can't explain. You don't even try. You don't know where to start. All your sentences would jumble up like a giant knot if you opened your mouth. Any words you used would come out wrong." 
 This is exactly how I feel as I sit here trying to come up with the words to explain this book and how it made me feel. I'm going to give it my best. 
 Kids can be cruel. Kids can be surprisingly empathetic. That's a part of what this book is about. 
 Auggie Pullman was born with a one in a million(s) facial defect. The kind of defect that startles the unsuspecting, the kind of defect that will stop a person dead in their tracks, and at 10 years of age Auggie decides to go to a real school. 
 It was called Junior High in my day and that started in the 7th grade. Today it's called Middle school and it starts in the 5th grade. According to my dusty memory, this time in a kid's life can suck even if you have a normal face, so for Auggie this year has the potential to be much worse. 
 When he was born he was not expected to live, but he did. Through the years of his young life he had many surgeries to make his face functional. He was home schooled until fifth grade when he and his family decided it was time to go to a real school. As you would expect, he had a hard time winning friends.....kids are shallow. But the friends he won early on were keepers, because they went against the stream when they became his friend. 
 The year had many tough moments for Auggie and many great ones. Told by six different voices, telling the story of the year and of Auggie's life, from each of their perspectives, and it was done brilliantly. It could have become confused and messy very easily, but it was spot on. This book is a little, sparkly, gem. 
 "The best way to measure how much you've grown isn't by inches or the number of laps you can now run around the track, or even your grade point average-- though those things are important, to be sure. It's what you've done with your time, how you've chosen to spend your days, and whom you've touched this year. That, to me, is the greatest measure of success."

I don't think words can describe the experience of reading this book and taking a journey with August. He's fortitude is inspirational. This book had my sixth graders sniffling through smiles as they finished. It will fill your heart. Fabulous.
Oh the book hangover I'm going to get from this...
Beautiful story with witty, fresh, genuine writing. Can't wait to see what else this author has in store for children's lit.

I love that this book isn't just about Auggie. We get to see through his eyes, but we also get to experience him through others as well. His situation is affecting everyone around him. I can see why my students raved about this book!

They don't care what you look like, they just want to love you. And I like that.

Holy Crap. I love this book.

I really enjoy reading books that have multiple voices as the narrator, and this one was exceptional. All of the characters are so well-constructed and each fits into the story nicely. I really liked Justin and couldn't understand why he was dropped from the storyline towards the end. Auggie's pain and suffering, coupled with the triumphant ending, made this book a tear-jerker for me. I would use this as an anti-bullying read aloud if I were in the classroom.
I liked how the author used multiple perspectives from the characters of the story to portray the character of August Pullman. This novel deals with the reality of life.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I could not put this book down, except for the handful of times I was crying and couldn't see the words on the page. "Wonder" makes me want to "be kinder than necessary" to everyone. I was taken aback when I realized that some chapters wouldn't be from Auggie's perspective and I really loved how it enriched the story. I was also surprised that that the adults didn't have their own chapters, but then remembered this is a YA book. And by the end, I didn't need to know exactly what Auggie's parents were feeling, as the author did such a superb job writing from the children's observations. My copy had the Julian chapter included and it was interesting to get the "other side". As much as I liked it, especially his Grandmere's experiences during Nazi occupied France, I think it deviated too far from the original story. Maybe the author could have put in Julian chapters throughout the novel to try to explain why he was a bully. Even so, it was such a great reading experience.

"If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." (-Wonder) 
 This is how I show people how much I love Wonder. 
 This is the second time I've read Wonder and this is second time I've quietly closed the cover after reading the last page and had myself a quiet little cry. I read a lot of books and it's rare when I find a book that can make me FEEL something, teach me something, humble me, uplift me, show me my heart and remind me how powerful books can be. Wonder is one of those special books that stays with you long after reading it. It becomes part of your thoughts and when you talk to anyone else that's read it, you can immediately see in their body language as they put their hand to their chest, watch their eyes soften and wait for the words when they say, "I loved that book so much." 
 Read Wonder and you'll feel the power and the magic that kindness has in this world. 
 "And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 R.J. Palacio, Wonder

** spoiler alert ** 
 I enjoyed this book very much. It was well rounded and captured the middle school experience accurately. Auggie was really just a regular kid who wants what every normal kid wants, friendship. He's blessed with a wonderful family. (And we see how that is why Auggie is also so special.) Auggie has a true friend at the beginning, Summer. I wish we had more of her perspective. I wish we had more people in the world like Summer. Jack's character was realistic. And his POV felt the most authentic because of his internal and external conflicts. 
 Palacio's writing style made this book a pager turner. It's a simple message that is then given to us at the end, but so important, kindness matters. Kindness when its tough matters.

August Pullman is an ordinary kid - except for a grotesquely deformed face and some medical problems that have prevented him from attending school. But now his health is stable and he ready for entry into Middle School! Olivia, his sweet and beautiful older sister is about to start at a selective high school on the other side of the city. We, the reader, get to experience Auggie's and Olivia's journeys from multiple perspectives; Auggie's and Via's own, of course - but also those of their friends and classmates. Targeted to grades 4-8, but a WONDERful read for all!
I laughed and I cried. A great story about human nature--the good and bad as seen through the eyes of August, and those around him. Highly recommend.

"Shall we make a new rule of life ... always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary." -J.M Barrie 
 This is a very beautiful book and I recommend it to absolutely everyone. Never underestimate the power of kindness, the effect it can have on someone. Such a simple thing, kindness. 
 I will always remember this book, and Auggie and Summer and Jack. 
 Cool beans. ;)

7.2012: This is an important YA novel about difference. I loved it for many, many reasons. 
 9.2013: I knocked Wonder down a star, only because the second time around I felt some instances of "authorial intrusion," as they say in the biz. 
 I'd like to know more about Palacio's writing process, like exactly how stories of the many "Auggies" inspired her. She learned about some of the ins&outs of craniofacial abnormalities, it seems, but did she talk to any "Auggie" families or did she just witness the one girl outside the ice cream shop? 
 I ask mostly because I wonder about the different ways parents of "Auggies" advocate for their children. Their unfailing love and acceptance is beautifully portrayed here. But other than paving the way for him to start public school, I didn't see any other instances of his parents advocating--and by that I mean, they never helped his classmates and their parents to understand why Auggie looks the way he does; no quick talk to classes, no letter home, no networking/socializing with school families. Maybe that's my idealism talking, my vision for what parents of children who are different (read: gender variance, food allergies) can and should publicly do. Because when people aren't given information, and they aren't provided a context for a given difference, they fear what they don't know, they tease, make passing comments, bully--this is adults and children. I want so much to eradicate the kind of bullying Auggie and Jack experienced... at least, I don't want my food-allergic child to experience it. 
 That's a small bone to pick with an overwhelmingly beautiful novel. It's not realistic, probably, to expect this book to do everything.
I heard someone say that if you need to restore your faith in humanity a bit, you should read this book. I agree. Loved it.

The boys enjoyed the current pop culture references. They couldn't wait to read every night and see what happened next. It kept them engaged and asking questions. We laughed and cried together. We all loved this book.
Quick easy read, with lots of good lessons for people of every age. Reminded me of how my parents brought me up.
A must-read.

This book should be a MUST read for kids 8-800..... It is amazing and heartfelt and wonderful. My 10 year old loved it- said it was the best book he has ever read.... and I agree 100%. If we could all start being a little kinder than necessary.... what the possibilities might hold. Every parent, teacher, wanna be teacher, wanna be parent, wanna be kinder.... person out there should read this book.

I have been wanting to read this book for quite a while. My TBR buddy this month suggested this book and I jumped at the chance to read it. I picked it up at the library on Wednesday and finished it today. 
 This book hits all the feels (got this term from the podcast Get Booked). There were a lot of tears but also laughter and feelings of pride. 
 Auggie was born with a genetic facial anomaly, so due to many illnesses and surgeries, he has never attended school until now. This book tells not only Auggie's story, but the story of his sister Via, her boyfriend Justin, her friend Miranda, and Auggie's best friends Jack and Summer. It is very well written and each character has their own voice. It is like they are talking to you about their stories. This is a story of transformation, kindness, bravery, raw and honest feelings. I think this is a book every child in the middle grades should read.

Upper elementary . 
 Wonderful story, realistic fiction about a boy whose facial deformity complicates his entry into public school. Would be a wonderful upper level read aloud.

This is a book you want to give to everyone you know... even those people you wish you didn't know. Absolutely fantastic. Can't wait to read it with my family. 
 If you have children, are a child, or have ever been a child... you want to read this book. 
 It touched my whole heart.

"I think the only person in the world who realizes how ordinary I am is me" August Pullman. Who can't relate to that statement?! Aren't we all ordinary and normal to ourselves alone, which makes us all so different and extra ordinary. That's what you get out of this book. Enjoy and read.
This is an absolute must read!!!!!

Sometimes YA skews Y, sometimes it skews A. This was definitely the former. The language and writing style were all extremely juvenile, like early teens. But more than that, was that everything had a happy ending and it was all light and fluffy and safe. I'm not sure if it's because I'm clearly on the A side of YA or just a personal preference but I would have preferred a little bit more tragedy and darkness. 
 But then again, it did make me cry twice.
This book is amazing. It should be required reading for all middle schoolers. Or really, all human beings

Oh my good gracious. Loved it loved it loved it. This is truly a beautiful and slightly heart breaking book. Man. Utterly brilliant and uplifting. Great characters. Fantastic how we see it from all sides. Melted me on the inside just a little bit.

Such an easy book to read so had it read in a day. I really loved it,sweet and sad at the same time,I was quickly immersed in the life of Auggie Pullman. 
 It was a nice touch to have chapters on the others in his life,his new friends especially,how they viewed Auggie and their friendship. 
 I enjoyed how it all turned out for him. 
 It's a thought provoking book on how there are many different types of disability and for young children it can affect their whole life,how they just want to be like everyone else but at the same time they simply see themselves as normal.

My 3rd grade daughter turned me on to this one. It is the hottest read at her school. 
 The author places a character with an obvious facial deformity into the treacherous middle school environment. He confronts making new friends and fielding bullies; two things every kid can relate to and every parent can remember. 
 This book should be required reading for every school official on dealing with school bullying. 
 A sweet sensitive story with authentic characters and a hopeful ending. Just the kind of ending middle schoolers need to hear amidst the social jungle of 5th-8th grade society.

I really loved this book. The prose is geared towards children, but it is not at all condescending, stiff, or cloying. I appreciated that Auggie has a personality that could be fun, but he wasn't secretly the life of the party or anything like that. The characters rang true for me, and I appreciated the range of viewpoints considered. 
 side note: I was initially a bit horrifed when the jocks started calling him "little dude" towards the end of the book and that he was treated as a bit of a mascot sometimes. I do think it adds to the realism of the book--it is mentioned in passing that Auggie is small in stature, that sounds like a semi-affectionate nickname kids would come up with, and yeah, he probably would turn into a bit of a mascot. I felt a bit conflicted about the different ways Auggie could have reacted to that, but I think most kids in Auggie's age and situation would have acted the way the author depicted.
Great realistic fiction for upper elementary and middle.
Loved this book's characters, humanity and message!

I enjoyed this book because it captured a great amount of depth in a book meant for younger children. I viewed the easy reading as though it was meant for a sixth grader which is great because there is so much depth and character to this book which isn't commonly found in books for that age range, and should be.

Starting of course with a little synopsis. August Pullman, more affectionately known as "Auggie" was born with a facial abnormality. He doesn't look like all the other kids, in fact one of the first lines of the book reads, "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 He has been home schooled all of his life and now upon entering 5th grade, his parents have decided that it is time for him to see the world outside of his home, outside of his comfort zone, and outside of his shelter. This is pretty much where the story for Auggie pretty much takes off. 
 Auggie to me is probably one this list of one of the most memorable characters that I have ever read. Despite knowing that people are staring, that people are talking about him, saying horrible and hurtful things, Auggie hardly ever complains. As unfortunate as it is, he has learned to live with the fact that people will always be, well, people. 
 Something that I really loved about this book is that it is told in different perspectives. His sister and his friends have parts in the book where they explain what it's like to live with August and to live with how other people react and treat him. His sister in particular hit me hard. She explains that she has learned to adjust to doing things on her own and not complaining about anything, not that she is being humble, but because that is just the way things are. August is priority. Each part of the book is beautiful and really teaches you to never judge a book by it's cover. 
 I can not recommend this book enough. I even encourage for younger readers to read this, to help better understand and maybe teach a lesson that everybody is somebody. I completely gave this book five out of five stars and truly plan to read this book again. 
 As with my other review, I will leave you two quotes from this book that I found beautiful. 
 ""Your deeds are your memories." This precept means that we should be remembered for the things we do. The things we do are the most important things of all. They are more important than what we say or what we look like. The things we do outlast our mortality. The things we do are like monuments that people build to honor heroes after they've died. They're like the pyramids that the Egyptians built to honor the pharaohs. Only instead of being made out of stone, they're made out of the memories people have of you. That's why your deeds are like your monuments. Built with memories instead of stone."" -August 
 "Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." - Auggie

CHOOSE KIND. 
 This book was amazing. It makes you think a lot about perspective and empathy. 11/10 would recommend to everyone.

Read in August. :) 
 This book got me in tears more than Where the Red Fern Grows.
Cute book. Not for me, but very sweet.
Everyone should read this book.
AAAAAWWWWWWEEEEESSSSSOOOOOMMMMMEEEEE!!!!!!!!!

Find all of my reviews at: http://52bookminimum.blogspot.com/ 
 "O, I believe 
 Fate smiled and destiny 
 Laughed as she came to my cradle 
 Know this child will be able 
 Laughed as she came to my mother 
 Know this child will not suffer 
 Laughed as my body she lifted 
 Know this child will be gifted 
 With love, with patience and with faith 
 He'll make his way" 
 For anyone who even is thinking about saying this is a kid's book . . . . 
 And also you are wrong. Wonder is a book for EVERYONE. Seriously. Like every single human being on the entire planet. And maybe even your dog. Hands down the best Middle-Grade book I've ever read. So much so that I just did a re-read and I never do a re-read. 
 This is the story of August Pullman and his experiences during 5th grade - which just so happens to be the first year he ever attended school after being homeschooled. Why was Auggie homeschooled???? Well . . . 
 "Rat boy. Freak. Freddy Krueger, E.T. Gross-out. Lizard face. Mutant. I know the names they call me. I've been in enough playgrounds to know kids can be mean. I know, I know, I know." 
 Fifth grade is the year that Auggie's parents decide they need to attempt to expose him to the real world. They realize that reality for Auggie might be harsh and offer him the opportunity to go back to homeschooling at any time, but remain hopeful that people will look past Auggie's exterior and see the exceptional person he really is. 
 A little backstory: Awhile back it came to my attention that my youngest child was claiming to be doing his required reading, but really was . . . well, pretty much just staring off into space and doing anything except reading. (He is my child so you have to figure there's some buttholery that rears its ugly head every now and again.) The easiest solution to the problem? Buddy read with dear ol' mom. So I forced him to read my favorite "kid book" and guess what happened????? 
 He started flagging quotes just like his nutcase mother . . . 
 Know what else? It really kind of kicks all the butt to have "book club" with a small human. We'd read 20 pages a day (the required amount - unfortunately I'm not a miracle worker so he still doesn't loooooooooove the process of reading like I do) and then drink hot cocoa and talk about what we read (to confirm he really was reading this time and not pretending). Sometimes we would share tears and sometimes we would share laughs. We always shared the importance of being a "Jack" rather than being a "Julian." 
 Small humans final reaction? "PHENOMENAL. 5 Stars. Every kid should read this and we should read books like this in class instead of the boring stuff they make us read." 
 My reaction????? 
 This book will break your heart . . . but then it will put the pieces back together again. Filled with lessons of being a decent person that it teaches in the best, most non-preachy way possible. Bottom line is it is just . . . 
 Have you seen Hot Rod? It's kind of the worst movie ever while simultaneously being the best movie ever. My kid is a freaky movie quoter like his mother and encouraged me to overshare this gif. If you read the book you'll see it makes sense. What are you waiting for? Go read it right now. Here, I'll even help you with the supplies you'll need before starting . . . 
 I bought a hardback of this book because it is seriously one of the best things I've ever read. I look forward to forcing my future grandchildren to experience all of its Wonder just like I did to their daddy.
Best book I've read in awhile- August is one of my favorite characters of all time
I think everyone should read this. Young and old. Beautiful.
A client told me that everyone should read this book, and she was right. I read it, then read it to my kids, then my eight year old read it again about four times in a row.

My son's 4th grade teacher is reading this with their class. My son loves it and she knows I enjoy reading so she recommended it to me. I thought it was wonderful (hence its title). A very quick read that teaches lessons on kindness, friendship, acceptance, and more. A great lesson for children and reminder for adults. I finished the book with a huge smile on my face!

I read this book in one sitting and could not recommend it enough. 
 Upon seeing it, holding it, reading the synopsis, your first thought will be...hmm...it's a children's book. I don't know if I want to read that. I don't know if it's for me. 
 That's what I thought at least, even though I found the synopsis interesting, I just wasn't in the mood to read a children's book. Eventually though, I folded and bought it. Boy, am I glad I did. When my sister saw me with it she said, Oh that's a wonderful book, you'll love it! I asked her, Will it make me cry? She said, I don't know. That depends on you. 
 Well, it did. It brought tears to my eyes and made me want to hug this kid so hard, along with each friend he's made. 
 So let's start from the beginning. This story is about a ten year old boy who is for a lack of better word "deformed", he was born this way, and doctors thought he wouldn't make it, but he did. Home schooled his whole life because of the way people react to his appearance, and because he couldn't take people's reactions (people can be so cruel sometimes), his mom finally decides it is time to put him in school. She argues that she can't teach him forever, she's not good at maths. His mom is great. As is his dad. 
 August (Auggie) tries to resist and argue at first, but upon being taken on a tour of the premises and meeting a few of his classmates, he makes the decision to go. Thus begins a very painful journey, watching Auggie have to deal with people's first reactions, the kids avoiding him, refusing to be partnered with him, refusing to eat with him, so far as to create a game in which if you are touched by him you'd have received the Plague. Until that is Summer, who sits with him during lunch, at first out of pity, but later out of friendship, and Jack who becomes Auggie's best friend and classmate. 
 What I loved about Palacio's delivery and execution of this story is he did not focus it entirely on Auggie, but rather gave us a glimpse of how everyone in Auggie's life dealt with it and how it affected their lives in turn. This included chapters narrated by his sister Via, his friends Jack and Summer, Via's boyfriend and even Via's best friend who has always been close to Auggie and bought him a helmet once, which he wore for 2 years in a row to cover his face and was able to play outside without the usual stares of shock and surprise and revulsion. 
 Palacio gave all the narrators a very honest voice, they all sounded sincere and real. It makes you feel like you really are taking this journey right alongside Auggie as we are given a glimpse into all their lives. I loved the relationship that developed between Auggie and Jack in particular. I loved how despite all the conflicts and "drama", fifth-graders are so much more straightforward than adults when dealing with things they like or dislike. I respected Jack for owning up to his mistakes, and I respect Summer for confronting Auggie head on when he tried to avoid her. I also absolutely love how the kids stood by and supported Auggie, almost protecting him, when they first introduced him to their parents, going to lengths in order to prepare their parents for who they're going to meet and how NOT to react. Palacio intertwines serious, heartfelt moments with humor that it makes the whole book very endearing and real. 
 You start out wanting to cry and take on all these bullies that are hurting this little boy. You end up crying because you're just so happy and proud of what he's become and the lives he's touched. 
 Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives. That line made my heart squeeze for the little boy. 
 This book may be written from children's point of view, in a simplistic child's way, but this is a book that everyone should read. And maybe learn a thing or two.

Wow! 
 My oldest daughter is 11 years old and I bought this for her. It sounded good, so I read it, too, and this became the first book we basically read and discussed together since she has hit pre-teen days. And, it was perfect for that - something good and wholesome for all ages. 
 Disclaimer: I did not read the reviews - I am probably going to say the same thing they already did, but I feel compelled to share a few words on Wonder. 
 The book taps on multiple, current issues that kids of all ages face: Bullying (in a roundabout way); feelings of exclusion; facing new environments and people; and, overcoming adversity. For everyone, there is heavy focus on the golden rule and manners. I loved that. It seems to me there isn't enough in our modern world on being kind to each other. 
 August, the lead character, goes through more in his life by 5th grade than most can ever imagine. 
 The book is good for teaching empathy and compassion to kids, as well. 
 I don't want to spoil it. This is, quite simply, a wonderful book for absolutely anyone.

Phenomenally written book about a young boy coming of age, while dealing with a facial deformity at a new school. It's hard not to love Auggie in this beautiful tale where he's so honest that it's heartbreaking at times and where the other characters are so genuine that it's hard not being mad at them for their repulsive behaviors. 
 This is a book that as an adult, it reminds me of my youth and how we treated other children at times. As a parent, it's a book that I hope my children, whom have all read it as well, will walk away with a different perspective on those who are different than them. I hope they will choose to be just a little kinder than necessary because THAT's what would make the world a little bit of a better place. <3

Although aimed at a younger audience this book was really wonderful for readers of all ages. It was a fast read and I hope the author does a follow up so we experience more of August Pullmans life as he grows up!
Wonderful!

3.5 stars. 
 "Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world" 
 Aw. 
 On the surface, Wonder is just the story of Auggie going to school and dealing with all the things that it entails. But in actuality, this book is so much more than that. It's heartfelt and so very sincere while being such a great representation of Auggie's experiences, good and bad.

A simply amazing book about growing up and coming to terms with hardship. Palacio uses multiple perspectives excellently to both move the story along as well as develop the characters. Every character is complex and interesting, and most importantly feel real. I laughed out loud at parts and I shed a few tears. Everyone needs to read this book.

Told from six different perspectives, this book does get the middle school experience right. It's uncomfortable, cliquish, jam-packed with kids trying to find their way in the world. The center of this particular experience is August Pullman, a boy born with a facial anomaly that can't help but make him an outsider. Stared at, rejected, Auggie toughs it out with kindness and humor. He wins some valuable friends along the way. 
 I have to be careful not to judge this as an adult read. Parts of the book were a stretch. Julian and his mother were a little too uppity. (Mrs. Albans's incorrect perception of "special needs" kids was classic, though. I deal with folks like her every day.) Parts of the book were saccharine (Daisy and Bear, for instance). And the ending was way too perfect. Auggie finds his way, is accepted by the whole school...really? Do we really learn to love all that easily?

Wonder is a marvel. I came to love Auggie, the main character who was born with facial deformities. I didn't pity him, but admired him and actually pitied many of this around him. By telling he story from the viewpoint of many of the other characters, the author reveals the pain and deformities that others have, but hide. 
 I laughed out lout several times and even "got something in my eye" a few times. It resolves a little too Hollywood, but I still felt satisfied.
So amazing. A touching story about the differences between people and the impact we can make on each others' lives. Best teen book of the year!
