My kids and I listened to this book every night at dinner and I must say it is my favorite Children's book from 2012. I absolutely loved this book. I think it spoke to kids about accepting other kids differences in a very unique and effective way. The approach was effective because the author uses various characters to explore the challenges of peer pressure, self-confidence, and identity. I am looking forward to seeing the success of this book and I would not be surprised if it turned into a movie.

Every person, regardless of age, should be required to read this book. It's quite the dilemma when you love a book so much--from the characters and themes, to the writing style, but yet it is hard to put in words how printed paper bound between two hard covers becomes so much more than a "book". It was a beautiful, personal experience to read this with my ten year old daughter. It isn't often that all the literary elements line up, but when they do and on top of a storyline that is universally moving and poignant. Magic happens. 
 Wonder is magic.
Everyone should read this book!!!!!!!
Very nice YA book with great message.

This debut novel is a "wonder". It's about much more than friendship and getting through middle school although those are important themes in the book. Very heart-warming and thought provoking. You will cheer for Auggie!

I read this book in one sitting, because I couldn't bear to stop being part of Auggie's world. And I admit, I got choked up at the end. What a great book about love, friendship, family, and being true to who you are.
An amazing book for people of all ages! It has a great message about kindness.

I devoured this book in one day, which is a quite a feat, considering that I'm a single mom with two toddlers and a full-time job. It was just THAT amazing. The plot centers on a boy with severe facial deformities who is about to enter middle school (in fact, ANY school) for the first time. You can imagine the struggles that ensue. However, this novel is incredibly uplifting and inspiring. The author does a great job of developing her characters, taking us along for the ride as they grow and struggle and transform into something stronger and wiser than they were at the beginning. Although this novel does indeed deal with some heavy themes, Palacio's use of well-placed humor and tidbits of wisdom leaves the reader feeling much more inspired than downhearted. I am not much of a crier, but I must admit that I teared up several times during my reading. This is definitely a novel that I will highly recommend to everyone I know, and will likely be re-reading it myself in the near future. Beautiful, beautiful story. A must-read.
Such a great book!!!!
I think Wonder is a great read. It's fun and sad at the same time. I loved reading from Auggie's perspective, but also enjoyed the changing POVs. I think this story was wonderful :)

This is a quote-rich story! I have told 1,000 students about this book, and had to buy 10 copies. In a day of look-at-me media for young teens, this is a refreshing book to make us think outside ourselves.

Wow! What a wonderful book! I can't believe it sat in my to-read pile for so long. I purchased this book to put in my 6th grade classroom library because it looked so interesting. It is genuinely one of the best novels I have read for children!! In fact, once I started reading I couldn't put it down. The pages seemed to melt away. This wasn't a book that I kept looking to see how much was left, it was a book that was over before I was ready for it to be done. I really loved all the characters, they were so real and believable. I really relate to the struggle that Auggie's family faced because my niece was born with facial abnormalities as well. I have watched her endure years of surgeries and the struggle. I feel like this book addresses this reality in a way children could understand. Not only that, but the characters and relationships are so believable! I just wanted to reach into the book and hug the characters more than once. I will definitely be recommending this book to my students. I hope that they enjoy it as much as I did. I will never forget the impact of "always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary." I really believe that I will make that a precept for my classes this year.
Always be kinder than needed

A fifth grader goes to regular school for the first time after being home-schooled. Only this fifth-grader's "facio-cranial abnormality" makes every other middle school kid who ever worried about looks seem like a movie star. We get to know Auggie from the inside. He's just a normal kid with a special sense of humor. But people stare when see his face. Some scream and run. No one wants to sit by him. They wash their hands afterwards if they accidentally touch him. Later in the book the author uses multiple points of view to show us what's going on in the heads of some of the other kids in Auggie's world. We see ourselves in Auggie, and we see ourselves in those who hurt him or want to avoid him. The action makes the point of acceptance, friendship and looking beyond the external very effectively. WE don't really need Mr. Browne's precepts or Mr. Tushman's graduation speech to tell us what is right. They get a bit preachy for me.

I loved this book, and although it's about a 5th grader, I feel like I could recommend it to anyone. Although my tears flow easily, this book got them going (usually in a good, bittersweet or touching way) several times. Thankful for "Auggie" and all the life lessons he leaned and unintentionally taught others.

I started reading this at ten pm and stayed up through the night to finish. Compelling characters and a heavy dose of reality make this book a combination of reliving the pain of being the kid that no one wanted to be around and the shame of being the kids who pointed and laughed. Most of us, if we are honest, have been both. 
 I particularly liked the role of Auggie's family. So many children's books feature broken homes that it almost seems a prerequisite for a good story, but there is also powerful story in the loving, imperfect and forgiving family. Just a joyful and redeeming book - though I felt that some of the final end-of-the-school year events did border on the cheesy (that's most that can be said without giving too much away!). You will enjoy this book.

Any adult or child would be "taken by surprise" when they see August for the very first time. Some reactions to August were more severe than others. In either case, August was fully aware of others' reactions. That is why he was home schooled by his mom until the fifth grade. August's sister Via described August's facial deformity as "his features are melted." A single gene caused August's facial deformity. 
 August's acute description of the pain he felt about the way his face looked, when he went to fifth grade, was painful for me to read. When August walked into school with his Halloween costume on, he "wanted to be seen. One kid wearing the same exact costume as mine, long white skull face oozing fake red blood, high fived me as we passed each other on the stairs. I have no idea who he was, and he had no idea who I was, and I wondered for a second if he would have ever done that if he'd known it was me under the mask." 
 August faced ridicule and his peers felt pressure by the "popular" kids to avoid August, who was the "Plague." Summer was the first girl to step up and befriend August the first day of school. At first she sat with August in the cafeteria because she felt sorry for him. Then she found out he was fun and they became fast friends. 
 Jack was another friend who could have an honest and authentic conversation with August. He liked the fact that August could laugh at his situation. But Jack bowed to peer pressure, betraying August's trust early on in the story. 
 The author, R. J. Palacio, sagatiously described each person's motivations and inner feelings regarding their thoughts about August. Each chapter was told in one character's point of view. His sister Via described her home life with August at the center of the universe, while all members of her family orbited him. Via understood August's needs and loved him deeply, but she needed some attention as well, and often felt she wasn't getting her fair share from her mom or dad. She thought of her younger brother as two people, "the one I saw blindly, and the one other people saw." Via was a fierce defender of August, but entering high school, she did not want to be defined by a deformed brother. 
 R.J. Palacio cleverly and wisely touched upon so many important themes - parents having conflicts over the upbringing of their children, peer pressure, character, empathy, acceptance... She even included a brilliant outline of one teacher's writing lesson plans for the year. Mr. Brown insisted that at the beginning of every month, students in his class would copy down one of his quotes, as he calls them, PRECEPTS. These precepts are rules for behavior. Each month, students had to reflect upon a precept, and write how the precept affected the student in some way. 
 The message here for all students is to "act a little kinder than necessary." This is R.J. Palacio's first novel for fifth or sixth graders. It is beyond brilliant!
A superb read! I got choked up at the end. I loved how the author used different voices to tell the story of Auggie. What an endearing character he is! Every person should read this book.

One of the ways I measure the greatness of a book is by the amount of tabbies I use as I read a book. You know what I mean. When you are snuggled in your favorite reading spot and you hit a sentence that makes you stop cold. Sometimes it may literally take your breath away. Well, needless to say, I used a lot of tabbies while reading this book. Wonder is 
 one of those books that should be on every required reading list on the planet. Read this book! You won't regret it.

Just read this book. 
 Really, just read it.

Wow.. I really am speechless right now. I feel like i just want to hold this book in my arms and never want to leave it. Like, ever! 
 definitely one of my favorites, i've enjoyed reading this book so so so much.
Loved this book. Beautifully written and such a wonderful message.
I would say 3 1/2 stars. Great message just a so so book all together.

This book lives up to its hype - very well-done. Loved it. My son (who's 9) read it right before I did, and he put it "in his top 20 of favorite books." (Wimpy Kid, Harry Potter, and the Origami Yoda series books take up most of that top 20)

First line: 
 "I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid." 
 This is a story that grade school children should read or have read to them. It teaches tolerance, kindness and inclusiveness. 
 August, or Auggie, was born with a cleft palate and or facial deformities. His mom homeschooled him but in this 5th grade year, they (parents and son) decided to mainstream him. Of course they are all worried. The principal asks a few students to be Auggie's friends and show him around school. The kids are typical in their reactions and responses to him: shock, surprise, bullying, meanness, ignorance. For the most part, they try to help him and soon Auggie finds he has a couple of good friends. 
 Through most of the book I was having a hard time sympathizing with Auggie. Perspectives and characters were on the extreme ends, it seemed. Maybe to help middle graders really grasp what is being taught? As I read I felt talked down to a bit but I think I understood better why as I read. 
 My favorite scene was the camp scene. 
 Many lessons to learn from this story and it's worth the time to read it to elementary age children. 
 Rating: PG 
 V: No 
 L: No 
 S: No 
 Liked: 
 The Journey 
 Teaching without preaching 
 Disliked: 
 The beginning 
 3 1/2 STARS
Loved it! Such a sweet lovely story, made me cry, but in a good way :)

A delightful heart warming read. It is a really simple story and yet I couldn't put the book down. If you ever feel that you are losing hope in humanity, do give this book a chance to change your mind. 
 Loved it. 
 This is why I highly recommend reading children's books. When combined with a glass of chocolate milk, these books make you feel like the world is giving you a tight hug.

Wonder is a wonder. August's family is wonder-ful. They aren't perfect, they've made mistakes but, they love him and one another. And they want him to have a full life in the wider world,even though it means facing more people who have to adjust to the shock of his physical appearance. 
 If you went to middle school, you know it isn't most people's favorite time of their lives. It's awkward, scary, and isolating for most of us. As life gets better, we tend to forget. Then, you have kids, and oh, yeah, it's a weird time for them, too. If only we could leap into being comfortable in our bodies and personalities and friendships and strengths without going through middle school! 
 Palacio writes about these things through the eyes of several kids. I enjoyed each of their perspectives. I loved the reminder that there's always more than one side to a story -- We should allow people to share their side and maybe we'll understand their actions. 
 Of course, Palacio has given us a touching story with a happy ending. It's not realistic. It is hopeful. Why not write stories of how we wish things could be, show a way that we can work towards? 
 As Mr. Tushman summed up in his graduation speech at the end, this book is about courage and kindness. Wake up every day, try to be kind. If you fall short, be brave enough to try to do better tomorrow.

This was a great young-adult novel. It had a good message and you couldn't help but feel for Augie. I enjoyed how the narrative changed and we heard from a variety of characters. 
 The only thing that kept this from being 5 stars was it was a little too "perfect." It could double as an after-school special from time to time. The heavy-handedness isn't enough to keep me from recommending it, but it does lead the book into "silly" territory from time to time.

Hmm. 2.5/5? Or maybe 3.... and I have some things to say. 
 So. I liked that Auggie's experience at primary school reminded me of my own.. though it was just validation (which doesn't really do anything for me now at my age) I've never come across a story dealing with physical differences and how that affects school relations, and if I'd read a book like this as a kid I would've really identified with Auggie's experience. (For those who don't know, my right hand/arm/chest is physically different... which was easier to hide than Auggie's difference, but when seen, elicited some of the same reactions in primary school.) 
 I also really liked how we heard from a whole lot of characters other than Auggie. In that sense, it wasn't really just dealing with "disability" or difference, the story also considered issues of race, class, grief... and these things create different perspectives... so that was great. The one thing that connected all the characters was Auggie... and he was defined a little by his difference in that sense... I don't know how I feel about that... 
 But the real issue for me was the view that Auggie's family takes in respect to his situation... that they see his facial deformity as an inherently negative and abnormal thing. There are constant references to how "the universe hasn't been kind to Auggie" and that he drew an unlucky card in being born looking different. Auggie is given special treatment and is spoilt rotten, all because he is different, which is to the detriment of his sister (though this is acknowledged as a problem in the story, the overall representation is that it's normal to fuss over "special needs" kids which only highlights that they're "different"), his sister says something along the lines of how they've all fussed so much over Auggie he "thinks he's normal. And he's not." (Excuse me? That's not the problem here!) And the big one: his Dad actually refers to Auggie's start in middle school as "leading a lamb to slaughter". Wow. Swap the term "disability" with "gay" and then imagine family and friends saying these things. I guess you could say my issue really is with how "disability" or just plain old difference is sometimes seen as inherently bad, however this story is aimed at kids so I think a more positive attitude towards Auggie's difference from his own family and friends would've been better. And that's not the same as erasing Auggie's experience. It's one thing to represent a not wholly positive experience of primary school from Auggie's perspective, but it's quite another to represent "disability" as inherently negative. My own parents never ever made me feel anxious about what opinions I might encounter at school (though of course there were negative ones... but also positive ones!), they've always treated me as a normal kid and it was not a problem! and they certainly have never seen my difference as "abnormal", a "problem", or something that needs "fixing" (and they've got mad at anyone who has ever suggested that it might be.) Had I read this in my younger years, I may've internalised negative feelings about myself. 
 I'm also not sure about the ending where Auggie receives an award, which is given to him just for getting through the school while also being different... I have also come across this perspective. People have come up to me, and have suggested that I be nominated for Young Australian of the Year, essentially because I am achieving things in life but with a funny hand!!! I always want to ask whether they actually think I am good at the activity in question or whether it's just because I'm doing it with "only one hand" (please note, only others tend to use this phrase). I also start to think perhaps they think I deserve an award because they naturally think I wouldn't possibly be able to do the activity and are so surprised to see me doing it. Now I don't offend easily. But I find that offensive. But anyway, I have issues with awards being handed out to people for simply dealing with life and doing normal things while also being "different" in some way. If you're trying to normalise diversity, I don't think highlighting differences and congratulating people for being different is the way to go. And I don't think it's an uplifting way to end a book. There, I've said it.
Easy read with a good message.
Great story, lovable character... Love it! but...

"Wonder" is a book I think every 5th or 6th grader should read. It teaches life lessons on friendship, compassion, empathy and kindness. My son's 5th grade class is currently reading this book and he begged me to read it because he thought it was that good. I'm grateful that this part of his curriculum. Sometimes books can teach & instill things in you that others can't.

I read this book on the tail end of Perks of Being a Wallflower. 
 What i liked about Wonder is, it didn't feel forced, it didn't feel politically correct and it didn't feel as if there were an agenda of topics that had to be touched and met. 
 I hate to compare it to Perks but i can't help but do it. In Perks it was like, high school outsider, check, anxiety and depression, check, suicide, check, teenage sister gets beat and pregnant, check check, cool friends, check, cool music, check, drugs and alcohol, check, gay sex, check, family troubles and incest, check, mental illness, big books, large words, literary mentor with patches on sleeve, check check check. 
 With Wonder, the plot flows nicely and without any check list of hot topics to check off. August Pullman is his own kid, liking his own things, and the story manages to keep the reader curious, sympathetic and pulled along without eliciting any forced tears or afterschool special moments. 
 We aren't forced to learn a lesson in Wonder. Mostly we just see that August is just a kid. 
 It's uplifting without being saccharine.

R.J. Palacio has created an amazing, heart-wrenching book in Wonder that will leave you cheering in the end for Auggie and the family he forms around him. Told in eight voices ranging from Auggie to his sister's first high school boyfriend, Wonder is the story of one boy's first year of middle school. This is a book that must be shared. 
 Starting middle school is rough. New kids, new classes, new places to get lost, and new people to make fun of you. Auggie is taken to his new middle school weeks before the new year begins to meet Mr. Tushman, the principal of Beecher Prep. Once there, Auggie is upset to learn that he's not only meeting the principal but that there are students there to show him around. Jack Will, Julian and Charlotte are all incoming fifth graders. They're all supposed to be nice kids, at least according to their lower grade teachers and they've been at Beecher Prep since they were in kindergarten. Yet only Charlotte can meet Auggie's eyes without looking down afterwards. Julian goes out of his way to avoid touching Auggie and keeps watching him out of the corner of his eyes. 
 The strange looks are nothing new, even though Auggie's never been to school before. Twenty-seven surgeries, his size and other medical complications kept him homeschooled at home with his mother until the start of fifth grade. Now that the next surgery is a few years away, Auggie's mother wants him to start attending school. Auggie's worried how the other kids will react to him. On the inside, Auggie feels like an ordinary kid, but kids have run away at the sight of him before. 
 Auggie's fifth grade journey has its dark moments filled with pain, such as Halloween when he overhears a friend say he only hangs out with Auggie because a teacher asked him or when the family dog becomes gravely ill. It has its brilliant moments, such as when Summer sits down beside August at lunch that very first day when no one else will. 
 I loved getting inside the head of so many people in Auggie's life and seeing why they behaved the way they did. Jack Will's chapters brought new light on what had happened earlier and brought home what it felt like to have a school turn on him after he stood up to Julian. Via's chapters rang with love for her brother but also with her shamed desire to not be defined by him. One of my favorite sections in this book came from Justin, Via's boyfriend. He didn't even know about Auggie until the third date. Even though Olivia prepped him for the first meeting, Justin is surprised by what he sees in August. He's determined to make things work out. That isn't what endears Justin to me as a reader. Rather it is how Justin is accepted by Auggies family and how that acceptance eases his tics. It's in how this awkward musical boy decides to help Jack and Auggie. One of the most surprising set of chapters came from Via's former close friend Miranda because it showed how much one girl wanted a family like Via's even with all it's difficulties. 
 The characters laugh and cry their way off the pages in Wonder. The adults and children all have foibles. Some are terribly flawed. All of them are alive. The nature retreat at the end and its aftermath are riveting, an unforgettable emotional roller coaster in a wonder of a book. 
 (First read as a galley from NetGalley)
Rereading from a different perspective is always a good thing. The book made me happy, without tears, and made me remember to be kinder than us necessary.

It took me a while to read this book, since I now have an 11month old baby that takes up a lot of my reading time ;)- no really... This was a good book.. I really enjoyed the story, & characters. I think it's important for kids, & young adults to read this, or at least as parents for us to instill in our own children, unconditional kindness, and the ability to look past outward appearances. 
 Overall, good book.
Everyone should read this book.
I am in love with August Pullman, this book was beautiful and I could not put it down. The bleeding scream scene broke my heart and I was glad things worked out there.

This was a very, very good story. I will certainly be getting it for the Maxson MS library collection. It seems as if writing about young people with different kinds of disabilities seems to be in vogue, as I had read Out of My Mind by Sharon Draper just a few weeks ago. This is the story of a boy, his mother and father, his sister, and the friends he meets as he enters school for the first time as a fifth grader. August was born with a rare condition, which has left his face so deformed, that most people gasp and look away when they see him. So, starting school in fifth grade is a huge step for him, and for all those people who care so much about him. 
 It is told by the different voices, but mostly by Auggie, and it is so well written that I could not put it down. A great read for all middle school students, (and adults, too.)

Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world. -- Auggie-- 
 It's hard to rate this book because I choose to read a book which is intended for kids. It was a wonderful book, I could see how the story was headed.. a moral message and this message was eventually achieved. 
 I would not go down on this book even though it's too perfect to be real because it is prompt for kids, but I'm wondering about Auggie the kid who was born with a face anomaly I was like his situation was described as extremely serious and 1 in millions of the world could have this problem.. there isn't psychological impact on Auggie's personality or did he ever face a low self steam! I mean It could be resolved at the end.. idk 
 The funny part is I do not imagine that there are 10-year-olds going out for a date or showing interest in each other! mind me I do not belong to their background but still weird and out of place :/

one of my top 5 books this years. 
 I had a couple of quibbles with the ending, but I think it is a me problem more than a book problem. 
 excellent!
Definitely a feel-good novel!

One of my best friends was reading it and as soon as I saw the cover and read the blurb, I was hooked. At first I thought I was slightly hesitatnt. I mean, what new could be bought to just be another sad story about a troubled kid facing a challenge we're all meant to be able to relate to, but as I read on I fell in love. Everything about this book was amazing, from the way it was written to the message it sent. 
 I'm hiding any plot in case you want absolute surprise it isn't really a spoiler at all but anyway... "Wonder" is the story of August's journey through Middle School. It may only be two years but they hold some of the greatest challenges of his life. August must contend with other students and even adults who are against him from the start, as the year progresses the other students at his school learn to accept him. Mostly, there is still a hardcore group that will never be able to see him for who he is. An amazing young boy that has faced more challenges in his short years than they have ever. 
 I think it was the hope that the premise of this book inspired in me that is why I loved it so. I mean, with that said, I'm not always a fan of books that are happily ever after. I am a stubborn realist. This book was different though, it lent something to the story through the supporting characters that made it - if not slightly realistic - but atleast understandable, as well as it being an incredibly sweet ending, but not a book of sunshine. The balance was perfect. And it was this balance, along with the reassurances that it gave me about the fact that there may still be hope for us, as people, that made me love it. 
 It may only be in a novel, but there was something about this book that really convinced me this could reflect actual people. 
 Absolutely perfect amazing. For anyone. 
 "Don't judge a boy 
 by his face!"
Great story of true friendship and the hardship of living with a deformity.

Loved this story! 
 The point of view and voice of each character came through loud and clear. 
 A must read for all!

LOVED this book! Everything about fifth graders rings so true. Their growing social awareness, their ability to still be little kids, and their confusion with the two. Made me cry, laugh and then cry again. Going on my favorites shelf!
Should be required reading for every middle-schooler.
This book kind of blew me away. I especially loved Via's perspective and even Miranda's. A must read and an awesome book to teach empathy to students!
Popsugar reading challenge - a YA bestseller.

This was a WONDERful book! I finished a dystopian book and needed something to get out of my "mourning period." Lots of my friends were pushing me to read this since I loved Out of My Mind and The Fault In Our Stars. I read it and literally was sitting there in awe on how amazing it is. 
 Wonder is about Auggie (August) Pullman who is suffering severe facial deformity. Auggie has been homeschooled till 4th grade and is going to start school at Beecher Prep. Of course Auggie has always suffered from stares and the mean comments, but he just wants to be normal. I loved how it was told from not only Auggie's pov but from everyone around him. We really got a great insight on how others thought of him and how he thought of himself. 
 R.J. Palacio really captured the voice for each character. She would use phrases that a 10 year old would use or she wouldn't use proper grammar for a 15 year old boy who doesn't really care about his writing, and I really admired that. For example, Auggie says, "But I'm kinda used to how I look by now. I know how to pretend I don't see the faces people make. We've all gotten good at that sort of thing: me, Mom and Dad, Via." This isn't grammatically correct, but it is exactly what a 10 year old would say. Another example, is when Auggie asked his dad what understudy meant when Via was performing in a play. 
 I am going to end off with one of my favorite quotes: 
 "It's like people you see sometimes, and you can't imagine what it would be like to be that person, whether it's somebody in a wheelchair or somebody who can't talk. Only, I know that I'm that person to other people, maybe to every single person in that whole auditorium. To me, though, I'm just me. An ordinary kid."
moving story of the importance of being kind set in middle school

*heavy breathing* *wipes ocean of tears* 
 are you crying? 
 No I just have Auggie Pullman in my eyes 
 Okay but can we just thank R.J. Palacio for writing a very v v v v v v realistic story with very realistic characters. Okay? Okay good. 
 Wonder is one of those books that makes you want to hug everyone. It's a simple and fast read but it will definitely touch your heart at some point in the book. 
 help i have so many feels i don't know where to start 
 See, the main protagonist in this story has a facial deformity. For a kid his age, people will stare and judge without even knowing the actual kid. August Pullman is a hero in a lot of ways. He remained strong and he understood everything. He wasn't those kids who just whines every time he has a problem. That's what I love about Auggie, you know? He doesn't freeze when something goes wrong because he's been through worse. This kid is also smart, understanding, a good friend, and a good son. If Auggie doesn't make you feel warm then I don't even know. 
 The book tackled different perspectives and it made the story much better. We can see everyone's point of view and their feelings about things. 
 This book also made me realize how people can be cruel and self-absorbed. BUT this cruel kids can also change. *cries* THE ENDING OF THIS BOOK WAS SO BEAUTIFUL CAN WE JUST. The kids who bullied Auggie and talked behind his back stoop up for him when Auggie was being bullied. I mean look at that character development. Such round characters. 
 Every character in this book was so great and realistic (lol except you julian i hope you realize that everyone is unique in their own ways and what makes you unique is that you are a little piece of shit). 
 Throughout the whole book, I was looking for the reason as to why it is entitled "Wonder", and when I finally found it, I cried. I cried so hard I don't even know why? This book is just so great and wow. 
 "You can't blend in when you were born to stand out." 
 Beautiful. Just beautiful.
Great book about a more difficult middle school experience. Could be great for kids who are bullying or who are being bullied

I often wait a bit before posting a review of a book I particularly liked in order to ensure that my feelings concerning the book are not just the of-the-moment, post-reading-excitement but rather of the more lasting variety. This book has stuck with me since reading it over two weeks ago. I loved this book! I want everyone to read it! No, seriously, go and get it and read it! It is intended for the grade school-aged set but this is one of those rare books, no, rather, it is what good books should be--it has something to say to every person regardless of age. Have I said enough? Don't bother to read about it, just read it and be happily surprised and moved.

Week 1 Book for "52 Books in 52 Weeks Book Group" 
 This is one of those books that could be read by all ages and offers many topics to discuss in book groups. The main character has a medical deformity, he has been home-schooled due to all the surgeries he has had. Our story begins with a new chapter he will be entering a private middle school and will now have to begin to deal with the real world. 
 I loved the many quotes that were used to incorporate the message of the story. I also enjoyed the various perspectives given by each narrator in the story. My favorite was his sister Olivia a high school student and the trials she found herself in: a new school, friends taking different paths and of course her brother and his disability.

Denne anbefaler jeg pa det varmeste til bade store og sma. Har hatt den med meg pa et par bokprater denne varen, og den ser ut til a fenge flere! Den beste anti-mobbe-boka pa leeenge! Synes det er viktig a trekke fram at vek er August en modig gutt, men jeg synes ogsa (soren, glemt navnet akurat na) han som ender med a bli den forste, virkelig gode vennen til August fordi han tor a sta imot bermen, er den som imponerer meg allermest! Les og bli varm ti magan! :)

"You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder." 
 This was a wonderful & great book about bullying and the difficulties that can face young children in school. It was so touching and heart-breaking to see how this young boy deals with his problems and people around him. To live with all the harassment and mean comments, even shocked looks on everyone's face. This book should me how can you be so powerful in such a mean world. 
 There is no much plot in this book, but it was so good, though. 
 It's about August, a 10-year-old boy who has a facial deformity, his parents decide to let him go for school for the first time after he had been tutored at home forever. Now, he has to face the world in this condition. He has many hard times at school which is so touching. 
 I almost liked all the characters in the book, his family and friends are so caring, honest and could understand Auggie's condition very well. 
 Except for Julian and his mother -of course-, they are the worst! 
 I also love his family and their tight relationship. 
 This book made me cry so hard many times, I just wanted to give Auggie a hug and alleviate his suffering. 
 And this is the most heart-breaking part in the whole book: 
 "Then why do you hang out with him so much?" Asked Darth Sidious. 
 "I don't know," answered the mummy. "Tushman asked me to hang out with him at the beginning of the year, and he must have told all the teachers to put us next to each other in all our classes, or something." The mummy shrugged. I knew the shrug, of course. I knew the voice. I knew I wanted to run out of the class right then and there. But I stood where I was and listened to Jack Will finish what he was saying. "I mean, the thing is: he always follows me around. What am I supposed to do?" 
 "Just ditch him," said Julian. 
 I don't know what Jack answered because I walked out of the class without anyone knowing I had been there. My face felt like it was on fire while I walked back down the stairs. I was sweating under my costume. And I started crying. 
 It is a middle-grade book, but it doesn't matter. I really did enjoy it. It was super easy to read and it gave me all the feelings. 
 Auggie, I am so proud of you, I love you. [?]

Loved, loved this book on so many levels. Beautiful writing, realistic characters, strong emotion. It makes you want to be kinder, love fiercely. As mentioned in the book, 'The universe was not kind to Auggie Pullman' - yet there was sweet justice throughout the book. And I love that. I can't recommend this book enough to my teacher friends (as early as 3rd/4th grade) and yet, I think it would be a great lit circle book for my GATE class. This is truly a book for kids of every age - and the adults that love them. There is not a book I've read this year that I recommend more highly.
Wonderful heartbreaking story. It will hit you at the core. Augie's persistance and resilience is redemptive.
A likable main character, but very predictable.

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." - Auggie 
 Wonder 
 is about Auggie, a young boy with an unusual face. His bulging uneven eyes are located an inch below the usual, his eyelids sag, no eyebrows, no eyelashes- just a few of his unusual features. August Pullman is about to face probably one of the biggest challenges of his life- middle school. After being home-schooled all his life, August Pullman is about to go on a rollercoaster ride full of ups and downs. 
 A great read. I thought the plot was simple and definitely nothing entirely new, but it was a good read nonetheless. The events in the book are just what you would most likely expect from a novel about an outcast or a peculiar individual, but still, I enjoyed going through one chapter to another. Auggie was very adorable and his character is what probably made me enjoy the novel most. I loved how his character was young, spirited and optimistic rather than pessimistic or bitter. I loved the sound of innocence is his voice. 
 I also enjoyed the other supporting characters in the novel. I liked how we also get to hear their voices in the novel since some parts were featured in their POV. Although, I think I would have preferred it if the POV was constant, in this novel. This novel is basically your typical Disney movie; a classic storyline but definitely worth reading. Oh, and I definitely loved the Sound of Music references! 
 No regrets buying this book. 5/5! :D
Cute. Quick read. A bit simple.
A book that makes you a better person for reading it. Amazing.
Even though this book in written on the middle school level, any age group would enjoy this touching story about accepting those who are "different."

I haven't cried so many Happy & Sad Tears in a long time. A sweet, funny, humbling and realistic story about kindness and strength of character; and discovering-sometimes surprisingly, who in our lives brings that strength out in us.

August was born different. His face didn't form the same way as everyone else's. This left him with eyes to low, ears that aren't quite right, no lower jaw and other things. His brain works fine though and his emotions work too. People don't know how to react around him. Even after countless surgeries to make his face useable, he still doesn't look like everyone else. August is used to it though, the stares. He doesn't like it, but he doesn't have much of a choice, it hasn't been to terrible...yet. Now his parents think it's time for him to go to school. His mom has no more left to teach him, and he needs to learn how to deal with other people. At first August is hesitant, the life he has now is pretty okay why would he want to change that? August should know best of all though, that sometimes change can be good. 
 August was mature for his age, but only about his appearance. In other ways he seemed like a typical ten-year-old boy. I can't really picture what August must look like, but I would definitely want to be his friend (except I'm not a big Star Wars fan). He has a great sense of humor and is in general a pretty cool kid. I enjoyed that we got to see different perspectives in this novel. It starts and ends with August, but in the middle we get to hear from his sister Via, her boyfriend, her old friend, and a couple of August's school mates. It was nice to get to hear their side of the story too, it made August's character even more developed and lovable. It was also nice just to see what was going on surrounding August, that he may ave not told us, or may have not even known about. I really liked the illustrations at the beginning of each new perspective too. 
 This was a truly inspirational and touching story about a boy trying to grow up without too much ordeal. August realizes he looks different, but he doesn't feel different and he wants people to just adjust to him. I really liked the friendships he made, it's always nice reading about people who show genuine kindness. I also really enjoyed his teacher's precepts, and the ones that the kids sent in at the end of the novel. They completely matched with the kid who wrote them. I thought this was a good little lesson in itself to include within the novel. 
 A great novel for anyone who has ever been stared at because they look a little different. Anyone who has had cooties, or in general was teased for something they had no control over, should read this book. Wonder is a great novel for kids to read and hopefully it will help them remember that all people have feelings. It's a great book for adults too, because as you will see in this novel it's not only children that can behave poorly. 
 First Line: 
 "I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid." 
 Favorite Lines: 
 "My name is August, by the way. I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 Read more: http://www.areadingnook.com/#ixzz1zgX...

A quick read that will have you laughing and crying all in the same chapter. 
 I loved Auggie's story! I think all of us at one point or another have felt judged by our appearance. Obviously, Auggie's challenges were extreme, but the cruelty and kindness of children (and adults) is played out wonderfully in this book. The voice of each character was unique and gave the full story we wouldn't have received otherwise. 
 This would be a perfect book for really any age from middle schooler to adult. 
 Content Rating: PG 
 **Robin-approved for ages 10+**

I have bought this book for my kids a few years ago. I just don't think I will ever read it because it is just a book for kids. When my daughter said she wanted to give it to her classmate, I think I should read it before giving it off (just to make the most of it). I am so happy I have taken the time to read it. I think Palacio is very good in giving her reader "kindness" wrapping up in a supposed-to-be unfortunate young character. I love all the precepts in the book too. I agree so much with Palacio we should always choose kind when given the choice between being right or being kind.

I really enjoyed this. Not too dark, included some comic relief. It had the heart-wrenching, aching for a person in a cruel world moments that brought me to tears but it also had the heart-felt, profound moments that brought me to tears. Although I wish they included more if how certain characters' stories played out (ie. Julian or Miranda), it's definitely an education that should be read by all. It was also am awesome book to listen to- added an entirely new dimension to perspective

WOW! I started this book yesterday and couldn't wait to finish it this morning. A powerful story that should be read by every middle school aged child and beyond. While the struggles of the main character pulled at my heartstrings, I was especially touched by his parents. I could so identify with their struggle to let go of their son knowing how difficult his journey would be. At times, we all want to protect our children from the possibilities of hurt and the evils of the world. I can only imagine how difficult it must be to gently push a child out of the nest under such extraordinary circumstances. Such a beautiful and inspirational book filled with life lessons. "Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness."
This is such a heart warming story. I just loved it?
A fast and enjoyable read (it is a YA book), but I expected more. I think this is a great book for younger children to read to learn about kindness.

As a middle school language arts teacher I'm always looking for new books for my kids. This is by far one of the best books I have read in a while for 4th-7th graders. The writing style is realistic, honest, and childlike. The multiple points of view are effective and was a good writing technique for the plot line. Olivia's thoughts, though short and sweet, we're eye opening. With stories like this, readers are often limited to one point of view and don't get the whole picture. Olivia's chapter filled that hole by discussing the struggles as a sibling and her future. This book would be a great read aloud or independent reading book for kids. The plot is straightforward and the sentence structure is simple but effective.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I liked this book but I did not love it. It follows Auggie, a boy with medical issues starting school for the first time as an older kid. He looks different from everyone else and has to deal with unwanted attention because of it. While I did appreciate the overall message of treating everyone with kindness, the ending kind of soured how I felt about things. 
 So, the school gives Auggie a medal. Not for any real achievement, just because he's different and courageous and inspires kindness or some excuse like that. Auggie is fine with it so maybe I should be too, but it just felt too sappy and unrealistic. If Auggie wants to be treated like a normal kid, then there shouldn't be some made up award just for him. It was like the school turned him into their little mascot, which is not the same as treating him like a normal kid. I didn't like the incident of bullying that changed things, either. It was like everyone went from seeing Auggie as "that freak" to "our freak," which is better, I guess? I don't know. Maybe I'm just a heartless person that is uncomfortable with this sort of big, uplifting, sweeping-orchestral-music kind of movie ending. 
 I do think for a younger audience this would be great to get kids thinking about empathy and encouraging kindness.

I loved this yp book about a boy with a deformed face going to school for the first time. The story is told from his point of view and that of his sister and their friends. The characters are very well drawn and believable.

I read this book a few days ago. I bought it because i thought the cover and the description seemed interesting. (Bare with me, english is not my first nor second language). 
 It's a book about a boy who's gone through several surgeries because of a birth-defect, making him look different, again making his mother overly protective of him. Being only ten years old, August's parents thinks he should attend public school instead of being home-schooled as he had been up until this point. He unwillingly tries, and this book is about his experiences meeting new people who are (to him) obviously disgusted by his face. Most people avoid him, but a few gives him a chance and befriends him. 
 What I really like about this book is how the narrative switches from August to August's friend Jack, his sister Via and a few more people. It gives a realistic picture of a school-situation to an outsider, how people don't dare to even touch him, how their glance lingers on his face the first time they see him. This is stuff August pretends he doesn't notice, but who would notice it better than him? 
 I laughed when August and Jack exchange emails (or was it texts?), because I am not accustomed to ten year-olds calling each other "dude" every other sentence (even though I'm 17 myself and know these things perfectly well.) 
 I can't really say I can relate to his situation (spoiler: even though it gets better for him), but I know a bit about being alone with barely any friends. It's a strong story, without too much drama. It's very informative, it shows how he hates being called "deformed" behind his back (in front of him as well, actually). That's why I recommended it to my mother, being a principal at a elementary/high school (grade 1-10 in Norway) who's reading it right now. At least to me, it was a waking call. It made me want to meet everyone with a smile and never have my eyes linger on anyone who looks different. August was a boy like any other, except he'd gone through a lot in a short life, and people were scared of him because of something he couldn't control himself. I consider it a wake-up call on my way to becoming a better person. It wasn't the perfect book, even though it referenced Star-Wars and Lord of the Rings a lot, so I gave i 4 stars.

An uplifting book that reminds us that "...the universe would not abandon us completely" (204). With a unique organizational structure, Palacio allows the readers to become intimately acquainted with the main characters. A simple and fast read that hugs a powerful idea. The idea that "...we carry with us, as human beings, not just the capacity to be kind, but the very choice of kindness" (300).
kasih bintang 10 deh :)

An utterly amazing book! I hate to use the label "characters" because the author did such a great job of creating people. This could so easily have turned maudlin, another testimony to the cruelty of people to those with severe disabilities or appearances. August "Auggie" Pullman was born with a severely disfigured face. During all of his surgeries and recoveries he was homeschooled but for fifth grade his parents enroll him in a private school. of course it's a tough adjustment and there are mean kids - and mean parents- but the author chooses to focus on the positive. Auggie's unconditional love, Via and her grandmother, who made her beautiful inside as well as out: Justin, Via's boyfriend - who very coolly plays a zydeco fiddle who finds family in Auggie's home: and finally Jack, forced initially to be Auggie's friend who realized that Auggie is more than just a face, but a really awesome human being. Like I said this book could have been a downer, like Stuck in Neutral but author Palacio chooses to show what happens to people when love and kindness rule the day! an incredible achievement for a first novel!!!
What a wonderful book. I will have to read it again, only next time aloud to my children.

august (auggie) pullman lost, and some, the genetic lottery when it came to his physical appearance. but the universe has a way of evening things out. 
 i have this thing for where someone's different, and not necessarily in the "good" way and the people around them love them despite of and for that difference. like in Boy Meets Boy by David Levithan, in which the town where the book's set boycott boy scout because boy scout has that thing for gay people. and in wonder, there's auggie's parents, sister, her friend and boyfriend, and auggie's whole school. and this makes me terribly sad because these places are beautiful and the real world is so much more terrible which makes the fictitiousness of these books so much more real. 
 this book is a breeze to go through. the characters are wonderful. and there's more than one narrator. as the middle school director said "there are more than two sides to a story", i love when you get to see through someone else's perspective. you laugh, cry, cry some more and feel good all over. and it has its fair share of quotable lines.

this is one of the books i don't feel like writing a review for because i cant get my feeling toward it to settle on one thing.. i loved it and i didn't and i enjoyed it but then i didn't .. one thing im sure of is that i recommended it to just so many people ..
I just loved this book.

I highly recommend reading this book to/with 10-12 year old children. The book has so many life lessons. My son loved it as well. My favorite quote from the book, "Always be nicer than you have to be."

I normally don't like school stories very much. Especially not sappy "poignant" "coming of age" books. But this was different. My younger brother suggested it and I was skeptical at first. I grabbed it, started reading the first page and.........I was HOOKED. 
 It is exquisite.

This book was such a gem of a read! It was so good to read this to remember how truly painful and still wonderful it can be to be a 5th grader much less a 5th grader with a congenital craniofacial anomaly. You will root for Auggie, the main character, as you have never rooted for the underdog before. A few quotes: " It's funny how there's a word like overprotective to describe some parents, but no word that means the opposite. What word do you use to describe parents who don't protect enough? Underprotective? Neglectful? Self-involved? Lame? All of the above?" And, " It's not all random...Maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in hte end. The universe takes care of all its birds." But best of all, and one to remember: "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." Please read this quick and short-chaptered book soon especially if you've got kids. It is a good reminder to choose to be kind and think about the ripple effect.
Beautiful and true. I bought this as a Christmas gift for my eldest nephew. I hope he will read and learn from it, as I did.

This book was on every list the year it came out, and I sort of missed it back then. But a friend reminded me of it recently. I'm so glad she did. In Auggie, Palacio has created a boy whose physical damage by definition defines his experience of the world. But she has also created a character who is not all hero. He is sometimes whiny and selfish and self-centered in the way all kids are. And she has successfully included not only his narrative, but the narratives of many of the kids who encounter Auggie and are changed by him. This is a novel that will inspire some great conversations about kindness, physical beauty, and what it means to grow up different. http://scribbleandhum.blogspot.com/20...
Excellent! Added to my bullying list
Beautiful!! A must read!!

Every kid should read this book while growing up. Every adult should read this as well. Empathy is a difficult concept to teach and so much can be learned by standing in someone else's shoes. This book allows you a glimpse into going through life a little different and how a little kindness can blossom and grow into something truly wonderful. This book is amazing!
Gorgeous, wonderful, funny, warm character and book - every kid in high school should be made to read this book. A modern classic.

Review - gYOEYgYOEYgYOEYgYOEYgYOEY 
 I think that all I can say about this book to sum it up is It was Truly Amazing! 
 I know I keep using that word but I've read some pretty wonderful books since creating the book club! 
 The story is about a 10 year old boy called August who is born with a disorder which causes severe facial disfigurement. 
 Book Quote: 
 'My name is August, by the way. I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse.' 
 The story is written from 'Auggie's' prospective as well as his sister and friends and how he and friends and family behave to each other. 
 The story covers many different aspects of how life and children behaved toward him when he started in a mainstream school and continues over a year as a fifth grader. 
 It is a heart warming story and tells how children can be very cruel to others. Lessons learnt abd a strong message of acts of kindness which in our cruel world everyone should confident to take on board more. It was and an emotional read, I can't lie to you there as I was in tears at certain parts. But, It evolves into a lovely ending and made me cry again but this time for happiness! 
 A truly fabulous book that every child and parent should read!! I'm passing it on to my son Max who is also 10!

So I actually finished this book within 2 days because it was such a lovely, speedy read but haven't updated you all yet. So here's a slightly belated, slightly soppy review for you to enjoy. 
 I absolutely loved this book and I would definitely recommend it to anyone. It is a sweet, inspiring, tear-jerking little book that I'm desperate to lend to someone already just so I can talk to them about it. Definitely a good recommendation by Waterstones. 
 The book is about a 10-year old boy called August who has been home-schooled all of his life so far and is just about to start secondary school (or the American equivalent). He has severe facial abnormalities due to a genetic birth defect that has caused him to have to endure numerous operations so he can eat and breathe normally and means that he can't help but stand out wherever he goes. The story is told from the perspective of August, his family, and his friends so you get a real insight his struggles and adventures settling into a new school and making new friends. It's done so realistically and isn't an over the top 'cute, innocent child overcoming adversity' type of story. Nor is it an 'oh isn't it sad, what a poor, unfortunate kid' type of story. It's more of a 'regular kid who stands out and learns to deal with it' type of story. It's really heart-warming and just makes you appreciate how lucky you are if you have a loving family, good friends, and all the little acts of kindness that happen in the world each day. 
 I found some bits definitely made me a bit teary. Not because it was a sad book, more because it was just so touching. It's like that section in the Metro where people thank others who have done something altruistic or kind to them. The stories vary from 'thanks to the man at Waterloo station who ran after me to give me my purse when I left it in the coffee shop' to 'thank you to the people on the train carriage with me and my mother who helped call an ambulance and stayed with us until it came when she collapsed on the way to Wimbledon'. I just get so unnecessarily emotional when I read things like this. It makes me want to cry even just thinking about it. It's just so nice. A man ran after me when I left my umbrella behind once and I actually welled up a bit. It's not that I don't expect people in the world to do nice things for no reward, it's just that from what you hear on the news the world is such a dangerous, selfish place so it still surprises me every time. Good job, world. 
 At the end of the book you get that warm, fuzzy feeling and the Head-teacher in the story sums it all up perfectly with his end-of-year speech to the students. "Be kinder than necessary" is the message that you walk away with, and honestly I think if you've read this book, you'll definitely want to do just that. 
 For the story, the speed and ease with which you can read this book, how beautifully written it is, and the wonderful message it leaves with you I am giving this book 10/10. I can't fault it. It's just lovely. 
 Soppy review over. 
 F x 
 P.S. I went to see the film of Cloud Atlas this weekend. We were in the smallest screen in the cinema despite the fact it was only the 2nd day of release. It was just as confusing and difficult as the book but without all of the information, with large chunks of the stories missing, and a lot of things left unexplained. My poor boyfriend, Andy, was dragged along and I think probably would have walked out if I hadn't been there. His opinion, having not read the book, was that it made no sense whatsoever, even with me sitting there trying to explain what the stories actually were. Not the greatest film in the world. I think fitting six stories into one book was challenging enough. Trying to fit six stories into one normal sized film was never going to work. It was pretty good to see the main characters changing roles for each of the six stories which included a lot of ridiculous prosthetics and the odd gender change.

one of the best feel-good books I've read. 
 excellent for all ages

WOOWWWEEE probably my favorite book of all time along with Butterfly Summer by Anne Marie Connaway and Gone by Michael Grant. 
 This AMAZING book is simply brilliant. It shows the perspective of a brave boy with a horribly distorted face. Whats fabulous about this book is that not only does it show the view of the main character and the boy with the problem, but the perspectives of friends and family . I think that the most amazing perspective was the sister, vie's. It shows how she herself has to cope, and how difficult it is for her. One of the most touching parts of the story is when Vie spends time with her grandmother and comes back after one month,and, for a split second she sees her brothers face as what everyone else, strangers, see him as. Where as she has got used to him and to her he is just auggie her brother.

Told from several points of view, this is the story of Auggie, a 5th grade student with severe facial deformities, who transitions from homeschool to public school. I feel the characters are very realistic and representative of how people, in general, react to someone who is "different." The characters show outright hostility, subtle meanness, cautious friendship, influence by peer pressure, and humane kindness. A wonderful thought-provoking read for adults as well as the intended audience of young adults.
I stayed up far too late finishing this book, but it was so worth it! What a beautiful story.
This novel broke my heart in all the right places. It gave me hope for the goodness in children to prevail.

A heart touching, warming and encouraging story. Nice! 
 Don't always criticize somebody at the back. If u are the person being criticized, will u feel good? And it is so mean to laugh at the deformed person, don't u scared of the retribution?and there is one pitiful person that I feel so sad for her ,Miranda. 
 She supposed to be standing on the stage, but she give up her opportunity and let August'sister be the actress and all because of her love towards August. Technically, her family is broken.None of her family members came to watch her performance that night. She treats August like her brother, I think her love towards August not less than August sister. Miranda is the one who never despise August, even August'sister once ashamed of telling others she had a deformed brother. 
 To put into a nutshell, August is really a wonder!
This book should be required reading for everyone!! Especially teenagers but many adults could also benefit.

It was a great book to listen to as a family as the kids all got really engaged and even my six year old loved listening to it and told me how it was teaching him to be nice. :-). I liked that it told the story from the perspective of the various kids, much like Because of Mr. Terupt. Overall, it wasn't the amazing book that I had heard it to be, but we all enjoyed it quite a lot.
SO AMAZING!!!! PROVOCATIVE AND HEART WRENCHING AND HAS COOL, UNEXPECTED POV'S!

The way Auggie spoke to you felt so touching, as if you could see this ten year old boy was in the end just a little boy. The book was like a little journey.

Yet another book recommended to me: this time by my 10-year-old daughter. I must say, I am impressed with the maturity level of this book for a young audience. 
 5th grader August was born with a severely deformed face. He has been through countless surgeries and has never gone to mainstream school until now. This book, in a realistic way, deals with his experiences of trying to fit in. 
 Well written - believable characters and dialogue. Plus, it really opened up a good discussion with my daughter about prejudice, stereotypes, and acceptance.

I was interested in this book when I first heard of it. I recently just finished reading it in a Novel Study with a class. They all enjoyed the storyline, the characters, the sense of humor, and the truth that comes from August's story/life.

" Kill 'em with kindness" 4 stars! Great easy read for all generations! Teaches us once again, that we are all different and deserve a life... Cute story, very easy flow of thoughts. :-) I recommend!

I enjoyed this book, a quick and absorbing read (young adult book). It is about a young boy, entering school for the first time at the age of ten. He's entrance into school is challenging due to a his severe facial deformity. It is not a 'poor me' book, but rather the triumph of human spirit, not only for the lead character, but for several others in his life. I enjoyed the telling of the story line from different perspectives. I think it would be a great teen read.

Fifth grader Auggie Pullman has been homeschooled all his life, but his mother has decided that attending school will allow him to socialize with others and challenge him academically. Middle grades are tough enough for so-called "normal" kids, but Auggie was born with severe facial deformities. Despite several surgeries, his facial appearance is so startling that children and adults stare at him on the street the first time they see him. Those who are familiar with Auggie don't really pay attention to his appearance, but he knows that middle school will be different. Still, you never know how others may react. It turns out that attending school and dealing with all the stares and averted eyes is one of the toughest challenges Auggie will ever face. Two classmates, Summer and Jack, befriend him, but most of the others avoid him and even play a game of Plague in which anyone who touches Auggie has thirty seconds in which to wash their hands. This is one of those novels that allows its characters to rise to the occasion, to be better than they were before or better than they might have expected. While Auggie's bravery is unquestionable, so are the courageous acts of his friends, classmates, and family members. Then, too, Mr. Browne's precepts serve as excellent life lessons, encouraging acts of kindess and reminding his students to take care of others. While he might not have had Auggie in mind when he introduces these monthly precepts, it's possible that they worked their messages subliminally in the minds and hearts of his students and became more than merely words. While the book contains its share of bullies and mean folks, there are many characters with kind hearts to offset them. Although I enjoyed this book thoroughly, I'm not sure that the inclusion of so many points of view helps the story. Some sections are stronger than others, offering a different take on earlier events, but others seem to introduce characters who are only tangentially connected to Auggie. By painting Auggie's sister realistically, she, too, is allowed to show a human side through which she resents the attention given to her brother and longs for a fresh start. Additionally, while many will applaud the feel good ending with Auggie winning a special prize and gaining acceptance, I felt that section went on for a little bit too long. Still, the book moved me while reminding me of how quickly we judge others based on appearance or what we think we know about them. Once again, assumptions lead to misunderstandings and distances.

I really enjoyed this book. I was a little sceptical at first about the different point of views but it was pulled off amazingly. I did get annoyed at times with how the way auggie acted which was like a baby especially considering he was in middle school but other than that i loved it and i do recomend this book for all ages.

3.5/5 
 It's fine as a young adult book, but I certainly wouldn't say it's a must read.

I think I was affected by some reviews and comments about this book. Plot: A year in the life of a boy with a facial deformity entering middle school after being home schooled. Reminds me a bit of Out of my Mind which is wonderful. Maybe I've read too many books on this theme lately, but overall I did like it. Ending was a bit too sappy/happy for real life, unfortunately.

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." -Auggie 
 So I started reading this book last August 27 and I said to myself "I have to finish it atleast until August 31, since the main character's name is August." (Okay I admit it, it is a lame joke.) And yet! I've finished it a day earlier than I wanted to, because who can stop it if they can't help but wonder about August Pullman. The story is just so wonderful, characters so beautiful; it was like seeing the world in the eyes of child, magical and enchanted. I don't even know what to write in this review for I am still getting ahold of myself after crying on the last part. This book should be read by everyone, regardless of age, it will teach someone something about life. It is true that while physical appearance is somehow important, what we make others feel, how we will impact their life, will what matter in the end. And Auggie just proved that. Yes in the beginning, he was so ashamed and angry because of his fate, but he survived, got used to it, lived through it, and eventually learned loving himself (thanks also to his lovely family). And by doing that, he made everyone also love him. And I do love him, too. His courage, love, passion, compassion, and empathy. I agree with Mr. Tushman, that if we all choose to be kinder than is necessary, the world will be a better place. Gosh. It is just so beautiful. So wonderful. 
 And this is one of my favorite Precept: 
 YOUR DEEDS ARE YOUR MONUMENT 
 "This precept means that we should be remembered for the things we do. The things we do are the most important things of all. They are more important than what we say or what we look like. The things we do outlast our morality. The things we do are like monuments that people build to honor heroes after they've died. They're like the pyramids the Egyptians built to honor the pharaohs. Only instead of being made out of stone, they're made out of memories people have of you, That's why your deeds are like your monuments. Built with memories instead of with stones." -August Pullman

This is one of those books that makes you want to be a better person. A little more compassion, a little more kindness, a little more bravery. I love the admonition at the end to "be a little kinder than necessary." It made me think of one of the quotes my mom would always say: 
 "I have wept in the night for the shortness of sight 
 That to somebody's needs made me blind; 
 But I never have yet felt a tinge of regret 
 For being a little too kind." 
 We all need to read books like this.

A heart-warming story that had me laughing one page and crying the next.

I simply adored this book. 
 It's such a sweet story - a young boy with a physical disfigurement goes to school for the first time; and we get to experience that first year with him. August not only narrates his story, but we also get to hear his sister, her boyfriend, her friend and Auggie's friend tell us what it's like from their perspectives. 
 It's nice to read a book with a moral that encourages kindness to others. I only wish that there had a been a section dedicated to August's bully. It could have been interesting to hear what a bully thinks when they are mean to someone. 
 Other than that comment, I couldn't put "Wonder" down. Perfectly lovely.
A beautiful story about overcoming the challenges of a physical deformity, making new friends, family and love.

finished in audio 3/1/13 
 A story told from many points of view about a boy named Auggie who was born with severe facial deformity and even after having many surgeries to correct the problems, still looks quite severe. After being home schooled for his entire life due to surgery schedules, Auggie's parents would like him to try to go to a real school so that he will be able to better deal with the way people look at and treat him due to the way he looks. There were several tear jerking moments, but the story is overall a good look how society treats people who don't appear "normal" in appearance. It shows both the cruelty of others and the kindness.

A must read for every child and adult. This story shows that there are always to sides to every story, the importance of being kind and accepting to everyone, and the what it means to be a true friend.

Excelente, no he podido dejar de pensar o hablar del libro......me conmovio muchisimo, hay muchos puntos de vista y frases muy inspiradoras.....si quieres hacer un regalo que en verdad deje huella....definitivamente este libro es una buena opcion.
A great read for all ages!

This was really more of a a 3.5-star read for me, but I'm going to be generous and give it four because the audio narration was spectacular. Not perfect, but a good representation of what it's like to grow up "different" or be a sibling of a child with special needs, though I did feel that some things were quite oversimplified.
Such a warm, enlightening book!

THIS. BOOK. It was unexpectedly beautiful. The characters were so real, and Palacio explored each and every one of them through the good and the bad. They were written so well that I feel like I have a personal attachment to all of them and wish I could reread Wonder for the first time. 
 Wonder is such a refreshing, heartbreaking, beautiful, unconventional piece of literary art. Please pick this one up! You won't regret it.

I love this book. The way the author has told the story through different perspectives is brilliant. I could relate to each person as they told the story. 
 I finished this book on the bus with a bunch of my students. Nothing like trying to hold back the tears amongst a bunch of 8 year olds as I read. 
 I love this story. It is a great conversation starter.

I thought having every point of view from different characters will help letting the readers know how bad the situation of Auggie is, but no, it is just that they have their own story to tell--it's like they are given their own spotlight. 
 I love how these characters developed. The fact that these kids are only from middle school and high school, you wouldn't realized they are just teenagers.

 But the only time it was good was in the middle pages, that's it. I (And I'm ashamed to say.) extremely disliked August. He was so nonchalant and cool about his deformed face that it frustrated me, almost.

This is one of the most amazing books I have ever read! Auggie is a beautiful person and all the characters are multi-dimensional. A stirring book, one I highly recommend.
So great. I cried big crocodile tears when I finished it. It has really great, memorable characters and a meaningful message for kids (and adults.)

I just finished this. I should be at work, but I'm sitting here with tears in my eyes ...from a Young Adult book. 
 A fantasticly well written young adult book that I had to finish this morning before I did anything else. Great story, great characters. Man, I love good books.

"Here's what I think: the only reason I'm not ordinary is that no one else sees me that way." 
 A story of an ordinary boy with an extraordinary face tells his tale about growing up, adjusting to a new environment, making friends and appreciating life itself. Told in different POV's from Auggie himself, from his sister, friends and just plain people surrounding him; we witness how this ordinary boy brings extraordinary in every page of this book. 
 August "Auggie" Pullman has had multiple surgeries on his face to save his life. He has Mandibulo Dystosis. Although he has this and what they call a "distorted face", he's a simple boy trying to live his way through life. Until that day that he begins middle school that is. The day he walked through the grounds of Beecher Prep he began his journey through acceptance from more public grounds. Gaining friends wasn't easy when everybody just can't stop staring and talking about you. 
 This story has taught me so well that not everyone is what they seem. Sometimes people are really shallow when it comes to the physical appearance of a person that we forget that what is important is not visible to the naked eye. 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 It took a while for Auggie's schoolmates to get used to him. There were loyal friends and there were also bullies of course but reading about his journey was really great. On how he survived all the criticisms not only from the students but from the parents as well. 
 Through the end of the story, Auggie grew so much and all of the people around him. And that made me happy. I admit, it didn't made me ugly cry, though there were other parts of the book that made me tear up, it's still a great book that will inspire anyone from any age group. Its about family, friendship and love as well. Anyone can relate to this book! 
 "The best way to measure how much you've grown isn't by inches or the number of laps you can now run around the track, or even your grade point average-- though those things are important, to be sure. It's what you've done with your time, how you've chosen to spend your days, and whom you've touched this year. That, to me, is the greatest measure of success." 
 If you want to read about inspiration and appreciate what you have today, then you have to read this! One of a kind story of a one of a kind boy that will keep you reading for more. 
 "Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed."

A very moving and lovely story. It's about tough topics - but it's a warm fuzzy story. I loved that it was safe to have the audio going in the car with my whole family - and the story was good enough and had a great message that I really loved sharing it with them. 
 I just loved every adult in this book! Which is really unusual for a YA novel. And I loved seeing them (and their humor and love) through the eyes of children. 
 a powerful read
IT IS AN AMAZINGLY INSPIRATIONAL BOOK THAT MAKES ME GRATEFUL FOR WHAT I HAVE IN LIFE! I WOULD RECOMMEND THIS TO ANYONE!READ IT!

saya baca buku ini cukup lama, maklum saja karena waktu itu hari libur dan memang lebih sering jalan-jalan. 
 kayaknya belum pernah baca buku yang dari awal sampai akhir, hati saya sangat terasa hangat. buku ini bahaasa inggris nya sangat simple dan mudah dimengerti. topiknya ringan tentang keluarga. tapi benar-benar sangat menyentuh. 
 bagian paling menyentuh adalah kisah tentang via, kakak august. kalimat yang benar-benar mendeskripsi via yaitu: 
 "mom and dad would always say I was the most understanding little girl in the world. I don't know that, just that I understood there was no point in complaining. I have seen August after his surgeries: his little face........ 
 After you seen someone else going through that, it feels kind of crazy to complain over not getting the toy you had asked for, or your mom missing a school play. I knew this even when I was six years old. No one told it to me. I just knew it." (page 82)
