 dalam penggambaran ini, via banya mengalami hal, setiao kalimat menunjukkan bahwa dia harus mengalah, tapi pada bab berikutnya jelas bahwa via sangat mencintai adiknya, August. 
 paling sedih waktu daisy, anjing mereka pergi. yang pecinta anjing pasti tahu banget keadaan ini. 
 aku suka jack dan bagaimana kisah jack dituliskan. sangat menarik. 
 aku suka ayah dan ibunya, terutama isabelle ibunya. gambaran ibu terbaik.meskipun tidak ada bab khusus tentang ibunya, tapi setiap ibunya muncul dalam dialog, benar-benar menjadi bagian terbaik. 
 sebenarnya, tiap bagian cerita dari tokoh yang ada benar-benar punya kisahnya sendiri dan sangat menyentuh. 
 bagaimana menjadi august dengan segala deskripsi dirinya yang dalam dunia nyata nggak tahu akan seperti apa. 
 kekurangannya, ntah kenapa pada buku yang aku baca, di bab Justin di hal 187-204 itu penulisannya semua ditulis dengan huruf kecil. sangat mengganggu sih, jadi setiap awalan kalimat tidak diberi huruf kapital, begitu juga nama dan istilah. 
 tapi tetap saja, aku sangat merekomendasikan untuk membaca buku ini, hati terasa hangat setelah membacanya.
this book was terrific! I loved the writing and the path each character took.

When I was reading the first part and Jack just dissed August & the chapter where August tells the story just ends, I threw my copy in the trash- How could it be that way? But after an hour, I took it up again. I am so blessed that I did!
Review to come : )
A little too unrealistic for my taste

I love exploring what it means to look beyond the surface. While the story focuses on August, a ten-year-old boy with a severe facial abnormality, the themes are universal. Friendship is earned on both sides, and it is worth fighting to keep it. Parents (and pets!) bestow unconditional love. Small events mark great turning points. 
 This young adult novel hits the right tone: sweet but not sappy, humorous and realistic. The changing perspectives (different sections are narrated by different kids) kept me engaged and served to move the story along. 
 Frankly, I could see a whole other book being written from the adult perspective. What thoughts and anxieties did the parents and administrators have about the children? How did that inform their actions? But, that is my bias as a parent to want to hear that perspective. 
 A quick, surprisingly light read with short chapters.

Another YA book, another 5 star rating. This was such a nice story. Auggie, the main character, felt like a real person and wasn't overly sentimental. I liked the use of different characters in the middle of the book to tell the story.

This really should be a required book somewhere in the middle school curriculum. It touches on so many themes our kids need to hear; kindness, respect, friendship, standing up for what's right, believing in yourself. At first I wasn't sure I liked the multiple narrator perspective for this particular story, but it really did push the plot along at a much greater speed. August Pullman is one of the most amazing characters I've had the privilege to meet in a long time. I adored this book!
Amazing book. I absolutely loved it. If only more adults could live by the precepts written by the children!!! Could not stop the tears streaming down my face as I read the end of the book.
Wow. This is a must-read for every person (especially those who work with or have children)!

"I think it's like the Cheese Touch in Diary of a Wimpy Kid. The kids in that story were afraid they'd catch the cooties of they touched the old moldy cheese on the basketball court. At Beecher Prep, I'm the old moldy cheese." We can only imagine what August (known as Auggie) looks like, but his facial deformity alienates him from most everyone. The reader empathizes with him but also marvels at his ability to finally make himself appreciated for who he really is. This book was hard to put down! A very impressive debut. The bio says that R. J. Palacio is a graphic designer by day. That makes me curious to see her design work.

Anti-bullying is the new black. Of course, the reason why nothing is REALLY ever the new black is because everything that's supposed to replace black is just the flavor of the month, and everybody with a clue knows this. And being against bullying is the flavor of the month. (Please. Is anyone FOR bullying?) Most of the portrayals of bullying we get are reductive, and the solutions we're offered are preachy and/or non-real-world, and the disconnect between language and action is huge. Most ADULTS, let alone kids, don't see the gulf between the way they talk about bullying while simultaneously acting (subtly or not-subtly) like homophobic, fat-phobic, difference-phobic, inclusion-phobic, classist, racist, privileged, we (I, my kid, etc)-are-brilliant-and-special-and-everyone-else-is-less-brilliant-and-less-special douchenozzles. Look, I'm so irked my syntax is going. 
 Anyway, I loved this book for a zillion reasons, but the primary one is this should be the book EVERY MIDDLE SCHOOL KID reads about bullying. It makes the importance of allies and bystanders really clear -- simply going along with the popular crowd, when they're being mean or smirky to someone they consider less-than, makes you part of the problem. The book makes it clear how hard it is to do the right thing. And it's a BOOK, not a sermon. This is a great story. (Two-sentence summary: Kid with horrid facial deformities starts going to school for the first time after years of being home schooled. And he starts in MIDDLE SCHOOL.) I liked the fact that different sections had different narrators. And that the writing is utterly un-showy. (I've been reading a lot of lyrical stuff lately and it's nice to read something so direct.) And that it's a very quick, fluid read -- I think MOST kids will really like it, not just book-loving kids. It's moving, and it's not pedantic, and there's humor (and my GOD there is a lot of Star Wars stuff). Yay. Adults who enjoy kidlit should read this as a way to talk to their kids about standing up to their friends when their friends are acting dicky. (And the portrayal of a popular, powerful ADULT mom whose helicopter-y, bad-behavior-excusing conduct lets her kid continue to be a bully SHOULD make parents squirm.) The ending was maybe too tidy, so I'll give it four stars as a work of literature and one more for wearing its importance so lightly.
4.5 stars. A little cheesy and predictable at parts, but I loved it!

A sweetly sad, joyful, funny,moving book for young people. August Pullman is a boy with a different face who goes to school for the first time in year five and this is the story of his first year with all its struggles and achievements for August, his family and his school. It's about the importance of kindness, a lovely message, given with heart.

This is the first of the 15 Sunshine State Young Reader Award (SSYRA) books that I'll be reading before August 2013, and I really can't imagine that the other 14 could possibly be better than this amazing, touching book. This is the story of August, a young man with a serious facial deformity starting school for the first time in middle school after years of home schooling. Three students are chosen to shepherd him through his first days, and his relationships with them make up much of the story. This novel is told from several different character's perspectives, allowing the reader to see events from multiple views. August's evolving relationships with his mother, father and older sister are the heart of this novel, be warned that there are several sob-inducing moments in this tender tale. This book is highly recommended for students in 4th grade and up, it would make an excellent read-aloud that has lots of topics for discussion such as bullying, friendship, family relationships and disabilities.

This was a very sweet and charming little book. Children's literature for sure but happy to have finally read it. Going to recommend that Sam read it soon. I think he will like it a lot, maybe even Emily.

I believe middle school students would benefit from reading and discussing this book. It is well written, fast moving and full of messages worth consideration. Although these messages are more straightforward than adults are accustomed to, they are never preachy. Very serious challenges are juxtaposed with just the right note of humor. The characters well developed using carefully selected details and actions. It would have been easy to include a bunch of cheap stereotypes but Palacio steered clear. Because August (10) has an older sister, a teenage perspective is interwoven. The use of some unexpected narrators adds depth. The dialogue rings true and helps to carry the story forward in a lively way that will captivate many young readers. 
 I cheered for Auggie's precept: "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." Now this could change lives. 
 A few other quotes out of many that I could have chosen: 
 "It's not enough to be friendly. You have to be a friend." 
 "The universe takes care of all its birds." 
 "You don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone."

Overall I enjoyed this book. I listened to this one on audiobook and though the multiple perspectives and storytellers added some fun with putting the whole story together, there were some that just seemed to kind of be there for a small part and then never really show up again or that I felt really had only one purpose just for a small detail that seemed unnecessary (Via's boyfriend and her best friend). As well, the climax didn't seem that climactic for me and ending at the assembly was just excessively and drawn out. However, it's a good message told in an understanding way that addresses emotions not only of those who feel they're the ugly ducklings, but also those who surround them and how they respond to it. 
 I think this book also struck a chord with me, as my 5th grade year wasn't exactly any walk in the park either...

Definitely one of my top 10 favorite books of all time. It's one of those books that just gives you hope for humanity again. I was also struck by how brave some of the characters are, especially since they're just fifth graders. I mostly read sci-fi/fantasy/adventure novels, where it's typical to see young people be brave and noble by physically fighting villains or taking on quests that put them in grave danger, but Wonder is full of a different, quieter kind of bravery that I am utterly in awe of. I don't know if, as a fifth grader, I would have had the courage to leave my friends and sit at a lunch table with a new kid with a condition that made him not too great to look at (that's putting it lightly), whom everyone stayed away from. I wouldn't have been able to spend half a year putting up with bullies who were picking on me just because I befriended someone who was different. Not conforming is hard, and yet, as this book shows us, when it's done for the right reasons, it can really make a huge difference. 
 Basically, tl;dr-- if I had working tear ducts, I would have been bawling my eyes out halfway through the story. I'm looking forward to reading the short stories from the same universe. 5/5

As it is, the topic of this book and the way it was written was enough to make it 'wonder'-ful but R.J. Palacio had a stroke of brilliance when she added different character viewpoints. First of all, she didn't leave it up to the reader to infer what other characters were thinking, and secondly, it added a whole new depth to the story that we wouldn't have seen otherwise. A really, really, good book. Fresh.

"Act a little kinder than is necessary." 
 If there's one major lesson I got from this book, it's that. 
 I read this book and found myself feeling the same emotions as I did while reading The Little Prince. Seeing the world in a child's eyes made me reflect on my values and not-so adult self once more. Auggie's story made me remember what I've recently forgotten: that it's not the achievements that make a person, it's one's character. But how do we truly measure one's character? I guess it's a little bit of how you interact with the people you know and more of how you relate with the people you don't know- strangers for example. Is it the little kindness you offer the world when nobody's looking? I guess so. My most loved author once wrote, 
 "Kindness connects to who you are, while niceness connects to how you want to be seen." -Levithan 
 Recognize someone in here? Charlotte? Julian, maybe? You see, there aren't guidelines on "How To Be Kind" or else, all of us would be saints by now. Ikr? Haha. One good deed a day is a start. One good deed a day will make a change for me, you, and the world. One good deed a day and we will leave our mark in this lifetime. I believe in that. It was even said in the book by Mr. Browne, their English professor: 
 "Your deeds are like your monuments, built of memories instead of stone." 
 Speaking of Mr. Browne, I really liked the whole idea of PRECEPTS. It's like an inspirational, motivational, self-reflection thing and I wish I had this too when I was a student. It must be really fun being a part of his class. 
 So my favorite character is Jack Will. He's so fun and I can see that he's a real friend. He wasn't a very good one at first but I'm really happy that he came to realize who really mattered and he's man enough to admit his mistakes. Sometimes, like Jack Will and me counted, people can be so shallow; only looking at the surface and not realizing that the much bigger and grander stuff is what's beneath. Like one great writer wrote, 
 "What's essential is invisible to the eye." 
 Okaaay so why am I quoting so many people? huhu just so many realizations when I read this book. Thank you R.J. Palacio. You made me realize so much from 10-year-olds, which is a shame because I'm already 23. 
 CHOOSE KIND

After being home schooled for his first 4 grades, Mom and Dad convince Auggie to give 5th grade a try. Auggie is very reluctant because he has been born with not one, but TWO syndromes which has given him a very different looking face. But, Auggie does go to school. He does battle bullies, those his own age, and those much older. He also meets some great friends, and learns a lot. 
 I see why teachers are assigning this book to young people. It reminds us that we need to look beyond physical features, and find the real person inside. :)
This book was amazing. Amazing. Peopled with characters I would love to have in my circle. If you haven't read it, rectify. Thanks to the indie bookseller who recommended it to me.
http://www.librarianosnark.blogspot.c...
Faith in humanity and myself restored. Thanks for the lovely story.

I liked it more than I thought I would. It isn't too heavy handed about accepting a kid who is different. I loved how it was told from the different perspectives of the people in August's life, especially the older sister.

I feel like I should just stop reading books at this point because I don't think anything will ever top Wonder. It's not your run-of-the-mill story about a child who has a genetic anomaly, entering middle school for the first time & the tough situations that the child has to endure. Well, it IS about that, but the story unfolds using unique perspectives - the eyes and voices of innocent children. The voice of Auggie is so endearing and pure, his observations so acutely aware. The author makes you appreciate the struggle of fitting in (cause we have ALL been there, even without any visible scars, defects...) because for every bully, for every taunt, for every kid who runs home crying cause he is ashamed, there's always kindness somewhere. I found this book in the juvenile section based on a goodreads recommendation, but this is a story for all ages. If every parent read this to their children, I think the world would be a kinder, safer place (or at the very least maybe middle school won't be so bad for kids...win win!)

One of my year ten girls is reading this so I thought I would too. And what a joy to read! I loved that Auggie's story was one of fun, friendship, kindness and courage. I loved that it didn't ever get down in the dumps about his plight, and that the characters in Auggie's life - from his quirky and cool family, to his awesome teachers and his classmates - were realistic and loving and delightful. And Daisy - the best dog ever! I liked the multiple narratives as well. I will be recommending this book to many students from now on!

How nice when something lives up to its hype! I thoroughly enjoyed my journey through Wonder, and was a bit sad to have it end. I had just read the NYTimes article about ways fiction can change the brain ( http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/18/opi... ), and it occurred to me that this could be a book that could literally change minds for the better. I also think this is a book that students can enjoy as much as the adults who are raving about it. One of my best students just finished the book, and told me she could see it as a great fit for lit circles and discussions among students. 
 Palacio does a wonderful job of presenting this book through different points of view. Much of the dialogue among students rings true, although sometimes I felt the kids seemed a bit older than fifth grade. Would parents really leave a group of fifth graders alone in their home for a party? Nevertheless, I kept picturing fifth graders at one of my schools and the ways they would behave. And, there are many wonderful adult role models in the book, including teachers, administrators, and Augie's great parents. One of the best expressions of their love was when Augie's dad confessed that he had thrown out the astronaut helmet because he loved Augie's face. I liked the fact that children felt they could confide in their families and adults, but not always. 
 I guess one thing that didn't ring true for me at first was how horrified students were by someone so different. Maybe in some ways it was due to the more elite nature of the setting. Kids do like to have targets, but at times I felt that was overdone. I see treatment of students with a variety of physical disabilities at my own school, and the reactions are not as severe for so long. Perhaps it is because my school is much more diverse. 
 As a former science teacher, once again I wish someone would go beyond volcanoes and potato clocks for science fairs! Have students complete real experiments. On the other hand, I wish schools would do more projects like the Egyptian museum, complete with flashlights, another event that Augie thoroughly enjoyed as a mummy. 
 I enjoyed Augie's anticipation for Halloween, and several plot devices and situations that were used. There were characters who grew, and some who did not. The use of quotes, songs, and "precepts" was so well done. One of my favorites was when Justin thought, "maybe the universe takes care of its creations in ways we can't see". The headmaster's use of "kinder than necessary" and Beecher's words were crafted so elegantly. 
 And, I can't help but wonder about the reference Palacio makes at the end of the book to "the little girl in front of the ice cream shop" who was part of the inspiration for writing it. I loved looking up some of the quotes, the music, and more. I found her interview http://rjpalacio.com/author.html very illuminating and thought provoking as well. This is a book that will stay with me for years to come, and will make me think of being more kind than necessary, and sharing genuine smiles.

Told from four points of view, this is a delightful story about a boy who attends school for the first time in 5th grade. He has a facial deformity. He tells how people look when they first see him. It is told with humor and empathy. Great read for all ages.

This is now one of my favourite books of all time. I'm a bit late to the bandwagon, but after hearing so much about it I finally picked up Wonder and experienced the emotional roller-coaster. 
 August Pullman is a ten year old boy who was born with severe facial disfigurements. Thanks to the various medical procedures he has had to undergo, he has never been to a school before. Until now... 
 The novel is broken into chunks, from the point of view of different characters. Besides giving more context to the events of the story, the different perspectives remind us that every person has their own story and we may not know what is really going on in their world. 
 Moving, heartbreaking, and inspiring. It is clear why this brilliantly crafted novel has gained so much praise and is being used in many schools to teach PSHE. Read it!
Every fifth grader should be given a chance to read this. Every last one of 'em.
Life changing. Every human should read this book.
Good message, it was just kind of slow for me, still a must read though for any pre-teen or even a teen.
I just flat out loved this book. Everyone should read it!

In a world riddled with hate and heartbreak, a little kindness can go a long way. I loved this story that chronicled the journey of Auggie from a sheltered child to a socially acclimated boy thriving in middle school. 
 This book is written in the first person, from a number of different perspectives, however I didn't feel it detracted at all from the story, but helped us view Auggie from a variety of people most closely associated with him.

"I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid. I mean, sure, I do ordinary things. I eat ice cream. I ride my bike. I play ball. I have an XBox. Stuff like that makes me ordinary, I guess. And I feel ordinary. Inside. But I know ordinary kids don't make other ordinary kids run away screaming in playgrounds. I know ordinary kids don't get stared at wherever they go. " 
 10 year-old August Pullman likes all the things other boys his age do, and wants to do all the same things. The trouble is, he'll never be like other boys his age. Augie was born with severe craniofacial abnormalities, and even after years of surgeries and procedures, his appearance is still shocking, hideous even, to people who have never met him. After homeschooling Augie throughout his elementary years, his parents think it might be time for Augie to go to school with other kids. At Beecher Prep in Manhattan, he'll find that he can handle the academics easily, but it's friendship, and the stark reality of his difference, that makes his 5th grade year so challenging. 
 This really was a charming book, and a fantastic tale of friendship, bravery, and what beauty truly is. I thought the way Palacio shifts perspectives between various characters (Auggie, his older sister, his friends, his sister's boyfriend) was outstanding; each character had a distinct voice, and allowed the story to go much deeper than if it had been narrated by a single point of view. The shifting pov's also kept the story from feeling too sentimental, or even manipulative, although there were still some parts that felt a little forced (I'm looking at you, Daisy the dog storyline). But these are relatively minor flaws; the story as a whole is marvelous, with rich characters and a powerful message. It'll be leaving my hands soon, and getting passed on to my daughter's.
Motivating read! Reminder that there are more kind people than hateful. People want to do right, it may just need time.

Probably one of the best books I've read. 
 If you've ever been bullied over the way you look, read this. 
 For now, I'm going to quote Emma Stone and say I have a twig in my eye, no, a branch.
This book has really taught me about myself and life in general I absolutely loved it! It's given me a different outlook on life!

This is really ****1/2 for me. It is an uplifting, WONDERful YA story, about the trials and tribulations of a 5th grade boy who attends public school for the first time, which is traumatic enough, but is in this case compounded exponentially by the fact that he was born with profound facial deformities. Everyone he meets has strong (sometimes horrified) reactions to his outward appearance, but Auggie just wants to make friends and be accepted . What this little dude goes through, how his parents react, how his peers behave, and how Auggie himself adapts and ultimately grows through the year is a story worth telling. There are good guys, bad guys, laughter and tears, inspiration galore, and a seemingly true depiction of things from a 10 year old's perspective. Note: Mr. Browne's Precepts are an added bonus. Loved it.
awesome story! one of my new favorite books. fantastic!!
An inspiring tale on how far kindness can take you. Loved the characters and the different perspectives the story was written in.

How do you teach your children to be accepting and kind to people who may look "different." This novel examines that concept quite well. It is very easy to fear things that may make us feel uncomfortable. These feelings can often lead people to react in unbecoming ways. Add to that a ringleader that uses his power for evil and you end up with a story that teaches quite a valuable lesson about tolerance, bullying, and being a friend.
A must read!

2014 Rebecca Caudill nominee. I actually listened to this on a playaway and really enjoyed the book. It is about a young boy who is born with severe facial deformity. He has been homeschool to this point because of countless surgeries. When he is about to start 5th grade his parents encourage him to enter the public school. The book is about this year of school, his adjustments, classmates reactions and gives insight about how his family supports him. You will laugh and cry with this book!
WOW. This is a story that will make you feel as uniquely as it is told. This is the most powerful thing I've read in a long time. I think that everyone needs to experience Auggies story.

A lovely, sincere book that will make you laugh, cry, and think. I give it 5 stars unabashedly - a truly wonderful read for people of all ages. I read this book along with my younger sister, who is in the 5th grade. I'm a college student, and I think I enjoyed it as much as she did. When I was home for Thanksgiving, we finished reading it aloud together and my parents were soon drawn into the story as well. A quick read for older folks, but no less charming.
Great Middle Age Fiction - The beauty of the book is that you don't have to know what the main character looks like to fall in love with his courage, personality and family.
Every kid (and adult) should read this novel. As a mother I appreciate that it teaches not only compassion but the ability to adapt and march on. Wonderful!
Very cute children's book. I read it to my kids. It creates empathy in children and adults. I cried many times. Very well done.

Auggie is my hero! This has to be one of the most heart warming, heart breaking, and beautiful stories I have ever read. It's an easy read, filled with very difficult topics. But its primary purpose is clear: be kind, be loving, and look deeper than what is on the outside. Although I don't always love books with multiple perspectives, I love the amazing young people portrayed. If my kids grow up to be like Jack, Summer, Via or even half as much like Auggie, I would be the proudest mamma around.
I read this more than a year ago but I forgot to write a review. In one word perfect. I recommend it.

I picked up Wonder cause one of my best friends in high school has a condition similar to the one Auggie's... so it was interesting to read something from their point of view... 
 And I adored this book, I mean, I related with it, cause some of the parts in it were just as my friend lived them... This book is sooo sweet and feel-good, cause at the end it reminds you that each of us are a wonder, a truly amazing wonder... 
 Me happy!
Asdfghjkln hermosoo! Hermoso libro!!! Aaahh sin palabras
Luke and I read this together, taking turns on pages/chapters so it took awhile! But we both loved it, really really special book.

I fell in love with this YA book from the beginning, but hated the last few chapters(about 20 pages). It is hard to explain without spoiling the book, but suffice it to say that Auggie's narrative was wonderful as were the conflicting feelings/fears/reactions from his 5th grade peers. It felt authentic and I liked the adults in the story and I liked that they treated him as a "normal" kid, much like he wanted and needed, but then the narrative turned and didn't treat him as a "normal" kid- but as "special", and not in a good way. 
 Because of the ending, I gave the book 3 stars instead of 4...

This book should be in everyone's list to read. It is one of those books that will move you in every way. As a teacher it is important to read but also students and parents should read it as well. One of the best books I have ever read. And one of those that I will probably come back to many times again.

"Shall we make a new rule of life... always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" by JM Barrie. 
 This quote used by August's headteacher, Mr Tushman, at his graduation ceremony sums up this beautifully written story about the life of August. A young boy with a one-in-a-million face deformity and his first year of attending middle school after being home tutored by his mum. 
 This story recounts his experiences and feelings and those of the loved ones around him. 
 An easy 5* rating and a book that all young people and their parents should read for an important life lesson in humanity, kindness and not judging a book by its cover.

This book reminds me of books like The Wednesday Wars and Sleeping Freshman Never Lie. The main characters were young (too young, in my opinion. I have a sister who is in 5th grade, and she is nothing like the characters in this book. They were all way too mature and aware of what they were doing. Personally, I would have bumped everyone up to 7th grade, and made the sister a Junior/Senior. That would have been more believable.) and the story followed them throughout the school year. Things happened, lessons were learned, etc etc. 
 I thought the writing was good--there was a scene at the end where I may have shed a few tears--but this isn't a book I'd want to read over and over again.
Read this for a good, happy, people are not all that bad cry. I enjoyed mine.
A heart warming story, written in all its simplicity capturing all the complexities of the young boy's life. make you want to hold your loved one real tight.
Breathtaking
Sigh. Lovely book.

I couldn't put this down. Auggie's story is sad and funny and inspiring. I loved all the different perspectives you get of this one boy's situation, and unlike many other books with similar subject matter, it isn't didactic or unrealistic. The book is much closer to real life.
I loved this book. It was really hard to put down. I loved all the characters (except Julian). It made me laugh and I cried happy tears at the end. A must read whatever age you are.

Odavno bolju i poucniju knjigu nisam procitala. Preporuka svima 
 Great book, left me speachless. ..Standing ovation...
no words can describe how amazing this book is
Amazing! I don't have any other words for it.
Will definitely give you a way better perspective in life. Very moving, inspiring, and fun. If this little Auggie does exist, he has my full respect. :)
Loved it. Story of a boy with physical deformities told through the eyes of his sister and friends. AR 4.8; 11 pts
A very beautifully and creatively told story. I love how it switched points of view throughout the book. Captured some of the ups and downs of middle school so well.

I personally doesn't like when a book is split into sections of characters describing the same scenario. But this was one of te books where the concept was truely needed and I fell inlove with Auggie, and I loved the Via-part. 
 This is a book everyone should read. It's about so much more than a little boy starting school for the first time, it's about society, family structures, friendship and love.

To me, this is a beautifully written book that makes you want to say: wow. The storyline is quite bittersweet, with epic wins and fails. This book is somewhat a feel-good awesome sort of book, if you know what I'm talking about. It made me see people and the world differently, in a good way, of course. 
 I recommend this book to anybody. Great job, R.J.!
What an awesome book! I really liked it!

This book taps into a whole range of emotions. Ultimately, it is guaranteed to break your heart... and then make it whole again. 
 "'Shall we make a new rule of life ... always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?' ... What a marvelous line, isn't it? Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed ... what I want you, my students, to take away from your middle-school experience is the knowledge that, in the future you make for yourselves, anything is possible. If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary -- the world really will be a better place." 
 Words to live by!

JF book told from 5 different perspectives. A boy with a servere facial deformity starts school for the first time in his life, middle school. You get his perspective, his friends, and his older sister. 
 The beginning turned me off, lots of jokes about butts, farting, etc. But once you get past that the book turns really good. 
 Good message about standing up for the right, even when it's not popular. 
 Clean, except for the jokes about butts and farting. 
 Favorite quote: 
 p. 204 - "The universe was not kind to Auggie Pullman. ... [the universe] takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see. Like with parents who adore you blindly, and a big sister who feels guilty for being human over you, and a little gravelly-voiced kid whose friends have left him over you, and even a pink-haired girl who carries your picture in her wallet. Maybe it's a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. The universe takes care of all its birds." 
 p. 313 "Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world."
This is a great book, written from different character's point of view. It really makes you think how you look at people and how you treat them.

Fantastic! Every child about to enter or in middle school ought to read it! 
 I could never manage to get my hands on this book at our school's library, which hopefully means many of the kids have read it!
Fantastic!!

I think this book is the best book I have ever read!! I LOVED EVERY WORD!! Well written, the characters are fantastic and the story is every day life but done in such a way as to touch your soul and teach you important lessons. 
 I read this to my children for homeschool, but I am so glad we read it out loud together, it was such a good book for kids and adults both. I think every child should read or have this book read to them. 
 I fell in love with "Auggie" and the other characters, I felt I knew them or lived near them. I hate to part with them and they will remain in my mind for along time and in my heart and soul forever. This is a book that touches you and makes hopefully changes you for the better, forever. 
 I pray that my kids took the lessons from it and apply and remember them the rest of their lives.

What a WONDERful book! I really wish it was longer, I didn't want it to end. 
 This may be considered a children's book, but it was so special and meaningful and I honestly recommend everyone to read this once in their lives. It made me laugh and I must admit I had a little happy sob at the end of it. 
 From the moment it started I warmed up to Auggie and although I could never imagine what he went through I felt an instant connection. It was so incredibly interesting to see his perspective on things and his conflicting emotions. He is so brave, funny, smart and hopeful! This book really demands you to see past the outside of a person and look to a persons true self. It showed the cruelty of kids, but also their ability to love, often stronger than any adult could. It reminded me of when I was Auggie's age and how kids were cruel to me sometimes but you just need to keep your head up and have faith that there are others that care. 
 I enjoyed the changing perspective and really gave an interesting insight to the other characters that otherwise you wouldn't have known. Definitely for young kids that would read this book it's great for them to see that there is always more than one side to a story. Always. 
 However, I had one tiny problem with Justin's bit. What was that about? The lack of punctuation and capital letters annoyed me to bits! Also I felt like it didn't contribute much to the story. Luckily it wasn't too long though. 
 If you need a happy cry, read this book! You'll love it, I promise.
Very cute book. A good read for anyone. :). Anyone can change the world.
Every middle school student should read this book. Absolutely no doubt in my mind that this is a must read that will teach adolescents about what it means to be "kinder than necessary."

I think this is a great book for all ages. It teaches a great lesson about embracing your flaws and realizing they are what make you special. This book also teaches others to realize the effects of bullying. And to never judge a book by it's cover. I think this should be a required read for preteens and middle schoolers everywhere due to the amazing lessons it teaches. I would recommend this book to anyone!!
A must read.
One of my Favourite books...
Heart wrenching, beautifully written.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I have to WONDER why any kid would finish this book when toward the end there is a lengthy speech by the school principal about kindness and good citizenship that, iirc, goes on for pages. Other than this cop-out grownup's lecture thrown in in order to wrap up the final scene, I very much liked this book. As the sister of someone born with a cleft palate, I found the chapters written from family members' points of view especially compelling.
5/2013 I had this on hold from the library not sure if it was one Jill wanted me to read. It was a good book and had many great lessons in it.
It's been a while since I read a book that made me cry like this one did. Very uplifting and endearing.

I read this for my daughter's book group. It's a nice, touching, feel-good story. I'm not convinced by the ending but for kids I think it's a good book and it has some valuable lessons about standing up to bullies.

This book is the worst kind of book -- it's the kind that made me feel all wonderful as I read it, ya know, "the world sucks sometimes but can still be an amazing place thanks to the heroism we're all capable of deep down inside!" Yet although the book made me feel this way, a good feeling, it also made me feel a little cheated as the writing itself is nothing special and often downright pedestrian (and the child protagonist is no excuse for vanilla drama.) The book is divided into numerous characters who are all given first person narration (including Via's oddly-illiterate sounding boyfriend?) yet all the characters read identically, all sounding like a grown up trying to write like a kid. The writing is never awful per se, but it's never that good either...Palacio is going for the heart rather than the gold, and stylistically, can't hold her own against other voice stylists such as Sapphire, Toni Morrison, Judy Blume, or even J. D. Salinger. 
 Yet, it's a quick, very easy read that pulls at the heartstrings in some moderately effective ways, and it's overall message of doing more kindness than is necessary is worth hearing. But doesn't that message deserve a strong narrative to embolden it, as opposed to a more sad, dramatic rendering of Diary of a Wimpy Kid? Hmmmm.
This was amazing and well written. Auggie is my super hero!
Wow. What a powerful little book. A must read for everyone about tolerance, belief in oneself, kindness, friendship, and something else. I got teary at the ending, difficult to do on a plane.
not bad....I didn't cry...I expected it to be more moving...I don't know. but a great insight into the life of a boy who...to say...has not had it easy...would be a serious understatement!
Incredible book. I loved that it sworn from the various points of view. I highly recommend this to everyone.
Enjoyable story. Good YA fiction with realistic characters and situation. Would make a great book club read.

I absolutely loved this book. It has been a long time since I have had such a good cry over a book. I think everyone should read it in order to be reminded of what it is like to be perceived as different when we are all really just normal. I am so sorry that this beautiful story did not get a nod from the Newbery committee.

This book made me sad-cry quite a few times, but more often I found myself happy-crying. This was one of the books I have ever read that made me want to stand up and clap once I had finished it. I felt like all the characters were real and I just wanted to hug them all.

LOVE LOVE LOVED this book. I am always wary of books meant for teens receiving such high ratings from adults but this one deserve every outstanding review it has received. I laughed, I cried, I became infuriated... and instantly knew that this was destined to become a favorite. I am thankful that kindness can prevail, I just wish it was more prevalent... and I vow to raise my kids so that they don't become the "Julien's" of the world. 
 I already had my 10 year old son start reading this and I hope it will spark some great discussion and have an impact on him as it did me. I am also toying with the idea of having my 8 year old read it... I think it would be great to again open those lines of dialogue. In all honesty, this book should be required reading for every child and adult...

4.5 stars 
 I really don't know how to describe this book. Beautiful, strong, endearing, heartfelt.. these words aren't powerful enough, in my opinion. 
 I teared up so much while reading Wonder. Especially since it's story told through several different points of views of August's year of fifth grade. I loved how honest every character was, including his big sister Via. You felt the love she had for her little brother, while you also felt the guilt she carried because of how she and the world thought of him. 
 The only thing I wasn't crazy about was the last quarter of the book. I felt the ending to be a bit sugar-coated. That's why I couldn't give a full 5 stars. However, it should've been expected on my end, because it is targeted for young readers. 
 I loved how this was the kind of book that shows how ugly the world can be, but yet it can also be amazing. I believe this a book that every age group needs to read. Everyone can take away something from reading this. 
 "Be kinder than necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed."

This book didn't have much going on for plot, but I was hooked from start to end. Wonder - aptly named - is a funny, heartbreaking, and touching tale that left me in awe. I kept getting teary-eyed throughout the whole book. It is packed with emotion and leaves a lot for thought. It is definitely a book for all ages so everyone should read it. I loved it and I would totally recommend it. 
 Don't just be kind. Choose to be kind.

I had heard amazing things about this book, and maybe went in with a little too high expectations. It is a heart-warming story, however I think that the characters would definitely be more relatable for younger readers. Overall I really liked it.

WOW! This book is a true wonder (pun intended). It lived up to it's hype and then some. I want to buy copies of this book for so many people that I'd go broke so I will have to keep prodding folks to buy it. Wonder is the story of August (Auggie) Pullman who was born with an extremely deformed face. His life has been full of people staring, people trying not to stare, whispers, and out-right screams. He has been homeschooled and sheltered until now, but the decision has been made that it's time for him to go to school. And so Auggie heads off to that hell known as middle school. 
 The book is told from multiple view points. The characters are very well developed and realistic. None of them, including Auggie, is all good or all bad - okay, maybe one jerk is all bad, but... I can't describe how much I love this book! READ IT! Now.

Loved this book. Told in parts by different characters (which is a technique I love), Wonder follows the life of Auggie, a boy born with a facial deformity. The reader follows his story of going back to school, meeting new friends, realizing public school isn't all it is cracked up to be, but in spite of it all, the underlying goodness of people peaks through. It broke my heart in spots, just because I'm a mom that hates the thought of a child hurting, but it also made me smile in parts, for the very same reason. 
 And in addition, I think the author's note on her inspiration for the story made me realize that you just never know how crossing paths with someone can change your life.
4.5-- near perfection!!
Fabulous! Says so much about human nature. I've added a few quotes from this book to my favorites.

More like 55 stars. This book should be mandatory reading for all middle school children. Or people. While the ending was a smidge hokey, this book - told from different children's perspectives about having August, a boy who has severe facial deformities, in their lives - was beautifully written, heartbreaking but also victorious.
beautiful beyond words.
Great book.

I love you Auggie. 
 "Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 "Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness."
Amazingly heart touching. An excellent book that I think every child should read. The ending gave me chills and left my heart feeling full and a huge smile on my face.
The different voices really added to this on the audiobook. The story itself is great, sensitively told. Recommended. :)
Haven't read this? Stop whatever you are doing, and read. Just have a box of tissues ready.

Wonder hit me in in all the right ways without beating me over the head to reach the "right" conclusions. This book encourages self examination and invites the reader to ponder what it really means to be a friend, accept others, and forgive. Sometimes friendship requires courage and sometimes it means giving a second chance. I normally do not care for books that switch points of views but this book did it masterfully and it added to the rich characters. As a mother I would have loved a chapter from Auggie's mom but I'm so glad there wasn't one because RJ Palcio knew her audience and stayed true to youth themes. My version of Wonder came with the Julian (the bully) chapter and I was so conflicted while reading it until his grandma's story and I then I bawled. It became very satisfying to see Julian's progression rather than leaving him a villian. The only chapter I did not enjoy was Justin's. Simply because there was no punctuation or capitals. It made me crazy! It was distracting and random.

I can't say enough good things about this book. It is more than just a good story; it is a tale that can, will and should change your perspective in a lasting way. And despite it being a middle grade book (and well written for that audience, I might add), it is still a book I could recommend to ANYone. Seriously, I can't think of a demographic that wouldn't get something out of this book. 
 Auggie's voice has a great blend of maturity from his lifelong experiences with physical and emotional challenges and childhood vulnerability from his tender age and his loving but sheltering family. Some of his insights can make you laugh and break your heart at the same time. Really well done. Later in the book, you hear from other people in Auggie's life, and each perspective is eye-opening. I especially loved his sister Via's portion of the book, but all of them clearly convey the fact that everyone is going through their own pain and challenges that are just as real as the ones you can see on Auggie's face. And that being "kinder than is necessary" is not just for the sake of the Auggies in the world, but to help all of us lift and be lifted.
I thought this was going to be an amazing book because of the ratings, but it was a disappointment. The plot was very boring and unoriginal.
I have never wanted to laugh and cry at the same time! Simply and beautifully written book that all people should read!

Una historia que trata de la vida real, de la amistad, de quererse a uno mismo. Que nos ensena muchas cosas. A pesar de tener un porte juvenil puede ser leido por todo el publico. Ambientando en una casa, una escuela, el parque... El ritmo de la historia es bastante rapido y la autora ha sabido poner la voz adecuada a cada personaje que ira narrando a historia. El libro no es nada predecible y aunque al final me quede con preguntas, pues queria saber como le iba a ir en unos cuantos anos a nuestro protagonista, me ha hecho llorar, reir, amar, odiar... Los personajes iran cambiando a lo largo de la historia. Finalmente decir que le hecho de que el protagonista no sea el tipico chico perfecto me ha encantado. 
 Resena completa: http://un-gran-mundo-imperfecto.blogs...

Wonder is a wonderful book! I wish I had it as a kid, and I am so glad that my kids can read it. I cringe inside when I remember how we - myself, my parents, my siblings, my friends, my neighbors, my teachers, my classmates, everyone I remember - or was it only me??? - reacted to other kids/people with disabilities. 
 Please, read this book. And give it to your kids to read.
The best book this year.

Absolutely wonderful! I loved the cultural references of these days. In a few years it will become a classic and a book to recall our current days. 
 Strong, powerful bonds within a family are the real strength of society. It renders beautiful people, beautiful souls. That's Auggie's family, you'll love them. 
 The only character I didn't like too much was Julian, I felt him like a cliche.
Fabulous book.
Great book, but 10-year olds dating? Really?
FIND MY FULL REVIEW HERE

Here is the first Newbery contender I've seen this year. August is deformed. He is sent to school for the first time with "regular" kids. This is the story of how that changes him, changes his family, and changes the kids at his new school. Really well written, you should check it out.
This book should be on every reading list at every school. Wonder could really impact young people when it comes to topics like bullying, being different and friendschip.

This book certainly is Onederfull. 
 Sorry. 
 "Wonder" tells the story of Auggie Pullman, a 10 year old boy who wants nothing more than to be seen as what he is - a normal, sweet kid. 
 But that's easier said than done. 
 Auggie was born with a rare medical facial deformity known as Treacher Collins syndrome. In public, people are known to double take when seem him, trying desperately to hide feelings of shock and disgust. Because of this, his social circle consists of his humorous parents, kindhearted-yet-guilt ridden sister Via and their dog. 
 Seeing as the dog has no reason to think of Auggie as "different" their relationship is very sweet. 
 But everything changes for Auggie when his parents decide to stop homeschooling him and send him to a local private school. A local private school filled with teachers. And other kids. Auggie doesn't know how to act around other people. Will he make friends? Will the other students be mean to him? 
 The book is told through multiple viewpoints: Auggie, Via and new classmates Summer, Jack, Justin and Miranda. Palacio does a great job differentiating their viewpoints as well as their voices, and it helps to create a more colorful picture of Auggie's world. Watching their opinions of Auggie evolve over the course of the book is sometimes frustrating, sometimes encouraging, but always believable. 
 You might go into this book expecting to feel like this: 
 And I'll be honest - there are those moments. But I walked away feeling this way: 
 Because at its core, "Wonder" is an uplifting story about learning to judge people on their hearts and not their bodies. 
 Or as it says in the book: "Be kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 kit: Twitter | Tumblr

This is one of those books that's very accomplished & that I'd describe as appreciating more than enjoying. I liked the different perspectives but it took surprisingly long to get there. Very sweet at points, repetitive at others, and ultimately a bit too saccharine and twee for my taste. As a middle grade novel, though, it's certainly well executed and worthy of the praise it has received.
This book is so adorable. I loved every single point of view, especially Olivia's.

One of the best books I've read in some time, this story follows August (Auggie) Pullman during his fifth grade year. For most kids, fifth grade is mildly painful--but for Auggie, fifth grade means going to school for the first time ever and dealing with the ramifications of his cranio-facial deformities. Palacio tells the story through a number of different voices--Auggie's, his sister, his sister's boyfriend, and some kids he befriends along the way. The book has been called a "meditation on kindness" and besides being beautifully written, the story makes a powerful case for the virtue of kindness.
Very good read. I wish this book would have been written when I was a kid.
Absolutely a must read for every parent and child - to be read and shared and discussed. Yes, kindeness matters. Outstanding read!

For a long time, Wonder by RJ Palacio has been sitting on my kindle unread. Well, a week ago, I decided to move it to the front page of my kindle and to read the book I'd heard so many incredible things about. 
 Palacio's debut novel not only lived up to the hype, but it lived up to its name. Wonder is a wonderful book that everyone should read, from children to teenagers to adults. 
 It's also an important book with an important message: always be kind. And sometimes be kinder than necessary.

Okay... I debated between 3 or 4 stars for quite awhile. The book is narrated by several different characters, but it didn't feel like different view points. Just felt like the same person talking throughout the entire book. The ending was also just a little too sugary sweet. I was glad for a happy ending, but it was perhaps a tad too much 
 That being said, this was a sweet and charming story. It was a quick read and I enjoyed it. 3.5 stars if I could. Bumped it up to 4 because it was a good story.
It touches the heart and teaches all that reads it a very powerful lesson of love and life from the eyes of the boy =)

This book was not only fabulous but one of a kind. I'm still too emotional to write a review. 
 It's really one the best books I have ever read.

heart warming story, quick read. i liked hearing things from each of the characters point of view. it's a little unbelievable at times - for 5th graders to be this in touch with feelings - but overall it's so compelling a read, i got past that.

This title is a hot pick for Newbery contention in January. I see why. 
 August "Auggie" Pullman has been homeschooled all of his short life due to a severe genetic facial deformity. His parents have (mostly) decided that it is time for Auggie to try out a real school. Of course Auggis is nervous about the idea but after having a tour of the buildings and meeting some of his potential classmates and principal, he feels like he just might be able to handle this school thing. 
 It's definitely a hard transition. It is for any school-age child. But it's especially difficult when everyone stares at you because you face looks like nothing they've ever seen before outside of a science-fiction movie. Auggie plugs along with the help of a few close friends he gathers at different points during the story. But he also has to deal with things like a mother who photo-shops him out of the class picture and offers a copy to any parent who would like one. This same parent ask the school board to consider whether Auggie should even be allowed in their prep school because the school is not an "inclusion" school. This same parents' child is especially cruel to Auggie in school. 
 Auggie bravely gets through his 5th grade year and decides to continue to 6th.
Read this book aloud to my fifth graders. We all loved it and loved the discussions it provoked. Very memorable ...very powerful message.

""wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary--the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 People should read this book at least once in their life!

This book is for sure a book that everyone should read no matter what age you are. I laughed at Auggie's humor and cried as if I could feel every feeling he was throughout the book. I am glad that a friend suggested having tissue handy. I'm sure this will be a book I reread in the near future!

It's only January, but I can already say this will be one of my top ten reads in 2013. This is a great book and a must read for 5-8th graders. 
 August is heading off to school for the first time. He's entering middle school after years of home schooling. As if middle school weren't difficult enough, August has a severe facial deformity. His year is documented by August, his sister Via, and fellow students in a carefully crafted novel that shows the honest and painful life of a child who is different. Surprisingly enough, kindness reigns in Wonder. You'll be cheering for August throughout.

There is just no way for me not to like this book. It's bittersweet -- sweet most of the time -- and beautifully expressed. The change of perspectives sometimes throw continuity off for me but the ending was rewarding and touching. Its characters are very believable and its portrait of middle school seems realistic enough to add vividness to a encouraging tale. It's highly recommended for all ages: Very accessible language, very touching and engaging story.

"Wonder" is putting it mildly -- this book was beyond wonder and wonderful. Simply terrific. A must-read for ALL ages. At the very least, I hope it is on the reading list of every middle school student.

This book makes me want to be a better person. I really wish everyone could read this and learn from Auggie and his experiences. Throughout the book, I just wanted to give all the characters a big hug (especially Auggie) and never let go. 
 And another thing; This is how you write children and teenagers! Many authors don't get young children's/teenagers voices right (*cough*Fault in our Stars*cough*). I never for minute disbelieved any of the characters or what they said. They all felt real to me
What a sweet book :)
"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." - Auggie
A truly feel-good book! It made me think about how I can bring more kindness into the world around me. I laughed, cried, and cheered my way through.
This should be required, make that mandatory, reading for all middle school kids. I loved, loved, loved this book!!
When you turn the last page you will be completely satisfied. You will love the main character and appreciate the author. Fantastic job for a first novel.
Wonder is a piece of art. It'll touch your heart and you just know, it'll stay with you for a long time. A must read for everyone!
perfectly imperfect characters that are too precious for this world
More required reading for my kids. If you can't learn any empathy from this book there is no hope for you.
Everyone should read this one. Beautiful from start to finish.

Diversity 
 RJ Palacio has written a book that is designated as a young person's book, ages 8 and up. And while the story of a child born with facial anomalies requiring repeated surgeries and still leaving him 'different looking' (read 'deformed') is told in brief chapters and solid writing that youngsters can surely appreciate, the message of the book is equally appropriate for adults. Diversity. Whether that be in physical configuration either from genetic determination or from intrauterine alterations for whatever reason, or from color of hair or skin (think albino), or from result of accidents (think broken inappropriately healed limbs or sever burns) or from language or form cerebral dysfunction - all elements that offer a unique individual unlike peers has an accompanying adjustment from the individual afflicted, the parents and siblings, from friends, from the atmosphere of the schoolyard, and from society in general. WONDER explores all of these in an easy to read, fascinating manner that warmly and fully explores the life of a child how is , as the title suggests, a wonder. 
 One aspect of Palacio's writing that sets this book apart from other that deal with similar subject matter is the brevity of chapters, than manner in which the author places the narrative voice for every person the main character encounters in the first person so that we come to understand even the borderline approach/avoidance conflict of coming into the presence of a deformed child. In addition, each person of importance in the main character's (August or Auggie) life is assigned a section that allows us to appreciate not only the psychology of change that accepting a different appearing child's effect on those around him but also provides insight into the 'problem' being dissected by this book - how we individually cope with diversity. 
 Plot summary: 'August Pullman is a 10-year-old boy who likes Star Wars and X-box, ordinary except for his jarring facial anomalies. Homeschooled all his life, August heads to public school for fifth grade and he is not the only one changed by the experience--something we learn about first-hand through the narratives of those who orbit his world. August's internal dialogue and interactions with students and family ring true, and though remarkably courageous he comes across as a sweet, funny boy who wants the same things others want: friendship, understanding, and the freedom to be himself. "It is only with one's heart that one can see clearly. What is essential is invisible to the eye." 
 An example of one of the characters Auggie meets - Jack, a fellow student asked by the school's principal to aid Auggie's move from protective homeschooling to his final entrance into public school, speaks in the section titled JACK: 'First of all, you do get used to his face. The first couple of times I was like, whoa, I'm never going to get used to this. And then, about after a week, I was like, huh, it's not so bad. Second of all, he's actually a really cool dude. I mean, he's pretty funny etc.....Third of all he's really smart etc...Fourthly, now that I know him, I would say I actually do want to be friends with August....He laughs at my jokes. And I kind of feel like I can tell August anything. Like, he's a good friend. Like, if all the guys in the fifth grade were lined up against a wall and I got to choose anyone I wanted to hang out with, i would choose August.' 
 And that about sums up why this book is bound to be successful if it can only find the readers it needs. I think it will. Talk about it. 
 Grady Harp

Oh. My. Goodness. 
 I feel like Wonder was one of those books that you don't want to end. That you just want to fall into the world of and become best friends with truly amazing and inspiring characters. 
 I felt like wanting to just give Auggie a hug SO many times when reading this book, and I wanted to keep reading about his adventure of life after Wonder had ended. 
 August may be different, but he is original. He is amazing. He is a Wonder.
What can I say that hasn't already been said. It is brilliant!
You are a wonder.

Most times, the person who you find it hardest to love is the one that needs it the most. 
 Wonder defines the true meaning of Courage, Kindness, Friendship, and Character. It shows that kindness is indeed a language which the deaf can hear and the blind can see.
A very well-written book that had a lot of positive "lessons".

My daughter just finished this book for 6th grade. She asked me to read it. Wow every 5th-7th grader should read this book. I was heartbroken. Amazing story of how children with disabilities deal with children and adults. Not only does this open your eyes to how Auggie deals with a new school, but also his friends and family. Must read. Choose Kind!

This book follows a ten year old boy name August, he had been home-schooled until the fifth grade. Sounds pretty normal, right? Well, August has a facial anomaly that sets him apart from everyone. This book rotates perspectives between August, his sixteen year old sister and several of his peers. 
 The main theme is kindness. Always kindness. 
 I loved this book because if you didn't necessarily relate to August. You are bound to with one of the other perspectives. Everyone in this book changed dramatically and it all had something to do with August. 
 While reading the book it kept reminding me of the "Prayer for Owen Meany." or "Simon Birch" which is the film loosely based on the story. So if you enjoyed those stories I definitely recommend this story.
Sunny and bright. A relatively simple book about friendship and kindness. Perfect for middle school.
Auggie is truly a wonder.
I loved this book. The characters are beautifully crafted and the story is uplifting from beginning to end.
This will probably be my favorite kids' book of the year. My students and fellow teachers love it.

NPR: "'Wonder' What It's Like to Have Kids Stare At You?" - March 22, 2012 
 http://www.npr.org/2012/03/22/1490826...

Excellent book for middle-school readers about a 5th-grader with a craniofacial deformity who learns to make his way in school after years of homeschooling. Told from multiple points of view, the story follows Auggie as he and his family navigate middle-school social pressures on top of very visible medical issues.
Stunning! A must read for parents and teachers, this beautiful book also works well as a read aloud for upper elementary and middle school students. It generates great conversations!

August (Auggie) is a pretty normal kid except that he was born with a facial deformity. The book follows Auggie's first experience attending school, he will be in the 5th grade; in the past he was homeschooled. The highs and lows of Auggie's school year are told through multiple viewpoints and with honesty. I really appreciated the artistic choice to have Auggie refuse to describe his physical appearance to the reader and I felt that the way in which his sister, Via, described him was honest and careful. I was a little uncertain about the portion of the story told through Via's boyfriend's eyes, but it mostly worked because it gave the reader another strong focus on Via. Secondary characters had interesting stories and points of view as well as important turning points in their respective journeys. Auggie's close family relationships was a source of joy throughout the book; all families should endeavor to be like the Pullmans. 
 An important look at the world from a different pair of shoes. Recommended for grades 5-8.
Such a good read. Laughed and cried.

This is a book filled with compassion. It tells the story of ten-year-old 
 Auggie who has been homeschooled his entire life and will now begin 5th grade in a traditional school. While other kids are dealing with "fitting in" as "normal" kids, Auggie has greater challenges. He must deal with fitting in as a child with a severe deformity that causes others to stare at him, look away quickly or be afraid of him. This is a story about parenting, letting children find their own way, bullying, friendship, heartache, bravery and a whole lot more. Each chapter is written from a different character's perspective in first person narrative. This allows us to see that what people really feel is not always what they exhibit to others; people can change and grow; we all have the power to influence each other. I highly recommend this book for all ages. It is an instant favorite for me that I think I will read again and again (which I don't do with many books.) I hope this becomes a classic for the lessons it teaches are timeless.

I don't even know how to start in telling you how much I loved & appreciated this book! Seriously. So please just believe the 5-star rating and do yourself a favor: pick this book up and JUST READ IT! 
 PS: I'm just very excited to watch the movie!
I'm late to this party but this was really a good book. Well written; the narrative is plain and to the point. Enjoyed it way more then I expected to.
Pop Sugar's 2017 Reading Challenge - A book you've read before that never fails to make you smile

This a very sweet and inspiring story meant for a younger audience. It was well written besides some editing mistakes, such as when the point of view changed to a new character, some events happened out of sequence. I also wasn't crazy about the some of the dialogue, such as the use of "I know, right?" I would highly recommend this book to 10-15 year old readers. Although I thoroughly enjoyed it, and finished it one day.

After I read this book, I realized that I have nothing to lose if I'll be a little bit more kind to other people in my words and in action :) So what if they are rude, mean, bully (or any words we can think of)? Someday there will be a cosmic shift and the universe will favor your side. Well, if you're kind. Choose kind. a~o 
 And... I am also encouraged to write my own precepts and pass it to people needing it. What is a precept? Read this book too!

Don't miss this one. 
 Halloween is Auggie's favorite holiday, because he can wear a mask. August Pullman, or Auggie to his family and friends, is an ordinary kid in most ways. He was born with facial deformities, and despite countless surgeries, he still looks different on the outside. On the inside, where few people are allowed, he is funny and smart and so so brave. Auggie embarks on a journey much more scary than any surgery - the 5th grade. 
 You will be hard-pressed to find any character as courageous as Auggie in children's literature this year. RJ Palacio gifts her readers with a fast-paced, heart-wrenching, honest look at a great family who was dealt a great challenge. 
 Told from different points of view, the reader not only gets to see inside Auggie's mind, but that of his sister, his friends, and even someone who sees his situation from afar. The role of the sister really got to me (those of you who know me understand why this is so) and I applaud RJ Palacio for giving her such an honest voice. 
 One of the most powerful parts of the book was not how loudly the other kids made fun of Auggie, it was how QUIET they were. It sucks to be called names, but it's even worse to be ignored. The kids at school had a secret game called The Plague, which was compared to the Cheese Touch. No one could touch Auggie without getting The Plague. The thing is, all the kids thought he didn't know...how could he not? This is bullying that no one sees coming. It's hard to identify, and even harder to stop, but it hurts the worst. 
 WONDER has stuck with me since I read it, and there are so many scenes I could point to and gush all over, but I don't want to give anything away. (The Precepts!!!) Do yourself a favor - read the book, give it to a middle grader to read, and then talk about it.

This book was recommended by my 10 year old. His fourth grade teacher read it aloud to him and he loved it. I totally agree with him. It is definitely a terrific read aloud book. The best lesson anyone at any age can take from this book is Kindness. "Shall we make new rule of life...always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" What a better world we would live in if we all tried to achieve this. I recommend this book to any age. We all need work on our kindness and excepting people who are different than us.

I loved this story of love and acceptance of a boy born with a facial deformity. It was well written and made me laugh out loud at times as well a made me cry. I loved the little quotes and precepts that give meaning to life. My favorites were: 
 "Your deeds are your monuments" 
 "If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 "Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness." 
 "WHEN GIVEN THE CHOICE BETWEEN BEING 
 RIGHT OR BEING KIND, CHOOSE KIND." 
 Charlotte's precept: It's not enough to be friendly. You have to be a good friend. --

I'm at a loss for words. Wonder is one of those stories that will make its mark on your bookshelf, and will change the way you look at the world, at the people around you and most importantly at yourself. 
 Through August's interaction with his family, classmates and enemies, I've come to question whether I am a good enough person. Its a reminder we all need once in a while, because we all forget the impact we have. 
 In Benjamin Cook's recent upload of Becoming YouTube (Videos #5 & 6), he so eloquently describes: "we all have the capacity to be dicks and we all have the capacity to be awesome, and we spend most of our time treading the line between the two, clumsily, occasionally falling ass over tit on to one side or the other, then crawling our way back". 
 So thanks to a couple of YouTube videos, and this wonderful wonder of a book, I've learnt a great lesson this weekend. 
 #choosekind
I LOVED this book! Amazing! So heartfelt and inspiring!

Loved this book! But I loved the premise of this book better because I was just hoping I could recommend this to my girls, BUT it's written a little on the young side so I was just a little disappointed, but otherwise LOVED it!

Extraordinario conta a historia do August Pullman (Auggie), um garoto que nasceu com uma deformidade genetica facial e que tem que frequentar pela primeira vez a escola e junto com ela todos os preconceitos que existem entre os jovens. Auggie tera a missao de mostrar seu eu, acima de sua aparencia e de convencer a todos que ele e um garoto normal. 
 O livro e narrado sob diferentes pontos de vista (do Auggie, de sua irma, de sua melhor amiga, etc) e isso da uma visao geral da historia, o que a torna mais interessante. A narrativa da R.J. e deliciosa, e impossivel largar o livro antes do final, que e espetacular. A autora soube mostrar com maestria como uma determinada situacao afeta as pessoas que estao relacionadas a ela. Da para se emocionar em varios momentos. Livro cinco estrelas e favorito, indico para todos os que querem ler um livro sobre superacao e que gostem de livros narrados sob a otica de criancas.

4.5 stars 
 everyone should be made to read this and the world might be a nicer, kinder place

Beautiful eye-catching cover (pardon the pun). Never underestimate the power of a good cover for a children's (or any, really) book. 
 What an amazing feat for a first time novelist. I'm jealous, R. J. Palacio! 
 I want to read this book with a small group of students and read it together in a book club setting. I'd be so curious to their thoughts and the beautiful conversations that could come of it.
Amazing, wonderful, and every other superlative you can think of. Loved this book!

This book appeared in the Little Free Library which we recently installed in front of our house. Xy said she'd heard of it, that it was a really good book, plus a movie adaptation is coming out this fall. So I read it aloud to my daughter (9) as a bedtime story which occupied us for the next month. I expected there to be some fantastic or science-fictional element because a movie ad shows a kid in a space helmet. Turns out it's entirely realistic. It's also entirely delightful and engaging. We really like how the story is developed through multiple points of view. However, I am puzzled how they make this into a movie that honors the opening conceit: "I won't describe what I look like." That element of mystery will be missing from the film, I suppose. It's a visual medium after all. Later, I learned that 500 copies of this book were distributed through Little Free Libraries to promote the film. Well, it worked. We got lucky, and we're glad, and as soon as we finished we passed the book on.

I didn't know that this would have multiple POVs. So, reading the first chapter (the first POV chapter of Auggie), where everything is what you would expect from a story centered around a boy who has deformed face because of some blahblah genetics, I said to myself, Well, nothing new here., and yawned. 
 I didn't like the POV of Auggie. It just seems unreal to me. It even bored me a couple of times. Like I said, it's the kind of story you'd expect. 
 And then Via's POV came. And I was like, "Oh God yes yes let's hear it!" It satisfied me. Really. The multiple POVs worked for me. We get to understand why the characters do what they do and how they try to let us know their points and situations and reasons they do such weird and unexpected things. And you will really feel their regrets. 
 You will feel the jealousy of Via how great she is trying to understand the situation of her family. How great she is for a sister. 
 You will understand how really nice Summer is. 
 You will understand how Jack doesn't really mean the bad things he says about Auggie. 
 You will understand why Merinda and Via's friendship starts to fade away. 
 I liked the multiple POVs. 
 In short, I liked the book if it isn't told by Auggie. I do not fancy the sun, I fancy how the planets and asteroids and everything revolve around it. I cannot have interests to a thing that moves and acts the way we expect. 
 I didn't like the too much feel-good vibe of the book. And if I raise the ratings of the books with philosophies I agreed to, I will lower the ratings of the books with philosophies I don't agree to. Is this kind of thinking bad? I just don't believe what the book says about how every one of us is special as long as we'll surpass our limits with kindness blahblahblah... just no. Some of us are special, some of us are not. I guess we need to deal with it. And addition to that, I cannot accept that everybody but the real main villain get so super nice to Auggie. They get so kind and everything... 
 So to sum it up, I liked the book. I liked the POVs other than Auggie. I don't like the overly unreal euphoric vibe of the book.

3 and a half stars. So sweet! It was a lovely read with satisfying characters and character development. No huge surprises in what happens, but it really didn't need any. I'm glad it's getting the positive attention that it is. I also really enjoyed the exploration of parallel themes to the ones in my book, The Ugly One, albeit in a much more modern setting!
