I set out to read "Wonder" because it was listed as a supplemental text for a middle school English curriculum and couldn't put it down. I laughed and sobbed, and firmly believe this should be a staple in every middle school classroom. From lessons on self-acceptance to bullying, R. J. Palacio truly has brought his characters to life.
A fantastic surprise -- I loved this quick read, which helped me to remember the true inner kindness in kids (even in middle school!)
"You really are a wonder auggie, you are a wonder".

I remember posting this on my IG and just like how this quote catches my attention, the blurb of this book did the same thing. This is such a nice read. The message of the story was so powerful, it lifts your soul to do good and be good. 
 Excerpt from the book 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." 
 > I guess this is true.. sometimes being right or knowing you're right won't make you a good person. Still depends on how you deliver it, right?

Auggie Pullman, main character of Wonder by RJ Palacio has been home schooled his entire life because of a severe facial deformity. This year all that is about to change as Auggie will go to a real school for the first time- and begin fifth grade at Beecher Prep. Wonder details Auggie's first year attending school -with it's ups and downs. Palacio masterfully conveys themes of family, friendship, and bullying in her debut middle grade novel. 
 Read the rest of my review here

So, while this book didn't actually make me cry, it got pretty close a few times. What's really embarrassing is that both moments involved Star Wars references. 
 This book, while a bit predictable, is so human and honest and downright daring, that I can't recommend it highly enough. The postmodern chorus of voices works perfectly, especially with one individual whose unique voice is depicted by playing with the text itself, something one would expect to see in a Faulkner novel and not a novel targeted at middle school readers. 
 That brings me to my next point of praise. This book never patronizes its readers. It's certainly targeted at pre-teens and specifically works to appeal to them, but it never shies away from those dark thoughts and unsettling truths that young people experience long before such things are often explained fully to them by adults. I really respect Palacio for tackling these issues head on. 
 I adore all of the characters. They're rendered with a minimalist elegance that makes them come to life without the author having to give a lot of complex back story or contrived dialogue. Really beautifully done. 
 My one criticism is that there is a moment that seems designed to be really emotional just for the sake of being emotional. It's well placed in the book, but it just seemed a bit cheap. It didn't affect my enjoyment of the novel as a whole, but it was the one moment that I saw the author's brushstrokes. Younger readers may not mind, appreciating the catharsis following so much internalized emotion. 
 Overall, I loved this. This would be a good introduction for young readers who ordinarily prefer science fiction or fantasy books to literary fiction. But seriously, everyone should read this just so that they can appreciate Palacio's deft blend of goofy and sophisticated humor and pathos, and get to know her wonderful characters.

As a teacher I really enjoyed this book. I think that it would be a great book for students of all ages to read. I found that some of the characters were a little unrealistic in how fast they accepted Auggie, but I feel that is a characteristic that we should strive to nurture in our students. Also, in my graduate class we were imagining how the story would be different if Auggie was of a different ethnic background or if he had multiple disabilities. Overall, excellent read and I would recommend it to my teacher friends and students.

"La unica razon por la que no soy normal, es que nadie me ve asi, pero bueno no me quejo. Uno no puede ser uno mas de el monton cuando a nacido para destacar" 
 Es asombroso, es facil quedarte atrapado en la historia !ES PERFECTO! la manera en la que tu vida cambia, tu punto de vista cambia despues de leer un libro, como pocos, La eleccion de August me dio el claro ejemplo de eso. Quisiera ser como August, es completamente optimista como nadie, a pesar de las condiciones fisicas que el tiene. !Por el Angel! ame cada parte de este libro. 
 Te ensena mucho, el mensaje es muy bonito. 
 #EligeSerAmable.

Children and parents alike will love reading the story. It entertains while showing how to be heroic and corageous in your everyday life. 
 This is the best anti-bullying book I've ever read.

August is a funny and smart fifth grade boy who loves Star Wars and his dog. He has has been homeschooled his whole life and his parents have decided that it is time for him to attend school. August also has craniofacial abnormalities that makes this transition more complicated for both August and his classmates who are not quite sure what to think about him. 
 The story is told from different viewpoints including August, his sister and friends from school. The author does an outstanding job of making characters that are real to me. Often in novels, fifth graders talk like high schoolers and high school kids talk like they are in a sitcom, but the words and thoughts from these kids felt real. Some kids are mean - really mean, but most of them aren't. 
 This book is touching and funny and a little sad, but it is never maudlin or depressing. If we can tear elementary kids away from Dork Diaries and Wimpy Kid books long enough to have a look at this, I think they would really enjoy this story.
Great book for teens or adults! August will make you laugh and cry and appreciate the humanity in all of us.

Wonder is the story of Auggie, a boy with severe facial deformities who starts school for the first time in 5th grade after being home schooled his whole life. Aside from his face, which Auggie describes as: "whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse," Auggie is a normal 10-year-old boy. He loves Star Wars, wants to make friends, and cares what people think of him. Wonder is the story of how his new 5th grade classmates -- and we readers right along with them -- learn to see beyond Auggie's extreme looks into the sweet, clever, funny soul that lies beneath. 
 Wonder is what I would call an "empathy builder" book. It exposes readers to a world we have never before considered, in a manner that makes us care. Like Out of My Mind, about cerebral palsy, and Rules, about autism, Wonder gently slides us into the shoes of a boy whose face scares small children, and asks us to walk a mile. It would be easy, as a Book Reviewer, to get snarky and dismiss this as just another tear-jerker about differences and bullying. But I won't do that, and I will tell you why. 
 First of all, Wonder is skillfully rendered. I was taken in by Auggie's story, by the challenges faced by not only Auggie himself, but his sister and his friends. I stayed up late to finish this book, and relished its happy ending, even if it is clear that, happy 5th-grade ending or not, Auggie's life will never be easy. 
 More importantly I believe there is a critical place for these books in the lives of young readers. Kids have a pretty brief window to learn empathy between the time when they are too young to understand difference and the time when they lose the ability to see beyond their own adolescent challenges (read: acne, dating, risky behavior, etc.). I would put this time period loosely between 4th and 9th grade. If we want our children to grow into kind and ethical adults, it is ESSENTIAL that they are exposed to ideas about difference, prejudice, and the impacts of human cruelty during this critical period. Call it character education if you like. 
 This alone is the most important reason to read fiction. It takes us to places, and introduces us to people, that we might not run across in your typical middle school, but that have important lessons to teach. People like Auggie. 
 During this brief character-building period, kids may find that one book can change their life. This book needs to come at the right time, and needs to feel fresh and timely. That is why books like Wonder: well-written, compelling books about a kid you can't help caring about, who just happens to look like no one you have ever met, should keep being published, read, and awarded prizes. These books do important work. 
 More reviews at: www.jennysbookreview.com
Heart warming and excellent writing! Quick read :)
Truly beautiful. A story that reminds us that even though people can be mean, there is also so much (even more, and also much unexpected) kindness in mankind.

Review : http://bit.ly/wonbrjp 
 Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcome the world...

Wonder is the story of Auggie, a boy who was born with severe cranial-facial abnormalities. His mother decides to send him to a mainstream school for fifth grade after having homeschooled him up to that point. His father worries that he'll be "eaten alive." The principal of the school assigns three of the "good kids" to show him around and basically be his friends. But that task is more than some of them can handle. However, he finds true friendship with a girl named Summer, who is kind to him without having to be asked. 
 Wonder is told mainly from Auggie's point of view but also includes the points of views of other people in his life, like his older sister and some of the kids at his school. It's interesting to see that different people have different perspectives on the same situations and events. I think that's a good lesson that you never know what is going on behind the scenes in people's lives and that you should try and find out before you judge them. And even if you don't find out, give them the benefit of the doubt and treat them with kindness. 
 My boys, who are ten and twelve years old, and I each read this book on our own and then went out lunch to discuss it, - a little mother and son book club. I was surprised at how in-depth our discussion was. This book touched them and made them think. Even though it's a middle-grade book, I think it would also be a good selection for a teen or even adult book club. 
 A movie based on Wonder is coming out in November. Jacob Tremblay, the child actor who was so great in Room, plays Auggie. My boys and I are looking forward to having a mother and son date to see it. 
 Wonder has wonderful lessons to teach and I recommend it for kids and adults alike.

Review by Karen, intended for young readers: 
 Okay, I'm just going to say it: Wonder by R.J. Palacio -- it's wonderful. 
 Couldn't be helped. Had to say it. And not just because it's a super cheesy thing to say and I'm a super cheesy person; I had to say it because it's true! 
 Wonder is about Auggie, who has been home schooled all his life because of his deformed face and all the medical procedures he's had to undergo. But now Auggie is headed to regular school for the first time -- and that would be nerve-wracking enough for a regular kid; for Auggie, it equals total upheaval of his life. 
 But that description doesn't do justice to the book and how totally, totally awesome it is. Because when you read Wonder, you won't think of Auggie as an interesting character with an interesting story; you'll think of him as a real kid, just like one of your friends, or even kind of like you. 
 To find out what happens when Auggie gets to school, and to hear more from him, his sister, and the other kids at his school... obviously, you should read the book! 
 This review also appears on Kidsmomo.com.
I think this is a wonderful book that middle school age children would definitely relate to. It was a quick ways read that I enjoyed.

Great voice in Auggie - Authentic, not sentimental. Severe disfigurement is not a common occurrence in most teachers' classrooms, but we all have students with lesser degrees of disabilities and afflictions. Auggie is honed in to every nuanced reaction to his face. His parents are cautious, but not overly smothering. His classmates are normal in their reactions, mostly following their own upbringing and personality traits in their actions. Loved the ending, as it was satisfying while not being maudlin enough to grab the tissues.
Great feel good story. Teachers this is a great read aloud discussion starter. The main character is pretty young I recommend for grades 4-7.

I would give this book 10 stars if I could. Palacio weaves a heart-wrenching story about Auggie a strong, brave little boy, his older sister, his parents, and his classmates. She tells the story from multiple points of view, which works well to help young readers understand the motives of characters. It also helps readers feel for these characters as they are faced with confusing and testing situations. I was brought to tears and can't wait to share this with my fifth graders. I think that anyone who reads this book will be a more empathetic person after reading it!

Really great book, a must read!! So sad to see how August was treated and all the ups and downs but the message was good no matter what you look like you should be treated with respect!! What a great read loved it!! Only downside weird sentence structure, small chapters and some of the grammar was off when Justin was introduced other than that a great book!
Amazing book! A must read for any YA fans.

Audience: Intermediate 
 Genre: realistic fiction 
 Discussion Questions 
 Remembering: What major event is August going through at the beginning of the novel? 
 Understanding: How and why is Auggie different from other kids his age? How does he handle these differences? Explain. 
 Applying: Think about your own experiences at school. Describe a time when you felt different from everyone else; or, a time when you wished you could be invisible (or both). 
 Analyzing: A static character is one who stays the same throughout the entire story. A dynamic character is one who changes as the story progresses. With these two definitions in mind, try to classify each of the major characters in the novel as static or dynamic. Be sure to give at least one example from the text to support your classification. 
 Evaluating: Is Wonder a good title for this book? Support your opinion with specific reasons or details from the novel. 
 Creating: Imagine the author has asked you to add one new character to the current "cast" of the novel. Name your character, and explain what their special job will be in the story. Make sure they fit in as seamlessly as possible with the other characters (i.e. no evil space robots trying to take over the world... unless you can really sell it).
Fantastic book!
Loved this book! I think every middle school student should read this.
Wonder by R.J. Palacio is a wonder in its own right--A poignant, sweet, inspiring read that will lift your soul and touch your heart.
All I can say is that if you can read this book without tearing up, you are a stronger (and maybe colder) person than I.

Gloriously un-cynical kids fiction, full of references to Star Wars that I didn't understand. Wonder is about a boy with a facial deformity, starting out in his voice but expanding into the perspective of other characters. This has a Beverly Cleary feel to it, in its dealing with the everyday problems of being in 5th grade.

This was one of the most inspiring books that I have ever read. 
 If you haven't read this book yet, I encourage you to pick it up as soon as possible. It will inspire you and encourage you to be a better person and more aware of other people's feelings. 
 August Pullman is a normal kid, smart, friendly, and funny, but the thing that sets him apart from other kids is what is on the outside. 
 He has many different genetic problems that make him look monstrous. Horrific. Not human. And everyone at school acts like he has the plague- they flinch if he touches them and can't even bear to make eye contact with him. Even though it is not his fault that he was born that way, he pays for it every day. 
 How often do we judge people from how they look? How often do we turn away our eyes because we can't bear to look, or how often do we make fun of others because of disabilities or deformities that they have? 
 I have experienced these feelings firsthand in my life. Although it does not affect how smart I am or how I think or anything like that, but it does affect many physical aspects of my life. 
 Even though some people may not mean to stare or be rude, that doesn't mean that I am oblivious to the stares when I turn my back, or the whispers as I walk through the hall. Whenever I run, I always feel stares on me, or even just walking down the halls. {I don't walk like other people do, and the difference is pretty obvious.} 
 Now that I'm older, people have gotten kinder and more sympathetic, but back in elementary school, I got bullied a lot. In first and sixth grade, it was especially easy to bully me because I had surgeries that required me to be in a wheelchair. I'm not saying that everyone was mean- most people were really nice. However, there were a few people who thought it was funny to whisper mean things to me when the teacher was looking away. 
 I'm here to tell you that all the people I've met with physical disabilities have been the sweetest and friendliest people that I've ever met. Don't judge people because of what you see on the outside- they can't change it and it hurts their feelings when you bully them. 
 I'd rather be seen as a girl with cerebral palsy that everyone can count on to be a good friend than a bully with nothing wrong with her. 
 Be kinder than is necessary.
Amazing! Every family should buy this book and read it together.

I loved this book so, so much. 
 This book offered me a new perspective on the world, and for that I will always be grateful.

Auggie Pullman is going to school for the first time...as a fifth grader. Auggie has been home schooled his entire life because he was born with a face that is different. Auggie's parents feel it's time for him to try public school and they send him to Beecher Prep. Auggie's year has it's ups and down, he encounters some wonderful teachers, some kind students, and some students who try to make his life difficult. But Auggie has an inner strength and a loving family that help make the transition and the school year a positive one. 
 My favorite quote from the book is... "Shall we make a new rule of life...always try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" -- J. M. Barrie from the book The Little White Bird. Kindness often seems like a little thing, but in Wonder, you see what a really big thing it is, and the difference it can make in our lives. 
 Wonder is one of those books that makes me absolutely LOVE reading and books and sharing them with others. This book is truly a wonder and it will make you think about how you treat everyone you encounter. It's a book about courage, strength, love and kindness. The ending is a definite RWK (Read With Kleenex), but in the best possible way. I wish this book were required reading for middle school students, but it's something we can all learn from it.

Jeez-louise! How could I not give this book 5 stars as I'm blowing my nose and wiping away my tears! 
 I've had this book sitting on my shelf for at least 2 years - what a shame I waited so long to read it. 
 These characters will really touch your heart. What a "wonder"ful read. <-- see what I did there? ;)

Wonder was a pleasant read. Nice and simple without too much to challenge you. 
 Auggie is likeable, so is Via, his mum, his dad, his headteacher Mr Tushman ... everyone is lovely and sweet and kind. 
 Except for Julian. He's bad, just because he's the baddie. No reason other than that. 
 Personally I would of liked there to have been more depth to the characters. 
 For a moment I thought I was going to get it from Auggie's big sister Via when the narrative moved to her POV. I wondered if we'd get more resentment from her (for Auggie taking time away from her parents). More temper tantrums. Maybe they could've fallen out and then resolved their differences at the end. 
 I would've liked to have had Julian's point of view. Why did he act so mean to Auggie? What motivated him to act so cruely? What hardships did he have to go through that made him so bitter towards a young boy with a facial disfigurement? 
 Or perhaps the story could've even been turned on it's head and Auggie could've been made to look bad from Julian's point of view. Maybe unknown to Auggie he did something that upset Julian in kindergarten. 
 Basically the whole story was played safely. 
 Which is either good or bad depending on what you want out of a novel. From the reviews I'd read I was expecting more. Maybe that's unfair for me to say. 
 The best way I can summarise this book, so that you know what you're getting, is to say: 
 Wonder is a nice gentle read with a happy ending.

I am always looking for new books to tempt my students, and because I have some voracious readers, I have to keep well ahead of them. I've started trolling for books that may make it on to the Newberry 2013 list and I read a whole lot of speculation about Wonder. I just finished it the other day. 
 Oh, this book. I just love it. Auggie is a boy who has some pretty severe facial deformities and starts fifth grade in a prestigious prep school after being homeschooled to deal with the multitude of corrective surgeries in the early stages of his life. 
 This is Auggie's story of his transition to middle school, an ugly place at the best of times, and how he struggles, and perseveres. Auggie's story is told from his perspective, as well as the perspectives of his sister and classmates. 
 Love. There were tears, of course, but they were worth it. Read this. Have your kids read it.

I could understand why this is such a bestseller to my 5th grade students because of all the connections they can make from their own 5th grade lives. It is a school setting and the subject is one of their favourites even if they don't want to admit it: Being different. What to do? How to behave? How to deal? This is the time in their lives that they, themselves and other people are judging them. Identity is the most important thing and as Mr. Tushman said in his speech, the 5th grade is a transition and I FULLY agree. I think the best thing about this book is the perspective my students are going to have and that, for me, is enough for them to take away.
Great Story!

Auggie Pullman knows he's different. He was born with a severe facial deformity and has spent his entire life dealing with people's reaction to his appearance. Due to the large number of surgeries and health issues he experienced as a young child, Auggie has always been homeschooled - until his parents decide that 5th grade would be the perfect year for him to go to a real school and interact with real kids. 
 And that is where the main conflict of this story begins. 
 What is so extraordinary about Wonder is that there are many different points of view to explore and discuss. Auggie is never explicitly bullied at school, but he experiences a great deal of unkind treatment from classmates. But there are also the behaviors of his classmates and family members that kids can discuss and empathize with. This is a novel that shows kids there are no simple answers in life. 
 I'm sure this phrase has already become cliche even though the book has only been out for a couple weeks now but Wonder is a wonder of a book. It's something you read that will stay with you for a long time. Auggie is one of the most lovable, empathetic characters I've ever encountered in my reading life. There's a scene in the book where Auggie's father hugs him and tells him how much he loves his face, and that very scene made me long to do the same thing for him. I loved Auggie in that moment in the same way his parents did. 
 If I had one criticism of the book it's that the ending was a little too perfect for real life, but at the same time, it was absolutely necessary for readers to feel satisfied that karma finally showed some kindness to Auggie. You can't leave readers feeling like the hand Auggie had been dealt was still rearing its ugly head. 
 If you're a middle grade teacher searching for your next great read-aloud, I can't recommend Wonder enough.
LOVED this book! I think EVERYONE should read this book!

This was a good book. The subject matter was intriguing and thought inspiring. I was annoyed by the shifts in perspective, but only because that's the trendy thing to do in YA lit, and in this book it felt like a lazy way to tell a complicated story. Also, the happy ending was a little too sticky sweet for me. Again, this may just be my bitter, I've-read-too-much-kid-lit pojnt of view, because I did enjoy most of the book.

August (who goes by "Auggie") has this weird fluke thing that makes him look different than anyone else. (He basically tells readers he won't describe himself, and then adds "Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse.") He was homeschooled for most of his life but now his parents have decided that he needs to go to school...just in time for middle school. Still, against all odds, Auggie makes some friends. (And, of course, spends a not-small amount of time being stared at and then avoided.) 
 Oh, you guys, this book. I have not loved a book like this since The Pull of Gravity. (In fact, I think this book is probably what would happen if TPoG and The Fault in our Stars got together and had a book baby.) I know it's a total cliche, but this is the kind of book that changes lives and definitely the kind of book that turns me into a crazy person and start brandishing it at strangers, saying, `GUYS. READ THIS. READ THIS NOW." 
 I've become a total sap in my old age (32 in April) and I find that the two things that make me cry most often are blatant cruelty and unexpected kindness. There's a lot of both in this book. 
 It's pretty impossible not to fall in love with August and his obsession for all things Star Wars. But it's just as hard not to love his family (his parents and his older sister Olivia---or "Via"), who love Auggie as fiercely as...well, as I do, at this point. And the group of friends that Auggie makes are pretty awesome as well. 
 I don't think I can talk about this book like a normal person. It's sweet and sad and profound and brilliant, but when I try to expound on that (so that people will want to buy this book), I just keep coming back to "This is probably the best book I will read this year. And I am so sad that I read it in February, because everything is going to be downhill from here." 
 Highly recommended.
How and why did I pass over this book for so long???
Everyone should read about Auggie... eyeopening, heartwarming experience!

This is a heart-warming story about standing up for friends and learning to love yourself. I really liked the multiple perspectives in this story, especially considering how self-absorbed August is. I mean, that is very realistic for a middle school age boy and getting some outside perspective helped move the story along. I think this would be a great story for a middle school teacher to read aloud to a class. It definitely has its sad and difficult moments but the moments of sweetness and hope outweigh those by far.
http://www.granitemedia.org/2012/05/w...

I did not want to let go of a single character when I finished this book - I just wanted to hold them close forever. 
 "...sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone..." pg 141 
 "...if it really all was random, the universe would abandon us completely and the universe doesn't. it takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see... the universe makes it all even out in the end. the universe takes care of all its birds." pg 208 
 "Huh. Here I was looking for symbolism and metaphors and, um... sometimes a duck is just a duck!" pg 291 
 "He is the greatest... whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own." pg 308

It is more along the lines of 4.5 for me. I wasn't sure how much I would enjoy this book but it sucked me in. I didn't expect that. I instantly cared about the characters and I loved getting to hear their different voices and viewpoints. I really felt like she gave a good feel for each character that had their own section. There were times in this book when I cried and I thought about it when I wasn't reading. It is a story that will stay with me.

A MUST READ! even if you are not in elementary school, you would benefit and still enjoy reading this book. 
 At first, I wasn't sure I would like it. The first couple of pages weren't as captivating as I wanted them to be. If it wasn't for my 10-years-old sister's insistence that I finish this book, I'm sure I would have put it down. That would've been a big mistake. 
 Wonder soon submerged me fully into the world of August; the book itself was written in the various mindsets of the characters. Whether it was August's mature 5th grade or his older sister Via's high school voice, I could easily believe that yes, this is a 5th grade boy or a freshman talking. Not only was it the narration that felt real, but also the transformation August goes through. I feel rewarded with reading how August went from just being the "strange" kid with a "strange" face to a strong little boy who found a place in a community that, at first, rejected him. In the end, you wonder who changed more in the book: August or the people who are apart of his story.
Full review following the book club meeting.

"Wonder" was wonderful!!! Such an important book for youth and adults alike. The lessons of kindness and acceptance of diversity that are taught in this book are paramount for today's society. As the mama of a special needs child, I couldn't have been more pleased with the way the author tackled the topic of loving and befriending those who seem "different." Our differences never make us "less" or unlovable.
Review to come.

Originally read in March 2013: One of the best books I've read in a very long time. I'm pushing this as our next read for my Jr. High book club because I think that it should be required reading for this age group. Or pretty much for everyone. I love how it makes you question not only how you treat people who are different, but also people who you think you know. I think that was my favorite part of the story, that it shows other perspectives on the same situation, that you're never really sure where someone can be coming from.

Wow. The title is exactly right -- this book is an absolute WONDER. It's powerfully emotional on a multitude of levels, all of them beautiful and poignant. If this were implemented in classrooms across the country, school climates everywhere would be changed for the better. I could share pages of dialogue snippets that touched my heart and provide life-lessons for readers of any age. If you read only one MG book this year, this should be the one.

Heartwarming ! 
 Good triumphs over evil

Auggie Pullman was homeschooled his whole life, but the summer before fifth grade, his parents drop a bombshell: from now on, he's going to be attending Beecher Prep - a real school filled with real students. That would be scary news for any kid, but it's especially terrifying for Auggie, who has what doctors call 'cranio-facial anomalies', or what jerks call 'a seriously deformed face'. Will someone so visibly different be able to survive middle school? 
 Well written, with likable characters and some funny moments. Although some lousy and sad things happen, there's still a positive vibe that runs through the book, and the focus on kindness is a good thing for kids to see. Good for tween guys and girls, and anyone who wants to get inside the head of someone 'different'.

Takes one of my favorite narrative devices, using several characters points of view, to create this very touching story about a boy with severe facial deformities who decides to stop homeschooling and join mainstream school. The main character, Auggie, has a self-deprecating humor that is particularly entertaining and endearing. Other character's conflicting emotions are told very empathetically, such as: Auggie's sister's fierce protectiveness but bitter jealousy of their mother's relationship with her brother, or his best friend's need to balance his affection for Auggie and his desire to stay popular. A great read.

This was a book that made me stop and think more than once. Dare I add it to my "best of 2013'' list already? Quite possibly. Dare I call it a "must read" for parents and youth alike? I think so. 
 A few weeks ago, the topic of people who are different from us came up while I was teaching 5th grade religious education. I asked if anyone had read Wonder and was shocked when every single student had. Apparently it's school reading already. 
 Had I known how popular it was, I probably would have really had a mental resistance to reading it, but as it was, I walked into it knowing that the friend who picked it for our monthly fiction book club felt really compelled to read it. I trusted her. 
 It's a book that's written from the heart and one of the things that I loved about it was the author's use of point-of-view. You don't just hear the story from the boy with the deformed face; you also get a good view of how things are for other characters in the story. 
 And this book is nothing if not totally, completely, wholly Catholic. It invites conversation that kids want to have, though it's never easy and hugely uncomfortable. This is a book I'd encourage you to buy, because there are passages you'll want to mark. The descriptions are vivid, heart-wrenching, and so real you'll look over your shoulder.
This was the most encouraging well thought out books!

So every 6th grade teacher had to read this book to the class every day in 4th period. I have math this period, and we've got a lot to do. We only got about halfway through in class, and we stopped altogether after Christmas break. Still, the book had intrigued me, so when I saw it at the library at the school were my mom is principal, I sorta stole it. I'm putting it back tomorrow though, so it's not really stealing, and I asked my mom if I could. The story is of a boy named August, who, for lack of a better term, is 'facially challenged'. He thinks and acts like a normal kid, but his looks get him generally ridiculed. His life takes a drastic turn when he enrolls in school for the time. The story is told through multiple POVs, like his sister, Via,, his friends Summer and Jack, and Via's boyfriend, Justin. The frequent change in the narrator gives an interesting outlook on August. It sends out a message, rather like the saying "don't judge a book by its cover", but it basically means "don't judge a person by their appearance". 
 The only real problem I had with this book was in Justin's POV. All through that, words like 'I' and proper nouns weren't capitalized, and not even the first word of the sentence was capitalized! There were no quotation marks around dialogue either. That nearly drove me insane! I would've really enjoyed reading about his experiences if only it was written correctly! I love his character, and his and Via's relationship was super cute. It would've gotten all 5 stars if it wasn't for that section. Overall, I loved the book 
 Wait: did anyone else have that problem in Justin's part, or did I just steal a defective copy of the book???

My former high school librarian recommended this book to me when it came out. I should have read it then. Always trust a librarian. 
 This is an impossible book to dislike. It's so full of human emotions - kindness, love, courage, determination, fear - and so full of beautiful messages. 
 August Pullman is a wonderful boy. Not retarded. He functions normally and is pretty smart. But he is facially deformed, which makes it psychologically challenging for him to go out, let alone attend school. 
 But his mom thinks it's time for him to stop being homeschooled. At school, he makes friends who help him feel like he belongs and enemies who remind him that he will never be a normal kid. Auggie wishes to show people that there is more to him than his appearance, but not everyone is receptive. 
 Told from various point of views in a very truthful and heartfelt manner, this story celebrates differences and proves that the human being is more good than bad.

Such a beautiful book :")
Amazing writing and some fabulous quotes that really made you think

I know most people have read this book by now, but it's an important one to spotlight. This is one of the best books I had read in a while. Its so original and unique and tells a story about what it means to want to be accepted and loved. One of the more important journeys Auggie goes through is the one to self acceptance. I really enjoyed the multiple points of view by those who interacted with him. The Julian chapter in the end really gave a lot of closure and perspective as to why children feel the need to bully. This book is important for not only children to read, but everyone to read. R.J. Palacio said she wanted to leave readers with the message that even the small things in our lives matter. When we do something mean, people suffer. When we are kind, others will benefit. Who do we want to be remembered for in this world?

I am going to preface this with a true story. Many years ago, at a Christmas party, I saw a boy like August. He was perhaps three or four years old. A sensitive little girl a year or so younger began sobbing when she saw him. What would it be like to be a child so handicapped? 
 "Wonder" answers that question beautifully. As Auggie enters fifth grade and goes to a public school for the first time, we live his experience through several points of view - his own, his sister's, his sister's friends, his own classmates'. Auggie is, in many ways, a lucky boy. He is smart and brave, and his loving family is solidly behind him. Many of his teachers are remarkable, and so are a couple of his classmates. Needless to say, this is still an incredibly challenging year for him. 
 An adult reading this book will appreciate the innocence of the children's voices, the clarity of the different points of view, and the life-affirming messages. A child, most likely, will root for August and his friends and look for comeuppance for his enemies. Both groups will find this warm and well-crafted novel entirely satisfying. Well done!

My Precepts; 
 Children will be raised with values that Jack built!!

I had seen and heard that this book had received good reviews, so it has been on my to-read list for awhile. I listened to this as an audio book. I really enjoyed this novel...it really is a great book for middle school students. I enjoyed the different precepts and liked that the author included a list of them at the end of the novel.

So my friend Rosanne read this book, and the first words of her review are READ THIS BOOK. Let me just say that I totally concur with her statement. 
 This book is amazing. August Pullman is a kid born with a serious facial deformity. "Whatever you're imagining," he says, "it's probably worse." For his entire life, he's been homeschooled, mostly due to his medical issues. But now that he's 10, he's stable enough to go to school for the first time. 
 Guess what? Middle school sucks, especially when you're the new kid. Middle school sucks even when you don't have a face that scares people away. His start at the school is less than auspicious, but somehow he manages to overcome, even though kids are cruel and total jerks. 
 I really enjoyed the way Palacio told Auggie's story from so many different viewpoints. I usually don't like that sort of thing; it tends to be extremely distracting. But somehow it made Palacio's story so much stronger to see Auggie from so many different viewpoints. 
 Seriously, read this book. It won't take long, and you will definitely not regret it.
Great book.

Without a doubt, this is my new favorite book. This is a wonderful story told through multiple points of view. You will cry tears of sadness and joy while reading this book. I wish I could put a copy in every student' hands. It is truly an inspiring story.

Read the entire book in one day at the beach. A lovely way to spend the day. This is an uplifting story of courage and knowing what true beauty and friendship really means evens when it is most difficult.

I almost read this entire book in one day, I just couldn't stop myself. It is engaging, endearing, and suspenseful in its own way, with character after memorable character. I loved the differing perspectives (something completely unexpected, but the aspect that brought this book up to 5 stars for sure) and just the authenticity of the story. Being a middle school teacher myself, by the end I felt like each triumph experienced by these characters was that of one of my own students. I was sincerely moved by it, and it was the kind of book I was sad to have finished.

Wonder was such a heartbreaking and yet uplifting read. It follows the story of young August, a boy with severe face abnormalities that set him greatly apart from anyone with a "normal" physical appearance. Auggie has been home schooled his whole life, up until now. And fifth grade has never seemed more impossible. 
 From page one, I felt myself rooting for August. I cheered for him in his highest moments and cried with him at his lowest. It's been a long time since I've read a middle grade novel with such a wholesome character. R.J. Palacio has created a little boy who simply captures your heart. Auggie felt so real, it was like reading the story and struggles of someone I know. 
 One aspect I really liked about Wonder was the shifting points of view. I wasn't expecting to get this kind of dimension in the novel, but it did nothing but add to the already touching story. I absolutely loved the different voices that R.J. Palacio included. Each character was clearly individual, with their own goals and weaknesses. This made the story much more real to me. 
 I'm so glad picked this book up. So far, it is my favorite read of the new year. The issue of bullying and the idea of spreading kindness is something that every young person should learn about, and this novel covers it in such a way that steals your heart and doesn't let it go until the very last page. I would recommend this book to anyone of any age group, especially those who are a fan of Jerry Spinelli's Stargirl.

"Wonder" by R.J. Palacio is one of the most unforgettable stories I've ever read about someone with a physical deformity. It centered around the main character, August "Auggie" Pullman and dealt with the fact that he was born with a severe facial malady that requires a variety of surgeries causing him to live as a semi-recluse and be home schooled by his mother, Isabel, until she can't help him any longer, due to her poor math skills, and enrolls him in "Beecher Prep" for the 5th grade. That set the premise for a tale that follows Auggie through his first year at middle school. 
 Set in New York, and alternatively narrated by Auggie, his sister Via (Olivia), his friend Summer, his friend Jack, Via's boyfriend Julian and Via's friend Miranda, their voices allow the reader to enter a world many might not know about because they're not in middle or high school any longer. As they tell their accounts of their's and Auggie's year I felt they were both inspiring and heartbreaking and they demonstrated how difficult it is to be different in our world. Challenging issues such as bullying, insecurity and stress were addressed in this book giving it a very modern feel and making it relatable for anyone who reads it, whether they are a child, teen or adult. 
 Even after I finished it I found myself thinking about it and being inspired by it's message. Ultimately I feel it's a beautiful story that fits into a genre full of other beautiful stories of characters who have lived through obstacles and overcome them.
Todos deberiamos ser ovacionados aunque sea una vez en la vida, porque luchamos contra el mundo.

Absolutely loved this book. It was a recommendation from my 10 year old and he was right on. It will go down as an all time favorite. I loved that all the characters were flawed, yet they still had so much good in them.

This book was a wonderful eye-opener, something that makes you think, and I hope that more children and adults will read this, especially when the movie comes out. 
 Auggie was a great character and I really enjoyed him so much, to be fair all the characters were really likeable. The flow of the book was gripping and it pulled me in from the beginning, with short chapters and a couple of parts through the viewpoint of different characters. 
 Reading this book has made me remember how mean kids can really be. I by no means had any facial deformities, but as someone who underwent a lot of surgeries that left me with scars on my leg, it reminded me of all the names I was called, and the questions children had about it.

I read this because my 11 year old son said it was a great book and I had to read it. He was right. It was beyond great. Such a simple beautiful message that is so needed right now. Highly recommend!!
talk about a tearjerker

This book is not one I would ordinarily gravitate towards, but with the hype and the fact that my elementary school teacher wife brought the book home, I gave it a read. And I must say, the book lives up to the hype! It is a wonderfully positive and uplifting story, that is well written as well. The book is incredibly moving and serves as an excellent exploration of human nature.

I read this after reading that it was a 'crossover' novel. I have a 12 year old brother and thought that it might be something he would enjoy. 
 This book made me cry and that doesn't happen too often. I loved the character of Auggie, got completely swept away by his narrative and the characterisations of his peers were spot on. It's currently down in my best books of the year list - and it may even be one of my favourite books. It's a beautiful, touching and ultimately heartwarming story. 
 One thing I would have liked is more of Auggies POV. But that's just because I loved it so much. 
 An absolute treasure.
Loved it and August!

What a good book. Were children's books like this when I was an elementary schooler? The plotline and characters are unique, without becoming preachy. Yes, the ending is happy and the bully problem is solved, but it didn't seem heavy-handed. I especially liked the glimpse of Julian's parents, just to show that these kinds of things are not just "kid-stuff". The story was told from a variety of POVs which is something I particularly enjoy in a reading experience. I would have liked to see a Julian POV, or maybe even one from Mr. Tushman, perhaps in place of Justin's. Also, in Justin's chapters, it seemed to be hinted at that he had some form of autism, which I would have liked more clarity on. That might have explained the significance of his POV, rather than just being the sister's boyfriend. Anyway, everyone and their interactions seemed very real, and I especially liked the way the Auggie/Jack storyline played out. My heart broke for Auggie on Halloween. Good, interesting story that appeals to kids and adults equally. Gives kids some great perspective without being too obvious. 
 Rating: 4 stars out of 5.
A fantastic story and who you're REAL friends really are...Loved it!!!

I was quite surprised that this book didn't sound as young as I was anticipating. For being a middle grade novel, they didn't really try and dumb down any of the writing, which I appreciated. I felt like I was reading a regular fiction novel, set from the eyes of a child. 
 I picked this up specifically because of the new movie that is coming out and really enjoyed it. It was a fast read with a great message. Of course it was fairly predictable, but I wasn't really going in looking to be shocked and awed. It was a sweet book.

Being a new student in a new school can be overwhelming, especially when making the transition from homeschool to middle school. However, it's even more overwhelming when you're unlike the rest of the student body. This was August Pullman's situation. August, referred to as "Auggie" by friends and family members, was born with a genetic abnormality known as mandibulofacial dysostosis which, as his sister put it, "made war on his face." Because of this, Auggie is constantly bullied, with others staring, screaming, or making rude comments directly to him. 
 Over the course of one year, Auggie faces considerable challenges, yet makes significant growth. With the story told from multiple points of view, you are able to gain a deeper understanding of each character and experience the tremendous obstacles they face as the story unfolds. Each character, so unique and different from one another, shares their raw emotions - what life is like in their shoes as a friend or family member of Auggie. R.J. Palacio doesn't hold back, enriching the reader's connection and overall experience. 
 In this inspiring novel, you will learn about kindness, friendship, and courage. Courage to stand up for what you believe in. Courage to be yourself. And the courage to make a difference. This will be a book that you will remember for a very long time.
A really sweet book - another one that would be good for all middle schoolers to read. Elise and I enjoyed it.

Wow. This is an exceptional novel with a deceptively simple premise: what if a boy with a terribly abnormal face went to middle school? The author's execution of this premise is exceptional, proving to the reader's surprise that we all have our crosses to bear. 
 This book is sure to win major awards this year.

I cannot put this book down! Not only is this book about a boy with extreme facial deformities, but it is also about being a sister, parent, and friend to such a boy. I love how this book examines this issue from all the angles and makes you consider what you would do in certain situations. 
 Highly recommend to anyone--guy or girl!

Best book I've read in awhile. Others probably won't like it as well as I did. But it kept me engaged and I liked that it was clean and (somewhat subtly) taught about principles I feel like kids need when they're in middle school: kindness, how to respond to hard times, and looking out for others. Not perfect but inspiring and a fun read. I just wish I hadn't read it so fast- it was a good day's reading, though.

Lo unico que puedo decir es que quisiera abrazar a August con todas mis fuerzas. 
 :) 
 "Cuando puedas elegir entre tener razon y ser amable, elige ser amable."

So first things first, what you need to know is that i have never cried when reading a book. Ever. But, this book was so amazing and touching that i actually cried. Now comes the actual review. This book is amazing nothing can compare to it. The emotions and the feelings were written so well and makes you feel for Auggie. The emotion. That is what made me love the book the most. I can't describe it to you to make you actually feel the emotion and let's you connect with the character, so I'll take an excerpt from the book. 
 "No, no, it's not all random, if it really was all random, the universe would abandon us completely. and the universe doesn't. it takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see. like with parents who adore you blindly. and a big sister who feels guilty for being human over you. and a little gravelly-voiced kid whose friends have left him over you. and even a pink-haired girl who carries your picture in her wallet. maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. the universe takes care of all its birds." 
 You see, just from that you get a glimpse of the amazing and fluent writing in this beautiful book so please read it, it has the power to change your life

REVIEW TO COME DONUT WORRY 
 ---------------------------------------------------- 
 Okay, this book is goooood! BTW, I went to Korea with my fam so that's why this is late. I will also post about my Korea trip in my blog! (soon) 
 Thoughts: 
 * This book is so beautiful, ahhhhh! 
 * Okay, in this book there were multiple points of views and that was cool. But what was really cool was that when we change POVs, the tone would also change. Let me give you an example. When we read from August, a 5th grader's POV, the tone of the POV is from a 5th grader. It doesn't have deep words and it is very easy to understand. When it changes to Olivia's POV, the tone is from a High School-er. Her POV has deeper words and stuff like that. To some of you this wouldn't be a big deal but for me, it kinda is. Usually in books that have 2 or more 1st person POVs, I would forget I was reading from this character and I would get confused. "*insert character's name* wouldn't do that! Why are you looking at yourself- oooh, I'm in*insert other character's name* 's POV. Oooohh" 
 * Having a face deformity is so hard. I can imagine how August felt when everyone was staring at him, whispering behind his backs, making him feel alone. Why must you do that, everyone? wHY?! 
 * Who wants to punch Julian? Me. 
 * I was so happy when Summer befriended August. ILY SUMMER 
 * there was pov (justin's) and everything was small caps. it was so cool. 
 * That time when Jack insulted August behind his back? I wanted to strangle him. 
 * ILY Amos, Henry and Miles! (at the end) I still want to punch you, Julian. 
 * When August won the award, I got a little bit teary-eyed. 
 * THERE ARE SO MANY QUOTES AGAIN I LOVE IT 
 That's it! Here are the quotes! 
 "Funny how sometimes you worry a lot about something and it turns out to be nothing." 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 "It's like people you see sometimes, and you can't imagine what it would be like to be that person, whether it's somebody in a wheelchair or somebody who can't talk. Only, I know that I'm that person to other people, maybe to every single person in that whole auditorium. To me, though, I'm just me. An ordinary kid." 
 "It's not enough to be friendly. You have to be a friend." 
 "Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives because we all overcometh the world." 
 "Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 "If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you wil try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 "The best way to measure how much you've grown isn't by inches or the number of laps you can now run around the track, or even your grade point average-- though those things are important, to be sure. It's what you've done with your time, how you've chosen to spend your days, and whom you've touched this year. That, to me, is the greatest measure of success." 
 "Jack, sometimes you don't have to be mean to hurt someone." 
 "Here's what I think: the only reason I'm not ordinary is that no one else sees me that way." 
 *note* IM GETTING REALLY EMOTIONAL RIGHT NOW BECAUSE OF THESE QUOTES 
 *note* I got some of these in the goodreads quote things and some of these I found myself. #triumph 
 *note* Sorry for the longest review/discussion ever.

Wonder is a WONDERFUL book. It is about a ordinary boy, named August Pullman with a facial difference. Actually, I wouldn't call it "difference" because what really is normal? Just because majority in this world have the 'same' features doesn't mean he/she is 'normal'. Who are we to judge? It is also about the different perspectives of the people around Auggie, like his friends, his sister, and his sister's friends. There were times in the book where I just want to hug Auggie. 
 It is amazing, actually it was beyond amazing. It made me laugh and cry hysterically. It was heart-warming. It made me look back on the things I did, the mistakes I made. To not judge based on the appearance of someone, because that's the most irrelevant part of knowing someone for me. It would really change your perspective on the way you see things.

I don't read a lot of "young adult" fiction but I read this for my book club and really enjoyed it. I wish I had read it with my 9-year old but I ended up telling him what happened in each chapter as I went along and he enjoyed following along too. 
 It's a touching story, a little bit heart-breaking; you want so much to tell this kid, "Hey, it gets better" but on the other hand ... will it really? His disfigurement is so profound and severe that getting out of school and into adult life isn't likely to make the stares and comments go away. The bravery that it must take just to go out and face the world every day ... you want to hug this kid and just somehow make it better for him. 
 The scene where the babysitter herds the kids away is so real and poignant; I could completely imagine being the sitter and feeling terrible about rushing away but also being just as determined not to let the kids say the wrong thing and hurt the boy's feelings. 
 Great book.
I don't like mean kids. I don't like vague descriptions about this kids face. I also don't like smart aleck kids.

A book like Wonder is a rare find. Main character August Pullman is born with a facial deformity so extreme that he "won't describe what [he] looks like - Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." The story is written from the perspectives of many different characters who love Auggie and, of course, is written by Auggie himself. Each character holds the piece to a puzzle that, in the end, displays the very picture of bravery, optimism, and "kindness greater than necessary." This book is touching and not one easily forgotten! I would recommend this book to any upper elementary/middle school educator who wants to prevent or stop bullying in the classroom, any student struggling with the social norms of pre-teen-hood, and to any person who has ever felt like an outsider. This book is a wonder!
Loved this book and everything in it! I think everyone should read this book!! What amazing lessons it has.
Everyone should read this wonderful book!
What a fantastic book!! Love the message of kindness that echoes throughout the text. Not sure if it will win the Newbery but I enjoyed it much more than the last two Newbery winners.
This book was incredibly touching and authentic. I don't even have the words to say how it stirred my heart.

For a complete, full and spoiler free review, check out the review post on my blog: 
 http://whatanerdgirlsays.com/2012/11/...

I only discovered this book when it was recommended by someone in my book club. I am so happy that I tracked it down and read it. Wonderful, cheerful, yes-a little too sweet, a little too well-wrapped up at the end, but overall, the book that would make even the most cynical adult smile and tear up at least once. I enjoyed the well-packaged words to live by throughout the book like "Choose kind", "everyone deserves a standing ovation at least once in their life", and others, and I think they are good messages for kids to hear. Note that it is written for a young adult audience, so I find several of the 2 star reviews I've read on goodreads calling it childish and simplistic a bit ridiculous. A fast read, perfect for the afternoon when life and adulthood might be getting you down.
I'm giving it 5 stars even before I finished it...

Excellent book. Gives great insight into what it is like to have a physical disability, how people treat you, what goes through your head, etc. Not just for the person involved, but their family members, friends and acquaintances.

Wonder, an impressive novel by first time author R.J. Palacio, is certain to win the ALA's Schneider Award for disability-themed fiction. Ten year-old Auggie has a rare genetic disorder that has resulted in severe facial deformity and has required many surgeries since his birth. His parents have home-schooled him through elementary school, but they decide it is time that he attend school with peers at Beecher Prep. Even though Auggie dreams of blending in, his face ensures that his arrival at Beecher will not go unnoticed, and as expected, kids react to him in a myriad of realistic and complex ways. Despite a fairly conventional and predictable ending, this book left me fighting back sobs as tears streamed down my face when I read it at Starbucks. Wonder is a truly rare book that can be enjoyed and appreciated equally well by anyone in grade 5 and up. Everyone should read this book! First read June 14-15, 2012; reread December 2014.

complicated emotions while reading it. i will love to read it again with the "wonder" playlist :) 
 it's hard to imagine Auggie as Auggie, but i find my self understand Via the most.

I've known everyone to love this book and when I heard that this book was about being different, not fitting into society and getting accepted I had to read it. I've always been bullied for being gay and looking female, so I knew that I would have some connection to August. And I did. 
 His story was bold and beautiful. We got to see what it was like for this 10 year old who was going to school for the first time and experiencing malicious bullying like no before. 
 Wonder broke my heart. It wasn't just August's story, it was his sisters and his friends. How he affected their lives for the better and the worse. 
 Being accepted is brilliant because you feel like you are worth something and this book made me realise that the people who never understood why I liked guys had to learn it for themselves. It was their learning curve. I couldn't teach them and I took that on board. Now I accept myself completely and I wouldn't change myself to fit in because I am different and different is good. 
 Without a doubt, this book should be given to every school kid because the message is up to date and we need to know about the importance of standing up for each other!

Doing some nice things, and doing them well. 
 Here's what I loved: 
 --It's a book about a kid with a facial deformity. Awesome. Let's tell these stories. 
 --It's also from the perspectives of the people around him, his sister, his friend, his sister's boyfriend. It was really nice to also see it from other people's perspectives. 
 --Some really nice pictures of family life. 
 --Deals with economic issues in kids lives nicely too. 
 --It's main theme is kindness. That's a great theme. 
 What I didn't love: 
 --The characters were all a little flat. Although we got to hear different voices through the book, the narration was pretty similar throughout, so much so that I was startled when one of them had a weird capitalization habit, and realized they were all supposed to be different voices. 
 --Emotional changes happen so fast. They get a new dog right away without even mourning their old dog? 
 --I guess I expected more of August. I saw some of the whiney self-centeredness, but I didn't see him reject it by the end. I wanted him to be something spectacular under that face, and I feel like the book worked hard to make his journey be "to become ordinary." 
 --I wanted the book with that title to be filled with wonder. 
 I wanted this to be Rebecca Stead's Liar and Spy. A book which like this one, deals with bullying, but deals with it beautifully. Or The View from Saturday which is a book with a lot of different voices in which each voice is vivid and distinct. So it was fine, and I liked it, but I expected more.
Loved this book!

August Pullman is starting his first year of middle school . . . his first year of going to a real school, ever. Due to a combination of genetics he has a facial deformity and doesn't look normal (kids call him Zombie behind his back), but is normal in just about every other way. 
 Loved it. Characters are always a major selling point for me, and the characters were so real and human in this book. They carried the story with their honesty . . . kids make fun of August, while others are kind. Although I think they seemed a little older than 5th grade- more like 7th to me. When I first started reading, I thought it was only going to be from the POV of August, but when it switched to other characters I loved it! The perspectives and background stories of the other characters made it much more interesting and rounded. Like maybe you thought August had it rough, but once you hear from the others you realize that they have their struggles too, and August actually has some really great things going for him. The way this was written really shows the difference one person can have on other people's lives. 
 This is definitely a book that touches you, and makes you want to be a better person from reading it. To see the characters act nobly despite their shortcomings and mistakes and completely normal and human feelings . . . makes me think that anyone can be a noble, kind person even in the small, everyday things in their life, and especially in the big moments. These characters had some big moments where they stepped up and were great. 
 - www.enjoyabookblog.com
Really good!! I couldnt put it down!! Loved the ending

PUANIM:4.35/5 
 Kitap bayagi elimde surundu kabul ama hem Ingilizce olarak okuyordum hem de bir turlu elime alamiyordum. Wonder tam anlamiyla bitirdigim tek Ingilizce kitap. Dili fazlasiyla basit. Zaten 10 yasindaki cocuklarin agzindan okuyoruz kitabi o yuzden cumleler cok basit. 
 Kisaca konusuna deginirsek; Auggie 10 yasinda ve dogustan yuzunde fiziksel bozukluklar var. Bu yuzden okula hic gitmemis ve evde annesi tarafindan egitim gormus. Ailesi artik besinci sinifa geldigi icin onu okula yazdirmak ister ama Auggie buna karsi cikar. Daha sonradan bir sekilde okula gitmeyi kabul eder. Ve kitabi ilk basta Auggie'nun acisindan okusak da sonradan okuldaki ve ailesinden olan kisilerin bakis acilarindan da okuyoruz. 
 Bolum bolum herkesin bakis acisini okumak gercekten keyif vericiydi.(Auggie'nin ablasi Via, Via'nin sevgilisi Justin, Auggie'nin okuldan arkadaslari Jack ve Summer ve Via'nin arkadasi Miranda) Herkesin Auggie hakkinda ne dusundugunu ve ne hissettigini okumak kitabi sevmemde buyuk etken. Sadece Auggie tarafindan aktarilsaydi bazi seyler tam olmayacakti. Belki de diger karakterlere bakis acimiz degisecekti ve onlara onyargiyla yaklasacaktik. Yazarin bize farkli bakis acilarini sunmasi kitabi tekduzelikten uzaklastirmis. Kitabi sikicilastirmayip canlandirmis. Ilk baslarda dram agirlikli bir kitap olur diye dusunmustum ama Auggie'nun neseli ve eglenceli hallerini gordukce oyle olmadigini anladim. 
 Auggie'nin daha 10 yasinda insanlar tarafinda sirf yuzu siradisi diye tepkiler gormesi ve onun hissettiklerini okumak hem uzucuydu hem de bir yonden ders vericiydi. Genel olarak insanlarin dis gorunuslerine bakip onlari yargilayan bir toplumuz. Bu kitabi okudugunuz zaman iste bu dusuncelerden tamamiyle ariniyorsunuz, ders aliyorsunuz. Dis gorunusun sadece bir hiclikten ibaret oldugunu goruyorsunuz. Auggie'nin hissettiklerini okumak beni cok etkiledi. Sadece 10 yasinda.10! Ve oylesine saf ve temiz duygulari olan bir cocuk ki artik bir sure sonra insanlarin onun yuzunu gordugunde attiklari cigliklari gormezden gelebiliyor. 
 Kitapta ilk baslarda Auggie'nin okula adapte olmaya calismasini ve insanlarin ona bir virusmus gibi davranmasini okuyoruz.Ve o umutsuz bir sekilde tek basinayken Summer onun yanina geliyor. Summer karakteri o kadar tatliydi ki en sevdigim karakterlerden diyebilirim. Zaman ilerledikce ikisinin dostluklarini okuyoruz. Fazla minnoslar. Cool beans! Ve tabiki Jack'i de en basindan beri sevdim. 
 Auggie'nin bolumleri kadar Via'nin bolumlerini de sevdim. Ailesinin surekli Auggie ile ilgilenmesi ve Via'nin ilgiden yoksun kalmasina ragmen kardesine hic kizamamasi. Bir taraftan liseye baslamasi bir taraftan arkadas sorunsallari derken ilgiye en muhtac oldugu anlarda ilgisiz kalmasi ve yazarin onun hissettiklerini cok iyi sekilde vermis olmasi cok gercekciydi. Gelelim Auggie'nin ailesine. Auggie dogdugu ilk andan beri onlarin "mucizesi". Aile baglari simsikiydi ve gayet neseli bir ailesi vardi. 
 Kitap fazla gercekciydi. Okuyan herkesin ders cikaracagi, dostluk, sevgi, nezaketin ne demek oldugunu bu kitapta goreceksiniz. Ve tabiki onyargilarinizi kiracaksiniz.Bol bol duygu karmasalari yaratan bir kitap. Bir bolumde uzuluyorsunuz sonra bir bakiyorsunuz Auggie yine yuzunuzu gulumsetiyor. Bazen de cevredeki insanlara sinirleniyorsunuz. Fazlasiyla duygu yogunlugu olan ama bir o kadarda akici olan bir kitap. 
 Sonlara dogru sanki olaylar gercekciligini yitirdi gibi. Bazi karakterlerin degisimlerinden dolayi sanirim ben oyle hissettim. Bu yuzden hafif hayal kirikligina ugramadim degil. Bunun disinda kesinlikle muazzam farkindalik yaratacak bir kitap. Yasiniz ne olursa olsun alin okuyun.

Wonder is well, Wonder-full!
Gorgeous and brilliant writing . Many tears and lots to think over now I've finished . Highly recommended ....
I loved this book! It was funny; it was sad; it made me think about how lucky I am.
In my top must read books of all time!

**5/5** 
 Choose kindness.
Everyone should read this!
OK book..nice story but very mediocre. Nothing surprising or earth shattering..don't judge a book by its cover and be kinder than necessary..there...that sums up the story.

More or less, I imagined August Pullman as the guy in 'All I Want' music video by Kodaline . Yap, the guy with that unusual look. In fact, both of them are completely different. Auggie is a 5th grade student. And he probably looks worse. Now, how does it feel to be a 'stand out' creature in a world full of normal people? . 
 Surely, this book has a special place in my heart. After reading, I feel like I should hug Auggie if we meet somewhere. And it's not because I feel pity on him, but because I know he's a wonder.

Great read aloud at the high school level. A great text to talk about position and how the secondary character Jack changes in the story. Great conversation starters about position. Excellent read. A go to favorite for reluctant readers at the high school level.

Oh, my. I so loved this book. 
 What a heartwarming, sweet, sometimes funny, sometimes sad, often inspiring story. 
 Ten year old August Pullman was born with a severe facial deformity. Due to his many surgeries and constant health concerns, Auggie has always been home schooled. So when his mom thinks it's time for him to go to a public school, he is shocked and extremely nervous. How will the kids treat him? Will he make any friends? Will this be a disaster of decision? 
 The story is told from different perspectives and I really felt like I went on this emotional journey with Auggie and his friends and family. 
 What a gem of a book I will always treasure. 
 "Shall we make a new rule of life...always try to be a little kinder than is necessary? " 
 The Little White Bird 
 J.M. Barrie

Amazing book! It's definitely a book that will make you cry at some parts. It is told from many different point of views from the different characters. The main character is a 10 year old boy called August (also known as 'Auggie'). He was born with a facial deformity and has the everyday struggle of being accepted and treated equally. You learn so much from this book and you can relate to all the characters at some point in the book. I'd recommend this book to everyone, even if you don't enjoy reading that much because the chapters are really short and it's quite an easy book to read. I think you should definitely read this book if you feel like sometimes you don't fit in or you feel like people treat you differently like they assume that because you're slightly different you aren't as intelligent or not human.
Such an amazing book! So emotional. The author conveys what he wants to say so perfectly.

Not sure how I ended up reading a middle-grade novel but I did, and actually quite enjoyed it, once I had resigned myself to the realistic, but horrible language that teenagers (and the author)used throughout. 
 It's a highly original tale told through the eyes of Auggie, an American boy with severe facial deformities who makes the transition from home-schooling to mainstream. His character is well-drawn. There is much sadness here, but also lots of humour. Eventually compassion wins through and there are a few surprises. 
 It's a great story for teenagers and hopefully will make them think about their actions and prejudices, but I don't think I'll be reading any more novels for this age group any day soon. (Jones)
One of my all-time favorite books. I have read it over and over and still love it. Choose Kind!

Wonder is a story meant for young adult readers but as an adult I really enjoyed this book. August (Auggie) Pullman is about to go to a "regular" school for the first time in his life. He was born with an abnormal face which makes talking and eating difficult, not to mention the way he looks. After enduring many surgeries and treatments for his condition, his family has decided now is the time for him to attend a regular school. Auggie is faced with lots of challenges in making friends when most people are unwilling or able to see what's beneath the surface of his looks. 
 He does find a few friends and teaches and learns some lessons in being a good person along the way. This is a heartfelt, feel good story that's a light read and not to upsetting or dramatic. A great way to unwind with a nice little book.

I love, love, loved this book. I don't read a ton of middle-grade fiction because I find myself judging it by the standards I bring to adult fiction and finding it lacking. By any standards, this book is awesome. Palacio does a fantastic job of both depicting the shitty things that go down in the life of a kid with serious facial deformities and painting a full picture of Auggie as a regular kid with a great sense of humor. It's not maudlin or sappy at all, which is kind of amazing given the subject matter. It actually reminded me a bit of great NYC-set YA from the 1970s like Norma Klein and Paula Danziger, although it's nothing like those authors, really, it just comes off as so fully-realized and authentic. Highly recommended.

I enjoyed this novel about August, going to school for the first time at 10 years old, who has a facial deformity. The author takes his point of view as well as those around him to this experience. Everyone has the "do I look or don't I look" experience at some point - but what does the person on the other side of that look think?

Chris Bancells 
 Palacio, R.J. (2012). Wonder. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. 
 Contemporary Realistic 
 Maryland Black-Eyed Susan Award Nominee (2013-2014) 
 Print 
 Selection tools consulted: School Library Journal, WorldCat, Maryland Association of School Librarians Black-Eyed Susan Award Nominee list (2013-2014). 
 Review: 
 Alienation is not a new theme in literature, much less so in YA fiction. The story of August Pullman, however, is as refreshing as it is familiar. Auggie (as his friends and family call him) was born with a startling cocktail of disorders that left his face so deformed it makes small children cry. As August himself puts it, "whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse" (p.3). His uniqueness is purely physical, but it brings with it a whole host of social consequences, especially when August starts middle school. Having been homeschooled his whole life, Auggie's mom, dad, and sister, Via, were able to protect him. Now, the reality of the world, of school life in upper Manhattan is a reality for Auggie too. Bullies and friends, betrayals and ambiguities, Auggie navigates them all with a genuineness that endears him to the reader. Wonder is a novel about middle school which, in its spare prose, avoids feeling juvenile. The narration passes between the main character and five others who orbit him to greater or lesser degrees. Interestingly, all the narrators are children; no adults give a perspective on August. Despite this variety of perspectives, the story remains tightly told, never straying too far from Auggie's evolution. The ending to somewhat too pat, but is also as uplifting as the book deserves. Although Palacio doesn't run from the realities of bullying, she never lets her characters descend so far into the darkness that they can't return safely (though not unchanged). In the end, the book is a hopeful message to the bullied and those who love them. Highly recommended.

This is such a popular book, and I know there's a movie coming out soon, so I thought this one was going to blow me away. I didn't feel like this was a book that I would have to store for my future children one day, or recommend to my school library, or choose it as a book to study with a class of students. 
 Spruked throughout the book were some very cliche messages on kindness. Also touched on in the book was the idea of transitioning from childhood to adulthood and how that may mean you can't do fun kiddy things anymore because you are trying so hard to fit in and be an adult too early in life - which is a bit sad. While these are important messages, there was definitely nothing new or inspirational from this story. 
 Having said that, the writing was not completely dreadful. This was a readable book, it was just pretty boring and predictable in terms of characters, plot, complications and themes.

I can't say properly how much this book touched me. The themes are universal but the story is unique and well told. This should be required middle school reading. Auggie will always hold a special place in my heart. I can't wait to read and discuss this book with my children one day.
Excellent and an easy read! Every middle-schooler should be required to read.
This is definitely one of those books that everyone should read in there lifetimes. When I become a teacher I wouldn't mind reading this to my students.
"If every single person [...] made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary--the world really would be a better place."

I didn't really like the form of the book (multiple first person narrators), but I understand why it was written that way. Justin was my favorite narrator, and his section was so short. He was the most perceptive and analytical of them all. He was the only one who saw how everything fit into the big picture. Everyone else just told how something made them feel. But Justin thought about it. 
 But I loved the message of the book. That seems obvious to say, but the real message is kind of subtle until the end: that those who are the most brave among us bolster our hearts and spirits and make us braver. 
 I can see a middle grade kid loving this book. Recommend.
This is a powerful book. I loved the different viewpoints. I cried and I wanted to beat up kids on a playground. amazing book!!!
Remarkable. So wonder-ful. I read it all in one sitting, which I seldom able to do.

I liked this story ok, but not as much as the recent Out of My Mind, another story about a student with physical challenge.
this book I had to read for school. it was very touching and moving. definitely a book to read.
