As a 5th grader, Auggie has had a difficult life because he was born with several deformities which required many surgeries. The book tells of his year as a 5th grader in a private school. Up until then, he has been homeschooled. 
 Auggie, whose face deformities are definitely noticeable, realizes that he may be different, but he still wants to be accepted like any other person. The story tells about his difficulties with different students, how he handles situations, how other students react, and how the 5th grade year develops. 
 I could not read this book without thinking of another book, OUT OF MY MIND by Sharon Draper that dealt with the differences in children. These two books would make good comparison/contract discussions in a classroom.
Definitely something worth reading.
I loved this book so much. It's a great book for everyone of all ages!

It's light and heartwarming, as everyone has said. I think it's depth came through its story-telling in a multitude of perspectives. I especially enjoyed that Palacio touched on the perspective of Auggie's sister, and her intertwining feelings of resentment, understanding, and guilt toward her family and brother. I must admit, it was refreshing to end a book with a smile and watch Auggie's (and peers') positive growth. However, as much as I'd like to believe the ending is realistic, it was too perfectly wrapped up with a bow on top and left me wanting just a little more realism.

"When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind"- Wayne Dyer. If every single person reading this made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, to try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world would really be a better place. And if you do this daily, somewhere someone out there may recognize in you the face of God.

Original post at One More Page 
 There was a time a few years ago when I was hearing mass with my family, and I happened to stand beside this man at church. The man wasn't dressed the way other people were dressed during Sunday mass. He looked scruffy, almost like he came straight from the streets to the church. He didn't look dangerous, and perhaps he even is nice given that he was in church and all. But what I really noticed were his hands. They were, if I were to be perfectly honest, kind of scary. The memory's vague, but I remember that it looked like he had some kind of skin disease -- lesions, wounds and spots -- the kind that one would refuse to touch in fear of contagion. I was afraid to touch it, knowing especially that at a certain part of the mass, I would have to hold his hand while praying The Lord's Prayer. 
 I tried, I really did. I was in church, and holding hands with a stranger during a prayer is the thing to do. It was the good thing, the kind thing, the loving thing. It was expected. I told myself that I would do it, that I would hold his hand during The Lord's Prayer and not be scared or repulsed or look for a hand sanitizer after the prayer. I told myself, I prepared myself and I wanted to do it. 
 But I didn't. When the priest told everyone to "join hands and as one family pray the prayer Jesus had taught us," I chickened out, opened my hand but did not take his, looked ahead and prayed, feeling the guilt grow heavier as the mass went on. 
 This particular memory may seem insignificant and well, I may be blowing things out of proportion. Perhaps the man never even noticed me at all -- but it struck me because I really wanted to do the kind thing, but I didn't because I was afraid. Just like how the other kids and grown ups in the book reacted to Auggie in Wonder by R.J. Palacio. August Pullman was born with a facial deformity that made him quite special to his family for his need of extra care. He has never attended a normal school, until he agreed with his parents to start attending fifth grade at Beecher Prep. Auggie is a perfect fit for the school, except maybe for his face. Told in Auggie's point of view as well as five more from the people around him, we follow Auggie as he faces one of the most challenging times of his young life. 
 I was prepared for a barrage of emotions that Wonder could probably give me, after reading several reviews and updates from Goodreads friends about this book. I knew that I was probably going to like it, but what I wasn't prepared for were what kind of emotions it would bring. Being a middle grade book, the writing was pretty simple and easy to read, especially since most of the narrators were kids as well. Wonder is bound to remind readers of their own middle school (or in my case, late elementary years, since we do not have middle school in the Philippines) experiences. It's strange to think of it, but young people can be very mean, even if it's not on purpose, and Wonder shows how it could be. My heart went out for Auggie, especially since he did not ask to look like the way he does. Like his parents, I wanted the best for him too. 
 The story was told not just in Auggie's point of view, but also with five other kids who surrounded Auggie's life. This made the book a little easier to relate to because let's admit it: most of us don't have what Auggie has. Of all the characters, I identified the most with his friend, Jack. I really wish I could be like Summer, that I could choose to be kind before anything else. I think Jack represents the side of everyone who tries to be good but fails, and then tries again anyway. And I think the trying is the most important part of it all. 
 There's a lot of buzz with what Wonder teaches, or attempts to teach, but I think maybe we shouldn't over think it too much. Sure, there are some parts that may seem a little simple, that the ending may seem to be a little too nicely wrapped up, almost like how a movie is done and we know real life is never that way. I see it as a simple thing: I see Wonder as a middle grade book that teaches kindness -- to quote, "...to be kinder than necessary." That as human beings, we do not just have "...the capacity to be kind, but the very choice of kindness..." and to choose that even when it's not easy, when it's inconvenient, even when it's uncomfortable. 
 Even though reading Wonder reminded me of that particular incident I shared at the start of this review which brought back some of the guilty feelings, this book made me feel a lot better after reading it. A little bit more whole, even. With a stronger resolve to be kinder than necessary. I think that a book that can make its readers feel like that is worth a second glance.
This is a sappy and sad book, but with a lot of humor and A TON of the cold hard truth. I loved it

Entranable. Lo que mas me ha gustado; la evolucion de la historia, que no hay nadie completamente bueno ni completamente malo. Las reflexiones de Via, Miranda, August, Summer... La familia de August cualquiera desearia tener una familia asi. Hay una reflexion que hace un personaje, respecto la situacion de August que es "el universo cuida de todos sus pajaros" y en este caso tiene tanta razon...
One of the best books I've read in awhile! Totally appropriate yet has a different message for every reader - everyone from my 83 year old grandma to 13 year old cousin loved it!

Everyone should read this book. 
 Not because it's well-written, funny, cute... 
 But because it will change your heart. 
 Wonder will change the way you view the world and the people around you. It provides a voice to the silent, and takes a stand for those people who are often just brushed aside. 
 You will laugh and cry while you read this book, and your heart will break multiple times as you get inside the mind of a young, isolated boy. 
 You won't look at people the same way ever again.

I really really loved this book. 
 It bought tears to my eyes everytime I read it, it was such an amazingly touching story of a little boy born with a severely deformed face. 
 It left me wanting to hug this little boy and his family. 
 If you are thinking of reading it do not hesitate, it's an easy reader and it's lovely.

Solid MG right here. Starts out as a study of a kid dealing with a terrible and seemingly unique problem, but it slowly expands outwards to show the different struggles of the other characters. A subtle and efficient study of how all of us have our battles to fight. (And the tiny illustrations make the point nicely as well. Oh, and extra points for The Magnetic Fields reference near the end.)

Reading this book is like riding a carousel, like eating ice cream on a warm day. It's not very often that I encounter books that make me want to hug everyone around me. 
 This book restored my faith in humanity.

Such a great read. This story follows the journey of a 5th grade boy who has a facial deformity through his school year. It's heart-breaking, eye-opening and hopeful. Although this book is for "young readers," I can't imagine all adults not enjoying it as well. At numerous points while reading it, I thought it would be the perfect book for every parent to read with their 3rd-5th graders. Maybe this story could transform the culture of our Junior High schools if every child (and parent) were exposed to it before attending. 
 "Always try to be a little kinder than is necessary."

My mother heard about this book from substitute teaching at a middle school and absolutely raved about how good it was, so I had to try it. I read it all in one sitting in just a few hours because I couldn't put it down, and wow did this author nail the middle school experience right on the head. 
 The premise of the book is that a 5th grader named August who was born with a really rare gene defect that caused a lot of problems with his face is about to go to school for the first time (because of health issues he was homeschooled up to that point). I expected the book to follow the trope of kid-who-is-different-is-mistreated-but-comes-out-stronger-and-shows-everyone-he's-awesome, and to some extent I guess it does, but it is SO MUCH MORE THAN THAT. 
 So often these types of stories fall flat in some way because the parents or teachers or background characters are two-dimensional and hardly change expect for when it's convenient for the storyline. This book had NONE of those problems. The parents were fleshed out, complex, realistic people who's reactions were consistent with their characters. The teachers and school officials you met felt like they had actual backstories and personalities, and their dialogue wasn't dopey or cartoonish. August's classmates (and his sister Via's high school classmates as well) had convoluted and shifting social dynamics that rang true to my experience as a middle schooler (despite the pop culture and tech differences that made it clear these were 2013ish fifth graders not 2005ish like myself), and none of the kids felt exaggerated or like they existed solely for the sake of August's narrative. The background kids also never felt like one giant mass made up of clones who didn't have their own lives unaffected by the protagonist and antagonist. They all had a place and were nuanced. The bullies were not stupid or inherently evil, nor did they never develop. 
 Most importantly, time and time again Palacio reminded us that the truth resists simplicity. Every time you thought you could pin-point who the "bad guys" were going to be, Palacio would smack you in the face with reality and remind you that labeling is not that simple in real life. She reminds us that these school environments are far from static, and that every child affects that, not just the protagonist and antagonist. She reminds us that even though kids can be cruel, they can also be incredibly kind, (or both at once) and they're all complex humans who constantly choose every day whether or not to follow the crowd. 
 The last thing I'll say is that range of view points were interwoven beautifully, and made me empathize and love each speaker. By the end of the book, you feel like you've seen the full picture, and you love every bit of it. The inspiring ending felt earned and honest, and is one of those "I believe in humans again" moments. 
 Anyone 5th grade to adult can love and relate to this book and I'd highly recommend it.
Wonderful read! Such a simple story/plot but just lovely to read :)

I LOVED this one. I laughed and cried with the Pullman family. The children's' POV makes for a quick read, but reminds you what it's like to be in fifth grade. 
 The voice shows the perfect amount of innocence of being a child and wisdom from living with his unpronounceable condition. It reads quickly, but after I finished I wanted more about his life and family dynamic. The characters certainly made the story.
Wow! What an amazing collection of voices! A stellar middle-school novel about patience and acceptance and taking initiative and how frustrating those qualities and their absences can be.

I liken Wonder to Pixar's movie Up: thought of as a kid's book (or movie in Pixar's case), but adults can glean far more from this book that is beyond the emotional intelligence of a child. That is not to say that children can't learn something from it; they most certainly can, and I plan on reading this to/with my children when I have them. 
 This book can be read in just a number of hours, quick read, but it feels like you're part of the story by the time you finish, like you have a stake in what happens to little Auggie. This book made me misty-eyed, sad, for Auggie, and also misty-eyed, happy, for Auggie, true emotion from a well written piece of fiction that is the reality for some children, some families. Even the teachers were five star; I thought to myself as I was reading: "Man, I would have loved to have Mr. Browne for English. Can't remember a teacher that had a gift and passion for teaching quite like this fictional one does." 
 This is one of my favorite books now, and if you read it, you will understand why.
This book is incredibly important. It teaches kids what happens when they are mean to people who are different. This book was handled very well, and wish it was around when I was younger.
For this review and more, please visit us at:http://tinyurl.com/kz8afe3

Recommended for: 
 If you want a break from action-packed novels where characters are always on the run for their lives, and you want a light read while looking for a bit of inspiration, Wonder could definitely work. 
 You'll finish reading this book feeling proud. It's very fulfilling. 
 P.S. There's also an appendix I'm sure you'll love. You'd want to frame all the precepts! (You'll know what I'm talking about when you get there) 
 Review 
 First of all, I just love the book cover. It's intriguing, minimalist yet loud, truly creative, and iconic. There's so much to say! I was hooked from the first chapter until the end. It was bittersweet, it was adorable, and it was light and dramatic at the same time. 
 In this novel we get to witness August Pullman, who has craniofacial dysostosis, get through the 5th grade at Beecher Prep middle school. 
 August is such an endearing character. He is only 10 years old, but there is a great maturity about him. He is analytical and observant, and even though he sometimes thinks his situation is unfair, he does not let this thinking get to him. He's optimistic, always cracking up on other's stories even if he is the butt of it. He has his fears but he listens to advise and acknowledges them if they're right (even if he doesn't want them to be right). August described this "laughing-crying" situation and that's exactly where his bravery led me. 
 We also get to see that August won't be the only one learning. The people around him change as well, and they change for the better - Via learned to be selfless since the beginning, Summer and Jack becoming true friends despite their schoolmates' oppressive advances, Miranda realizing she didn't have to pretend to get anyone's approval, Miles, Amos, Henry, for standing up to what was right, and August even got Justin to ponder about the universe. 
 I also loved how the book was written. The chapters are short and the titles are concise and straight-to-the-point. It's like I'm reading diary entries from these kids which makes it even more personal. 
 More on the Characters 
 Via 
 There was a point when Via thought August needed to grow up. I can understand that. She observes August pretending he is normal but she doesn't believe it's working nor will it ever work. To her and everyone else August is far from normal than anyone could describe. 
 To hell with that, I say. What August thinks matters more than anyone's judgement. And he's 10 years old, still too young. Besides, August has been handling his life with poise and dignity where a lot of older people fail. 
 Summer 
 He's just a kid. The weirdest-looking kid I've ever seen, yes. But just a kid 
 Everyone should be like Summer. She's compassionate, honest, and kind. She's such a strong character. No one should be treated differently just because of an unconventional appearance. She realizes this and goes out of her way to treat everyone equally. 
 Jack 
 Can I just say that the excerpt on 'Part Four: Jack' was really fitting. 
 Now here is my secret. It is very simple. 
 It is only with one's heart that one can see clearly. 
 What is essential is invisible to the eye. 
 - Antoine de Saint-Exupery, The Little Prince 
 Miranda 
 She said it. When she changed she felt fake. But I understand she was just lost. 
 August 
 He keeps believing he is like everybody else because it's what he wants himself to believe, no matter what anybody else thinks. I think there's a beautiful humility to this thinking. His situation isn't ordinary, in fact it's been mentioned more than once that he's a medical wonder, he gets stared at, whispered at, sometimes outright bullied, yet his heart feels he isn't more special than anyone else. He sucks it up, thinks for a while about anything that transpired, he doesn't ignore his hurt feelings but gets over them and he goes on with his life. After all, we all overcometh the world 
 LOVE THIS PART 
 #JustinAndTheUniverse 
 "No, no, it's not all random, if it really was all random, the universe would abandon us completely. And the universe doesn't. It takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see. Like with parents who adore you blindly. And a big sister who feels guilty for being human over you. And a little gravelly-voiced kid whose friends have left him over you. And even a pink-haired girl who carries your picture in her wallet. Maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. The universe takes care of all its birds." 
 - Justin 
 There's the graduation scene as well, and Mr. Tushman's speech and Auggie receiving an award, but hey who doesn't love that part.

I love this book! I'd read it over and over again. It's just so beautiful. I can't really describe what I'm feeling now. But I'm just high. I'm up in the clouds, and I don't want to come down from this cloud. And it's this book that made me fly.
The feelings are unexplainable.

Palacio has a very clear understanding of people, of all ages, with all their complexities. Of course, I say that as an adult. Teens and pre-teens may disagree with me. She writes very well for the most part, getting us inside the heads of various characters; however, I would have liked to see Julian's or his friends' points of view. An emotionally moving book, my few criticisms are that I felt she overused the word 'dude,' I found that the story dragged near the end in a few spots, and I kept thinking as Auggie's classmates started jumping in to get their picture taken with him that many of them still weren't his friends, but we're just jumping on the bandwagon. I've also never heard of anyone graduating from fifth grade or any other grade where you don't actually leave the school. That seemed weird to me. I also wondered what the headmaster's job was, if there was also a director who was obviously the principal? 
 As for the trailer for the movie, I can't say enough bad things about it. I'll be avoiding that at all costs.
A lovely and heartwarming story.
Simplemente maravilloso,lo termine en unas horas. Creo que este es un libro que todos deberian leer :)

This book was absolutely amazing! I read "Wonder" with my fifth graders, and they were always begging to read more, so we bought "Auggie & Me" so we can continue! This story is a great opportunity to teach kindness and compassion for others, and being realistic fiction, it dips a toe into a genre that most (of my) students wouldn't ever read. I recommend this book to anyone!

This book took me by storm. Various characters are given the opportunity to tell their "Auggie" story in their own words. Auggie the main character was born with a severe birth defect that has caused his face to be deformed despite many surgeries to correct it. His family is fiercely protective of his feelings so he has been homeschooled until the fifth grade when his mom feels he has reached her limits of teaching so he is enrolled in a private school. Auggie is quite perceptive to how others react to him and is expert at reading people. He meets some kind students and of course the mean ones. Parents also get involved which adds another level of stress. Auggie and his family learn to navigate middle school with some sad and touching moments. This should be required reading for everyone.
Loved it! Not going to do any spoiler alert but I am certainly glad my daughter's teacher chose this one! Works well for 5th and 6th grade kids.

One of the best children's books I've read in a LONG time. You'll want to share it. My copy is loaned, but you can be next 
 Some reviews seem to rate this as an adult book, rather than a child's book. The story will hold your attention... But it it written for your third or fourth grader. 
 I cried tears. Immediately wanted to share with my kids , in the way I wanted to share Tuck Everlasting.
Wonder is wonderful! Smart, touching, funny & lively.

When I finished this book for a sudden I felt like " losing a great friend of my " . It's was just an amazing,truthful,one of kind novel. 
 My feelings were like a wave of sadness, happiness, hysterical laughing and other mixture of emotions. 
 I would love to meet August, to tell him he's more than an ordinary kid, and how he changed my thought. 
 Wonder is all about this simple lines : 
 " Who we are ! Us! Right ? What kind of people are we? What kind of person are you? Isn't that the most important thing of all? Isn't that the kind of question we should be asking ourselves all the time? What kind of person am I ? ".

Every person, young and old should read this story. The best message in the world is illustrated so clear and engaging and impossible not to have a huge emotional reaction to: "Be kinder than necessary." That is so brilliantly shown in this story about a young kid entering 5th grade after being homeschooled until then... because a rare condition made him have a deformed face. The way Auggie faces down peers... with integrity and courage would have put me to shame as an adult. Who is harder to get along with than one's own peers? And in middle school? It's almost impossible. We see it in the many peopole who are either friends or learnign to be friends with Auggie. In the end most everyone learns from him. His beautiful soul comes through and shines. Truly a book for all. Especially in the social climate of nowadays.

This book was awesome! I rooted for little Auggie the ENTIRE time, and I kept hoping that he wouldn't have to deal with the coldness that sometimes hits us all in this world. But, when Auggie does have to go through with LIFE, he does it with amazing strength. He's still 10, so of course, we see a bit of immaturity, but in general, the kid has more grace, understanding, and strength than any other character in the book. 
 I fell in love with the story in the very beginning. I cried, laughed, got annoyed, and laughed some more. 
 The characters are well written and I thought seeing Auggie in all of the different points of views was awesome. 
 I do have to say one thing, though: I hated Justin's POV. I have a really hard time reading when there is no capitalization in a sentence. The words honestly blur together for me, so I ended up grazing over his POV a bit, which was a bummer, because he did something really awesome in his section. But I got the gist that he was a good guy, and that's fine with me. 
 I really recommend reading this book! It was excellent.

A sweet story about how minds can change and what is inside is truly all that counts. I enjoyed the varying perspectives, as it gave richness to a genre that can be at times, single-layered. You will root for Auggie, his family, and friends!

Interesting and fast read. I liked the characters. It's a great story of what it means to truly be a friend as well as family. I want my kids to read this so we can all discuss it together. Family book group.

"Whose quiet strength has carried up the most hearts." 
 Wow. This book has shaken up my world. Awoken me from a deep slumber. It's like I'm seeing life from brand new eyes. Not only Auggie's story, but Summer's, Miranda's, Olivia's, Justin's and Jack's story all made me reflect about... everything. Made me question countless things in life. Helped me realize how much I have to be thankful for and how sometimes this world might get a bit too hard. But it's not about who has it the worst, it's about what we do to overcome our obstacles and become better people because of it. 
 This book is inspiring, memorable and it ignited a fire inside me I thought had perished long ago. Truly a master piece. Just by thinking of Auggie and everything he (and I) went through in this book, I feel braver, stronger and more capable of facing tomorrow's trials. So thank you Auggie. Thank you Via. Truly, all of the book's characters taught me something different in their own way, and for that I will always be grateful.

This is a Must Read for younger middle school kids. I especially like the use of multiple narrators, which, in and of itself is an important lesson for this age. Things can always be seen from a different viewpoint.
such a beautiful book. I am so in love with the main caracter :D <3

Ahhhhhh I don't know why I waited so long to read this. Thank god there is a movie coming out so that it got me to read it. I LOVED it. The power of positivity, and true kindness wins out. Auggie is a true hero and an inspiration for everyone. First 5 [?] of the year.

I like stories where families love each other. It was nice to read a story where the sister loved her brother and wasn't snarky to him. The book could have been a tragedy but instead leaves the reader with hope for the world.
This was a great, quick read. Really enjoyed this. Lots of depth for such a simple delivery.
This is one of those books that just warms the soul- a must read- I am insisting my boys read it- the message is to find ways to be kinder to others!

The writing felt a little clumsy at times--things seemed to tie up a little too conveniently at times, and conflict occasionally seemed a little forced for conflict's sake. One thing that really threw me off was a really sudden and unexpected POV change. I was already about 100 pages in and expected to be with Auggie the entire book when all of a sudden we were reading Via, and it threw me off a bit. I really didn't love her POV, and I thought it was just that I wasn't into the POV switch, but once her part ended and we reached Summer's POV things picked up again. Which really upset me, because I think Via's perspective could have been really important. I loved the other POV's, but for whatever reason Via's voice fell really flat, and the things she talked about didn't really add much to the story for me, which was disappointing. I think it could have been really great for the story, but it just didn't hit the mark. That being said, I did love this book. There were major problems with execution, but I adored the overall idea of the story. Auggie just touched my heart, and this book really did elicit so many emotions from me. It was heart-warming, painful, infuriating, and some of the people we met were just so beautiful.
This was a great book (and great to listen to as well)! But I could've done without the OVER THE TOP sappy ending. Would definitely recommend to anyone 5th grade and up.

This is a fantastic middle grade novel that everyone should read. August is a character that stands out, even as he sometimes crumbles inside from the abuse heaped on him by classmates as well as the average person who might pass him by. He has a sense of humor, intelligence, and a warm and loving family. His journey will stay with me for a long time.

Dear wonder, you have officially earned your spot on my favorite middle grade book. 
 Not only did you do a remarkable job of taking me back to middle school, but you sharpened my sense of empathy as well. Praise for such a emotional intriguing read! 
 Love You auggie doggie!

Absolutely Wonderful Book 
 It has everything Friendship, Family, Challenges, Forgiveness, Courage, Growing up. 
 It sure was a page turner and i loved all the characters and i wouldn't have liked it so much if it wasn't for all the different POV's (Except for Justin's). 
 This book is completely honest and true it was emotional and uplifting without being cliched. 
 It definitely had a great impact on me and it reminded me 
 "Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 This is one of those books that everybody should absolutely read.

This is a spoiler free review so don't worry! (: 
 I experienced several emotions as I was reading this book; from anger to sadness and then felt happy for a second and back to sadness. This book is about acceptance, friendship, and love. This book is simple and it doesn't have many plot twists yet it's still a very touching book. 
 The book is basically about August's life and how he struggles with school, in society and to make friends. August was born with an "extraordinary" face and he was homeschooled until one day his parents decided to put him into a regular school. The plot basically takes off from there. 
 It is also interesting that there are more than 3 POV in this book; from August himself, his sister, his sister's boyfriend, and his friends. This allows us to experience different feelings and emotions toward August and they're all relatable :) 
 Definitely a book that will be your quick read. It will warm your heart! :)

What an amazing book! A must read for everyone, especially the classroom. This was a book on CD for me and often I was so glad I wasn't driving, because I would have been too caught up in the story and often too emotional to concentrate. I loved how the author told August's story from multiple main characters, weaving in their story, their struggles, while keeping the focus on August. What a strong character and like the book said, what a lifter of hearts! Oh and the monthly precepts--yes!

I was debating giving this 4 stars because sometimes the writing did skew very young, but given the first person narration, that is to be expected in some of the chapters. I really did love this book, and marathoned it pretty quickly. I admit to having wept at the end, very touching and emotional to join August on his journey to a new school and through his 5th grade year. I had a great time with this book. Various topics are touched and dealt with very wonderfully in what it's like to be so young and dealing with being different and dealing with bullies.

Honest and brutal in parts. It's about loss, loneliness, compassion, bullying, friendships, empathy, the choice of kindness--anything but acceptance which is what I hoped for. Liked the quotes, not sure if all of them worked. 
 SPOILER: 
 Daisy's death and the cheese touch brought tears to my eyes. 
 August calls himself freak and orc among other things but I wanted to see a change--some growth. I also feel like he remained weak throughout. When will everyone realize August is as human as they are? This could have happened the moment he lost his hearing aids. I also feel the writing gets too clinical--re: Via's perspective on August'medical background. 
 This story needed something more to make the main character (August) a well-rounded individual. On one hand he's self-loathing but when does he see himself as more than just a person with a rare deformity? Yes, all these bad things happen to him but as a reader, I wanted everyone in the book to stop treating him like a victim and to realize that it doesn't matter if you are deformed, everyone has challenges. When does the silver lining stir some positivity in his life and provide strength? Where is the beauty beyond what he perceives? 
 Gave it 3-stars but it's more like 2.5.
what a wonder, that i read this book in only 3 hours. it's amazing, since i don't read much book as i used to years before. love this book. very much.
Increible.

Lovely little novel. 
 "I wish ... we could walk around and get to know each other before we got to see what we looked like under masks" (73).
Pero que cosa mas hermosa acabo de leer

This was a very honest and beautiful book with a realistic child protagonist. 
 I enjoyed it greatly and believe that it would be a great tool in teaching a child how to deal correctly with others and to act with compassion. 
 one of my favourite books I have read this year.
3.5 stars

This is a wonderful story about a boy with a disfigured face. He has a supportive family but is very scared of what other kids think. He has been homeschooled but he finally goes to school. The characters aren't predictable at all and I felt very moved by the book. It is uplifting and different. A must read.

I'm late to the Wonder party, but I'm so glad I still came. This book is fantastic! I had heard that it was great, and I was happy to see it on the Texas Bluebonnet List. 
 Told from various points of view, readers take a journey with ten-year-old Auggie (real name August) as he journeys to school for the first time. Born with facial disfigurement, Auggie is prepared for people to stare at him, but school turns out to be harder than expected---not just for Auggie but for his family and friends. 
 What I find amazing is that the author captures so many different characters perfectly: their voice, their feelings, their background. Each character is unique and adds to Auggie's story while telling their own. 
 Add them all together, and you get a beautiful story of friendship and triumph and, most of all, acceptance. 
 I'm going to promote this book heavily at school this coming year and encourage teachers to use it in their classrooms. The book's theme of choosing to be kind is one that is much needed in today's society for both the young and the old, and Palacio shares that lesson in a thought-provoking, wonderful way.

I don't usually cry when I read. I normally keep it together, but this book was a tear jerker. I'd recommend it to everyone for its message of looking beyond the exterior and reaching out in kindness to everyone.

Great story! Told from various points of view, the story is about a boy named Auggie who will be attending school for the first time having been home schooled until now. He will begin 5th grade at a private school. Auggie has severe facial deformities that make it difficult for other students to accept him. Auggie keeps his spirits up as he adjusts to school and his classmates adjust to him. Auggie is able to laugh at himself where others run away. He accepts his face and has learned to live the stares. This is the perfect story about accepting others for who they are.
My 8-year-old and 5-year-old listened to the audio book on our way to and from school. We all loved it.
A masterfully written, multiple narrative - this heartwarming story of perspective and acceptance is recommended to all readers - not just YA fans!
What a great book. I think it should be required reading for all middle schoolers!
Read this book again this week and it is in our top ten favorite books. Fantastic, fantastic, fantastic.

Loved this book. Great YA book that exposes many of the view points of the characters involved. It seems this past year has brought with it many books that expose the idea that physical make up does not display a persons true beauty and worth. Will definitely recommend to my students. 
 Reading it a second time and love it even more. Download Julian's chapter on your Kindle. August Pullman, I want to hug you!

Well okay then, just rip the beating heart out of my breast why don't you. 
 Eleven-year old August "Auggie" Pullman has a genetic defect that makes his face look like Darth Sidious after he gets burned by Sith lightning, and boy does he know it. 
 Rat boy. Freak. Monster. Freddy Krueger. E.T. Gross-out. Lizard face. Mutant. I know the names they call me. I've been in enough playgrounds to know kids can be mean. I know. I know. I know. 
 All he wants is to be an ordinary kid and that just isn't in the cards for him, but now he's 11 and his parents have decided that it's time for him to leave homeschooling and enter the fifth grade at Beecher Prep. 
 The book is told in first person first by Auggie, then his sister Via, his friends Summer and Jack, Via's boyfriend Justin, and Via's friend Miranda. (I do wish Julian's voice had been included.) The voices are so individual and so convincing that sometimes you forget this book was written by an adult. The texts between Auggie and Jack (and Jack's letters of apology) after the big fight are just priceless 
 Auggie: wud u really wan to kill urself if u wer me??? 
 Jack: no!!!!! I swear on my life but dude--I would want 2 kill myself if I were Julian :) 
 Auggie: lol yes dude we'r frenz agen. 
 Auggie is different, he is other, it's not something he can hide and it's not something anyone can ignore, and this whole book is pretty much a teachable moment whose message could be distilled into two words: Be kind. People behave badly at Halloween 
 I'd been talking to Julian about August. Oh man. Now I understood! I was so mean. I don't even know why. I'm not even sure what I said, but it was bad. It was only a minute or two. It's just that I knew Julian and everybody thought I was so weird for hanging out with August all the time, and I felt stupid. And I don't know why I said that stuff. I just was going along. I was stupid. I am stupid. 
 and with the plague and the shunning and at the nature retreat but the effort to ostracize and demonize Auggie fails utterly in the end. It's partly because of Auggie himself, who all he wants to be is ordinary and is anything but. It's partly because the staff and teachers of the school and some of the parents lead by example. But mostly it's because of the kids' own innate goodness. Maybe they didn't know it was there before they met Auggie but they know it now. (Although one of my book club members with a vision-impaired child who was picked on a lot in school was more than a little skeptical about just how good these kids are.) 
 Palacio saves the best for last with the Postcard Precepts. Milo's is so great, Julian's hints that he may have learned something more than his mother wanted him to this year, and of course, Auggie's 
 Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world. 
 Auggie sure did, with a little help from his family and friends. And I would like to have seen that production of Our Town. Highly recommended, with Kleenex. 
 One quibble: According to the author's acknowledgements this book was inspired by a girl she met in front of an ice cream store. Why isn't Auggie a girl? Why do the writers of childrens' books continue to favor male characters? It's like Katniss Everdeen never existed. The 5th grade teacher in my book club said, "But Dana, you can't get boys to read books about girls" and I said, "I've been hearing that since I was a kid. If writers and publishers--and teachers--keep catering to boy readers nothing will ever change." If girl readers are force marched through books about boys it seems only fair that boys should be force marched through books about girls. And I have made grown men read The Hunger Games, so what is the big damn deal here???

I was not sure what to expect with this book. Half of me was expecting a "disease of the week" type affair, a la Jodi Piccoult, but the cover drew me and I suspected it was something more than that. 
 The story is told from various points of view, the main one being August the terribly disfigured boy who's sweetness of nature seems almost too good to be true at times. There are also sections written from his sister's point of view of the same events, and her boyfriend, and August's best friend at school. 
 I thought the writer totally nailed the language and tensions of an elementary school environment, the bullying the ostracizing, the knitting together of friendships and the feelings of the people involved. I could feel for them all, and the fact that peoples' actions were not necessarily for the presumed reason, was a valuable lesson, without being at all "preachy." In short, it was a great read, an easy read as it was mainly told from childrens' point of view, but no less profound for that. Some would probably argue that it was all tied together too neatly, with a nice bow at the end to make it pretty, but you could tell that August's transition into high school would not be easy, however lovely things turned out at the end of 5th grade. It was just the first chapter of his challenging life, but an ultimately triumphant one.
Just a Happy feel good book.

Just a lovely story, heartwarming and inspiring. There were moments that broke my heart and made me cry. But, there were far more that made me laugh and feel the warm fuzzies. Palacio did such a wonderful job of making the children and their relationships feel real and relatable. I didn't expect to see shifting perspectives, but it just made me more excited about the story and each character's take on Auggie's first year in school. The ending was a bit over-the-top sweet; however, I actually kept anticipating something really really bad would happen, so I was pretty relieved when I got a (little too much of a) happy ending. Overall, great reading for the young and young at heart.

Have you watched a book spread from one kid to the next? It starts with just one reader connecting to it, telling a friend about it - then that friend has to read it. A few more try it out. This spring, Wonder has our classrooms buzzing with excitement as kids pass it from friend to friend. This is a book that is truly reaching kids, speaking to them, making them think - think about friendship, about bullies and about what it means to be kind. 
 my review: Great Kid Books

This is the type of book where I want to shove into the face of all the bullies in my school, and tell them this: 
 YOU SEE THIS GUYS. LEARN FROM THIS. 
 But sadly the world does not work that way, and superficial bullies will tend to remain ignorant. Especially to a masterpiece like this. 
 Anyone who reads this, and I do mean anyone, will take something out of this book and bring with them for a long time. R.J. Palacio exploits one of the biggest mistakes of humankind, and one we all plead guilty for: Judging someone by their looks. She takes this fault, and makes us learn that "when given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind,". Im utterly thankful for reading this book, and also thankful that R.J. Palacio has written a fantastic, and inspiring story about the mistakes us humans have always made, and makes us forcefully learn from them through the eyes of the young August Pullman. 
 Now brb while I cry over how beautiful this was.

'Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world'-Auggie <3 
 WOW ! This is probably the slowest I've ever read a book but not because I hated it or was bored at any point but the complete opposite I loved it so much I just didn't want it to end truly one of the best books I've ever read in my entire life :-) 
 It follows the story of a little boy called Auggie. ( who I wanted so much to be real ) Auggie is you're average boy apart from the fact he has a a serious facial disfigurement and this book chronicle his first time in fifth grade at a proper school his parents have kept him home schooled up to this point to keep him safe ! You here from various P.O.V's throughout this book including his sister and friends he makes at school ... This book made me laugh, cry and everything in between and I will definitely be re-reading this endlessly :-) x
Best book of the year. That good, yes.

Well, I just finished it and love it so much. 
 I love the way Mrs Palacio tell the story, love to see it from Jack and also Summer. 
 It must be absolutely difficult for Auggie to live his life, born with such a condition, but love what Justin say: 
 "You purchase a ticket when you're born. and it's all just random whether you get a good ticket or a bad ticket.. It's all just luck...... 
 no, no, it's not all random, if it really was random, the universe would abandon us completely. and the universe doesn't. it takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see...... the universe takes care of all its birds" 
 It's true, don't compare your life to others because you have no idea how their life is all about. But somehow, you have a reason why you're born to this world. There must be a very good reason.
Everyone ahould read this book specially kids. It was a delight to read and a very special message!

Sheer perfection. This one will stay with me a lifetime, and ties for the best book I have read this year (so far) with The Fault in Our Stars. I did notice that both books have blue covers, the main characters names are similar (August and Augustus), and both are books about tough subjects with super shiny hope-filled centers that will change your life for the better when you read them. 
 In a perfect world, this would be required reading for all kids in grades 5-7.

Sometimes when books receive heaped up praise, when I sit down to read them, the books fall short of all the praise. This one was as good as the praise I read. The author carried me along with the story and by page 300, I was both getting weepy and getting out my pen to write down quotes (those two qualities in a book get me every time). However, as much as I like the book and will probably buy it (I checked this one out of the library), I'm glad someone on Goodreads critiqued both how the antagonist was treated and something that happens at the end (which in the interest of not spoiling the ending, I won't reveal). The person critiquing had a valid point: Is it right to bully and hate a bully? As for the ending, a slight question rose up in my mind as well, but I thought the author explained what was happening well with this quote from Henry Ward Beecher: "He is the greatest whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own." Also I just now read the bully's precept at the end of the book.
I gave this book 3 and a half stars because I just didn't have the connection to this book. I think everyone who likes ya should read it. I enjoyed this book very much.

The quote mentioned in the book about being a little kinder than necessary is one of my favorite quotes. You truly never know the battle someone else might be fighting & your simple kind words or actions can mean the world to them. This book teaches so many great lessons, not only for kids, but adults as well. Sometimes we get so caught up with trying to "be cool" and wanting to fit in that we forget about other's feelings. It's so important to instill in children at the youngest age possible to be nice and accepting to EVERYONE... your face and body are just the wrapper covering the real treasure within.... your heart and character are the parts that can truly make you beautiful.

What a delightful book! Extremely well written and a joy to read. Thank you Tyler and Mandy for recommending it and buying it for me. If you liked "The Wednesday Wars" and "OK for Now" by Gary Schmidt, then you'll LOVE "Wonder."
Not my type of book but I couldn't stop reading
I love it :')

Read this about a month ago after someone recommended it to me. I must confess I wasn't too keen initially cuz I'm not one to take YAF seriously. However, to say that the book exceeded my expectations would be an understatement. Lovely li'l tome that is sure to tug at your heart-strings, especially if you've got a young 'un (as I do). Also having reported a case of Treacher Collins Syndrome which is quite a rare facial disorder, I can't begin to fathom the kind of trauma and mental baggage afflicting someone like 'Auggie'. So yeah, well done all 'round. 
 So you might well ask, why only three stars? For starters, this is precisely, the kind of book that is really not that difficult to write. Now the author writes well and has a keen sense of humour, but writing this wouldn't/couldn't really be much of a challenge for obvious reasons. Secondly, 'kindness' is oversold over 'self dignity' and that makes this book a tad preachy. I could cite a coupla other reasons but minor quibbles do not really take too much away from the sheer 'feel good' factor that the book manages to evoke in you. A definitive change of scene for yours truly and one I quite enjoyed.
Made me cry. Brilliant

Since the seventies, I have stuck firmly to my resolve to avoid Issue books; while I applaud the earnest and well-meant wish to highlight these various aspects of human suffering, I discovered that enduring yet more misery and suffering through fiction was not exactly bringing me much enlightenment. And definitely no pleasure. (Also, since even earlier, I have been very wary of any book that has a Beloved Dog, because Beloved Dogs never seem to make it to the last page.) 
 I avoided this book for nine months, because I knew it was an Issue book--further, one that had a Beloved Dog as well as the issue, in this case a boy born with a rare genetic marker that resolves into severe facial distortion. 
 But I finally gave in, as one too many friends said, "No really, you need to read this one." 
 So I did. 
 They were right. 
 I began the book at bedtime . . . and discovered I was four chapters from the end when my eyes began burning about three a.m. 
 The story is divided between several voices, but central is fifth-grade Auggie, sent to school for the first time. What happens, how, why, who changes and how, takes up the rest of the story. There are a zillion reviews here on Goodreads, most of which indicate that others closed the book feeling better about their fellow human than they did when they opened the book, which is no small achievement. 
 Rather than repeat the raves, let me conclude with the most significant quote (and there are a lot of quotes in the book), about the nature of greatness: He is the greatest whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own.
This was a very moving story.

Oh, this book. I loved this book. LOVED. First, I read it in two days, which I haven't done to any book since before I had kids. If I could give this book more than 5 stars I would. I think Wonder should be required reading for all middle school and HS students, as well as parents and anyone who has a heart. This story makes you think about you as a person. It makes you think about your kids and what kind of people they will be. This book made me cry in a good way. I cannot say enough wonderful things about it. I wish it wasn't over because I want to know more about August. All the characters were so real. Love, love, love.

If I had to choose between this book and "The One and Only Ivan," I would probably die. 
 I love this book because life is like this. People feel this way and love this way and hurt this way and do weird things this way. People are horrible and wonderful. I loved Auggie and I want to hug him. His character development is perfect, so subtle that you barely see it until it's already happened, and then you're so happy and proud you could burst - proud of him and everyone else. This book is perfect. 
 Goddamnit, R.J., why did you do that to Daisy? I hate you and I'll buy every book you ever write for the rest of your life.
Loved this heartwarming story that reminds us that beauty is only skin deep, but unkindness can cut to the bone.
Just as its title, Wonder is a wonderful book. A must read prior to watching its film..

This book is about a 5th grade boy named August who has a horribly deformed face. He goes 
 to middle school after being raised in a protected and loving home environment. The author presents various viewpoints--Auggie himself, his sister and various friends. The story is very realistic, 
 yet positive. I loved the quote "Shall we always try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" 
 "Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." I want to have a copy 
 of this book in every one of my elementary libraries.

In floods of tears. 
 I rarely deviate from reading adult books now, but every once in a while, a book like this is good for the soul. 
 " 'Shall we make a new rule of life... always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?' " 
 Auggie Pullman won't make you weep out of pity but of awe. The characters are all well-written and have real life sentiments and emotions. It inspires and challenges readers to stay true, have courage and to always choose kind. Can't reiterate enough. 
 Loved this!

This book really is sweet and endearing, and Auggie is a character that it's impossible not to root for. This would be a great whole class novel to raise the issue of how we treat people who look different than us, and it ultimately reinforces that the most important way to celebrate humanity is to embrace and cherish these differences, no matter what they look like to our eyes.

I adored this title. As a YA librarian, it's wonderful to get a break from the gritty realistic fiction and often depressing dystopias that pervade the shelves right now. I'm sure my high school students will enjoy this.

Great story - felt so very real. Also, I thought I knew what to expect after the first 50 pages or so, but it definitely moved in a variety of different directions throughout. Highly recommend to just about anyone.
I wish I had read this as a 5th grader!
We listened to this one in the car on our Spring Break trip to Virginia. It's still a very good, heart wrenching book that I'll be reading and recommending for years to come.

From the book jacket 
 August (Auggie) Pullman was born with a facial deformity that prevented him from going to a mainstream school - until now. He's about to enter fifth grade at Beecher Prep, and if you've ever been the new kid, then you know how hard that can be. The thing is Auggie's just an ordinary kid, with an extraordinary face. But can he convince his new classmates that he's just like them, despite appearances? 
 My reactions 
 This is a wonderful debut novel dealing with bullying and courage. Auggie is an endearing 10-year-old, who, despite his extraordinary face, is really just an ordinary kid; he likes ice cream, riding his bike, Star Wars, and his X-Box. But he's been sheltered at home and doesn't have all the social skills he needs to navigate the "deep-end-of-the pool" that middle school represents. Still, he's courageous, resourceful, and knows he can rely on at least one friend who has seen past his face to the find the great kid that he is. 
 The novel is told from various perspectives. We hear from Auggie, his older sister Via, her boyfriend Justin, and Auggie's friends Jack and Summer. There are scenes that broke my heart and made me want to jump into the pages of the book to hug Auggie and assure him that things would get better. There are scenes that had me cheering for Auggie and Jack as they took a stand. The ultimate message is clear: We should all strive to be kinder than necessary. It is also uplifting: Everyone in the world should have a standing ovation at least once in their lives. 
 A couple of things in the story did bother me. No adult stepped in to stop the bullying. Yes, I realize that Auggie and his friends refused to go to any adult to report what was happening, but it's clear by the end of the novel that at least one adult recognized the pattern of behavior, and apparently did nothing. I was also bothered by Via's troubles as she also found herself an outsider in a new school. Parents that were portrayed as sensitive and nurturing seemed to not notice at all that their daughter was struggling and so very unhappy. There were times when I felt worse for Via than for Auggie. 
 But this is a book written for a middle-school audience and I think the message is one that is empowering to children. You can choose to be nice despite how others treat you, and your worth is not dependent on how popular you are, or on who finds you attractive. Important precepts for all of us to adopt.
Amazing story! Highly recommend to anyone who loves children's books, who has ever been a child, who has ever felt like an outsider or a weirdo, basically everyone should read this book.
http://www.goodbookfairy.com/2013/01/...

I read this book back in 2014 without going through any reviews. Yeah, I just picked it up and started reading. But for last few days when I saw a lot of people adding it, I felt like I should also express my feelings about this book. 
 Wonder is story of a 10 years old wonder boy named Auggie. Why is he a wonder boy? Because he showed the boldness that many of us cannot even think of! 
 Nowadays people are always so wary about their looks, which has almost built up a common conception that appearance is everything. If you don't look good, you are not fit for the society. 
 Obtuse people with their absurd hypothesis! 
 Auggie's face was deformed due to some facial disorder. So, he looked a bit different from other kids. And this made his life almost unbearable! He used to be homeschooled by his mom until he started his 5th grade in a local school. 
 New place, new people, new experiences.....For Auggie, everything seemed quite unfriendly and this was supposed to be happen in a society with those so called appearance theory! 
 A 10 years old, getting a creepy look from everyone around him is not a very pleasing scenario. So Auggie was really upset. And he was devastated when he finds out that the boy, who was pretending to be his friend, is actually badmouthing about his appearance to others. This leaves him in tears. 
 But he copes up with everything, makes new friends, actual friends and some incidents make the people around him to believe that he is like everyone else. 
 Well, yeah, it ends like a fairy tale because people love stories with happy endings. But in real life the picture can be somehow different. 
 Although, its' genre is middle grade or young adult or children, it is a perfect book for everyone. I believe after reading this book, everyone one of us will feel bad for any kind of criticism ever made by us on someone's appearance. 
 Wrapping up the review with a quote from this book which I really love- 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 Indeed! A little appreciation to others won't do any harm to you. So, I never felt being a miser in appreciating people! ^_^

Such a wonderfully written book! The main character in this book, August, was born with facial abnormalities and, as a 5th grader, is entering public schools for the first time. Up until now his mom has home schooled him. Everyone in the family is concerned with the new adjustment and August can't decide whether to be excited or scared. August discovers true friendship and realizes just how wonderful he is.
Heartwarming.

What can I say? This book rocked. The author found a nice balance between character voice and tone, making me feel the various personalities of the characters while still keeping a cohesive whole that didn't feel beneath me, for lack of a better term. Good quick read.
Charming & uplifting!
I loved this book!

I enjoyed this book- easy to read; I finished it in a day. I like the premise of the book and I want lots of kids to read it, but I don't know that they will really take it to heart. Kindness counts and it really matters, but in order for kids to get that, they have to really live it, just like August, Jack and the other kids did in the woods. That's what makes the tides turn. I know our big push at school this year has been kindness. I have said it over and over the past week - practice kindness. Reading about it is one this, but actually understanding it is another. Maybe I am being too harsh about this book - it is sweet, but I just don't know how meaningful it is to kids without actually experiencing.
Lovely and touching. Everyone should read this book! It could teach us all to be a little bit kinder.

Wonder is a simple yet powerful read about a 5th grader Auggie, who has major facial deformities and how he feels and acts in a society that often judges based on looks. 
 Wonder is 'Auggies story' - but we also read from 7 (I think) other perspectives (family and friends) to create a full picture of how everyone was feeling and acting and why - it's quiet clever how well it worked. 
 I would recommend this book for anyone from around 10 years to 99 plus - it's a rare book IMO that can be read/enjoyed and be educational to such a wide age group.
Loved it.
A quick, enjoyable read.

This was a great book! I'd totally recommend it for a variety of reasons, but from a writer's perspective it handled multiple perspectives very well (which can be difficult to do). These narratives overlapped, but also enhanced the plot really well. I think this is a neat book for anyone. A pretty quick read, but it goes by really fast!

i am absolutely and irrevocably in love with this book! i just have to have a hardbound copy of this for my personal library.. it will leave an imprint in your heart once you read the book. way to start my 2014 reading list. another one for my favorite book list!

Bueno, ?por donde empiezo? 
 Sinceramente, cuando acabe el libro, no tenia muy en claro si me habia gustado, o no. 
 Veredicto: Me gusto. 
 Pero no se, siento que falto algo, el final me parecio de lo mas....no puedo decir tonto porque no lo es, y tampoco apresurado porque es un buen final pero... 
 Ok, mejor empecemos con las cosas que me gustaron: los personajes. 
 El libro se divide en 8 partes, y cada parte es narrada por un diferente personaje, eso hace que el libro no se vuelva aburrido bueno menos la ultima parte que sinceramente no la soporte , los personajes que mas me gustan fueron Via (que es la hermana de Auggie) y Summer. 
 Pero tambien habia personajes que no entiendo el porque se narraba desde su punto de vista, ejemplo: el novio de Via. 
 A lo largo del libro hay varios problemas con diferentes personajes, y algunos de estos, me parecieron que en ningun momento del libro se resolvieron y otros que se resolvieron de manera muy tonta. 
 Sin embargo, lo recomiendo :) 
 ...oh, por cierto me ha encantado de que autora se la pace citando canciones o libros al comienzo de algunas partes del libro. 
 "Si de verdad quieres algo en esta vida, tienes que trabajar. Y ahora calla. 
 que van a anunciar los numeros de la loteria" xD

Knigata razkazva za zhivota na 10-godishno momche, rodeno s mnogo seriozni litsevi deformatsii, preminalo prez desetki plastichni operatsii, no izglezhdashcho vse taka uzhasno. Knigata proslediava p'rvata mu godina v normalno uchilishche, k'deto se sbl'skva s predrazs'd'tsi, podigravki, svikva s novata sreda i s'shcho taka namira priiateli i zapochva da se chuvstva uiutno v kozhata si. 
 Knigata e naistina mnogo sladka i topla. Glavite sa mnogo k'si (1-2 s.), ezik't e izkliuchitelno prost - kato za 8+. Knigata e razdelena na chasti ot po 30-40 s., v koito se reduva razkaz't za tazi p'rva uchebna godina v osnovnoto uchilishche - p'rvo razkazva glavniiat geroi, sled tova sestra mu, sled koeto edno po edno razlichni detsa ot uchilishche... Na v'zrastnite dumata ne e dadena - avtorkata e reshila da zapazi istoriiata, razkazana samo ot detska gledna tochka. Trogatelen e konflikt't mezhdu tova kak se chuvstva glavniiat geroi (kato normalno momche) i kak go v'zpriemat drugite (chudovishche). Interesna e i glednata tochka na drugite detsa - niakoi direktno go zakleimiavat, na drugi im e m'chno za nego, no ne pokazvat simpatiite si (i dori se prestruvat pred priiatelite si, kato priglasiat v podigravkite, v'preki che v'treshno chuvstvat, che ne sa pravi), treti p'k prev'zmogvat p'rvonachalniia shok i uspiavat da vidiat momcheto otv'd viziiata mu. No obshcho vzeto tova e motiv't - da priemesh sebe si i drugiia tak'v, kak'vto e.
I had a hard time getting into this story, but I liked it by the end.

El libro es maravilloso, creo que todos deberian leerlo. El unico PERO son los capitulos de Justin, creo que la autora se arriesgo para mal con la escritura de ese capitulo, visualmente me molesto que no tuviera mayusculas y eso mismo, provoco que para mi, el personaje de Justin pasara sin pena ni gloria... creo que si no existiera en la historia, daria exactamente lo mismo!

This book deserves a standing ovation! I was afraid it was just going to be a really depressing book. Boy was I wrong! I learned so many great lessons from this book like to be kinder than necessary. I listened to this book and I think it would be a great audio book for a whole family to listen to.

I loved this book! I began reading it because it is nominated as one of the Carnegie Book Award books and I've set up a shadowing group in school. I left it until last because I didn't think it would be as good as everyone says it is...boy was I wrong! Auggie has severe facial deformities and has been sheltered by his parents for his whole life. It comes as a shock to him when they persuade him that he needs to try going to school. This was such a moving story in many ways, but also very funny. I love the way that Auggie touches the lives and hearts of everyone he meets

Such an amazing book:) You can't help but really connect with Auggie and his family. Palacio does a wonderful job creating a story around middle school kids and the difficulty of growing through that age. Heart-warming. I am a librarian and read this book from a recommendation of one of my 5th grade Lunch Bunch (reading club at a local school during lunch time). She said it was her favorite book. I understand why.
This is a book everyone should read. I can't believe I literally cried my heart out every turn of a page.This is such a gem.

I have always said that I never ever want to relive Middle School because it is the worse and this book shows that but through the eyes of a boy who has a disability...well more of a rare face deformation. I felt that this book does a great job with showing all sides of what it would be like or is like to be Auggie (boy with deformed face) and also how his family deals and feels with this. I did not want to put this book down and think every middle school kid should read this book. If I were a middle school teacher (yeah right, anxiety just thinking about that) I would assign this book for sure. Hopefully the movie will be just as good as the book =)
What a lovely little book everyone should read this it deals with so many issues and really opens the eyes to not only the cruelty but the kindness of children. Beautiful

Brilliant POV changes in this novel about a child with severe facial birth defects. How he sees himself, as well as his sister, friends and others. Loved the dimensions that approach gave the story. Voices were so realistic and all were sympathetic. Lovely family is protrayed in this story. Made me laugh and made me cry. I wanted to know them.
"Wonder"ful!

I want everyone i know to read this book its heartwarming without being sickly and exceptionally well written 
 Anyone who wants a copy let me know and i'll lend you mine
Real review to come hopefully around the end of next month. I'm definitely going to start writing them as my New Year's resolution but I want to release them in batches. Idk.

It's a cute book that delivers a vital message about tolerance especially important for the young readers. 
 I especially liked the different voices or points of view particularly August and his sister, and found the portrayal of what is like to be a disabled kid, and the family of one very authentic. 
 I mean not that he was disabled he was just born with a syndrome, because otherwise he was a perfectly normal kid and that is in my opinion the most important lesson of all. 
 However, the book does not follow a specific plot line and for that I felt a bit disappointed.

Originally posted on A Life Pixelated. 
 Where do I even begin with a book that has quite possibly managed to change all of my feelings towards books just by reading it? When I requested Wonder from NetGalley, I thought that I was going to read it and end up enjoying it since the few people I know have given it good reviews. I never, ever expected that I was going to fall in love with this book the way that I did. Not only did Wonder give me the chance to reflect on the way that I think about certain aspects of life, but it also made me laugh and cry from happiness and sadness and all the -nesses in between. 
 Ten-year-old August has been through more in his life than half a dozen people and he's still going strong. Suffering from a chromosome deficiency, he was born with severe facial disfiguration that twenty-seven surgeries hasn't managed to fix. His parents finally decide that August should go to school, and enroll him in a private school where the principal has three other kids who've volunteered to help him adjust and watch out for him. 
 This book is definitely listed as one of my favourite reads of 2012. Probably the absolute favourite, right up there with The Fault in Our Stars by John Green. I stayed up until 6am to try and finish Wonder, and was so disappointed that sleep needed to take priority to reading. Reading about Auggie's life through his point of view as well as others' (his sister, Via, his best friend, Summer, his other best friend, Jack, Via's beau, Justin, and Via's best friend, Miranda) gave me the chance to fall in love with, not only the plot, but each and every character just because I got a chance to see how they interacted in the life of Auggie and his family. 
 My favourite person (but least favourite point of view, unfortunately) was Via's boyfriend's, Justin. While I really disliked the way that Justin's part was written in the same aspect of David Levithan's Will Grayson (worse, actually, because I wasn't sure where the characters were speaking at some points) I really enjoyed the way that he had with words, and the feelings that he had for Oliva were the most beautiful in the world. I found myself wanting to cry a little bit when I reached the end of his part, when he said: 
 "olivia reminds me of a bird sometimes, how her feathers get all ruffled when she's mad. and when she's fragile like this, she's a little lost bird looking for its nest. so i give her my wings to hide under." 
 I know the focus of the story really isn't about Via, but I really, really liked the way that her character was written. She was so understanding and protective of her brother, where most teenagers would have been somewhat selfish in that aspect. She never asked for anything, never tried to have her wants and needs taken care of first. She put everything aside for Auggie, and I found that to be the best part of the novel. Even though the focus of Wonder was on August, I found myself loving Via most when it came to the characterisations. 
 Speaking of August, that boy... He's amazing. I can't even begin to imagine going through twenty-seven surgeries and then being brave enough to go to school and try and be normal. Being two years younger than everyone else was enough for me to hate school, so I can't even imagine what it must have been like for him. August is such a strong, wonderful boy, and while they mistreated him so much in the beginning of the novel, he grew, as did those who hurt him and those who helped him. I loved seeing the transformation when these kids realised that it wasn't about how their friend looked; it was about who he was as a person. 
 Wonder is a book that will probably always live with me, and I can't imagine a day where I'll find myself completely forgetting that I've ever read it. It's one of those books that touches your soul and makes you realise that there's more to humanity than what's on the surface. If you have this on your to-read list, or even if you don't, stop what you're doing and go pick it up, because I guarantee that by the time you're done reading it, you'll realise just how wonderful Wonder actually is.
Five stars are not enough!!!!
"todo el mundo deberia recibir una ovacion del publico puesto en pie al menos una vez en su vida, porque todos vencemos al mundo" Auggie. Muy cierto

I've been wanting to read this book for months. I've seen its mysterious cover on tens of blogs. I've read tens of reviews of it, all of them raves. 
 And now I've finally gotten around to it. Wow. All I can say is, If you want children to understand what it's like to be different, share this book with them. Powerful story.

August Pullman is about to attend a proper school for the first time in his life and middle school can be nerve wrecking for so many reasons. This book left me with a huge smile and feeling general goodwill to my fellow human beings, which is nice to get once in a while...
I loved having the other points of view in the book alongside Auggie's. And I also loved Auggie--how could come out ofn this book not loving him?
I read it 3 times and I love it so much, I can go back and re-read it all over again
All the feels!!!!
Every kids needs to read this book.
All of the feels.
I absolutely loved this book, and can't believe I waited so long to read it. This will be a book I will read to my children, and recommend to parents and kids at the library.
I liked how this book was told from different points of view. Wonderful story!

I don't know how to put down in words how much I loved this book. It was just one of those books that leave you breathless, you seriously don't want to believe it's over. It's one of those books that you will grasp on forever and never forget it because you will always remember it. This book, wow. This book! THIS BLOODY BOOK!! R.J. Palacio wrote down the feelings of a thousand kids who feel what August feel and have something similar to what he has and it's so hearbreaking as you read it because you know that these feelings are real, and that this does happen, that there are mean people in this world. I hated reading this book in public, I'm on the train and I open up to the page and I'm either trying to hold back the tears or trying not to laugh. We're inside the mind of a 10 year old boy who is entirely mature for his age and who is surrounded by people who try to avoid reality when he lives in it and understands. He understands that people turn the other way when they look at him, understands the reason why people are mean to him. We also read other people's point of views but it's all associated with August and I absolutely love how much love they share with him and it warms my heart. This book is phenomenal. Absolutely incredible. Just a beautiful, heartwarming, heartbreaking read. It takes you on a whole rollercoaster ride of emotions and I love it when a book affects you so much, and no it's not just a book. It's a voice that is speaking out for those who are afraid to speak out with a condition similar to this. It's to prove to the world that they are normal human beings, that they should be treated the same. That words hurt. This book will forever stay in my heart and it was such a pleasure reading this book!!

6/14--Re-reading again in preparation to read Julian's chapter. Third time is STILL a charm. 
 5/13 Just as good the second time around! 
 This amazing MG story made me laugh and cry. It is the story of Auggie, a fifth grader new to school. He was previously homeschooled due to multiple surgeries to try and correct a severe craniofacial abnormality. However, the surgeries haven't done much to fix Auggie's face and he is still a frightening sight to many. The author did a wonderful job of showing not only Auggie's inner feelings but also those of his friends and family. Palacio used the multiple POV in this book to perfection. I have heard this is a possible Newbery contender and I would say.... YES!... Please! This is a great book and would probably be most enjoyed by 4th - 8th graders.
This is a great example of book with sense and lesson. It's truly an eye-opener.
The kind of book that warms your heart and makes you see the good in the world more clearly than before. Truly inspirational :)

This was a sweet book with a heart-warming message. I really enjoyed the different perspectives the story is told from. At first I was disappointed when I realized it was changing pov, but then I loved hearing how the events affected different characters in the story. It gave more depth to Auggie's (the main character's) life and experiences. 
 Although it might have a bit too much of a "happily ever after" ending, I loved the author's perspective that, "there are more good people on the earth than bad people, and the good people watch out for each other." Believing that gives us hope in this crazy world, and maybe inspires each of us to try a little harder to be "good people" and have more faith in each other. 
 The only thing I didn't like about the story, was the focus on 10 year old "dating". I'm sure it happens in "the real world", but 10 year olds are just too immature for relationships and the frequent discussion of it just rubbed me wrong. I got over it, but wish it could have been left out, or at least downplayed a little more. 
 Here's one last favorite quote from the book that sums up the overall message to me: "...if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 I'll be reading this book again with my kids soon.

Such a great book! I used it as the mentor text for my 4th grade reading and writing workshop. My students were captivated by Ms. Palacio's writing style and by Auggie! It was the perfect springboard for discussing bullying and being unique. I continued with this theme by reading "Becoming Naomi Leon."
This is a tear jerker. I loved it! I would recommend this book to everyone.

Wonder was simply enjoyable and wonderful. 
 You know those books that you thought would be quite childish for you? Well, that was what i thought at first. Since it was written in a kid's perspective and known as a children book, I thought maybe it wouldn't be one of those books that would have a strong impact on me. Oh boy I was so wrong. It taught me so many lessons. I simply loved it. Love love love it. This is probably a children book that I enjoyed so much. 
 I especially enjoy being able to see things in August's perspective. The way others treat him like he is special but all along he is as normal as me and you. Also, August is so cute and hilarious!
