 Another thing I love is how we are able to see the story progress from the perspective of all the different characters. This just makes things much more relatable because you might be any one of those other characters. I especially love how great his sister is towards him. She is so understanding, mature and deserves respect. A lot of respect. The flow of the story is just nice. Not too fast. Not too slow. You can just walk through August and his life as he starts school. 
 At the end of the day, the main moral of the story is being kind to one another. Going through the journey with August has reinforced the importance of being kind to others. How everyone treated him as a plague initially and finally being able to accept him and respect him. :') 
 Words to live by: "Kindness than necessary".
Simple, enduring, practice kindness... certainly this is a modern classic.

This is a great book to teach younger kids about empathy and kindness. I would say it's appropriate for 5th-7th graders. The key aspect that really supports empathy is that the story unfolds from a variety of viewpoints around August Pullman's transition from home school to a real 5th grade class. August has a severe facial condition and by telling his story from multiple voices, it truly shows how we can all overcome differences and the difficulties facing the protagonist on a daily basis. A great teaching book. It is simply written but it's authentic.

A MUST READ for everyone, young and old. It's simply heartbreaking and heartwarming. Great lessons on empathy, sympathy, and friendship. It truly teaches you how to walk a mile in someone else's shoes before you speak or act. 
 August is such a great, courageous and aware young boy. I wish parents and children alike knew and understood how to truly be authentic people like this young man. 
 My kids (6-12) loved it and wouldn't let me turn it off. 
 Great life lessons!

"If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary--the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God."
Delightful!

Being kinder than necessary isn't always easy. This is a wonderful story about humanity, kindness, and friendship. It's funny, sweet, and heart-opening. I'm not sure I was as self-aware as the kids in this book are, but I appreciate their insight. :) HIGHLY recommended reading.

Everyone needs to read this book. Everyone. 
 August has a facial deformity and is terrified of going to school for the first time. As you can imagine, it's not easy for him. 
 I love that each section was from a different person's point of view. You can really see how each person (those who know him well and those who don't) is affected by him and his deformity. 
 I'll admit, I got a bit chocked up. It's a fantastic and quick read and everyone needs to read it.
I really enjoyed this sweet little book! Choose kind.
Good story but played to the emotions a bit too much.
Incredible and beautiful. A wonderful coming-of-age middle grade book that reminds us all how important it is to be kinder and braver than we are.

When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind. 
 I had big expectations for this story, given the huge amount of good reviews that it has. But it was even better than I expected, I've surprised myself smiling and believing in humankind like I haven't done in a long time. 
 Marvelous. 
 But the best way to measure how much you've grown isn't by inches or the number of laps you can now run around the track, or even your grade point average - though those things are important, to be sure. It's what you've done with your time, how you've chosen to spend your days, and whom you have touched this year. That, to me, is the greatest measure of success.

This was everything that I thought it would be. Very well done. I completely understand why this book would be a community book for schools to read together. Although, as an educator I did cringe a bit with how freely teachers and administration talked about other students and their medical needs. 
 Spoilers ahead: 
 My issue is with the Julian chapter in the special edition. Sometimes a bully is just a bully. Sometimes, kids don't have a pattern of irrational fear and night terrors to explain away that mean. Sometimes, there isn't a grandma who can tell a quick story about Nazi occupation and dynamically change a character. Sometimes, bullies are so hurt themselves it takes more than a French vacation to set things right. And sometimes, kids are just mean. I thought this chapter hurt an otherwise strong story. I'm not disagreeing with the decision to include a Julian chapter, I just would have preferred to be handled in a more realistic way.

I loved this book simply because of the message. Be kind to each other. This author does an incredible job of writing from different perspectives, and shows how kindness, compassion, and forgiveness can make all the difference.

Me encanto la historia, es bonita, simple, me hizo emocionar siempre. Pero si tengo que admitir que la manera en la que esta narrado no me encanto, hay algo en la forma en la que brinca de personajes narradores que no me convencio del todo. Es un libro sencillo y facil de leer.
this book is so beautiful and everyone should read it. I'm also drowning in my own tears.

Wonder is one of the best books that I have ever read. It had a beautiful storyline, with characters that anyone can relate to and get attached to. It was one of those stories that I didn't want to put down, and I am not afraid to admit that my eyes filled up at a few points. I could read this book over and over and I don't think I could tire of it. I recommend it to anyone, and I would love for more children's books to be written from this truthful approach. It was powerful yet simple. It deserves more than 5 stars. I loved it.
This should be required reading for everyone.

I enjoyed this book about a boy who is, well, a regular boy. He looks a little different from other boys, and he's had some health issues, but he's a regular boy with a best friend, parents who love him to death, a big sister who wants to occasionally be selfish, and a dog. At times, I had a hard time remembering that most of the characters are fifth graders and not high schoolers; I'm not sure if fifth graders are more mature than I remember being or if this is a case of "Dawson's Creek syndrome," but the aforementioned boy, Auggie, brings out a lot of the WONDER you'd expect to find in a fifth grader.
Great book!

"The universe takes care of all its birds. " This is a wonderful story about kindness, courage, and friendship. I think what I enjoyed most though was this sentiment from Justin. The author does an excellent job in detailing the challenges each character faces. While some are more visible than others, everyone has their own burdens that they hope to have the courage to face and somehow Auggie is able to help them all in his own way.

This should be required reading for every middle school student. Such a compelling story told from the point of view of August, his sister and some of his friends. It is an emphatic reminder of how to treat each other with genuine kindness.

Such a wonderful, positive book that any age would benefit from reading. A very fulfilling read. 
 *Clintonville Book Club*

So warm and touching. The author is quite good at grabbing all the emotion details of the characters and I feel like automatically depicting all these pretty little faces in my mind. Everyone has his angle and they all make sense. Just feel so human reading it. No saints here, everyone got his bright and dark sides being sympathetic, fragile, phony, smart and sensitive. It's not some unexpected story but sometimes you need ordinary stories warm like this.

Great read for all ages. Reminded me a little of Freak the Mighty. All the characters are well drawn and pretty believable. I think my new life motto is going to be "Everyone deserves a standing ovation at least once in their life."

I loved this book!! August, the main character, was born with face that is deformed ... he is so surprisingly likable, relatable, vulnerable and funny. This story is told from Augusts' perspective as well as the many different perspectives of the other characters in the book. It is done so well that you get the whole story of August starting 5th grade in a public school in NYC that highlight his trials and challenges. I read somewhere that this is being made into a movie... can't wait to see it!
Beautiful story! I laughed and cried:) Great book to share with kids about acceptance and friendship.
This book was beautiful, powerful, sad, funny. And mostly, authentic about the power we have to be amazing, to be kind.

Auggie is in the fifth grade when he decides to go to a public school. He's been homeschooled up until now, and if making new friends in a brand new school isn't hard enough, Auggie is very different because he was born with a facial deformity. This is his story. 
 I was surprised by how much I loved this book. Told from the perspectives of a wide variety of people, Wonder is a book about a little boy born with a heavy facial deformity, and his decision to go to a public school. A wonderful coming-of-age story, and gives hope for the good in people. Heartwarming, beautiful and strong. Character development was extremely well done, and her vast spectrum of personalities was accurately portrayed. One second you could want to knock the teeth out of a character, the next you want to hug him to death. Definitely glad to have this in my private library.

Breathtaking. Wonder is a inspiring novel about a physically deformed boy that wants nothing but to simply fit in. Is that too much to ask? R.J Palacio takes readers through this question as August travels through the twists and turns of being different while at the same time noticing the impossibility of being "normal".

A down to earth and realistic exploration into living with a physical disability told from multiple perspectives. I loved how this book made me feel empathetic rather than sympathetic towards each of the characters. Life can be tough for a kid who has a physical deformity, but it can also be tough for their friends and family. Each of the perspectives had a distinctly different voice, which was enhanced by the audiobook narrator. I'd been planning to read this for ages and I'm glad I finally made the time.

I read this book at the insistence of my 11 year old son. All I can say is I waited too long. This is one of the most beautiful books I have read in a long time and it's a wonder unto itself that this book can be appreciated by 11 year olds and 40 something year olds alike. I read most of this during a 4 hour plane ride after vacation - a bit embarrassing because I couldn't stop intermittently crying and smiling. A clear cut recommend for any age!

Going into this book, I was worried it would be an "issues" book. I don't like "issues" books. They cheapen the characters and the story to teach a lesson. This, thankfully, was not an "issues" book. Its main focus was the characters, and all of their voices came through separately and beautifully. I laughed, I cried, and I want to adopt all the kids in this book (even Julian, who needs better parenting). Such a wonderful, uplifting story.

The first 100 pages weren't so impressive. But after we delved into more multiple perspectives- Miranda, Jack Wills etc. it started to get more interesting with how we saw certain situations repeated throughout the book when documented by different people involved. The ending was satisfactory and the structure of the story was pretty good, basing it on one school year. Easy to get through and a definite lesson-teacher. Not amazing, but good.

August's first year in school- Middle School. His presence will be a challenge for all- he is a 'medical miracle' a perfect storm of genetic anomalies; his face is malformed- his intellect and spirit are not, he is a great kid. After many, many operations he can eat, his eyes are in an unusual place, but he can see, and he can hear. Although a hearing aid would really help- he doesn't have much of an ear to hang them on, just another obstacle. 
 His Mom thinks going to school would be all around good for Augie. It will also present a huge challenge in day to day courage on Augie's part and day to day acceptance of a visual surprise on the part of his classmates. 
 Ultimately a tale of uncommon bravery, forgiveness, large-hearted generosity and fierce family love.

August was born with mandibulofacial dysosyosis and a few other problems and looks, well, different. He's also very smart and very funny, and he's 10. During the summer he learns that his mother and father have decided that perhaps now he should start school, rather than continuing to be homeschooled. Starting fifth grade at Beecher Prep will be a challenge in more ways than one, as his looks make the initial "getting to know you" part difficult, plus the idea of learning with others at a set pace? He's not happy. 
 From the beginning, Augie's voice is very real. It's not relentlessly upbeat, it's realistically filled with ups and downs, and his moments of true despair were ones where I, too, would have despaired. The other voices we hear are not always as real, particularly Justin's and Miranda's. Miranda's decisions didn't always make sense (of course, what we day and do as we attempt to reinvent ourselves in a new place aren't always the most thought-out decisions! on the other hand, the play...) and Justin's virtual lack of reaction to Augie just didn't quite seem right. Summer and Jack, on the other hand, were almost as pitch-perfect as Augie. 
 The turning point in Augie's first year of "real" school comes as a surprise, and again it seems just a little bit off. Not what happens, but the aftermath back in school and the graduation celebration. 
 Still, those are minor quibbles. Over all, this is a book I'm guessing we'll hear more about during book award season. 
 Copy provided by publisher.

Heel mooi boek dat je weer doet geloven in de mensheid en empathie. Vlot en eenvoudig geschreven. Voor jong en oud. 
 Don't judge a book by its cover!

Potentially a life-changing book, more than just a good read. I cried quite a lot reading this book, and finished it in one day. A story of the often difficult transition into middle school, made even more difficult by being visibly different from everyone else in the same boat. We can all stand to be more kind every single day.

Rarely, you read a book which really digs itself deep into your soul and starts fiddling with the buttons. This, for me, was one of those books. 
 I started reading this book so I would not get told off at school for not having a book to read, so I borrowed it from a friend. Little did I know that later that day I would be sat in the library sobbing into the same book. 
 Not much happened, I'll admit, but the pace of the book was great so I had no trouble getting into it. I love the way it is written. The perspective changes so you get other people's points of view, which really added to the story. When it was just August's viewpoint it was very one sided and you never thought about the feelings and opinions of the other characters because August never thought about them either, or knew what they were thinking. But when it happened it really opened up the story and made it so much bigger. 
 This book touched me on a personal level, and is one of the best I've read. I'd recommend it to anyone. Just don't read it in public if you get teary-eyed easily.

Hace mucho tenia este libro guardado para leerlo. La razon por la que no decidi leerlo antes es porque este es el tipo de libro que uno ve por todas partes pero no tiene ni idea de que esperarse. En mi caso, antes de decidirme a tomarlo, leia incontables resenas de lo mucho que agradaba pero nunca llegaba a hacerme una idea de que era lo que llamaba tanto la atencion del publico. De cierto modo lo adulan de una forma muy simple. 
 Y ahora, luego de leerlo, me doy cuenta de que la idea que tenia del libro era correcta. Este libro es simple. No por esto deja de ser un libro especial. 
 La narrativa tiene una simplicidad sincera. Al leerlo se siente que los personajes en verdad te cuentan la historia. En este aspecto me recordo mucho a The Perks of Being a Wallflower. Esta escrito de tal forma que por mas que sea super rapido y simple de leer, tambien esta cargado de emocion. Mientras lo leia, por mas comun que fuese lo que me estaban contando, mi corazon palpitaba sin parar y las lagrimas estaban al borde de escaparseme en cada capitulo. 
 Al principio parecia un libro plenamente normal, pero mientras mas lo leia mas me daba cuenta de lo rapido que uno se encarina con los personajes y sus historias. 
 Al llegar al final, no pude contener las lagrimas. Lagrimas puramente cargadas de felicidad. Este libro volvio a darme una razon para creer en la humanidad y su capacidad de hacer actos bondadosos, algo que en verdad necesitaba. 
 En conclusion, creo que es un libro que uno debe leer para entender lo que lo hace especial. Es un libro que sin dudas queda en la memoria luego de varios anos de haberlo leido.

** spoiler alert ** 
 Definitely heed the warning on the front about "sob-making" (and this from The Wall Street Journal). 
 August was born with serious facial deformities thanks to a perfect storm of the combined genetic mutations from both of his parents. Well, that's nice; one parent can't blame the other. Their concern and love for him, as unswerving as it is, leaves his older sister in a sort of no-man's land. We learn of this family from the various voices of the two children and their friends. August starts school for the first time in fifth grade, when everyone else is starting middle school, at a New York City prep school. His mother had been home-schooling him because of his health and many operations, but has finally reached the limit of her abilities and feels he must finally join the real world. 
 The real world, of course, is populated with real creeps as well as their really creepy parents. I can't believe that a parent would photoshop a child out of her son's class picture for any reason but then I just saw a political flyer where a black woman's face was photoshopped out and replaced with the face of the white woman next to her in line*. So what do I know? 
 At first shunned by his schoolmates in a most believable manner (Oh, yes - I remember the "Tony Baloney, the ice cream pony" episode from my own grade school experience), August learns to stand up for himself. But not after discovering that someone he thought was his friend has feet of clay. 
 His sister, Olivia, now in high school has the chance to be not August's sister for the first time since he was born. But for some reason her old friends have rejected her. 
 Okay, it's a children's book, so I have to accept that it's going to end in an upbeat note, even if as an adult I find that unlikely. Fortunately, the upward progress of August's social life is marred by ... 
 spoilerrrrr! 
 the death of the family dog. I have to admit that that came close to making me sob. 
 Now, what did I actually get from this book, since I don't have any facial deformities or even know anyone with any? And, thanks to my childhood, I already knew that some kids were cruel. 
 Well, I think the English teacher's "precept" project made me think - especially the "Your deeds are your monuments" one. I mean, what have I done in my life? 
 "This precept means that we should be remembered for the things we do ... The things we do outlast our mortality." I like to think that my work with children (when I'm not yelling at them or being cross with their parents) is my memorial. Of course, I always tell them that they are free to mention me in the dedication of any book they write or illustrate (and I fully expect that that might actually work one day - hee!), but what I hope that I've managed to get some of them to love books. No one will carve it into a pyramid, I'm not going to get any awards for it, but I had thought it was enough. 
 Now I'm worried about that. What are people's memories of me? y este aplauso que recibe, en el viento se escribe, y en cenizas le convierte la muerte. Shhhhugar. Now I'm all depressed. 
 *http://www.alternet.org/tea-party-and...
Love love love. Heartwarming and funny.

Wonder has gained a fair bit of attention, and for good reason. In a time where even the slightest bit of difference can render one exiled from social groups, from political discussions, and even from going to the bathroom, it's heartwarming to read a story about a kid who embraces his differences and rises above those who would keep him down. Everyone loves an underdog story and this is a prime example. 
 Wonder is the story of fifth-grader Auggie Pullman. Born with genetic abnormalities that resulted in facial deformities, Auggie has been sheltered by his parents for most of his life. This year promises to be different, as Auggie enters school for the first time. As might be expected, not everything goes as well as his parents have hoped. Although a small group of peers has been chosen to help Auggie acclimate to school life, not everyone's intentions are pure and Auggie is the target of some intense bullying that causes him to question whether school is something he truly wants. Fortunately, some students do magnificently have Auggie's back and they show him what having real friends is like. 
 I was afraid that this would be a simple retelling of the "it's not how you look, it's what's inside you that counts" moral. Thankfully, Palacio's writing gives the story far more depth. I was particularly pleased to see that we were privy to viewpoints aside from Auggie's and that not everyone served as Auggie's cheerleader. Most notably was the chapter told from his sister Via's point of view. With Auggie and his needs forming the center of the family, Via is known mostly to others as the deformed boy's sister. Entering high school and enduring changes within her own social circle only complicates Via's life and, despite her love for her brother, Via is sullen and withdrawn. However, instead of vilifying Via, Palacio is sympathetic to her needs and shows how hard these challenges can be for everyone involved. 
 Wonder is billed as a middle-grade novel, but there's much to be taken from it as an adult. As grown-ups we typically know that it's wrong to poke fun of someone who is visibly different from us, yet we continue to bully and ostracize with the best of them. For everyone who is different in some way - whether that is through the clothes one's culture or religion prescribes or through the food one eats due to health restrictions or to the gender with which one identifies - Wonder serves as a hopeful tale of redemption. Likewise, it serves as a reminder to us that we are not all so different, and that kindness goes a long way.
Se houvesse a opcao de 3.5 estrelas, eu poria. Ainda estou a pensar se mantenho o 3* ou passo para 4*

Heart-warming story of August, a boy with a "craniofacial abnormality." After being homeschooled for the first several years of his education, he starts fifth grade at Beecher Prep School. Ms. Palacio captures the difficulties of middle school (Beecher Prep is 5th-8th) for "ordinary" kids as well as the extra challenges for a person as different on the outside as August is (though he says at the beginning "I think the only person in the world who realizes how ordinary I am is me."). 
 I liked how Ms. Palacio traded off narrator duties between main characters like August, his sister Via, and his best friend Jack; and minor characters like his sister's boyfriend Justin and his sister's ex-best friend Miranda. Each of them were able to provide the perfect perspective for the section of the story they told. 
 She also provides gold nuggets of wisdom mixed in with the story. When August doesn't want to go back to school because of a betrayal, his big sister says, "You have to go back to school. Everyone hates school sometimes. I hate school sometimes. I hate my friends sometimes. That's just life, Auggie. You want to be treated normally, right? This is Normal! We all have to go to school sometimes despite the fact that we have bad days, okay?" 
 And when Via's boyfriend is mulling over how "the universe was not kind to auggie pullman" he concludes (with appropriately emo disregard for capitalization and proper punctuation), "no, no, it's not all random, if it really was all random, the universe would abandon us completely. and the universe doesn't. it takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see. [several specific examples from auggie's life]...maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. the universe takes care of all its birds." 
 From the school principal's graduation talk: "It's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed...If you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 And then Auggie's prescient maxim: "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 I may be too cynical, but I wish I had the confidence that the same happy ending August had would be the result for other kids at other schools, but experience has shown that's not always the case. We can all of us, though, try to be a little kinder and bring reality closer to this beautifully told story. 
 For more book reviews, come visit my blog, Build Enough Bookshelves.

My personal notes: August Pullman has been homeschooled and now is going to school. He was born with a facial anomily. He visits the school and three kids are there to show him around. At lunch summer comes to sit with him. He has a birthday party and 5 people from his class show up. The kids pretend that he has the plague. He loves Halloween but this year he overhears his friend jack talking meanly to Julian the bully. Via, Augusts sister, knows the world revolves around August. Her best friend from middle school has changed now that they are in high school. So she starts to hang out with a different group and meets Justin. Summer got invited to a holloween party but wants to leave shortly after she gets there because it's all drama and they want to set her up with a boy. Summer ends up giving jack a hint at why August isn't talking to him anymore. Jack didn't initially want to be a tour guide for him because he remembers running into him when he was younger with his babysitter. But once he gets to know him he really wants to be Augusts friend. Jack picks up an old sled from the sledding hill and cleans it up. When he is trying to tell his friends about it he realizes that it's one of their sleds and they are saying a hobo took it. He realizes then that he doesn't want to hang out with them anymore. When jack gets paired with August for a science project jack realizes why August is not speaking to him and how mean the things he said were. Julian tries to get to switch projects to be with Jack and jack ends up punching him. Jack apologized to August and they are friends again. There is now an Jack vs Julian war going on that has the class divided. Charlotte clues them in. Jack switches to summer and Augusts lunch table. When jack is over at Augusts they meet Justin, vias boyfriend. Justin and via bond over being in the play our town. One day Justin walks jack to the bus stop and sees Julian picking on him. Later he goes up to them and pretends to be tough and tells them not to mess with Jack. Justin finds out from Miranda that she and via used to be best friends. When he asks via about this she gets defensive and admits she feels guilty because she hadn't told her family about the play. August ends up getting hearing aids and they aren't as bad as he thought they would be. And they help his hearing out a lot. August finds out that via and they fight and August yells at his mom. He runs to his room expecting his mom to follow but she doesn't. A long time later via comes to get him and says that their dog daisy is dying. They have to say goodbye. Via and Justin's play goes amazing. At the last minute Miranda can't play the main role so as her understudy via steps in. At the end August is amazed at the standing ovation. That summer at camp Miranda didn't have a great time. Her parents were getting divorced and she never really got attention from them. She begins to tell people at camp about herself but it's all facts from vias life but it makes her more popular. When she gets back from camp she doesn't call via because she knows that she cares and will ask too many hard questions so it is easier to ignore her and start fresh. So on opening night of the play she has no one there to watch her so she pretends to be sick so via can perform while her family is there. After that she and via make up. August goes on a nature retreat with his school. He is very nervous at first but ends up having a great time. They go to a drive in movie of the sound of music which is vias favorite. The only bad part is when some older kids from another school pick on him but some boys from his class and Jack are around and defend him. He looses his lobot hearing aids though. After this things change at school. People aren't afraid to touch him and they all call him little dude now. When he gets home his family surprised him with a new dog called bear. In the principals office he sees his assignment of drawing a self portrait as an animal. It is a duck and Mr tushman wonders if there is any deeper meaning but August says no. When his dad is dropping him off to graduation it comes out that the astronaut helmet August wore as a child was not lost but was thrown away by his dad. August is mad at first but his dad just wanted to see him and not have him hide. They end up making up. August ends up getting an award for having quiet strength and building up greatness. The crowd gives him a standing ovation and he thinks it's the best thing ever. After, everyone wants their picture with him and he's ok with the camera. Summer and her mom and Jack and his parents and justin go to Augusts house after and they are all having a great time.
What an awesome little book.
Excellent

Lovely book. Another one that all ages should read for it puts you into another's shoes. "If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary--the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God."

amazingly written 
 could happen any day 
 one of my favorite books
Great read for middle school. Valuable.

This book was a beautiful book. It made you think that nobody is ever perfect and sometimes you have to deal with it. I could not put this book down. I had to read it as a 7th grade reading book assignment for summer. Wonder is a very cute book about a August Pullman who has multiple disabilities and is homeschooled. His mother and father finally make the decision that will change his life forever. They ask him if he wants to go to a public Elementary School where there are kids. His sister is starting high-school, and his parents think it might be a good idea to get him involved and start making friends and come out of his shell. When this young, determined kid and his mother are called in for an appointment to tour the school and visit the principal, August Pullman is very anxious to go and see people. He had never gone to school before and he was worried what people would think of his differences. August had been born with a facial deformity that prevented him from going to a mainstream school. He had to have many surgeries but none of them helped him. His parents always supported him and coddled him and made sure he was comfortable and welcome. The principal has called in three experienced 4th graders who are there to help tour the school. They were also there to help August and help him understand Beecher Prep. The kids consisted of 2 boys and 1 girl. The two boys were very different. One of the boys was very generous and seemed to really understand what was going on in August's curious mind. The other boy wasn't friendly at all from the start. He kept on making very rude remarks on August's face. He asked him if he got burnt and those mean things. However, the other boy stood up for him. The girl told him everything he needed to know about this school. She mentioned all the classrooms, the curriculum and the major clubs that were offered at Beecher Prep. As August's goes home, he thinks about what the rude boy had said. August is just an ordinary kid, with an extraordinary face. But can he convince his new classmates that he's just like them, despite appearances? 
 If you haven't read this book, I hope this review has convinced you to go and read it because I will guarantee that it is the most wonderful, inspirational book ever. I strongly recommend this book for kids and adults that are scared and worried that someone will judge you because you act, talk, and behave weirdly. We all have out differences and where we stand and at the end of the day we all human beings. Appearances shouldn't be our concern, but how our attitudes are matters. Everyone should have the chance to come out of their shell and feel welcome.
16/05/13: I can relate to this book a lot. Wish I read it several years back.
This is a book that reminds you that everybody has a story to tell.
La verdad me encanto este libro al principio no me llamaba tanto pero me alegra de haberlo leido

"I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 "It's not enough to be friendly. You have to be a friend." 
 Such a heartbreaking/Heartwarming book! I couldn't stop reading this story and it really made me emotional just thinking about Auggie and his day to day life. I loved the family dynamic and how they didn't make it this "Too good to be true family". They all had their flaws and difficulty with Auggie's condition and the author wasn't afraid to shy away from them. 
 I love how the main part of the story was about friendship which is a very important thing especially in middle school and how just one act of kindness can change everything! I constantly felt like jumping in the book and helping Auggie out and that just shows how many children are going through this exact same thing and how the world/society might treat them. It breaks my heart but it's such an important story to be told. 
 There are so many Auggie Pulmans out there waiting for that one act of kindness. 
 The characters in this book were amazing and I was surprised by the different points of views since I had no idea there was going to be different POV's but it helped the story immensely and helped me see the thought process of everyone else. I could see the story play out in my head and I could picture everything perfectly even though at the beginning even Auggie said: 
 "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 I'm so glad Auggie gave school a chance and gave this new life a chance and it shouldn't even be a question in the real world. I think this is a book for anyone big or small and I'll definitely be going to see this movie as soon as it comes out.
Newbery winner!

When I was working on my masters degree, one of the practicum placements I had was in a middle school. At the time, they were reading Wonder and after hearing the premise of the book, I decided I'd read it one day. I'm glad I did. The book is entertaining and also has a great message for students about people being different. What I thought was important in the story too, was the fact that all the people connected to August, the main character had issues too. The difference was that their problems were not visible like his. Its a great way to show kids to look past the differences we have, whether it be facial deformity, poverty, or whatever issues we face and look at who the person truly is. 
 This is an easy read. I read it one siting and recommend it for middle schoolers or, really, anyone. I will not lie---a couple of times it put a lump in my throat as I read it. Makes a great discussion for students, your children or just among friends. And, from my understanding, its coming out as a movie too. Read the book first!
Thank you to the 4th grade student who encouraged me to read this book!

This is only my second 5 star book of the year! Woo Hoo! I am not sure what it means that the only two books I have given 5 stars to this year have been middle grade books (the other one was A Monster Calls). I found this book so engaging and inspiring beginning to end. I particularly liked that the author did not try to make Augie a perfect child whose only flaw is his appearance. So, though he wasn't perfect, he was just really great....what we would all hope our children would be if they were considered "normal". Kids can be mean. So can adults. This will be a great book to have my kids read as they navigate their growing up school world. I will encourage mine to be an Augie, Jack Will, or Summer. Love, love, love this book.

Three years ago one of my campers recommended this book to me, and I wish I listened to her and read this sooner! 
 This book was incredible! The writing, the characters, the messages. Everything was fantastic. I teared up so many times throughout this book, both from sadness and from being touched and happy. 
 I love all of these characters! Auggie is such a sweetheart and I love the way he was written. While I cannot truly speak on this, I feel like it was great representation. His character isso sweet and kind, and I love his sense of humor. I also love his parents. While we don't get to see into their head, I feel as if we know them and I really felt for them as having to deal with a child that has the issues that Auggie does. Via was amazing as well. I loved being able to get into the mind of the sister of someone like Auggie. I like that we got to see her struggle with her feelings and acceptance. She seemed very real, and I truly felt for her throughout the book. Also her boyfriend Justin is a sweetheart. 
 Jack and Summer are such great friends! I was really mad at Jack over what happened on Halloween, and so I love that we got to see his side of everything. It doesn't justify what he said, but I can understand it. Being in fifth grade is rough and it can become very important to be popular. Many people in real life make stupid decisions based on this. I'm just happy that Jack was able to recognize his and fix it. He's a good kid who made a stupid mistake, just like Auggie, I can forgive him for it. And I love that Summer was the opposite! Someone who right away said, screw it, I'm going to be friends with who I want to be friends with! 
 I also grew to love the other kids in the school, minus Julian of course. The only person besides Julian that I didn't like was Miranda. I think she seems like a terrible friend, and honestly, nothing she did redeemed her. She's selfish, and even though I feel bad for her, I think Via deserves better. 
 Overall this was an incredible story with an amazing message and I think everyone should read it! 
 Famous last words, but... I'm kind of excited for the movie! Let's hope they don't ruin this masterpiece!
Always choose kind.

Recommended for fans of "Liar and Spy" by Rebecca Stead and vice versa. Both books deal with elementary/middle schoolers who are bullied, and overcome the bullying by forming a community of friends and allies. Great read, devoured it in one day. Well written. The message, "choose kind" is important to readers of all ages. I was pleasantly surprised that it switched between different characters' viewpoints throughout the book. Highly recommended.
I found this better than The Fault in Our Stars.

I had a hard time getting into this book in the beginning and I was wondering if it was something only 10 year olds could enjoy. But once the story started switching perspectives from Auggie, the main character, to his teenaged sister and to his school friends I couldn't put it down. It was so interesting to see the family and school dynamics at play throughout Auggie's school year. I'd recommend this to anyone who is in school or to any adult, like me, who works at a school.

I loved this book so much! I think I cried about three times when reading it - especially during Mr. Tushman's graduation speech. This is the perfect book to give to kids when they are struggling with all of the social changes that middle school brings. Even though most of us do not share a deformity like August, we can still relate to his struggles and the struggles other characters have when coming to terms with who they are in relation to August. This is a beautiful book about the strength of human kindness.

Told from the perspective of six different people, Wonder is the story of a ten-year-old named Auggie Pullman who was born with severe facial deformities that has always unsettled people. But Auggie is used to this, and knows he is different. After being homeschooled his whole life, Auggie is going to join middle school for the first time and he is going to need all the love he can get from his family and friends for the tough year. 
 It doesn't matter even if you're not into Children's fiction or feel like Contemporary is not your thing, I think everyone should read this book just to give Auggie a chance to inspire you and touch your heart. Yes, it's true. Auggie Pullman is a little boy who can - and will inspire you in a way that could possibly affect your life. 
 The Pullman family consisted of Auggie's loving parents and big sister, Via. They were all very protective of Auggie and were eager to show the world that their little boy was just an ordinary boy with an extraordinary face. And yes, that is quite true. He was an ordinary boy in every aspect excluding his deformities. He played games on his Xbox, he obsessed over Star Wars and he did everything that ordinary kids do. 
 I must marvel at Auggie's courage and bravery. He did hate the idea of school and thought of not going there anymore. And he did go through moments where he wished he didn't have to be so "ugly". But he also found the willpower to walk through the gates of his school and kept up with the pointed stares and whispers. He eventually found friends, kept up with his school work, and accepted his differences enough to be able to joke about it at times. 
 The dynamic relationship when it came to the Pullman family was another amazing and beautiful thing about the story. The parents and the big sister supported Auggie and aided him, perfectly aware of the kind of attention Auggie got. I especially feel for Via, who was known often known not for herself, but as the girl with the deformed brother. 
 Miranda was another character that I liked very much. Miranda is the best friend (sort of, I guess) of Auggie's big sister and has always loved Auggie just as a sister would. She was one of the people who saw Auggie as a wonder. 
 This is a very, very realistic story in many ways. One thing I recon I should mention is how the ALL the kids at Auggie's school don't start bullying him or hurting him, and I'm excluding the few people who actually did that. Now you see, those kids were not rude on purpose, but would end up doing things like flinching away from him or staring or not meeting his gaze probably without even realizing it. What more, was that Auggie understood that. 
 Several times, all I wanted to do was hug Auggie and tell him that he is beautiful in a way his deformities could never erase. That he was beautiful because of his humor and bravery and his amazing personality. That he was lovable no matter what. 
 The author's About section mentions that she got inspired to write this novel when she encountered an extraordinary child in front of an ice cream store. Well, miss R.J., you have inspired I - and many others with this beautiful novel of yours. 
 In conclusion: This is a compelling book that will definitely touch your heart.
Cannot wait to share this little gem with my kids!
Love love love this book!!

I'm in class and just finished this book and I'm tearing up it was so sweet 
 even the things I didn't care for (the gimmicky lowercase boyfriend, etc), the book gets 5 stars just for being itself

I would highly recommend this book to anyone interested in what it takes for a person to overcome something in their life they feel they cannot overcome. This story gives a view of how a person can handle adversity and still not lose their self-image. This story also teaches the reader that at times it is worthwhile taking a chance on someone who is different from us. Enjoy!

3.5 stars. 
 I admit it. I have a Costco habit. Last time I was in the Culver City store, I noticed the stack of Wonders at the endcap. I grabbed a copy and put it in my cart. But as I neared the check-out, I decided to save some money and check it out from my library system. I mean, I'm a librarian, right? 
 After waiting a month for my turn on the holds list, I finally got my hands on the book and read it in... oh, about 4 hours. True, the book was way more enjoyable than my other task of assembling Ikea furniture. And I don't think that I would've been so enamored with the book if I wasn't using it as a way to procastinate. 
 Auggie is a likeable protoganist, if a bit too good to be true. Like others have noted, the first person narration changes frequently, but all of the characters are connected to August in some way. I think this keeps the book from being too shallow in its depictions of the players without adding unnecessary length. 
 However, I thought it was a bit cloying at times, particularly the ideas of the precepts. The quotes for each character at the beginning of their narration irked me. I do have to say that I liked the artwork in the chapters - it was the graphic depiction of the faces that drew me into the book in the first place. 
 Via was my favorite character, but the others, particularly Miranda and John Will, confused me with their actions; the motivations seemed odd and half-formed at times. 
 I would totally book talk this piece; it's an easy read and enjoyable. Life-affirming, yes. Life-changing, not so sure.

Wonder is about a boy with facial deformities named August. He has always been homeschooled and is finally going to an actual school. The story follows August's struggle as he attends school and tries to fit in. It's hard to fit in when you're a new student, bit it's even harder to fit in when don't look like everybody else. 
 Wonder is one of my favorite books because it's so inspirational. Most YA books nowadays are all about a young female struggling with something (Tris struggling to hide her Divergence, Katniss struggling to survive, and Hazel struggling with cancer). Wonder is so different because it's not dystopian the (main) narrator is a male. I think that R.J. Palacio wrote this book with many narrators and the main character being a male because she wanted to show that Wonder is different from other books, just like August is different from everybody else. Everybody is different. If we were all the same, life would be so boring because you would never meet new people. I feel like everybody can relate to August, not because of his facial deformities, but because everybody has trouble fitting in. This book is truly inspirational because it tells a story that could actually happen and does happen to people everyday. 
 My Three Words: Inspirational, different, and relatable. 
 My Recommendation: Everybody should read this because everybody can relate to it. 
 My Rating: 5/5

As a funny looking person myself (not pictured) , I was excited to read a middle grade novel about a kid with craniofacial deformities who goes to middle school. This book certainly means well, but I found it maudlin and irritating. I mean, do they have to give him an award for leaving the house and joining society? Also, no thanks to R.J. Palicio for perpetuating the idea that playing D&D in middle school is complete and utter social suicide. My husband, all his friends, my BFF and my 10 year old nephew all appreciate your denigration of their beloved hobby. Ugh. Maybe I am actually a little bit angry at this book.
Such an amazing book, loved every page and every word. Loved auggie <3

This book is a wonder. If books were teddy bears this would be the book that I want to cuddle all the time. This is one of those few books that makes you feel good and victorious. After reading it,I just want to get all the characters out of its pages and give them all great big hugs. 
 Life is a wonder and so are you. :)

When we finished the book, my 9yr old son summed it up perfectly, "It doesn't matter what's on the outside; it's what's on the inside." The diary format really connects you to the characters and the different points of view surrounding August ("Auggie") and how he's treated at school due to his severe facial malformations. It was emotionally difficult to read at times w/ tear-jerking moments, but it was such a beautiful story about kindness, friendship, and the importance of standing up for what is right. I highly recommend this for ANY AGE.
5 stars. 20 tissues.
I listened to this with my 12 year old and I think every 12 year old should read this book. Taught some good lessons about being kinder than necessary.

I loved the how genuine and realistic the narrative in this book was. August is a very likable main character, and my only complaint was that I missed Auggie's narration when the perspective changed. One thing that I appreciated was how he actually has involved, normal, loving parents... that's kind of rare in YA.

** spoiler alert ** 
 This was an amazing book. At first you think it will be a sad ending, but then Auggie gets friends and the Beecher Prep award. This is my favorite book!
Intriguing, heartbreaking, but absolutely wonderful.

This has been on my to-read list for ages. My daughter had to read it for school for the Helen Ruffin reading bowl, so I went ahead and read it while she had it. I loved it. It was a great story and very timely for our household, with the lesson of being nicer than in necessary. I highly recommend this one.

"Todo el mundo deberia recibir una ovacion del publico puesto en pie al menos una vez en su vida, porque todos vencemos al mundo" Auggie. 
 No tengo palabras para explicar lo bella que es esta historia. Al terminaro la calidez que provoca en el lector es inexplicable. Te da una dosis de realidad. Saca a la luz nuestros propios defectos, nuestros propios prejuicios sobre los demas y sobre nosotros mismos. Entre lineas, cantidad de refelexiones sobre como ser mejores amigos, hermanos.. y personas.

At first glance, I thought that this book would be another depressing one about someone who is cast out by society. Like The Fault In Our Stars, for example. A charming plot, but nevertheless depressing. However, in Wonder, it isn't as depressing, with happiness woven into the plot. And yes this is a Disney ending (SPOILERS) where he wins everyone's respect and is not considered a deformed monster. But sometimes books need happy endings to spare the reader the bulk of the pain.
I definitely recommend this to everyone. This book is truly amazing. It made me cry & laugh. One of my favorite books for sure!
Mas bien es un 4.5
Cute and a fast read.
Fabulous book-- a great "coming of age" story for tweens and parents of tweens alike..
Interesting little book. Enjoyed the quick read.

AR level 4.8 
 This book has won many many awards. Excellent !
One of the best books I've ever read.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I thought it was cute. I was really sad when the dog died. In the end everything was great though.

A good fun reading. A story about a strong brave boy who had good reasons to be depressed, but decides to be happy and succeeds. A story to teach us that when surrounded by a loving family and good friends no obstacles are unmovable. 
 dY"sGood reading! dY"s

I help in a 3rd grade classroom as an Instructional Aide, and we, as a class read Wonder by R.J. Palacio. What a wonderful middle grade book. I don't own the physical copy, but I want to. It's definitely a book everyone should read. I'm giving it a solid 4 stars. The characters will definitely stick with me for awhile. 
 Wonder is about a boy named August Pullman (Auggie), to his friends and family. August was born with an extremely rare birth defect. If I had the book with me I could tell you the very long word for it. Just know it is a facial defect. There is a very good description in the book, but every time I think of Auggie's face I think of Sloth from the Goonies, except on a 10 year old. 
 When we meet Auggie and his family, they are trying to enroll August into a public school. Beecher Prep is just down the street (in walking distance) of August's home and this will be the first time August has EVER went to school. He has been home schooled this whole time. One of the major reasons for home schooling Auggie was because of the scare factor. Before all the surgeries Augusts face was very different. August had to deal with people staring. Some people would openly say rude comments. It got to the point where Olivia's (August's sister) best-friend Miranda stepped in and gave August a space helmet. This was like his security blanket. He never left the house without it. 
 Back to Beecher prep. August decides he does want to go to school and he is enrolled into the 5th grade. We spend all of 5th grade with Auggie. During the good and the bad. We meet his friends. We see how August deals with bullies and feeling like an outsider. We also get to see other people's point of view. This book has many POV's from Auggie to his sister Via, to Jack his best friend. 
 There were many times I got teary eyed reading and listening to this book. Truly inspiring. If you are looking for a heart-warming story of a boy over coming adversity this is the one to pick up.
Fast, funny, uplifting read! Will never forget Auggie Pullman.
A cute children's book with a good message, good morals and anti-bullying sentiments.
An interesting read that made several unique points
I really loved this book. All the characters and their actions and reactions. Looking forward to watch the movie.
Could-not-put-it-down. Engaging, endearing and impressive. Could not believe this was a first time author. Deft and deliberate, involving and compassionate. Just everything good.

Wow. 
 This is the story of August, or Auggie, and his journey through a year of public school for the first time in his 10-year-old life. He has a combination of genetic disorders that have rendered his facial features quite unlike a typical child's. The story is told through the eyes of several different characters in a cascade that fits so well together, I was never bothered by the switch in narrators. Books that have to do with accepting each other's differences can often become cloying, preachy, or predictable. I felt that Wonder was able to resist those pulls. Highly recommended for upper elementary, middle and high school students.

great great book 
 strongly recommend!
This is an amazing book. The narrator is so likeable, the obstacles realistic and heart wrenching, and the finale perfect. Heartily recommended.

The central message of this book is about the importance of kindness. When having to choose between being right or being kind, always choose kind, says the author. The protagonist of this novel (Auggie) is a child afflicted with craniofacial abnormality. He struggles to be accepted among his peers. He is able to be accepted by the end of the book.

Every middle school...heck, every HIGH school student...should be required to read this book. It's quick, well-written, well-rounded (which is even more important for a book like this, I think), and charming. The characters are heart breaking and wonderful, cruel and kind. Although I am not always a fan of a shifting POV, I adored the way it was done here. It really helped to not only further the story, but to give readers a view of Auggie's life from ALL perspectives. Incredibly well done.

Amazing book -- great for Grades 4 and up as a class read-aloud. Very insightful to the stresses of having physical disabilities and also what it is like being part of a family that has a child requiring surgeries and special treatment to survive.

I have been hearing about this book for a long time, and now that I finally read it I can understand why. Wonder is one of those books that, perhaps despite its flaws, will definitely stick with you. The main character, Auggie, is a lovable hero. The reader finds themselves falling in love with him even as the children at his school do. 
 But, and perhaps I am too cynical, this was one of the main issues I had with the book. Everything seems to eventually come up roses for the main character. I guess I felt like there might have been a place for more conflict. Then again, I realize this is a middle grade book and aimed at children of that age range. More meanness or stronger conflict may have seemed out of place, even if perhaps more realistic. The message certainly would not have been as clear. 
 This is why, despite feeling that at times it was not as realistic as I would've liked, I decided to go with a four star rating for this book. I think the book serves two purposes. The first is to tell a compelling story, which it does. The second, and perhaps more important goal, is to help people walk in the main character shoes for a little while. It may not have been the most perfectly written book I ever read, but I also think it succeeds in this second goal as well.
This is simply one of the most heartbreaking and beautiful children's books that we've read as a family. It had us all in tears without ever feeling manipulative.
Absolutely loved everything about this novel - so well done! It will be one I read again many times, I'm sure.
Great story. I love Auggie and his family. Why does the dog have to die in every book I read? I am passing this one along to a 5th grader in my family! Excited to see the movie now.

This book was extremely moving. I loved the characters and the themes of the story. I'm looking forward to sharing this book with the junior high students that I will be meeting soon! My only issue with this book is that I absolutely LOVED 75% of the book, but the last 25% I found disappointing. I don't want to say why as it could be a spoiler. Regardless, I would definitely recommend this book to students and adults alike.

I loved this book and so did my children. I read it along with my 8-year-old daughter, and my 11-year-old son read it on his own. There were many times while reading with my daughter that I got teary-eyed . . . sometimes because of Wonder's amazing strength and innocence, sometimes because of the cruelty he endured and other times because of the genuine kindness of others. There were parts that my daughter didn't understand (what does that mean?) so it was good that we read it together and we had some great conversations about differences and the importance of being kind. She (and I) never wanted to stop reading . . . "please, one more chapter?" Excellent book and one that I will recommend to everyone!
Brought me to tears on every chapter. Probably the best book that id read this year.
A beautiful middle grade book that I have no doubt will be listed as a classic. Oh darling Auggie, I am so glad that I got to meet you.

I really enjoyed this book! I think it communicated a lot of solid lessons for readers of all ages about kindness and acceptance. I particularly enjoyed the conversations about comparing Auggie's conditions to special needs and how that line could be easily blurred for people who aren't as educated about special needs and Auggie's condition. I think the multiple points of view added a lot of dimension to Auggie's struggles but there were times I felt like the tellings were a little too mature to be realistic (there were few times but nonetheless I thought it was worth mentioning). However it was an overall wonderful book that is worth reading by anyone of any age. It was a quick read with short, enlightening chapters that will break your heart and lift your spirits.

Any book that gets middle school kids excited about reading earns an automatic star from me. Wonder came recommended from a student, and I could not put it down. An extremely accurate picture of middle school, with important themes and extremely realistic narrative voice (the story is told from a variety of perspectives). A great candidate for next year's "One School, One Book".

This is a sad story with all the heart in the world! Who can not love Auggie? The sweetest child who deserves all the best! This is a story about being different, about acceptance, friendship and family. This is a novel for all ages, even tho the main character is only ten. Everyone needs to read this and learn how to accept that all people are different, some more than others, and we need to accept all the differences! Both the ones that shows on the outside, and the ones on the inside.

5 stars!! 
 Absolutely amazing! 
 Beautiful! Touching! 
 EVERYONE NEEDS TO READ THIS BOOK!!!

I'm giving this one 4 1/2 personal stars, but a definite 5 star classroom, middle grade read. I cannot wait to share it with my teachers and see who I can convince to read it with their students. 
 August: "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 I absolutely love Palacio's choice to not describe Augie's face in detail until about 90 pages in during Via's point of view. In this way, the reader gets to do something the characters don't - we get to know Augie without making judgements about how he looks. And you have to love Augie. I also love the switch to other viewpoints - especially, as other reviwers have pointed out, the glimpse into the minds of some of the "villians" so we know exactly what was going on and why they made some of the choices they made- another reason this would be an amazing classroom read. 
 I hesitate to say it about an otherwise great read, but I did feel everything was tied up a litle too neatly in the end, but I can let that slide for middle grade when I enjoy the characterization and plotting so much otherwise. Definite recommendation.
A story every person should read and take to heart! Then read to their children and always, teach them kindness always.
Uplifting, heartwarming and thought-provoking.
Truly wonderful, empathic, powerful read. The narrator, a boy with a severe facial deformity, is genuine, funny, earnest, and brave. You'll love it. Read it aloud to your children and friends.

"I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid. I mean, sure, I do ordinary things. I eat ice cream. I ride my bike. I play ball. I have an XBox. Stuff like that makes me ordinary. I guess. And I feel ordinary. Inside. But I know ordinary kids don't make other ordinary kids run away screaming in playgrounds... I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 From the first page of R.J. Palacio's debut novel, Wonder, readers are rooting for Auggie Pullman, who due to the 27 surgeries needed to help correct his craniofacial abnormalities, has been homeschooled all his life. But now, he'll enter the middle school at Beecher Prep, like a lamb headed for slaughter. 
 Auggie is keenly aware of how people react to his face, from averting their eyes to staring to talking behind their hands about him. Auggie, his parents and his sister had created some level of comfort on their block and in their normal routine, and even through things like a toy astronaut's helmet he wore everywhere when he was a few years younger. But now it is time to face the world, and readers come along for the journey. 
 Although Auggie is a character that induces a great deal of sympathy, there is a depth and realness to his character. He loves Star Wars, he tells good jokes, and he loves his dog, not unlike most of the young boys I know. Because he is more than his exterior, this book is able to transcend the "after school special" land that a book about a child with a birth defect often remains in. 
 Palacio's choice to tell the story through sections with different narrators is what propels it into award-winning territory. Hearing from Auggie's point of view is very important, but hearing from his sister Via, and some of the children at school adds another dimension to Wonder that works to its advantage. And it's rare that so many points of view are given and done well in a book for young readers. 
 One line that is repeated by the teenager characters in the book is "the universe was not kind to Auggie Pullman." And though this is true, and painfully real to readers, Wonder is not bogged down in Auggie's suffering. It's a book with a great deal of heart and joy, and a message that will resonate with both children and adults without seeming forced or contrived. The universe may not always be kind, but we are all able to be. I am thankful for the reminder. (10/10)

Yeah, it's really really good... 
 (I'm coming back years, later, because I've thought a lot about Wonder, as a book and a phenomenon. I enjoyed the book, and I'm wowed by the effect it's had in the world, but something about it has nagged at me. I think this book is essentially a fantasy. I really wish the end was more realistic-- that the power of the "Choose kind" message would be more powerful if it was paired with an understanding of how one has to move forward even when people make less kind choices.)

I love a story told by many viewpoints and understand how hard it is to write that well. This was a sad, beautiful and true story. The setting and actions seemed so real. I loved how each person revealed a little bit of themselves and moved the story forward. I found myself tearing up many times in the story. Would make a great read aloud and classroom discussion- so many themes.

I think the value of the book does not lie in the story itself but in the writing. Taken to an extreme to demonstrate a teachable moment and make you think about beauty inside and out, but also in a My Sister's Keeper-like way the impact of Auggie's disfigurement on the family as well. 
 I loved the progression of the story through the multiple points of view tied together to move it forward and was drawn to Olivia's point of view. She has learned to fend for herself because of her brother's disfigurement with all of their parents' attention on him, but the reader also learns about her thoughts in the family but also at school and the differences, even hiding a part in the school's play, though no one doubts her love for Auggie. Readers also learn about Auggie's father's feelings-- he threw away a space helmet Auggie used to wear because he wanted to see his son's face. 
 So while I wouldn't say I unequivocally loved the book from the message to the writing to the story, I will say I appreciated the story and the language. A book for a new generation on kindness and understanding especially when facing adversity.
Everyone, young and old, should read this book. Parents, teachers, kids...everyone! Loved it!
I can't say enough good things about this book.
Who's cutting onions in here?
Creo que no he leido libro mas increible en mi vida

4.5 stars, rounded up. This book easily lived up to the hype with its heartwarming, and occasionally heartwrenching, story. This is a very likable school story laced with a strong message about being kind. 
 I didn't find any of the alternating voices terribly distinctive, but it was nice to get the story from different perspectives.

Wow! What a little gem. I love it when the right book lands in your hands at the right time. Change is difficult for anyone, and currently I have my own amount of change happening. It's not easy, and well, I've been a little mopey about it lately. Then I read Wonder and I'm reminded how ordinary I am and how everyone deals with their own version of life's ups and downs. Yes, Auggie has facial deformities, and going to school (middle school) for the first ever, is a huge change. But like he says, he's just an ordinary kid too. 
 There are a ton of awesome lines in the book. The writing is realistic and honest, though I did have a hard time believing a 5th grader would call his mom and dad "mommy" and "daddy", but whatever. 
 Favorite lines: 
 Justin (Via's boyfriend) my head swirls on this, but then softer thoughts soothe, like a flatted third on a major chord. no, no, it's not all random, if it really was all random, the universe would abandon us completely. and the universe doesn't. it takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see. 
 Auggie - Now that I look back, I don't know why I was so stressed about it all this time. Funny how sometimes you worry a lot about something and it turns out to be nothing. 
 Auggie - That's not exactly true: I do know what I'm really known for. But there's nothing I can do about that. A Star Wars duffel bag I could do something about. 
 Would I recommend it? Yes, yes, yes.

I never take the time to write full reviews... but this book totally warrants one. 
 This book is AMAZINGLY done. 
 It's important and meaningful without being preachy or sappy. 
 It's subtle and yet mind-opening. 
 If you love MGlit or know kids who do... read this. You really must.

Definitively delightful and heartwarming story of a middle school boy with a severe facial deformity. I loved the character development throughout and the way the author didn't shy away from the difficult questions/experiences that the protagonist faced. 
 While the point-of-view shifts were fun, I felt like they were a little bit of a copout, especially since they dwindled toward the end of the book. August's perspective was clearly the main pov, and I wonder if we would have gained more if we weren't able to see into his sister's and peers' perspectives. I also wanted to hear more about how certain narrative threads resolved themselves at the end of the novel (as opposed to hearing a too-long narrative of fifth grade graduation). 
 But all in all, this book was a pleasure to read. I'm sometimes accused of reading only depressing books, so this was a welcome alternative; a novel that is well-written, compelling and optimistic at the same time is a rare feat, one I quite enjoy.
Everyone should read this - all ages! I know 4th and 6th grade teachers who are integrating it into the classroom and I know 60 year olds who loved the book.
I liked the book but the plot wasnt that fun or misteroius
Citando Las Ventajas de Ser Invisible: "Es ahora mi libro favorito de todos los tiempos, aunque siempre pienso eso hasta que leo otro libro"

This book was chosen for my school district that everyone in grade 3 and higher reads. I really enjoyed it, especially as an elementary teacher because it deals with acceptance and bullying in a new, fast way. It's simple enough for the younger students to understand, but also there are things that only adults would notice and interpret from the book.

Aw crap,another book I left behind for almost two months but I'm glad I finished it as well as The Scorch Trials. 
 I really love this book so much, it's so heartwarming and I think I just had a tear in my eye.
Absolutely loved this book!! A definite must read!

-E M P A T H Y- 
 I really wish there could be schools like these all over the world so kids could learn a thing or two about empathy, of how accepting differences makes world a little, even if a tiny bit more fortunate. 
 Overall i found this book really cute, which is - a total opposite of what i would have expected. I thought this was going to be a slightly depressive story, given by the synopsis. The depressive feeling kind of pulled me in, yet i was not disappointed, not even slightly. What i actually read was a story of how you can get through hardships if you have people around you who support you. I think it's a wonderful thing to have, meaning you really have to care about people who you are surrounded with. Sigh i should try to be a better person, too!! 
 Not to mention this made me think that why on Earth do I frown about my own looks, when right there is this little boy who has it way harder than myself, and yet he is able to laugh and get through this. Although i do know that he has loads of hardships to come, since it's only middle school, but for now, in that book's universe, he is who he is. August Pullman :) A cute little orc. 
 Overall, this book is for all ages, cause you learn a thing or two how should people be. 
 Spoilerish sidenotes, read this if you have read the story: 
 Sidenote1: I might want to try drawing him, at one point.With those eyes around his cheeks, with little longer hair and all that. 
 Sidenote2: Oh and August had the best parents ever. EVERY PARENT SHOULD BE LIKE THAT!! Seriously. 
 Sidenote3: The funniest part was surprisingly with Olivia's boyfriend. The way he defended Jack was hilarious!! Using that case to pretend to be a hitman. Just lol! 
 Sidenote4: The only thing that i wish could have been better if the author had used more synonyms, but i really liked how she used loads of idioms! 
 ENDING (SPOILER) My eyes got wet in the end because i was so happy for him.. especially that ''Everyone needs a little applaud once in their lives.'' And that happened to August, too. And when he went there on stage, i kept thinking maybe it's the last time he could be this happy, or will this last forever for him?.. mixed feelings made me just.. Gawww... Anyways really nice story!
The most compelling, deep and serene book I ever read in my entire life. Especially August POV.
Lovely book. A bit optimistic, but nice.
I cried!!!!! I didn't want this book to end.

I like Wonder a lot but I didn't LOVE it. I think a lot of that has to do with the fact that I don't like little kids that much, so I found August and Jack somewhat annoying. Unpopular opinion, I know.
I loved the original book 'Wonder' and could not wait to read this version, from Julian the bully's point of view. It gives a great insight into why Julian behaved the way he did with Auggie...

I don't often give five stars but this book was absolutely amazing, right off the bat I felt for the main character and his parents. I couldn't put this book down it was way to good if you have not read this I highly suggest that you pick it up, young and old alike will find something relatable about this heart warming coming of age book.

I don't know how to describe this book. It has so much power in it. I think everyone should read it and maybe,just maybe, the world would be a better and kinder place. 
 This is a heart-felt book,so much meaning into it. Its about being different,being kind to the people who are different,its also about family,friendships and its just all the was amazing. I cried so much while reading this BUT i also laughed a lot. Its not a 'omg this is so sad' book,its a 'that's the world,it may be ugly sometimes but its also really really GREAT.' kind of book. I seriously laughed out loud while reading this and i was in public so people thought i was crazy xD 
 I loved so many parts of it,where do i even begin? The POVs were perfection. I loved how each character got a different kind of writing and expressing themselves,because we're ALL different and its beautiful. I also loved how it was so honest. His sister loving him but also sometimes feeling guilty about the way the world or herself was thinking. Jack,trying to figure things out. Auggie being this funny,sarcastic,brave little boy. I just LOVE him afijailf *FEELS* :') And don't even get me started on the Julian chapter. Such a powerful piece. WOW. This book should win all the awards. Seriously. It needs a standing ovation.
Enjoyable read!

This book will have you crying ... sad, heartbreaking tears and happy, proud tears. The story revolves around August, a 5th grader starting school for the first time after being homeschooled for medical issues. He is used to people staring at him and his differences... but starting middle school is new scary and exciting ground. 
 I look forward to reading this book with my almost middle school son. It has moments that will appeal to kids used to reading humorous middle school titles such as "Diary of a Wimpy Kid" or "Justin Case", but it also reminds me of "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone". It is not similar in the magical sense, but in the feel of someone starting something new and being different. I think it is a great book to promote kindness and opening children's eyes about what it means to be different.
Well what can I say. Its a make you cry some book. Remind you to be thankful book. A book to tell us love can overcome all things kind a book. A good simple story.

I enjoy these kinds of stories due to my work in supporting young adolescents at a middle school. Times are challenging just being a teen and having a disfigure, disorder, etc., puts that much more stress upon one's self image and success. 
 Learning empathy, kindness, and humility are character traits that heed positive growth and community leadership~ 
 Hands down, this is a novel that should be read by ALL middle schoolers!
I feel like my time was well spent reading this. Such a positive book with so many wonderful characters. This is a keeper for me.

August Pullman is different. He was born with severe facial abnormalities that affect the way people perceive him. His parents have primarily home-schooled him, but this story introduces to August at the cusp of transition. He's going to start 5th grade at Beecher Prep. 
 This is a very sweet, loving story about learning to be kind and courageous while navigating the trials and tribulations of pre-middle school. We all know that kids can be mean. We all know that parents can be mean too. This book has six different points of view (August, Summer, Jack, Via, Miranda, and Via's boyfriend.) Each character brings a new depth to the story and I thought their voices were clear and distinct. 
 I think this would be a great recommendation to any pre-teen who's struggling to fit in.
Everyone should read this. Loved it.

wow. I totally forgot to write something, okay. I will do so now. wow this book. I know I'm a tad late since it's been out for like what a year now? But wow. This book is about a boy named August (Auggie) and he has a face deformity. Auggie is going to school for the first time (as he's been homeschooled his entire life up until grade 5 when he enters school). This books is his experience in school, and how difficult it is for him. 
 The character development in this book was perfect. I loved the different perspectives because I feel like we get a lot more understanding that way since we get to see how other people view August. This book was inspiring and very eye opening. I would suggest this book to anyone, and age! My mother's currently reading it to my younger brother and from my understanding they're both really enjoying it! I really enjoyed it! So yeah.
Good book.
Great a must read!
