Acabo de terminar de leer Wonder o la Leccion de August, asi que voy a hacer una especie de resena/reaccion de lo que me parecio el libro. 
 Para ser sinceros, pense que el libro me iba a gustar mucho mas, que lo iba amar de principio a fin y que, por poner una comparacion algo burda, terminaria con la sensacion que me dejo TFIOS. Sin embargo, no fue del todo asi. No es que no sea un buen libro, o una buena historia, o que este aburrido o pesado, solo que me falto mas para que me ganara. Es un libro bueno, si, pero pudo ser mucho mejor. 
 La historia es muy sencilla de seguir. Tiene una descripcion muy ligera, por no decir que es casi nula; y con ello te enfocas en la linea argumental y puedes disfrutar el libro. No te pierdes ya que no necesita "mucha" interpretacion. Es decir, lo que te quieren contar es exactamente lo que estas leyendo. Nada de entrelineas. La escritura en primera persona, y la narracion perfilada a la edad de los personas fueron de las cosas que mas me gustaron. 
 El intento de contar la historia por diferentes puntos de vista me parecio algo ingenioso y que podia complementar/ enriquecer la historia, pero se quedo ahi, en un intento. Algunos de los puntos de vista los considere necesario y en algunos puntos repetitivos. Siento que al final con haber sido narrado por August o tener un narrador iba a poder explicar las cosas que intento hacer J.R. Palacios poniendo diferentes angulos. Ademas, aunque se que es cuestion de la edicion, la narracion del punto de vista de Justin esta toda en Minuscula y es un poco raro/incomodo. 
 Mis personajes favoritos fueron: August, Jack Will y Summer. Sin duda dejan a todos con una leccion de vida, ya que para ser ninos parecen entender a los demas en una forma que a veces los adultos no pueden. La historia merece ser leida, sin dudas. Aunque en algunos momentos me parecio muy predecible, muy linda, muy "todo es perfecto", ademas de un final poco cerrado. 
 En conclusion, La Leccion de August es un libro bonito recomendable tanto para las personas que aun no estan del todo en la lectura como para las que ya estan y quieren leer un libro ligero, enriquecedor y positivo.

A disfigured from birth 10 yr old boy. This book gripped me from chapter one till the last page. I admit I shed a few tears, maybe giggled hear and there. I loved the arc the story took. The trials and tribulations that not only a kid, who had been home schooled, would face entering school for the 1st time, but throw on top of it the added pressure of being so different. I hope if I have kids, or that my nieces and nephew, turn out to be as good as Auggie, Summer and Jack.
It is one of those books that's heart-wrenching and empowering at the same time. It will be cherished for a very long time. It exposes human flaws and strengths in it's most realistic nature.

"Me encanta tu cara, Auggie. La amo apasionadamente. Y me partiria el corazon que siempre estuvieras tapandola" 
 Dios mio este libro fue hermoso y tuvo un final perfecto. 
 Me encanto. Me encanto. Me encanto. 
 Es un libro rapido, te atrapa y es facil de leer. La manera en la que esta escrita es lo que mas me gusto del libro, como cambia de punto de vista y en ningun momento se hace aburrido 
 Fue uno de los primeros libros en los que en el final llore mas por felicidad que por tristeza y dios me fascino. 
 Lo recomiendo infinitamente. 
 Precepto de Henry Joplin: No te hagas amigos de imbeciles.
One of my favorite books I have read. Review to follow.

He's not like Harry Potter; he doesn't do magic. He's not like Percy Jackson; he's not really a demigod. He's not like Clary Fray; he's not even a girl. 
 He's just an ordinary boy who, unfortunately, is a bearer of some genetic disease. Not very heroic, but I think everyone would agree that the courage that he showed throughout the book was exceptional. I don't think I could have done that. 
 The scenes is the book were so heartfelt that I can actually picture myself in the situation of August. And I could really tell, even from my kindest imagination, that what he had been through is difficult, especially when placed upon the shoulders of a child. 
 This is a very inspirational book and a great reminder for everyone to appreciate each and every blessing that we have. We must understand that we are lucky compared to those people who suffer not only physical anomalies but also spiritual and emotional ones. 
 And by all means, let us try to be "kinder than necessary" to others. As they say, your deeds are your monuments. 
 Do all the good you can, 
 By all the means you can, 
 In all the ways you can, 
 In all the places you can, 
 At all the times you can, 
 To all the people you can, 
 As long as you ever can. 
 -John Wesley's Rule
This is terrific adolescent literature.
Oh I can't wait until my son can read so he can read this too! Such a good book.

This is one of those books where everyone can find someone to identify with. Even if it's just in the tiny details, we've all met people like the characters in Wonder. For me, it was Via. There was a point during her section when something she said struck a chord in means I just broke down in tears. It was the kind of thing that I'd had that exact same feeling and I hadn't known how to put it into words or if there was anyone who could empathize with that emotion. 
 This book is incredible. There is so much emotion and heart in it. The characters feel real, the themes resonate, and the writing is beautiful.

August or "Auggie" Pullman was born with severe facial deformities and because he has had to undergo so many reconstructive surgeries in life, his mom has homeschooled him. Up until now. Auggie is about to start the fifth grade and his parents have decided that it would be good for him to go to school for the first time. Auggie has learned to live with the stares, the sideways glances, the mean comments, but he's especially scared of starting middle school where students can be especially mean to one another for reasons less than Auggie's facial deformities. And Auggie's suspicions are right except for two students, Summer and Jack, who befriend him through lonely lunches, "the Plague", and an especially rude parent who doesn't believe Auggie should be a student at his school. Auggie's family is wonderfully supportive and his sister, Via, begins attending a new school just as Auggie does so she can especially relate. His dad is funny, his mom supportive. Everyone wants to be a part of Auggie's family. The school year comes to a climax towards the end of the book when Auggie is bullied by students from another school and his classmates stand up for him. Auggie's awarding of a special award at the end brings the book to a wonderful conclusion. 
 This was one of the best books I've read for this age level. It is especially appropriate for discussions about bullying and would make a fabulous read-aloud, especially with the short one to two page chapters. This book is told through the eyes of not only Auggie but his sister and his friends which provides different perspectives of Auggie's stories. Again, this would make for great classroom discussion. This is, by far, my pick for the Newbery this year!
I posted my review on my blog: http://serenalawless.wordpress.com/20...

So often in this life do we take for granted what we are given. "Wonder" helped me to realize all I have been blessed with. But more importantly than all that, this novel gives one of the most powerful messages: Choose kindness. I believe everyone should read this story so that all people, regardless of appearance, race, religion, sexual orientation, etc, have equal treatment and opportunities. I cannot wait to share this beautiful story with others for years to come. 
 "Such a simple thing, kindness. Such a simple thing."
One of the best books I have read. Ever.
Wow. So good. One of the best I've read this year. Definitely a contender for Newbery.

August is the child that everyone stares at, because he's different. This, I can empathise with. Palacio has beautifully written characters that we can relate to eg. Via - the sister who is shoved to one side because of someone who needs more care and attention. For me, this was perfect, because I could relate to the characters, although not having been entirely in their shoes. 
 Liked this book :)
Touching little gem, although the parents always seemed too perfect, too understanding. Would have liked to have chapters dedicated to their point of view

A little candy-coated, but there was a lot that rang true for me -- as someone who grew up with a disabled sibling and now has a child with a disability. A little preachy at times, but painfully, beautifully honest at other points.

I read most of this book (save the first 25 pages) in one sitting. I just couldn't stop reading it, I didn't want to put it down. 
 This was a beautiful, wonderful book. 
 RJ Palacio does a fantastic job of capturing the voice of a 5th grader and really getting the childish aspects as well as the mature aspects. She does a fantastic job of showing the complex social structures of 5th grade an high school. She also does a beautiful job writing many other voices in the story to create a truly fleshed out tale of one remarkable kid. It was also a relatively quick and easy read, which is always a good thing in my book. 
 I really loved the storyline, all of the characters were incredibly endearing (which usually makes for a good book for me) and it was really, really touching. I think this was beautifully, gracefully written and Palacio had so much respect for her character that showed in her writing. 
 I loved this novel, I HIGHLY recommend it.

I seldom come across books that I feel confident recommending to everyone I know, but if I have any sway as a librarian, I'll be using it to push this book as far and as widely as I possibly can. I loved it almost, almost, completely. 
 The characters were wonderful: complicated, fragile, and believable. August had me from page one. I thought the multiple POVs added much to the story. Via's take on things brought me to tears -- the first of many I cried over this book. Palacio knows a lot about human nature, the good and the bad. 
 The ending, though, was so schmaltzy and Hollywood-ready; I can't describe my sense of dread as I read the last sixty or so pages, and the crushing disappointment I felt as everything wrapped up in the most predictable, precious way it possibly could have. 
 HOWEVER, this is still a book that I think has the potential to make the world better, or at least make people nicer and more aware of and more sympathetic to people's differences. I hope that kids enjoy it as much as adults seem to, because this one will make a difference. 
 Don't disappoint me, Newberry committee! 
 p.s. A bajillion bonus points to Palacio for making The Magnetic Fields' "Ugliest Guy in the Lower East Side" Auggie's favorite song.

What a fantastic book! My daughter needs to read this for school so I thought I would read it aloud to everyone. We couldn't put it down. "Another chapter please" was the constant cry after each chapter.

Words cannot express my love for this book and the characters that live and breathe within the pages. The changing points of view add to the charm. August Pullman ranks up there as one of the most beautiful characters I have read.

"When given the choice between the right or being kind, choose kind" _Wonder, R.J Palacio 
 Given the first quote about being right or kind might be tickle your expectation. This book should be humanism-theme when human torn between his duty to be kind person to the other, or just to be the rightful man and leave the heart locked in somewhere. 
 The truth is, this book is a heart-feeding book. A very good vitamin to made us as kind and heart person. Spoiler alert, this book will squeeze your heart because there are many sincerity, love and attention. 
 the complete review can be seen here < a href="http://theflybirdsnest.blogspot.com/2...
Mas lindo. Hace mucho, mucho que no tenia tantas ganas de abrazar a un personaje :') <33

The story of Auggie Pullman drew me in immediately, as he describes his experiences transitioning form being home-schooled, to entering middle school. A treacherous time for any child, but made even ore challenging because he has several facial deformities...he and his family have several coping mechanisms in place, but even they get challenged in ways they could not anticipate. I, likewise, found the voice of Auggie's sister to be bittersweet and honest as she narrates a portion of the story from the perspective of a sibling to a special needs' child. This book really resonated with me and I would they recommend it as a read-aloud for younger children, or an independent reading selection for those 'tweens' out there.
Loved it! Plan to have my kids read it also.
A lovely little book. To be honest, people had raved about this book & although I enjoyed it, it didn't really blow me away.

Heart-warming story about a boy born with a facial deformity who overcomes adversity to become admired by all those he comes into contact with. The passage to adulthood is never an easy one and even moreso for Auggie but with the help of a kind, loving supportive circle of family and friends he achieves a real sense of self-belief and inner strength.
I am late to the game reading this, but it was worth the wait. I hope the upcoming movie does it justice.
This book is incredible.i can't praise it enough

I read this book after it was recommended to me by my fifth grader, and it is, indeed, wonderful. It's a powerful story of bullying and kindness and the particular pains of middle school. Auggie is an impressive character. Even though he is unique, he ends up representing all of us. Well done.

Buku anak-anak terbaik yang pernah aku baca setelah beberapa tahun ini(menurutku). Sudah hampir lupa ada buku anak-anak yang bisa membuatku menangis sambil tertawa setelah The Highest Tide oleh Jim Lync, The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Nigh oleh Mark Haddon, dan The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas oleh John Boyne . Semua keluarga yang mempunyai anak harus membaca buku ini.

August Pullman was born with a rare genetic condition that left his face horribly deformed. Although several years of plastic surgery helped, his face remained disfigured. After home-schooling Auggie through fourth grade, his parents decide to send him to school for fifth grade. This story tales of Auggie's struggle to be accepted for who he is rather than what he looks like. 
 This is a spellbinding book that is hard to put down.

Rating ***** (5/5 stars) 
 AMAZING BOOK!!!! Thoroughly enjoyed every page of this book. 
 BRILLIANT writing style.. Get to know each character from their own perspective. Not just form protagonist. 
 You have to read this book to understand the greatness and kindness, act of friendship, what is meant to be a friend. 
 This book is just amazing. 
 "You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder." 
 He is the greatest whose strength carries most hearts by the attraction his own.

Actual rating: 3.5 
 This book is heart-warming, yes, but it's far too long considering how (un)interesting the story is beside August's problem.

I almost didn't start this book because I knew what was coming. The hero is a boy with a terrible disfigurement, reminiscent of the movie "Mask." We all know how cruel children can be. But we also know how loving they can be. We see both in "Wonder." It's a beautiful story of one boy's journey to have a normal life when he has been dealt a cruel hand. We also see that things aren't always as they seem, especially in the world of children where they are being pressured to fit in and conform from so many sides. The characters are well done, the plot realistic, and the outcome fantastic. Do yourself a favor and read this with your kids\parents.
PRECEPTS!

I loved this story, Auggie is such an amazing and adorable kid and I was rooting for him till the very end. I knew what I was expecting from this book and I was still pleasantly surprised with how great this was. I loved reading through the different perspectives and I loved the lesson in this story. 
 100% positive I would have sat with August during lunch on the first day of school!

Wow. Such a good book. I can't put it down once I have started it. I litereally flew through the book. 
 I like how the author managed to differentiate the 'voice' of the characters. They didn't sound the same. It's like they are real. 
 And I'm so glad the ending is not something depressing (someone kill him/herself, etc)

This book is so beautiful. Not only the story is beautiful, the writing style is also amazing. I love books with different POV and this author managed it perfectly. I have no much to say, this is one of those book that you have to experience... Its simply heartwarming.
Me gusto, buen libro. Pense que seria un libro muy triste pero resulto que no era asi. Se me hizo muy facil de leer.

I choose kind, Auggie! Maybe it's not hip to be an optimist anymore, but I don't care. I believe people still try hard to do the right thing, say the kind word and help others. 
 This is a must read book to all the Auggies, Mr. Tushmans and Julians of the world!

A story of a bold Kid born with a genetic defect. I really liked the way the authour has pictured his story through different eyes and the emotion running through the family. Must read for all kids to develop empathy and compassion as sometimes they are mean without understanding the scars their casual remarks and pranks leave.

If you read just one book this year, make it this one. This book will have you crying and laughing all in the same breath. You will come away from the book, desperate to become a better person. A truly life changing book. If you go to buy one book, buy a few copies of Wonder, because I can guarantee you will be urging other people to read it too. 
 I am old enough to remember watching Mask and The Elephant Man, which were both based on similar true stories, so I had an inkling as to what I was letting myself in for when I began reading this book. I knew that the book would emotionally rock my world and it did. I think I actually put off reading it for awhile as I just knew I would be upset by it. 
 Not that I am upset by the way the Auggie looks, no not at all. I was more upset by the way society reacted to Auggie. He was just a kid, who loved to do all the things other children do. He hurts and feels just like everyone else, so to suffer such torment really did upset me. I loved Auggie completely and if I was his mother, I would be just as protective. He is the sweetest child I have ever come across in literature. 
 I think one of the things that really stood out for me in this book was the way the dog, Daisy, loved Auggie and licked his face in the same way he would anyone else. Animals don't see the differences in people, so why do we as humans make such a big deal about it. Auggie really is a wonder, he is a medical wonder, as his condition is such a rarity. His heart is so big, it is impossible not to fall in love with him. 
 I loved all the secondary characters in the book, especially as we got to view Auggie and his life through their eyes too. All of the secondary characters were very strongly written yet each had their own quirkiness that made them very real. Via was one of my favourites. She loved her brother completely, but sometimes she just wanted to be seen for herself and not as being the sister of Auggie. I could understand that as it must have at times been very difficult for her. She was very strong and supportive and was desperate to see her brother stand up for who he was. She didn't want to see him being treated like a baby all his life. He needed to be able to face people and deal with the way they looked at him. 
 Throughout Auggie's school year, you see how everyone learns to love Auggie for who he is and not for what he looks like anymore. He finally has friends and they love him just as they would anyone else. Truly heartwarming to read. 
 I cannot praise this book enough. It truly is a wonderful read and I will nag you all to read it. Although make sure you have lots of tissues available as I can guarantee you will cry. A book you want to hug! 
 The saying at the back of the book says it all - 'don't judge a boy by his face!

Wonder = WONDERFUL! I could not put this book down. Who can't love Auggie, a 5th grade boy entering school for the first time after being homeschooled all of his life due to 27 surgeries to try to correct facial abnormalities. With incredible courage the journey begins and Auggie shares the good and the bad of 5th grade. The book is told from multiple perspectives, his, his sister, Via, his classmates at the school, and even some of Via's friends, which put me in mind of Because of Mr. Terupt by Rob Buyea, but more often some of the treatment that Auggie received reminded me of Melanie in Out of My Mind by Sharon Draper. I hope that teachers will consider reading this book aloud to students, because it certainly will open the door for discussions. 
 May 8 2013 - I just reread this book, having the opportunity to read it with a group of 4th graders. Although the book was passed over by awards committees, it gets full raves and reviews from me for the messages of friendship and looking past the "cover" of the book to see the inside. My students are absolutely loving the characters in this book, Auggie, Via, Summer, and Jack, and are shocked when Auggie is treated with disrespect. It gives me hope that kindness is still alive in our world.

First of all I have to say that M. Manekofsky was right! This was a great read with a character you will absolutely fall in love with. More than that this is the book every "cusp of middle school" child should read. 
 I was thinking of a conversation that Jamie Johns Whitehurst and I used to have about YA and even Juv materials. It seems like in the majority of these materials the reoccurring theme is that one or both parents are missing, dead or neglegent in some way. No one writes the story about the kid who has a great relationship with his family. Now there is one! This is it! Part of what makes this book so special is that the main character's development is tied directly to the relationships he build--the most important being those of his family and close friends. No one is dead, lost,or on drugs. It's just the story of a kid overcoming some crappy odds. It's great!

This book was worth the long waiting list. August is a young boy who lives with a rare condition. The people in his life including his family and friends experience his first year of school after being homeschooled all his life. A real tear jerker.

There aren't enough good things to say about this story, its characters, and its understated moral lessons. Palacio writes with the empathy and grace only a mother can have in such vast reserves, and the novel serves as a lighthearted but powerful reminder to simply choose kindness. It falls apart a little at the seams, however; there are too many narrative perspectives that are not distinguishable enough from one another, with a couple undoubtedly irrelevant sections (definitely Justin's and maybe even Jack's), although it was a joy to read from the perspective of Via and Summer and, surprisingly, especially the "after" section from Julian. The end of the story is neatly packaged and tied in a perfect bow, yet within that package not everything seems to be in order - for example, the sister who figures so heavily into the story in the first two-thirds has all but disappeared at the end. In more than a few places throughout the book, the dialogue seems a little off, but we can always count on Auggie to give us the most honest and bittersweet story. It's a must-read for all primary education teachers, and parents or parent-hopefuls, too.
Me gusto mucho pero una parte la odie porque se me hizo muy Damn

Read this book in 2 and a half hours. Couldn't put it down. I would say its for young and adult above. It was recommended to me and I have recommended it to others who have also enjoyed it. A thoughtful book.

This book was so hard to listen to....this little boy was born with birth defects and had no control over how he looked. People were mean, kids were mean..... I cried a lot listening to this book because of how mean people can be to a little boy. But Auggie was brave, didn't quit and in the end came out on top. A lot of lessons can be learned from reading/listening to this book. It tugged at my heart strings a lot, it was sad, it was happy - I really enjoyed it.

One of the best books I've ever read. 
 The story focus on the protagonist August and his struggles to adapt himself to middle-school.The narrative follows up linking the points of view of other children who are close to August. 
 I'd rather not talk about August's appearance... the whole story is much more than that and the way his family is portrayed kind of makes you jealous!
Very sweet, short read. Maybe a little too sweet.. Kinder than is necessary is a lovely concept though. And I did cry about 3 times.

At one point Auggie describes his mom smiling at him as "Her smile kind of hugged me." Well, this book kind of hugged me in a way that I haven't been hugged by a book in a long time. Read it if literary embraces are your thing!
Fantastic book. I really didn't think I would like this book but I loved it.
I loved it. It had a very real feel when it came to the everyday of middle school. Add to that the equally real feeling of isolation, it was painfully accurate. Good ending, which is important to me.

i absolutely loved this book! I think it will win the Newberry and make a speady entrance onto every school's summer reading list. (for kids going into middle school) 6, 7th and 8th grade! 
 What good lessons to be reminded of! loved the precepts.

This book makes me think about how the story and characters refreshen me. It is hard to deny that you would end up crying after reading it. It hooked me since I finish it without delay. It's been a great emotional journey, and it is about a wonder boy, August. I guarantee that this book will leave you better feeling. 
 At the very first page, there is this quote; 
 'My name is August. I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse.' 
 Definitely a must read...

My expectations may have been too high going into this book. I think this is a book I would want my kids (I don't have kids but if I did) to read. The perspective shifts are great, but the writing style was so child like-short sentences, the hilarious faux poetry of high school, slang, etc that it didn't have the weight I was hoping for. A sweet story, not "sob-making" as the book jacket review claims, but one that feel like it will be more important for a younger person to read.
My feelings are like up, down, down, down, up, up... roller coaster of feelings
A fun heart warming story that really did make me smile x

I went into this blind only knowing the basics. My expectations were pretty high going in; this book is highly praised and then quoted one of my favorite songs in the beginning. That all being said, it definitely exceeded them.

I can see why just about everyone likes this book. I enjoyed it from cover-to-cover. There are some core values in this book and they are presented in a way that people can really take them to heart. The characters were thought out and developed. The emotions were true-to-life. The author did a good job in describing action. In my opinion this book can be read and enjoyed by all ages.
This is a fabulous book! The characters are heart-felt and compelling. I loved seeing the story from many different angles and voices. A must read!

There is much to like about this book, but the warm, fuzzy, Hollywoodish ending, with things wrapped up in a nice little bow, just didn't ring true. It's these "stand up and cheer" moments that just don't work for me. Otherwise, I felt the book was first-rate.
Read this book in one sitting. Absolutely phenomenal read for anyone at any age. Should be required reading for teachers.
Ok, as childhood stories go, this was a good one. It teaches lessons of empathy, assumptions, stereotypes, how to be a good friend, love, loss, and above all, being brave.

Sometimes you come across a book, and it's one that you hope everyone will read; because really, everyone should read it. R.J. Palacio's Wonder is one of those books. 
 Unlike the Great Gatsby, a "classic," you don't read Wonder for the symbolism and plethora of literary tools (I actually don't really understand why we force it upon high school students). Instead, you read Wonder because it's about kindness and appreciation - two things from which this all humans would benefit. 
 Wonder centers around August Pullman, a fifth grader with a facial deformity that kept him from going to school. The story is told from the point of view of several young people - mainly fifth graders, but a couple of high school students as well. It's not all heavy. There's some laughter in there, and there's determination and resilience. 
 There's also a clarity that comes with children and their perception. This is actually my favorite part of the book. Kids see and understand more than we adults think they do, and I like how Palacio captures this in her story. 
 So, go get this one and read it. If you have kids, read it with them, and talk about the book. There's great lessons to be learned - especially if you wonder what you would have done had you been August's parents, and what you would do, had you been August or his sister, Via. But most of all, remember this book. Remember it when you're having a tough time. Remember it when you meet someone different.
Very good book. Quick read.
Loved this book. I would like all my grandkids to read this. A good reminder how to treat people.
I read this book in two nights. I finished after midnight last night. I'm still thinking about it.
By far one of the best children's books that I have ever read! Full Review to come!

This book is very sweet and August is a great character, you can't help but love him. But, I think I had too high of expectations for this book. Some juvenile fiction is able to capture the troubles of life in a realistic way while still remaining age appropriate and other juvenile fiction captures the troubles of life but simplifies and sunshines it. I feel like that's what happened with this book and it all felt a little formulaic. What you think will happen when he starts school happens and of course a transformation occurs and we have a happy ending. I think this book would be really great for fourth and fifth graders, it just didn't pack the emotional punch that I thought it would for me as an adult.

Oh my God! This was beautiful. 
 Everything about it was just that- beautiful. 
 Going into the book, I thought it would be about struggle of being different... but, no. 
 This story was about courage, about kindness, about empathy, about growing-up, about forgiveness and about goodness. 
 I thought this would be August's story, but it was the story telling everyone gets it bad sometimes, but what matters is how you get up, how you choose to always keep fighting. There would be so many times when people would wrong you - some intentionally, some non-intentionally - but what matters is how you choose to react. Do you let them put you down? If asked, do you forgive them? Can you? Should you? Would you? 
 Honestly, all I am trying to say is, read this book. 
 It doesn't matter if the narrative is by a 10-year old kid; because sometimes the most beautiful lessons are taught by the people who aren't trying to teach you anything.

This was an absolutely amazing book, especially since I went in with low expectations. I thought it would be just another in a long line of books about disfigured/disabled kids that manage to succeed in spite of their obstacles (can you hear the soundtrack music playing in the background?) But I actually loved this book in spite of all the obvious plot points. It is a very well-written book, especially for a first time novel. 
 My favorite lines were "Here I was looking for symbolism and metaphors and, um... sometimes a duck is just a duck", as well as "If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary--the world really would be a better place." 
 Very uplifting, and a good bedtime read as well. My nine year-old is loving it, and I highly recommend it.
I look forward to the day I can read this with my daughters. What a powerful story.

"Some things you just can't explain. You don't even try. You don't know where to start. All your sentences would jumble up like a giant knot if you opened your mouth. Any words you used would come out wrong." 
 --Jack Will, Wonder, P. 155 
 What am I to do in trying to write a review for a book like Wonder? How rarely do authors in their first published novel come through to the extent R.J. Palacio has in this book, blasting open the walls of the learning curve to travel places beyond what ninety-nine percent of writers will ever comprehend, let alone actually reach? Wonder is one of the most rawly emotional books I've read in years, a parade of short bits of story, character development and anecdotal demonstration of feelings and thoughts racing all toward the singular point that is the end of the narrative, when so many different pieces of volcanically emotive drama fit together in what was being created the whole time, though we couldn't always see it: a completed portrait of Auggie Pullman, a boy heading through life with genetic burdens no one person should ever have to carry. A year in fifth grade with a facial deformity that will be the first thing everyone he meets notices about him, so serious a malformation of features that even those used to seeing people with physical abnormalities instinctively recoil at the sight? That's a long year to endure no matter the other circumstances, even when the school administration has taken the proactive approach of setting up a small network of acquaintances for the boy with a few preselected students a couple of weeks before the first day of school. Is it really possible that out of the furnace of middle school's first year, Auggie will emerge not burned to a crisp by the open hostility of those students who will never try to understand that he's a normal kid deep down, but rather refined by the furnace's intense heat, granted absolution by the few persistently kind kids there are for a facial structure he cannot change and never asked for in the first place? This is Wonder. This is the story of Auggie Pullman, a story and boy I had come to love deeply by page last, because it would have been impossible for me not to love them. What could have been just another excellent story among so many others became, because of the extra labor of love put forth by R.J. Palacio to the creation of a story as close to perfect as possible, a life-changing event that has affected me as powerfully as pretty much any other book I've ever read. There was never any real doubt over my awarding it five stars. 
 "Here's what I think: the only reason I'm not ordinary is that no one else sees me that way." 
 --Auggie Pullman, Wonder, P. 3 
 Born with a series of chromosomal maladies that clicked all wrong in exactly the wrong places, giving him a face distorted and caved in with features scattered where they don't quite belong, Auggie has been protected his entire life by his parents and older sister, Via. Regular school has never been seriously considered an option; to have put Auggie into the traditional elementary-school learning environment with other young children who had never seen anything like his face would have been an invitation to disaster. So Auggie has been homeschooled up through fourth grade, and exposure to other kids has remained limited and always a product of careful engineering. While this process seems to have worked decently well, landing Auggie a handful of kids over the years whom he could call real friends, he doesn't see any of them frequently. In the year he'll be entering fifth grade, though, Auggie's social paradigm takes a crazy turn when his parents tenuously suggest he consider attending a regular school for the first time. Unbeknownst to him, he has been accepted into one of the best private middle schools in the area, a haven for academic success and challenging school curriculum that will test Auggie's adept mind more comprehensively than his mother has been able to at home. It's Auggie's choice whether or not he wants to go, but even as he struggles with the offer, treading water on the rising sea of his emotions at the idea of shaking things up after years of consistency in matters of education, Auggie knows this is an opportunity that doesn't come along every day; never, for most students. Introduction to the mainline stream of formal education isn't going to be easy for Auggie, even at the start of middle school when all the students will be adjusting to a new school and new peers, but he can't dismiss its ultimate value. 
 And from that first day of tentative investigation into the idea, when Principal Tushman has Auggie meet three students he praises for their kind character and welcoming personalities--Julian, Charlotte and Jack Will--it's off to the races, a never-slowing run down a Black Diamond ski slope that feels as if it could go careening totally out of control at any moment, at devastating cost of life and limb. Auggie's acclimation to his new school is torrentially paced, the smallest yet most crucial nuances of communication and lack thereof to give us a clue as to what's really going on whizzing by unnoticed if we're not observant. Yet just as much as it feels like a wild downhill ski run, Auggie's emotional existence also feels like a walk: one foot in front of the other, upon the edge of a giant sharpened knife, where one slight misstep could send him plunging to a fate better not discussed. This is middle school for Auggie; at times, that is. There are also moments when kids in the student body cast aside their revulsion at Auggie's strange outward appearance, some temporarily and others for keeps, and approach the newest new boy of them all with only slight trepidation, just a modicum of horror at what they never perceived a human face could be. It is these kids, shirking the curtain of isolation that has surrounded Auggie since his first day of attendance, who are able to lead him off the knife's edge on occasion, giving him respite for a while from the intensity of the knife-walk that his life at school usually is. 
 One can never guess the twists and turns of an entire year as it lays unmapped, sprawled in the ghostly mists of the future where even our most honorable intentions in attempting to divine its secrets cannot penetrate the thick fog. With immaculate skill light-years beyond her modest experience, R.J. Palacio spins with all the skill of nature's master architect, the spider, the tale of one year alongside Auggie Pullman, doing Charlotte A. Cavatica proud with every story strand both silky and not-so-silky she threads to join with and strengthen the larger web structure of the narrative. It's only fitting that one of the most important characters Auggie is introduced to at school is named Charlotte. And just as the strength of the spider's web belies its graceful, wispy appearance, so R.J. Palacio's story of personal acceptance, kindness in the face of blatant rejection, the complexities and realization of genuine friendship and the rewards of living a full life when confronted again and again by sadness and trauma in its many forms is shored up with internal fabric stronger than steel. It's the same stuff Auggie is made of on the inside, and he's not the only one in the story about whom I could say that. Is it any surprise, all considered, that perhaps the best word to describe this book is stamped right on the cover: Wonder? 
 The story glitters with jewels spread throughout, and it doesn't take much digging to find caches of the valuable stuff. When Auggie is informed that the first three kids he's going to meet at his new school are right on the other side of Principal Tushman's office door, waiting to be introduced, he briefly reflects on why it's different meeting kids in middle school than younger children. "What's cool about really little kids is that they don't say stuff to try to hurt your feelings, even though sometimes they do say stuff that hurts your feelings. But they don't actually know what they're saying. Big kids, though: they know what they're saying." Even though he's never been part of a class of other kids, Auggie has already drawn this observation about how things work, and it's an astute one. One really is, in general, much safer with younger kids, who have no agenda to want to say mean things to gain the approval of unkind peers. Readers should also keep their eyes out for "Mr. Browne's Precepts" in the story, included when their meaning intersects with Auggie's narrative. One of my favorites is "When given the choice between being right and being kind, choose kind". I also like Charlotte's Postcard Precept she sends in to Mr. Browne to complete the summer assignment: "It's not enough to be friendly. You have to be a friend." The depths of that statement are quite profound. I should pin those words up somewhere I will see them everyday and be reminded that real friendship is so much more than the sum of its parts. 
 Auggie's take on Halloween is a great one, his feelings reflecting more than just the wishes of a boy who knows this is the one day of the year when his facial eccentricities can be kept hidden behind facades of latex and plastic. "I wish every day could be Halloween. We could all wear masks all the time. Then we could walk around and get to know each other before we got to see what we looked like under the masks." Of course, this tends to happen anyway, in a much subtler sense than Auggie is suggesting, but not even something as traumatic as the Halloween Incident can ruin Auggie's use for Halloween as a day when he can take a vacation from being himself. An opportunity like that is important to have once in a while. Even as Auggie deals with the ups and downs of a year in which so much has changed, and is continuing to change, for him, not every transformation is scary or unwelcome, no matter how bad he may have expected it to be. After receiving a bit of medical assistance that increases his ability to enjoy life in one particular way, Auggie is relieved it doesn't turn out to be the ordeal for which he'd been steeling himself. "Funny how sometimes you worry a lot about something and it turns out to be nothing", he thinks. That does seem to be a near universal experience, just as it is that one's own most terrifying troubles often go unnoticed by most of the world. As Auggie observes after a sudden crisis he gets through with the help of some friends, "It's so weird how that can be, how you could have a night that's the worst in your life, but to everybody else it's just an ordinary night." Auggie is growing increasingly capable of handling his own problems when they do crop up, apart from the abundant help his parents have been there to provide for most of his life. And even though Auggie will always love his parents specially, differently than other kids feel about their parents, knowing how to troubleshoot independently from them is an accomplishment that will serve him through all the many days to come after fifth grade. Whether or not it ever gets easier, Auggie knows he has what it takes to make it. 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 --Auggie, P. 231 
 My thoughts on this book would not be complete without a mention of just how much I loved Jack Will. It's not because he's a perfect kid, a paragon of faultless kindness in a sea that often hides nasty creatures and sharp, dangerous bits of debris; no, we learn for sure in Wonder how imperfect Jack Will can be, like any other human. I think I love Jack so because of his imperfection; because he was able to create such happiness in us at his initial attitude, it made the shock of the Halloween Incident feel all the more treacherous, sparking feelings of real anger and bitterness, a cathartic desire to side with Auggie and press the eject button on so-called friends, because who needs to hear their side of the story? But it's exactly that shift from glowing pride to deep resentment that makes it all the more an emotional experience when the story does come full circle, and the little pieces of unseen truth we felt it unnecessary to see back in the moment of first hurt come to mean a whole lot more than we could have guessed. That is why I love Jack Will, why his presence in the story is so stingingly poignant, why I never wanted the book to end. While his story, such an integral part of Auggie's, was still going, I, too, was part of it, and friends the likes of Jack Will are much fewer and farther apart than I wish they were. I actually find myself missing Jack Will, and I hope I never stop. What does that say about R.J. Palacio's abilities as a writer? 
 Books like Wonder are maybe a one in a hundred proposition, at best. That is, if I read a hundred books I have legitimate hopes will blow my mind as Wonder did, perhaps one of those hundred will actually live up to that potential. I'd have to say Wonder is, in my eyes, one of the bigger surprises of its era among deserving books not to have received official commendation from the Newbery Committee. I could easily see it having won the Medal, a book as worthy of the decoration as almost any other that came before it. If R.J. Palacio never wrote another book, she would be the one-hit wonder whose single contribution to literature was equal to a lifetime of compelling fiction from most authors, a tribute to and challenge of the stunning beauty of the best humanity has to offer, played out by those most likely to take up the challenge and carry it farthest: kids, like Auggie and Jack Will and Julian and Christopher. It is on their shoulders that Wonder takes its voyage, and therefore could only ever have gone as far as they were willing to bring it. To me, that's the most beautiful part of all.
