(Leido en 2013) Apenas caigo en cuenta que nunca lo resene. Es una historia enternecedora y a la misma vez muy fuerte, donde reflexionas bastante gracias a la increible personalidad del protagonista. Un libro para todo publico, simplemente encantador.
Awesome book!! [?][?][?]
Melted my heart from the start till end :) nice good read!

Summary: August, Auggie, has never been to school. It isn't because he never wanted to, it was because he never could. After being born with an almost unknown birth defect, he has had over 25 surgeries in his short 10 years of life. Now, after a time of surgery-free life, Auggie's parents have decided that it is time for Auggie to go to school. As a 5th grader. Which is the first year of middle school. As Auggie's dad says, it is like leading a lamb to slaughter and the ride that Auggie goes on is a roller coaster of emotions. 
 What I think: There are certain books that while you are reading, you wish that you could share it with every person, adult and child, that you know. This is one of those books. It is almost too hard to explain because of how wonderful it is. It is a book that will make you want to be kinder to every person that you meet. It is already a lesson that I try to teach my students and a book like this will assist me in showing them how words and actions can affect another person. 
 Although August is amazing and you cannot feel for and love his character, there are 2 other characters that made this book for me. First, Summer. She shows that there are 10 year olds that are still loving and thoughtful. The other is Mr. Browne. I love his precepts and how he teaches his class. What a way to make students reflect about their lives and to think deeply. 
 "I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid. I mean, sure, I do ordinary things. I eat ice cream. I ride my bike. I play ball. I have an XBox. Stuff like that makes me ordinary. I guess. And I feel ordinary. Inside. But I know ordinary kids don't make other ordinary kids run away screaming in playgrounds. I know ordinary kids don't get stared at wherever they go... My name is August, by the way. I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." (p. 1) 
 Review posted at: http://www.teachmentortexts.com/2012/...
This book is so very cute. I really liked the different voices here and how the story wasn't only about August, but acknowledges the challenges of everyone else in his life. Lovely read.
Obviously written for a younger audience. But a great display of kids being kids. Admittedly, I choked up a bit at the end, but I'm a bit of a sucker.

It took me a while to get into this book because I didn't really like the tone or the writing style. But different sections are narrated by different characters, so the tone is really important to the story line and serves to distinguish the characters from one another and is a very effective way of developing their personalities. After I got over the "Auggie" tone, which was choppy and very matter of fact, similar to his personality, I was drawn into the story itself. 
 The specifics of Auggie's disease and the actual physical deformities it causes are never described in detail in the text, which bothered the scientist in me at first. But the book isn't about that; it's about friendships and the ability of people to look beyond the physical. To do this, the author writes this story from several perspectives, which really highlights how different people struggle with this. 
 We read from all of August's peers and his sister, but never from his parents or the few teachers that are central characters in this story. Given that it is a middle grade book, this makes sense, but I would have liked to have heard more from the adults. 
 August is a special child and he is lucky to have found such a great group of friends. I question how realistic this story really is though. I'm a tad bit cynical, but realistically there would be fewer people who are able to look beyond the physical. Sad, but true.

** spoiler alert ** 
 Wonder is a beautifully crafted book that peels back the harsh middle school environment one perspective at a time to show the insecurities and humanity of each child. There are no huge surprises here with the plot, but the candor of the rotating narration keeps it out of afterschool special territory. My only real issue with the book is that the narrating characters had similar voices, which made it confusing at times to keep it all straight. However, the message of the value of kindness was well set up and made for a great ending.
so great, should be a must read for all jr high, high school, university, and beyond people.
llore un oceano y me ahogue en el

I need to stop picking books that are gonna make me cry, seriously. 
 I really liked this book because it shows the different perspectives of the characters about the same thing. It was a super fast read that I enjoyed a lot and I guess the only critique I have is the ending. 
 SPOILER-y critique ahead 
 People don't ever change that fast. Kids are cruel. Kids don't find their moral as they could find their lost mp3 in their room. Nope. That doesn't happen. I've been bullied for several years and let me just say that things do not change from one day to another. People don't start being nice just for the sake of being good guys. Huh, huh, no. In real life, Auggie would have had to deal with the same a**holes. He wouldn't become popular, nor loved by everybody. I think that ending, even if it's cute and such, made the book unrealistic. 
 Anyway, the book overall is good so there they go, 4 Auggie-is-cool stars for you!

Everyone should read this, kids and adults! 
 It is a beautiful story told from shifting perspectives about a fifth grade boy with severe facial abnormalities. I cried a lot reading it (be warned, don't read it in public, I was crying at my daughter's cello lesson in the corner over the book) but not all sad tears - it's a very honest and tender and non-sanctimonious examination of the highs and lows of what human beings are capable of in their interactions with each other. 
 A quote I loved - from Mr. Tushman's commencement speech at the end - "'Always try to be a little kinder than necessary.' (JM Barrie) ... Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed. Why I love that line, that concept, is that it reminds me that we carry with us, as human beings, not just the capacity to be kind, but the very choice of kindness. ... If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God."

Comenzare por admitir que este libro no me llamaba nada la atencion. Primero porque sentia que era como que otro libro que no aportaba nada, y porque tenia como la impresion que el final traeria una especie de "milagro" Dios mio, no puedo estar mas arrepentido. 
 Wonder o La leccion de August como lo conozcan sigue a Auggie Pullman, un chico que posee deformidad facial, y que ha sido intervenido varias veces para ayudarlo a tener un rostro casi humano y por supuesto para solucionar algunos problemas de salud. Auggie nunca ha asistido a la escuela con otros ninos, y ahora su madre cree que es el momento de hacerlo convenciendo asi a su padre y finalmente convenciendo al mismo Auggie. Las preocupaciones son claras, la crueldad que puede llegar a existir en cierto grupos de ninos y que podrian terminar afectando a este chico. La travesia aca es lograr que el resto de su clase, el resto de la escuela, el resto del mundo puedan llegar ver mas alla de lo que el fisico de este chico representa y puedan ver su increible personalidad, su hermosa alma y un gigantezco corazon que posee. 
 La trama transcurre justo como lo esperaba, no dire que es como una sorpresa porque no se permiten sorpresas aqui, sabemos que pasara en cierta manera y sabemos como queremos que se desarrolle e incluso como queremos que termine. Y me encanta que todas las personas que intervienen de manera significativa en la vida de Auggie tengan la oportunidad de relatar como ven su mundo y como observan al chico. Sin embargo, he odiado la manera en la que esta constituido como en pequenos capitulos, siempre me provoca una especie de confusion como si me he saltado algunas hojas. Me lo he leido super rapido, porque ha sido sencillo. Y de no ser por tener otras responsabilidad probablemente lo hubiese acabado el mismo dia. 
 Auggie es un chico maravilloso, a pesar de como es, y de como muchas personas lo ven, El ha sabido llevarlo de una manera increible, y no se ha negado ni por un segundo a que todo mejorara con el tiempo y esta decidido a dejar que las cosas mejoren. Me encanta como personaje, creo que es divertidisimo, es especial pero no por su apariencia, es especial por la manera en la que conectas con su alma. Y es el personaje adecuado del cual aprender un millon de cosas. Tambien me encantan sus amigos Jacky Summer, aunque parezca absurdo estos chicos demuestran valentia en ir contra todos porque ven lo especial de este chico. 
 De verdad me he equivocado con este libro, me ha encantado y creo que deberia ser compartido millones de veces y llevarlo hasta las futuras generaciones. Hay mucha crueldad en el mundo y libros como estos podrian ayudarnos a erradicar parte de ella. El mensaje mas importante es claro: no importa como luces por fuera, sino por dentro.
WHY DID I NOT READ THIS SOONER?!
Choose kind is one of the themes of this book. Loved it and I hope everyone reads it.
Best book ever! It's really sweat!

It has been a while since I've read a book I didn't want to end yet I constantly wanted to read what happened next. August is starting middle school after being home schooled his entire life. But in that short life he has faced 27 surgeries and constant stares from people who don't understand his deformity. He has the love of a great family and soon he has the support of friends. It is the story of a year in his life but it is so much more. Told in alternating points of view, the reader comes to see that there is more than one side to a story. An incredible book that I'll be encouraging people to read for years to come.

This book is an easy read, yet, it really touched my heart. I love how August felt that some kids (or some people) do not really intend to be rude, but it's just how they react. 
 I wish more people would have the positive outlook that August has. He is aware of his deficiencies, and sometimes feels sorry for it, but he has come to terms with it. He really is a wonder. 
 I love that the book has different voices (the kids involved in the book), so the reader is able to identify with the actual feelings of the person who is talking at that time. 
 Love love love this! 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives."
This was quite a thought-provoking read.

3 1/2 stars. 
 This book is quite the emotional roller coaster! It is very compelling and sweet. A friend of mine had mentioned it to me a while back but I was reluctant to read it due to reviews saying it is sad. And yes it is! It is a bittersweet, and sometimes depressing story. Sometimes the way the parents were, or kids acted toward their parents annoyed me a bit, but aside from that, it is a good book! Jack got on my nerves a few times but he ended up being a nice kid. I thought Auggie was endearing and his relationship with his older sister was refreshing. They weren't the "get-outta-my-room!" "you're-so-annoying-I-hate-you!"-type stupid children that are so prevalent nowadays in literature (and even in movies and tv!) The way the children talked also bothered me, but it is a cute story. Prepare to tear up in the end.
Sweet (if corny) book about accepting differences in others.

** spoiler alert ** 
 Auggie has severe facial deformities. He has gone through countless surgeries to fix how he looks & while it is better, he will never look normal. His mom decides he should stop being homeschooled & start school at a private school. At first he is against it, but he ends up going anyway. It is tough at first because he has no friends & is kind of a freak show. But slowly, he starts to make friends. The story switches perspectives so we can see how torn his sister is over sometimes feeling like she doesn't want people to know about him & how other people he interacts have their own issues with parents divorcing etc. Towards the end of the school year his class goes on a 2 day trip where they hike around the woods. He has a great time until some kids from another school make him feel like a total freak and try to push him around. Then some kids from his school rally around him & get in a fight helping defend him. After that, he really is treated like one of the gang. He graduates with friends & is looking forward to the following school year. Good book.

Augie, age ten, has all kinds of lessons for us. This book was recommended to my by my granddaughter, 11 year old, Savannah. She loved it and I did also. I always like to read books, see movies, and hear stories about people who are willing to bridge the gap to meet others no matter how diverse they may be.

I appreciate that, at the end of the day, this book is not that different from every other middle-grade novel about a boy, because the point is that Auggie is not that different from every other middle-grade boy. But I have read so many of those books lately that it made enjoying this book difficult for me. It was a lovely story, I cried a couple times, but I just didn't get pulled into it. 
 I also heard an interview with Palacio in which she said that one of the reasons she wrote this book was to try to compensate for handling herself badly when her own child was frightened by another child with a facial abnormality. I have some mixed feelings about that, which also colored my reading.

This is probably the most moving and instructive piece of writing I've ever seen. It's for "young adults" but anyone can enjoy it. I read this, and the sequel chapter "Julian" with my 10 year old and was blown away. It's like nothing else you've ever read. Nothing can describe it. This book will pick you up from your very soul, hold you, then put you down in a different place. Read it. Share it. Let it take you. That's all I can say.

Every middle school student should be required to read this book. August, the main character, was born with a severe facial abnormality. He is just like any other kid only he looks different. He is entering junior high/middle school for the first time and trying to find a way to fit in an already awkward environment. This story is narrated from everyone's point of view in August's life, from his sister to his friends. They share how they learned to accept and love August and the impact he has had on their lives.

I don't know why it took me so long to read this book. It was really good. Should be required reading for 4th-6th graders. I'm going to have my 9 year old read it before I take it back to the library.

Favorite book I've read, in a REALLY long time... So touching, loved the change to different perspectives and also the writing styles changes. Beautiful character that helped me understand perspectives, similar to Out of My Mind by Sharon M. Draper. I wept when the book ended because I couldn't handle it concluding. Beautiful, touching, fabulous, unforgettable book. Complete treasure for every moment read. 
 Favorite pieces: 
 "If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 "It's like people you see sometimes, and you can't imagine what it would be like to be that person, whether it's somebody in a wheelchair or somebody who can't talk. Only, I know that I'm that person to other people, maybe to every single person... To me, though, I'm just me. An ordinary kid."

Wonder --- was a wonderful, tug at your heart strings book & oh what a message it sends! 
 What a powerful message was conveyed in this story of Auggie Pullman! What does it mean to be seen as "different" in the eyes of others---especially kids? Middle school can be an extremely rough time for many but through just a bit of kindness, a young student's life could be made just that much easier. 
 Wonder is a book to be read by kids and adults. Parents could most definitely share in the reading experience to help to instill & discuss the message found throughout the book - showing kindness towards other.

This book is meant for YOUNG readers, not young adults, in my opinion. Grades 3-6 is probably the most appropriate audience. That said, for children in that age range, it is an excellent book, and would be a great first novel to read as a class to introduce concepts such as point of view and theme. The story reminded me of Freak the Mighty, which I taught as a first year teacher, in tone and character; however, this novel is not as plot heavy, and for that reason, it may bore some reluctant readers. The characters were likable and the morals portrayed in Palacio's book are truly good, solid lessons to drive home to kids. A very short, quick read, and a decent story.

This is the story of Auggie, a 5th grade boy who was born with severe facial deformities and has spent much of his young life recovering from multiple surgeries addressing various realated issues. Auggie is used to being stared at and shunned for his unusual appearance, but he has always been somewhat sheltered and protected in the safety of his family and homeschooled by his mother. Now as a 5th grader, Auggie is about to begin attending a regular school for the very first time. As might be expected, Auggie's physical appearance makes his first year at Beecher Prep extremely challenging but ultimately rewarding. 
 This is a very moving book. Kids can be cruel as we all know, but this book shows that kids can also be kind. There is cruelty but also a lot of goodness in this story. I especially liked Auggie's parents. It seems in books written for this age group, parents are often represented as absent or negligent or self-absorbed or clueless. It was refreshing to read about solid parents who were right there and really trying to do the right thing for their kids in the midst of difficult circumstances. 
 I really liked this book...but you might want to keep some tissues handy while reading.

Much like main character August Pullman, on the surface, Wonder is a book that seems flawed. 
 A first-person account of a young boy with an uncommon face, the narrative pops from one young head to another in a way that should be distracting, if not downright chaotic. Instead, by giving you the chance to step outside of August's perspective and see all the hidden ways in which his condition affects family and friends, this brilliant bit of rule-breaking broadens your appreciation of a tale that's bound to remind you why kindness is -- and forever will be -- king. Along with the true-to-tween ramblespeech that sometimes meanders across the page, there is an optimism and innocence to each chapter that nicely balances the emotional heaviness of the main character's first attempts at joining the "normal" world of middle school, where bullies hide behind friendships, flashlights, and parents alike. 
 In short, it is uplifting, it is entertaining, and it wields each blemish like a lesson the rest of us have yet to learn. Just like August.
One of the best. A simply written tearjerker. To describe it one word, it is a WONDER

this was a quick one-night read, and it was great. the ending was a bit too happily every after, but it's a tough subject for a kid's book and so it was like the characters, and reader!, deserved a prize (i.e. the tidy happy ending) for getting through it. as a new parent, it was tough to read about auggie at times, and i really liked the very believable ways the adults were portrayed in the book. the pov shifted, and i enjoyed that too, though justin's section was the weakest, and most distracting with the lowercase writing (though, ha, that's how i write too! ;) ) all in all, a very good book that i would not hesitate to recommend to any kids, especially boys. and that's always a yay.

Well written preteen book about a boy who is born with facial abnormalities and how the world reacts to him when he starts school for the first time...in middle school nonetheless. I really enjoyed this book and I can see why our town chose it for the incoming sixth graders summer reading. The characters were realistic middle schoolers (although I feel they seems more like sixth graders than fifth, but maybe kids that are raised in the city mature faster?). The book is told from a few points of views so even the kids you don't like in the beginning you see their side by the end. This tale of acceptance and the importance of being kind are not just for kids. Adults can learn a thing or two because you never know what battle people are facing.

Wonderful: the first word that came to my mind after reading this book. The story is simple and at the first instant it looks like hundreds of others wherein the protagonist has some disability and then he overcomes that becoming a hero. I would not call August a disable, yet he is no ordinary child. Imagine yourself screaming away people! Imagine people giving you that pity look! Imagine children of your class having this view that one touch of yours will make them like you! Imagine born with that face! 
 In a world where how you look holds paramount importance, August does not only have an ugly face, he has a deformed face. But hold on, he is not someone who sits back and cribs about it. Yes, occasionally he has breakdowns; he has those moments where he wonders what has he been wrong to get this treatment but this small kid of 13 knows how to laugh at himself. And this is what touches you the most. Protected by a loving family, August has always been home schooled until his parents decide to send him to school. A new experience altogether, here August finds friends who initially talked to him out of pity but soon realized that inside the ugly face lies a normal teenager, one who is not superficial, one whom you can trust, one who is brilliant in academics inspite of being homeschooled . 
 What has left me awestruck is the maturity of this child. While reading the book, I was wondering had I been in his position, would I have had the courage to go out? I think not! 
 This book made me sad and happy at the same time. Sad, because of our narrow perception of beauty: How do we judge people and make choices in our life has so much to do with how we look and how other look according to us! Come on, be true to yourselves: how often do we give those glances to people who do not look like us, people who are born different 
 Happy, because despite all our judgement of people based on how they look, there is enough kindness in the world. I was happy to read about transformation of people from befriending him out of pity to being true friends. And the book made me smile when August got his well-deserved 'standing ovation' in the end. 
 I think it should be made must read for every child to instill in them seeds of kindness and to make them sensitize towards others. And not only children, this book is for every person because there is an August Pullman in everyone. And because everybody secretly wishes that 'there should be a rule that everyone in this world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lifetime'.
I enjoyed this book and found it to be inspiring. Great book-and message-for middle school age, thought younger and older will enjoy it.

Wonder is the heartwarming yet at times heartbreaking story of Auggie, a young boy born with a very rare genetic condition. The story not only follows Auggie but we get to see from some of the people in Auggie's life too which was a great addition. 
 Teaching important lessons throughout a novel without preaching or patronising is a very difficult line to walk, in my experience not many authors can do it, but R J Palacio did just that and then some. People of all ages should read this book. Going into this I thought "What could I possibly learn from a book classed as middle grade?" Please don't dismiss this book because of the middle grade label! Anyone from 9 to 90 (or older if you manage to get there. Kudos to you!) can enjoy this novel and really get something out of it. 
 5 big, shiny, Wondrous stars!
Heel mooi boek voor kinderen, maar ook volwassenen. In een keer uitgelezen en aan mijn zoon doorgegeven, die het ook niet weg kan leggen.

This was a moving and very sweet little book. I wasn't actually going to give it 4 stars until I read the last hundred pages or so. Up until that point, it was a lovely story about a young boy (August, or Auggie), with serious deformities trying to settle into a new school. It was an endearing yet unremarkable story. But the whole book seems to be working up to the last 1/3 or so where the author really brings Auggie's story to a moving and captivating climax. I was very close to tears in the last few pages which is strange for me as I very rarely cry when reading. I would definitely recommend this relatively short novel as its childlike innocence and heart-warming truths are unparalleled in anything else I've read.

Love, love, loved this book. Listened to the audio book with the whole family on a car trip. It had something for everyone. We laughed, I cried a little, we all really enjoyed it, even my husband who isn't really into reading.

I'm so glad that I just discovered I can add a shelf "For Arlo" to my goodreads reviews, as this one definitely makes the cut. I LOVED this book. It's the story of a boy born with a severe and very rare birth defect that has mostly affected his face and hearing. It's the story of growing up with this challenge told not just from the boy (August Pullman)'s perspective, but also told from his those that come into his life as he turns ten and attends school for the first time entering the fifth grade. 
 I straight up cried three times while reading this book, and teared up another three - four, so there are definitely heartbreaking moments in this story. Emotions expressed through the way that only a fifth grader can, that brought me back to my own experiences growing up and also made me brace myself for Arlo's experiences to come. This is one of those books that as a parent makes you so thankful for your healthy children, and also makes you aware of how important it is to have those children be kind, empathetic people. 
 As August enters school for the first time he has many challenges with making friends, especially at first, as there is a class jerk (of course), but there are also those kids that are simply good people. You cheer for August as things become easier for him and he makes friends, and your heart breaks for him when the pitfalls come, and of course they do. For whatever reason I was very much able to take this fictional child right into my heart and wanted to protect him and help him as he goes through this year. As he experiences the same things that we all did: a bully, those kids that you thought were your friends talking behind your back, isolation, and acceptance. 
 I don't want to give anything away, as I usually try not to do with my reviews, so I will just say that this is a book that I think everyone should add to their reading list. It made me think of an article about how those who read are able to be more empathetic and understanding because we experience these things that we read in a way that you can't simply by watching it on television, and this is something that you will be glad you experienced.
"Todo el mundo deberia recibir una ovacion del publico puesto en pie al menos una vez en su vida, porque todos vencemos al mundo" Auggie
This week has a big lesson about kindness and humbleness, i think It is technically a kids book but everyone should read it.

Aside from this being a great book with a great message, I really enjoyed how it was written. Once I finished I showed it to my 8 year old son and told him I'd like him to read it in a year or so. He responded "Wonder! My teacher has that book and I've been reading it!". It turns out he is reading the illustrated version and I'm not sure if it's an abridged version or not, so I'll definitely have him read the original full book soon. Such an important read for kids and adults.
Must read for all. Auggie has a message that children and adults need to hear.

I listened to this with Alex for his book club. It was a heartwarming story, and we plan to see the movie with his friends when it comes out this fall. It was a bit young for him as a reader, but it was a good story with good characters.

As a teacher of fourth and fifth-graders, it's sometimes hard for me to find the right books for them. I enjoy lots of young adult books, but many of them are too much (in a lot of ways) for my students. This book provides plenty of interesting food for thought, but is really a book for the age I teach. Reading it, I was smiling sometimes, in tears at other moments, and I stayed up late last night to finish it. I was trying to decide what book to use for our last read-aloud for the year, and when I put this down last night I knew I'd found it. (My students are used to me getting teary during certain read-alouds, so they're prepared.) 
 In fact, I'm proposing that our entire 4th/5th unit read it over the summer so we can come back in the fall and start having discussions about kindness, about being an upstander, about how hard it is to be a good friend sometimes, and about how to apologize when you screwed up. I just think this is a terrific book.

Wow, I don't know what else to say. I love the entirety of it! It's well-written and I'm deeply touched by Auggie and the other characters in this story. I lost count how many times I've watched the movie trailer and I'm just really excited to see the movie next month!
EVERYONE should read this book. Especially kids. I wish I had read this when I was younger. All it takes is for one brave kid to make a world of difference to someone who really needs a friend.
Another children book that made me cry. And yes, sometimes the universe isn't kind to some kids, especially a kid that's not ordinary.

Wonder is perfect for all ages, from kids to adults. The story of young August, who has a severe facial deformity, will make you cheer! 
 -Steph

Daha azini veremezdim ki :( Kitabi okurken yasadigim duygular, burkulan kalbim, doktugum gozyaslari... Hicbirinin degeri kalmazdi. Su boktan zamanlarda okunabilecek en naif, en olmasi istenilesi seyleri anlatan kitapti. Bilerek veya bilmeyerek kirmasak birbirimizi, onyargilari asabilsek, baskalarinin dusuncelerine gore degil de kendimiz icin kendimizle barisik yasasak vs. Soguk dus etkisi yaratti. Tekrar tekrar sorgulamaya basladim bazi seyleri. Tesekkurler Palacio.

mixaria,rom ch`emi patara mamidashvilis saqvarel cigns shemt`xvevit` gadavacqdi missave saxlshi, vinat`xovre da cavikit`xe. iset`i t`bili, tkbili cignia, bednieri var,rom avgust pulmani amieridan ch`ems mexsierebashic` gach`ndeba. namdvilad vapireb,rom qvela shemxvedr mozards vurch`io es cigni. 
 noembershi gamodis p`ilmi da mot`minebit` veli :)

This is a really good book, well written with heartfelt lessons about including others and not treating someone poorly over outward appearances they can't control. I enjoy YA books, however this one is not timeless such as Harry Potter or The Giver. There were a lot of references here to to modern day middle school culture such as Diary of a Wimpy Kid and newer Star Wars movies. This really brought the book down for me. Also, the fart topic in the first chapter and the repeated jokes about Mr Tushmans name got old FAST. I almost discontinued reading the book due to those. Beyond that, the book is great. I love how the story is told from the viewpoints of different characters, how not only Auggie is affected by his facial deformity but his friends and sister etc. I recommend this book as long as you can look past the immaturity of the first chapter and the modern references.

Excellent YA fiction book about a facially-deformed boy's struggles through his first year of middle school. Narrated mostly by the main character, August, with some chapters told from the point of view of friends and family. This book runs you through a gamut of emotions as you watch August go from being a protected home-schooled kid to experiencing the cruel realities of being a new kid in school. According to a twenty-year veteran middle school teacher I know who also read the book, Wonder is a very accurate portrayal of what goes on in a typical middle school. Despite its 320 pages it was a really quick read. While I was reading the book I kept thinking of a quote from one of my favorite authors, Kurt Vonnegut: "Hello babies. Welcome to Earth. It's hot in the summer and cold in the winter. It's round and wet and crowded. On the outside, babies, you've got a hundred years here. There's only one rule that I know of, babies-"God damn it, you've got to be kind."

Auggie Pullman has been home schooled his entire life because of a severe facial deformity. This year all that is about to change as Auggie will go to a real school for the first time and begin fifth grade at Beecher Prep. Wonder details Auggie's first year attending school with it's ups and downs. Palacio masterfully conveys themes of family, friendship, and bullying in her debut middle grade novel. Wonder is divided into eight parts told through a different character's perspective. The first and last parts are told through Auggie's perspective which brings all of the parts together. Palacio is not one to waste words and thus the pacing of Wonder is very tight and moves along. 
 Yet, what truly drives Wonder are the characters. Auggie is a sweet, earnest kid who loves Star Wars. He handles reactions to his deformity very well, he is used to people reacting badly to his face. Yet, we see his vulnerable side too. He is very realistically drawn. Via, August's older sister, is another exceptional character we meet in Wonder. We see her struggle between being Auggie's protector, the girl who everyone knows as August's sister, the easy child and between forming an identity for herself at her new high school. It's quite a touching side story and speaks to the complexity of family interactions. Palacio shows that kindness is necessary and something we should endeavor to treat others. I think in our fast paced world treating others with dignity is something to strive towards and not forget, and Wonder beautifully reinforces this idea.
Everyone needs to read this book immediately. It's heartwrenching and heartwarming at the same time, and it's absolutely beautiful.
Everyone in the world should read this book. Appropriate for 10+

Susah amat yak bikin reviewnya. Bukunya bagus, mengharukan. Mengingatkan kita untuk bersyukur terutama untuk yang suka mengeluh soal penampilan. Ketampar banget deh yang merasa gendut, merasa kurang cantik. Well mungkin lo tidak putih, tidak langsing, tidak mancung, tapi setidaknya terlahir sempurna. 
 Sempurna karena lahir dengan perangkat lengkap. Langit-langit mulut menyatu, punya rahang, gigi geligi yang lengkap, punya tulang pipi, kelopak mata, hidung, bibir, alis, daun telinga. 
 Si Auggie ini nggak punya kelopak mata, nggak punya bibir, nggak punya rahang, nggak punya daun telinga. Gue sendiri agak susah membayangkannya. Ada pembaca Goodreads menyarankan untuk googling tentang sindrom Treacher-Collins syndrome...tapi gue nggak tega. 
 Melihat yang seperti itu memang mengejutkan dan IMO, reaksi kita selanjutnya yang menentukan kualitas kita sebenarnya. Bagaimana pun, yang cacat itu manusia juga, punya perasaan, punya pikiran. 
 *review ini belum selesai*

If you only read one book this year, this should be the one. If you know a 10 year old, or ever were a 10 year old, this book will produce a huge lump in your throat. It will make you reexamine how you treat everyone around you every day. You will instantly relate the characters to people you know. This book will make you become a better person. I hope that it becomes required reading in every middle school!

Wow. I can't even begin to describe how amazing and enormous this book is. I hope I get the chance to teach this someday, and even though it's about a fifth grader, I would teach this in high school. Beautifully written and full of empathy and love, this is one incredible children's book. Awareness makes you kind, and reading this has already helped me to translate that into my life. 
 I couldn't love this book any more than I do.

"Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 Everyone needs to stop what they're doing and read this book. Right now. It's that good. It's a "I'd rather sit and read this book and cry next to a pool than do tequila shots with my friends in Mexico" kind of good. It is written in such simple language and yet has such a profound messages and undertones. Have I mentioned how much I loved this book?
Nunca antes un libro me habia hecho llorar de orgullo y felicidad!

"I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 Who deserves that? R.J. Palacio. This book was completely life-changing for me. 
 Think of the worst thing that's ever happened to you. Well, I bet none of that explains the life Auggie went through. 
 This book taught me a very important life lesson without even telling me to. It triggered that tiny little speck I had in me called "sympathy"

When I finally broke down and purchased this book at B&N, the check out girl was blabbing on about how she has had several friends read this to their elementary kids. I smiled, nodded, took my bag moved right along. Now I know why. 
 I think this book gives us a beautiful opportunity and platform to discuss how we treat those that are different from us, physically and mentally. I could definitely see myself reading this to my kids when they are a bit older. It does provide a platform to teach us how judgement can be painful. The importance of empathy and compassion. 
 I thought Palacio did a wonderful job writing from the view point of these kids. My heart ached for them. I cheered for them. I wanted to hug them. In fact, after reading this, I wanted to hug everyone that I am close to and love dearly. 
 So many people talk about how sad the book is. Honestly, I only cried once, and it was when the DOG died. So I didn't really find the book SAD, but it did tug at my heart strings. 
 I did have one problem with this book, and I am definitely running the risk of sounding cold and heartless. But I think I am just thinking realistically. I feel like the book ended a bit TOO positively. The mean boy changed schools, August suddenly was friends with everyone, and he was given an award. It was beautiful...but was it true to the real world? In todays world, the mean kid won't always just change schools, or change his mind about you. The whole world has yet to learn to overlook things like physical deformities. I hope all those like August WILL have the courage to take on the world. And I pray that they encounter people like Summer and Jack, not Julian. 
 Oh, yeah, and I felt like Justin's POV was a bit unnecessary.
Being Mom to two versions of an Auggie, and a Via/Summer, I loved this book.
This book grabbed me like no other book in a while. It made me think and ultimately wonder not only about the character in the book but how we treat other people. Awesome book!

At first, the chapter kind of reminds me of David Levitan's The Lovers Dictionary, where there's a title and the story started with that title. The differences are, R. J. Palacio - La leccion de August really tells the story, not a few sentences put together and most of the titles are a phrase. 
 It's important for the readers to know that August (main character) won't tell us what he looks like (especially the face) because he think he has an extraordinary face. So Palacio keeps us guessing as we read it, though she drops hints here and there and finally, she reveals them all. 
 Palacio plays every character very well. 
 She's consistent about the character's personality, down to the little details like responses and behavior tendencies. 
 As I read this book pages after pages, it occurs to me that the story was written beautifully raw it gives me a warmhearted feeling. I also stepped into the shoes of the less aggressive bullying victim and feel how uncomfortable it actually feels like. 
 Even though there's some repetition of the story, but we get to see it from another point of view. 
 About the plot: you never really know what's coming. 
 My favorite character: August. He can turn mean things people do to him into jokes that make me smile or laugh. His sarcasm is the best. 
 "Sometimes people surprise us" just like Palacio did when she tells me this story and reading this book is a wonderful journey. 
 I said once that even though kids are young, doesn't mean we can't learn from them and honestly, I learn many things from August. 
 I hope one day they turn this incredible story into a movie. 
 One more thing. I love this book, like love Augiee. 
 P.S. 
 Those last part bombards me into smiling tears.

just a few points about the actual writing of the book, ive always found that i can finish a book quicker if the chapters are shorter, for some reason a really long chapter will intimidate me and ill think "nah cant get that done before bed or going out" so having only a page or two between chapters allowed me to devour this book in just a few hours. 
 secondly, the use of multiple point of view characters i found gave me a greater experience and helped me see Palacio's story in several different ways, i was a fan of this method of storytelling in Eleanor and Park, The red pyramid and A song of ice and fire (even though that's on a much grander scale) 
 as for the story, i was very entertained and enjoyed the experience immensely, not on the same scale as my 5 star books but still excellent. You will definitely enjoy this book, hopefully the words cute and heart warming wont demean this novel but hopefully the experience makes you approach each new day with extra kindness.
Very sweet and heart warming story, with both laugh out loud, and tearful, sombre moments. Excellently written, almost like the story could jump off the page and be a reality.

An excellent middle school read. Although the main characters are younger I honestly think it would be an appropriate high school read as well. A story of overcoming obstacles, friendship, family, courage and compassion. I will be adding it to my high school library.

I'm sorry, I passed out. I just don't understand what the fuss is about. How do you take 300-some pages to explain that the kid looks weird? And what's all this talk about fully fleshed out characters? Actually, this book reminds me of something I wrote once called "Foundling Fathers." I was once very proud of it, but even then I had an uncomfortable intimation that it was too sentimental and that the characters were all too much like sympathetic bobbleheads. This book is the same way: "sure, sure, sweetie. The principal's name is Mr. TUSHman! Oh, ha ha! Isn't that endearing." 
 I just don't get it. And it suffers terribly in comparison to the great Golden Compass. (That's one for two on our reading selections there, George! <3)
SOOOOOOO good!!! If I were a person who cries from emotion by reading I would!

Ma che ci sia qualcosa che non va in me, visto che la maggior parte dei casi letterari degli ultimi tempi a me non dice nulla? 
 Come per Miss Peregrine, anche qui sono partita con tante speranze... ne avevo sentito parlare sempre molto bene e ho fatto di tutto per convincermi che quello che stavo leggendo non era pessimo come sembrava. "Dai, continua, vedrai che il motivo per cui tutti lo amano sta per arrivare!" 
 Non e arrivato. Per me questo libro e un festival di buonismo melenso.
Adored!
A true gem. I'm only sorry it took me so long to get a copy and read it.

Wonder is a middle grade fiction about August Pullman and how he is defined by his facial deformity. After being home-schooled he starts fifth grade in a private school. August just wants to be accepted and fit in without being treated like he has the Plague but he is still unique and stays true to himself which I think is wonderful. Even though he looks different, he is funny, intelligent, and a loyal friend. 
 This story didn't wreck me emotionally like I thought it would, granted, there are some really mean, sad, and heartbreaking moments, but it's still funny and lighthearted feeling. 
 There are a few different POV's besides August's and I thought they melded nicely together to bring August's past and future together. Like I think all middle schoolers can attest, those particular grades are hard-even if you don't have a facial deformity. Kids are cruel, but August has a big, kind heart, and I love how authentic and genuine he is. 
 I feel this will be a wonderful book for children this same age, on up to adults, because the message it brings of how to be yourself and how to treat others is one we can all take to heart.

Wonder is wonderful! A great creation! A ten-year-old boy named August has severe facial deformities. He has been home-schooled. Now it is time to start Middle School. Should he be mainstreamed? His parents disagree. 
 He becomes expert in knowing the exact milli-second a person notices him in the room, even when the person attempts to cover up the shock at seeing such a face. We get several clues in mid-point of the book as to what he looks like. 
 Auggie's favorite holiday is Halloween, because then he can wear a mask and no one knows who he is. But something happens on this Halloween Day .... 
 At first, I thought the whole book would be the P.O.V. (point of view) of this ten-year-old. I was pleased to come to Part Two, and find out the author switched to his older sister's voice. Via is starting high school and has problems of her own, including squabbling with her mom. Palacio did a great job writing differently for these two siblings. The other Parts include additional characters in the book. In sum, this is one of the most excellent books that give different P.O.V.'s in assorted styles of writing. 
 Natalie Merchant's song Wonder has this chorus: 
 They say I must be one of the wonders 
 Of god's own creation 
 And as far as they can see they can offer 
 No explanation 
 The author RJ Palacio stated in an interview about seeing a girl with facial deformities and being ashamed of her own reaction. She was afraid her younger son would say something rude so she rushed out of the ice-cream shop. This scene is in her book. On the way home, she heard Merchant's song, thus the idea for Wonder was born. 
 Wonder is geared toward middle schoolers, but will appeal to YAs and adults too. It should be nominated for and even win the Newbery Award.

Augustine--Auggie--Pullman has been homeschooled all his life, but for fifth grade, he is going to go to a private middle school. He's smart enough, but he's anxious. This will be the first time he's had to deal with the push and pull of the middle school society. And he's right to worry. Due to an extremely rare genetic disorder, Auggie has severe facial deformities. He knows people will make fun of him, and that it won't be easy. 
 Auggie tells the reader that whatever s/he imagines that his face looks like, it is worse. He has no ears--no outer ears, so none that show. His eyes are too far down, in the vertical middle of his face. Everything about his face is misshapen, and though he's had nearly 30 surgeries, his face is still a shock to those who see him for the first time. 
 For a kid with so much going against him, Auggie is pretty centered. He has parents and a sister who really love him. And the principal at his new school has selected good students, 'good kids,' to show him around before the school year starts, to be nice to him. 
 That some of these students put on a face of kindness in front of the adults at school and then bully him behind his back shouldn't be a surprise. That one of them can get almost the entire school to turn against Auggie isn't a surprise either. What is a surprise is how the author catches the nuisance of this bullying--from kids who are truly mean to those who just don't know what to do and are having a crisis of conscience. 
 In fact, Palacio catches pretty much everything about middle school that illuminates what a difficult time of transition into adolescence it can be. 
 One of the things I really liked about Wonder is that it isn't peopled by saints/heroes and demons/villains. Auggie's older sister is tired of being thought of as the girl with the deformed brother (who takes up most of her parents' energy through no fault of his own). Still, she is fiercely devoted to Auggie. And even good people really are taken aback at Auggie's appearance. But while the novel accepts that this is normal, it also reminds us that after a week or two, people get used to the unusual features of Auggie's face and then forget about them. He just becomes Auggie, a kid, a schoolmate. 
 I'm always a sucker for good writing, and Wonder has got it. Palacio captures the kids--their conversations and interactions--realistically. 
 While Wonder is a children's book, with a target audience that is Auggie's age, give or take a few years, it's a quick read that even adults will enjoy. I highly recommend it to all. 
 High school housekeeping: Another thing that I love about this book is that, since anyone of any age can enjoy it, it's a great read for high school students working on their reading skills. This isn't true of most middle school books--they just don't interest high schoolers. And because teens like edgier stuff, books written for high school students who are reading below grade level usually deal with issues of teen pregnancy, drugs, gangs, etc. There's nothing wrong with that, and there are many of those books I recommend. But Wonder is another option--an opportunity to become immersed in beautiful writing, in Auggie's emotional responses to his classmates as well as the feelings of everyone who comes in contact with him. It's an opportunity to see how perceptions can and do change, how everything in the world isn't black and white. And that's great for anyone, struggling reader or not.
This book, while intended for 5th-8th graders, is one all ages will love. The writing is great and the story is tender. I loved it!
Auggie Doggie you are the coolest bean

1st time- Dec 9, 2012 
 2nd- Nov 27, 2016
This is a charming, heartbreaking book, and I can't recommend it highly enough -- particularly for nervous parents of future middle-school students.

I have to admit. at first, the idea of a 10 year old boy who has a difficulty in fitting in middle school wasn't appealing (BTW I'm not really into cliched self improvement based books). But this is one of the books that makes you think more about your actions and their consequences. Inspires you to improve your over all attitude toward people and the world. All that without being too self improvement-y.

Before: I wrote notes to record every thought I had while reading this book and to prepare them for the Scarlet book club discussion. I will delay writing a review until the discussion. One thing I will say is that reading this book was a WONDERful experience! 
 UPDATE: 
 I want to mention first that rating this book was the hardest decision ever. I am still doubting my rating and I changed it twice already. It's an absolutely perfect book, I have no issues with it whatsoever but It was not THE BOOK so I couldn't give it 5 stars. 
 One thing that Nicholas Sparks said in a review of this book is "The pages almost turn themselves". I find that very accurate! 
 Alright My Review: I'll just copy everything I wrote in the notes I made after filtering 'em. here we go:- 
 (1)I love how in the book they describe Auggie's ability to read body language & to know or feel people's reactions even without directly meeting their eyes. I think people with special needs or those who suffer severe visible deformities feel that way too, and no matter how how 'normal' people try to pretend everything is or try to look like they didn't notice, they always know.. no matter how nice you try to be, it's still there, and I think it hurts in an indirect way, in a way no one can control.. i think it's one of the most difficult things to live with. 
 I support August's mother decision in admitting him to a school, because sooner or later, he's gonna have to face the world, so it's better for him to earn to adapt to everything around him now instead of hiding behind his mother. 
 (2) VIA'S POINT OF VIEW. Well done! 
 We needed to hear from her. Usually characters like her are neglected by both the family and the author, so thank you Palacio for giving Via a voice. 
 (3) I was in the car on my way to Dubai when I read the part about Daisy's Death and the note I wrote says: " Sad.. Sad.. Sad 
 I would've allowed myself to cry if I weren't in the car with 7 people around me. The story might be fiction but my tears aren't :'( 
 P.S: I did tear up eventually 
 Finale: SO SO SO beautiful. 
 Heart-warming in such a lovely way. Heart-warming is the perfect word to describe this book, If I am to choose only one word. It reminded me of why I read books. It's the FEELS, this zeal of emotion that completely washes over me after I finish a good book is the reason why I love reading. 
 Last bit: I was wondering about Julian's perspective when my friend told me about the two sequels for Wonder and one of them is "Julian's chapter" so no more wondering.. there I will find my answer :D
such a beautiful book. that's all I can say
I really enjoyed this book, though I thought the ending was a bit too happy/unrealistic.

Very well done. It's hard to think about how mean kids are and the things they go through, you want to protect them from everything. This was a quick read but I liked it. Each different perspective added something to the story that would be missed with a single first person narrator. The only thing is I don't think that it was realistic that the meanest kid in their grade would end up getting what comes to him. I wish it was like that in real life. It is surprising that this didn't make the Newberry list, I can't imagine something better came out that year.
LOVEED IT!!! it's the cutest book Ive ever read, I read the special edition that included a Julian Chapter, I strongly hope this chapter makes part of the film
3.5 stars.

This is a book that both young and old should read. It is about August Pullman, who was born with mandibulofacial dysostosis. What that means is that he was born with a very misshapen and contorted face. Up until 5th grade, he was homeschooled because he was having surgeries to try and correct some of the facial abnormalities, but the surgeries did very little in making August look like a common 10-year-old boy. The story basically starts when it was decided that he should attend Beecher Prep School for the first time, starting in 5th grade. At school, kids were afraid to get near him and even ran to wash their hands if they came in contact with him, calling him a monster, ET or a mutant. However, there are always those who step up and Jack and Summer friended August. The teachers, along with several children and his sister Via, helped August find his way in his new world. 
 One of the teachers taught precepts in his class, that is rules about important things. One being: When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind. This is a great book about not judging by what we see.

This is a beauty of a story. It's told in several different viewpoints, some of them surprising. It's definitely more triumphant than tragic. I think that's all I want to say, except that it's appropriate for anyone who thinks it sounds interesting, IMO.

Another great read. Palacio does a great job with developing the character August aka Auggie. It should be a mandatory read for all kids coming into sixth grade. Kindess. The story is about Auggie who has a facial deformity and mom enrolls him into school for fifth grade. He has been home schooled since birth. However, we see the journey he takes for a year in school. The ups and downs of school and his relationship with his sister Via.

A bold look at what life is like for a boy with severe facial abnormalities and how his family, friends, and those around him react. Loved the kid, loved his family, especially his dad and sister, and I can see why this book got so much positive buzz. The writing is quick and spare, snapshots of life for Auggie from his point of view as well as several other people's. 
 It was almost a 5 star book for me, and I certainly recommend it very highly, but I felt a couple of the situations were resolved too quickly or not at all. I wanted to see what happened to Eddie Johnson, and where the heck was Justin at the end? Still, a very satisfying, very heart-wrenching book. I laughed and cried in several places.

Auggie and Melody (from Out Of My Mind) have much in common: they are both intelligent, kind and have something that sets them apart from everyone else. That special something might be, to the outside observer, a physical difference that can be spotted without looking deeply. But that's what makes these two books so great. Looking deeper, we see that they both offer much to us in terms of teaching us what it is to be human-truly human-in an inhumane world. 
 My own complaint was that it contained (yet another) dead dog. I think keeping Daisy alive would not have hurt the storyline at all. 
 Wonder (and Out Of My Mind)should be placed on every classroom and school library shelf. Highly recommended. 
 "...no, no, it's not all random, if it really was all random, the universe would abandon us completely and the universe doesn't. it takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see. like with parents who adore you blindly. and a big sister who feels guilty for being human over you... maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. the universe takes care of all its birds." 
 "Do people look the same when they get to heaven?" 
 "I don't know. I don't think so." 
 "Then how do people recognize each other?" 
 "I don't know, sweetie." She sounded tired. "They just feel it. You don't need your eyes to love, right? You just feel it inside you. That's how it is in heaven. It's just love, and no one forgets who they love."

Just what I needed after reading 13 Reasons Why! I very heart warming story about not judging a person by their appearance. I love the quote at the end "Always be a little kinder than you have to...."

Well this was kind of a disappointment 
 This book was not what I was expecting it to be, and had some things that really bothered me, for example it had six or so points of view, and some of them I Would live really good without... 
 But besides that I really enjoyed the book, I think it deals with the really important subjects, and I would recommend it to anyone... just don't go into this book expecting it's the best book ever.

Hay que leer 'La leccion de August'. Porque no es una simple novela narrada por un nino diferente, sino porque es una leccion vital que nos ayuda a cambiar nuestra percepcion del mundo. Y no puedo terminar de otra manera mas que con un precepto del propio protagonista, nuestro entranable August Pullman: "Todos deberiamos recibir una ovacion al menos una vez en nuestra vida, porque todos vencemos al mundo".
