This story is amazing! As a librarian in an elementary school I think this story should be read by educators and older students. It provides such a great perspective on just being a decent human being. The character of Auggie is such a strong voice for those deemed different and then to have the voices of the others really provides a big picture of "seeing things through someone elses eyes.

One of the most beautiful and inspiring stories I have ever read! I couldn't help but have a huge smile on my face reading the final pages! 
 Would recommend this book to people of all ages.

Really enjoyed this feel-good book about a boy who is "different" and his trip through the 5th grade. Gave a nice perspective from other people's point of view. Had a nice overall theme of the book being kind.
MY. EMOTIONS.
So good. Delightful.

I know the end can be a little 'happy ending' like a children book. But i loved it, it's my favorite book since all the quotes, and the story lf Auggie. Maybe it's not the best book ever, but i loved it
LOVED this book! Different, funny, emotional and just a good good read. I would recommend to all.

I know I'm in the minority with my rating of this book but I must be honest. I knew going into the book that it was written for a younger audience but by the reviews I had read I guess I thought I would be knocked off my feet any way. Unfortunately, it put me to sleep more then knock me off my feet. I found it no more heartwarming, endearing or thought provoking then the story of Peter Rabbit. I also found that the reactions, to Auggies appearance, by both his peers and adults was somewhat dated. I know childhood is a tough time with bullying, peer pressure etc but I do believe that children and adults are more aware of and less judgemental of the diversities within society. I believe this to be true when it comes to race, culture, colour, sexual orientation and of course those with special needs. Perhaps if my kids were 8 or 9 I would read it with them but even then I honestly feel they would be bored. Sorry guys but I have to disagree with everyone one this one.

This is a book about a fifth grade face with a genetic abnormality that causes facial deformations. It is a realistic character study which a switching perspective narrative of the boy, his family, and kids at his school. It sounds depressing but it is touching, and even at times funny. 
 I would have liked a plot, but the subject matter was very interesting in it's own right and well worth the read.

This novel is about August Pullman. He is a ten year old boy who was born with many abnormalities and "defects". He does not look like the other kids, but he is funny, thoughtful and kind. This story accounts Auggie's experience in the 5th grade, the first time he has ever attended public school. You will witness the character transform and you yourself will also transform. 
 Beginning this book, I was a little skeptical. I thought it was starting slow and feared it would be very heavy. However, I loved it. It is so worth the read and teaches a very valuable lesson about appearances and kindness. It was heartwarming and life changing. Thank you R.J. Palacio!

le doy 5 estrellas, aunque tenia mis dudas al iniciar la lectura me ha encantado la Leccion que el libro te deja pienso que sin duda alguna todos necesitan un Auggie pullman que nos ensene el valor de la esencia del corazon para asi restarle un monton de importancia a la apariencia fisica.
a book that's worth every peso you paid for.

Palacio, R.J. (2012). Wonder. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. 
 310 pages. 
 Appetizer: Ten-year-old August "Auggie" Pullman is going to school for the first time in his life. He, his parents and his sister, Via, who is starting the ninth grade at a different school, are all nervous about this. Auggie's face looks different from those of other kids. Due to a one in several million chance of genetics, people stare at Auggie wherever he goes. 
 Despite the fact that his parents, the principal, and some of the teachers and students try to create a welcoming environment for Auggie at Beecher Prep, Auggie still faces bullying, questions and betrayals from his classmates who fear being near him. At times, Auggie will want nothing more than to return to homeschooling. 
 What a powerhouse of a book with such a moving story! Experiences of love and loss, kindness and cruelty, and devotions and betrayals abound. With content related to science (genetics), social studies (Ancient Egypt) and messages about bullying, acceptance and being kind, this is a great classroom read for 4th-6th graders. 
 Wonder is an allusion-rich text. I found myself wishing I'd watched all six of the Star Wars movies more recently so I could know exactly what Auggie was describing. There are also references to The Wizard of Oz, The Hobbit, The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe, Our Town, and a particularly powerful reference to the Cheese Touch from Diary of a Wimpy Kid, that truly demonstrates how ostracized Auggie was during the first part of fifth grade: 
 Tristan didn't even care about the spilled powder on the floor or that he ruined the experiment. What he was most concerned about was getting to the lab sing to wash his hands as fast as possible. That's when I knew for sure that there was this thing about touching me at Beecher Prep. 
 I think it's like the Cheese Touch in Diary of a Wimpy Kid. The kids in that story were afraid they'd catch the cooties if they touched the old moldy cheese on the basketball court. At Beecher Prep, I'm the old moldy cheese." (p. 72) 
 Yikes! And very moving! The way Palacio and Auggie describe his classmate's behaviors ring true. This book can be a very upsetting mirror for some readers' behaviors. (But don't worry, this metaphorical mirror doesn't always reveal the worst of ourselves. Palacio does a great job of showing the complexity and varied natured of a lot of the characters' struggles.) 
 I was rather surprised when I reached Part II of Wonder and I realized that the book jumped to Auggie's sister's point of view (and in later parts to those of some of both siblings' classmates). I wanted to stay with Auggie! But, the more I read, I saw the importance of seeing different characters' perspectives and motives. 
 Also, I'm rather fond of Wonder's booktrailer. You can watch that here: 
 Here's also a Publisher's Weekly article describing how support for Wonder has lead Random House Children's Books to launch an online anti-bullying campaign called Choose Kind. 
 Dinner Conversation: 
 "I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid. I mean, sure, I do ordinary things. I eat ice cream. I ride my bike. I play ball. I have an XBox. Stuff like that makes me ordinary. I guess. And I feel ordinary. Inside. But I know ordinary kids don't make other ordinary kids run away screaming in playgrounds. I know ordinary kids don't get stared at wherever they go." (p. 3) 
 "'I don't want to go to school,' I answered, folding my arms. 
 "It would be good for you, Auggie," said Mom. 
 "Maybe I'll go next year," I answered, looking out the window. 
 "This year would be better, Auggie," said Mom. "You know why? Because you'll be going into fifth grade, and that's the first year of middle school--for everyone. You won't be the only new kid." 
 "I'll be the only kid who looks like me," I said. 
 "I'm not going to say it won't be a big challenge for you, because you know better than that," she answered. "But it'll be good for you, Auggie. You'll make lots of friends. Any you'll learn things you'd never learn from me." (p. 12) 
 "They were just being normal dumb kids. I know that. I kind of wanted to tell them that. Like, it's okay, I know I'm weird-looking, take a look, I don't bite. Hey, the truth is, if a Wookiee started going to the school all of a sudden, I'd be curious, I'd probably stare a bit! And if I was walking with Jack or Summer, I'd probably whisper to them: Hey, there's the Wookiee. And if the Wookiee caught me saying that, he'd know I wasn't trying to be mean. I was just pointing out the fact that he's a Wookiee." (p. 62) 
 "For me, Halloween is the best holiday in the world. It even beats Christmas. I get to dress up in a costume. I get to wear a mask. I get to go around like every other kid with a mask and nobody thinks I look weird. Nobody takes a second look. Nobody notices me. Nobody knows me. 
 I wish every day could be Halloween. We could all wear masks all the time. Then we could walk around and get to know each other before we got to see what we looked like under the masks." (p. 73) 
 "August is the Sun. Me and Mom and Dad are planets orbiting the Sun. The rest of our family and friends are asteroids and comets floating around the planets orbiting the Sun. The only celestial body that doesn't orbit August the Sun is Daisy the dog, and that's only because to her little doggy eyes, August's face doesn't look very different from any other human's face." (p. 82) 
 Tasty Rating: !!!!!
this. book. everyone should read it. everyone should choose kindness. the end.
Beautifully written novel. I especially liked the structure, with multiple first person points of view and short chapters.

***4.5 stars*** 
 I found this book beautiful. Because? It tells a story of beautiful people. Those people who live and love in the most beautiful way possible, no matter how they look on the outside. They know that even if they had done wrong, they can always try and do better to make things right, because that's worth it. 
 I think everyone should read this book, especially kids and teenagers, so that they can get inspired to become kinder than necessary. 
 P.S.: Finally I found a fictional character who shares my birth date... no wonder I liked Auggie so much!

Auggie was born with severe facial deformitites that required many surgeries. He is 10 years old and will be entering the 5th grade. He is finally healthy enough to go to school, rather than being home schooled. He just wants to be treated like a "normal" kid, but Auggie isn't sure that is possible.
THIS BOOK IS PLAYING WITH MY FEELINGS.
I couldn't put this down. What a wonderful, kind, beautiful book.

Oh goodness, what a terrific book. I love books that are so simple but have such an impact that you are still thinking about it hours, days later. This is one that I will gladly recommend to friend and family.
Recommended by Scott & Sarah
Awesome! A must read for middle school!

Ten-year-old Auggie, who has always been home-schooled because he was born with severe facial deformities, enters fifth grade at a private Manhattan school. His experiences with teachers, administrators and other students are chronicled in this very memorable and important book. Auggie deals with bullies and insensitive people, but also develops good friends who learn to see beyond his appearance. 
 The author's decision to tell this story from multiple points of view is absolutely inspired and adds immeasurably to the book's impact. Funny, poignant and ultimately uplifting, this excellent book should--in my opinion--be read by every middle school student.
Amazing. I loved this book. The way the writer brings out the different perspectives of each character was really interesting and refreshing!!!!
A great book that surfaces all of the social insecurities that we, as humans, experience at some point in our lives. Life can definitely be harsh but kindness and honesty always prevail.

Beautiful books like these make up for the crappy world I live in - and that's exactly what Wonder is all about! <3 
 I adored the simplicity of characters more human than we could ever imagine in fictional worlds and a story that warms me to the bottom of my soul. 
 August "Auggie" is neither special nor wonderful - what he is is different; in ways that outwardly look different to other people. 
 But he doesn't see himself that way - he sees someone who loves star wars; is kind of a geek; adores his family and loves his dog. He also has the same insecurities that other kids have; and honestly if he hadn't been described physically at the start of the book; I wouldn't hhave even known that he was different. 
 And when THIS realization hit me; I knew what I had in my hands was a gem of a book - for the author did the unthinkable - they made sure that we as readers understood Auggie for him and not for his physical attributes! 
 Wonderfully and beautifully done - can't wait to watch the movie in November! <3 
 For more reviews visit For The Love of Fictional Worlds :) 
 Do come join us at For The Fictional Worlds Facebook Page
Funny and believable characters, if a little cheesy Hollywood at times. Presents a topic which I hadn't really read much in other literature so a refreshing change.

I have many things to say about this book, but I will start with this: had I known one particular thing about this book going into it, I would have been better prepared and less emotionally crippled. It isn't a spoiler, per se, but I'll hide it just the same. 
 The dog dies. 
 Shew. I feel better now that I've given you all the opportunity to prepare yourselves. 
 Honestly, I adored this book. The chapters are approximately 2 pages long, and the sections are divided up among central characters. Thankfully, though, August serves as the bookends to this book--he opens and closes it in a way. It's a lovely book about overcoming challenges out of our control and how people approach those challenges differently. Nothing about this book is obvious; nothing hits you over the head (except the above "spoiler"). Instead, you are almost courted with the author's soft, subtle descriptions, gentle and believable dialogue, and characterization that was just so spot-on. 
 This book, imo, will make you want to be a better person.

The question at the top of this review box reads, "What did you think?" As I sit here and try to answer that, all I can think is, "Wow!" I seriously want everyone to read this book - young and old alike. It is well-written and the characters come to life, grab your heart, and make you care. 
 It is difficult to summarize this book. You could say it about the external face we show the world, versus who we believe we are inside. It is about being different and wanting to be normal. It is about families and friendships. It is about the difficulties of middle school. There is a quote in the book from Henry Ward Beecher that reads, "He is the greatest whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own." The heart of main character August Pullman will lift up your heart as you root for him to the final pages of this book.
Very interesting perspective. Middle School students enjoyed it!
Loved the book and the multiple perspectives.

4.5. 
 Touching, heart-warming, and uplifting. I mean, I wouldn't say that this book perhaps deserves all of the hype that it is getting, but it is most definitely a really amazing read. I liked the looks into not just this boy, but most everyone around him and how their lives worked, and how Auggie's life did affect them. It might have been a tad on the overly optimistic side, but that doesn't really bother me all that much. I feel like in this type of book, I'd much rather read this type of story than a supremely depressing one. Anyway, I really, really enjoyed this book, it just didn't completely blow me away as much as I may have wanted. 
 August's face is not "normal." The specifics aren't important, but many would call him very ugly and deformed. This story is about his fifth grade year, his first time in a real, physical school, and the lives of everyone else around him during this time. 
 SPOILERSSSSSSSSSSSSS DISCUSSION!!!!!!!!! 
 So I think my favorite character may have been Miranda, and that's not to say that I agreed with all of her decisions or anything, but I just liked her. I liked that she did kind of try new things, even though it may not have ended up perfectly, she did try. And I liked how close she was with Auggie, despite it all, and how she cared about him a lot, even when she and Via had separated a little bit. When she called him I may have literally "aww"ed. I also loved that she let Via go on instead of her when she saw everyone who had come for her. I just really liked her, which surprised me because when we were first exposed to her character I was definitely wary. 
 I also liked that we saw that life for Via was also kind of crappy sometimes. Like, Auggie is going to get most of the attention in the family, and that makes sense, he is in a tough place. But she also has bad times and he can't always be before her, and I also really liked that whole part of the book where she didn't want to tell her parents because she didn't want to be defined by Auggie. And that makes sense, I also wouldn't want to be defined by my siblings (though sometimes I think it's kind of inevitable) and I think her feelings are totally valid, but it is also totally valid for Auggie to feel a little betrayed by that. In my personal opinion, I would say that her feeling should have been slightly more respected in this instance (though that would have ruined the ending) just because she's been looked over so many times. 
 Okay, it was very odd to me that the boy on the cover has about three features (all of which are normal) and two of which are the very two features that Auggie hates the most. It loses some of it's validity in regards to his appearance. Like, that Auggie feels like his ears are super ugly (and it is pointed out multiple times that they look NOTHING like normal ears) is a fairly important part, and I feel like if a cover is going to have the face of a character who's face is very infamously not normal, you want to make the face on said cover very obviously not normal. It just wasn't... what I would have been looking for. Based on the cover before I read this book, I would have thought that he had one eye, two ears, and then the rest of his face was scarred over or something. This is not the case. Anyway, that was an overly long paragraph, I just didn't like that facet. 
 I know this is a middle-grade book and I should take my hopelessly romantic teenage brain out of it, but I ship Jack and Summer so badly. 
 I felt like Summer was really impressive, just because she wasn't asked to or assumed to hang out with or be at all kind to Auggie, but she went ahead and did so with such kindness. I did want her to be a little more in depth, for her to have a couple more dimensions than "that nice girl." I think she just deserved a little bit more to her character. 
 I really liked Auggie's mom and dad. I really, really understood how his mother felt a lot of the time and it was also very easy to understand his dad. It made both of their perspectives, even when they changed their minds constantly. It would be so, so very difficult to make decisions for a kid who was in such a difficult position. 
 I did want to hurt Julian's mom. She was horrible, and so was Julian. I disliked them, and I really wasn't up for him trying to "start over" or something, he frustrated me enough and I wasn't ready to forgive him all that quickly. 
 I think that the amount of "mean" that the kids were was fairly realistic. I think that the students reactions were very natural, some people have said that they thought that they should have been meaner, but I felt like that was how it would have worked. That's how it's always worked when I've been in classes with people who have some kind of mental disability (which I know is very different that how it is with Auggie, but it's the closest comparison I have.) 
 I really liked Mr. Tushman, he just seemed very kind and understanding. And I liked Mrs. G when she wasn't smiling her "shiny smile", as Auggie called it. 
 And the ending just made me happy. It was sweet and he got his standing ovation and it was all beautiful and happy and I cried tears of joy. 
 FFFFFFFIIIIIIIIIIIINNNNNNNNNNN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! 
 Very, very good, but perhaps not worth ALL the hype: 94%

Great book. Very heartwarming story of a boy's attempt to fit in at a new school. Augie has several birth defects that leave him with a face that is disfigured and so he struggles to make friends. 
 Very powerful message of kindness and acceptance.
Simple.

"Shall we make a new rule of life...always try to be a little kinder than is necessary?"

 Read aloud with my 12y/o son, we LOVED this book!

This book is a child fiction, a story of a boy named August with a deformed face. The book cover portrays it very well indeed. The story revolves around August aka Auggie who is going to attend school for the first time ever in 5th grade. There are episodes of bullying, other children at the school avoiding him, whispering when his back is turned and treating him like he is mentally ill. 
 "They would take the longest way around me to avoid bumping into me in any way, like I had some germ they could catch, like my face was contagious." 
 But he is merely a child with a facial deformity. He struggles with making friends, even though he is funny and smart at studies. 
 I loved reading this book. Why? Because, first of all, it's hard not to adore Auggie...he is such a sweet kid. His character is so beautifully written that I was instantly taken by him. Secondly, the author goes on to say that the book is based on a real story of a girl in front of the ice cream shop (no names specified). But the author's dedication is so heartfelt that you could feel it throughout the book. Thirdly, it feels unreal, hard to imagine a deformed face, yet not so fictional. In one way or another..we all have been bullied, called names and pressurized to surrender to societal norms and conventions. And lastly, it was an easy read. The writing style is simple and from multiple POVs (mostly kids). 
 I wouldn't be telling you all if the story has a happy ending or not, but it is definitely worth reading - it makes us question our beliefs and behavior, how many times we hurt people by our words and actions and what it feels like to be picked on if you are different in any way. 
 "You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder."

This book was absolutely amazing. I teach 5th grade and this is going to be my first read aloud next year. I was in tears through a lot but smiling too in other parts. Great book about acceptance and getting a long. Highly recommend!

!Que libro mas dulce! Desearia que una antigua amiga mia lo leyera. Estoy segura que la ayudaria mucho. 
 Este es el primer libro de Palacio y, para ser honesta, no es para nada malo. Es un libro que te hace querer ser una mejor persona, y estoy muy agradecida por eso.

Everything about this book is perfect.

'Sometimes I think my head is so big because it is so full of dreams'. 
 Wonderful 5 stars ***** 
 Before I say anything else, let me confess, I Ammara Abid, wholeheartedly love this book. 
 A big hand for R.J. Palacio for such an excellent write-up. This book hit me, it hit me hard. I can't explain in words the effect of 'Wonder' on me. I was completely awestruck.

 'Be HUMAN' 
 & 
 'Be HUMANE'. 
 Most of the time tears rolling down my cheeks and yet no time to stop. The story is so moving, touching and gripping it grab your attention. There's no way out. You can't put it down. You can't. That's it. 
 Auggie 'the wonder boy' the main character of the book, the story revolves around it but what makes it more amazing is the narration. Not only narrated by Auggie but Via, Summer, Justin, Jack & Miranda too. 
 In the end when the Mr. Tushman announced the final award, Henry Ward Beecher medal, not only his friends cried out loud but me too with tears in my eyes and smile on my face

 Precisely, this book stole my heart. I love it's title too I love everything about it. 
 Do you want some wonderful read? 
 'Wonder' is your book to hold. 
 Unstoppably amazing 
 "Surprise is one of those emotions that can be hard to fake, though, whether you're trying to look surprised when you're not or trying to not look surprised when you are." 
 My heart weep :'( 
 "Do people go out of their way to avoid touching you, Via?" he answered, which left me momentarily without an answer. "Yeah, right. That's what I thought. So don't compare your bad days at school to mine, okay?" 
 Modesty :") 
 "The main thing I have is this thing called man-di-bu-lo-facial dys-os-tosis--which took me forever to learn how to pronounce, by the way."

I was nervous picking up this book - would it be terribly sad? Is it tragic? What a lovely surpise instead! This is a marvelous little book and everyone should read it. The story of August Pullman, 10 years old about to start school for the first time ever. He has been home schooled due to the many surgeries he has had for his severe facial deformities. The story takes place over his year in the 5th grade. He faces many challenges, meets friendly faces and not-so-friendly faces. I laughed in this book and i cried. I truly loved this story and i cannot wait to read it to my own children. I love finding books like this - books that can make us better people just by reading them.

I have mixed feelings about this book. This book was so hyped up for me. Everyone was telling me to read it and how great it is. I think there was no way this was going to live up to the hype for me. I also paused this book 2 or 3 times before I completed it for the bookbuddyathon. I thought I would of had a way more emotional connection to this book but I just didn't. I connected more with Via and Summer than August. I think switching the points of views so many times told a different story than I was expecting. It seemed to be not a story about August but about August and how his abnormality effects everyone in his life around him. I felt for Via being the older sister and constantly having her life revolve around her brother. I also loved Summer's story since she was the only kid at school in the whole story who was genuinely kind to August from the beginning, not because a teacher told her to. I also thought that it had a much more happy ending that was sort of unrealistic. What is going to happen to August when everyone starts dating? I also am conflicted on the message of "If you have a choice to be right or be kind, always choose kind." In this political climate with "alternative facts", that is a confusing message for adults let alone kids. I know this book was written before all of that but it is still confusing if you think about it to much. I think this is a good book for older elementary to read but you should read it with your child and discuss it, since it does go into the point of view of highschoolers and complicated issues. I believe in the message of judge people on what is within and not on the outside. I just wanted more to it.

I really enjoyed the different points of view in this story, it was interesting and I liked seeing why the different characters acted the way they did. I wonder what a story of our own lives would look like from the perspective of our friends and family. 
 Also, I loved the characters in this story although really they were too good to be true; Summer, Justin ( loved his perspective), Via (related to her a lot)... They were all pretty interesting.

Aww "everyone should get a standing ovation at least once in their life" this book was the cutest book ever! It warmed my heart :') I loved the precepts that they got each month and the little lessons that were learned along the way. Made me year up a couple times.

5/5 estrellas: La perfeccion ^_^(SIN SPOILERS) 
 Es un libro HER MO SO. La historia es simple, pero muy bonita. Me encanta el protagonista, es un nino muy feliz a pesar de todo lo que le paso. Este libro demuestra que no hay que dejar llevarse por las apariencias. Amo a Summer, es muy linda y a Jack, ay, me encanta. Me encanta el tema del Halloween, esta es mi festividad favorita (Igual, no se festeja en mi pais :( ) y me agrado la forma en al que la ven y a la vez me puso muy triste. El libro es muy lindo, no se que mierda decir salvo !Leanlo!. El libro, como dije, me encanto y lo super recomiendo. 5 estrellas *-*

Books Like This (meaning books about people who are "different" in one way or another and get loads of acclaim) don't come around very often anymore, and when they do I'm always a bit skeptical. Maybe I'm just scarred by the bad experiences I've had with books that TRIED to get into the heads of really different people and failed to do it right. Or maybe I'm just afraid I'm going to cry too much. In any case, like Anything But Typical and Mockingbird (two of my favorite books in recent memory), Wonder was a book I took one look at, then promptly filled up with feelings of discomfort. (The fact that it wasn't a book about autism but a book about facial disfigurement didn't make a difference.) I thought it would be a manipulative tearjerker that belittled the experience of the truly different, and that bugged me. But the reviews came in and they all tripped over themselves trying to gush about this book. Elizabeth Bird said it was "the one to beat" on her 2013 Newbery Predictions list. Anything that has that kind of press is something that I, a diehard Newbery Prediction junkie, simply cannot resist. So I ran out and bought it, and in three quick reading sessions it became very apparent why this is the book everyone is talking about: It IS that good. 
 I love books that make me feel something. Preferably the kind of something that leaves me a sobbing empathetic wreck. This is one of those books. In the book's 300-odd pages are events that are so astoundingly cruel that I actually had to put the book down. I was actually so shaken by one event that I became too sad to cry, if you can imagine that. Yet, there are moments that made me cheer and moments that made me laugh out loud, two things I almost never do at books. You'll be dragged all over the place emotionally when you read this and, I think, you won't feel the least bit manipulated. 
 Truth be told, the book would've been really good even without the multiple points-of-view. The first eighty pages as narrated by Auggie were heartbreaking and moving enough, and the insight was already pretty strong. However, the story REALLY gets going when Via starts narrating, and it doesn't slow down. I don't agree with the reviews that state that some of the narrators were unnecessary. I loved all of these kids. Via, the fiercely protective and serious older sister who tries to break out of her family's solar system, Summer, the devoted friend, Jack, the friend who did wrong but was determined to make it right when he did, Justin, Via's hipster-in-the-making boyfriend (I REALLY liked him, I won't lie... he seemed a little bit of a daydreamer to me and his thing about the universe taking care of everyone reflected that), and Miranda, Via's former best friend and honorary big sister to Auggie, these were all a wonderful group of young people that prove that not every kid is ignorant. 
 (Side note: I don't think Julian's point-of-view should've been added like so many others do. Perhaps ironically, he would've been a misfit among all of these sweet, caring kids. That, and I absolutely didn't want to hear of any other horrible things his wretch of a mother said or did. Julian has the excuse of being an ignorant ten-year-old boy; his mother does not. Hearing any more from these ugly-on-the-inside people would've marred the book for me.) 
 Auggie himself is a wonder of protagonist and narrator. In all the Books Like This for the younger set that I've read, no protagonist has come close to being this self-aware and funny. I think if you're different, you HAVE to have a sense of humor about your plight no matter how bad you have it. It's a coping mechanism that works wonders, and it's great to see that he's developed it at such a young age when it takes some people entire lifetimes. It's also great that first-time author Palacio realized that even having a sense of humor about yourself doesn't mean other people can't hurt your feelings with horrible remarks. Finally, the best thing is that Auggie, though being a smart, sweet, and funny kid, still has flaws, like being self-centered. Having saintly protagonists makes a book insulting, and thanks to the skill with which Auggie was created, I don't think he's going to be an insulting character to anyone. He represents the outcast in all of us, but succeeds in being a cool kid in his own right. 
 Finally, the writing was just amazing. Deceptively simple, I'd say. Short chapters punch at the reader with matter-of-fact emotion. This is a much better tactic than describing the events with poetic metaphors and "gorgeous" writing. That stuff works for certain kinds of books, but it wouldn't have worked here. This is the kind of book that needs to be blunt, direct, and real. Fortunately, it was. 
 It's relatively early in the year, but this book is the frontrunner for the Newbery Medal already, and it deserves it. It should (and probably will) get the Schneider Award too. It deserves the latter because, quite frankly, this book could've fallen into so many disability book traps that it avoided (that and their picks recently have been... off). And it deserves the former because, frankly, this is a marvelous book that has giant, extremely important things to say about how we should treat each other. No other book this year will be able to top it for me. If you read only one book in 2012, make it Wonder. Thank you, R.J. Palacio.

This book was very heartwarming and sad at times. I'm glad that it was told through different perspectives. Don't hate me for saying this, but I found August pretty whiney. So, I'm happy that he was not the only narrator. What a great book for teens to read, and what a great life lesson to learn.

Superbly written. Funny and definitely inspiring. 
 I love all the characters in this story; they're relatable and real. There are some parts where it really got me teary - especially in the Daisy incident (I wont give away spoilers, just in case); and I was reading this while I was in the subway, imagine how I tried to secretly wipe my tears just so people won't think I'm crazy. Lol. 
 This is the kind of book I would love to keep in my book shelf for years so my children and my great, great grand children could read it and learn many life lessons. 
 Definitely recommended. :)

this is a wonderful book that gives you so many feels; it speaks frankly and without fuss about being different, about caring and about respecting yourself and accepting your strengths and weaknesses. a book to read alone a with your kids, specially relevant now a days when bullying is everywhere, a pervasive a dangerous behavior that even the best kids can fall prey to, either as a victim or a perpetrator. it's a teaching opportunity as well as being well written. But I will see for myself. Our Mock Newbery book club will start meeting in a few weeks and I will definitely quiz them on this book.

Full review here: https://malloryreadsblog.wordpress.co... 
 As soon as the book starts you love Auggie he is very sweet and smart. And you want everything to go right at school. Of course it doesn't, and the kids are awful to him. And I can imagine this is exactly what would happen. It is written so realistically that you feel so sympathetic towards Auggie but you also smile when some of the kids are very kind to him, as they should be. 
 The whole book focused on the importance of kindness, towards everyone. It shows that friendships are important and that the most unlikely friendships can be the best ones. That if you really believe you can do something and stand behind that 100% that you will achieve it.

Okay, I'll try to explain. 
 For me, this book doesn't have anything at all. But somehow as another book it is rated really high. And I can't understand why. 
 I have read a lot of children's books and they can be really great like this or that. But this one have nothing inside. 
 The plot seems to be extraordinary, but the protagonist is not someone you will like. And that has nothing to do with his appearance. He is just a little boy, he is not brave, he is not funny, he is not kind as the author tries to convince her readers. 
 Some events in the book happen without any logic, and some chapters are there I can't explain for what reason. 
 That's my first review of the book, so I can't express my opinion really well. But all I can see, this kind of book doesn't raise any emotion and doesn't fill my head with new, important ideas.
A fantastic read. Well done.

Toward the end of the story Auggie's mother tells him, "I really believe...there are more good people on this earth than bad people, and the good people watch out for each other...." Which pretty sums up why I loved this book and why I was so touched by it. I love it when kindness wins!

'Wonder' by R.J. Palacio was truly -- cue the drums -- wonderful. I've been stuck on the same book for a month, finding it hard to get into, but decided to pick up 'Wonder', hoping it would give me a breath of fresh air; and it did. I was hooked from the first page. 
 The main character, August, is very lovable. He's a character you'll remember. But the other characters, many who were POVs, were also extremely great. They were all human, they all made mistakes and said stupid things, but I loved each and every one of them. Jack, Miranda, etc. They were interesting as people. 
 The only thing I would "complain" about is: the younger children spoke very maturely for their age. But you can forgive that because they're cute and witty. 
 'Wonder' is easily 5/5 stars. A new favorite, and a book that should be shared among everyone, especially children.

"The universe has not been kind to August Pullman." Miranda--the former best friend of August's sister Olivia, spoke these words to Olivia's boyfriend, and no one at Beecher Middle School would argue with the truth of her statement. August, a fifth grader at Beecher, was born with a severe facial deformity, requiring twenty-seven surgeries before he was ten years old. Concerned about overprotecting their son, Auggie's parents decide that instead of home schooling, he should start attending school. After all, at the start of middle school, everyone is a new student. At first unenthusiastic, Auggie finally agrees to give it a try, armed with the knowledge that if it's too horrible he can give it up and go back to the safety of home. 
 Palacio's first novel is warm, funny, and full of, well, wonder, as Auggie experiences both expected cruelty and surprising kindness from the children in this private school in New York City. By shifting the narrative between Auggie and several other characters, Palacio helps readers witness not only Auggie's maturing courage, but also the growth of other students who learn to accept him as one of their own. This book is not a reflection of what life is like for a disabled student, but rather a glimpse of what it could be. What makes this work are the characters themselves. Although some characters fall into stereotypes--the inspiring English teacher, for example--most are richly imagined, dynamic, and at times flawed characters who don't always do the right thing, but mostly want to. Augie is not an angelic, always easy to love character, but is both courageous and at times a little self-centered. Violet is a loving sister who at times feels guilty for wanting a life without the complications his disfigurements bring. Jack is a friend who must make the choice between popularity and kindness--in middle school, no less. Palacio shows us what is possible when people courageously make this choice, without feeling dogmatic or preachy. Illuminating possibilities is the magic of fiction. 
 --reviewed from galley

I enjoyed this book more than I expected. The author did a good job of getting inside the head of a kid dealing with a severe birth defect. Having spent all his life under the protective wing of his parents, Auggie starts out a little young for his age, but gradually he grows up and learns how to get along in middle school which is probably the worst time ever to begin school when you have such a disfigurement. The author could have given Auggie a bit more voice. He comes off sounding a little vanilla. Enjoyed the shifting viewpoint, too, but wish we could have gotten inside Julian's head for a while. Good book.
REQUIRED READING. DO NOT LET THE FRENZY OF WEEPS DETER YOU.

4 out of 5 Stars. Everyone, for different reasons, has days of struggle in their lives. It's hard to put yourself in someone else's shoes and understand their struggles. This middle grade book helped me understand, a little better, what it must be like for someone who struggles every day.
It was a good book and very interesting at the beging!
a beautiful story!

This book was unique, interesting, and sweet. I thought it handled the idea of difference very well and really enjoyed the multiple perspectives. I can see why this has been on the best seller list for so long.

I absolutely loved this book. A heart-wrenching tale of a boy dealing with physical differences and how his situation has effects on others. What a great book to discuss what it is to be different and remind kids to have empathy for all those around them.
This is such a touching and wonderfully heartfelt book with a powerful message! I'm giving it to my 9 year-old son to read next. I loved it!

"You have to write the book that wants to be written. And if the book will be too difficult for grown-ups, then you write it for children." 
 -- Madeleine L'Engle 
 This is the second time I use this quote in a review. 
 Is it really a coincidence that the book I'd finished right before this one was "Einstein and relativity"? 
 That the first chapter of Einstein and relativity was about how our brain works, that there is no such thing as red or blue, that there is a wavelength of 450 nm and a wavelength of 620 nm and our brain can't recognize them as frequencies and wavelength so it gives them definitions and sense of familiarity, so when you see a wavelength of 450 nm your brain instantly translate it to blue so you can recognize it. That the world is not what we see, that we're not so different from a blind man who forms his world through his four remaining senses. Truth is, our senses are incomplete. 
 Another concept, relativity, is that there is no such thing as an absolute thing, we compare everything to something else, to understand anything you have to compare it to something else to understand it's nature, giving an example "What if we all fell asleep and everything got 10X bigger, the room, our feet, the books near our bed, our pillows. If we wake up in the morning, we won't notice any difference, because to us, everything is still the same, our pajamas still fits, we can still hold the book in our hands and we're smaller than the wardrobe" 
 Why did this cross my mind while reading wonder? It's because I had a simple question, what makes us think he's deformed? Because we compare him to others, because to a 1 year old Auggie wasn't any different than any 10 year old, but to a grown up, he makes the comparison in his head and decides that he's ugly. But aren't we plain blind? who says what we see is real? who says that any of what we see is real? that what we see is actually beautiful? If we are all actually deformed, how do we know that we are? 
 We just make distinguishable patterns in our head so we can know the way back home but what's home? something that our eyes can't always distinguish but our heart does, our soul does, but what's the soul anyhow? something that our brains can't distinguish but knows it exists. 
 It's not a novel about self pity or trying to send a moral message, it's a novel about real people, a real 10 year old kid, who's not being a hero, who's not absorbed into a self pity 
 I didn't learn anything from Auggie and I didn't learn to be more sympathetic or to be grateful for what I already have. But it softened my heart. Dunno if it was the reason why I have been having those flashbacks for the past two days or so. 
 Proving as well, that my life is a series of coincidences. 
 The book on its own level deserves five stars. Along with the little prince and 13 reasons why. 
 Such a delightful blue book.
What a sweet little YA book. I recommend this one to anyone who wants to read something positive.

I absolutely loved this book. It was funny, it was sad, it was enlightening, it was eye-opening, it was a pleasure and a joy to read. 
 Auggie was the cutest character ever, I just wanted to bundle him up and squeeze him. It was really refreshing to read about a character who obviously has a lot more issues and problems than your average Joe, but who is still such a happy-go-lucky type of person. He's still such a happy boy, he takes things in his stride, he tries his hardest not to let other people get him down and it's not often you see that in books. It's so easy for him to become a recluse and hide away and become depressed, but I'm so thankful this story wasn't like that. 
 Full review on my blog: 
 http://originalbooker.blogspot.co.uk/...
Picked this up at airport and read it completely before the end of my 7h flight. Wonderful! Inspiring! Made me teary at times, quite moving. Well worth reading.

A heartwarming little novel that brings to light the realities many children face because they are 'different.' I think this novel should be on Middle School Reading lists. There's a current culture in the writing that I think kids today would find appealing, but the humanity of the story thankfully isn't lost in the matter of trying to stay relevant to time. Its morals and characters are good examples for young and old minds alike.
One of the best books I have read in a long time. Every middle school teacher, parent and child should read this book and discuss it.

3 stars for reading as an adult, probably 4 for reading to a kid aged 7-10. Sweet story about importance of kindness and not judging someone on how they look and standing up for your friends. Summer was probably my favorite character. A few things I didn't like included the fact that she had August use the word "retarded," in a book that emphasized kindness and sensitivity and there was no sense that the word shouldn't be used. I was also bothered by the coupling off of fifth graders and discussions about dating. Seemed surprising for 10-11 year olds. Evenwise (as my son would say, I liked the book, and would recommend for lower elementary aged kids).
Krasne, ale konec byl trochu moc preslazeny. Ubrala bych.

'Wonder' is a fascinating tale of August Pullman, one of the bravest boys I have ever read about. He does not only feel real, he feels like a brother or a best friend- you can't help but love him. I read this in one sitting and I was never disappointed by the authors writing. Everything came through, there was no cliff hangers, and all in all a truly amazing book.

I can't think of any word to better describe this book than amazing! It grabbed me from the first couple of pages and I devoured it - which I haven't done to any book in many years. August's story about starting middle school while dealing with facial abnormalities is heartwarming. The overall message of being kind is one we all need to hear and I can't wait to share this one with my kids.

This book gave us so many topics for discussion. Having each section narrated by a different character was very effective. It was loved by all from the first grader to the parent. While it may be argued that things wrap up too neatly and unrealistically in the end, it gave us yet another topic for discussion. A must-read for all ages!

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind."
....If you act just a little kinder than necessary-the world will be a better place... someone else, somewhere, someday may recognize in you..thr face of God.

WOW! 
 I really liked it! I loved how the main character was different from the rest and how his sister was okay with it, though sometime she didnt like it. Nice outline, nice moral! Overall, great book!
Every kid 5th grade and up should read this. Heavy subject, but plenty of light.

I loved this book and the way it showed thoughts and feelings from different characters' perspectives. Auggie, the central character is living with a facial deformity and this is especially hard to deal with at his young age. Middle school students can be cruel and he is tormented by the way they ostracized him. Luckily he makes a few good friends who stand by him. Before the story ends those that teased him soon realize the harm their bullying causes and change their ways. There are a lot of moments in the story when you realize the value of friendship, understand importance of kindness, and appreciate individual differences.

Fans of heartfelt stories with happy endings will love this book about Auggie, whose facial deformities, multiple surgeries, and health problems have kept him out of school... until the beginning of this book, where he starts 5th grade. His face is still messed up despite the surgeries and the story of him starting school for the first time is both heartbreaking and uplifting. The book ultimately presents a positive view of human nature, so the sad parts are kept from being depressing. Readers who enjoyed Rules, Out of My Mind, Anything But Typical, and similar stories will like this.
Should be required reading for pretty much everyone. And everyone will get something out of it - they'll be able to relate to a character, or an emotion, or a situation. A lovely book.

"But hey, if they want to give me a medal for being me, that's okay. I'll take it. I didn't destroy a Death Star or anything like that, but I did just get through the fifth grade. And that's not easy, even if you're not me." 
 This book was truly wonderful. It was funny, sad, beautiful and awe-inspiring. This book will definitely be in my heart forever as it really changed my views about a lot of things, and It's one of those books that changes peoples lives --and I know that sounds cliche, but it's true! I cried lots of times. It's such a heart warming story, and I think everyone should read this, whether you're old or young, it doesn't matter, read it!

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least one time in their life." August Pullman, Wonder. August, "Auggie" Pullman is an ordinary boy with an extraordinary face. "I won't describe what I look like," he tells us, "Whatever you're thinking it's probably worse." Having been homeschooled through the fourth grade, Auggie is about to embark on a journey both exciting and terrifying: attending fifth grade at Beecher Prep. How teachers, fellow students and other parents react to Auggie's presence ranges a wide spectrum, from awkward to cruel, to benevolent and even heroic. Told from various character perspectives, Auggie's courage in the wake of cruelty from children and adults alike, transforms those closest to him. Though tackling the painful reality of what it's like to be judged and persecuted for something out of ones control. Wonder is also a clever, funny and hopeful story with a simple but profound underlying message: Be kinder than necessary. - See more at: http://www.thursdayreview.com/WonderR...

This is a novel that borders the Middle Grade and YA and has been near the top of NYT Children's Bestseller list for over two years. It is one of those rare bestsellers that is truly wonderful. While it's about a fifth grader with a severe facial deformity, and the struggles he faces when entering a school for the first time, it's much broader than that and really captures the struggles of growing up and the difficult years of Middle School and early High School. It deals with many difficult topics in a sensitive and realistic way that can't help but cause readers to become emotionally attached to the wonderful family at the heart of the book. 
 The novel is told from a number of perspectives, but the Pullman siblings dominant the narrative. They were also the strongest and most sincere voices. When some of the periphery characters take over, I found their voices to be less authentic and a little more forced, but their insight to the story was crucial for the instilling the sense of empathy that young readers should develop while reading this book. 
 I'm fairly certain this is one of those novels that will become a classic, read in school for years and years to come because of the powerful message of kindness and acceptance. A delightful and moving read for all ages.

Wonder is a special book....the kind that should be read aloud and talked about with kids of all ages. It's an excellent classroom read aloud as it builds community and provides kids with an amazing shared reading experience.
Beautiful, touching and warm. One of the few books that I will definitely make my son read. Kind people and good books are my favorite things on earth! Highly and absolutely recommended.
Este tipo de libros me hace querer ser mejor persona cada dia.
Always choose kind.
I have no words to describe my love for this book. From the way the book was written to the characters I fell in love with every part of this book. I'll probably give it a re-read in the near future.

This is the kind of book that will allow one to see the beauty of the world despite of its share of ugliness. A book that will let you see pass through the physical and let you see the soul, its beauty and its kindness. The kind of book that can touch one's heart because of its rawness and Auggie's somewhat innocent but the realest of heart.
Wonderful!!

Good story about the shifting morass that is middle school. August "Auggie" Pullman has been homeschooled because of profound cranio-facial abnormalities, but his parents decide before the start of fifth grade that it's in his best interest to attend a regular school. 
 Multiple narrators (including some of his new classmates) relate his struggles to adjust to middle school. Many of these - where to sit, who to talk to, what to wear, which hobbies to emphasize or hide - are ones common to any middle schooler. Auggie's physical appearance just makes everything more difficult. Narration from Auggie's older sister and her friends in high school, who face their own struggles, add some additional depth to the story. 
 The melodrama is pushed to limits on a couple of occasions, but it's a good story overall.

This is s remarkable book for 5th grade children, thru adults. The message is awe-inspiring. There are lines in this book that gave me goosebumps and made me cry, but more than that, it made me so happy. My students loved it as well.

"El mas grande es aquel cuya fuerza conquista mas corazones con la atraccion del suyo propio"..... 
 Amistad, familia, amor, companerismo, amabilidad, odio, humanidad y podria seguir..... este libro tiene de todo y gracias a eso y a nuestro lindo Auggie es que es una de las historias mas hermosas que he leido. ?Que si lo recomiendo? !Por supuesto! ?Que esperas para leerlo?

If you want a book to soften your heart, to make you cry your eyes out (because I did, in the middle of the bus), this book is for you. 
 this is one was literally roller coaster of emotions, I didn't expect to like it as much as I did, Auggie will always have a place in my heart.
I absolutely loved this book. I really want my kids to read it now.
Loved it. An amazing book which makes you want to laugh and cry.
amazing from start to finish , such a feel good book
Who knew a book about a kid with a facial abnormality entering 5th grade could hit you so hard in the feels? Well written and compelling, this is a very easy read. Highly recommend.
My pick for the Schneider Award. Excellent!
This book is exactly as it says in the title - a 'Wonder'!

I really enjoyed this well-written book. The first half hit a little too close to home and there is some stuff in the second half that I probably am the only one in the world to nitpick on. But this was a beautiful and thought provoking book.
Really sweet story, just not my favorite.
Couldn't put it down and cried at the end = excellent read.

I would probably really stretch this to 4.5. I struggled at first to get going in this story. But I must admit I was reading it on my e-reader and I definitely have a more difficult time connecting with books in that format. 
 The thing that finally hooked me was hearing the story through all the different voices of the characters. By the time I finished this book I understood all the buzz around this story. This would lend itself to wonderful discussions in class. Every player in the trauma of bullying is represented in this story. The victim, the parents and teachers, the bully himself, the peers who stand by and let it happen, the brave friends who step out of the crowd and befriend the victim. I really did enjoy this book and look forward to setting up a book club featuring it.

Starts out well, with believable characterization, then goes cartoonish and unbelievable midway through. Too many pointless point-of-view characters, simplistic, predictable, a short story forcibly extruded as a novel. Don't get the hype at all.

Audience: Intermediate 
 Genre: Chapter Book, realistic fiction 
 Bloom's Taxonomy: 
 -Remembering: State a happy event that happened on Auggie's first day of school. 
 -Understanding: Explain why the story has the title it does. Can you think of any other fitting titles? 
 -Applying: Think of when Auggie and Jack were in the forest during the movie. What would you have done if you were with the boys when the 7th graders came? 
 -Analyzing: What is the relationship between Auggie and Olivia (Via)? 
 -Evaluating: What is your opinion of Summer and why do you feel that way? 
 -Creating: What inferences can you make about Julian since we never read his point of view?

When choosing a book to read aloud with a loved one, this book seems far from fitting the bill. A ten-year-old boy with severe facial deformities goes to school for the first time. This does not sound like a read-aloud winner. 
 But after the first few chapters, including a humorous "the day you were born story" of a rude farting nurse, it was clear this was going to be the one. 
 This book is such an excellent match of believable and likable characters and a plot that keeps you moving through the book without being sensational. The author does a superb job of telling a story of this boy and his family by using multiple perspectives (each section is told from the POV of a different child, including the main character, Augggie's, sister, sister's friend, sister's boyfriend, and a few kids from Auggie's school). 
 This book is funny, touching without being schmaltzy, and forces you to grow and think as a reader. What more can you ask for? 
 The only thing that felt unreal was the character's age. Auggie and his peers acted and talked much more like kids in 7th or 8th grade, but who knows, maybe I have a warped sense of age. 
 This is a great book because it will have broad appeal to many ages, I imagine. My only question: how do you convince a young or older teen to pick up this book? I'll be curious to know the non-adult responses. 
 Outstanding first book by this author.

This is one of the best books I have read in a very long time. I have seen this book in Amazon countless of times but i never paid much attention to it despite its stellar ratings. I had this pre-conceived notion that this is another sob-story book where i will feel depressed and raw after I'm done reading it. Boy, was i wrong! 
 I absolutely love this book because it is life-affirming and very touching. It reaffirms the love and support of family despite overwhelming odds. It reminded me the value of forgiveness, friendship and redemption. 
 This book has touched me to the core and reaffirmed the truth that people are still innately good in this very cynical and selfish world. It took me several days before i can stip thinking about this book. Once I finished reading the book...I had to call my close friends who are book lovers like me, and urged them to buy and read this book ASAP!

I didn't think I'd like this book as much as I did after finishing it. It's not the story itself but the message of positivity, love, kindness and "to make the world a better place" kinda of thing that makes you feel like you can and should do more for the people that are around you, even those ones that are "different" just like Auggie. Wonder is the kinda of book that is very simple to understand and to assimilate the message. If you want something lightweight and touching, this book is for you.
I loved this book so much that I found I'd finished it far before I wanted to! Heart-wrenching, brilliant, beautiful!

One of the best books I've ever read! Auggie Pullman is a ten-year-old who has a facial disfigurement. He has to deal with all the difficulties of starting public school for the first time at Beecher Prep, along with the natural rudeness that his appearance provokes. The book takes us throughout the whole year. I loved every chapter, and I never lost interest. I loved how they were short and to the point. There are point of views from Auggie, some of his classmates, his sister Via, and some of Via's friends. It was great hearing everyone's version of the year. I could really feel Auggie, and it taught me how tough life can be. It reminded me how mean but amazing some kids can be. It was such a touching book. Auggie really is the best kind of wonder.

I don't have words to describe how amazing this book is. I felt all the feels. August is an amazing character that is extremely relatable. I love this book and will definitely be reading it again soon!
A surprisingly touching story from the point of view of what it is like to be a kid (or maybe even an adult) and to be recognizably "different."
Lovely, lovely, lovely. Everyone should read this book; and everyone needs to have someone like August Pullman in their life.

Wonder is a marvelous book. It's told in a very fresh way. The characters feel very real. It's powerful and reaches your heart in a way you never could prepare for. This is one that will stay with me a long time. 
 Auggie Pullman is one my literary heroes.

Wonder by R.J. Palacio is a well constructed story about a young boy with a facial deformity. At age ten, he goes to school for the first time in his life. It was a very unique experience to look through the eyes of someone with a problem like that, which I haven't had really any experience with at all. The way that he deals with all the stares and gasps when people see him was one of the most interesting things that I noticed in this book. He found patterns in the way that people would look at him, and how they would react. In my opinion, the author did a very good job of creating a window for us to see what it is like to suffer from a deformity like that. 
 One of the things that I didn't like about this book was her lack of difference between characters. There are several sections in this book, and each of them are in the point of view of a new character. This was a good idea to switch point of views between Auggie and the people in his life, but I found myself thinking that they all sounded the same. She made their thoughts, and their "Voices" sound identical, and it was hard to distinguish between them all. This said, she had a very good grasp on what its like to live like Auggie, and I think that every kid should know how hard that is. 
 I would recommend this book to children between 10 and 15 as its main age range, but I think that adults would enjoy it just as much.
This is a must read for every junior high student...actually everyone should read this book.

Interesting premise, and I liked the perspective from other kids as well as August. It has ups and downs and may make you shed a tear. However, it was a little too perfect, if that makes sense. 
 Quick read - anyone could get something out of this book.
Be kind.
Loved the story. Loved the message. The ending just seemed to happy and weepy for me. It could have been a good ending a couple chapters before.
lovely.
Like any parent, I wanted to protect Auggie and hold him close. This book had me constantly feeling like there was a fist in my throat. What a beautiful story!

This isn't an easy book to describe without suggesting it's something other than it is. But, here goes. 
 WONDER is (mostly) wonderful. Heartfelt. Inspiring. A feel-good read in large part because the book does not convey ONLY "feel-good" moments. Of course, inasmuch as the book has become a bestseller since its February 2012 publication, plenty of readers (adult and child alike) have already met the memorable Auggie Pullman for themselves. 
 So, who is Auggie Pullman? 
 Well, let's let Auggie begin introducing himself: "I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid. I mean, sure, I do ordinary things. I eat ice cream. I ride my bike. I play ball. I have an XBox. Stuff like that makes me ordinary. I guess. And I feel ordinary. Inside. But I know ordinary kids don't make other ordinary kids run away screaming in playgrounds. I know ordinary kids don't get stared at wherever they go." 
 "...My name is August, by the way. I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 Whatever we're thinking???? It's probably worse?? Yikes. This isn't going to be just any ol' story of any ol' kid starting school now, is it. 
 Cuz, as I just hinted, this is a book about a ten-year-old boy, who is about to be the new kid at school. Middle school, that is. Fifth grade, to be precise, at Beecher Prep. A kid who has never ever been to any school before. 
 Well, why not? "People think I haven't gone to school because of the way I look, but it's not that. It's because of all the surgeries I've had. Twenty-seven since I was born. The bigger ones happened before I was even four years old, so I don't remember those. But I've had two or three surgeries every year since then (some big, some small), and because I'm little for my age, and I have some other medical mysteries that doctors never really figured out, I used to get sick a lot." 
 But Auggie's done for a while with surgeries, and he's stronger. So, at last he can attend school. A dream come true, finally? Well, wait a sec: " I can't say I always wanted to go to school because that wouldn't exactly be true." 
 So then, what is true? "What I wanted was to go to school, but only if I could be like any other kid going to school. Have lots of friends and hang out after school and stuff like that." Oh. 
 Hmm. But Auggie's our hero, and yeah, he's got a face that startles people, but he's been brave with all those surgeries, so he'll be fine with the school idea, right? Uh, well, nope! He's "pretty much totally and completely petrified." Petrified or not, he does end up at school and the story is off and running. 
 How will the year go? Will Auggie's fears prove groundless? How will so many new people encountering him for the first time react? How will Auggie cope? And will he get his wish to have friends like other kids "and hang out after school and stuff like that" ?? 
 Auggie is not the only one who tells the story. Surprisingly, multiple characters get a chance to weigh in: classmates like Jack and Summer, his sister Via, his sister's old friend Miranda, his sister's boyfriend Justin. These shifting points of view allow the reader to get a fuller perspective on events, though Auggie himself begins and ends the story. 
 And, to borrow and mangle Shakespeare a bit, the course of true [middle school], never did run smooth -- for anyone and especially for Auggie. 
 But by the time the last word is read, many readers will probably agree that their hearts and minds feel fuller. 
 And they will miss Auggie, the boy who thinks "everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in ... life " 
 Suggestion: More food for thought in a non-fiction package: An extensively researched book I recommend to help adult readers broaden their understanding of related cultural and familial issues/context is Far From the Tree: Parents, Children and the Search for Identity by Andrew Solomon, first published in Nov. 2012. The author spent about ten years researching families and individuals dealing with such unexpected challenges as severe disabilities, deafness, autism, schizophrenia, dwarfism and so forth. The book won The National Book Critics Circle Award for General Non-fiction 2012.

Todos merecemos recibir una ovacion al menos una vez en nuestra vida, porque todos vencemos al mundo. 
 Lo hiciste, Auggie, lo hiciste.
Everything

An extraordinary novel for kids and adults--a reminder to always be kind. Highly recommend. 
 I wanted to read this book because my fourth grader was coming home everyday talking about this book his teacher was reading to the class.
An amazing YA novel that speaks equally to adults. Filled with life lessons as seen through the eyes of 5th graders.

Un excelente libro, sobre una tematica muy actual, en el momento que nos adentramos en la vida de este nino de 10 anos podemos observar todo un mundo de miedos, alegrias y sin duda de mucho amor. Un libro narrado desde el punto de vista de muchos personajes lo convierten en algo inesperado pero que te permite conocer como viven cada uno a su manera los diferentes momentos de la vida de August

I will recommend this book to everyone. It is absolutely beautiful and heartbreaking and joyous. From the point of view of August, an intelligent and sweet boy with a rare facial deformity, who is entering school for the first time after being home-schooled previously due to various medical issues. The book is split up into a couple (I want to say 6?) parts, each from a different point of view with a distinctive voice and tone. The writing is so poignantly clear and definitely made me cry on more than a couple occasions. The whole book probably took me 4 hours to read and yet it is seared into my mind. So many of the reactions and characters in the novel seem very real and I absolutely loved it.
Great kids book !
What an amazing book! This one is life changing. Themes of bullying turn to messages of kindness. I predict that this one will be the Newbery Award winner for this year.
Everyone should read this book at least once! And be a little kinder then necessary after that! (:
I must say, this book kept me reading, and was definitely well written.

10-year-old August was born with a several facial deformity. He has always been homeschool, but the story starts when his parents decide he should attend a private middle-school. Most of the kids are afraid to go near him for fear of catching "The Plague" and some are outright hostile, but August does manage to make a couple of friends who help him get through the year. 
 What I liked: I really appreciated what the author was trying to do--get kids to see that even when people look different or even scary, they are just people like you and me. I loved the message of being kind, and I liked how Palacio showed how August's condition affected his family and friends. I could emphasize with the good and bad choices each character made when I understood what it was like for them to have August in their life. 
 What I had a problem with: I had a hard time getting emotionally attached to the characters and I think the problem was the 'voice.' Though each section was from the point of view from a different character, they all sounded the same. The dialogue too . . . most of it sounded too adult with some kid slang like 'dude' or 'dissed' thrown it to make it seem juvenile. And way to much use of "I know, right?" from most of the characters. I can't help but compare this to Firegirl which really had me emotionally involved . . . something that I felt missing in this book.

Really great story about bullying and what it's like to be different in the mean world of middle school. My only issue is there wasn't much of a plot and I found it slow at times but I think that may be because it's middle grade. I guess I just would've liked a more cohesive story line.

I really liked this book about a boy named August with severe facial deformities. It was on the Georgia Book Award list last year so I read it. I enjoyed the characters and the family interactions. It was funny and popular with my book club at school this year. Some of his schoolmates could be so mean and that was heartbreaking, but realistic. I like that they come around in the end. Kids can learn about how important it is to be kind to one another with this book. It would be a great read aloud to middle grades and up.

This book is "Wonder"ful. 
 I am a 6th grade teacher. Let me state upfront, that the only reason I read this book was because it had been selected for our 5th and 6th grade book club. I tend to prefer adventure, fantasy, or horror, so this was way out of my genre of preference. Compounding my reluctance to read this book, was the subject matter. I can't stand intentionally sad books. When I first read about the condition of the main character's face, I expected the story to focus on all the bullying...all the unfair treatment...all the heartache that Auggie, the main character, experienced, everything that further painted a picture of the fallen state of the human condition. And while, it had some of these aspects, they only served to highlight the book's overriding themes of hope and courage. 
 In the end, I found this story wasn't so much about Auggie, as it was about the condition of my own heart and what I want this heart to look like to my students and my own children. I think if we are being honest, we all carry a little Auggie inside of us. We are all afraid of failure and what others might think of us when we do. I know for sure that each one of my students wears a space helmet from time to time, embarrassed by one perceived shortcoming or another. But hopefully, when they read this book, they will be encouraged like I was. They will see that if Auggie can be brave enough to live his life in the face of what others might think, there is no excuse for any of us. Maybe then, they too will be free to live their lives with a renewed sense of wonder. 
 In the end, I found this story wasn't so much about Auggie, as it was about the condition of my own heart and what I want this heart to look like to my students and my own children. If we are being honest, we all carry a little Auggie inside of us. We are all afraid of failure and what others might think of us when we do. I know that each one of my students wears a space helmet from time to time, embarrassed by one perceived shortcoming or another. But hopefully, when people read this book, they will be encouraged. They will see that if Auggie can be brave enough to live his life in the face of what others might think, there is no excuse for any of us. Maybe then, they too will be free to wonder.

I liked it but I didn't love it and I wonder if it's because I listened to it as an audiobook. 
 Ultimately, it was a unique and touching perspective on the triumphs and troubles of the middle school years. I particularly enjoyed hearing the story through a number of different characters' views. Of course, August is one inspiring cool bean and had me in tears a couple of times throughout the story. Such a relatable story with brilliant life lessons, told with humour and compassion. I listened to this book a long with my children and they loved it even more than I did.
Beautiful. I loved having all the different points of views and being able to see so much growth in every single one of the characters and having all of their opinions as to August's deformity.

Things I enjoyed: I loved the strong familial bonds between Auggie, his parents, and his sister, and I liked how almost every character had at least one redeeming moment. Even Julian gets a hint at a better future, when the precept he sends his teacher the summer before he starts at a new school is, "Sometimes it's good to start over." I know that Julian was not at all sympathetic, but I always prefer it when villains--if you can call a ten-year-old boy a villain--have a chance at redemption. I liked the optimistic outlook, and I liked the way the different POVs meshed together to form an interesting, three-dimensional story. 
 There were only a couple of things I didn't like. 
 One of them was that the book kind of bashed you over the head with its message, but since it seems this is an MG book and not the YA book I was expecting, I guess I can forgive a bit of non-subtlety (which isn't to say that you can't write an MG book with a subtle message, but it's not really expected as much as it is in YA and adult fiction). 
 The other thing I didn't like was, unfortunately, the ending. I was feeling good enough about this book that I expected to end it on a high emotional note, and while I did walk away from it feeling contemplative and, overall, pretty happy, the ending fell rather flat for me. 
 Frankly, Auggie's winning the award just didn't ring true the way most of the rest of the book did. It felt... false, almost. I feel a little bad saying that, because Auggie is an admirable character, but let me explain. 
 The award he won was the "Henry Ward Beecher medal to honor students who have been notable or exemplary in certain areas throughout the school year," and the passage the principal uses to explain his giving the award to Auggie is this: "He is the greatest whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own." The way I see it, this refers to the way Auggie's courage and kindness had a profoundly positive influence on all of his classmates. 
 Except... that didn't happen. Don't get me wrong; Auggie was a brave, considerate, and endearing character, and I was impressed with how well he dealt with his situation. But only a few of his classmates were actually influenced by him--by who he was--and, when that happened, he was just as influenced by their strength of character as they were by his. And yes, by the end of the book the majority of his classmates were feeling more kindly toward him, but that was mostly because of his run-in with the seventh graders at the nature retreat, which gave him and his classmates a common enemy--it made them feel as if he was one of them, and that one of them was being attacked by an outsider--and in which he, frankly, didn't actually do anything outstanding. 
 So, in the end, it seemed to me as if Auggie was given the award for what he was--a kid with a facial deformity who's had a rough time of it--and not who he was. And that, frankly, seems like a total departure from everything the book was very thorough in trying to teach us. Maybe other people interpret this scene differently, and that's fine, but that's the way it came off to me. 
 Furthermore--and this probably isn't true for a lot of people--I don't like it when the high point of a book consists of the main character gaining the approval of the masses. It would have felt a lot more satisfying and fulfilling to me if the ending was focused on Auggie looking around and seeing the small group of people who, over the course of the book, have learned to truly love him for who he is, instead of a bunch of people applauding him because the tides of popular opinion have turned in his favor (or is that just me being cynical?). This way just... didn't seem to live up to the rest of the story.
