 Overall, though, I did quite like this book, and if I ever see it sitting on a bookstore shelf when I have a few extra dollars in my pocket, I'll be sure to grab it for my collection.
LOVED THIS BOOK! Read it to my young elementary-aged children. Wonderful themes to explore - acceptance, bullying, friendship.
best book, a must read, or read aloud, recommend it to all. Heard a review on NPR after it was published.
So wonderful. Tears.
Beautiful and touching story. Wonderful message, something I think we all need to be reminded of. Makes me very grateful for all the things that I have and the people I share my life with

A friend who teaches fifth grade recommended this book and she was right, it's incredible. I will recommend it to all my middle schoolers. 
 Auggie was born with severe facial deformities. In spite of numerous surgeries his face is grotesque and frightens people. So when he starts school (after home schooling) it's a big adjustment for Auggie and his classmates. This book tells Auggie's story from several different character's point of view. The book describes how everyone grows and develops throughout the school year. I recommend this book to adult's too. It's very emotional and sweet and leaves you hopeful in the end.

I enjoyed this book. I read other reviews when I was about halfway through with it, and I have to agree with a few other people that the younger characters at times seemed a little older than they were. They did childish things and had childish jokes, but the things they talked about often seemed to be a bit beyond what 10 year olds would be concerned with, even given the unique situation they are in. I think the author could have just changed the age of the children to 12 and nothing would have been missed. I do think that children would benefit from reading this book from the age of 9 or 10, however, because it does deal rather well with differences and how we approach and act around those who are different from us (as adults and children, really).
I wasn't expecting to like this book as much as I did, but I feel like everyone says that.

This novel was truly a page turner. I literally stayed up until 5 in the morning to finish reading it (luckily I didn't have to get up early). I loved the alternating points of view. They added so much dimension to the story and I felt like I really understood all sides of August's story - except maybe his parents. 
 Now for August himself. He was such an enthralling character and the things he did made me reflect on my own life and actions. The last line was just perfect "She bent down and whispered in my ear. 'You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder.'" (310 Palacio). The way he handled everything including his horrible luck in the gene pool really moved me. He was only in the 5th grade and he already had to experience things many people don't have to deal with their whole lives. He knows both sides of the coin of the human existence and truly doesn't blame people for how they treat him. He only gets visibly upset when people aren't truthful with him which is a trait I admire. 
 I really liked how Palacio didn't try and sugar-coat anything. Like with Olivia, she said it how it is. This is a truly original novel that doesn't flinch in the face of truth. The book could make the world a better place (I know I'm so dramatic!) :D 
 Five big stars for this book with no reservations or complaints at all!
Loved this book <3 especially the ending. Such a great inspirational book!

This took me way too long to finish. Once I realized it was going the Disney channel movie route, I kind of lost interest but was too far to stop reading. I think this would be a wonderful book for any kid to read. There's a reason it's so often assigned for school reading now. The narrative encourages perspective taking and offers insight from several different angles. As an adult, however, I found it too perfect and neatly (which, in many ways, was what it needed to be). But this book wasn't written with me in mind, so there's that.

Okay. This book is hard to "not like" and I didn't "not like" it, but it was so meh after hearing all the great reviews of it. The subject matter pulled at multiple heart strings but I couldn't get past the way it was written. Why was it in 6? 7? different POVs? (Some of them were pointless as far as I could gather, too). Obviously they needed the POV of Auggie and I really, really enjoyed getting the neglected-sister perspective. Still--they all just sounded the same??? Why??? The one difference was the musician boyfriend who didn't use capital letters: oooooh. 
 This is going to be the 6th/7th/8th common summer reading book so I hope they like it better!

I went a bit kicking and screaming into the reading of this one because I thought --- yet another soppy sad story of a kid with a serious problem. Not to mention realistic school stories too often feel forced to this veteran classroom teacher. But as I read further into it I was completely taken in. This is a truly lovely story and beautifully, beautifully told. The movement between different characters' points of view is nicely done. The children and adults all seem real as can be, not a one seemed a straw man or someone pontificating a moral. There were moments when I was brought to tears, but they were genuine moments, not a one felt overly sacharine or manipulative. Nothing, in fact, is the slightest bit manipulative in this book. 
 Nicely done indeed.
This book really was everything it's said to be. R.J. Palacio has written a book that I believe everyone should read... not just young adults... but everyone.
''Todos deberiamos recibir una ovacion al menos una vez en nuestra vida, porque todos vencemos al mundo''

Some books just leave you with a warm, fuzzy feeling in your stomach. I think everyone can learn something from Ausgust. For me it would be courage and from Summer kindness. And I really like the last page where everyone's precepts were there. 
 My favourite precept is 
 "All you need is love" 
 - The Beatles

Es un libro muy facil y rapido de leer. Con capitulos muy corto y vocabulario sencillo. Pero que no os engane: es un libro genial. 
 Desde el primer momento entras en la historia, en la vida de August y de las personas que le rodean. No solo narra el, tambien otras personas cercanas. 
 Te hace pensar, te hace recapacitar. Sobretodo cuando Narra el propio August, sus pensamientos, sus observaciones sobre el resto de gente que le dedica miradas de odio, asco... te hace darte cuenta de muchas cosas. 
 Lo recomiendo a todo el mundo. Absolutamente a todo el mundo. Es un libro tan ligero de leer, con una trama tan sencilla y a la vez tan profunda que te hara reir, pensar, entristecer, encarinar, conmover, compadecer y muchisimas mas cosas en pocas paginas.
A beautiful, beautiful, beautiful book. Favourite of the year so far, by a long shot. Enough said. Read it!

I wrote my review on this book at booktrib.com but I will say that I so loved this story. I still feel emotional talking about it. Let's teach our kids kindness so this is a better world for them and all the "Auggies" out there.

4.5/4.75 stars 
 Fantastic adorable touching book!

I really enjoyed this book. I struggled with fitting in as a child/teenager and I definitely cant imagine dealing with the issues the main character Auggie had. It was great to see how the characters developed as the book got further along. I would definitely recommend to everyone. It is great to see how things are not as bad as they seem.
What an incredibly heart warming book about true friendships. An amazing lead character. Go out and do yourself a favor by reading this amazing book

I didn't know what to expect when I started reading this book. My daughter had read it months prior and had insisted that I should read it. Well I am glad to say that she was right. This book, even though is meant for young readers, was fantastic. A must read in the school system. It teaches lessons on standing up for one another, being okay with being different, humility, bravery, bullying, and most importantly....... being kind. A great read for any age. It will make you feel grateful for what you do have and learn to not judge people by their looks. People's feelings always matter and bullying is always wrong. (Whether it's with kids or adults)

Words cannot convey how I feel about this book. From parts that made me cry to parts that made me laugh, this book was so real. Written from the point of view of a fifth grader with a big heart and an 'unordinary' face, his friends, his sister, and her friends, this book sends a message of kindness above all. I loved reading the different perspectives; this book was truly inspired. I will be ruminating in Wonder for years to come. This is a must read.
Read this for a local book group. Good book to read in light of the "bullying" issues.

Wonder was such a wonderful book! August is an amazing character he was so adorable, but also such a wise person for someone his age. His parents and their love for August was something that really loved. It was very beautiful how much they love and care for him. His sister Via and Summer and Jack too. The students and Beecher prep as well. I fell in love with so many of the characters in this book 
 It's already hard to make friends in middle school and August has an even tougher time doing that because of his rare birth defect that affects the way his face looks. People give one look at him and they're turning the other way, or stealing glances at him without even trying to get to know him. But once they do. Once they get the courage to strike up a conversation they realize that's he's just another ordinary kid, a hilarious and intelligent kid, who just, happens to look a little different from everyone else. 
 This story really touched my heart I was crying tears of both happiness and sadness throughout the book and I absolutely recommend this book to everyone, whether they are a boy or a girl, an adult or a kid. It's the kind of story that is hard to find and it teaches a great message and I think everyone should read it and experience Auggie's story because they won't regret it. 
 "There are always going to be jerks in the world, Auggie," she said, looking at me. "But I really believe, and Daddy really believes, that there are more good people on this earth than bad people, and the good people watch out for each other and take care of each other." 
 I believe there more good people than bad people on this world too. At least, I hope so.

two and a half. 
 If I weren't a 35 year old woman reviewing this book, but the 9 Plus (it's children's, not even YA?) the review would be different. 
 But I am, so there we are. 
 Although I enjoyed the flow and overall "goodness" of the story, the plot line had some huge issues. 
 The school that's *perfect* for Auggie just happened to be down the block. is too conviently located, especially when Via goes to a school that's much further away. Not sure why this bugged me so much. 
 A 5th grade gratuation? Wrong. They aren't even changing schools an they get a gratuation ceremony? Possibly every year? Moving on. 
 This was a set up for 2. where Auggie basically gets an award for having a facial deformity, acknowledges this, and it's okay with him. 
 Most importantly, while Auggie's parents taught him to deal with other's meanness by laughing, they didn't teach him any other methods. 
 Any tensions are resolved by laughter or simply ending the scene/writing off of a character. Get beaten up and have your hearing aids stolen? It's okay, don't tell anyone. But teachers will learn about it and then all the kids in school will love you. Odd. 
 This makes me sound like I really hated the book, and I didn't. I always enjoy the mutliple POV story (although in this case, they all had similar styles of voice) and would have glazed over much of these issues I was the target audience.
Inspiring and moving.

I absolutely loved this book about a 10 year old boy (Auggie) with a major facial deformity who goes to school for the first time as a fifth grader at a private school - Beecher Prep. I felt it was going along fine, but I wasn't terribly impressed until the story changed perspectives from Auggie to his sister to his two best friends and then back around a bit. I was afraid it would seem too redundant, telling the story from all those points of view, but Palacio really did a great job moving the story forward and not dwelling too much on what we already know. It was a very creative approach I thought, and made the book so much more interesting to me. Lots of good insight into living with a deformity. I would highly recommend this to be read aloud to elementary school kids. Would make for fantastic discussion.
I read this book with my ten year old daughter. It was a very difficult read as the subject matter is pretty sad. Overall, it was a sweet book with some important life lessons for children.

With about one hundred pages to go I'm trying to decide what this book is going to teach me...what point is trying to be made? It was an engaging story until then, but I really wanted it to draw out more. The subject matter was crying for something deeper than middle school drama. Some foreshadowing was way too obvious and took away from the emotion from a particular struggle. But, the last 100 pages delivered a beautiful message...that may have even provoked a tear to fall. Maybe. A good reminder of kindness and that "your deeds are your monuments" (page 325).
My son and I read this together. That made the reading that much more wonderful. Our discussions every night after reading were so great! Looking back it was like captured time!

I'm such a mess. I don't remember the last time a book made me cry so hard. This is the story of a boy, August, who is born with a severly deformed face. At the age of ten, his parents decide to try sending him to school for the first time. This decision not only puts August out into the spotlight, but also changes the life of his sister and his new friends. 
 I loved Auggie. Yes, I admit that maybe at times his thoughts sounded more like the adult author speaking than a ten year old boy, but I don't care. I'm willing to believe there could really be a boy like Auggie. 
 I know this is getting a lot of Newbery hype, and I must admit I'm hesitant. The story itself is so heart-lifting that it at first seems to be an obvious choice. I'm not sure about the writing, though. I'm not sure if it's good enough for the Newbery. The writing flows very well, but some of the narrator's voices felt forced and artificial. I know Palacio was trying to give each character a unique voice, but it came across as a little gimmicky to me. That's the one big thing that's keeping me from screaming Newbery (though, really, I would be very happy if I does end up winning). 
 But I will say that between this and The One and Only Ivan, this year is turning out to be a excellent year for children's literature.

"I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 One of my bookish new year's resolution is to write book reviews that consist of more than just crying and screaming, so here we go! 
 It's really tough to buy in Poland the books I want to read in English version. So when I noticed this one among copies of '50 Shades of Grey' and countless supernatural romances which usually fill the English sections in bookstores, I didn't hesitate even one second. I'm so happy that I started my reading year with such a brilliant book! 
 The story follows August - a child born with severe facial abnormality. He already endured a lot, people staring, pointing, talking about him all the time. Yet, he find himself in the toughest situation so far - after years of being home-schooled he's about to attend school like every other child. Middle school is tough for every child, but no one has it as tough as him. 
 Things I loved: 
 -August! Such a lovely and kind kid, I admired that he had his better and worse days but he always managed to stay optimistic and found ways to laugh and live a life of a normal kid as much as he could. I can't fully enjoy a book if I don't connect with the main character and thankfully August caught my heart from the first chapter. 
 -The POV changes. It usually annoys me a lot but in this book it was probably the most interesting part for me. It made it possible to see the whole situation from different perspectives, to see August through different eyes, not only his family but people from the outside as well. 
 -Via, August's sister. Her POV was the most heart-breaking to read. Caught between loving her brother and wanting to be recognized for being herself, not only her brother's sister, her chapters felt the most realistic too me. 
 -Pullman family dynamics. They were so lovely, trustful and honest with each other even when it was tough. It made my heart melt :))) 
 -Star Wars references!!! I saw the newest movie last week so I'm all for anything Star Wars in every amounts, haha! 
 Things I didn't love: 
 -A bit too sweet. It felt unrealistic at times. 
 -I kind of wish there was a chapter from Justin's (the bullying one) POV to see that was inside his head and add a different layer to the story. 
 In overall, I wish everyone read this book, it's a kind of message that will be always needed.
Great read. Recommended.

This was an unusual read--story of a boy born with facial deformaties who has been home-schooled until his parents decide to send him to private school as a middle schooler. Parents waffle as to whether or not this is the best choice for their son. He encounters kids at the school who seem unusually cruel which adds a an unrealistic tone to the story. I enjoyed the first person narrative shared by three characters --the main character August, his older sister and her boyfriend. Would suggest this to 4th-6th graders, good choice for reading about over coming challenges.

Its an inspiring story of a boy name August who is suffering from a complicated syndrom and has been home school and starts his school in grade 5. How he faces this new world and makes new friends and learns some of the most important lessons of his life. Its a story of friendship, trust , relationships and humanity.

This book reminded me of 13RW (the series) because it revealed how one person's truth isn't the ultimate truth and that there are many sides to every story. It also help remind me of important things in life about how we treat other people
I read this with my grade six class and they were so interested and invested in the story and the characters.
I saw this in the school library in 4th grade and it looked good but I've never seen it in Barnes and noble yet.

Was unsure of how I felt about this book at the very beginning. But LOVE, LOVE, LOVED it. I greatly enjoyed seeing the story through the perspective of the different characters. I think if it had only been written through August's eyes, it would not been as good. Great story with a male child protagonist. Many lessons throughout on how to be the bigger person and how to stand up for what you believe in. Favorite quote from the book, during a graduation speech: 
 "Greatness lies, not in being strong, but in the right using of strength...He is the greatest whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own." 
 Henry Ward Beecher
Every person should read this book. What an incredibly touching story with good lessons to learn, for kids and adults alike. I definitely needed to pull out the tissue.
Lovely book. Crisp, clean writing and a fantastic story of human compassion and triumph.

I love that this book is written from Auggie's point-of-view as well as several of the people who play roles in his life. The reader gets to know the boy behind the mask (sometimes literal) and see the stress he experiences and the rest of his family. Then you forget, much like those who know and care for him, about his deformity as a constant presence.
Este libro me dejo una sonrisa plasmada en la cara. Ame el precepto final de August.
sinceramente me quede con ganas de seguir leyendo mucho mucho mas! me gusto muchisimo!!! i love august!

EVERYONE should read this book. Everyone. It is about kindness, choosing to be good, and empathy...which I have come to care a great deal about in the last couple of years. I think we could all do with more empathy, and this wonderful book is a delightful reminder of that. The story, a beautiful story about August, who is not "ordinary". And yet, he is extraordinary and many of the people in his life are too. Some will give you hope, make you laugh and smile. Some will remind you to be a better person. Some will make you angry. Some may remind you of your own adolescence or even adult acquaintenances. All will make you feel. The characters are authentic, and I can recognize people I know in every character of the book, the kind ones and not-so-kind ones. This story will lift you up and remind you there are more kind people in the world. "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." - Dr. Wayne W. Dyer

Words cannot express how much I love Auggie, the main character, and his family!! This is such a powerful book!! 
 2nd read -- in the wee hours of April 1, I finished Wonder for the 2nd time, and this time I read far more carefully in preparation for our GREat Book Discussion (parent/student) this Tuesday. If possible, it was even better the 2nd time, because I read more thoughtfully, with post-its at the ready. Characters were richer and more fleshed out for me this time. LOVE this book! 
 3rd read -- Dec/ - Knowing that this was going to be the read aloud for all 4th and 5th graders at my school after break, reread this book once again. Having chatted with R J Palacio at Nerdy Book Club party, love this book even more. Am hoping for some very powerful dialogue between all the students.
The book to read when you need a feel good story. I liked the different narrators point of views. The only thing I didn't like was the fact that the bully in the school wasn't really that bad.

I read this with my daughter. it is a middle school book. we both loved it. it is the story of a boy who is born with "a perfect storm" of facial deformities. his mom home schools him until middle school when he goes to a small private school. the book covers his first year at the school. highly recommend.
This was a tender, heartfelt book that is great for anyone a little too young for The Fault in Our Stars.

This book should be required reading at all elementary and middle schools. This book should be required reading for every parent, teacher, and really every person. Thank you, R.J. Palacio, for this beautiful and hugely important story.

A family book club choice from my son-in-law, who always comes up with interesting picks for the group! The late elementary/middle school years can be tough going sometimes, and Wonder should be on the required reading lists for that age group; maybe it would help people think twice about bullying and/or mercilessly teasing others. While not everyone will encounter someone with Auggie's severe challenges, our schools -- and our entire culture -- could use the reminder this book offers about being more compassionate toward people who are different than us in some way. 
 I felt Palacio made a great debut with this, her first book; yes, it was a feel good story -- yes, it was predictable to a degree; but it makes a great point about how we treat others. I enjoyed hearing the story through several narrators, and most especially from Auggie himself. I should also say that, at my age, I was happy that I knew who Jango Fett was!
I was surprised how much I loved this book. It touches you deeply. The only book that made me cry this much was Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close.
Fantastico!!! me rei como loca y que puedo decir de la admiracion hacia el personaje, wow! Maravilloso.... :)

simply extraordinary. the story is narrated from different points of view, of the main characters or not, with an impressive realism! It makes you think so much about the conception of most people, largely of teenagers, of different people only outwardly from the crowd. 5 stars deserved!

Wonder is a story anyone who went through school can relate to on summer level. While not all of us are teased or experiencing the extreme self-consciousness that Auggie faces, you can't help but to feel that there is a bit if yourself in him. The underlying message throughout, that we should all act with kindness, is never forceful as Polacio gently reminds all of us what it is like to be in middle school and how even the seemingly unimportant can feel overwhelmingly huge.

I loved this book,and the main reason why is that you can feel the emotions of the characters. With every POV, I shared the character's feelings. It was a great book, it made me loath prejudges and bullying even more. A heart-warming book.

This book started out absolutely precious, a wonderful concept, a highly emotional read. It had me laughing and crying and cursing and ranting and I read it all in one go...and with the last three or four chapters, it was completely spoiled for me. The ending is moral high horse, religious, and shiny happy. 
 Plus, despite being traditionally published, this book has editing issues.
So so good! Auggie is awesome.

I kept seeing this book on the Scholastic book orders that I was sending home with the kids, so I decided to read it. I was especially drawn to the fact that this is about a boy who has a facial deformity and how the kids react to him. I was hooked with that since I was thinking, "How could I use this in the classroom?" 
 I cried and laughed with this book and I couldn't put it down. The chapters are short, which lends itself to a good read-aloud book. I liked how the story is told from several characters' perspectives about Auggie, the protagonist. That made it more of a dynamic story for me. After watching the Bully movie, and since we have instituted a bullying prevention program at school, I was hyper-aware of bullying at this point. This book gives an implicit view of it with someone who has a physical deformity. I lost it at the line, "Mommy, why am I so ugly?" I really felt for him then and through the rest of the book. Good story arc which kept a good pace. Just a good reminder of how prejudice and cruel the human race can be, but there are people out there who have the compassion of Mother Teresa, and they are in the kids we teach. Adults should read this, even if it is for that moral of the story.

August (Auggie) Pullman has always been homeschooled due to a birth defect which left him with a disfigured face. When he opts to attend school for his fifth grade year, he is worried about being tormented by his peers. While much of the expected bullying occurs, his middle school experience proves to be much richer - and more pleasant - than Auggie ever imagined. 
 This heartwarming novel is divided into sections narrated by August himself, his older sister, Via, some of his sister's friends, and some of his own classmates. In straightforward prose, the characters explain how they see Auggie, and how Auggie experiences the world. References to Star Wars, Diary of a Wimpy Kid, and Justin Bieber place the story squarely in the present day and contribute to an overall feeling that August is just like other ten-year-old boys in all the ways that count. The emotions experienced by each character, and their ways of expressing them are very real, and every major character is sympathetic, even some of the ones who treat Auggie poorly. 
 For much of the story, the author succeeds in conveying an important message without a hint of preachiness, but sadly, she ruins this effect in the final chapters by singling Auggie out as special just because of his condition. While most of the book captures the fifth grade experience perfectly, and will appeal to kids who see themselves in the characters, this over-the-top Hallmark movie ending is too saccharine to feel believable to anyone except adults with an overly romanticized view of childhood and a mistaken belief that bullies are softened by kindness. 
 Based on all the hype surrounding it, I was surprised when Wonder didn't win the Newbery in 2013. Now that I've read it, I can still understand its popularity, but its flaws are also glaringly apparent, and I couldn't manage to award it more than three stars.

This one is going to stay with me for a long time! 
 A book full of positivity.
Phenomenal. A must-read for children ages 10 - 14 and it couldn't hurt for most grown-ups to read it, as well. Beautiful story of kindness and empathy.

I recommend this book to all people who have been touched by someone "extraordinary" during life. To be able to live and experience the world from their point of view is a really fascinating and exciting journey. 
 I also recommend this book to all people who have a good heart and who understand that it is far better to accept that judge and isolate (even when it's someone very very "unusual") 
 I cried a lot with this book. It was a good cry. 
 Basically the book revolves around Auggie, who was born with a facial deformity and for the first time in his life is entering a college in which he will engage with other children (away from the protective cradle of the family). 
 Observe the world changing and people changing because of the pure acts of Auggie gave a little hope that humanity is not thaaat bad (maybe 70% bad and 30% good). 
 The best part, in my opinion, was the chapter that shows the point of view of Auggie's (super protective) older sister. Needless to say how much I identified with this characters. [Older sisters ruless /o/] 
 Beautiful book. Beautiful message. Loved.

HERMOSO ME DEJO MUCHA FELICIDAD CUANDO TERMINE DE LEER, HACIA MUCHO NO LLORABA ASI POR UN LIBRO TE HACE PENSAR SOBRE LA VIDA, SOBRE QUIEN ES UNO Y EN SER MAS AMABLE CON LOS DEMAS. ME GUSTO PODER SABER QUE PENSABAN O SENTIAN LOS DEMAS QUE RODEABAN AUGUST, AME CADA HOJA !!
A page-turner with a heart of gold and fun storytelling device of getting the new twist on the same-ish story from a diverse crowd of kids. Also, I want to go to Beecher Prep.

I've been hearing amazing things about this book and it does not disappoint. It's heartbreaking and heartwarming and it's so beautiful! I cried at least a few times, and will keep thinking about this for a long time. Whatever you are reading, put it down and read this right away!
"Isn't that the kind of question we should be asking ourselves all the time? What kind of person am I?"

If you want to have your heart ripped out and thrust back in with this emotional doozy of a story, this one's for you. 
 Wonder is a story about Auggie, a boy born with a facial deformity, and his struggle to find a place to fit in as he attends a mainstream school for the first time in fifth grade. The point of view switches between various children, from Via, his sister, to Jack, a fellow classmate in his fifth grade class. And it is these perspectives that you gain a deeper understanding of not only the kindness that everyone possesses, but also the cruelty that we are all capable of. There were some situations in this story that just rang so true, and any reader will find someone that they will be able to connect with. 
 Overall, it's a uplifting story about just being yourself, owning up to your mistakes, and learning that it's important to be kinder than is necessary. This is a wonderful book that every child and adult should read.

August Pullman, aka "Auggie," was born with severe facial deformities, but otherwise he was a normal young man. He had loving parents and sister, and a wonderful dog named Daisy. Due to numerous surgeries, August had been home schooled. But, that was all going to change as he enters 5th grade! 
 Auggie can't understand why his parents are "making" him go to Beecher Prep. Why did he have to be around people all the time? People who would stare, make faces, make ugly comments. But, Auggie was likeable and did make some friends, the best of whom were Summer and Jack Will. But then, there were those others! Come along and learn about 5th grade with Auggie. Meet his Director, Mr. Pullman; his teacher, Mr. Brown, who teaches them Precepts during English; his parents, his sister "Via," and the other students in the school. This is a story that will touch even the toughest heart! 
 "You can't blend in when you were born to stand out." This is one of my favorite lines in the book. I agree with so many others that this should be required reading in middle school, and even for older students/parents. Kindness, courage, friendship, just some of the themes of this book. This book made me laugh, cry, feel anger, and feel joy. You will even see that those you think are dysfunctional really aren't, and vice versa. I highly recommend it to everyone!

A WONDERful book! This is beautifully written from different characters perspectives. The story is set in NYC around ten year old August Pullman. He was born with many facial abnormalities. He is a normal kid in every other aspect of his life, except how his face looks. Because of this, he has been homeschooled. For 5th grade his parents think it might be better to start going to school. This book is about his 5th grade year at his new school. Palacio did a beautiful job with her first book. It certainly makes you appreciate how lucky you are! Newbery contender?

Read it cover to cover in one sitting (it is quite a quick read). I just couldn't put the book down; I was completely sucked into Auggie's world. I think it would be a great book to bring to the classroom. It brought me to tears multiple times, both for heartbreaking moments and uplifting ones.
Takove krasne cteni, pri kterem si uvedomite, co prava laska je. :)

I can't say enough about this book. The middle grade voice is spot on and you can't help but love this kid and root for him. I love how well the author tells his story from different perspectives. Anyone who grew up with a special needs sibling will wish that we could have put our family situation into words as beautifully as the sister in this story does. I would recommend this wonderful book to anyone of any age. It's one of the best I've read.

Wonder, the story of a boy with a severe facial deformities, tells of his journey into Middle School after having been homeschooled for years. The book made me laugh and cry and I did like the admonition to "Be Kind". Being kind doesn't mean always flattering or lying to make someone feel better. Being kind means treating others respectfully, honestly and with empathy.

This book was highly recommended to me by the eleven year old across the street whose teacher had read it aloud to his class. I can see why it would appeal to kids in his age group. It is a story told from many (young) points of view that manages to teach a number of moral lessons without preaching. As an adult I found it to be a bit candy-coated - I only wish it could have gone as well for Auggie - but that small complaint would not stop me from recommending this book to anyone of any age. If its message of love and acceptance gets through to one in ten people who read it, that can only be a good thing. Thanks for another great recommendation Michael!

Read this with my with 8 year old. Some of it was above his level of understanding (about the life of middle schoolers) but the story was endearing. I'm of the opinion that every child should read this at some point in their middle childhood. Seeing someone imperfect from their point of view breeds sympathy and understanding that one can only get by living it or reading about it. I think it changed my child for the better. Maybe even me too.

Much has been written about the character of Auggie and I love him, but I also love all of the supporting characters, especially Olivia, Jack Will, and Summer. 
 WONDER is the kind of book that makes you want to be a better person. I plan to keep a copy on my shelf to remind me that, "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." 
 The ending made me cry, but it wasn't a sad cry. It was a life-affirming cry about all that's right with the world in spite of the things that are wrong. 
 It's almost a shame to classify this book as Middle Grade because then many people won't read it. I think it's a book for everyone. In many ways it reminds me of Cynthia Lord's RULES.

I really enjoyed this book! I would give it a 4.5. Such a sweet and heartfelt read. Even though the topic was a difficult one, the author manages to show you a glimpse into the world that is August and those that surround him. A great read for all ages and one that I would recommend to many, especially kids. Keeps you thinking, long after you have finished.

"When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." 
 Auggie Pullman is a boy with a cranial anomaly, meaning his face is genetically deformed thanks to a 1:4,000,000 chance of chromosomes matching up. Previously home-schooled, it is now time for Auggie to enter the fifth grade in a normal school, with all of the middle school drama that comes with it. Well, even more so for Auggie. A tale of friendship and kindness overcoming ignorance and bullying, this is a great book for everyone to read. 
 I had heard so much about this novel before picking it up in the store. I even heard RJ Palancio speak at a conference about writing the book and her inspiration for it. Now that I have actually bought it, I can tell you it certainly lives up to the hype. I thought I knew what to expect from a book about middle school kids picking on a new kid who was different, but the style of writing made it a million times better than what I was expecting. Not only do you get Auggie's story, but you also get the points of view from other family members, kids at school, the works (even with some chapters written in emails and text messages thrown in). It is a very cool novel to read. You should get on it. 
 "There are more good people on this earth than bad people, and the good people watch out for each other."

Now that Auggie is ten, he no longer is going to be homeschooled but will attend a private school in Manhattan as a fifth grader. This situation would give anyone cause to wonder how he would survive but this experience would be even more compounded if you had extreme facial abnormalities to deal with like Auggie. We learn how six other people and Auggie are affected as he tries to be a normal kid.

I wish I could give this book 4.5 stars - it is written from multiple perspectives about a boy who was born with an extra chromosome that caused several features of his face to be out of place. His mind was not affected, and he watches as others react to seeing him by treating him badly and calling him names. It is heartwarming and heartwrenching at times - well written and great for children to step into another's shoes and build empathy. 
 There were moments when I felt that the plot didn't follow a believable path, but overall it is a great book.

This book was WONDERful!! Every kid, teen, adult, teacher and jerk should read this book. God made us all different for a reason~ what a boring life if we were all the same. 
 Since my babies (who are 19 & 17) could talk, I would ask them, "What matters most?" And their response was instantaneous, "Only kindness, Momma." It were serve our world to share kindness and then a little more ~ 
 Kindness is love...and everyone can use more!!!

Real. Simple. Wonder, o La leccion de August es el libro ideal para una tarde de sabado. Un libro que termina sacandote una sonrisa -de las sinceras y verdaderas- y que conservas en algun lugar tuyo para siempre. 
 Aunque no por eso deja de ser un libro fuerte, que es posible que te haga, por lo menos, hacer caer una lagrima, si dejas que te afecte lo suficiente. 
 Lo mas interesante del libro, en mi opinion, son las diferentes versiones de cada historia que existen; como de cada situacion siempre hay mas versiones, dependiendo de los ojos desde los que lo mires. 
 Lo unico que me resulto desconcertante fue la parte narrada por el novio de Olivia, que esta todo en minuscula, sin dialogos y en presente. Si alguien sabe el motivo de esto, me gustaria escucharlo.

This book was a quick and easy read, but definitely a good one. 
 It had me tearing up at spots. 
 I personally didn't mind the different POVs. Some people do but they're fine really. 
 I think that it definitely has a lesson that a lot of people could learn. Choose to be kinder

I really enjoyed this book, not because it was action packed, but because it helped me to make a realization about myself. 
 Auggie is ugly, "deformed", but if you really get to KNOW him, he is beautiful, in "every single way", and the blending of the perspective of other characters (have seen this technique used many, many times) was important. 
 When you look at Justin's life, or Miranda's life from their own perspective, and don't limit Justin's life to Via's perspective, or limit Miranda's life to Via's perspective, you see Auggie in a brand new light, a brand new perspective. 
 And the thing is, you can't really see yourself, and I can't really see myself as dynamically as you & I can see Auggie after this book because we don't necessarily have the perspective of all the people around us about us, even if we know them, are in relationship with them. We are, and they are too complicated. 
 And that is hard because we don't have an accurate viewpoint of ourselves, not as accurate as the reader has of Auggie after the book is over. 
 Because we were able to see Auggie from Via's perspective, and from Justin's perspective, and Jack's perspective, and Summer's perspective ... and we see bravery and cowardice in Jack's character & Summer's character. 
 I really enjoyed this book, and I will recommend it to kids who ask me what to read. 
 It has the capability of making them think about themselves, their lives, and making the choice to be a better person, for themselves, & for nobody else. (but for others if they so choose).
Wonderful. A good read.

I confess I couldn't even finish the book (yeah, yeah, I know, how can I rate it then). I didn't finish it because I was just plain bored. None of the characters interested me, and I just could not get into the story. Ah well.

Ok I admit it is a bit naive and sometimes too sugary but its so charming, warm and life affirming that I couldn't be my cautious sarcastic self and not to be moved. One of the books you finish with a light heart and a smile, and maybe a few tears in the eyes while knowing its not like you just witnessed future Pulitzer winner.

This is one of the most uplifting books I've ever read although the beginning is somewhat heartbreaking. Hopefully it will teach kids to be kind to one another, it definitely reminds me a little bit of phantom of the opera except the phantomish character August shows his face publicly and is eventually accepted by his peers despite his differences!
This is a must read! Great lesson on empathy and the different perspectives of this affected by being or being around someone who is "different".

This book has so many themes: tolerance, bullying, friendship, family, and coming-of-age to name a few. The characters in this heart-warming tale are crafted with sensitivity. Highly recommended for everyone!

Beautiful reminder of this book which I found on the internet. I just had to share it. 
 Wonder 
 was undoubtedly a memorably read. Between the narrative and the narrative structure and the book's message, it could very well have been phenomenal for me. But it wasn't. It felt to me like a great piece of art with lots of nice parts that didn't fit together enough to merge into one great piece of absolute beauty. Well, something like this. I love that the narrative bounced between characters, allowing us to see what it was like, not just for Auggie, but for all the people affected by Auggie's facial abnormality - even though I appreciated some narratives more than others. It was important to read about the perspectives of some of the people directly and indirectly influenced by him. I definitely loved the themes that inspire one to exercise simple human virtues like patience and kindness. The contrast made between middle school and high school life as Auggie and his sister, Via, try to fit in their respective schools was also something of notability. It's clear that abnormality or not, it's tough trying to fit in and belong in both worlds. School - High, low or middle - can feel like a religion or culture. Or worse, both. 
 I relive moments from this book and it makes me really appreciate the importance of true beauty and human goodness and those who are strong enough to attain it. True beauty is earned, we have to fight everyday to be beautiful inside and I cringe at how easy it is to be the opposite - ugly and cruel. That's one of the finest morals of this story. 
 My biggest problem with the story was the ending was too glassy, too blindly bright and shiny. Too squeaky clean - and dare I say it turned plastic. But(and this is a humongous BUT) like I said, I believe the true beauty of the story lies in the boy behind it - again even if some characters would have been more reader friendly if they had been a little more developed and more interesting in their narratives. All in all, this was a fairly good read. To read Fabian's review, please click here

I put off reading this book for a long time, figuring it for a tearjerker. Luckily, I was wrong--it not only did not make me cry, it made me laugh a lot! It also made me think, a great deal, about what some kids go through under the surface; their difficulties are not always this apparent.

This book was recommended to me by my favorite little bookshop (again!) A very nice story of middle school friendships and the meaning and importance of kindness. Many reviews that I saw felt that the book could have been 'grittier' and maybe they're right, but I still found myself shedding a tear at the end and joining in on the standing ovation.
I loved this book. It was so real. I laughed, I cried, I fell in love with this Auggie's story. Reminded me a little of Spinelli's "Star GIrl".

This book is probably for middle-school age, but I loved it. The main character has a horrible facial deformity, and you learn how different kids react to it. Most are cruel, but some are kind. It is told from several points of view. I really liked it.

The cosmos has not been kind to August Pullman. That is what his sister's friend says, but Auggie is a brave, funny, & normal fifth grader....who just happens to be a medical wonder. Of course everyone who sees him is horrified by the face he was born with. This story tells how he and his new classmates grow to appreciate who Auggie really is.
Really good I actually had read this a really long time ago and accidentally got rid of it on my account so sadly i dont really remember it

I've been reading this book out loud to Christopher for about the last month or so. It's slow going, but he's pretty into it (although he struggled with Via's section). We're almost half way through the book. We borrowed the book from a friend after Christopher was reading a little at her house. I read this book back in 2014 and loved it. We're both excited for the movie coming out this fall, so we're pushing through. I don't remember much of the details of this book, so it's to be re-reading it. 
 http://www.momsradius.com/2017/05/juv...
Heartbreaking in the best way!

This promising story failed to deliver what I felt it could have, dealing, as it was, with a hard-hitting and edgy subject. August, a severely deformed student (in a society that so worships beauty) enters school for the first time, and faces some of the reactions one might expect under these circumstances. 
 The problems I had with the story were: 
 - The story is told by August, his sister Via, his friend Jack, and Via's boyfriend Justin, yet the characters' voices were all very similar. 
 - The characters were largely one-dimensional and this detracted from the emotional impact that more realistic portrayals could have achieved. 
 - August's parents were practically saints. 
 - The dialogue often did not ring true. 
 - Some happenings were too bizarre to be believable. For example, the school principal sends an email to parents of a child who has been assaulted, and in this message he launches into character praise of the responsible child. 
 - The ending tied everything up far too neatly. 
 The biggest problem I had with the story structure was the way conflicts were almost glossed over. There was far too little shown of what August (and even Jack) went through during periods of adversity and shunning. This was a significant missed opportunity. 
 In my opinion, a story that is meant to offer an honest depiction of life as a deformed child owes more to the reader than pat resolutions on all fronts, with the lone remaining bad guy neatly removed, and everyone else living happily ever after. 
 Despite all of that, I did enjoy much about "Wonder" and was entertained enough to read through to the end. Younger readers will undoubtedly find far less to fault in this story, and may well benefit from seeing the world through the experiences of someone like August. If it can help make young readers into kinder, more thoughtful people, then all of this book's shortcomings can be easily forgiven.

August's parents say at one point in the book that they think there are more good people than bad people in the world. That's essentially what this book was about. 
 It was beautiful and wonderful for me to read about a disfigured child who goes to a mainstream middle school to approach the real world head on. It wasn't easy for August (Auggie for short), but I loved watching him win everyone over in the end. August has a genetic disorder that has left his mind sharp and intelligent, but as one character says "the universe has not been kind" to his face. 
 You get chapters from all the people in his life which I enjoyed including his sister, struggling with very real and related issues of her own, his new friend at school, one of his sister's friends, and his sister's boyfriend. Some know August really well and some barely at all giving the reader a very thorough view of August from the inside and outside. 
 His parents are amazing. They struggle with some of the challenges August faces, but they're amazing. Also, the principal of the school is an inspiring and warm character that I believe all principals should aspire to. 
 The book left me with an incredible feeling of hope in humankind.

Quote unquote. "You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder." 
 This is such a wonderful, beautiful, inspiring book. I had cried even on the first page. I had cried countless times throughout the book, which is saying something since I rarely cry over books. 
 Also, nice touch on changing the perspective because that way, we can know more about the characters and their backstory. 
 Solid 5 stars because I really enjoy the story. You, R.J. Palacio, are brilliant.

This is a wonderful book that describes what it is like to be a boy with a severe facial deformity. The book is told from different points of view -- each character gets a voice. The book is both heartbreaking and uplifting. This was written as young adult fiction, but adults will also enjoy this story!

August Pullman was born ten years ago with a severe facial deformity. He had had, in his short life, many surgeries to try to correct and make his problems better, but they were still enough to startle people who weren't prepared for how he looked. Auggie lived at home with his Mom, Dad, and big sister Olivia, who was called Via by her family. His Mom had home schooled him up until now, and between them, his Mom and Dad decided it was the time for him to start school. So Auggie was to begin middle school as a new student, and he was terrified. He knew how people reacted to him, and he was prepared...but it still hurt and upset him, some times more than others. 
 When he went to his school prior to classes starting, to have a tour and meet some kids, he also met the Principal, Mr Tushman, who was very understanding. Mr Tushman had organised some other children to come in as well, to meet Auggie and show him around the school. Jack, Charlotte and Julian were noticeably uncomfortable with their role, but escorted Auggie around, and answered his questions, when he finally asked them! He was humiliated, and didn't want to be there... 
 Via was starting high school at the same time Auggie was starting middle school, but she had been left to her own devices for so long, as Auggie was the one who needed all the attention, that she managed everything pretty much on her own. 
 The story is broken up into chapters by the main characters all the way through, so we meet and hear their points of view. It is a heart-breaking but at the same time, heart-warming story of love, honesty, beauty and an incredible depth that can be found within certain people in overcoming adversity. 
 I highly recommend everyone read this remarkable book as it's one of those books that you will think about long after the last page is turned.

This book has made me cry sad tears, angry tears and happy tears! Its just such a WONDERful and I wish I could force everyone to read it and feel all the feels and hopefully get people to understand that a little kindness goes a long way *goes back to crying on the bus*
Perfecto...
Amazing! Soooo exciting and has everyone's point of view! Love it. No read it!

4.5 Sterne. 
 Was fur ein schones Buch. Die Charaktere um Auggie waren so liebenswert, besonders naturlich seine Familie. Es hat nicht ganz zum "Lieblingsbuch" und 5 Sternen gereicht, dafur hat mir irgendwie noch was gefehlt. Trotzdem hab ich die Geschichte sehr gemocht und auch mal wieder das ein oder andere Tranchen verdruckt. Hach, Auggie, I love you :D
Rigtig god og vigtig bog om hvordan andre ser pa dem som skiller sig ud.
So very good.

LOVED it!!!! 
 I read this book a year ago, my 16 year old could NOT put it down, and she started reading this to my 9 year old son. We were all touched by the wonders of human nature and I know that so many of the Sells students have read this and enjoyed it too!

"Sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone." 
 This book is such a wonder and a very heartwarming story. When I finally finished reading this book it was hard to stop thinking how it inspired and refreshed me. It is a book that I can guarantee will leave any reader teary-eyed but also feeling better. 
 The message of this book is do not judge people by their appearance and also it increases our bullying awareness.
This one was suggested to me by my students. I could not put it down. A sweet book with a beautiful message. This young adult novel should be required reading for all middle school students.

"Dicen que debo de ser una de las maravillas de la creacion de Dios, pero son incapaces de ofrecer una explicacion." 
 "Creo que la unica razon por la que no soy normal es porque nadie me ve como alguien normal." 
 "Todo aquel nacido de Dios vence al mundo." 
 "A veces, cuando tengo la sensacion de que estoy a punto de echarme a llorar, acabo echandome a reir" 
 "CUANDO PUEDAS ELEGIR ENTRE TENER RAZON O SER AMABLE, ELIGE SER AMABLE." 
 "Tus actos son como tus monumentos. Estan construidos con recuerdos y no con piedra." 
 "A veces pienso que tengo la cabeza tan grande porque esta llena de suenos." 
 "Deberia haber una norma que dijese que todo el mundo deberia recibir una ovacion del publico puesto en pie al menos una vez en su vida."

I've had this book on my TBR list a while. I got an autograph signed copy, and it has the extra Julian novella at the end. I finally decided to read it because my own book about special needs and bullying, No One Needed to Know, is on several lists with it and has been compared to it a few times. Well, all I can say is that I'm honored that anyone has ever made that comparison. Wonder is a brilliant middle grade novel. Telling Auggie's story from 6 different points of view makes the world he's living in vibrant and real. It was like I was walking the school hallways with him. Auggie is a smart, brave little boy with a cranio-facial abnormality that scares some kids so much that the only way they can handle it is to bully him. Thankfully, a couple outstanding children see past his looks and become true friends. He also has an amazing sister with an equally cool best friend and open-minded boyfriend. The addition of the Julian chapter at the end cinched the book for me. I'm sorry for people who read the book without it. He is the bully of the story, and this section of the book gives quite an insight to people who don't understand why they are the 'bad guys'. The way he finally learns to feel remorse for his actions brought tears to my eyes. The only thing negative I could say is that having dealt with bullies as a child and as a parent, kids aren't as easily won over as they are in the book. Buy hey, fiction is great and designed to be motivating. I recommend this readers young and old. Pure genius in these pages.
I miss auggie doggie. I miss him so much!
Awesome! One of the best books EVER. Well told story with interesting characters... and character building story lines... one of the best...

It was a really heart warming book. It was a quick read and I enjoyed it. Throughout the book you get to see how August is treated because of his deformity and it really opens your eyes to just how mean people can be.

1. Genre - Multicultural Literature 
 2. Awards - Carnegie Medal in Literature Nominee, The Judy Lopez Memorial Award for Children's Literature Medalist, NAIBA Book of the Year for Middle Readers, Waterstones Children's Book Prize 
 3. 5-6 
 4. This extraordinary story deals with physical differences. Before reading the story, I would have a discussion with my students about differences all people have mentally and physically ranging from things as simple as being outgoing and having glasses to having depression or autism or being paralyzed. It would be important to communicate to my students that people who have more extreme or noticeable differences are really no different in character. Everyone wants to be loved. While reading the book in class, students would break into groups to discuss Auggie's difficulties throughout the book internally and externally. They could also talk about their own personal difficulties with difference or those of close associates and/or friends. At the end of the unit, we could watch a film that shows a person with a physical or mental disability overcoming their obstacles and demonstrating how they have the same amount of self worth as someone without a disability.
Amazing.

This is a "younger" novel than I usually read, but after hearing about it a few times, I decided I had to try it, especially when I discovered that it was available as an e-book from my library. 
 Loved it. Loved August. Loved the whole book. I hope I can convince my boys to read it.

I really enjoyed this book! I liked how this story features multiple perspectives, and not just Auggie's. It was neat to see how Auggie touched and impacted the people in his life in various ways. I also liked seeing how Auggie matures and transforms into one who is comfortable in his own skin, despite how difficult it was, because of his condition. While reading this book, I was able to sympathize and understand, as much as I could, about the characters' lives and experiences. Overall, a very good read that reminds the reader of being kind beyond what is necessary!

Is it because I'm so tired that this book made me cry so often, and for so many different reasons? I don't think so. I finished this in one night, in HOURS. In these hours, I befriended so many wonderful characters. I hurt with them, loved with them, lived through them. It was an amazing and significant experience that nobody should miss out on. This book is going to stick with me. It represents all that I believe in and breeds a powerful message about kindness. I can't recommend this book enough.
Absolutely fantastic book! It was funny, heartwarming and man oh man did I ever cry! Looking forward to watching this movie and probably reading this book again.

Okay I really really really enjoyed this book! I loved the characters and their growth throughout the story. 
 There were two inconsistencies that I noticed and it slightly bothered me. 
 1. At one point, either in the blurb or in the beginning of the story, the author says that Auggie's deformity was not caused by his surgeries. In another instance, his surgeries caused his deformity. Which is it? 
 2. Auggie was talking to his mom or someone about Summer and how he only had lunch with her; no classes. Later on, it is stated that Auggie had English with Summer and lunch. Which is it? 
 These aren't really major issues and I could have misread things. 
 But overall, this was a great story with wonderful characters.

I absolutely loved this book. I loved the way she wrote it using all of the different points of view. It made me definitely want to be kinder. I can't imagine how hard life must be for the mothers of these children and have to sit back and watch the hurt and pain. I think this should be read by all middle schoolers

Es una maravillosa lectura infantil, descrita desde varios puntos de vista principalmente por August claro. Podria recomendarle este libro a todos los ninos del mundo, que digo, a todas las personas. Incluye una gran ensenanza, porque es, ahh, no tengo palabras para describirlo. Es muy muy bueno.

Amazing, amazing, amazing! I love books that stay with you long after you've finished and this will definitely be one of them. It should be required reading for every person on the planet over the age of 10 and should be reread every year until we all get it. 
 A big thank you to Kendall, my 13 year old cousin, who recommended that my mom and I read it. I will be forever changed ... in a really good way. :)

I read this right after The Fault in Our Stars, so the comparison is difficult. This is written for younger kids, so naturally has a different outlook, happier ending. I don't think that's necessarily a weakness. You have to consider the age range and the lesson the author is trying to get across. I enjoyed it, it's well written. Auggie could have had a much harder time, but it all works out in the end.

Makes you think a lot about how you treat people in the world and if you should be judging the book by it's cover. I would highly recommend this for teenagers starting a new school.This book could be used to stop bullying.

This was a sweet story with a lot of heart. The changing cast of narrators kept my interest and made for a lovely audio book. 
 I think that it's just me and the fact that I read the book in late summer (in the midst of "fire season"), but I felt like the author put a smoking gun on the mantle and never let it go off. Here in the west, firecrackers in the woods + smell of smoke = wildfire. But there wasn't one... so the climax seemed very small by comparison.
Great school story!
LOVE!
This was a very interesting read. I wasn't a huge fan of the voice acting when it came to the main character but I understand why it was like that.
Every bit as good as everyone says it is. I love that the kids are real and none of them are some perfect stereotype (except maybe Julian).

A brilliant book for all ages. 
 This book is written for the Young Adult market but is certainly highly readable for adults as well. It is a story of hardships, played out by some hugely likeable characters. Happy in places and sad in others. I laughed, I cried and didn't want the book to end. 
 Auggie was born with extensive facial deformities caused by genetic aberrations. He is fortunate in being born into a loving stable family with an older sister, Via, who loves him dearly. His younger years were spent in and out of hospital with operations to make him more 'normal'. He was home schooled. When we meet him he is 10 years old, the operations are far less frequent and his parents are struggling with the idea that school would be good for him. Unfortunately his appearance is still shocking and his adjustment into school is traumatic but we are cheering him on every step of the way. 
 There is a strong moral content to this book but it is not preachy. The narrative is written from several points of view, but mainly Auggie and his sister. I couldn't put it down - this is certainly an author that I hope to read again in the future.
Beautifully written book. A great story for both kids and parents.

This is such a wonderful book. One of those rare creations that make you fall in love with characters because of how real they are. This book not only shows how cruel humans can be, but also how kind and loving and truly amazing they can be. It's a one-of-a-kind novel that I would recommend to people of all ages...it tells a story that each and every one of us can learn from.
A beautiful book!

Wonder is a book that begins with a quote from the eponymous Natalie Merchant song, then continues to tell the tale of a young man going to public school for the first time being forced to face (no pun intended) the cruel public with his facial deformity. Auggie loves Star Wars and science, has a wonderfully supportive family and maybe even a lesson to teach. Told from varied viewpoints, this story is an interesting conversation starter regarding the power of appearances, the magic of kindness, and the indomitable will to belong.
Everyone should read this book!
beautiful book
OMG I dont understand why i stopped this book and wait like 3 months to continue it ! THIS BOOK LET YOU WITHOUT WORDS TO EXPLAIN HOW MUCH GOOD IT'S!

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." 
 This is a kind of book that made me; both, laugh and cry at the same time. One of the sweetest reads. It is such a beautiful book. There were a couple of moments in this book where everything felt so real, like it just happened to me. 
 "You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder." 
 A Must READ !!!!

wow, I truly loved it! 
 I can't find the words.. 
 Can't believe it took me so long to read it, it really is amazing! 
 Going on a search for a "Keep Calm and Don't be a Julian" t-shirt straight away! 
 Read it! The book deserves its hype!!

La verdad es que no pense que me iba a gustar tanto. No soy una persona de esas que leen contemporaneos y libros asi, pero la verdad es que me gusto muchisimo. August es re tierno y los demas personajes (excepto Julian) me encantaron. Me resulto super facil de leer y rapido tambien. 
 Cita favorita: "Todo el mundo deberia recibir una ovacion del publico puesto en pie al menos una vez en su vida, porque todos vencemos al mundo."

I read this book for the first time a few years ago, but I wanted to reread it before the movie comes out. I loved it the first time I read it, and I loved it again this time! It is a beautiful story about family, friendship, and relationships. The main character, Auggie, has facial deformities, so people stare at him and some are mean to him. He has been home schooled up through 4th grade due to all of the surgeries he has had to have over the years. 
 Through the story, we meet several characters and their points of view. I really like how the author wrote the story from the different points of view, but much of the story was repeated because of this. 
 This is a must have book in every school library! I have had several of my copies "disappear", because the kids love this book so much! 
 Were there some parts that were unbelievable? Yes, but they worked with the book. Were there some cheesy parts? Yes. Still overall a great story!
"I love it, it's a really beautiful story."Universe takes care of all its birds,its wonderful,auggie is really a wonder,book showed pov of everyone auggie, via, summer, jack, justin & miranda.
My 11 year old suggested this book to me. What an amazing read!

The book was good, in the beginning it was very sad how people, like his family saw him different as a person who has a lot of disabilities. But I loved the authors true message, it doesn't matter what is behind all those bruises and weird body parts, internal beauty is the one what really matters. I would reccomend this for people who ever love reading books about disorders, and those who love friends cause this book has a lot of that. Out of all people who would really enjoy it, I would defiantly reccomend this book to mrs sue Stevens because she will like it a lot and learn from it

Wonder by R.J Palacio is amazing book no wonder it is a New York Times best seller. One thing i would like R.J Palacio would do better in her writing is include more detail. I never had a good idea of what things or people looked like. I really loved everything else her writing is wonderful and is filled with rich vocabulary. The writing is amazing and the book is truly a Wonder.
Absolutely fantastic. I laughed, I cried, and I loved every minute of it.

I almost gave up on this one. I kept reading because the sixth grade neighbor-boy who is so kind to my kindergartner told me it was a really good book. The beginning felt slow and one-dimensional. As soon as the narrator switched to Auggie's sister Via, I was hooked. There was real tension, redemption, and character development. It just took more chapters to get rolling than this impatient reader would have liked.

Man I love this book! It's definitely turned into one of my favourites. 
 You know that feeling you get so involved in the world of a book that the real world seems strange? Well, I guarantee that's how you'll feel after reading Wonder by RJ Palacio. 
 It is a heart-warming, heart-breaking story that it poignant and beautiful. It's a story about the importance of kindness and strength and courage. It's about doing good to other people and accepting others no matter what. There are many good people in this world and they definitely outnumber the bad. That's always been my saying and this book proves it. The amount of love that Auggie gets is astounding and you get definitely feel it - not just from his family but also from the friends he meets at Beecher Prep and the staff there. 
 Every child in middle school should read this book and every parent should too. It will teach them about the importance of being a good person and how being a good person will get you farther than not. 
 I can't even form proper sentences - that's much I loved it!
Loved this! Thanks to Carsen for recommending it!
A nice feel good book.
Everyone should read this book
It was 5 stars because it made me cry (tears of joy and sorrow). It takes that or a real laugh to get a 5 from me.

For the past two months I have heard nothing, but wonderful things about Wonder. Last week I finally got my hands on a copy. I have to be honest I was a little worried about starting this book. I had heard such wonderful things about Wonder I was worried it would not live up to my high expectations. I was wrong. 
 This book was amazing! I was immediately sucked in and could not put the book down! In fact, I brought it to a hockey game last night and read it in between periods. I was that hooked! This is a wonderful story that can spur so many discussions about how we judge people by the way they look, the value of friendship and family, and how being kind everyday is an amazing power we all have inside of us. Thank you everyone who gave this book high praise and pushed me to read it. Wonder truly is a wonderful book!

As I was reading this, I kept thinking, "This would make a good read aloud; a good discussion starter." And, now that I am finished I still think so. How DO you get past the initial shock of someone who has a physical deformity? What IS the kindest way to react? How can you look past the outward appearance and get to know the person? 
 I once taught a girl who had severe cerebral palsy and I never managed to answer these questions. In her case, I never even managed to figure out how to communicate with her, but that really doesn't explain (or justify) my reactions to her. 
 There were parts of this book that were just a tad too good (Auggie's family), but most of the book was spot on for each of the different characters. The craft of the author really shows through in the shifts of points of view - with each character adding to the depth of the story. In literature for students of this age (somewhat young for YA; too old for middle grades), there is sometimes the temptation to simplify people and situations, but here the author purposely adds to the complexity, illustrating convincingly that you need to know each character better, before you really understand the situation. 
 Highly recommended.

I love August Pullman. And this book is the way the world SHOULD BE. Sadly it isn't the way the world is. However, it gives readers a look at what the world could be and says, "Make a choice." I am reminded of a bumpersticker that says, "If you're not part of the solution, you're part of the problem." So - what choice will you make? I, for one, choose kind.

Beautiful story about a special little man. At 10 years old, August (Auggie) Pullman was treated as though and acted as though he were an overgrown baby. After his parents argue and then finally agree that it is time for Auggie to grow up some, to have other relationships, other experiences, the parents enroll Auggie in a prep school (in preparation for university). The main administrator selects some other students to introduce themselves personally and to introduce Auggie to the physical layout of the school. Bravery and Kindness are the underlying themes to this novel. 
 Maybe because the book is written for the young adult age group, the Pullman parents are perfect parents and the Pullman children are lovely and well loved. Or maybe because the repeated theme of kindness is approached and re-approached and approached again. 
 Heart opener.

A really worthwhile and enjoyable read for lower secondary students. Nothing unexpected or out of the ordinary about the story but very likeable characters and a great message for kids to read and hopefully take on board. Woud be a good read for an English class or project as it is written from different viewpoints of several of the key characters, although never from an adult perspective. Be prepared to feel quite an emotional attachment to each of the characters. Definitely worth reading if you haven't already.

Bien, Sinceramente me esperaba... no se, mas de este libro, pero no estuvo nada mal. 
 Al final tienes una sensacion de que aprendiste algo, que valoraras mas tu situacion y seras agradecido, pero aun no me quito la sensacion de que falto algo.

This may in fact be the perfect young adult book. It deals with so many themes and has such a diverse group of characters that I think any young person could see some of them selves reflected on the page. It was amazingly well written; it is funny and heartwarming. Any person of any age would enjoy this read!

This book is on the short list of Newberry predictions, and I can understand why. This is an amazing book, and I will be recommending it! Loved the way the author used several characters to tell the story.
One of the best books I have read in a long time. Not many books bring me to tears but this book did I several places. The writing is amazing! The main character Auggie will touch your heart.

What a book! I wasn't so sure I would enjoy this when I set out to read it and I honestly did so for a Library Class that I am taking. However, just a page or so into the book and I knew it would be much different than I had initially expected. 
 The story is told in multiple perspectives and it is refreshing to experience the story from various characters and see it through their eyes. August, the main character, is so strong and inspiring! His unique perspective about his situation is amazing. Reading the story through his eyes and learning to overcome his lot in life is just beautiful. 
 Everyone should read this book. I am going to share it with my students and encourage them to experience the uniqueness of this inspiring tale! It is easy to see why it has won so many awards and received so much hype!
I want to read this with my kids. Lovely book would be wonderful for a parent /child book club.
This book was beyond amazing.. I cried at at least three different parts. Everyone, of any age, needs to read this book.

This is the book I'm reading to my children this month, simply because it reminds us to be kind and to be a friend. I think the main character in the book is surprisingly mature in his attitude and understanding of human nature. Given the handicaps he is born with and his sheltered childhood, this seemed unrealistic to me, but I hope it will spark a discussion about understanding others who are different from us and help my children to see that people are always more alike than they are different. Sometimes the greatest hero is the one who is kind.

August Pullman is about to start fifth grade; the problem is he's never been to school before. He was born with a deformed face, and for reasons vaguely wiped away as "parental overprotectiveness" he's never attended school. During the course of the novel August treads an uplifting but entirely predictable story arc. From outcast with no friends, August eventually wins the hearts and minds of the entire school by being kind, smart, and brave. 
 It's a great lesson for kids, of course, to look beyond appearances to the soul within. But the circumstances of the novel are more troubling for adults who can see through the veneer of the classic feel-good tale. There's a lot of class-based virtue signalling at work in this book: August's family is wealthy enough to have a nice home in/near New York City, to send August to a private school, and to pay for a series of elaborate reconstructive surgeries. As in, money can't buy you happiness, but it sure can make you less unhappy. 
 Also, August is a bit of a Mary Sue: He never really does anything bad, is a smart, attentive student, a good friend, and brave soul. He likes Star Wars and his dog and family, and eventually grows to accept his role as sainted member of his middle school. 
 I'm not going to fault the author too much for her decisions, though, because ultimately the book succeeds at what it sets out to do. It just feels like it left a lot of interesting ideas unexplored in favor of a neatly wrapped bow of upper middle-class self-congratulation, and became a standing ovation to itself.

Three and a half stars for Wonder 
 Here's a book you just have to like for its feel-good story and important message. Fifth-grader Auggie Pullman has been born with a severe facial deformity, one that has required many surgeries. Previously home-schooled, his family enrolls him in a private middle-school in New York City, and that's where the story begins. 
 Not many people can say how a child like Auggie feels to be so disfigured, to be stared at, made fun of, and worse. He has felt it all, yet he remains remarkably upbeat, even when he's sad. Palacio does a nice job presenting Auggie's character, through his own words. She continues the story through other characters' narrations, giving us a wider perspective.
