Most interesting of these points of view is that of his older sister, Olivia, who has always loved and protected her brother, but begins to push away from that role. She is someone who has lived in the background at home, with necessary attention being given to her brother. 
 There are some stereotypical characters meant to underscore the author's message. Julian the bully, Summer, the good-hearted friend, and Jack Will, whose character is the most developed of August's friends. Jack is an on-the-fence kind of friend who is forced to choose between the popular kids and Auggie. 
 This is not a complicated story. The characters are simple, the plot somewhat predictable and the ending is neatly tied. I think it's important to try to read this from a fifth-grade point of view because that is the intended reader. I don't think it is meant to be completely realistic because its overall message of kindness would be lost to the reader if presented in the messier world of middle school, high school and parent dynamics. 
 I was a little disappointed, however, that Olivia's story was not developed more. I think there's the potential to write a great deal about the sibling who has to grow up with less attention. In addition, I read a review on Amazon that suggested Julian's point of view would have been interesting to read. I agree with that, but maybe the author thought it would make the book too negative. 
 Someone else commented that there are two kinds of children's books: the kind that are meant to entertain and the kind that send a moral message. 
 If you're not sure which one Wonder is, Mr. Tushman, the school principal, caps the story with this: Quoting J. M. Barrie in The Little White Bird, he tells the children, "Shall we make a new rule of life...always try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" 
 Personally, I like messier, complicated stories, but I'm not a kid anymore...

Great book. I think maybe one my favorite things about it was that it was not the tiniest bit condescending. It wasn't written "down" to middle schoolers; I believe anyone of any age could read this book and enjoy it. In that respect it reminded me of a Judy Blume book. The characters were allowed to be imperfect; even the adult characters were realistic - neither imbeciles nor saints. The overall message was inspiring and not preachy. Highly recommended.
If you read this book and don't wish every child you ever teach gets a chance to read Auggie's story, I would want to know why. It is brilliant.

Would recommend: Yes 
 This book is so, so good. I would recommend it for students from grade 4 and up, basically, and really any adult. I think the author did a really good job capturing the weirdness that is 5th grade and middle school in general. Even though I usually hate books with multiple narrators, this device was effective here because a lot of Augie's experience was how people saw him, and you don't get that from just his perspective. 
 I listened to this book on audio, and there was one part about 4/5 through when I was crying LIKE A BABY. In my car. Yes. It was awesome (-ly embarrassing).

4.5 
 "Todos deberiamos recibir una ovacion al menos una vez en nuestra vida, porque todos vencemos al mundo." Auggie

I understand the strong themes behind this book. However, I think it was a disservice to place the main character in fifth grade. They should have been ambiguous with his age. Middle school students don't want to read about a fifth grader. Also, thought the boyfriend character was unnecessary.
I'm too emotional to write a review. So save me the trouble, and just read it already.
This was a great book and I wish I had not waited so long to read it. It would make a good read-aloud for 5th grade and up.
Extravagantly written through many perspectives, the book is rich in detail and emotion. This Colorado Book Award winner is a must read. It will from now on have a special presence in my classroom.
A great YA book with an overall message of kindness!

Everyone on the planet NEEDS this book in their lives. 
 I read Wonder aloud to my family, which includes my hubby, a teen son, and a tween daughter. Averaging our ratings, we came up with 4.5 stars. As I read, I often had to pause, as each point of view resonated with me in some fashion, especially Via. I grew up with a sister who has cerebral palsy, and was confronted with many of the same things as Via was. 
 My tween daughter read this first and brought it to me, asking if it could be our next family read-aloud. I've been reading aloud to the family for fifteen years, and hands down, this is THE BEST thing I've ever read aloud. I'm astounded that this is a debut novel! We've also read aloud the Julian Chapters (to be reviewed separately) and look forward to the release of Auggie & Me. The message of these books MUST be shared, and I encourage everyone reading this to give these WONDERful books some time and a good listen.

This book was told first from the perspective of August, who has a deformed face, and is entering middle school. Later there are different chapters from the perspective of his sister Via, his friend Jack, then back to August. It definitely is a young adult book describing the cruelty that is possible when we confront someone who has an obvious physical deformity, both adults and kids. It also could be inspiring for middle school kids (and adults) to learn how small kindnesses could be life-changing. 
 Quick read and left me inspired to be more conscious of how to be kind. In spite of all that, I still felt like we were scratching the surface of characters.. and the mom and the dad were way to perfect to be real.

This was a GOOD book. Not the outstanding that I expected, but solidly good. The changing narrative voice was appreciated, as I sometimes grew tired of one perspective, but then the perspective changed, adding freshness and interest. Unfortunately, I was unable to finish the final section, told in the voice of the antagonist bully, as it seemed inauthentic, whiney, and forced. It was as if readers had asked for this section to let us have at least a bit of empathy for him, but the author couldn't even figure out why he was such a jerk. This took away from the whole book for me. 
 On the positive side, it was nice to read a story about a "different" person that you might see on the street, trying not to stare. This tension of trying to be normal and respectful was the most successful part of this book. Understanding from the perspective of family, new friends, old friends, bystanders and the protagonist himself... This acknowledgement of a challenging social situation was handled sincerely and artfully by the author. 
 Turning the protagonist into a hero and changing all of the hearts and minds except for the most intractable (and inauthentic-- see my bully comments above) seemed somewhat forced. If the author had stopped somewhat short of total acceptance and celebration from an entire middle school, and, instead, developed a more intimate understanding among a smaller group would have been more impactful to me.

Ah, this was a wonderful book. If I picked just one book for the whole year this little book would have fit the bill just perfectly. The story with a middle school aged boy with a facial deformity as its main character just rang true in every respect. It's difficult enough to have to BE in middle school let alone in a way that makes you just stand out so horribly, but that's August Pullman. And he does it with struggles and heart ache enough for me to be filled with absolute compassion for this young man, his sister and his parents. Pick this one up and read it right now!

Auggie has been homeschooled for his whole life, but the year he is to enter fifth grade his parent encourage him to attend a real school for the first time. For most kids this might be a little intimidating, but mostly exciting. For Auggie, though, the thought is mostly scary. Entering a new place where everyone will be looking at him, whispering behind their hands, maybe even laughing at him. This is because Auggie isn't like most other kids. He was born with a severe facial deformity that always gets a reaction no matter where he goes. Auggie decides to give school a chance and has a year of ups and downs while he deals with the trials and tribulations of middle school as a kid who is different then everybody else. 
 An important book about the value of kindness and tolerance that is being read pretty heavily in the community I work in. The book skirts preachiness by viewing Auggie's story through many points of view. Seeing how other characters feel about Auggie and how he affects their life kicks it up a notch above other stories with similar themes. Several well developed characters grow throughout the book, Auggie most notably, but also his friend Jack and even some peripheral characters as well. Dialog sometimes seemed more like a transcript then a novel - distracted parents talking about one thing while someone else talked about something else - probably wouldn't bother most people, but it irked me for some reason.
One of those books everyone should read.

Really great middle school book. Really really great. Love the characters, the descriptions, how the middle schoolers act like middle schoolers (as a middle school teacher, trust me I know). 
 If the editor had taken out about 10-20 pages somewhere in the forrest, this would have been five star read, but as it is, it's a solid four.

I read Wonder slowly and savored it. It seems to me that there are so few novels about loving families that it is a real pleasure when one comes along. The things August goes through during the novel felt real--the kind of quiet underground viciousness that anyone who is chosen as a scapegoat endures. The kindnesses, both the tentative and wide open genuine offerings are also typical of children learning who they are and what they will choose to stand for.

A really affecting book. I'm skeptical of kid's books featuring characters with issues/disabilities, because they're often not very good. This was pretty dang good though, for a number of reasons. 
 1) The main character is not perfect or saintly. 
 2) The other characters respond to him in a wide range of ways, with lots of nuance. And the negative responses have an explanation - not an excuse, but a backstory that helps them make sense. The mean kids are not just mean because they're evil (most of them). 
 3) Middle school is the perfect setting for this, because there's so much general meanness and weirdness going on anyway. 
 4) Lots of different first person narratives, lots of points of view, again, great insight into the complicated machinations of adolescent relationships. I'm kinda sad we didn't get Julian's because it would've been interesting if a little disturbing. Maybe that would've been too dark. 
 And of course, very thought-provoking and useful for exploring the issue of facial anomalies and how much we humans react to appearance. But really good for just exploring how to be, and how to be good, without being too sappy. I liked it very much and would like to know what kids think of it.

Li este livro num apice, muito por recomendacoes de pessoas na internet, e descobri que tudo o que diziam sobre este livro e verdade! 
 E um livro de bastantes emocoes, talvez pela seu caracter ingenuo, faz-nos reflectir sobre muitas coisas, e ligeiramente triste em certas partes, mas completamente recomendavel.

Cool beans. I honestly didn't think it would touch my heart. August Pullman, your story's no doubt a WONDER. 
 Yes, it's a children's book but it was filled with excitement and goodness. Also, I noticed how perfect the Pullmans were. August might be the very reason why their family was blessed. 
 This book was so sweet and the ending melted my heart. I love Auggie Pullman so much! And I'm now marking it as one of my favorite books ever written! Hoping this book had helped kids like Auggie, including their families and friends.
Excellent, excellent tale of acceptance, understanding, and love. Recommend to all!
Fairly honest book. Didn't make me cry but there were a few moments that did make me smile.

I thought this book woud be a lot of things but spiritually uplifting was not one of them. 
 I know I won't forget the little dude for a long time.

Ok, I am going to be completely honest. I don't read a lot of contemporary books. It's not that I hate them at all, it's I seem to enjoy falling into worlds that aren't real instead of books that I can happen on Earth. But every now and then I enjoy the contemporary read. So far all the books I have from that genre have been really good and I loved or really liked them. And this one is no exception. Wonder was such a fantastic read. 
 The characters who were nice to Auggie just made me so happy for him, and the characters who weren't I just want to push off a cliff basically. With Via and how her life is like in her first year of high school felt so relate-able to me, and the choices she made. I just felt like this story was just really good and for the most part realistic. The one part I didn't find realistic was at the end where Auggie gets the award, and every one is cheering for him. I kind of expected that some of the parents at least would not be cheering (and Auggie would notice), or something like that. But they all cheered for him. I personally don't find that realistic. But I am somewhat letting this slide since it's a middle grade book. 
 Overall, this was just an amazing, amazing read. 4.5/5 stars, and I really really want to read more from R.J. Palacio since I really loved Wonder.
This was a beautiful book and story. A simple but powerful message: Be kind.
it is such an awesome, lovely but also sad story!
This book is so heartwarming. It touched my heart in so many ways that I can't even put my thoughts into words. It was just, simply beautiful.

I cried almost the at every couple page.. I don't know why.. There is something with this book that you will want to finish it at just one set.. Amazingly beautiful.. Recommend it for everyone.. There's no way y'all won't fall in love with this book and its characters 
 August is really a Wonder

** spoiler alert ** 
 Book for middle grade readers about tolerance and acceptance. Auggie Pullman is born with crano-facial abnormalities. After years of surgeries that make home schooling more practical than traditional school, Auggie begins 5th grade at a private prep school in Manhattan. The book traces Auggie's fifth grade year: making friends, dealing with bullying, field trips, and the death of the family dog. 
 While mainly narrated in the first person by Auggie, the book does shift perspectives to include sections narrated by his sister, Olivia, her boyfriend, Justin, her former best friend Miranda, and two of Auggie's new friends, Jack and Summer. This technique allows the reader to see others perspectives of Auggie but I didn't find it all that necessary. Auggie is an appealing narrator and fairly perceptive about the world around him. 
 For some reason I kept expecting Auggie to die in a tragic manner (he does not); instead the kids graduate from 5th grade (do they really have elaborate 5th grade commencement ceremonies these days?) and many of Auggie's classmates have been changed for the better by getting to know him. 
 I liked the book but did not find it as touching and moving as many people have. Kids especially seem to like the book which is ideal for using in a school curriculum about tolerance and kindness.
Read this book! Absolutely amazing.

I would give this book 4.5 stars if I could. While it's not the most amazing book I've ever read, it's an excellent book with a great message for both kids and adults alike - don't judge a book (or human) by it's cover. 
 August (Auggie) was born with a very unfortunate and rare mix of genes that left his face severely misshapen and disfigured. Until 5th grade, he is schooled at home by his mother, who he is very close to. However, as 5th grade approaches, his parents feel it might be a good idea for him to go to a real school. August hates the idea at first, but is soon talked into it, especially after he tours the school and sees the possibilities. 
 August has to go through a lot of trials while at school because of the way he looks - genuine horror from people who've never seen him before, taunting from other children, a game called the "plague" where if anyone accidentally touches him, they have 10 seconds to wash his germs off of them. Through it all, August reacts in turns like the child he is but also the more mature child he's been forced to become due to his disfigurement. With the help of some kind children who befriend him, August blooms and overcomes, eventually winning over essentially his entire school. 
 I very much enjoyed this book and especially the fact that the author broke the story into narrations from several of the key characters - August; his sister, Via; his friends, Summer and Jack; Via's boyfriend, Justin - etc. It's helpful in ways like initially, August refuses to describe himself, saying only whatever we, the reader, are thinking, it's much worse. But when Via narrates, we get a description. Also it's helpful to understand the emotions and feelings of all of the characters involved in the story - for instance Via, who can't remember what life was like before August. While she loves her brother and understands the circumstances, she can't help but envy the fact that he gets more attention from their parents. And she can't help the guilt that, as she starts a new school, she doesn't want to be known as the girl with the deformed little brother. 
 I think the book is an excellent read for pre-teens through adults. Hopefully, it will help us all look and react a little more kindly to those less fortunate than ourselves.

Wow! 
 I highly recommend this book. Different perspectives give us more information than a single view. 
 Wonder is not just for children. Adults also need to learn how to accept differences & value the strengths we each have. The book contains some great quotes taught as "precepts". 
 Some Passages: 
 I wish every day could be Halloween. We could all wear masks all the time. Then we could walk around and get to know each other before we got to see what we looked like under the masks. 
 _______ 
 Maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. The universe takes care of all its birds. 
 _______ 
 One should be kinder than needed. 
 _______ 
 " ... in the future you make for yourselves, anything is possible. If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 He paused and shrugged. 
 "Or whatever politically correct spiritual representation of universal goodness you happen to believe in," he added quickly, smiling, which got a lot of laughs and loads of applause, especially from the back of the auditorium, where the parents were sitting. 
 _______ 
 Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness.
Quick, easy read. Hit home just a smidge.

Wow! This is a fantastically brilliant, heartwarming, and beautifully uplifting little book! It is an amazing story told with empathy and humor. 
 10 year old Augie Pullman, born with a terrible facial abnormality, won't describe what he looks like but says, "Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." Previously homeschooled, this narrative is about his being mainstreamed into 5th grade at a middle school. It is described in short chapters by 6 different narrators: his older sister, 2 of her friends, 2 of his classmates, & himself. 
 Palacio, the author, does a skillful job giving each of the narrators a very honest and distinctive voice. They all sound sincere & real. It makes you feel like you really are taking this journey right alongside Auggie as you are given a glimpse into all their lives. The characters are complicated. No one, not even Auggie, is all good or all bad. The situations are realistic, from the bullying in the halls of Beecher Prep to the small family dramas in the Pullman home. 
 The multiple perspectives also allow the reader to know more than any one character does, even (especially) Auggie. As Mr. Tushman, the school principal, points out, "there are almost always more than two sides to every story." 
 This is an awesome book about a kid who is truly a Wonder. At times heartbreaking & at times triumphant, it is a story of how one person can make a difference. Despite the expected sadness in Wonder, there is also much humor, joy and hope. Kids and adults alike will love this stellar debut by a first time author. If you haven't read it yet, I think you should - it's worth all five stars and even more. 
 favorite quotes: 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 "Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 "My mom smiled at me. Her smile kind of hugged me." 
 "It's not enough to be friendly. You have to be a friend." 
 Don't try too hard to be cool. It always shows, and that's uncool."

One of the best books I've read. It was also nice to see the other character's point of views. The author gave this ambience that everybody was an important character, not just August. It was a very heart wearming book and I'll make my eleven year old sister read this too.

I thought this was, overall, an absolutely incredible book and it is now up there with Les Miserables and The Deathgate Cycle on the list of the best books I have ever read. I like a good adventure, but there will always be a place in my heart for books like Wonder that bring me to see the world through new eyes. I wish everyone could read this book at least once in their lifetime.
This book was amazing! Very well written! I believe it is a wonderful read for all ages!

Wonder is a fantastic book about empathy, courage, judgment, loyalty, self-expression, and surviving middle school. It would be a great family discussion book. Palacio leads the reader gently through an exploration of the process of how we form (mis)impressions of the other humans with whom we share our lives. It explores prejudice of all kinds, not just against Augie with his facial deformities, but also against popular kids, rich kids, weird kids, and jocks. Despite the subject matter, the book is not didactic.
Outstanding book of 2012. Found perfect book club book for middle school.

I wanted to write a review for this the night I read it, but go figure, I was out of reach of the internet and had to wait on it. 
 I enjoyed it - it was bittersweet and a bit wrenching, but overall pretty good. 
 I didn't expect the multiple perspectives - I thought the book would follow Auggie all the way through. I ultimately liked that the portrait of Auggie was fleshed in by those around him. 
 There's a bit of Owen Meany going on here in the character, with a bit of "Heft" in the vulnerability and ache of trying to find acceptance (both from himself and others). 
 I enjoyed it and feel it's a great pick for Battle of the Books and an excellent read for kids approaching middle school. 
 I'm so glad I didn't read this in June after putting my dog to sleep. The scene with Daisy squashed my heart and got me ridiculously choked up. 
 Loved the Principal. 
 Thought it interesting that it touched on the theme of inclusion in the sense of "ownership." Someone who is an underdog in one circle and not treated as a member of that group can suddenly become the person most protected and "owned" by that group when threatened by an outsider. In this way, the fight in the woods/cornfield felt like a believable turn of events. I've seen similar situations play out often in other contexts - online communities, work circles, real communities... 
 It may be something to think about (getting kids to take ownership and step into a protective role vs. competitive) in terms of bullying and strategies to help stop it.

This was just as good as Betsy said it was. I predict it will get some strong Newbery consideration. Told from multiple viewpoints, it's the story of August, a student entering the fifth grade. Auggie's previously been homeschooled due to a host of medical issues related to a severe facial abnormality. So it's the trauma of being brand new to school, added to the challenge of being remarkably physically different than his classmates. 
 The general plot is pretty much the one you expect from the premise of the book -- he has trials and tribulations, and the other kids have various reactions that he has to navigate. But overall, this is just QUALITY writing for middle readers (it's not YA). Almost all of the different voices add something to the story, and the characters and their situations are reasonably complex and the emotions feel very real, even given the somewhat boilerplate nature of the story arc. 
 A small mention that it's set in New York City, and it feels very believable and supports the plot nicely - but doesn't, I think, make things so New York-centric that other readers will be put off. It reminded me a little of When You Reach Me in this respect (although it's not at all similar to that book in terms of theme).

I checked this book out of my library today, knowing it had good reviews, wondering if I would think the same thing. Well, here I am, 8 hours (5 of which were spent in school) and 313 pages later, sent to tears by how happy this book left me. It sets off so many emotions in anyone, even if you don't have your own little brother with a genetic disorder like August. I could relate to this book in ways I haven't related to any person ever. I can't believe how well this book encompasses my own life, my sisters life, my parents life, my friends lives, all of the people who have parts in this story have a mirror image character in my life. I have so much to say about this book. I just can't say it all in one review.

I really enjoyed this book. I love the points of view and how the writer shows the experiences in a real way from a lot of the people involved. I would have enjoyed a chapter from the point of view of Julian but I suppose that would have taken away from the tone of the book. I definitely recommend this book.

Wonder is the most adorable book I've read in 2017. I just wanted to hug the book and lay on my bed ( with that silly smile I had after reading it). 
 So Wonder is about Auggie ( who has facial deformity) who is starting 5th grade. He was homeschooled and had never studied in a mainstream school. Wonder follows Auggie's journey through 5th grade. 
 What blew me away was how well all the characters' POV chapters worked together. There are multiple POVs. So many POVs. It's a recipe for disaster. It's not supposed to work! But it does! 
 We have chapters from Auggie, his sister Olivia, his friends Summer and Jack, and even from Olivia's boyfriend Justin! All in a 300 pages book! It's astonishing. It never felt too stuffed or forced. I was never annoyed by the change in POV in each part. Each character had a unique voice. They all had beautiful character arcs ( especially Jack and Olivia. I love them so much). 
 We even have a Julian chapter. It was like an addition, after the story had ended ( I've seen it being listed on Goodreads as a novella. My edition had it in the book itself). To be honest, I wasn't going to read it. I loved how the book had ended and I kind of despised Julian(he was on of Auggie's main bullies). But I'm so glad I didn't. It was so wonderful! So don't skip that chapter ( it's not exactly a chapter. Sort of a part, like 100 pages long). 
 Posted on: https://beingabooknerd.wordpress.com/...
WONDERful. I wish this was our fifth grade's class book. The different perspectives were so eye opening. You never know why people behave the way they do. I can't wait to read "Justin's Chapter."

Have you ever wondered what it would be like to be different, so different that others would stop and stare, or worse? Have you ever wondered why we judge people based on their physical appearances? Have you ever stopped to wonder how you treat others and if it is always with kindness? 
 August Pullman was born with a facial deformity. He has been homeschooled his entire life due to his health. Finally Auggie has the opportunity to attend public school for fifth grade. Wonder is the story of his fifth grade year, told from the points-of-view of August, her sister Via, Via's boyfriend Justin, her best friend Miranda, as well as Auggie's friend Jack. 
 Why I picked up the book: It has been recommended to me numerous times by a variety of people. 
 Why I finished it: I could not put the book down, even the second time! I especially loved Auggie's parents. I would hope to be that great of a parent in that type of situation. 
 I'd give it to: Absolutely anyone. It has a great message about kindness, love, and acceptance that we all (teens, adults, parents, teachers, students) need to hear and be reminded of on a frequent basis. I took the book with me to school visits, in case I had a few minutes to read between classes, and anyone who had read it and saw it in my hand always said "Wow! That's such a great book."

I promise I'm not heartless, but I didn't love this book. It wasn't just me either. I buddy read Wonder with my son and he wanted to DNF. It was required summer reading so no such luck for him. Our favorite parts were the precepts at the end. I'm fully aware that our experience is in a crazy minority for this title but that's how it goes sometimes. Neither one of us felt engaged or connected with the characters at any time in this story. We tried though. We took a lot of breaks, discussed the book as it progressed, brainstormed precepts of our own...it just wasn't happening. We wanted this book to be over. Regardless, I would still recommend Wonder to others, because like I said, our experience appears to be rare and the morals of this story are invaluable for every age. You're never too old to practice kindness or to re-evaluate how success is really measured. This book may have sucked for us but the life lessons made it worth it. Two stars instead of one :) 
 Note: The audio narration for Auggie's voice is awful in our opinion. Just because a person may have facial abnormalities does not mean their voice will be equally impaired. I found the narration insulting to Auggie's character and frankly it was grating to listen to based on my personal reading experience. It's hard to say if we would have enjoyed Wonder a bit more if we read it off the page instead. I thought this element was worth noting. 
 My favorite quote: 
 "Isn't that the most important thing of all? Isn't that the kind of question we should be asking ourselves all the time? What kind of person am I?" 
 6/20/16: 
 Buddy read with my boy
Every single person needs to read this book. This book needs to be in every schools curriculum! It was so beautiful, so painful, and so motivating. I love this book!

WOW! I loved this story. I loved all the different points of view. I love that it's about the power of kindness and what true friends are. So touching and sweet. I am having my kids read this one, Lisa Blake you need to read it for sure! :)

Intriguing. Love the Precept of the Month the teacher. Liked the voice of Auggie's older sister and how his disability impacted her. Overall good story and very engaging for children. I would recommend every 4th and 5th grade teacher read this aloud. Lots of community building and classroom ethics can be created from discussing this book with children. 
 My notes, questions: Good for Mock Newbery and OBOB. 
 Do children with the type of genetic deformity Auggie has, usually have normal cognitive ability, too? 
 Did use of email, lover case, texts, all work and seem believable?
Everybody should read this book. So beautiful and deep. Aw, Auggie <3
I thought this was really sweet. I cried at the ending. I liked the different perspectives and kind of wish there had been more of that.

An incredible message but the vehicle of delivery felt a bit contrived. I enjoyed the different perspectives from which the story is told and most of the voices were relatable and took me right back to middle and high school.

3.5 
 This was a really solid book. I didn't really like August's character personally. I thought he shifted between childish to insanely introspective, too quickly. But the sad parts really hit me. The ending felt a little bit too neat. I really really liked Mr. Browne, though. I want a book just about him. I also kinda want a book just about Justin. Something about him really struck me as interesting. Olivia's character was beautiful and I so much appreciated her. Gosh a book about her and Justin would be fantastic. Amazing. I really appreciated the message of this book but in the end it was just kind of average to me?? There were a lot of redeeming factors though, and I can totally see why it's rated so highly.

This book won't ever be on my favorites list despite my giving it five stars. What I like about it is that it is well written, realistic, and deals with differences and bullying in a unique and powerful way that gets the reader to think rather than telling them how to feel and act. I'm going to strongly advocate for this book to be required summer reading for students entering our MS. The reading level is relatively low and there really isn't anything I consider questionable. It is a powerful book for dealing with serious issues in middle schools and even HS. I'd say the lowest grade you use it with would be the end of fourth grade.

Excellent book, highly recomended, especially to a kid who maybe hasn't had a lot of experience with kids who are "different." This book is about a middle school kid who's as different as you can possibly imagine and the story touches on empathy, kindness, and friendship in the face of social hardship and ridicule. An excellent book.

As a piece of literature, maybe 3 stars. But I am evaluating this book for the purposes of teaching 7/8 grade, in which case it's a five star book about a boy with a facial deformity. 
 Unit ideas: 
 --Fiction/Non-Fiction Pairing: Wonder would make a great bookend to Lucy Grealy's "Autobiography of a Face" 
 -- Differences: Wonder might fit in well in a diversity unit when we end up asking questions about differences that are "skin-deep" 
 -- Possible literature pairing with Frankenstein, with a focus on deformities and "monsters" 
 -- Point of view: book is told from multiple perspectives 
 What I love most about Wonder is its portrayal of adults and elders as imperfect but ultimately redeemable human beings. There are moral villains in this book, yes, and I appreciate how Palacio doesn't give them a change to reform -- that would be too unrealistic-- but does handle them in a somewhat "happily ever after" kind of way. That is to say, this book is ultimately optimistic but we know that there are real challenges ahead for our hero, and that no matter how many friends our hero will gain the world will still sometimes be a cruel place without reason. 
 This is the kind of simple yet sophisticated message I hope students discover through reading.
Yes. Yes. Yes. Be kinder than necessary...
It's good. If I was the age for which the book was intended it would be better. Still worth reading.

"If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 Awesomest book ever :)

I can't believe I postponed this book for so long, for real. 
 I'm still processing the story in my head. I'm still amazed. 
 This was the kind of book that only after 20 pages I started crying like a baby. There were many moments while I was reading that I started crying like a baby (the Daisy chapters, particularly). 
 The end of the story, though... The standing ovation... I'm still speechless. Speechless out of love for this character that never gave up, never stopped being funny, kind, friendly. And this character, this August that I fell in love with, was so well-written and so brilliantly good throughout the entire story. 
 This is the kind of book that make you remember how you should be good. How you should be kinder than necessary, like Ms. Tushman said. And I thought it'd get a bit boring like "Room" did, because it was written through the perspective of a 10 year old, but I was really into the whole thing and just couldn't stop reading. 
 So, so in love. So stupidly in love with this book.
really really great book. Loved it.....would recommend

I'd only read a few pages of Wonder when I realised that it was going to be one of *those* books, one of those rare and wonderful books that can make you both laugh and cry on the same page, that you read with a lump in your throat and a smile on your face, that as soon as you finish reading you eagerly pass on to somebody else just so you have someone to discuss it with. Yes Wonder is one of *those* books. 
 What I love about Wonder is how simple it is. This is a book about a ten-year-old boy whose face is deformed. And that's it. There's no huge complex plot, no far away land, magic, or fantasy creatures. This book doesn't need any of that stuff to hook the reader, August's voice is enough. 
 Auggie believes that he is just an ordinary ten-year-old kid but that's the one thing I'd have to disagree with him on. But Auggie's face isn't what makes him different it's his huge, brave, heart and big personality. Auggie is the kind of character who touches your heart and who you fiercely want to protect and want the best for. He's such a special little guy who I think we could all learn a thing or two from. 
 Wonder is full of fleshed out and vibrant characters and although the majority of the book is told from August's perspective the book is also told from several other characters point of view. Each protagonist has a unique outlook on Auggie and tells their story and how having August in their life has affected them in both good and bad ways. Before reading this book I'd never given much thought on what it would be like to know someone like August and the bullying a friend might go through for hanging out with him, or how a sibling might constantly come second to a little brother who has much greater needs than a normal child. This book is a real eye opener not only to what it might be like to be in Auggie's shoes but also for what it's like for those who know and love him. 
 R.J Palacio is such a talented writer. Not only has she created such warm and likeable characters but she writes with such honesty as well. Whilst this book is definitely sad in parts Auggie is such an inspiring, happy go lucky, funny kid and at times he's simply a ten-year-old boy observing the world around him. Yes this book made me cry but it also made me laugh out loud too. 
 Wonder is a book for everybody young or old. It's an important and special book to be shared and discussed by both adults and children. This book makes you want to be a kinder person and I can't help but feel that if everyone were to read it the world would be a nicer place. This is one of the best books I've read all year and I would whole heartedly recommend it to absolutely anybody.

Great story about kindness, middle school and learning to just be "you" which is the simplest & hardest thing to do. Check it out from the library, borrow a copy from a friend, buy it, download it- try to read it this summer before the start of the school year. Cool beans.
I loved this book. It should be required reading for all 5 th graders. I especially loved Mr. Browne's precepts.
I have to tip my hat for this author.I LOVE THIS BOOK!!!I truly wished it had won the Newberry Award. Now I NEED to download the Julian Story ASAP.

This book was such realistic books that people should read to learn how to be nice to others. Also August (Auggie) though he has plenty going against him he has such a positive view point. He may not look like everyone else, but he's nice, smart, and pretty much a little dork. 
 This is told not only in August POV but others around him. At first I didn't know how to feel about that, but understand why it was important. It was to see the point of views of those around August. 
 It was also told by different voices (thanks to audible) which was a fun time to hear them with the other characters. 
 LOVED: 
 Like I said the realistic elements in these book. Like how August reacted to another school. Or the way people react to him, along with the bullying. Sure August had his ups and downs which is expected however he grew up to the challenge which was wonderful. 
 The friendships (mostly Jack and Summer) are the best. Yes they started off as his not so sure of him to being his best friends. August grew a friend base slowly with the other students with his humor and charm. That ending shows how much August touched the other kids at Beecher Prep School. Well except one but that's not to bad in the whole picture. 
 The grownups where written very well in how they treat August. His parents are like the most supportive and fun parents. The Pullmans have there inside jokes and such a close bound. Then we have the grownups that August school who didn't treat August differently which was nice. Also they didn't let bullying happen. There was also those who weren't so nice however it was good to see the other side of it. 
 Audible Version 
 I liked the different voices and thought they did really good for making the characters have different voices. I will say though August voice wasn't my favorite. Other than that this was a really good book to listen to. Now though I want to own and read it in physical format. 
 The only thing that I didn't like is that these is the only book. There are also novellas of some of the side characters. I still would love to continue with all these characters.
I found the end a bit too sappy. Otherwise, a great YA novel that has valuable lessons for 5th graders and adults alike.

Sin duda este fue uno de esos libros que te hacen preguntar una y otra vez el por que no lo habias leido antes. ?Saben de esas historias que les deja como una punzada en el pecho una vez que lo terminan? !Este es uno de ellos! Y solo porque quieres mas de el, a la vez estas totalmente satisfecho. Creo que de las pocas lecturas que he tenido, Wonder (La leccion de August) me ha dejado sin palabras, me hizo darme cuenta de monton de cosas y una de ellas y la mas importante es aprender a valorar lo que tengo.

Seriously - this book was AMAZING. Should be a required read for every kid in 5th-9th grade... multiple times even!! There's a powerful, heartfelt message about (anti) bullying, kindness, acceptance, and friendship. I can't wait for my kids to read it!!

This should be required reading in all middle schools. I love the Barrie quote "....always try to be a little kinder than is necessary." Put this book on the shelf with Sharon Drapers Out of My Mind and Nora R. Baskin's Anything but Typical.

I absolutely loved this book. I've recommended this to all of my friends in school. 
 It has really helped me, and whenever I feel sorry for myself, I would always remind myself of August and his unfortunate predicament, and how so many people in the world have it so much harder than I do, and feel as though I have much lighter boots on. 
 I also loved the Hobbit and Star Wars references in here, being a hard-core fan of both. 
 I can't even imagine how I would be able to face the world as boldly as August does, I would probably use my hair to cover my face as much as I could, or be like August and use a cool astronaut mask. 
 I thought that August's sister's problems were extremely relatable, as my own younger brother has ADHD and dyslexia (he may be a demigod, who knows?), and he's the only one in our family who has learning difficulties. He gets bullied a lot and I stick up for him as much as I possibly can, but it does nothing to deter the name-calling. 
 Anyway, I thought it was a beautiful book, and I really hope everyone who has read this has found it as inspirational and uplifting as I did.

Rat boy. Freak. Monster. Freddy Krueger. E.T. Gross-out. Lizard face. Mutant. I know the names they call me. I've been in enough playgrounds to know kids can be mean 
 My daughter's teacher gave her this book as an end of school year present, intrigued by the cover I began reading and quickly became immersed into Auggie's world. 
 August is a 10 year old boy born with a facial deformity, after being homeschooled his parents decide it is time for Auggie to enter school. The book follows Auggie's journey from the first day of school to his 5th grade graduation. It's such a lovely & hopeful journey, I really can't imagine anyone disliking this beautiful book.

What I most liked about this book was August's difference. I loved how he think and how he act. I loved everything. 
 I cried, I smiled and at the end I looked like a little baby which just cry all the time. 
 In this book there was so much of pain, strong and all kind of feelings. R.J. Palacio, you are a genius ^^

I honestly don't know how to rate this. 
 From a writer standpoint, I'm not sure why all the different point of views were necessary. It could have been pulled off I think with only the main characters'. 
 From a theme perspective, I was a bit disappointed by the whole 'life will take care of you', 'things have a way of working out', message. Life isn't really like that. 
 It's well written, of course, and I enjoyed many aspects of the premise. But it felt a little like a Disney movie at the end, where I was crying but knew I was being manipulated into crying. 
 My daughters read the book too and they loved it (aged 10)--they give it five stars (so I will too). Maybe I've just grown cynical.
Loved this book!! It makes you feel good inside and that there are nice people left in this world!
This was the most heart warming book i have ever read! I wish i could read it over again and again!

This children's book is actually a third re-read for me. The first time was a pre-reading before introducing it to my previous students. Then, I read it with those students. This third time, I read it for my in-person book club and in preparation for the upcoming movie. 
 Normally, I do not take the time to re-read books unless I absolutely love them. With three reads, I obviously love this one! 
 The major theme of acceptance is something, I believe, relates to not only children, but to everyone. How many times have we judged someone due to their outward appearance? It isn't right, but it's reality. In this chapter book, the author cleverly pulls in a variety of children (middle school and high school) to give their version of the interactions and reactions toward the central character, August, and his facial deformity. 
 If you're curious, you can read my full review here: https://bookloverblogs.com/2017/05/08...

I thoroughly enjoyed reading this book. What a wonderful book! Wonder is about a young boy, August, who was born with a face deformity and is about to start fifth grade in a private school after being home-schooled his whole life. R.J. Palacio did a great job depicting the different young characters' points of view and in a way that one can relate with all of them. I don't usually read YA books, but found this one as part of a list of books being made into movies in 2017. I am a second grade teacher, so reading the plot is what initially attracted me to this book. I am so glad I found this book and I cannot wait to watch the movie. I would definitely recommend this book to young readers and adults. It has a great lesson of acceptance and kindness. These were my favorite quotes: 
 "The things we do outlast our mortality. The things we do are like monuments that people build to honor heroes after they've died. They're like the pyramids that the Egyptians built to honor the pharaohs. Only instead of being made of stone, they're made out of the memories people have of you." 
 "The best way to measure how much you've grown isn't by inches or the number of laps you can now run around the track, or even your grade point average-- though those things are important, to be sure. It's what you've done with your time, how you've chosen to spend your days, and whom you've touched this year. That, to me, is the greatest measure of success." 
 ""It's like people you see sometimes, and you can't imagine what it would be like to be that person, whether it's somebody in a wheelchair or somebody who can't talk. Only, I know that I'm that person to other people, maybe to every single person in that whole auditorium. To me, though, I'm just me. An ordinary kid."

I made the mistake of reading this on my train journeys between home and university. If you don't want to be crying in front of strangers, avoid doing the same. This is an important book and reading it almost felt like making friends.

This book is incredible. Full stop- the reasons being: 
 1. It was actually realistic, and all the scenarios were believable. They school dynamics were echoed perfectly and written about like the author had first-hand experience. 
 2. Auggie was so hard not to like, you ended up living the story with him. Although it was written from many different viewpoints, I always felt like it was HIS story. 
 3. I actually connected emotionally with the characters, and when they felt strong emotion, I felt it too. In particular, when Julian's snobby mother writes those emails, I felt like I wanted to punch her in the face with rage. 
 An AMAZING read!

I'm looking forward to reading other reviews about this book. For me, the character of Auggie was absolutely real; a very convincing portrait of an unusual person. That said, I wasn't pulled into the emotional highs and lows of his story. I loved the chapters that told the story from the viewpoints of the people around him though.
I enjoyed this book. Although it is a book for kids, the story was authentic.

Oh my! This book was so perfect. While reading I personally felt connected to each and every character. As cheesy as that is, I truly did. I love the way this book was written and I love Palacio for creating the different point of views throughout the story. Truly a remarkable novel.

This is one of those books that ANYONE can enjoy - your parents, your friends, your teachers, your siblings, your hamster. ANYONE. Such an important and timeless message. 
 (Don't mind me just adding reviews to my favorite books.)

I am in the minority on this one. I picked Wonder up and put it down countless times. Did not hold my interest in the least. Not only do I vividly remember what it is like being a young person, I am surrounded and interact with them on a daily basis. In a myriad of capacities. Kid Laura would've hated this book. Way too slow and truly felt inauthentic in almost every way. I am aware that many reluctant readers embraced Wonder. That is always an incredible accomplishment. Three stars.

Quite honestly, I've read this book probably more than a year ago. I loved it, but I shot prejudice at it when I was handed it from my mother and was told that it was supposedly a good book. I refused to agree, but the days after I started reading, clearly I was into the book. More than a year later, I still am wondering how August's face looks like. (Lol it's such a popular name sometimes; it's a month name for crying out loud.) Does he have one eye? 
 IDK. Well, goodnight!

The only reason I'm giving this novel four stars is because at times it seemed to drag; other than that it's an inspiring read that every child of every age should read....Wonder shows us that sometimes the easy way for yourself is the hard truth for others. 
 ~Emily
I thought this was a good and important book about differences and empathy. I will definitely read it to my kids at some point.
A must read! Auggie is a character that will live in my heart forever, I hope. As long as I choose to be kind not right.
I thought this was one of the most heart-felt books i have ever read. I couldn't stop reading the book! I thought it was really creative how it was told from different points of view

Since I spent the whole day at the train station 'working' but not actually being able to work. Long story. I managed to read almost this whole book in one day. I have to say I really enjoyed it. It read very quickly and I liked the way it was written. For me it was a pretty good feel-good story. I'd actually like to see it made into a film. It was very touching and inspiring. I loved the way it ended. But won't spoil that for anyone ;). Just read it, it's worth the very little amount of time it takes. :)
This book had me laughing-out-loud and crying. Great story of overcoming adversity!

Finished this so quickly! Absolutely adored it. 
 Although I'm not 100% sure all the points of view were really needed, I did feel that it worked most of the time, allowing us to see Auggie's story from the points of view of those he came into contact with, so we could understand not only how Auggie was feeling and why, but also why others acted the way they did around him, and what it was about their own stories that made them that way. 
 It added an extra depth to the story that I don't think could have been gained from telling it purely from Auggie's point of view. 
 The characters were all really fantastic, and there are some really beautiful moments in the book - some made me laugh, some made me cry so fiercely I thought I'd have no tears left to give (both sad and happy tears!). 
 This was an incredibly moving story about friendship, equality, understanding, kindness, forgiveness, and so many other wonderful things. It gave me goosebumps. It's probably one of the most heartwarming little stories I've read, and I highly recommend it to anyone who hasn't yet had the pleasure of picking it up!

While I really enjoyed the message in this book, I'm not entirely convinced that a child with a facial deformity will find happiness and friends in middle school. Based on personal experience, I think that middle school is especially hard for almost all children but even more so for the child who is perceived by others as being "different". Auggie Pullman has been homeschooled all his life; in part because he's had so many different kinds of surgeries and in part, because his parents wish to protect him from the unkindness of strangers. Finally, his parents relent and allow him to start fifth grade at Beecher Prep. He is bullied, shunned, teased and ignored but Auggie does win a couple of friends. In the course of the story, we hear from his sister, Via, and his friends both old and new about what it is like to orbit planet Auggie. The climax of the book comes when Auggie and his friend, Jack, are set upon by some seventh graders from another school while on an outing. In the nick of time, three boys who had not had any use for Auggie before show up and chase the seventh grade ruffians away. This cements their relationship with Auggie who is now seen in a new light by all. In addition to being more widely accepted, Auggie wins a special award at fifth grade graduation for his bravery in just going to school for the first time and for bringing out the best in his fellow students. All I can say is that while this is a wonderful message of hope for children who are "different" in their appearance, it shouldn't be generalized to offer hope to all children who are "different" in behavior or intellect.

This little book is like totally amazing. And I'm like super stingy with five-star reviews. 
 It's probably like maybe a YA, with chapters that are like only 2 pages long, but that really pulls you along and you can't help like cheering for this kid with his small size and his severe facial deformity. 
 Touching and compelling and had me in tears more than once. And a satisfying ending. 
 The book just arrived one day in the mail, but I have a vague recollection of signing up for it quite a while ago. Happy to have received it, because I'm not sure I would have picked it up otherwise.
Wonderful book from a completely different perspective.
QUE SHORO MUZO

Just like MOCKINGBIRD, this blew me away. A real story from a unique set of POVs with true meaning. I wrote a post on my blog after reading this about how it inspired me. 
 (Showcased in Disabilities and Community: A Book Recommendation and 6+ Top Book Recommendations)

I loved this book! 
 Usually I like fantasy, intense books without happy endings and basically all my favorite characters usually end up dying :( 
 (Why I love books like that, Idk I just do lol) 
 But it was nice to take a break from that and read a happy book! 
 Totally inspiring and uplifting! 
 I always have been annoyed when people think less of people who have mental or physical issues or deformities or anything like that. They're people too an they didn't choose to be like that. This book completely supports that! I love it :)

3.5 Stars 
 This book is about August, or Auggie, who was born with facial deformity and after years of homeschooling due to his multiple surgeries, he's finally going to be starting fifth grade in a public school. It's a story about a boy trying to live a normal life despite what he might look like. 
 I really liked the plot of this book. And I liked the fact that it was a middle grade novel because I love middle grade. 
 This book has a great premise and a great story to tell. The book is well written and well paced. I even like the multiple perspectives. It was nice to know what others thought of Auggie and how they dealt with it. I wish we'd gotten the perspective of Auggie's parents though that's okay. 
 My favourite part was the one with Via's POV. I really liked her character as well. 
 I do have a few problems with the book, though. 
 One problem is the narrative. The reason I love middle grade is largely because the characters are just kids. I love getting the perspective of someone who has yet to get to the angsty, lying stage of their life. I love the innocence and the simplicity. But the narrative here didn't sound like that of a 10-year-old at all. Auggie didn't feel 10. 
 Another problem was the format for Justin's part. It was with minimal punctuation and no caps. I might have been okay with it if there had been a reason given for the format, but there wasn't. 
 The story became a bit dull and cheesy near the end. Predictable too. I wasn't as interested at that point. 
 Finally, there was the message about being kind. Kindness is great and all but other things are important too. The message worked for this book but not otherwise. I didn't agree with it entirely. 
 Overall, this was a good book but it didn't resonate with me, emotionally.
Quick happy and sad ya novel. Good characters.

Quite simply wonderful! I wish it had been around when I was in Middle School. 
 Everyone could do with a reminder to CHOOSE KINDNESS!

The thing that made this story stand out was the way it was told through multiple perspectives. You don't learn about the boy with the deformed face going to public school for the first time just through his eyes, but also through the new friends he makes, through his sister, and even his sister's boyfriend. It was well-rounded and entertaining.

Wow... just wow. This book was beautiful. It tells the story of Auggie Pullman, a little boy born with so many facial 'deformities' that he is homeschooled until 5th grade. 
 The author does a wonderful job of showing human cruelty and kindness...and that kindness can ultimately be more powerful. 
 The book moves quickly, building in power and sentiment. You will be charmed by 'Auggie' and learn the paradox that probably every 'different' person feels: Different. But 'normal' on the inside. 
 A character quotes from a book by JM Barrie: "...always try to be a little kinder than necessary." It's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed. 
 Such a simple but powerful concept. The book brought tears to my eyes. Because of the kindness part, not the cruelty. I'm reminded that we are all so powerful. A kind word...look or deed is within all of us. 
 Read this.
This book was a kind of slow read but over all it was really good!!

Why I picked it up: It's been on a lot of lists of best books of 2012 and the audio recording is on the list for the YALSA Challenge. 
 August Pullman has been home-schooled, partly because of extensive surgeries, doctor's appointments, and physical therapies he's needed due to the extreme facial deformity he was born with. And, let's face it, partly because kids can be cruel. But now the 5th grade is willing to try school, a middle school near his home. The principal hand-picks three kids to show Auggie around before school starts, but that doesn't mean that he is accepted right away. 
 I liked it. While most of the story is from the point of view of August, we do see things from some other characters, including his older sister. Parts are very, very heartwarming, parts make you really examine your own actions, and parts make you just want to do bad things to some characters. (Julian's parents, anyone?) One thing I really liked were all the references to great kids' books. 
 Contains: mentions of smoking; death of a pet; bullying 
 Challenges: Jessica's Scavenger Hunt: Geek 
 YALSA Challenge: Amazing Audio top 10
Aw, such a good story. We can all learn something from Auggie and his friends.

Loving this book--absolutely loving it. 
 The only reason I haven't finished it yet, is because I promised to read it at the same pace as my son's class (which is killing me, BTW -- I wanted to finish it weeks ago...) 
 Final review to come when I'm (finally) done. 
 finished today! 
 Brilliantly written. The author sounds like a fifth grader -- a fifth grader who has been through a lifetime of trials and tribulations already, but attending a real school might be the most challenging yet. ABSOLUTELY LOVED this book. Highly recommended. In fact, if you have kids around this age, reading this book together is a great springboard for some really important discussions regarding friends, bullying, and just plain being kind.

Very, very good. I liked the shifts in POV, the overall story-- just about everything. I would have liked for the precepts to be more evenly distributed throughout the book, but it was nice that they were all added at teh end. The character of Julian seemed especially realistic to me. A great read for MG, YA or adult.

I loved Auggie - he was interesting, funny and loveable. The parents were very, very, VERY nice. 
 The ending was tied up in a tidy bow, just a bit too perfect.
A really great book about the capacity for human kindness and strength. There were some editing errors and I thought some of the dialogue needed polishing, but overall this was beautiful.

I really enjoyed reading this book and I recommend it. Without revealing the ending, let me just say that the ending is why I did not give the book five stars. I think the ending was unrealistic and simplified the very complex issues revealed in the book. 
 That said, I loved reading it as I was doing so and all of the characters who narrate the various sections of the book were complex and interesting. There was one obvious "bad guy." I wondered how the story would have played out if he had been given an opportunity to narrate (this could be an interesting assignment for students if you really want to develop empathy).

Did I say this book was probably going to make me cry ? Because it definitely did. Yes, I am a very sensitive person and this book was just beautiful, heartbreaking and heartwarming. I felt both sad and happy and I don't know it just made me feel a lot of things I'm not sure how to transcribe here. This kind of books always make you look back on your own behaviour around people with disabilities or physical differences and it is a good thing because it's so easy to be offensive because you don't want to be offensive. All August want is for people to understand that he is not different, he's just a boy. And I have sooo much love for this little boy and his family (and Daisy). They filled me with joy and love. I will definitely remember that book for a very, very long time !

Ugh...this book. It's beautiful, I loved it. Every kid should read this book. 
 I definitely got teary eyed and that doesn't normally happen to me while reading. I can only imagine the tears the film adaptation will bring for me. Seriously...everyone go read this book. 
 The characters are wonderful and realistic. Some kids are mean. Like really mean. Other kids are slightly mean and unaccepting at first, but learn and grow as the story progresses. Other kids are kind and caring right from the start. This is beyond realistic and believable. 
 Auggie is just such a great kid. He is brave and kind and beautiful and every young child should strive to be exactly like him. 
 I loved this book and everyone needs to go read it NOW!
Wow.
It was a very interesting book! And I got a very special kind of copy! It had an extra chapter!
wonder is exactly what the title says - a Wonder. It's been a long time since a book made me cry. Twice. Read this book and bring on the wonder . . .

Oh my goodness, what a powerful read! I read this out loud to my seventh graders and what a perfect book to teach them that what is inside of you and what you do with it is what matters most, not what is on the outside. Love, love, love Auggie and who he is and how he handles things. What a brave "little dude" Auggie is. I can only hope that his character has taught us something. Being different is good!

This book really got to me. It was beautifully written and I think everyone in their life should read this book at least once. IT shows how cruel the world can be sometime and not to let anyone's insults get to you. #AntiBullyZone

I was a little hesitant to read this book given its classification as a "Young Adult" novel, but I am so glad that I did take the time to read it. This novel is so heartbreaking, and so poignant that I wonder how much young adults will truly take from it, although I hope it is a lot. I cried so many times during this book, my heart really aches for this main character. I feel as though I really connected with August in light of my own personal journey and it felt some sort of cathartic to read the words of his pain, his fear of being labelled, and his bluntness about his differences in a voice other than my own. 
 I also found it so interesting that this novel was told not only from August's point of view, but also from those of those close to him. I found this a very effective way to examine not only the issues that come with being "different" but also those that come along with dealing with differences, choosing sides, and doing what is right over what is easy. At least for me, I had never really considered how profoundly my own differences could have impacted those around me. 
 Overall, I think this was an amazing book. And while I am cognizant of the fact that this is a novel for young adults, though I was happy at the end of the novel, I found the ending a bit unrealistic. While I would love to believe that the ending that happened is one that would realistically happen, I can't say that I found it really believable. The fact that those are the feelings I ended this book on, I actually felt really sad at the end, disappointed in my own jadedness and pessimism when it comes to humanity as a whole.
Love, love, love this book, so beautiful and sweet. Handing it off to my almost 10 year old niece next.

: Se merece un lugar en el cielo. 
 This book made me smile and made feel bad for our little Auggie. I really thank the author for writing so close to my feelings: I really felt what Auggie felt, so when he was happy, my chest was pounding about to explode. I wanted to be part of the group, of his friends; I wanted to go back in time when I was ten and laugh and cry like he did. 
 This is the best example of a children's book that can be read as an adult or as a teen. I devoured in almost one day, I almost cried in the end, I highlighted so many phrases... I totally recommend this book for begginers and for those with kind hearts.

Omigosh! Everyone should read this book! 
 It is a lesson in kindness and the power of love.
Spectacular read! I don't think my words will do this book justice, but I thoroughly enjoyed the read and the tears it brought were welcomed! Wonder deserves its very own standing ovation!

August (or Auggie) faces many of the same challenges any new kid in middle school faces: where to sit at lunch, how to find friends, how to deal with betrayal, what to do with an older sister, etc. Because of his facial deformity, he also deals with more-than-average bullying. 
 Despite these challenges, Auggie manages to survive school, thanks to some wonderful classmates and his devoted family. A unique aspect of this book is that it is told from the perspectives of multiple characters, allowing readers to better understand the characters' motivations and actions. 
 I couldn't put this book down and really enjoyed reading it! Highly recommended book for readers in upper elementary and middle school who enjoy realistic fiction, including those who are reading above their grade level. This book would also make a good read-aloud for a family or classroom discussion about bullying, students who are "different", and general middle school issues like making and keeping friends.
This was just an AMAZING story. It made you sad, it made you empathize, but most of all it made you human.

I listened to this on audiobook once while on vacation, having been wanting to read it for a long time previously. 
 I was unprepared for the impact that this book would have on me. The wonder of bullying really confuses me. This poor boy who, obviously, had no choice in the fact that his face would look this way was mercilessly bullied and teased. 
 The book itself was beautifully written and constructed. 
 I personally know a little baby boy who was born with the same facial deformity that August has, and I know that I would never think of him differently. His mind works just as well as anyone's-- it's just his face that is different. I hope that he grows up without bullies-- though I know that there will be some kids that treat him very differently.

A recommendation from a friend. Once I started this book, I read it in essentially one big insomniac gulp. This beautifully told story reminds us all that while we may look different on the outside, our inner lives and feelings are often very similar. A worthy read for anyone, this book should definitely be included in upper elementary reading groups or used as a teacher read aloud.

I really, really wanted to give this book at least 4 stars. Truly. I did. I really appreciated how Palacio captured family interactions so realistically, I genuinely felt that she understood how middle school feels, and I felt that the concepts of acceptance landed without being preachy. In terms of emotion, thoughtfulness, and messaging, this book was a 5-star. 
 But I didn't give 5 stars. The writing seemed somehow off. I think my biggest issue with the novel was the shifting point-of-view. I felt that August's chapters felt the most authentic, especially since it's essentially his story. I liked Via's as well, and Summer's didn't bother me, but, once we got to Jack's, I wasn't feeling it anymore. I felt disconnected from August, in a sense. Justin's chapters threw me off too -- the shift from regular punctuation and capitalization to a lack thereof seemed awkward and forced. Overall, I feel like the novel could have worked better had it been told entirely from August's POV, or possibly in the 3rd person. I think multiple points-of-view can work really well, but I don't think it did for Wonder, which felt very jumbled and incohesive at times.

I thought this was a great book talking about overcoming bulling, I happens on schools no matter what we do about it, I think that learning what you can do to stop it and how to overcome it is an important lesson to learn. I loved wonder and thought he was such an amazing kid. I wanted to punch some of the kids in the face but that just shows I'm not as awesome as wonder. I hope I will get to see students in my class room like wonder to show as what is really important in life and that is friends, family, love, and the fight to carry on :)
Wow, there are so many great things about this book. If Auggie doesn't steal your heart, something is wrong!

I just realized I never really reviewed this book. It's true that I don't really review most books, but this book deserves a few words. I first read this alone and then read it to my class. The experiences were different, but were both very special. When I read it alone, I got caught up in the characters and the story, and I bawled my eyes out at the end (but ultimately found the ending to be very uplifting). When I read it to my class, I thought more about the themes of kindness, bullying, friendship etc., and it lead to some great classroom conversations. 
 The kids are still talking about Wonder. I often hear a kid saying, "Oh, that's like in Wonder when..." or "That character reminds me of ___ in Wonder because..." In science, we read about Stephen Hawking and I heard a few comments about August then as well. I feel like it really had a big impact on my students, and they'll remember what they learned from this book for a long time. Wonder is cool beans. :-)

Absolutely, totally, and completely amazing. This book will stay with me for a very long time -- and should be on everyone's required reading list. Touching and tender and funny and it will make your heart ache at times. Beautiful, beautiful writing. August Pullman is about to enter school for the first time in fifth grade after a facial deformity kept him from attending school. His experiences and perspective, and those of the people in his life, will make such an impression on you. Can't recommend highly enough.
Fantastic! I can't wait for the movie!
I'm not sure realistic it is, but I loved all of the characters, and appreciated that the author didn't throw the character with the worst behaviors to the sharks in this book.
I loved, loved love this book. So many great life lessons to be learned from it.
Excellent. Touching and moving.
Billy gave this 41/2 stars. I would give it 2 1/2. I felt the writing was pretty lazy. Lots of incomplete and clunky sentences.

I liked this book, and I think it's one that everyone should read. And that many older kids should read. While we all may "judge a book by its cover" -- even if it's just for a moment -- we all want to be liked for who we are, not what we look like. It's not okay to bully, it's not okay to make fun of someone for being different. And how much more enriching can our life be if we let people's personality shine? 
 It's interesting that I finished this book around the same time that the news story about the KFC employee and the little girl that had been mauled by dogs came out. This toddler girl has lost an eye and has multiple scars on her face because of the attach, and some insensitive person had the gall to say something about it. When I actually looked at the little girl, my heart went out to her, and I thought, "Poor baby girl." Yes, there was a moment of pity. Pity that she had to endure this. Pity that I'm sure she has suffered a lot (both physically and emotionally). And, I would have perhaps blinked a moment, and then shown her kindness (like this book espouses). 
 Some people may think that being kind to someone with a "deformity" or "handicap" is being condescending, and perhaps some people are/can be, because they don't know what else to do. I'd rather someone be shown a slightly feigned kindness for a moment than outright ruddiness or disgust. Yes, we can respect people on a basic human level, but even that seems hard for people. 
 There were a few little things about this book that did take me back a little. There are different voices used for narration, so that was interesting. And ... it did seem a little too neat and tidy toward the end. I did tear up a little for the things being said. 
 All in all, recommended.

For all the great reviews about this book, it didn't resonate with me. Maybe it's because the audio book voices were so utterly TERRIBLE!!! We could hardly endure them enough to get through the book. Also, the writing was really lacking. It was mind-numbing to keep reading, "I was LIKE, I was LIKE. . . " The same wonderful story could have been told from the different viewpoints of all these kids, with the same wonderful message of kindness, using higher quality of writing. I also didn't appreciate all the references to dating in 5th grade!!! Really?
Too beautiful for words.
effin a.
"Todos deberiamos recibir una ovacion en pie al menos una vez en nuestra vida porque todos vencemos al mundo." August Pullman.

This book was pretty good, with a good moral lesson to learn about kindness. And a good reminder to everyone that we all have our own trials, each one of us, no matter how things look from the outside. It was neat to see each individual perspective about how life is hard. 
 A few quotes from the book I liked: 
 "The universe takes care of all it's birds." 
 (-p.204 Justin in response to Miranda's comment: the universe was not kind to Auggie Pullman) 
 "Funny how sometimes you worry a lot about something and it turns out to be nothing." 
 (-p.215 Auggie about his hearing aids) 
 "You don't need your eyes to love, right? You just feel it inside you." 
 (-p.227 Auggie's mom about people in heaven) 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 (-p.231 about Via's play...and it was obvious at that moment that Auggie would end up with his own standing ovation) 
 "I was going to be extraordinary, but there would be no one there to see." 
 (-p.243 Miranda making a sacrifice for her friend) 
 "It's so weird how...you could have a night that's the worst in your life, but to everybody else it's just an ordinary night." 
 (-p.273 Auggie reflecting on the normalcy of everything just after he'd gotten beaten up) 
 "The sky was the same. The movie was the same. Everyone's faces were the same...but something was different. Something had changed." 
 (-p.274 Auggie realizing the world was going to be different...the "big turning point") 
 These were all great lessons and things to remember. 
 With all that warm fuzziness said, here's why I didn't rate it higher: 
 The idea of this book was good, there were a few sweet moments and a few tears shed, and it'll probably be a great movie, but I kinda feel like it only got published because the author worked in the publishing industry and "knew people". 
 There is a great moral lesson for children, but it reads sort of like a "travel log" or "interviews with the characters".
