And I never really "felt" what August was going through, all the characters were sort of flat and removed. I was actually kind of bored and kept waiting for the good part that's making everyone rave about it and turn it into a movie. Honestly, I cried the most over the dog dying than anything else, and that had very little to do with the overall story other than it helped Auggie realize the world was bigger than just him. 
 Not a lot really happened in this book and the "big turning point" for the whole story was sort of unrealistic, almost seemed "made up" to give the story conflict. Seriously? I would never let my "normal" 5th grader go on a 3-day retreat out into the "woods" with a bunch of other 5th graders and no parents. I know that's just me being "over protective" but supposedly Auggie's parents were also "over protective" and they had sheltered him his entire life. Why would they suddenly send him off "as a lamb to the slaughter"? I understand the whole analogy of "a lamb to the slaughter" when referring to sending him to a real school, but sending him on this retreat was way more literally "a slaughter" waiting to happen. 
 And, the ending was "happy-fuzzy" with the awards and such, and "they all lived happily ever after" but it was all sort of forced and predictable. I was happy Auggie won an award (yay for him, he got his standing ovation!) but realistically he didn't do anything to earn it. He was kind of whiny and self-pitying, and then he got beat up in the woods and suddenly he's this big hero? Jack and Amos are the ones who actually "did" something in that situation, they probably should have gotten that award. 
 And what ever happened to Justin? Was there really even a purpose for his character? 
 In summary I gave this 3 stars because it's a good message and I like the idea of it, but the execution of the idea is lacking. The kids were unrealistically mean and the conflict was too staged. The adults were too dumb and oblivious and the characters were all very flat. The voice of the 10 year olds didn't really sound believable to their supposed ages and other than everyone "wondering" what happened to his face I failed to see the "wonder" in August. He was just an uninteresting, unexceptional kid with a facial deformity.

This book is fabulous!!!!!!!!!!!!!! 
 If you have not read this you haven't lived! 
 Wonder takes you through the journey of different kids all experiencing life. August Pullman has a quite different fave than others therefore most people won't give him a chance to speak to him and now he has start something he has never been to As ten year old: school. 
 Wonder makes you wonder about all of these kids and there life. 
 It is rather quick and for all ages(I read this with a book club). 
 READ THIS BOOK!

The focus of this book is a ten year old boy, August ("Auggie") Pullman. He has an obvious genetic injury, which only affects his face and hearing. While both adults and children are characters in this book, the most resonant, are the voices of the children. 
 There are chapters (called parts) from the viewpoints of Auggie's sister Olivia ("Via") and other children whose lives intersect with Auggie's. This technique makes the flow of the book especially easy for even a young reader to develop empathy with the viewpoints presented. It is almost a surreptitious way to learn empathy. 
 The reader can take this as Auggie's coming-of-age story as a middle school student who is unfamiliar with school routine, but very familiar with self-knowledge, irony and human nature. Or on a deeper level, this story can be taken as a primer on how to be a human being. 
 Originally I felt that the author should have included a table of contents. After completing the book, I feel that the author's design worked. Auggie's world requires some immersion; the part titles and quotes are much more appreciated while traveling through Auggie's life in middle school. 
 In the Appendix, the author gives the reader a peek into the state of mind of various characters during the summer vacation following the grade 5 graduation ceremony. To avoid spoilers, I will not mention specifics, but I enjoyed the information. 
 Many parts of this story made me sad which does reflect life in general. However, this story is not just of the accomplishments of one ten-year-old boy, but also how others around him become more than what they once were. Ultimately, the ending is one of hope and happiness.

"Shall we make an new rule of life.... always try to be a little kinder than is necessary" 
 One of my favourite sentences in this lovely book, I could easily have read this book in one whole sitting but I didn't want to, I wanted this one to last. If you loved Room and The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time then this one is for you. 
 It's a gem of a story, about a little boy called August "Auggie" who has an genetic defect that has changed his face, himself and his family are perfectly aware of the attention he attracts and because of this, he was homeschooled, so when his parents decide to send him to an outside school in fifth grade.... This forms the basis of the storyline. 
 This is just a truly lovely story and beautifully, beautifully told. It definitely pulled on my heart strings. To finish with another great sentence... 
 "Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life, because we all overcometh the world. - Auggie.

A wonderful story with an underlying message to choose kindness and to even go a step further and be kinder than kind. It's true that you remember when people are not kind and no one wants to be remembered for the nasty things they did or said. August was a wonderful, strong character who faced many challenged with grace and bravery. Definitely recommend for children entering the hard stage of friendships and self identity.

This is a great book for any genre, and certainly for Middle Grade. The author switches perspectives (all are 1st person), but does it on a section to section basis, making it easier to transition. Most of the time you see the world through Auggie's eyes--he's been affected by improbable set of genetic and happenstance set of circumstances that affected the way his face developed. His is not a "normal" face and he's also had a lot of concomitant medical issues. This isolate him and he's come to expect that people will treat him differently--although obviously unfairly. 
 This is about a year in his life and in the lives of those around him, how each changes and grows--or doesn't, in one case. Throughout the book, you see that this is an exceptional young man with a superficial difference that the people around him learn to accept. 
 His family is very close, very supportive, but even they have to deal with the prejudice that others feel. The adults have long since learned to deal with it, but his sister is going through a troubling period of her own and she begins to see (as she says) with two sets of eyes--the eyes of a sister who loves her brother and doesn't notice the difference and the eyes of how others see him. For a freshman in high school this can be challenging, since she's trying to make a new life for herself as well. 
 I'd recommend this book to, pretty much, everyone. It's theme is classic and the characters are compelling and realistic.

I'm not going to go on and on about this book, because I think most of you have probably read several reviews of it by this point. But I do want to share my thoughts. 
 In short - it was fantastic. Read it. 
 To say a bit more - I'm a teacher and I hate bullying with a white hot passion. Bullying makes me angry more than anything else. Why? No one has the right to make someone else's life horrible and difficult and unhappy. No one has the right to target another person for no real reason. No one. I just can't fathom someone thinking it's ok to do! So this book hit home a lot. To watch Auggie go through what he did hurt my heart. Yes my heart was healed in the end, but it hurt to watch him have to cope with the cruel behavior of others. I'd love to be naive enough to think stuff like this doesn't happen. I so wish that was true. 
 I loved the way the story was told. To hear from multiple characters was amazing. It created this completely full and well rounded story. You came to understand what was happening with many characters, and you could understand more why they did what they did. It also helped you gain a stronger understanding about how bullying affects all people involved not just the person being bullied. It would not have been the story it was without constructing the book this way. 
 Really - if you haven't read this book you should. Yes it was hard for me to watch it all unfold, but the hope and optimism at the end was so much stronger and uplifting.
Any book where I cry more than once deserves 5 stars.

I adored this book! it's so relate able and cute plus you read this super quickly since the chapters are short. The best thing about it is it's in multiple POVS which I love since it's great hearing from different characters in the story.

10-year-old Auggie, born with a rare chromosonal disorder that causes severe deformities to the face, is used to the reactions that his appearance evokes in people-- the stares, the horrified looking away. Homeschooled all his life, he has lived in relative isolation. Now, with his parents' encouragement, he decides to take the plunge and attend middle school. He finds out that, compared with the reactions he has grown used to in strangers, fifth graders can take cruelty to a whole new level when they're faced with someone who is "different." But there are a few friends in the bunch, and slowly but surely, other students learn to look past the external and see the warm, friendly kid underneath. The writing is superb, and the shifting points of view between major (and some not-so-major) characters adds depth. This is so much more than a "underdog-kid-overcomes-obstacles" story. While the conclusion is a little Hollywood feel-good, that doesn't detract, and kids and adults will cheer for Auggie the whole way. Highly, highly recommended for grades 4-7.
eh...
ageless

I'm a little shocked at some of the praise this book has been getting. I understand that people are impressed by the subject matter, but it's also been getting praise as being well written, with good dialog, and I thought those were two of the biggest holes in the book. I also thought there were some plot holes and unbelievable characters, but mostly I just thought it was very poorly written. 
 Update: some more of my thoughts on the writing here: http://crossreferencing.wordpress.com...

R.J. Palacio ha escrito un magnifico libro. Es un libro maravilloso que se ha convertido en uno de mis libros favoritos; la historia es preciosa, me rei, llore pero de felicidad, me enoje; pero lo mas importante es que me senti feliz. Termine este libro con una sonrisa y me levanto y aplaudo a R.J Palacio por esta maravillosa obra ya que como dice August: "Todo el mundo deberia de recibir una ovacion del publico puesto en pie al menos una vez en su vida, por que todos vencemos al mundo"... Trabajare en mi propio precepto... sin olvidar ser amable. Un libro que todos deberian leer.

What an amazing story. It is told from the perspective of August (the child born with a rare mixture of diseases which made his face very disfigured), and those children surrounding him in his life. Auggie is entering 5th grade at the start of this book, entering a 'real' school environment for the first time. It follows him through his whole 5th grade year. There are many 'typical' reactions from children, but also some that surprise the reader. 
 A wonderful story of acceptance, being who you are, and perseverance. Favorite line from the book? Everyone should get a standing ovation at some point in their lives. I totally agree!

It reminded me a lot of the book Schooled by Gordon Korman, though with the difference in Auggie being on the outside. Not as wonderful as other "overcoming an obstacle" books for this age level, but still a thoughtful read.
I loved this book.

An incredible book about acceptance of differences, what friendship really is, and the bonds of family. A lovely, humorous and incredible book that aught to win all sorts of awards and accolades - and will be enjoyed by readers of all ages.

I read this book with my nine-year-old cousin. I think it is a really nice book for children and teenagers, and it explains for them, in a simple (but from multiple perspectives) things like compassion, acceptance, and difference among people. However, as an adult, I had the tendency to read it as a fairy-tale, especially the ending ... I wish that kindness could be learnt, but I really don't believe that August would have ever been truly accepted by all the members of a real community.

it's heartwarming, sweet, funny and it will make you cry and laugh at the same time :"""") 
 the way Palacio tell the story of Auggie through other characters and how Auggie influence them indirectly is unique. 
 Love it !!

This book is one of the most inspirational books I've ever read. The main character, August, is a 5th grader who is going through an extremely hard time in his life. (Not to mention he kinda has a rough life as it is..). 
 This book shows his experience for his first year in a public school- middle school (which is already tough!) and how he copes with other students, and learns how to deal with many difficult hardships. 
 From page one, I was drawn into this book. Now I have to admit my slight post-book depression.,I feel like the book went by WAY TOO FAST! It's just such a fantastic read, as you see how looks don't matter, it's what's inside that really matters! 
 5 STARS. I would give it more if I were able.
Awesome story. Loved it!!

Wonder is incredibly easy to read and is a definite page turner, it is brave about issues that sometimes seem complicated to us adults but that seen from the perspective of a child don't really matter. Either way, Auggie is relatable and funny, he is a character that shines and is never fearful. All other characters are also human and may make mistakes but, what is life but that?

Frankly, this is one of the most amazing books I have ever read in my entire life. I laughed; I cried. I feel in love with the characters, and the lessons inserted in this story affected me deeply. 
 This book tells about August's fifth grade year of school. August has never attended a school before. He was homeschooled because of all of the surgeries he had as a child...for his face. "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse," August said concerning his severely tarnished face. Wonder takes you on a journey though the ups and downs of August's first school year. It also tells the perspective, thoughts, and experiences of some who were profoundly impacted by this ten year old boy (August's sister, his sister's boyfriend, his sister's friend, and his friends). 
 Firstly, the sensitive subject addressed in this book is handled pretty perfectly, in my opinion. It definitely changed my perspective on people like August. I seriously recommend reading this book to children; I believe it would help them be more understanding, unafraid, and kind to people who look different from the medium. 
 The characters are incredible. I love how Palacio told the story through different characters, rather than just August. August, Via/Olivia, his sister, and Jack, one of his friends, are my top three favorites. The way Palacio portrayed August was phenomenal. In one way, he was a regular, naive ten year old boy, yet at the same time, he was a wise old man who had been to hell and back. I fell in love with August. When reading Wonder, I cannot tell you how many times I wished I could reach into the pages and give August a hug. I laughed at his jokes and cried at his hardships and triumphs. I found myself relating to Via/Olivia a lot. Our experiences, personalities, and thoughts are very similar. Jack was an awesome character. You go from loving him to hating him to loving him again; I really like characters who make you teeter totter like that. 
 The lessons this book taught are timeless, relevant, and very, very true. The main message of Wonder is kindness. I think today's world often forgets to be kind. Wonder stresses that, "It's not enough to be friendly. You have to be a friend." The world we live in is so concerned about winning and being right; we often dismiss the fact that everyone needs kindness and love in order to thrive. Another quote from the book says, "If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 Overall, Wonder is a magnificent book. I honestly have no complaints about it. I highly recommend this book to every single person on the planet. This book portrays physical abnormalities in a perspective altering way; the characters are captivating and relatable; and the lessons are imperative, especially in today's world. This book has everything. It will make you laugh and cry. It will cause you to fall in love. It will change your life forever. 
 http://justalili.blogspot.com/2014/10...

'Wonder' is the story of August Pullman. Auggie is different: he was born with severe facial deformities that have resulted in multiple operations, which have often left incredibly sick and have thus meant that he has never attended school, but has been consistently protected by his family, who adore him. Yet for all his difficulties, Auggie is also a sweet, caring and deeply moral young boy. 'Wonder' tells the story of Auggie's struggles during his first year at school not merely through his perspective, but also those around him, who sometimes struggle to accept him, sometimes struggle to befriend him and sometimes can only admire him. 
 One of the most engaging things about this novel was the way in which Palacio told the narrative from a range of perspectives not merely August's so that we could empathise with their points of views and understand their behaviour even when they perhaps made the wrong decision. There was also limited sentimentalisation over his condition: she did not shy away from revealing some of the more disturbing aspects of his condition or simply present everyone as being won over by Auggie's personality. Rather, she seemed to capture the struggles of the middle/ high school student perfectly and the difficulties they all experience in finding themselves and being accepted regardless of their appearance as they negotiate a new world and are forced to grow up, ready or not. Moreover, despite all these difficulties, the novel remained full of humour and was at once emotional and upbeat. It is rare that a book can make you shed a few tears, but this one genuinely did. There is something truly heart warming about 'Wonder'. I would recommend it to anyone who is feeling a little bit down or hard done by. Reading 'Wonder' not only makes you realise how lucky you are, but also how much better you can be.
Started out the book with a lump in my throat. Finished in tears. Yes, it's preachy, yes, it's idealistic, but sometimes kids (and adults) need a reminder to choose to be kinder than is necessary.
Such a 'feel good' book! Loved it.

Wonder is one of those books you know you're going to love. Ever since Jill Mansell and Matt Dunn recommended it it's been on my Amazon Wishlist and i finally got around to getting myself a copy. I read it as soon as it arrived and it blew me away. 
 Auggie Pullman doesn't look like you or me, in fact he doesn't even look at all normal and for this reason alone he's never been to a proper school, until now. Auggie's journey through fifth grade is inspiring and uplifting and the characters who don't judge Auggie make me believe in the wonder of humanity again. 
 I just thought this was a truly amazing book. It made me cry, it made me cheer, it made me want to punch the air in triumph because of how Auggie faces the world. Kids like him are an inspiration and it's a shame the society sees them as outcasts or freaks. This is a book everyone should read; it's a book you can learn a thing or two from and it's just bloody amazing.
I would never be able to find the words that describe how this book affected me, so I won't even try. Just read it.

This book I would give about a 3.5/4 out of 5 stars for the storyline, but for the positive message and increased empathy the book creates towards disfigured/deformed people I give it an undisputed 5/5 stars.

I read this with my daughters, 9 and 11 years old. We couldn't wait to read it together each night. I enjoyed the writing style, including, the point of view switching from chapter to chapter. I adored the quotes at the beginning of each chapter, as well. The book overflows with messages about honest love, fear of differences, kindness, forgiveness. It's definitely a must read for young people navigating friendships, but also for adults, reminding us to open our eyes and hearts.

loved this story. i loved the author's technique of switching narrators and telling auggie's story from the perspective of a variety of characters. the message of the book - be kinder than is necessary - is a good one, and i think that all kids should read this to learn a thing or two about empathy, compassion and kindness. this stop a bit short of what i consider brutal honesty (like the fault in our stars), but given that the story focuses on 5th graders, that makes sense. really beautiful story - definitely will read again.
I finished this book and immediately wanted to start it over again aloud with my daughter.

Remember the movie Mask with Cher and Eric Stoltz? It was based on a true story about a boy with a medical condition (I don't recall what exactly) and he had facial abnormalities. I loved that movie and couldn't help being reminded of it as I read this book. 
 Wonder was excellent and can probably be read in one sitting. As I was reading it, I was keeping in mind that if it was age appropriate, I would like my younger son to read it also. Then something happened in the book (the "Halloween Incident") that almost made we want to stop reading it. I'm glad I didn't! 
 The movie Mask came out in the politically incorrect 1980s and I was a teenager at the time. Even so, this movie had a big impact on me. But as I read Wonder I read it through a completely different lens. I read it as a mom of two young boys. I read it as the mom of a son with a severe developmental disability, with a sibling who will all too soon be navigating through the rough waters of middle school. I read it in 2012 where bullying just doesn't happen in school, but happens everywhere--on Facebook and through texts. I read it in a time where more and more headlines shock us with the fact that young children are taking their own lives as a result of bullying. As a parent this weighs on me, it keeps me up at night. I applaud R.J. Palacio by taking this subject on with finesse. 
 ***mild spoiler below*** 
 Unlike Mask this book had a happy ending, to my relief. It was inspirational and uplifting and I loved it! While my son isn't old enough to read this yet, I will introduce him to this book in the future, as it has a great message. I would recommend it to any preteen, parent, and teacher.
If you are looking to cry, then bawl your eyes dry, then cheer yourself hoarse - this is your book.
This book made me cry. Well done.

I started reading Wonder on a whim over the weekend and couldn't put it down. I'd heard good things about the book for months, and liked the book trailer, but for some reason I kept finding other books to read instead. Even though I do like middle grade books, the subject matter of this one gave me pause. Anyway, the story is so engaging and uplifting, much more so than I had expected. Totally a worthwhile read and I'm so glad I finally read it. 
 10-year-old August Pullman was born with a severe facial abnormality. His parents home schooled him all of his life due to his frequent surgeries and medical appointments. Now, when others August's age are starting middle school, his parents think the time may be right for August to attend school as well. Auggie is a normal kid inside, smart and funny, and loves Star Wars and videogames. But will his new classmates be able to see past his outward appearance? 
 Auggie is so endearing- he won me over from the very first pages. I was so scared for him to start middle school. Middle school is terrifying under the best of circumstances! And even though Auggie has seen reactions of strangers around him all his life, it's hard to prepare yourself for this age group. I, like Auggie, hoped for the best but steeled myself for the worst. His experience has highs and lows and focuses in on a handful of students and teachers and the different ways they interact with Auggie. 
 There are a few kids assigned to keep an eye out for Auggie at school to show him around. Auggie is very perceptive about others and is a good judge of character- he really is a brave little guy. It's interesting to see the world through Auggie's eyes and then later revisit the same scenes through the eyes of his friends when the book shifts to multiple POV. I hadn't expected the book to shift POV actually, but it does satisfy some curiosity by hearing other characters perspective. Two of Auggie's classmates, as well as his sister, her friend, and boyfriend all take a turn at the narration. Auggie's sister Via is a standout character, as she shares the effect her brother has had on her life. 
 Hearing the different reactions to Auggie made me think about who I would be in the scenario, and I'd react in middle school if I had a classmate like him. My daughter and I had a dialogue about it, and you always hope you'd be compassionate, but it's hard to know what is the right way to respond in the moment. The book does a great job of making you think about how to treat people fairly and with compassion. The writing is accessible and has a light touch, even though there are some heavy and distressing scenes. It is just perfect for a middle grade audience, and to read aloud for class discussion or at home. But really I think this uplifting story is appealing for all ages.
Meant for middle schoolers, but a definite must read for everybody in my opinion!!
Jackson and I read this together! We both loved it!

Very good book! Should be a must (along with Mockingbird by K. Erskine)read for middle-schoolers. Teaching our kids to be tolerant and understanding and kind is as important, if not more so, than teaching them math and reading.

Sometimes I roll my eyes when adults try to write kid characters, as they often sound nothing like real children. This book was a shockingly accurate depiction of fifth graders. It was a bit optimistic in the end, but that is just one of the many things I loved about it.

This is the story of what happens to people when they encounter individuals who really know and understand themselves.You just cannot help but be effected. Fifth grader Augustus does not look normal, but he knows that in all the ways that really count, he is just a normal kid. And those who take the time to discover that truth will discover things about themselves as well. 
 This is the book I'll be telling others to read for the rest of the summer, starting with my son.
I related to Auggie in this story with the deformities. Made me realize I was still more fortunate than him. It's an inspiring read for me.

This book will grab your heart and wrench it in about a dozen different ways. I liked the various points of view (sections are told my Auggie, his friends, his sister, and other people who come into his circle), and I also really liked the pace and style of the writing. That being said, I kind of wished for a more adult perspective, which would be counter to the YA nature of this book, but I wanted more details on science and psychology! (Dah, I'm such a nerd!)

What a wonderful, beautiful and moving book. I knew this book would touch me before I read it, but it made me both cry and laugh, and the ending truly warmed my heart. I really believe that everyone should read this book. I'm usually a pretty slow reader, but I flew through this in a day. An undoubtably inspirational story.
Beautiful. A really beautiful and eye opening book
such an easy read but what wonderful simple human concepts explored here.

Excellent book to introduce bullying to teens and preteens. I also like the style of writing from different POV. It add a lot of missing pieces to the story. I think it reflects real life very well. This can also help to understand bullying and peer pressure. We can only see our side of the story. But with an open mind, we can begin to understand the view of other people. But even then, we are limited in our vision. This book introduces this topic very well. The main character has a great sense of humour so he is very likeable by readers. Some of the bullying jokes are actually a little funny, and it feels wrong to laugh at them. It can be useful for teaching students how to react during difficult, realistic situations.

One of the best books I've read in the past year. This is my favorite kind of novel--a kid that I like (even though he has flaws) battling huge obstacles. Auggie is going to regular school for the first time, having been home-schooled up through 4th grade. He has a severe facial deformity, so you can sort of imagine what he's up against. And he faces all of it, not with a fake bravery, but with a vulnerable spirit that makes you want to wave a magic wand and make everything better. But of course you can't. 
 One of the things I really love is that the pov changes throughout the novel. We start with Auggie and get to know him really well, but then the viewpoint changes to his older sister. A range of other kids, both Auggie's age and high school age as well, take their turns as viewpoint characters, which is really cool. In real life, the kid with the difference, the special need, the disease, whatever--that kid gets all the attention (good and bad) in a family, in society. But whatever affects one of us affects everyone close to that person. 
 I think every kid should read this novel, and there aren't many books I feel that way about! I finished it feeling uplifted and inspired, and trusting that most people really are good at heart (yes, it made me feel a bit Anne Frankish). And the people that aren't--the jerks and bullies who just aren't going to change--well, forget them. They will always be there, and they don't deserve your energy.
Everyone needs to read this book. It should be required.
EVERYONE should read this book! EVERYONE.

Well... 
 Me hizo reir, me hizo llorar, tiene absolutamente todo. 
 Always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary.
Great story to teach about difference and acceptance.

At ten, Auggie has already gone through 27 surgeries to partially correct his extreme facial anomalies. He says early in the book: "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." Mainstreamed into a regular classroom for fifth grade, Auggie slowly adjusts to life at his new school and gradually makes some friends. Told from the perspectives of Auggie, classmates and family, the story reveals humans in all their fifth grade (and older) varieties: dumb, funny, bullying, kind, afraid, clique-ish, etc. Numerous details ground the story as Auggie slowly realizes his own need for human connection outside his family and how no one is just the way they look but rather how they act towards others and themselves. An insightful, sometimes painfully honest book which pushes the reader to confront their own prejudices.

Sorry but this book was boring. I know it touches on important topics like inner beauty and just be yourself but it had no plot. It was not an actual story and there was no conflict to get over there was no character development. The writing was decent but it was just a jumble of random short stories. I found myself bored and disappointed with this book.
Amazing, a must read for students, teachers, and parents of children ages 9+
This is literally one of the best books I've ever read, and I'm recommending it to everyone I know.
I loved this too. May it make us all better people.

"MR. BROWNE'S SEPTEMBER PRECEPT: 
 WHEN GIVEN THE CHOICE BETWEEN BEING 
 RIGHT OR BEING KIND, CHOOSE KIND." 
 The first time I opened this book, it was so well-writing. Despite this book is for fifth grade, I'm 21 years old, and I don't care. This book is beautiful, heartwarming, and touching. I'm weeping while reading the part August's parents give him so much strengths. 
 This book taught me to become kind person, you may ugly outside, but you are definitely beautiful inside Auggie Doggie. 
 Best book that I have ever read in 2016!
This is a book that everyone should read, I laughed and cried.

This was definitely a 5/5, and I recommend it to everyone no matter your age or the genres you like, it's just So Good . 
 For those who don't know, Wonder is a book about a kid, August, whose face is "deformed" (though that word is discouraged in the book, it's the best way to describe it to someone who hasn't read it) because of a DNA thing. August doesn't have any disabilities or special needs, he just looks very different. Wonder follows his first year at a normal school, after being homeschooled most of his life. It's told in like 5 different POVs, and you can easily read it in one sitting. 
 I know that whatever I say in my review probably won't do it justice, considering it was the cutest thing I've ever read, really mind-opening and just full of happy feelings, but. I'll try. 
 The first thing I liked about this book was the writing style: R.J. Palacio writes in such a light and easy way, and the book is full (and I mean literally Full) of Star Wars references, which I really liked. You could also tell that the author is a David Bowie fan, as we see that August has an ongoing inside thing with Miranda where she calls him "Major Tom" and they listen to Space Oddity together, and Palacio kept using Bowie quotes wherever it was fitting (which made me really happy). Just, yes. Thank you. Plus, the chapters were really really short, and that made the book so fast-paced and impossible to get bored of since it was constantly changing. 
 Then, obviously, the story. It was so innocent and heart-warming and it made me cry (for like, 20 pages in a row). Especially one of the last scenes, the graduation award ceremony, oh my god. 
 "'He is the greatest'", he finally continued, "'whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own.' Without further ado, this year I am very proud to award the Henry Ward Beecher medal to the student whose quiet strength has carried up the most hearts. 
 "So will August Pullman please come up here to receive this award?" 
 MAANNN. August gets up to receive an award for bravery and strength while all his friends, teachers, classmates, classmates' parents, are clapping and smiling really big and standing up for him, and it's just the cutest scene in any book ever, because in a previous chapter August had said: "I imagined how cool it would be to be Via and Justin right then, having all these people standing up and cheering for them. I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." , and in that moment he actually gets his own standing ovation, everyone in the crowd crying (me included, okay). Just: 
 And as I walked up the steps to the stage, the most amazing thing happened: everyone started standing up. Not just the front rows, but the whole audience suddenly got up on their feet, whooping, hollering, clapping like crazy. It was a standing ovation. For me. 
 Oh damn oh damn ! Oh Dang! I can't stand things that soft and that cute because Too Many Feelings. It was great. August describes how he had the Star Wars song playing in his head, the one that was playing in A New Hope when Luke, Han & Chewie come back from destroying the Death Star, and this makes me too happy. I should stop, cause if I don't do now I don't know when I will. 
 But please, please read this if you haven't already. :)
L'unica ragione per cui non sono normale e perche nessuno mi considera normale

EVERYONE SHOULD READ THIS BOOK!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! 
 and yes, I know I just shouted, but it is a shoutable book!

My ten-year-old granddaughter recommended this book to me because she enjoyed it so much. It is a touching story about a boy with a disfigured face who is attending a public school for the first time, and middle school at that. Middle schoolers can be tough on each other because they are trying to figure out who they are. This book has a great message about being kind to others, and the message is for all of us, not just kids.

Son les memories d'un adolescent que va neixer amb la cara deformada. Explica com s'adapta a una societat que el rebutja. Les seves fortaleses (i les del llibre) son: 
 - Que te una familia que se l'estima 
 - Que ha apres a trobar amics i a construir el seu caracter en un mon ple de dificultats. 
 - Que encara que no ho sembli, hi ha mes persones bones que dolentes. 
 Coses que m'han agradat especialment: 
 - El paper del director a l'institut i la feina del seu professor amb EL PRECEPTE DEL MES (P. 368) 
 - L'exposicio d'objectes egipcis (tot a les fosques) i la de ciencies naturals 
 - L'obra de teatre. Un centre educatiu fantastic.
A beautiful story.

This story made me so happy. Auggie is such a wonderful main character, but I also LOVED the side characters just as much. There were heartbreaking moments, but also moments that made my heart swell :)

Este libro lo tiene todo, recomendable para todo el mundo realmente. Te deja otro punto de vista y te hace reflexionar ante muchas cosas, osea, al menos yo trate de asociarlo siempre con cosas que me pasan a mi o que eh echo y vi esas situaciones desde otro punto de vista !Maravilloso! Me encanto.

the audiobook is terrible with the narrator trying to make child's voice.

Wonderful book. Auggie breaks and warms your heart all at the same time. I loved this book!
I think everyone should read this book once in ther lifes, because everyone deserves a marvelous and wonderful story like this.

Another "children's book" but very much worth reading. It's a thought-provoking, heartwarming, unflinching story of a severely physically deformed child as he goes to school for the first time aged 10. We see the challenges he faces but also the difficulties of others ~ his friends, teenage sister, teachers and parents.

*NO SPOILERS* 
 Wonder is a story about a young boy,named August,preparing for his first day of 5th grade. But WONDER is no ordinary kid, he was born with facial deformity,its just a face, but will he be able to show is new classmates that he is just like them from the inside. 
 WONDER is one of my favorite books of 2013, if you read, you will find it quiet inspiring and might need to keep a tissue box on hand.

My sister gave me this book for Christmas and I couldn't put it down. Captivating story about a young boy going to school for the first time with his peers and you quickly learn that he doesn't look like everyone else. It opens up your heart and mind to new ideas and outlooks.
This is a delightful, touching book. I think everyone should read this book. Heartbreaking and heartwarming at the same time.

Wonder tells a wonderful heartwarming story. 
 It is very easy to connect to endearing August (mc), after all we've all been bullied or cast aside at one point in our life. So we know how it feels, we can very well imagine how August must feel, and yet we rarely see him weep in his room. It is uplifting to read a book about a brave boy who is and manages to remain sympathetic and positive despite everything he has to endure. 
 The story is told from different perspectives, thus offering an insight what each of these characters was feeling and it wasn't all roses for them either. There was a lesson there: no matter how bad you're off, don't feel sorry for yourself, because someone else might be happy to trade places with you. All the bad things that happen in life, sometimes make us blind for all the good things we still have. 
 The only thing I didn't like at all was the far too perfect ending. Everything is neatly solved and tucked away in a sweet and saccharine way that left me with the need to brush my teeth. Nothing wrong with that, but it is incongruous with the rest of the story. For the most part the characters and most events seemed genuine, realistic even, the good, the sad and the bad. The ending however, is pure phantasy. Maybe life is that perfect somewhere, but I have never seen it happen. Kindness does not magically overrule it all, the power of bigotry, prejudice and plain old meanness is always a force to be reckoned with. Unfortunately. And to just sweep it under the rug in oder to end the book on a positive note, is a bit too simple.
Auggie wants to go to school like a normal kid, but his face is anything but normal. (USA)
Simply beautiful! Finished it in 6 hours. Review to come.

Wow! Que hermoso libro, me encanto de principio a fin. Como bien expuso Nicholas Sparks- parece que las paginas pasasen solas.... Aprendi tanto junto a August, sus amigos y familia. Hay tanto sentimiento, tantas frases, tantas experiencias, puntos de vista y como bien dice el titulo tantas lecciones.... Ame profundamente este libro, lo recomiendo muchisimo. "El mas grande es aquel cuya fuerza conquista mas corazones con la atraccion del suyo propio".

There are a great many thoughtful and well-written reviews here that say quite well what I would struggle to say about this book. So, I'll let them stand as they are. Instead, a warning: if you are a cryer, especially a sobby, blotchy, nose-running cryer like me, don't read this book in public. Or do. But don't say I didn't warn you.

everyone should read this book. it's short, it's sweet and it's one of those books that just teaches us about what it means to be human...what is humanity and how the most basic thing is to treat each other with kindness. 
 the book is about August who is NOT deformed and doesn't have special needs but he has this genetic thing and he had a cleft plate and basically lots of problems with his face which means he is 'ugly' or looks like a 'zombie' as his features are not where they should be eg his eyes are lower and his ears are tiny and not properly formed etc. 
 so anyways when people see august they cry out in horror or stare in shock or look away quickly. he is used to it. 
 this has made life hard for august and his family because whenever they go out or whatever people stare and whisper etc 
 so august is 10 and has been home schooled but his parents think it might be time for proper school. not a special school just a normal school. august isn't so pleased but soon he find she loves school and he starts making friends even though most of the school hate him and it took a few months for everyone to get used to his face etc. 
 i mean imagine a 10yr old boy having to cope with this? his whole life? like he just sees himself as ordinary, yes he hates his face but he can joke about himself and he is a funny, intelligent little kid and so lovely and THAT is what makes him who he is. 
 i love how the book is written from different perspectives so it's mostly from August's POV but also his sister Olivia and his friend Jack and then some other people and i love books like that because there is no one side to a story. and also shows how August touches everyone's lives and also not just about August but how other people have to deal with it as well. 
 i mean imagine hearing someone say that 'if i looked like him i'd kill myself'. :| 
 people can be so mean. especially kids. sometimes they mean it and other times they don't but it still hurts. 
 and having people pity you and treat you differently etc. august just wants to be a normal kid. but yeah sometimes he does act baby-ish etc but school has been good for him. 
 anyways i just love this book. it's quite funny and just makes you think about how grateful you should be for not having to deal with anything like that UNLESS you do...like you are in a wheelchair or you don't have an arm or whatever it is. it's not easy having people stare at you and pity you. 
 anyways i love the whole precepts thing. 
 and my fave thing was when mr tushman said 'always try to be a little kinder than necessary' - J.M.Barrie which is just beautiful. 
 so yeah read this book, it's not long and it will change your perspective on things and it's just beautiful. and i may or may not have teared up a few times. but then laughed. 
 Happy Reading! =D

I absolutely love this book from start to finish. It was amazing to see Auggies point of view, with him starting school and his encounter with bullying. He continues to live life to the fullest and doesn't let his syndrome stop him from doing what he loves.

I went into this book with high expectations, and Wonder met them. I absolutely wasn't expecting the different POVs, but they were merged so well, that I didn't really mind. The only thing I had a problem with was Justin's POV. It didn't have correct grammar (the first letter in a sentence was never capitalized, and there were no quotes around dialogue, etc.) and I never understood why. Was it clarified and I just skipped it over? 
 Either way, this is a phenomenal coming-of-age novel. Due to the fact that it's almost midnight, I shall leave it to this puny review to tell you to read the book.

A heart wrenching story told with compassion and warmth. The different viewpoints add poignancy and allow the reader to empathise not only with the title character, but with all of those who are important in his life. A three handkerchief conclusion.

This is one of those books that, like Out of My Mind, allows kids a glimpse into the inner life of someone who seems very different from themselves - a window into a different experience based on physical appearances. The perspective shifts between several characters, which felt very effective and allowed the story to be about both August's own experiences and the way other kids and teens interact with him. The writing is straightforward but the style still feels lovely, somehow. 
 There was one plot element that spoiled the potential emotional resonance of the story. At the graduation ceremony, when the principal is about to give out the special Beecher award, I knew what was coming and began cringing. As I read the story, there were many things I felt that other kids learned from being around Auggie, but he never struck me as a lesson in kindness. Perhaps his presence encouraged the other kids to learn to be kinder? But Auggie himself never exemplified the spirit of kindness. He was just being a normal kid. And giving him an award for kindness completely detracts from that aspect of the book and undermines what I thought was the primary theme of the story. That issue aside, I thought the story and characters were well-constructed and I enjoyed reading it. 
 Source: my public library

 (Update 34 minutes later) I am editing the review section to add few things. I thought I would jump into another book right away. But, it doesn't feel I can do it right now. This book is a tearjerker and I have a stuffy nose right now.

I can only come up with one word to describe this book: 
 "Wonderful."

I first heard about Wonder by R.J. Palacio while listening to NPR; it was the September selection for the NPR Backseat book club which is a book club for young readers. I was immediately taken with the story's premise and then really loved the author interview. I also really enjoyed the passages of the book being read by fifth graders. Even though we did not select it for our book club, I was excited to read it and LOVED the characters and the story. 
 Besides Auggie, my favorite character is Summer. She is warm, funny, and kind. The book captures the complexity of middle school really well; in particular, the struggle to fit in while doing right by your fellow humans. Many of the scenes made me cry; I was especially moved by the lunch room image of Auggie sitting by himself. I was brought back to the anxiety and worry of having someone to sit with at lunch. I also keep thinking about the emperor's guard chapter which makes me want to high-five humanity. I did love Auggie's voice, but I was glad that we got to have the perspective of other characters as well.
Wonderful! You cry, you laugh, you learn, and you love.

I think I underestimated this book. Since I had to read it for my Children's Resources course, I was expecting to feel "meh" about reading it. Y'know, since no one likes to have to read for school -- even those of us who love to read, like I do. 
 And yet I ended up loving this book. 
 This is the story of August Pullman, a boy born with a cleft palate, among many other facial issues. He's been homeschooled up until fifth grade, when his parents decide to enroll him in Beecher Prep for middle school. 
 I think I was also wary of this book because stories about characters with disabilities or sicknesses or what have you tend to do one of two things: 1) use the character's problem as a device to manipulate the reader's emotions (rather than making it a part of the character's identity), thus coming off as almost romanticized in a warped way (in my opinion, this is what stuff like The Fault in Our Stars and Me Before You are guilty of), or 2) become cliche, completely lack in creativity, and horribly misrepresent those with the disability/sickness/what have you. 
 But Wonder doesn't do that. It is clear that Palacio did her research on these types of physical issues and that she learned what it is like, not just for the person born with the problem, but for their family, friends, and even total strangers around them. What I loved about this book was Palacio's skill at exploring this topic from multiple and diverse viewpoints, from Auggie himself to the sister's boyfriend Justin. Each of these characters had distinct voices; Palacio is a very skilled writer of characters. 
 I was going to give the book five stars. However, the very last section of the acknowledgments made me take a star off. Palacio apparently based the story off of a real-life encounter at an ice cream stand with a little GIRL who was born like Auggie. Or at least that is the impression I got. Which made me question two things: why did she make Auggie a boy, and not a girl? And why did Palacio use only her first two initials for her name on the front cover? 
 For the same reason J.K. Rowling uses hers, of course: perhaps the publishers told her they wanted this book to appeal to boys and girls. Because "boys don't read books about girls." Right? 
 This maybe isn't the fault of Palacio herself, but rather the industry and our society as a whole. But still, it was disappointing to read about that encounter, and made me wonder how much different and how much more impactful the story could have been were August instead named Augusta. There are even more issues of gender expectations that could have been explored. But, oh well.
What a delightful, heartwarming story about growing up and learning the power of everyday courage, empathy and kindness. A fast read, this is one I'd recommend to readers of all levels!
great, funny and touching

CAUTION: Read with tissues close at hand. "The universe has not been kind to August Pullman" but fortunately, Auggie doesn't need the kindness of the universe. Auggie's story takes the reader through the full range of reasons to cry: anger, sadness, joy, mourning, relief, fear... It is full of life's lessons. Lessons for parents, teachers, administrators, siblings, friends, and students.

Excellent book about what it means to be different, how to accept these differences in ourselves and others, and how to love life even if you don't "fit in". I originally got this book for my son to read and ended up reading it myself. It took me back to my middle school days when everyone was growing, changing, and just beginning to discover who they are. This is a great book for readers of any age, young and old alike. I give it 4 out of 5 stars.

A heart-warming story about the journey 10-year-old August Pullman takes from home schooling into fifth grade at a private NYC middle school, and the even more significant journey he takes towards greater self- and societal acceptance. You see, "Auggie," as he's known to family and friends was born with severe facial deformities, and the intensity of surgeries he experienced made home schooling a better choice to this point. But now, his parents and he have decided it's time to learn how to face the world (no pun intended) outside the bubble of family, house and safety. 
 You can rightly predict what will happen next: some meanies and bullies, some nice people who see Auggie's deeper worth, some imperfect human characters who start out nice but have mean moments (and vice versa). Luckily, what could be a cloying ABC Afterschool Special of a novel is saved by the vibrancy of Auggie's narrative voice. Unfortunately, Palacio chooses to shift POV voices throughout the book, resulting in a string of narrators that are insufficiently distinct from one another (with the exception of Auggie's older sister's emo-e.e. cummings boyfriend) and whose internal monologues don't add enough fresh perspective to the story. 
 So: enjoyable, charming, but not a home run.

This book is a gem,and should be required reading in school. 
 This is a book about August who was born with severe facial deformities. Deformities so severe, that there was doubt that he would survive when he was born. He had a plethora of surgeries to repair his deformities so that the things we take for granted,like chewing,would become easier. 
 He was bright and homeschool by his Mother up until 5/6 grade when his parents decided he should go to private school with children his own age. 
 This book is about an extraordinary family, a lionhearted child and a wonderful,supportive cast . 
 Of course,there are bumps along the way and a bully or two,but overall this was a feel good little book. 
 Would highly recommend.

Every kid ages 7-100 should read it. Will definitely add it to the list to read with my children in the coming months. What it is like to have your hardest and most embarrassing challenge be all over your face? This story from the perspective of a boy with severe facial abnormalities and the perspective of some those close to him provides fantastic thoughtful discussion. 
 For children: what sort of person do you want to be? The kind that tears others down, or someone who is kind even when it's hard? 
 For adults: how can we teach kindness to our kids when dealing with others who have obvious and less obvious special needs? How can we teach compassion? 
 This funny, sweet story gets the juices flowing.
This is simply one of those books that make you a better person.

I loved this book. It wouldn't normally be what I would pick up in the bookstore, but I read it in class for a novel study....holy moly, great book. 
 I felt like I could really connect to Auggie. He isn't a typical character who has a facial abnormality. He is a funny, kind boy. I thought this book made me realize the different types of people out there. Maybe there are people like Auggie out there. When Auggie described his feelings, I felt like I was the and experiencing everything through his eyes. 
 The different view points were really interesting. I liked the many p.o.v's. I'm sure that my fellow classmates did as well. I really liked the kids who stuck by Auggie. I admire them. 
 The other thing too, the short chapters, they were really easy to read. So, if you hate long chapters, this book is for you. 
 I can't really say more, I don't want to give it all away, so, I recommend this book to you all!

This was a decent read, although the first half is significantly better than the second. Palacio does a good job of setting the scene and really allowing you to feel like you're part of the characters' lives. In the first section, where we get to know Auggie, I was really drawn in. So much so that I was initially disappointed when the perspective switched to Via's... although that ended up being my favourite part of the book. It felt so authentic! 
 And therein lies my main issue with 'Wonder': the authenticity. While the first half felt very real, the ending was too perfect. Everything comes together in a tidy manner, out heroes are happy and the 'bad guy' leaves. Case closed. But life isn't really like that and writing it into a book that is otherwise so good is disappointing. 
 That said, I generally enjoyed this book. It was a quick, mostly engaging read with a lovely central message: Choose kindness. I wouldn't read it again, but I would recommend it to friends looking for a quick, sometimes emotionally moving read.
[?][?] this is one of best book I've ever read !
I admit I cried at some moments. Auggie is a very inpirational kidl! He didn't backed down even though people are mean, cruel and judgmental. Everyone should read this book.

I immediately fell in love with this book! You root for August (Auggie). He left a lasting impression on me... I wanted this book to go on forever! Wonder is a rare gem! Do yourself a favor and read it!
A good story with a great message. I liked the different perspectives given from those in August's life. A must read for younger kids to teach empathy and understanding.

Great book. I love the whole purpose of the book and teaching everyone to be unnecessarily kind. It was a cute story

I love this book! I saw some of my friends read it but I never got the chance to read it myself and I'm glad I did! August Pullman has been looked and stared at all his life. I especially appreciated it as a genetic counselor, as the protagonist is a fifth grade boy with craniofacial abnormalities who is going to public school for the first time. Wonderful story, quick read, written for a young audience, centering on kindness and courage and originality. Would be great to read with your kids.

Absolutely phenomenal. A must read for anyone who works with kids. Also, a must read in any intermediate classroom. I know that I'll plan on reading it aloud with my 4th graders this year, though I know I'll be weeping in several key scenes. Haven't figured out how I'll handle that. 
 August (Augie), his family, and his schoolmates teach us so much about kindness and humanity.

La leccion de August es un libro que no te deja indiferente, no solo por el tema que trata - las apariencias fisicas, los defectos y las deformidades - sino porque se queda dentro de ti mucho despues de que hayas acabado el libro. 
 Desgraciadamente cuando conocemos a una persona lo primero que vemos es su aspecto fisico, su cara, su cuerpo, no su personalidad. Y nos quedamos con eso: si nos gusta el aspecto fisico le damos una oportunidad a esa persona, y si no, nos limitamos a quedarnos en el exterior. Juzgamos a una persona por su aspecto fisico y creemos conocer todo de esa persona por como es, por la organizacion de sus rasgos, por su forma de hablar, de reir, de caminar, de vestir... 
 Pero no es asi. Una persona es muchisimo mas que el cuerpo que tiene, y eso es lo que nos ensena este libro. 
 Resena completa en mi blog

August, who was born with a severe facial defect, goes to school for the first time and deals with the social aspect of being born different. 
 I really enjoyed this book. It was well-told and even got a tear to trickle out of my eye at one point. However, I thought some of the points-of-view were unnecessary, and the ending was quite long and teetered on boring.

i am going to be kind and rate it as a middle grader. every middle grader should read it. 
 but.... for all the talk of kindness and overcoming difficulty, i was most struck by the described horrors of middle school in america and the underlying apparent acceptance that people are essentially jerks, and only rise to the challenge when some underdog represents a challenge. what a depressing premise, not made better by the meddling of class and money. everyone seems to be in a box, from jocks to brainiacs to deformed, and that seems to have "always been like that". instead of teaching kids and adults to break the boxes for some real advancement, all characters in this book conform to "the rules", but sometimes, all just comes together in just the right way for something remarkable to happen *skies opening, angels singing*. 
 best quote: it is not enough to be friendly, you have to be a friend.
read it NOW

This book was touching and heartwarming. The only reason I didn't give it any more stars is because I didn't like how the story was developed and even though the story was amazing I felt like with the main character there wasn't much character growth that wasn't because of the conflict in the story. I understand that was what the story was about but the plot didn't progress. In the beginning of the book, there was people mean to the main character and there still was and would be at the end. In the book, it was more like a documentary about kids with this disease and how to live with it, not how to stop bullying and things like that.
This should be required reading for all pre-teens. So many warm fuzzies.
Should be required reading for every educator and every student.
This book was really touching. It even made me cry at the end, but in a good way. I loved the characters, the dialogue, the simplicity of the story - everything. I just plain loved it!

This book was so enjoyable. The more I think about it, the more I like it. And there's a lot to think about. 
 I had two book club discussions on this and it didn't get stale. 
 Yes, the ending was a bit much. Yes, a couple characters were flat (particularly the dad, who could have been plucked out of any middle-grade book), but it was much more nuanced than I expected. 
 The best part of the book was that, unlike some books of its type, it didn't try to "shame the reader" for not having been more sensitive in the past. 
 Great book. I cried like eight times. If you're a sap like me, you might want to grab a hankie.

-- 5 stars -- 
 Such an incredible story!

Initial reaction but may add more later: 
 This book is beautiful, uplifting and a little heartbreaking all at once. It's a quick and easy read, but a worthwhile one. The story of Auggie Pullman not only impacts the lives of those around him but those who read this book as well. After all, wouldn't the world be a better place if we were all kinder than is necessary?

1 children's audiobook (chapter book) from ALSC Notable Recordings 2010-2012 
 Palacio, R J, Nick Podehl, Kate Rudd, and Diana Steele. Wonder. Grand Haven, MI: Brilliance Audio, 2011. Sound recording. 
 August Pullman is called Auggie for short by his friends and supportive family and Zombie Kid by the kids in fifth grade at his new school. However, not all of the fifth graders call him that. Jack and Summer, Auggie's only two friends refuse to take part in the atrocious treatment Auggie receives from his classmates. Due to birth defects and rare medical conditions August has immense facial deformities, causing the kids at school to refuse to touch Auggie for fear of "The Plague". Auggie is unsure how to deal with the typical ways in which children interact with each other as he has been home-schooled for his entire life. He soon experiences the harsh realities of middle school as an outcast, such as betrayal, fake friendships, and the joys of finding someone to spend lunch periods with. Auggie's sister Via is also experiencing a new reality as she begins her first year in high school. She recognizes that her family's lives must revolve around her younger brother's needs, but has problems and new experiences of her own with old friend Miranda and new boyfriend Justin. Read by a cast representing the voices of August, Via, Summer, Jack, Justin, and Miranda this audiobook is a thoughtful examination of the way human beings treat one another. Readers have the opportunity to learn how to empathize. In order for young readers to grasp the text completely, a reader's guide was put together to identify objects, famous people, and songs referenced in the book:http://www.helpreaderslovereading.com....
This book was sad, wonderful and inspiring all at once. It made me want to be a better person.

This is the story of August. He is 10 ten years old, has never been to "real" school, (homeschooled) and has a rare and seriously deformed face, but one incredibly big heart. This is his story about how he had to go to school for the first time and face the world, and its middle school! 
 "My name is August, by the way, I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 I fell in love with August the first time he spoke until the end of his story. This book is beautifully told through the eyes of different people, through August, his friends and most touching and heartbreakingly so by his older sister, Olivia. There are so many gems in this book and teaching moments that truly stick with you. I hope this is true for the younger kids who will read it. This is a book that everyone should try, it may bring back some of that lost compassion we sometimes forget about as adults. 
 I had many emotive moments during the audio and also had some big smiles along the way. I can only say this is truely a wonder and it would be a gift for anyone to read it. 
 "when given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind". Dr. Wayne dyer
This is one of my favorite books I've read so far! I thought auggie was so cute and was so optimistic!

Oh Auggie, I love you. 
 This book has my heart. 
 Couldn't out down. 
 Loved the quote and speech by the principal 
 At the graduation and the award Auggie got. 
 Everything about each character was perfect.

Absolutely one of the best books I have ever read, and I read a lot. 
 The characters are very real and the scenario is very typical of middle school culture. You will recognize kids you went to school with. 
 Auggie, through the lottery of genetics, has been born with facial deformities that cause people to look away. Even though he has endured multiple surgeries, he does not look "normal" on the outside, but on the inside, he is quite a "normal" boy. He has always been home schooled, but when he reaches middle school age, his parents feel he should enter school and learn to deal with society's various reactions to him. 
 And the reactions are varied, running the gamut from horror to bullying, acceptance to love. 
 This book makes the reader confront the question of what makes a person who they are, and accepting others for more than the superficial. 
 This book will make you cry, get a bit angry, and ultimately, stand and cheer for Auggie and his friends.

What a great roundabout way to get your kids to understand how to be kind. I appreciate that it is told from multiple viewpoints and that not all of those viewpoints are without flaw. When I have a child I think this would be a great book on tape for a car trip that we can use to talk about what happens at school and help them decide their place in the social hierarchy.

I loved this. It was sweet and sad and funny-my favorite combination. 
 Auggie Pullman was born with significant craniofacial abnormalites that, despite multiple surgeries, have left him with a face that startles even the kindest of adults. In 5th grade his parents decide it's time for him to stop being homeschooled. 
 The author does a great job of presenting Auggie's story without turning him into some cliched martyr. She does such a good job of capturing the daily heartache a kid like Auggie faces-the fact that even when people aren't trying to be mean-their looks of shock still hurt. The book is filled with ordinary kids who display extraordinary courage.

Amazing. I mean, AMAZING. 
 Everyone who can read should take the time to experience this wonder of a book. 
 Teachers and parents, take special note. WONDER is an incredible opportunity to make kids think and get them talking. 
 Okay, now, go and buy it already!
A charming book which I very much enjoyed despite the difficult subject matter.

"my head swirls on this, but then softer thoughts soothe, like a flatted third on a major chord. no, no, it's not all random, if it really was all random, the universe would abandon us completely. and the universe doesn't. it takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see. like with parents who adore you blindly. and a big sister who feels guilty for being human over you. and a little gravelly-voiced kid whose friends have left him over you. and even a pink-haired girl who carries your picture in her wallet. maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. the universe takes care of all its birds." 
 This book is about courage, kindness, love, family, forgiveness, and friendship. I cry and laugh and cry again until the end of the book. It actually deserve 5 plus stars. 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind."

My daughter was so enamored by this book that I decided to read it, too. I'm so glad I did. This is a terrific book for kids. Complete with a good message and lovable characters, Palacio's story will have kids staying up past bedtime to read. The book far exceeded my expectations.

I found this book heartwarming and uplifting as well as sad and tearful. With amazing character development and a story of friendship and family that addresses the ideas of courage and struggle, this book was definitely a deep and touching story. I really enjoyed it, however for some reason it took me quite a while to read for a short book but I would reccomend Wonder to all ages and to people who are looking for a unique and beautiful contemporary story.
