REALLY AMAZING!!! This book makes me cry and laugH, Its WONDERful :)

I wasn't quite sure about this book. As I got into the story, it showed me what happens when a person who is deformed at birth (if this is the word to use) and how people react to that person. 
 August is a young boy who has a deformed face. I like that he doesn't come out and tell you what he looks like but as you read, you learn about him. He is an intelligent and caring boy, and as he enters middle school (he has been home-schooled), he knows what reactions all the kids will have of him. There are a few that work through his deformity and find out what kind of person he is underneath. By the end of the book he becomes a hero of sorts. 
 This is a wonderful book and I think most kids would learn about people and feelings. I would recommend this to all kids and adults alike.
This book made me cry. It was so moving.It had a lot of great sentences and referrals.This book is perfect for all ages.
Amazing book! Everyone should read it. Absolutely changes the way you see persons like auggie
So good!!! It's what my early tween stages were craving

A young boy named August Pullman has a facial deformity. His parents had always homeschooled him, until recently when they decided that he had to be a "normal boy" and go to a regular school. But with his face condition, how can he ever be treated like a normal boy? How would he even be treated? 
 In her first novel, Palacio has written a wonderful story, a "modern classic". In the first couple of pages, as we start to get to know our main character the story might seem to be a bit boring. But as you keep reading you will grow to love "Auggie" and sympathize with his struggle of wanting to be treated like a normal kid, apart from the fact of the way that his face looks. 
 As you read you will not only be seeing things from August's point of view but you will also see them from the people surrounding him. As if telling a story from a first persons point of view isn't hard enough, the author changes between the mind of Augustus and other characters, related to him, to aid her in her storytelling. By doing so she helps us, not only to understand the reactions of the characters but as well as their emotions and thoughts. By changing to points of views from different characters and reading how they feel I, myself, couldn't help but engage on how real their emotions felt. 
 It was a surprisingly heartwarming story. Very well written, fast and easy to read. If you are in the mood for something nice and easy to read I would definitely recommend this book to you. And if you are going to read it, make sure that as you get closer to the ending you have a box of tissues near you, because it's beauty will most certainly touch your heart.
3 a 3.5 ster: Bijzonder, maar toch ''gewoon'' (zoals Augustus zou willen!) vermakelijk

One of the best books I've ever read. The author captured how it feels to look different and how it can affect a person in life. I loved the part where the main character is no longer known by his looks, but by his actions! As one who "looks different" I really appreciated the author writing such an insightful book for young adults. Empathy is the greatest skill we can give our children/young adults.
wow. this book perfectly captures something that i think should be captured more often. more realistic then most books today, and it certainly brings things in to perspective.
A must read!!!!
Excellent story! It was a great listen. Bullying themes, sticking up for your friends, being yourself

I read this book as a part of a book club I started. 
 I have learned that I should not have a book club. For one thing, I'm currently reading at least 20 books. If my mind isn't as sharp as it is, Auggie would be a racist cyborg demigod mockingjay who lives in Germany during WWII and his life drastically changes when he finds a dragon egg in the woods and discovers that he's gay. 
 For another thing, I'm just terrible. I am such a punctual person when it comes to most things, but I deliberately do not get my reading done when I'm supposed to just because I CAN. We're currently reading The Hobbit, I'm 80 pages behind, and I've just been getting by by making comments like "The plot . . . am I right?" 
 My point is, the tables drastically turned when I was reading this one for the book club. I finished the book weeks ahead of schedule, I was punctual, and I didn't dread picking this book up. I had problems with it, but no book is perfect. I overlooked the flaws and found myself stupid in love with this book, and I'm pretty damn proud.
This is an amazing book! I'm all for the movement it inspired, Choose Kind.
Everyone should read this book . . . old and young alike!
This one gets my vote for 2013 Newbery! Wonder is a wonderful, hopeful, feel good book! A must read.

Desde "Harry Potter y la piedra filosofal" no habia leido un libro tan encantador. Ideal para todas las edades. 
 Una historia maravillosa, llena de frases inspiradoras que valen mucho la pena leer. 
 Puedo entender perfectamente la alegria de convivir y trabajar con un nino especial. Sin duda alguna todos merecen sentir la emocion de ver la transformacion de aquellos que pudieramos llamar los mas "debiles".

I'm not sure if I was just going through an emotional phase when I read this one but I loved it. I love how Auggie seemed totally gullible at the start of the book but then how he overcame his fear of what others thought about him and was able to form good friendships. 
 I love how the story was written through different point of views. It allowed the readers to feel more of what each character is going through. I thought it makes the story more poignant because you see each one's struggle to maintain 'normalcy' in an otherwise unique situation brought about by the main character's condition.
Amazing book! I would recommend this book to anyone!

In the past, his facial deformity prevented him from attending mainstream school, but now August Pullman can finally start 5th grade, but can he really convince his fellow classmates he is an ordinary kid, despite appearances? A story of how hard school can be, through the eyes of a young boy and his family and friends. 
 What first drew my interest was that it revolved around disability/deformity, a challenging thing to address. Secondly, that it would pay attention to a student starting school altogether -- where even starting a new school, like primary or secondary, even college, can be a stressful milestone -- and what sort of influence that can have over a child or teenager. This was something I could relate to on a personal level, and along with the original concept, looked forward to where this story would go. 
 Upon first reading this quote, expectations shot through the roof. A very true statement, in a sense, though the need to protect might not necessarily depend on how a person looks, rather just an instinctual thing between siblings. It did hold promise of future conflict, despite the fairly simple start. Unfortunately, not much excitement nor tension came to light -- a story revolving around the simplicity of school life isn't bad; in fact, it is a favourite setting of mine, but must be supported by strong conflict. Wonder had conflict, but sadly weakened with childish behaviour from classmates, which had that element of bullying been expanded on further, may have kept my attention until the end. For the point of view changes, though I have nothing against them, if not done well or suit the story, they can really dwindle the story or message the book is trying to make. 
 The style did not make up for the lack of conflict, with unclear direction and a dialogue that seemed too juvenile for a ten and/or eleven year old. As was the theme of this book. Where disability was the main subject matter, and was shown, again it wasn't strong. Age might be the key here, in that perhaps children would not take it so seriously, but if that were so, it did not show that careful power and impact that a book about disability I would assume to have. 
 All characters were hard to connect with; they did not possess a strong personality, besides Via's need to protect and temper when it came to dealing with those bullies. 
 It was sad to put this book down after only a hundred pages, when seeing so much potential before. I take my hat off to Palacio for attempting to write about a sensitive subject; some might think it did a good job of it, however I did not. I, personally, would not recommend it, but then again it is something different to try.

'When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind'. This is one of the precepts provided to the reader of WONDER, a novel by P.J. Palacio. The book is full of wonderful messages and insights into the struggles of August Pullman, a 5th grade boy who has a rare craniofacial deformity. It's a book of empathy and compassion intertwined with the realities of the world. As a counselor who works with children, I think it's a wonderful book for students who find themselves struggling with acceptance and for those who feel misunderstood. Beyond that, it's a novel that should be read by all students as it challenges each child to find within themselves the ability to be kind and compassionate in the face of differences. 
 Because WONDER is really a children's novel, I gave it three stars based on the writing style. Really, that kind of criteria for rating isn't fair as I'm judging a children's book based on adult tastes. However, if I were to rate the book based on the message alone, I would give it five stars. Consider the following excerpt from the book that speaks to the theme and message of WONDER: "...I came upon a passage that Henry Ward Beecher (the nineteenth century abolitionist and defender of human rights) wrote that seemed particularly consistent with the themes I've been ruminating upon all year long. Not just the nature of kindness, but the nature of one's kindness. The power of one's friendship. The test of one's character. The strength of one's courage. Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness." 
 Every school should have this book on their reading list. Children would be made to expand their understanding through the thought-provoking precepts and messages provided throughout the novel. Bravo to P.J. Palacio for writing a book worthy of our children and our expectations for them regarding their character.
Un libro emotivo, muy bonito y con mensajes y frases dignas de recordar. me encanto.
4 Words: This. Book. Is. Wonderful.

A page turner. Loved it. 
 I love, love, love books that features several different points of views from several different characters. It allows you to understand how each character is feeling, and you learn about the characters more that way. 
 I love how this book is fictitious, yet brings a sense of realism to the reader, and it really teaches you about what kindness is really like. Just because you are different like Auggie, it doesn't mean you can't be accepted. This book is inspiring.

Es un muy hermoso libro que te hace reflexionar, valorar la vida y modifica tu modo de ver a las personas, es una lectura ligera y sencilla pero una historia que te llega al corazon, nos hace ver lo crueles que aveces llegamos a ser ya sea intencional o no, en definitiva Agust tiene la capacidad de ganarse el carino de aquellos que lo rodean al igual que el del lector.
tear-jerker. recommended for kids in school to learn about emphatic, friendship, loyalty, and the most important thing; KINDNESS.

This book didn't seem to pull any punches and addressed a tough issue, facial anomaly. I loved the way chapters were written from different character's perspectives and no one was perfect. Good tie ins for discussion: bullying, genetics, friendship, image, normality

I read this book with my daughter who is nine. So many really great lessons are found inside the pages of this book. From the POV of one little boy who is struggling to fit into a world where he is very uniquely different to the POV's of those important to him; this book is a well rounded look at attitude, love, and discovering what is important in life.

This book was simply AMAZING! I loved the characters and the plot. It was so well done and, even though the story was kind of a sad one, this book still managed to make you smile. It was an amazing story and I loved this book so much,

Loved it <3 
 It was such a short and light read. We get to know this story from multiple point of views which manages to keep it interesting. The protagonist, August, was a very nicely created character with a unique personality and, of course, look. 
 All the other characters were good on their own. Not too good nor too bad, just the right amount of 'human', if you get what I mean. 
 If you are looking for a short, refreshing read, this is a great book to go for!

This heartfelt tale of August is a must-read. August was born with a severe facial deformity that required several surgeries throughout his young life, making it nearly impossible for him to attend school with other kids his age. As he is about to enter the fifth grade, his parents decide that it would be a good idea to try out going to school for the first time, which is going to be difficult for Auggie since he has never been to school and has a deformed face. This is a wonderful story that teaches many lessons on not judging a book by its cover and the power of friendship. 
 I gave this realistic fiction novel five stars out of five stars. The characters are described in such depth that you feel like you know them in real life. The story is told from several different characters' points of view, so it keeps it interesting by hearing several different narrators. Plus, you get to hear many characters' thoughts and feelings about the same events. I recommend this book for anyone that has ever felt out of place, which I would guess is almost anyone! It is a quick read and leaves your heart feeling light!

4.5 stars 
 Everything was a little too neat for me (but that's probably due to the genre), but I loved this anyway. It made me happy and hopeful and believe in the goodness of people. Even though it's a work of fiction. 
 If I had a bookshelf titled books-for-my-future-kids-to-read, this would be on it. I don't though because I don't want you all to think I'm crazy.

I expected to dislike this book but instead found it completely charming. 
 I would give it five stars but I felt like the graduation scene went a little to far and thus seemed forced. 
 Auggie is a great character and I appreciated the multiple POV. 
 Read it in one sitting.

The story was easy to read and predictable. I loved the characters and how the author gave narration voice over to different character perspectives throughout the book. Both heart-aching and heart-warming, you can truly connect with the characters and see what school experience is like for Auggie. 
 Side Note: I love Mr. Brown's monthly precepts idea and plan to borrow this notion for my students.

This book should probably be required reading for everyone from age 10 - 100. Even younger than 10, if the reader is mature (my 6 1/2 yr old nephew read it with his mom and they discussed as they read). 
 I laughed. I cried. Okay, I sobbed. Full on ugly cried. My heart hurt so much. But the story also renewed my faith in humanity, just a little. 
 Fantastic read.

This book is truly full of wonder. 
 August is entering fifth grade and he's going to school for the first time. He's been home-schooled until now and his preciosity is making it hard for his parents to keep up with teaching him at home. He's full of the adolescent awkwardness and self doubt we all remember. But August isn't actually an "ordinary" kid. He's been home schooled because he's needed 20+ surgeries on his face to address a severe birth defect, with the simple goal of survival. So this story is really about what it's like to be an extraordinary kid who is always stared at, or who is never looked at, because he looks different. And as told from the perspective of August, his classmates, and his sister, it also carries an underlying question: if August was your classmate, would you have included him or shunned him? Would you do better today?

*****Review not yet completed 
 I liked reading from each character's POV. It gave insight on how each person saw Auggie. It was realistic in how the characters acted towards him. His life consisted of bullies and a lot of challenges, not everything was flowery and good. The novel progressed nicely in portraying how people came around to accepting Auggie when they were originally so afraid of him. 
 This is definitely a book that pleases all audiences. I'm not typically a young adult reader, but I enjoyed this a lot. I'd recommend this to preteens through adults. It's a feel good book that all ages enjoy.

Auggie is a normal fifth grader in every way - except for how he looks. He was born with a terrible facial deformity and has been home schooled all of his life. Now his mother feels it would best for him to go to a regular school. Needless to say this year is very difficult for him. All children, as well as their parents are not always kind. There are many trials and tribulations that are faced, but there are good times, fun and laughter as well. The underlying message for this book is that as humans we are need to be kinder than necessary. 
 Each segment of this book is told by a different character giving his outlook on how Auggie is treated.

Good book for teaching life values, but not particularly memorable.

I saw this book on NetGalley and wasn't sure if I should request it or not. I was afraid it would be overwhelmingly sad, and I like to keep my reading happy and light. But, just from reading the summary, I had to know more about August and his story and decided to request the book. 
 And I'm so glad I did, because Wonder was an excellent read. It is told from several points-of-view, which I love because I really got to know several of the characters. I loved reading about the same events from different points-of-view. It's neat to see how different people view the same event. Everyone has their own interpretation of things. 
 Wonder answers the question: how does it feel to be the person other people stare at? The one that causes people do a double-take when they see you? Everyone has probably seen someone different and looked twice, or looked from the corner of their eye (to keep from staring). August catches all of these looks, as well as ugly comments, and nothing escapes his notice. To see how much people's reactions affect August and his family was truly heart-breaking. 
 I went from laughing on one page to crying on the next, this book was that emotional. I was in awe of August's strength of character and unfailing positive outlook (as well as his parents'). 
 I thought that Wonder would feel very young, since it is written mainly from a 10-year-old's point of view, but it did not. August is mature for his age and his voice was sometimes young, but sometimes much older than a 10 year-old's should be. He has to grow up fast due to his abnormalities and his narrative voice reflects that. 
 The book ends on a positive note, although that did not stop me from crying yet again, just due to how emotional the book was on the whole. I loved it and think everyone should read about August!

August Pullman was born with a rare facial done disorder that required many surgeries and recovery. He was home schooled until he was ready to start fifth grade and his mother enrolled him in Beecher Prep School. 
 This Book follows August's school year and the chapters are written from his eyes, his teachers, sister and friends. As a mother I could see how you would want to protect and help a child with this condition. There were moments of friendship, and moments of ridicule. 
 This is a pre-teen book, It was very well written and it will touch and teach people of all ages. (Movie coming out this fall)
This book and its message should be spread far and wide, especially in schools. In today's world, where bullying and abuse are rampant, we all could do with a little kindness.

As a teacher, mother, fellow member of society, this is a must read. Auggie is a lovable and unique character, and the nastiness that exists in the world is brought to its knees by his simple courageous actions of every day life. There are scenes in this book where I just poured tears because of the mother in me; others where I did as a child would. The different perspectives make the book very interesting to read and give you insight to some of our own thoughts about the subject of beauty and kindness.

I wanted to like this book. I really did. 
 This story is about August- a ten year old boy who was born with severe facial deformities and is attending school for the first time ever this year. As you can imagine, there are a lot of challenges that Auggie experiences during his first year of school (most of them regarding his social relationships with his peers). 
 It's well written and flows well- which is commendable considering that it's always a little difficult for books with multiple narrators to avoid choppiness (and there are six in this one). However, there are a handful of problematic aspects to this novel that I just can't get over. I can't say them specifically without spilling major spoilers but I will say that Auggie was given a belittling ending only with bells and whistles attached to make it seem like he was being celebrated. This detracted significantly from Auggie's character (which is a shame because his character is great and deserved a much better conclusion) and, instead of making him a unique and whole person, left him as a flat mascot for "different" kids. 
 I will say that I love Auggie's family. Were they complex, 3D characters? No, not really, but I was self-indulgent in enjoying them for how loving, kind and sweet they are.

Okay, here we go again with me probably being the lone voice in the wilderness, dissing a book that everyone seems to think is of Newbery caliber. 
 Not me.I find this more of a Disney movie caliber. A kids version of the Cher movie Mask, with the parents neatly cleaned up, set in the sort of LaLa Land version of New York that people read about in the New York Times. Emphatically not MY New York, though that NY is just on the other side of a small river bridge! 
 This is a "feel good" book where everyone (save for the one cardboard bad character and his family) find the better angels of their nature. The last section of the book (from the camp sequence on) is as predicatable as can be and the ending is perfect and satisfying and as phoney as a $3 bill. 
 This is well written and engrossing to the point where I read it avidly in one sitting. And finished it feeling that I'd been suckered.

My oh my, this book. The emotions that will run through you are limitless; happiness, amusement, love, pain, fear, sadness, anger, joy. Auggie's narrative will make you smile, break your heart, make your teeth clench in anger and make you fall in both love and hate with the very nature of life. Rarely will you find a book that will touch you and stay with you as much as this one will; it is a truly beautiful creation.

Ever look back on your school life and think 'Glad I don't have to do that again!' Imagine dealing with the typical school issues (opposite sex, hierarchy of groups, invites to parties ... this is before we even get into grades) when you also have a disability? Then imagine the disability is a physical one. 
 That is the challenge that meets August. August was born with a facial deformity. He is approaching grade 5 and after dealing with surgeries and hospital visits most of his life, his parents feel he is ready to bridge from home schooling to main stream school. August lives with his very loving parents, older sister Via who is 'normal' and his dog Daisy. 
 This very powerful and moving book by first time author R. J. Palacio is a touching story of August, his family and the friends he made in his first year at mainstream school. From the incredible first paragraph with the sentences: 
 I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year old kid. ... But I know ordinary kids don't make other ordinary kids run away screaming in playgrounds. I know ordinary kids don't get stared at wherever the go. 
 You are hooked into August's life and boy what a life he leads. It's an emotional roller coaster as you find yourself wanting to protect this fictional character. The author captures the awkward feelings everyone has felt in 'middle school' from the sitting alone at the lunch table to the cliques that every school seems to have. August has to deal with these plus know that everyone is avoiding him. Well, not everyone. 
 August's new head teacher, Mr Tushman, has arranged for students Jack, Julian and Charlotte to come to the school over the summer to show August around. While on the tour, we can start to sense some of August anxiety but also the willingness of some kids wanting to get past the 'looks'. 
 The book is one that you continue to think about days after reading it. I was told it was geared to kids but really don't think that this is a book that can be pigeon holed into one genre. The writing is beautifully crafted to embrace the many complex emotions most of us has ensured at one time or another. It also covers many difficulties that people of all ages continue to battle in adulthood. 
 I'd be very surprised if this doesn't win awards.

I loved this book even more than the first time I read it. This story is so beautiful and touches on a topic that is usually left alone and forgotten. The author was able to develop a plot line that is one of the most real that I have ever read about. She did an overall fantastic job and I can't wait to see what else she writes.
It's a weepy one.
Funny and poignant and realistic and fantastic.

Wonder is a beautiful and important book. If it was up to me, I'd put it on the required reading list in elementary schools. The moment I finished it, I pushed it into my son's hands. There's nothing preachy about Wonder, just genuine emotions that I hope my kid will recognize in himself and his friends in school. There's so much he can learn from it, and at the same time it's entertaining, funny and wonderfully paced. 
 Definitely one of these books you wish the whole world would read.

I heard so many good things about this book and really enjoyed reading it. I liked how the story was told from the perspective of the various characters. I wouldn't call it a issue/complaint, but I found that the characters acted way older than they were stated in the book. Auggie felt more like he was 13 or 14 rather than 10 and Via felt maybe like a freshman in college rather than in high school. Did anyone else feel this way?

This book was Wonderful, pun intended. 
 I don't think I've ever wanted to slap a child more than I wanted to slap Julian. I loved August and I felt bad for him. I loved his sister Via, and his parents who all just wanted the best for him. I loved his friends, Jack and Summer. Seriously hated Julian and everyone else around him, like his stupid fucking parents, his mother needed to go suck a dick. Photoshopping him out of a class photo. Where do you get off? 
 This book made me cry, he was so brave, kids are so mean, life is so cruel and unfair. But I loved his response to it, I loved that he tried to see the best in everything and how positive he was for what he was going through. I would highly recommend this book.

An engaging, page-turner. The characters jump off the page and grab your heart. It is well plotted and the characters change for the better from knowing each other. A book that appeals to adults as well as children.
Read this in one go! Amazing!!!

This is a terrific book. I liked how the book was split into sections representing different characters' perspectives, and the characters' interactions and internal dialogue felt honest and true to life. It was easy to relate to and feel for each character, and the story definitely pulled me in and stirred my emotions. I highly recommend this book. (I also liked the Star Wars references, although there a bit too many from the prequels. :))
WONDER - ful!

The multiple narrators add considerable strength to this story about a child with facial abnormalities and his introduction to the realities of middle school. A younger audience of 5th and 6th graders will particularly fall in love with this poignant novel.

I'm the last person in my household to read this book, but my peeps didn't do it justice. I haven't read much fiction for middle schoolers, so I don't want to say much in the way of criticism. I found some of the characterizations a little too perfect (Auggie's parents), but the story itself was believable and painful and sweet and lovely.
It is beautifully well-written. I am going to recommend this to everyone I know. Kindness is what the world needs dY'--

Really sweet and profoundly effecting. 
 Spent four and half hours cleaning my entire apartment from top to bottom while listening to this on audio which made it a really enjoyable experience! The readers did great voices and bravo to R.J. Palacio for bringing us a story that is both important and believable. 
 Best of all, in the final minutes, I was collapsed on my couch, feet up and surveying a job well-done when the ending hit me like a ton of bricks. Not that I didn't see it coming, but let's just say my tear ducts can't resist a Mr. Holland's Opus ending like this one. I'm a sucker for those. 
 Definitely a gem of 2012!

August (Auggie) Pullman was born with a facial deformity requiring 27 surgeries and preventing him from going to school--until now. He's about to start 5th grade at Beecher Prep, and if you've ever been the new kid then you know how hard that can be. The thing is Auggie's just an ordinary kid, with an extraordinary face. But can he convince his new classmates that he's just like them, despite appearances? 
 Wow, I don't even know how to write a review for this book because whatever I write won't do it justice. This story is powerful and beautifully written. You will laugh, you will cry, and you will come away with a stronger resolve to be a better person. I absolutely loved Auggie. He just wanted to be treated like a "normal" kid and had a great attitude in spite of the fact that people were constantly staring at him, bullying him, and making him feel like he was a monster. Surprisingly, the story was told through six different viewpoints which really allows the reader to learn more about Auggie through the eyes of other people, including his sister Via. She wasn't always perfect but she was the best sister anyone could have. And Summer--we all want a friend like her and most of us wish we would react to Auggie like she did. But would we? Especially when we were in the 5th grade? The speech given by Mr. Tushman at graduation was touching and reminds us all what a difference kindness makes. 
 --"Shall we make a new rule of life . . . Always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary? What a marvelous line, isn't it? Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed. Why I love that line, that concept, is that it reminds me that we carry with us, as human beings, not just the capacity to be kind, but the very choice of kindness. If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary--the world really would be a better place." 
 This is a wonderful story of courage, love and the reminder of what a little kindness can do. Although it was written for middle school students, everyone can benefit from reading this book. As a former elementary school teacher, I think this is a great book to use as a read-aloud starting in 3rd grade. If I still had children at home, I would be reading it with them too.
My absolute new favourite book <3 it gives you ALL the feel !!! If you haven't read this book yet YOU MUST !! Love tfios ? Read this !
This book completely took me in. It's my new favorite--Ruby and Sydney will love this, and Rachel as well.

Not my favorite book of all time, 
 Very easy to read and interresting 
 The way this book is writen, with the many narrators makes it quite compelling 
 but I might be to old to enjoy fully this story^^

Augustus (Auggie) is ten years old and attending school for the very first time. He's been homeschooled for the first ten years of his life. You see, Auggie is an ordinary kid in most ways, but he looks different from most kids. He has been through hundreds of surgeries, attempting to correct the affects a wayward gene had on his face. Some look at him and run. Others look at him and feel sympathy. But what Auggie wants more than anything is for people to look at him and see him for who he is on the inside: a caring, bright, funny boy. Will his new classmates be able to look past his exterior and get to know the real Auggie? Or will they run in disgust and horror like so many other?

Man, I don't even know where to begin with this book. I can't tell you how many times my heart squeezed in pain for Auggie. But not only him. Because this book is so character driven (with 6 or 7 character POVs - which I thought would be annoying but proved otherwise), you can relate to each person. You see how everyone has their roles, and everyone thinks they are doing what's best, whether it is or isn't. And how when you are in a family with a child that has a disability or deformity it puts strain on the whole family. And the friends of the family. Everyone is affected. 
 It tells the true story of how in schools all over the country kids are being bullied for much less than having a disability of some form or another. How sticking up for or defending or befriending someone could guarantee you bullying. 
 But I think the biggest story behind it all is to do what's right. We've all been there before. No matter how low or high you are on the totem pole of popularity - we've made fun of someone "lower" than us. But all it is, is a ploy to make ourselves feel better about our own lives. This is about sticking together and lifting eachother up no matter what the circumstances are. 
 This book will be a read aloud I do this coming school year, and I'll probably wait to read it until after the holiday break, right around when bullying and ugliness starts to spread like wildfire around the room, and I hope it hits my furture students in a sensitive spot that will change the way they treat people forever.

I don't know why it took me so long to read this amazing book. It is so good! August, "Auggie" is an ordinary ten-year-old boy, except for one thing, he has a deformed face. Like the Elephant Man, he is shunned by society. He is lucky though as he was born into a wonderful family. His parents and older sister love him very much. They are overprotective, of course, but encourage him to try attending a normal school for his fifth grade. (He has been homeschooled up to now.) What happens in his fifth-grade year makes the story. It is so well written and from the points of view of a number of different kids as well as Auggie's. You will fall in love with all the characters as they grow and learn a lot over the course of the year. It is a poignant story about family, friendship, prejudice and forgiveness. It will leave you laughing, crying and cheering for Auggie. If you haven't read it yet, what are you waiting for? Make sure you have a tissue nearby.

This is a beautifully written novel about August, who is a 10 year old boy who has a facial deformity who has been home schooled until now and his parents are sending him to middle school. He has always had the same friend from when he was younger until Christopher had to move out of state with his family. Since that happen Auggie has kept himself to himself and only really spends time with his parents and sister, Via and also his dog Daisy. 
 I loved how Auggie was narrating it and how his words just leapt from page. There were some parts of the novel were I was close to tears and then at some parts I was sobbing my heart out. Auggie has had a lot to deal with his whole life and his has dealt with it so well, I know that if I had a facial deformity I wouldn't of been able to cope with people stopping and staring at me. Auggie coped with this amazingly and he just wanted to be treated like a normal person. 
 When Auggie starts at school he is helped along by 3 people, Charlotte, Jack and Julian. All of them seem very shocked at who they are helping around the school. They all have different opinions of who Auggie is and why he looks different from everyone else. There are so many names that are thrown around, orc, zombie and elephant man but Auggie doesn't react to any of those names and just carries on his life as normal. 
 Auggie meets Summer on the first day of school at lunch time when she comes and sits on the same table as him and suggests that they should be friends as their names are both from the same season. When I read this I thought that it was really sweet of Summer. I did though have a deep thought that she was only doing this for a dare but I learnt further in the book that Summer like Auggie for his humour and personality and not just cause she could of been told to be friends with him. 
 There is so much that I can say about this book, but it would give away too much of the plot. All I can say is that it is the most amazing book that I have read for the year or so. The way it is written is with lots of thought and understanding of how a person would feel and be like with a deformity of any kind. R.J Palacio has a fantastic way with words and makes you feel like you are there with Auggie everyday going through what he is going through. If there is one book that you should pick up this year, make sure it is Wonder as it is truly a remarkable novel and I haven't read anything like it since Jenny Downham brought Before I Die to the publishing world.
My favourite book ever
What a wonderful book, I laughed at a time and teared in some parts.. it's amazing how auggie made a difference in our lives.

THIS BOOK! THIS BOOK!! THIS BOOK!!! 
 This book took me in every way possible and it was just fantastic. The way it is written and how the author has written the story isj fenomenal and quite original. (I did cry)

Auggie Pullman's story has inspired me greatly to strive to be a kinder and more thoughtful person. This beautifully written novel touched my heart and pulled at many of my emotions. Even though Auggie may have had an unlucky life he still has a amazing outlook on the world and events on a day to day basis. The world has been so unkind to Auggie, yet this tragic life story makes me want to be kinder to the world.
A nice message wrapped up in a preachy, didactic mess that manipulates you into having an emotion. I wanted to like this book so much yet it fell far short for me.

Lately I've been obsessed with books that have super positive main characters. But, seriously, if ever there were a main character that could hate the world, it would be Auggie from this remarkable novel. Born with a rare genetic condition, his face is seriously deformed, leading to twenty seven surgeries by the time he's ten years old. In turn, it's kept him from ever attending a real school. But, that's about to change. Auggie's set to enter fifth grade at Beecher prep and though he's scared, he's also ready to venture out of his home-school and make new friends, and he's hoping someone will see him for the ordinary kid he is behind his extra-ordinary face.

This book is quite the sweet tale of a little boy with a "craniofacial abnormality," his family, and the friends that come alongside him. Through the many trials and triumphs of August Pullman, we see a story of strength, love, and beauty. I must recommend all books that promulgate such hope.

Been awhile since I cried once, let alone several times while reading a book, but this one gets you! Navigating middle school is hard enough, but when you have a difference that makes it all that more difficult. You hope you are raising your kids to be good people, but herd mentality start early and kids can be cruel...sadly they emulate what they see adults do. Excellent book, can't wait to see the movie, I hope they do it justice.
sorry but i didn't like it at all it is so boring

I had heard so many good things about this book from so many different people and I finally got it from the library so I couldn't wait to read it. It's a quick read, but seriously amazing. Loved it. I seriously don't have the words to convey how beautiful this book is and how much I loved it. Highly recommend.

I FINISHED IT ALREADY! That's one of the quickest read I've done. 9 hours and 35 minutes, to be exact! 
 When I found out that the movie is coming out, I was so stoked! Jacob Tremblay is going to play Auggie, and I don't want to be this way, but I'm having a big expectation for this movie. I hope it won't ruin it! 
 It is such a great and moving book. I shed a tear couple of times. Very fast-paced, it was like I was only skimming through, but no, I was taking every sentences by heart. I love how the characters developed. I like how it is written in many point of views, because I get to know how every person reacts to Auggie, but I'm kind of bummed that Nate and Isabel aren't one of them. But that's just me. 
 I stand with my original 5/5 stars. It's an easy read with a moving story. I would recommend this to everyone!
Excellent portrayal of multiple character perspectives. Very enjoyable read!
You (whomever you are) gotta read this.
August el nene mas estupido!!! No queria que lo diferenciaran cuando queria
I did not like this book. Wonder had no problem and solution. The only problem was, "his face is weird". We read it as a read-aloud in school. It was boring, the book just droned on.

That, was amazing. Wonder is the type of book that makes you feel good, restores your faith in humanity, and makes you want to do something for others. And everyone needs a book like that at some point. Auggie is incredibly realistic and makes you realize so many things that you normally wouldn't. All the other characters are strong and amazing. I actually can't even express how much I loved this book. All the characters are incredibly realistic and make you feel really feelings for them. And yeah. I can't say how much I loved this book, but I do know that if you didn't cry tears of happiness, you're lying.

I really liked this book. At first, it took me a while to get into it. I wasn't crazy about it but I loved the ending. I think it has an important message that through all walks of life - no matter what you look like or who you are - people are going to treat you differently. Some will be kind and some, not so much. 
 This book teaches you to think in a different way. It encourages you to empathise with people. It also has an important message of kindness. I think one of my favourite aspects of this book is that it told the story from the perspective of many different characters. 
 I don't really know what I'm rambling on about but I would recommend this book as it is an easy read and also lifts you.

A friend of mine read this book with his son and it looked pretty good so I decided to but a Hold on it at the library. When it came in for me and I added it to my Goodreads list I saw that my nephew had also read it and liked it. 
 This is a kids book, but that is okay because some of my favorite books are kids books. The main character, August "Auggie" Pullman, is a 10 year old boy that was born with some pretty severe facial deformities. Because of that and some other medical issues that went along with it he is home schooled through the 4th Grade. But for the 5th Grade his parents convince him to reluctantly agree to attend a regular school. I say a regular school but it is a private school, so not completely regular. The book is about Auggie's 5th grade year at Beecher Prep Middle School. It is told in sections from several different perspectives. Auggie's, of course, some family members, and some friends. Some of the sections overlap a little so that you read about some events from two or even three perspectives. I read the book over only 2 days so it was pretty easy not to get confused but if you read it over a longer period of time I suppose you might forget who was speaking or what others had said about the events. The author tried to write each section differently so that you could kind of "hear" that characters voice. The only one that I really did not like was Justin's where no capital letters were used. That was a little weird and distracting. 
 I thought that the characters and the book were very realistic. One thing about many kids books is that the good guys are all good and the bad guys are all bad. Like it is in real life, however, the characters in this book go both ways. Sometimes the good guys make mistakes and sometimes the bad guys aren't all that bad. The ending was predictable but that is not always a bad thing. I read some reviews that said that there were too many little side storylines that did not seem necessary. In my opinion that is how life is. There is what we are trying to do and there are the big things that happen to us. Then there are all of the little things that happen to us as well. If you were telling someone the story of your life for a year you could not go into detail about everything that happened to and around you, yet if you left some things out completely the story would be incomplete. I thought the author struck a good balance. 
 There are probably several morals that can be found in this book. I'm sure that when this book is read by a Middle School class there are many "teaching moments" that the teacher will bring out and that will be the topic of essay questions. It is also a fun story to read and one that I am glad that I read.

2.5/5 stars 
 There was a lot of people all over social media talking about how much they adored this book - so obviously I had to pick it up! And it was definitely super cute, but I didn't love it as much as I thought I was going to. I'm a sucker for middle-grade novels, and this one was entertaining and everything, but I think it's my lack of interest in realistic fiction that made me not enjoy it as much as others. I'm not one for slice-of-life books/comics/anything really because I always say "why would I read something that could actually happen?" which explains my love of fantasy. I always just find realistic fiction super boring because there are never exciting plots or action. This novel was cute, definitely. But it didn't capture me at all. I loved a couple of the characters, but I almost felt like they could have gone into greater detail with a few of them. As well as the fact that it had almost no plot except the fact that Auggie had a syndrome that made his face a bit screwed up. There was no set plot, which made me question why I was reading it, and it made me not care to continue usually because there was nothing I was looking forward to. 
 I do suggest people who LIKE realistic fiction read it - all those people who like metaphors and morals and a greater meaning to things would love it. But I personally wasn't all that impressed.
What can I say about this book that hasn't already been said? I loved it. I plan on having my family read it when our kids are a little older and having some good discussions.

 A beautiful, heart-warming story of little Auggie. Bought this for my brother, but it turned out I needed this sort of life-is-good, people-are-not-all-mean-aliens book more than ever. Such wonderful moments. You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder 
 "...there are more good people on this earth than bad people, and the good people watch out for each other and take care of each other. Just like Jack was there for you." 
 "Shall we make a new rule of life... always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind.- Dr. Wayne W.Dyer" 
 "What is beautiful is good, and who is good will soon be beautiful. - Sappho"
I JUST LOVED IT!

first read : october 2015

 this book is just amazing!!!!!!!! I. can't. deal.
Simply written, good messages
Everybody going into middle school should read this. Adults will also enjoy this tale, it is well written with musical references from my generation

I really liked this book overall, and its message and Auggie, but I usually have mixed feelings about switching POVs, and it really read as MG (not that I dislike middle grade, but the writing was too simple for my tastes at the age I'm at now).

This is an amazing book about humanness. I love that it encompasses the perspectives of all those involved, because as Mr. Tushman says, "there are almost always more than two sides to every story". And, every character has something invaluable to teach. This book holds truths that everyone, adults most especially, need to meditate on daily. The lack of importance of our physicality is just the beginning. The need for simple kindness is just the surface. The forgiveness in this book is the most beautiful illustration of humanness I've seen since The Lovely Bones. The struggle of understanding ourselves and others is what kept me glued to every page to the point that I had to force myself to put it down just to sleep. Palacio has created a cherished portrait of the search for self that we all, whether conscious or unconscious, engage in every minute of our stay here on Earth.

I was expecting this book to be quirky and extremely well-written and while I did enjoy it, that isn't exactly what I got. I liked the idea of the story and thought it was very cute. I would love to teach this in a middle school ELA classroom because I believe there is a lot to discuss and learn from the book. That being said, a few things bothered me. One was that there were obvious typos, which always bugs me. Also, I didn't see the point of Justin or Miranda's narration. Why were they included? They were minor characters and I understand their part in the story but dedicating an entire section to each of them seemed a bit pointless. They didn't do much for the story and I would have liked it better if the author stuck to Auggie's, Summer's, Jack's, and Via's point of view. Also, what was up with Justin's section? There was no capitalization and seemed more like a train of thought. I didn't understand the reasoning behind that type of narration; it just didn't fit with the rest of the book. Lastly, I don't think that's really how kids just beginning 5th grade talk to each other; it just seemed a bit too mature for me.

Check my blog: http://bookburnn.wordpress.com/ 
 Finally, a book that lives up to its title! 
 Actual Rating: 4.00 
 Plus Points: 
 Simple. It doesn't need highfalutin words to give validity to the essence of the story. It also helps because it's set in a child's POV, so it makes everything a lot less complicated and straightforward. (And obviously, because of the genre it is in) 
 Different POVs. I wasn't actually expecting different POV's from other characters however it was interesting to see their own story and what they have to say. It's nice to see how the story progresses and translates to different characters. Judging a character is inevitable, I know. But this book gave (almost) everyone a chance to speak up and defend themselves. Also having different POV allowed the reader to see characters in different lighting. 
 Compelling. The plot is just gorgeous. I haven't seen books that talk about deformity as subtle and heavy as this one. 
 I like the fact that not everything was centered in Augustus' facial deformity. I wasn't expecting this to have an impact on me, but I'd be lying if I said it didn't. It was just amazing how R. J. Palacio put something sensitive (facial deformity) and translates it into an innocent child's POV. It was compelling because you wouldn't expect a child to go around with facial deformity and say it's okay. 
 However, I was really hoping to read Augustus parents POV especially his mom. Throughout the story she was the one that felt very quite and distant, it left me wondering why and what lead her to be that way. That's the only thing that bugs me. 
 Do I like it: Yes! 
 Recommended: To people who haven't read this

I just couldn't put it down. Although it deals with a very serious problem it' just so lighthearted and up-lifting to read. It leaves you with a warm feeling inside and you've regained faith in humanity. 10/10, definetly a new favourite !

Read this book. It's a young adult book and by that I don't mean teens, I mean younger readers. Even though it's written at a less challenging reading level, the book is appropriate for all ages. 
 * When given the choice between being right or being kind choose kind. 
 * Your deeds are your monuments. 
 * Fortune favors the bold.

Auggie is ready to start 5th grade but Auggie has never been to school. He was born with a deformed face and has had many surgeries but still people who see his face are repulsed. His mama has home schooled him but he is a regular 10 year old boy who likes friends and video games. Auggie has a sweet and understanding nature and is very intelligent but nobody ever stops to talk to him to find out that he is a real person. His dad comments that sending Auggie to school is like sending a lamb to slaughter. He doesn't know what that means but he finds out all in the fifth grade at school. 
 Quote from The Guardian: "This is an incredible book. The story-telling is marvellous, the styling superb and the honest, raw truth is: heart-breaking. 
 It offers up a harsh critique of our society and, finally, subtle praise for those people who dare to break out of the mould and stand up for what they believe in." 
 My Opinion:Will this be the Newbery winner come January 2013? I bet it will.
An amazing novel for all ages! A must read!
One of the best books that I read.
As an elementary school librarian, I am always suggesting this book. I thought it was as honest a book as I've read in a long time.
Delicato, pungente a tratti, ironico e splendido. Si, splendido. Ed e per tutti. Sul serio, dovrebbero leggerlo tutti.
i'm crying! it's really good...

Such a great book to read with the kids! Perfect timing as one has just started middle school, just like the main character, Auggie. There are so many opportunities for discussion with this book, so many of those key life concepts you want your kids to grasp onto (like, always choose kindness over being right and it doesn't cost you anything to be kinder).

I thought I had posted this one already- It was amazing and really goes to show what a difference people can make. One mean act or one kind act can start a domino effect. 
 Don't recommend the audio version though- tried to listen to it after I read it and I just didn't like how it was done.

This should be required reading for middle schoolers and teens. Would make for a great book club read. 
 "If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God."

Should be required reading for all upper elementary kids. You can try to "teach" empathy all you want, but the best way, other than real-life opportunities, is likely through fiction wherein readers get to assume the experiences of the characters.
I really want to continue reading this book it's just that i didn't really have much time or patience at the time but i will read it sooner or later when i get the other books out of the way
A must-read for all ages, to teach us about empathy and kindness.

What a great read that led to lots of introspection about how I interact with others. I thought about how I see/judge people and my personal levels of sensitivity about others' lives and experiences. Kindness--a wonderful theme, richly illustrated in this book. And I love a book that causes genuine self-assessment. 
 Auggie, the main character says "I wish every day could be Halloween. We could all wear masks all the time. Then we could walk around and get to know each other before we got to see what we looked like under the masks." Wouldn't the world be a better place if we put less emphasis on appearances--a great message from a great book. 
 I might have given this 5 stars, but (because it's written for a young audience) it felt a bit juvenile. Despite showing some really unpleasant aspects of the world, it all ended in an unrealistic, too-happy feeling that isn't (in my experience) true-to-life. 4.5 stars.

Kitaba bayildim,kesinlikle bu sene okudugum en iyi kitaplardan biri.Cok eglenceli fakat ben okurken bazi yerlerde oldukca agladim,merak etmeyin ben cok sulu gozlu bir insanim buyuk ihtimalle ondandir. 
 Auggie'ye bayildim!Tam anlamiyla muthis bir cocuk! Fakat beni en cok etkileyen kisim Via'nin anlattigi kisim oldu.Herkesin korktugu,tum ailenin ilgi odagi olmus bir kardesle yasamayi anlatiyor bize ve bu kiz daha 14 yasinda.Her ne kadar eglenceli bir kitap olsa da cok huzunlu bir tarafi da var. 
 Kafama takilan tek sey su oldu; Auggie ve arkadaslari 10 yasinda fakat hepsi en az 15-16 yaslarindaymis gibi olgun davraniyor. Fakat bu olumsuz yone ragmen kitap cidden muhtesemdi,kesinlikle okuyun! 
 Hakli olmak ile nazik olmak arasinda secim yapmaniz gerektiginde,nazik olmayi secin.

I loved, loved, loved this book! It was well written and portrayed a fairly unique dynamic. This book's emotion and story span age groups and I am so glad I read this. 
 If you're looking for something outside of the norm and want to be reminded the power of kindness, this is the book for you.

Me ha hecho llorar y reir a partes iguales. Es un libro que te llega hondo y te hace pensar. Creo que tanto ninos como adultos pueden aprender mucho con este libro y cambiar la manera de tratar a las personas.

Much to admire and love here, yet there is a yet. I don't know how to pinpoint it really except that sometimes I was very aware of the adult voice in Auggie. I mean, of course we know it's written by an adult but I want to believe it's him speaking, and I didn't always.

Once in awhile you read a book in which the character remains important deep within your thoughts and heart. A character so moving, so special, and so inspiring... so alive. Wonder is a book in which the main character has made the decision to enter Middle School after being home schooled. It is a decision that will leave him vulnerable and exposed. A courageous step beyond the safety of his family. 
 Meet Auggie (August Pullman), who was born with a facial deformity, intelligence, and courage. All of his life he has endured the devastating looks, reactions, and fearfulness of strangers. Now is the time for him to become a student among many who are finding their way as middle school students. Given the "all encompassing" emotions and hormonal changes, middle school can be a roller coaster of fear, bullying, anger, and uncertainty. Why would Auggie want to begin public school at such a time is beyond reasoning for most of us. Yet, Auggie is blessed beyond measure with courage and a determination to live without "superficial" boundaries. 
 "I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid. 
 I mean, sure, I do ordinary things.... 
 But I know ordinary kids don't make other kids 
 run away screaming in playgrounds." 
 Mr. Tushman of Beecher Prep school has prearranged a meeting with Auggie and his mother before the first day of school. Like any ordinary "new" student, Auggie will meet some of the staff and tour the school. It is with great foresight, that Auggie's tour is lead by a few "homeroom" students: 
 Jack is the first student that will extend friendship in the halls and classrooms. Yet, at some point he will need to decide if he wants to fit in with his old friends or stay friends with Auggie. 
 Jullian is rude and obnoxious (you know that type that acts one way with adults and another with students). The type that is loud, arrogant, and will not let Auggie escape being bullied. When push comes to shove, Auggie will demonstrate true character strength. The question will be if Jullian will learn acceptance of Auggie as an "ordinary" kid... and a friend? 
 Charlotte is an "artsy" girl. She enjoys all aspects of school, including science. She doesn't waiver in her support for Auggie, unless maybe it's in the lunch room. Will Charlotte be strong enough to overcome peer pressure? 
 Mr. Browne is Auggie's English teacher. He values his students and begins school with learning about precepts (any important thought, motto, or saying that guides you when making really important decisions). His students will write-to-learn a new precept every month: 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, 
 choose kind." 
 Dr. Wayne W. Dyer 
 Summer is the first student who braves the whispers in the lunch room and chooses to sit at the table with Auggie. It might seem a small gesture to many... but not only will it prove to be a courageous step towards friendship... it will also be an experience of a life time for both of them. 
 Whether it is Auggie's first birthday party, the first Halloween school event, the first school trip (outdoor school away from home), or the first meeting with his sister's high school friends... Auggie is on a life-changing quest... to be just another "ordinary kid!" 
 The depth of characterization will leave a lasting "thumb-print" upon every reader's heart. Those middle school experiences will be confirmed and/or "pushed" to a new level of awareness with dignified choices. The story line is expertly woven between Auggie's story and the voices of those who are changed by their encounters with Auggie. 
 There is so much that Auggie offers, care enough to experience the "Wonder," 
 MrsK http://mrskbookstogo.blogspot.com/

But the parents can't help it because they're protective of their boy and trying to make sure he's as normal as he can be. I loved how loving they were though. And I loved how much Auggie grew up within that year, he gained so much confidence and he's such a brave little boy.

I really wish the author would make another book of August, Jack, and Summer for when they're about 17 or so; see what adventures they get up to being teens, and watch Jack and Summer fall for each other.

Yes Yes Yes! 
 I loved this book. Although I believe this was meant to be a middle grade read, it seriously transcends age range. R.J. Palacio has done well in writing a book to inspire many a generation. 
 While most would assume it's a book about 'not caring what people think of you, and just be yourself' yadda yadda, I felt a stronger undertone. For me, it was more so a book about living life to the fullest, and treating people with compassion. Simply to look past what people are doing in the moment, and accept them as they are. 
 R.J. did a wonderful job in making Auggie real. She showed us how a real little boy would deal with the hand he was dealt, not some middle aged woman writing as a ten year old. 
 I personally loved the book so much I gave it to my brother as a high school graduation gift. If there is a book for anyone to read, where they can be inspired before jetting off into the world, it's this one. A beautiful life lesson. 
 Kudos to you R.J. Kudos to you.

August "Auggie" Pullman is a medical wonder. But for him, he is just an ordinary kid-stuck with a not so ordinary life. Unavoidably touched by this life are the lives of his amazing parents, his sister Via's, and his new friends and classmates at Beecher Prep. 
 I read the book in one sitting, smiling, laughing, crying. It's one of those books... 
 This wonder-filled story is told through different point of views- each voice unique and spectacular - in such a way that gives the reader every side and angle of the story. It's like seeing every facet of a gem to really understand how valuable it really is. 
 Of course you think Auggie could never be ordinary- not until you hear him tell his own story. Via is too good to be true, but just wait and get to know the normal teenage human side of her. Miranda is the worst, disloyal friend...until you give her the chance to explain herself. Jack is worse that the meanest kid in Beecher... until you hear his side of the story. Then there's Summer, cool, awesome, unbelievable Summer and once you really know her...she's even more cooler beans! 
 This story simply proves that what seems to be extraordinary is really not and vice versa, that appearance is not what makes the difference...but our kindness and bravery. Beauty is not at all in the eye of the beholder- it's in the heart. Because real beauty can not be seen. It can only be felt.

Auggie Pullman, a sweet little boy with face deformity, is heading off to his first year of "real" school. After years of surgeries and being terribly sick, Auggie is finally well enough to go to a public school. 
 I expected this book to be good - and it did not let me down. The story was so charming and gripping, I read it one sitting. It follows Auggie through his first year of school, told in the perspective of Auggie as well as his friends, his sister, and his sister's friends. It was a pleasant surprise, as I had expected it all to be in Auggie's point of view. Though Auggie is the one who's experienced growing up with the deformity and the surgeries, it's been hard on the people around him, as well. His sister was understandably upset for herself in the situation. She wanted to have attention and wanted to be her own person without the image of Auggie following her around. Auggie's friends were good to him but at times made mistakes and hurt him, like real humans do. 
 This book was very real. It pointed out truths about how people react to medical issues and things that aren't considered the norm. The characters had very real emotions and reactions, even if they weren't all kind. 
 Wonder by R.J. Palacio is definitely a favorite book for 2014.
I hope this becomes a popular read for all middle schoolers, or even parents and kids to read together. Great kid, and great story.
A must read. So good.

I knew this book would be fabulous. I had been told by several coworkers and awards lists that it would be fabulous. I was prepared for the fabulousity . However, it still blew my mind! 
 Summary: "Wonder is a rare gem of a novel--beautifully written and populated by characters who linger in your memory and heart. August Pullman is a 10-year-old boy who likes Star Wars and Xbox, ordinary except for his jarring facial anomalies. Homeschooled all his life, August heads to public school for fifth grade and he is not the only one changed by the experience--something we learn about first-hand through the narratives of those who orbit his world. August's internal dialogue and interactions with students and family ring true, and though remarkably courageous he comes across as a sweet, funny boy who wants the same things others want: friendship, understanding, and the freedom to be himself. "It is only with one's heart that one can see clearly. What is essential is invisible to the eye." From The Little Prince and R.J. Palacio's remarkable novel, Wonder." 
 I started off with a concern. You see, I had recommended this title to some middle school teachers. But it was about a boy in fifth grade. Uh oh, had I recommended a novel that was too young? I was pleasantly surprised to find that the reading level varied by narrator. Different people in Auggie's life narrate the action, so the reading levels change to match their tone. It varies all the way from a young Auggie starting fifth grade, to the commencement speech given by the principal at Graduation (written at a much higher grade level). 
 This book brought tears to my eyes on several occasions and gave me goosebumps. It is truly a beautiful piece of art. 
 One of my favorite quotes: "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 Go pick it up from your Library today!
Awesome! I think this may be our next One Book, One School novel!

 I can imagine this as a really good book to read for school. It has short chapters, which is good for portioning it into lessons, and it has good morals without being cheesy. 
 I didn't find it to be especially exciting or gripping or funny or anything, but it was cute and imaginative. I like books for kids that celebrate diversity and encourage kindness. I think this story can inspire kindness. And that's amazing. 
 But I probably won't read all the extra books around the story. I'm not THAT into it.

I am a sucker for kindness. Sometimes, when I can't get the words out to complain to a waiter about cold food or an empty drink, I think of my fear of seeming unkind as a weakness or failing. After reading Wonder, by R.J. Palacio, I have decided that I will always, always, always err on the side of kindness...cold food and all. 
 You see, this is an excellent book. It is about kindness. It is a book I think everyone should read. It is a book I gave to my seventh grader immediately after finishing and said, "Please read this," and hoped and wished he would and not ignore it like he does with some of my suggestions. He did and he loved it too. We have had some great conversations about it since and I learned some things about him when we discussed the various characters. 
 Good books do that. They teach and inspire and warn and rebuke. I felt all of those things as I read about a nice young man with a facial deformity that made him an outcast at school and in life. I read about his fears and about his courage. I read about how people treated him. Once, in a moment of real confusion and questioning, I asked my mom what God could possibly have intended in his plan for people who suffered from debilitating mental illness. I will always remember her response. She said, "I think, in large part, they suffer so he can judge how we treat them." 
 Here is a quote from the book: "If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 There. I dare you not to love that quote. Auggie suffers so we can learn how to treat God's creations - deformed...beautiful and everything in between. Read this book and decide which of Wonder's character's you most resemble. They might be in middle school but I don't think any of us are too old to learn from Auggie. Read this book! Then have your spouse/kids/peers read it too!
