If you were an outsider growing up you will appreciate this book more than someone who wasn't. Auggie is a 10 year old who struggles with every day issues for a kid that age but what sets him apart is the fact that he has a 'hideous' face. That severe facial deformity catches attention from everyone no matter where he is or where he goes. This, of course, emphasizes all of the problems that arise because of it and in spite of it. 
 It's not your typical bully story and there is redemption in the end but it's not an easy read on the heart. It WILL make you want to love everyone around you a little harder so that they never second guess whether or not they are indeed loved. 
 August is a lovable kid and his fun personality is one that should be modeled by the kid in each and every one of us. He will win you over no matter how hard your heart is and you WILL agonize with him as he endures and perseveres through the ups-and-downs of growing up. In the process of it all, he learns invaluable lessons that should be taught to each and every one of us. 
 This is not an easy story to read. Your emotions will be all over the place and at times you won't really know what to feel. 
 The book is told mostly from Auggie's POV but it does switch to the POV of various other characters - which to me only adds to the validity and foundation of the book. Each POV offers a different take on certain situations so that you, the reader, get an honest account of all angles. 
 This story is sensitive and uplifting when you need it to be. To say that you will embrace life a little more when you finish it is an understatement. A true gem in a library full of like-minded works - and while written for those in the middle grades, is a book that can truly be appreciated by those of all ages.

Fantastic young adult book! (Keep in mind this is a book for middle-schoolers, so no nit-picking by adults thankyouverymuch.) 
 Wonder is a year in the life of August. August was born with multiple facial anomalies, requiring several surgeries over the first 10 years of his life. Since he is done with the surgeries and life has pretty much settled down, his parents (mom) decides he should go to a regular school instead of continuing to be home-schooled. What follows is the story of this first year of "regular" school told by August, as well as friends and family. Beautiful, sad, terrible, honest, wonder-full:)

I had spotted Wonder quite some time ago on Pinterest. I guess that does say something about how good the cover is: it's quite simple but it tickled my curiosity. Fast forward a few month later, this was one of the possible choice for the Coffee & Books group monthly challenge and I seized the occasion. 
 I was a bit worried about Wonder being a children's book. I've recently read some books geared toward teenagers and found I really couldn't relate to all that teenage angst. I feared it might be even worse with a children's book, but was pleasantly surprised. 
 August story, narrated by himself at first, is very interesting. Showing us the world through Auggie's eyes is a clever choice, since we have very little clues about August's appearance except that "Whatever [we]'re thinking, it's probably worse." Is it that I lack a child's imagination, but I think my idea of August was probably nicer than what is described in the rest of the book. 
 So I really liked August's narrative and was a bit taken aback when it switched to Via, his sister. I initially wasn't so sure I liked the change but The Via's chapters really add depth to the story. The role of the healthy sister in an Auggie-centered family certainly isn't an easy one and I really felt for her and wished the parents had divided their attention a tad more equally. 
 The book then switched to yet another narrator [ *me is looking in the book to find who that was]=], one of August's friend, Summer. Well let's just say I don't really remember much of Summer's story except that I don't think it added much to the story. Well at least it's someone close enough to the main character 
 Next in line, Jack. His input was justified, it was nice seing the other side of that element of the plot. Besides Jack is really easy to identify with, like most readers, he feels bad for August, he wouldn't bully him or be mean on purpose but he wouldn't have gone out of his way to befriend him either (cause he is afraid?). 
 Justin... Well unfortunately Justin seemed to be typing with a broken keyboard. Please can we raise some money so he can buy a keyboard with a working shift key? The authors tried to give each character it's own voice which went quite well until Justin's account. This change of style is too much "in your face" and makes that part a bit tedious. And much like Summer he didn't add much to the story. 
 Let's just not go over each different character that comes after, the point is just that the multiple narrators were a nice idea but it was taken just a bit too far. 
 Anyway this is just a very minor flaw. R.J. Palacio writes very skillfully about what it is to be normal (or not), how that notion is quite overrated and makes people act stupid sometime. But more importantly, and I think that's a great message that "sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone". 
 The last chapters are very inspirational (although a bit sugar coated) and is where you will find one of my favorite quote from the book: "One should be kinder than needed. Why I love that line, that concept, is that it reminds me that we carry with us, as human beings, not just the capacity to be kind, but the very choice of kindness." 
 I just wish the ending had stayed in line with that quote... because giving an award to Auggie was nice, but I feel giving it to Jack would have been just. Jack was the one who made the choice of kindness, and wouldn't praising August for something he'd done be much more rewarding?

After recently reading Out of My Mind just a few weeks ago, I found this one to be very similar in the theme and appreciated that Wonder told this story from all the points of view of the children/teens involved. While I think I preferred Out of My Mind's ending a little more, I definitely found Wonder to be just as profound of a middle-grade story and appreciate the emotions it evoked. I must say, pets dying is not a favorite thing of mine to read and I did cry when I reached that part here. :-(
Well, I cried at the end which usually means the book earns 5 stars. Can't wait to read it aloud to my students!

Though I had a few problems with this book, they were fairly minor ones, and for the most part I enjoyed this; I really liked Auggie and his family, and Summer, and Jack Will... I thought the situations here a little oversimplified, but there was still enough depth and care to keep me from focusing on that too much. The overall message is definitely a good one. Really, in the end, the biggest annoyance for me was the use of song lyrics (I really just don't like it when authors assert their musical taste in books, and also I really, really, really hate the song "Wonder"). No, wait. The biggest annoyance was actually Justin's chapter written entirely without capital letters. Or, no--maybe the part where Auggie and Jack Will are IM-ing each other in horrible, horrible text speak. Things like that are what made me give this book 3 stars instead of 4. Anyway, I certainly don't think this book is perfect, but I can see why there's a lot of love going around for it, and why it's been picked for a number of awards and book lists. And it's well worth a read, and might just possibly cause folks to think a little harder about the way they treat other people, which I think is kind of the point. I can get behind that!
Loved this! Just loved it!
WONDERful.
I loved It!!!

This is now one of my favorite books! My 9 year old son recommended it to me and I'm so glad he did. The writing style was unique and the story was well written. I'm going to buy the book and look forward to reading it again. 
 ***Just read it again and still love it. ***
Excellent middle grade read. Love the topic being presented to kids. Easy to read, engaging story and characters. Eye-opening even for adults. Read because it is one of our best sellers for schools!
I've read a few books about dying and deformed children recently, so this one felt a bit contrived.
One of my all time favorites!

This book was one of the most important books I've read in a while. I cannot stress enough how important it is. That no matter how flawed we are on the outside, it's inside what really matters. In our hearts and our minds. Everyone is different. That's how it was always supposed to be. Otherwise the world would be so boring. No matter how old you are, you should definitely read this book. Maybe if all would read it, we would eventually be a better person. Kindness is all around us, we just have to open our hearts to see it.

Read this book with my daughter and found it to be a wonderful and true story of feeling of being 10, being "different", and being the "same". Highly recommend this book for 5th graders and up. Great book!
a heartfelt look at differences and human kindness. a must read.
Great story. Laughed, cried, was shocked. I appreciate the different viewpoints that were portrayed. Everyone had a reason for behaving the way they did.

-empathy 
 -anti-bullying 
 ....

I can't remember the last time I got so emotionally involved in a book, this story didn't just leave me a crying mess it broke my heart a little too, and I couldn't have picked a better ending for this fantastic book. 
 We have August (Auggie) ten years old a regular kid who's funny, really sweet loves his Xbox, Star Wars and reading but there's one thing that stands him apart from every other ten year old his face is deformed, he has had twenty seven surgeries on his face since he was born but he's still left with facial deformities, his eyes are halfway down his face, he has a hole inside his mouth so he can only chew with his front teeth, he has no cheekbones so his face is all sucked in and people describe it as if he'd been in a fire and his face has melted and he has pretty much no ears but can still hear. 
 After being home schooled all his life his parents decide to enrol him in grade 5 at school but Auggie doesn't want to go because he knows the reactions he'll get, the same ones he's been getting all his life from both children who sometimes scream when they see his face and adults who should know better but move themselves and their kids away when the see him. 
 Auggie also wore an astronaut helmet two years straight so no one could see his face. 
 While at his school to meet the principal before school starts he's introduced to three kids Jack, Julian and Charlotte who were asked to come in on their holidays to show Auggie around, and of course like most people are taken aback at his appearance, school starts and Auggie is excited he sits next to Jack but Julian is a mean boy and makes remarks that Auggie knows are directed at him, lunchtime comes and Auggie is sitting all alone while everyone is staring not wanting to get close in case they could somehow catch something off him because of his face which later becomes known as the Plague where everyone goes out of their way not to touch him, a girl called Summer sits down with him after initially feeling sorry for him but soon finds herself enjoying his company and becoming friends. 
 Anyone who decides to be friends with Auggie is ostracised thanks to Julian, him being in the popular clique. 
 One of the most emotional parts for me was Halloween, students were allowed to go to school in costume and at the last minute Auggie ran out of time to put his costume on so he put on his Bleeding Scream costume from the previous year and because he had a mask on no one recognized him and he overheard someone who he thought was a friend calling him names, so being all upset he pretended he was sick so he could go home,. 
 Just the anguish he went through wondering why he couldn't have a normal face like everybody else, even going camping on a school trip and he gets picked on by a bunch of kids from another school after he's been having such a good time. 
 The end I loved and I was crying tears of happiness for an ending that was perfect in my opinion and for one of the lines his Mum says to him"Thank you Auggie, for everything you've given us, for coming into our lives, for being you" (wow I started crying just typing that). 
 For all those people who have ever been bullied and who judge people on the way they look and yes I'm big enough to admit I've done it, but this book has made me sit and think for those people who have some kind of deformity they are still people too they just look a little different to you and I. 
 I can't say enough about this book, the writing was flawless and heartfelt and the author is amazing for being able to get into that mindset and believing in a character that just seemed so incredibly real and brave and courageous. 
 So please read this book it's fantastic and as Auggie would say 'cool beans'.
This book was amazing/ a wonder :) Its a kids YA book but it was so heartfelt and lovely. It made my heart melt ( I know, corny sounding) but I loved it.

It was a great book!!! first of all, i would like to point out, that of course this book deserves a lot bounch of stars, because the plot was magnificent, the characters seemed very realistic and not idealized (which i pretty much appreciate) and generally it was very well written. Though, I' ve got to confess, that the genre of this book is not my favourite, and that is the one and only reason why I give it a four-star, (because i found that it was kind of too sober for my tastes in books. i am not into paranormal books either, but in this book, there was the rougness of life being illusrtated in a very very TRUE way, so i felt that a tiny little bit of the fairytale-spirit was missing. of course the end was magnificent and i will never regret reading this amazing, heartwarming book). Furthermore, it was one of those books, that awakened so many intense feelings into me, while reading it! i found myself being terrified, cheerfull, thankfull, delighted and very very excited!!! it was a thrilling ride reading it and certainly i am very gratefull for getting the chance to peruse it! no doubt why it was nominated as a bestseller book!!! congratulations to mr. palacio for donig a great job at mesmerizing as with the tough but simultaneously excilarating adventure of augustus' life. ogi was certainly a very admiring character full of innocence, uncomparable power, high-spirit and..... BEAUTY!!!!!!!!!

Wow! What a great story with such an important message for kids! Recommend this for anyone who works with kids, has kids, and so on! We can only hope more children have the love of family, the strength of August, the empathy as Summer, and the courage as Jake. And I too would have punched Julian!

"I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 August (Auggie) Pullman was born with a facial deformity that prevented him from going to a mainstream school--until now. He's about to start 5th grade at Beecher Prep, and if you've ever been the new kid then you know how hard that can be. The thing is Auggie's just an ordinary kid, with an extraordinary face. But can he convince his new classmates that he's just like them, despite appearances? 
 This book was amazing. It was a kid book, yes, but was better then some Young Adult books I've read. I have a horrible habit of judging books because they're written for kids. I went into this book thinking,"it's just a kids book. I'll try to get through it as fast as I can." Boy, was I wrong. From the minute I picked it up, I was unable to put it down. It got to where I was up at three a.m finishing it. 
 Auggie Pullman was born with a facial deformity. He's never went to a real school. Now he can. As he start school at Beecher Prep, he gets bullied and makes new friends, but still gets the disgusted stares from classmates as he walks through the halls. Does Auggie really have what it takes to go to school facing the rude comments? 
 August was an extraordinary character. It was very nice being able to see how he handles things. I actually was shocked with how dealt with rude comments and how he would joke about the way he was born. He was an amazing character. 
 Jack Will and Summer were Auggie's two main friends. They were both sweet and always nice to Auggie. They treated him like a normal kid. Summer sat with him at lunch and Jack did end up doing that also. And Jack was in his homeroom and most of his classes so they quickly became friends. 
 Julian was a complete jerk. He was this evil twisted boy who found pleasure in making fun of August. He was always leaving rude notes in his locker, and making disgusted looks at him from across the room. He was in the "popular" crowd (if you can be popular in fifth grade.) so everyone liked him. 
 Olivia, ninth grader Augusts sister, was caring to August. She also treated him normal. She knew he was different. She just didn't act rude about it. She was a good character. But, at times, she made me disappointed and upset. 
 This story has eight parts, 1. Auggie, 2. Olivia, 3. Summer, 4. Jack, 5. Justin, Olivia's Boyfriend, 6. Auggie, 7. Miranda, Olivia's old friend, 8. Auggie. 
 My favorite POV, other then Auggie's, was Jack's. I also loved Summer's and Miranda's. I gave this book five stars and wish I could give it more. This book is a must read. If your like me and think it will be weird or stupid cause it's a kids book then prepared to be blown away by this amazing KIDS book.

This book goes straight to your heart and stays there. I feel like I've learned so much about myself and how to be a better person, all because of a fictive 10 year old boy. 
 Bravery is daring to be vulnerable and August Pullman has more bravery at the age of 10 than I'll ever get in a lifetime. 
 I'm not going to write about the story, but I will share this quote: 
 "Shall we make a new rule of life... always try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" 
 You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder.

The thing you should know before reading this middle-grade book is that it is told from multiple viewpoints. Either you like that style or you don't. I do. 5th grade is tough. But it is even tougher if you have been home schooled, and have a facial deformity that has people gawking (or worse) when you are in public. This lovely story explores themes of courage, friendship, kindness, loyalty, family and love. I'm buying a copy for all the middle graders in my life.

5th grader Auggie Pullman was born with facial abnormalities which made him the butt of unkind remarks from some of his classmates. The author takes us through Auggie's first year in a school setting - he was previously home-schooled. The transformation of his classmates and Auggie himself is awesome. I shall recommend this book to my 11-year-old grandson; it's really a life-affirming narrative for all ages.
This is the kind of book where you just want to hug everyone after reading it.
Great book to encourage empathy in all of us. Read it aloud to my 7 and 9 year olds and loved the many discussions that transpired. Feel that it changed all of us and how we look at others.

A wonderful book, I learnd so much with it and I can say that I grew as a person. I was blow away by the way that August handeled his "problem", because it wasn't a problem is was him just him. 
 Loved it, Iwill recomened to everyone.

A fabulous book! Don't let the fact that this is listed as a Young Adult book deter you. This book is so full of heart that I can't think of a single person I wouldn't strongly recommend this to. Began reading this with my 11-yr-old son and it quickly expanded into a family read-aloud. We all laughed out loud, were moved to tears and were ready to cheer at different times throughout the reading. If I could make this one required reading for all human beings, I would. One of the most "wonder"ful books I have ever read.

I really liked this one and it was especially fun to read because it was a well loved library copy. I can totally understand why this one is taught in schools. I'm very excited to see it turned into a movie.

Wonder was WONDERful!! Such a sweet inspiring story that will bring tears (happy tears) to your eyes on many occasions. The ending was perfect and I admit I had to stop reading to wipe my eyes from being so touched!

This is an exceptional book. It was recommended by a teacher and my daughter and I read it together. We both loved it. It really makes you think about how your interactions impact the world around you.
try awesome!
A very innocent and touching read, lightly written yet penetrating. Definitely an indulgent story but I somehow didn't mind it.

This review first appeared on my blog: http://www.knittingandsundries.com/20... 
 What a wonder of a book! 
 First sentence: I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid. 
 August (Auggie) is 10-year-old born with a cranio-facial abnormality that, in spite of who he is inside, makes him stand out in a crowd. 
 This is the story of his first year in school, told in the first person through various viewpoints - Auggie, his sister Olivia(Via), her boyfriend Justin, her friend Miranda, and Auggie's friends Jack and Summer. 
 I love how this story is told in a realistic, "that's just the way it is" fashion - even Via, who is a teenager, pretty much rolls with the fact that most of the attention goes to Auggie - with all of the surgeries that he has had, that's just to be expected. She's always stuck up for him, and never, until this first year of her going to a new high school, felt at all ashamed of his appearance. 
 Auggie? Well, he's just a great kid - a Star Wars fan, an XBox-playing, joke-making, pretty smart little dude who loves his family and their dog Daisy, bought off of a homeless guy for $20 by Auggie's father. He has a loving and imperfect family, he doesn't feel sorry for himself (much), and seeing the world through his eyes made this reader even more grateful and appreciative. 
 Of course we run into the casually (and not so casually) cruel kids and adults, but Auggie, who wasn't too keen on the idea of going to school, manages to make some friends, and, if he doesn't blend in, at least people get used to him. Then a boy he thought was his friend seems to turn against him, and we all feel the hurt. Another boy starts a bullying campaign, and here is where we see Auggie's true strength come to the fore. His friendships are tested, and his friends make the reader proud. 
 At the end of this book, and throughout the last pages, I was wiping away tears, the kind of tears inspired by hope and a touch of the happy. 
 This book is geared to middle readers (8-12 years old), but is definitely one that everyone should read. Teachers, homeschoolers, parents, and even adults - pick this one up - you will love it as much as I did. 
 And you will LOVE Auggie! This one will definitely be showing up on my "Best of" list for 2012; it's a winner all around. 
 QUOTES (from an ARC; may be different in final copy): 
 Auggie: I know ordinary kids don't make other ordinary kid run away screaming in playgrounds. 
 Auggie: I think it's like the Cheese Touch in "Diary of a Wimpy Kid". The kids in that story were afraid they'd catch the cooties if they touched the old moldy cheese on the basketball court. At Beecher Prep, I'm the old moldy cheese. 
 Summer: So I just went over and sat with him. Not a biggie. I wish people would stop trying to turn it into something major. 
 He's just a kid. The weirdest-looking kid I've ever seen, yes. But just a kid. 
 Writing: 5 out of 5 stars 
 Plot: 5 out of 5 stars 
 Characters: 5 out of 5 stars 
 Reading Immersion: 5 out 5 stars 
 BOOK RATING: 5 out of 5 stars
Amazing book! loved it.

I absolutely loved this book. Yes, it was a little childish, but it perfectly captured the perspectives of 10 year olds (which is quite hard, considering the POVs changed at least 5 times in the book). The entire story was heartbreaking, and I was laughing-crying throughout. I would definitely recommend it, for all age groups.

This is one AWESOME book! The theme of this book is so relevant in today's society. It really shows how bullying can hurt a student and how frustrating or turned off from school. I am glad that she wrote the book the way that she did. If I was a teacher I would make each and everyone of my students read this book. I would make every student who decides to bully someone to read this book. They may think their actions don't hurt someone but it does. This is a must read if someone has a middle schooler or high schooler.
"Tus actos son tus monumentos."

Read on the Blog 
 "Sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone." 
 My Summary: 
 August (Auggie) Pullman has wanted nothing but to be normal but with a facial deformity that causes everyone to stare at him everywhere he goes, ordinary is out of the question. 
 He's never been in a mainstream school and would never want to go until his parents tell him otherwise. 
 Being the new kid in school is challenge enough but with his extraordinary face, will he be able to show them that despite his face his just like everybody else? 
 My Thoughts:> 
 I've seen this book a year ago and I've always been interested in reading it for 2 reasons: First, I like topics regarding anomalies, I know it's weird but it's just really fascinating for me. Second, The cover really attracted me and I like kids. Okay, so that's like 3 reasons. Ooopppsss. But I always end up buying other books first until recently I bought it. It's a life changer guys. :-) 
 From the first chapter, I was already hooked. When Auggie explained that he wasn't ordinary, I felt my heart pang. I could just feel how much he wanted to be ordinary but he just can't. His words, feelings, stories, actions are just all inspiring really. 
 It's not just Auggie's point of view the book tackes but also the people closest to Auggie. With these different point of views, I was able to understand how others see him. My favorite has to be Via's (his older sister) because I can relate to her somehow. I could see how much she really loves him. But it's not just her love but Auggie's whole family's love for him that's overflowing which is why I think he's able to give love to others too. 
 Via isn't perfect. She makes mistakes too. But nevertheless, you could never deny the fact that she will always love Auggie no matter what. In a way, I feel sad for Via cause all the attention always goes to Auggie and it seems that she has to fend for herself. I would just suddenly feel the urge to cry when I read her POV. (This is a feat for me cause I'm not a cryer.) She's a very strong woman and I'm glad she has... *wink* and her Grandma. 
 Auggie's parents are just the loveliest people ever. All of Via and Auggie's friends like to go to their house because they can feel the love. It's in the air. I love households like that. My sisters, my mom and I are really close and I can relate to this overflowing love that their parent's give them cause I'm a full tank as well. 
 In his new school, he starts making friends. Summer is just this cute little girl who befriends Auggie. She's amazing. At such a young age, I could say that she'll grow up to be this wonderful & beautiful human being. 
 Jack Will. He was nice to Auggie and they started talking all the time which lead to them being best friends. Something happens that broke my heart into a kajillion pieces... but then he tells his part of the story that seemed to mend my broken heart. 
 Mr Browne. He's this genius of an English teacher. Love him and his precepts! He speaks the truth. You guys will love him too! 
 Seriously, guys, this is the book I recommend everyone to read. I mean EVERY single human being in the world. The heart of this book is for us to be kind. You might say you already know that. It's pretty obvious. But the important thing in this book is that we are reminded of it. There are so many things happening in our lives that we simply forget the most important thing... Who we are--- what kind of people we are. 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind. Choose kind." 
 At the end of the day, how you treat people is what really matters. The genre of Childrens might scare you off but give this book a chance. This is a wonderful book and yes, you should read this. Auggie has definitely left imprints on my heart. The ending of this book is just heart warming so prepare to have tissues when you read this! 
 Highly recommended! 
 Happy Reading!!!

Wonder is one of the books that makes you believe in humanity. 
 We are all humans after all. We tend to make mistakes. We judge before we realize that we are judging. What's great is that we have a chance to make it right. And like in the book, we should be kinder than necessary.

"The things we do outlast our mortality. The things we do are like monuments that people build to honor heroes after they've died. They're like the pyramids that the Egyptians built to honor the pharaohs. Only instead of being made of stone, they're made out of the memories people have of you."
LOVED it! I would recommend grade 5 and up. Great book.
It's amazing. Wonder is amazing. If you didn't know, and you should, this book is amazing. So now you know. Go read it.

I loved this book. I loved the characters, I loved the story told from different points of view (although I was resistant to the changing POV at first, I loved being able to see situations from different characters' perspective and it really helped round out the story.) I think this is a must-read for everyone. I'll be encouraging my kids to read it for sure! 
 My favorite Auggie Pullman quote: ""I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." <3 <3 <3

On the inside, August is a normal 10 year old boy. Born with severe facial deformities, he has been home schooled until now. This is the story of his first year at school. 
 Wonder is told from a variety of first person perspectives, starting with August himself. Things don't seem all that bad from his point of view and as you read on you get the sense that he has really come to terms with how he looks and what people think of him. I was thinking everyone seems far too kind to be real but that is only how he sees it. 
 It's only when you get to his sister Via's narrative that you are told what August looks like and get a real sense of the reactions towards him. It seems odd that August's condition isn't named and Via goes so far to say it doesn't even have a name. I wonder if this is to deter younger readings from googling images? August does in fact have Treacher Collins Syndrome, in which the facial bones fail to develop fully in the womb. This causes a number of problems including difficulty with breathing, eating and even hearing as the inner ear is made up of tiny bones. However mentally, people with TCS are just like anyone else. 
 The story is also told from the point of view of August's friends, Summer and Jack, and Via's friend Miranda and boyfriend Justin. I get that Justin was used as an outside perspective but his section is told in lower case and without speech marks which made it hard to follow. It makes the point that August's family don't judge on appearances but I really don't see the point in the change of style. Justin suffers from a tic and the writing style makes you think he may have learning difficulties but does this not go against the whole point of the book, do not judge people on things outside of their control? 
 The alternating narrators are otherwise used to great effect. It is all about perspectives and goes to show what we display on the outside is not always what's going on inside our heads. Personally, I would have liked one of the parents' perspective but there does seem an unwritten rule in young adult that anyone over 20 doesn't get a featured role. Also all the narrators are very sympathetic characters, it would have been interesting to know what was going on in Julian's head. 
 I was glad that Palacio included the passage where Jack's little brother is scared of August. When I think back on all the things I was scared of when I was little, disfigured faces were high up on the list. Not in a malicious way or even a learned fear, it is something that is instinctive. The first time I watched The Goonies, Sloth terrified me, and he turns out to be one of the good guys. It is of course awful for August that he is feared, but it is one of the most real parts of the story. 
 There are some really moving parts but I think the bullying is watered down a little to what it would be in reality. Kids can be cruel but even the bully character, Julian, seems sanitised. Either they seem too mature for their age or they are not old enough to have developed the bitchiness that comes with hormones and peer pressure. The ending was too unbelievable for me but works as a moral message.

3,5 
 Un libro con un buen mensaje, frases muy hermosas. 
 Disfrute mucho leyendo a Via :) 
 Encuentro que todos los ninos deberian leer esto.

Wonder was recommended to me by Jillian at Heise Reads, and I can't begin to say enough how incredible this novel is. August is a boy born with severe facial deformities and finally has the opportunity to attend school. He's accepted into an exclusive private school in NYC, but not everyone is thrilled he's been admitted. Even August isn't sure attending fifth grade is such a good idea. To say what he endures is horrific is an understatement. Kids stare at him, whisper in front of him, and are terrified of him. August loves Halloween because it's the only time he can "fit in." Heartbreaking. But not all is bad in his life. He has loving parents, a sister who cherishes him, and a few true friends. Still, to read this story, you'll see life through completely different eyes and wonder how often people are judged first and foremost by appearance. I dare you not to fall in love with Auggie. I did. 
 If you haven't read Wonder, put it on top of your list. Even though it's a MG book, everyone of all ages will be touched by it. 
 For an outstanding review, check out Jillian's at: http://www.heisereads.com/2012/09/mmg...

This New York Times Bestseller is one of the best, well-written, books I've ever read. Yes, it's designed for middle schoolers, but anybody 10 years and up would appreciate this book. R.L. Palacio, the author, writes with just the right balance of humor and pathos, making each character both flawed and sympathetic. She understands kids -- how they think, how they talk, how they have the capacity to be both horribly mean and incredibly brave and kind. I recognize these characters from my childhood, my children, my grandchildren and my years of teaching. The book is so authentic. The short chapters and shifting narrative make this a quick, easy read. It's a feel-good book with a great message, and the ending is a tearjerker that will leave a sweet, sweet feeling in your heart for a long time.

I read this story aloud with my 3rd grade kiddo as our bedtime story and we both really loved it! It's a story about being kind to others and understanding what it means to be a true friend and a nice person. 
 This story is about Auggie Pullman, a soon to be 5th grader who is going to school for the first time. He was born with facial defects that required extensive surgeries early on in his life and has deep scarring on his face and ears. Thus making middle school that much harder for him. This is soon to be a motion picture & I highly recommend as a great lighthearted read [?]
Dit boek was fantastisch, ik ben blij dat ik dit boek in een dag uit heb gelezen want dit boek had ik voor geen goud willen missen! Binnenkort kun je een uitgebreidere recensie lezen op mijn blog!
I rounded up from a 4.5. I appreciate that at it's heart this book is really just about being kind to one another.

Wonder was hard to put down. Auggie is adorable, the story is warm and all the characters real. R. J. Palacio, when she signed my paperback at Edbookfest was lovely too. The reason for four stars, and I'd really like that to be four and a half stars, is that it slid into schmalz towards the end. I definitely wanted a happy ending but I felt the conflict resolved itself a little too early and there on it just became a little sickly sweet.
Hollow, ham-handed moralizing (to paraphrase: choose being kind over being right). Most of the characters' voices sounded the same. The plot was unrealistic.
Such an inspiring book. Life is so hard and good people make it all worth while. Be nice to everyone no matter how different. Don't just be kind be extra kind.
Me encanto, es de esos libros que mientras lee te cambia la manera de ver muchas cosas.

Such a good book. When my teacher was reading it everyone loved it. We talked about how thee characters changed and we talked about that you shouldn't judge people by their looks. Get to know them! Because Uggie had a problem with his face and everyone talked about it. His sister, Via, wanted more attention from her parents because Uggie gets most of their attention. Uggie was once home schooled but now he's in school and he's having trouble with bully's. But does he change this, oh yes. If you want to know read the wonderous book of Wonder!
Absolutely fabulous middle-grade book. Have tissues handy.

This is a fabulous story. It is definitely a "two tissue" book--have a box of tissues nearby for some of the scenes. I liked how the story was told from many different points of view (the main character, his sister, the sister's boyfriend, and his school friend Jack). I think this book should be mandatory reading in all jr high schools. I highly recommend it

"Like a lamb to the slaughter": Something that you say about someone who goes somewhere calmly, not knowing that something unpleasant is going to happen to them." 
 Wonder is the story of August Pullman. Entering fifth grade is scary. Entering fifth grade after years of being homeschooled is even scarier. But entering fifth grade after years of being homeschooled because you were born looking differently from others is the scariest. In this story, we are taken through Auggie's first year at school. Throughout, we learn why Auggie looks the way he does. We learn the struggles of his daily life, along with his sisters & her boyfriends, and even a couple of his new friends at school. 
 What I enjoyed most about the book was that it did not hold back. It showed the inner ugliness of some people in this world, but it did not fail to show the complete and utter kindness of others too. Auggie is my favorite character in this book for so many reasons. The fact that he is loving, understanding, resilient, and absolutely hysterical are only just a few. This book made me laugh, made me cry and at times, made my blood boil. 
 All in all I thoroughly enjoyed this story. While this book is certainly geared towards late elementary, middle school, and high schoolers..do not count out YA or adults. It can teach everyone a lesson on being kind because lets face it; you do not only have to be young to be taught kindness.

Este libro se a convertido en uno de mis favoritos, sabia que no me decepcionaria, pero no crei que me gustara tanto, me cambio la forma de ver las cosas, lo ame demasiado, ahora mi hermano pequeno se lo esta leyendo y creo que le esta gustando

This book brought so many different emotions. I think some of the characters were given importance in the beginning and middle of the novel and then stopped really playing a part in the book. However, I still thought it was a sweet book, and I enjoyed it.

I loved this book! Every kid should read it and every adult too. Insightful, touching, and realistic but optimistic. A real reminder of the importance of kindness, how much there is of it in the world, and still how far we have to go. Auggie was an enchanting character that you fall in love with immediately, but it does make you "wonder" how much longer it would take you in real life to overcome appearances. It definitely teaches some important lessons without being preachy and still being entertaining; what children's fiction should be.

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." 
 I picked up Wonder when I found out it was going to be adapted as a movie this fall. Yes, I'm one of those people who only reads a book once it's going to be a film, but whatever. I always like giving the book a chance before I see the movie, and I'm sure many of you can relate. Anyway, I started this book on a whim and was pleasantly surprised by it. 
 Much of the book feels as though it were narrated by children, and that's because it is. Auggie is only in fifth grade, and the writing style in his chapters reflects that really well. Auggie cares about the things kids his age care about: Star Wars, friends, school, and his family. There's a sweet naivete to his narration, and yet the story is still strikingly profound at points. I was thoroughly impressed by Palacio's ability to weave childhood innocence into a complex understanding of human nature. Also, Wonder is by no means a children's book. That is to say, children can read and enjoy it, but so can adults and readers of all ages. 
 The novel doesn't just include Auggie's POV. Part two of the novel is narrated by Auggie's older sister, Via, who has just started high school. She gives an interesting perspective from the "other" child's point of view. The third and fourth parts are told by Summer and Jack, two of the students he attends school with. Despite the young narrators, the actions and opinions of adults play a big role in the story. It was interesting to view parents through the eyes of their children, and I was impressed by Palacio's ability to show multiple points of view throughout his story. 
 I won't lie. Not much actually happens in Wonder. There's no big climax, no life-or-death situations. The story mostly revolves around Auggie and his friends and family as they make their way through everyday life. At points, I kind of wished for a little more action, but I also understand why Palacio weaved the story this way. Every day requires bravery for these characters and plenty of people in the world, and Palacio really taps into that ordinary strength. 
 Overall, Wonder was definitely an interesting break from the typical novels I read. It's lighthearted and amusing, and you'll definitely walk away from it feeling as though the world might not be such a bad place after all.

"Something you just can't explain. You don't even try. You don't know where to start. All your sentences would jumble up like a giant knot if you opened your mouth. Any words you used would come out wrong" - Wonder 
 And that, right there, sums up my reaction to this book for me. It is, in short, beautiful. August, who was born with a major facial deformity, must face the real world as he begins mainstream 5th grade. His family needs almost as much support facing this new adventure as he does. But August thrives, changing everyone around him. 
 This is a book for EVERYONE. I think any patron with the ability to read this book should. Suggest it to anyone asking "What's a good book for me to read?"

I'd been wanting to read this book for a while now, but was afraid that it wouldn't quite live up to my expectations. I was definitely wrong. It far exceeded them. 
 I used to work with youth, and in particular special needs youth. One particular moment always comes back to me, and made this book hit especially close to home. There was a young girl who was just going into the sixth grade that has Asberger's. We had a sleepover weekend and she was put into a group of "normal" girls that she had never met before. At first, I will fully admit, I thought she was just as annoying as everyone else. She talked at all the inappropriate times, she talked about weird things that no one else could understand, and she couldn't form any emotional attachments to any of the other girls. 
 But she was just a little girl. 
 About half way through the weekend, she had a massive breakdown. She came bawling to me saying, "People think that I can't tell that I'm weird, but I know I am. I know I'm not normal. I can't help it. Everyone is always looking at me funny and I hate it. I can't help it. I really can't help it. They think I can't tell, but I know they're staring." I seriously think those words will haunt me for the rest of my life. 
 If reading this book helps even one person to be kind to someone else... or rather, kinder than is necessary, this book is worth it. Thank you, R.J. Palacio for expressing what so many cannot!
verry good book.
Loved it. Excellent book.

There is a reason that this book has won awards. It is a book that all kids should read right before they go into fourth or fifth grade. It is written from the point of view of a disfigured boy who endures bullying when he starts at a new school. This is eye-opening and heart-warming.

Wonder is about a 5th grade boy who enters middle school after having been homeschooled all his life. A genetic malady has grossly deformed his face. The novel is an expose about the capability of human beings to be cruel or kind, and the difference between inner and outer beauty. 
 Auggie has a rough time at the start. Only a few brave students have the guts to talk to him. The novel takes place over a school year. Things happen but this is not a book with much of a plot. The novel is more about a state change with the students surrounding Auggie. 
 Palacio says she was inspired to write the novel because she turned to see a young child sitting on a bench eating ice cream who was deformed like Auggie. She pulled her daughter away and then thought back on her actions. That night she began writing Wonder. A scene in the novel reenacts her own actions but seen from Auggie's POV. 
 It's first person, limited POV and Palacio wisely moves it to different people from one chapter to the next. The first third of the book was Auggie's POV only and I think the novel would have failed had she not had other narrators. 
 There's no scintillating action. The end is somewhat predictable. There are some memorable lines, like "Everyone at one time in their life should receive a standing ovation." But the book has touched many people because we all, I suspect, to a lesser extent on the outside, but perhaps to the same extent on the inside, have had to deal with other's opinions of ourselves. 
 Wonder gives us a very upbeat view of human nature: that most of us eventually gravitate to kindness instead of cruelty. Auggie is the catalyst for people to discover the kind part of themselves. Finally, the kids grow to like Auggie not because it's cool, or it looks meritorious to do so. They do because Auggie is as beautiful and kind on the inside, as he is unattractive on the outside. Auggie is a one of-a-kind, a wonder.
Funny, brave, heart-breaking, and uplifting. Read it and weep. And laugh. And cheer. For ten-year-old Auggie Pullman really is a wonder. Just beautiful.

I kinda feel like I'm joining team Julian right now, but it wasn't the right book for me. 
 The book was quite simple. It's not a bad thing, but I like being emotionally challenged. This time the only moment I was moved was saying goodbyes to Daisy. Reading Olivia's point of view might have been the most interesting part of the book. 
 It was too calm. It had its ups and downs, but in the end we got a nice picture we can cheer for. It was nice to the point of losing reality. Kids are cruel creatures and there are more Julians in this world than we'd like to think. I'm sorry to say that but that was in the back of my mind every time I was getting the sweet family picture.

"Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 This is the kind of story that should be read by everyone, from children to adults because it teaches many valuable lessons, and most importantly it shows us what it's like to be in someone else's shoes. 
 The storyoif Auggie is different because he's simply different, we witness his experience in life and also the experience of the people around him, from family to school mates. So we got to read the story from different POV, the chapters are also very short and keep changing between characters which made this easy and fun to read. 
 This story was packed with so many emotions, I nearly cried at some parts and laughed at others, 
 The writing was beautiful and fun, i finished this so fast and could not put it down, i never got bored and always wanted to have more. I rarely enjoy realistic stories but this one is brilliant and fun. 
 And I will always try to remember to be kinder, because being just kind is not enough.
Review to come

Historia dulce de un nino con una malformacion congenita (Sindrome de Treacher-Collins). Con facilidad para leer, muy dulce con un hermoso mensaje, que realmente me dio un poco mas de fe en la humanidad. Mis personajes favoritos fueron Via y la perrita Daisy. El libro realmente te deja una gran leccion, no importa la edad que tengamos siempre hay que tratar de "cultivar el arte de ser amables". De mis preceptos favoritos--> "El mas grande es aquel, cuya fuerza conquista mas corazones con la atraccion del suyo propio".

This is an amazing book that everyone should read. I was hesitant at first because of the subject matter - the main character has a serious facial anomaly that makes him look very different, and he's attending mainstream school for the first time ever. Sounds like a sad book, right? And I don't do sad books. Not to mention that having a child with special needs makes me extra sensitive to the way kids treat those who are different. 
 But I was pleasantly surprised. I think I cried multiple times, but at least some of the time, it was a happy cry. The story is awesome. My only critique is that the changing narrator format was too much at times. However, it didn't detract much. If you haven't read it yet, do it now!

This book really moved me. It made me realize how lucky I am for being the person I am today. 
 The last part of the book where Auggie and his Mom were talking to each other was just emotional. 
 Auggie's story is just inspiring. GREAT BOOK! Highly recommend it to everyone!
4.5 this was really good

I loved this book! We read it aloud with the whole family, and it's the first book I've found that my 10 year old, 8 year old, and 6 year old all listened to with rapt attention. At some points of the book, I had to stop reading because I got choked up, and was surprised to find my 6 year old boy was also tearing up. It is a great look into how other people feel, and how to treat people who are different than you. From a middle school teacher position, I really feel like everyone who works with kids, and the kids themselves should read this book. I loved how REAL the book was. It showed the students real responses to someone who is different. Some kids were real jerks, other kids were great, and most kids just kind of sat by and did nothing. Great book!
Incredible story. Loved the first person narration and author's craft moves!

4.5

 This may be labeled as a middle grade book, which is true about most of its protagonists. But it is certainly for adults as well, especially for those who have lost hope in the world. 
 4.10 stars
Interesting, but more like a YA book.
Awesome story, great characters -- I loved reading this book even though I cried through most of the second half. Not because it was sad. More because the story just touched me. Highly recommended.

Wow! I received this book for Christmas, and I didn't think it looked like "my kind of book," but it sucked me with the first page and didn't let me go until I finished. Beautiful and brave, this novel spoke volumes about courage and friendship. 
 However, I almost gave it a 4 because a terribly cynical part of me doesn't quite jive with the ending . . . but I don't want to spoil it for anyone. Let's just say it went a bit Disney in the last four or five chapters and although I believe that people can change, I'm not sure that masses of people can change that quickly without God's intervention. 
 So, it's a 4.5 for me leaning into 5 because it is so beautifully and wonderfully written.
The best children's book of the year. Deeply moving and very rewarding. August is a character not to be pitied, but to be celebrated. Highly recommend.

http://readingpassport.wordpress.com/ 
 Wonder is the first novel by book cover designer and artistic director R. J. Palacio. It has been all the rave on book blogs and recommendation sites since its publication last year so naturally it has been on my TBR (To Be Read) list for a while. 
 The book tells the story of August Pullman who, with a stroke of bad genetic luck, was born with a rare disease that seriously deforms his face. Of course, people treat him differently because of that. His loving parents and older sister, however, have showered little Auggie with love and have given him the childhood that most children his age could only dream of. He has grown into an extraordinary young man. If only he lived in a society that didn't judge a book by its cover... 
 It's time now for August to leave the comforts of home and go to school with "regular kids." Middle school , of all places! Will little Auggie be able to survive? How will his classmates treat him? 
 The author expertly chronicles August's first year in middle school through the eyes of August himself and those closest to him. There are definitely parts of the novel that will pull at the reader's heart-strings. By the end, readers will marvel at August's bravery and, perhaps, learn to appreciate the normalcy in their own lives. 
 Verdict: Loved, loved, loved this book! Highly recommended!

Excellent, excellent, excellent. 
 This book is 5 stars. I think that every fifth and sixth grader should read this book, and I hope that my future students do. Through massive character development all around, this book shows what kindness is. It shows bravery and courage, standing up for yourself and your friends. The values taught in this story are irreplaceable. 
 The book takes a disorder and, unlike other modern children's/YA lit, writes about what the character goes through. Palacio doesn't use Auggie's face as a means to something else. 
 Wonder also offers a great look at WHY kids do the things that they do...it is rarely for no reason, and is always related to some external problem that they are experiencing on their own. Miranda is not simply a bad friend to Via because she just wants to be, there is something deeper. Summer isn't just a beautiful, bi-racial girl. She has a story. While Auggie is the central character in this book, each one is well-developed and grows throughout the story. 
 This book, to me, is a reminder of why I want to teach middle school. Middle schoolers are going through a hectic, confusing time. But they are good kids. Each one of them is going through something so different, it is so hard to blame them for their actions in school. I have seen the power of kindness growing up in public school and now in my own classrooms, and things like this do happen. Kids come together. It is truly amazing and it's one of the reasons I want to be a teacher one day. I have so much faith in those kids.
This book was so cute but powerful at the same time, it was amazing

What a little gem it was. 
 This book has been sitting on my shelf for many months and now that I finally picked it up, I wonder why I haven't done it before. 
 "Wonder" was SO refreshing and unique. The concept and the characters are very interesting and I love how the story is told from so many different prospectives (none of which was uninteresting or irrelevant) that help you get a clear idea of the sequence of events. 
 The author also does a great job in managing to make the reader love August and care for him. He's sweet, fun, kind and smart at the same time. Probably one of the most likable characters I've ever read about. 
 This novel also teaches a moral lesson or two, which is always nice. 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." 
 This might come out corny, but I am a huge supporter of spreading positive messages about being nice to each other, like this precept, and seeing that in books just makes me very happy. 
 Surprisingly, I really enjoyed reading from a 10 year old's POV. I'm new to the middle-grade genre and this was a great start. I'm very amused. 
 I highly suggest this because I think it's something everyone would enjoy, whether they're 12 or 70.
Great book not only from the perspective of a physically disabled child, but also showing his family and friends' perspectives-the good and the bad of a difficult issue.

A must read! 
 If you don't cry, laugh, or get mad along with Auggie than you don't have a heart.

Such an amazing book. My ten year old son read it in school and told me all about it. I read the entire thing tonight. Laughed, cried and more then anything truly appreciated how beautiful we all are.
This book is WONDERful :)

"I wish every day could be Halloween. We could all wear masks all the time. Then we could walk around and get to know each other before we got to see what we looked like under the masks." - Auggie Pullman 
 Wow, just wow. I did not expect this book to have this much of an impact on me. But that's what I love about it. I love to read those books where after finishing, you're still thinking about it. And that's what R.J Palacio's book 'Wonder' did to me. 
 'Wonder' is a story that starts off by being told by fifth grader August Pullman who's starting school again. He was born with a face deformation and believes that he'll never fit in at his new school. This is such a touching and emotional story where we get to see the vulnerability that's known to follow August around through his life. 
 But that's not it, we also get to hear from several other voices in this story. Via, augusts sister, shares her feelings and actions. It's like a whole different side of the story and even though Via is lucky enough to not have been born with the same medical issues as her brother, she too has many problems and difficulties going on in her life. Then there's also Some of Augusts friends like Summer and Jack Will too. 
 We even get to hear from some others that don't even play a really main role in the story, like Via's friend Miranda and Via's boyfriend Justin. Even though these characters don't play huge roles in the book, their point of view still leaves a huge impact on you. 
 This is a book where I'm hungry to find out more and there's never a dull moment. It has made my fully appreciate my life and how fortunate I am today. 
 "So doesn't that make the world a giant lottery then? You purchase a ticket when you're born. And it's all just a random whether you get a good ticket or a bad ticket. it's all just luck. 
 Author R.J Palacio has definitely opened our eyes around some issues like bullying and has taught us about living life to its fullest, and being grateful with what you have. But above all, she's taught us how important a single word is: kindness. To be kinder than is necessary. 
 And lastly, "everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world."

Auggie is a boy who's been homeschooled for a his whole life, and he's entering a real school for the first time this year. He and his family are understandibly nervous, since Auggie was born with major facial deformities. 
 That's the basic setting of Wonder, a book that hits all the right emotional notes while remaining realistic about the cruelty and kindness of young children and the adults that surround them. It's a book that has a message while also having a good, coherent, and worthwhile story. 
 If I have any complaint, it's that it ties itself together a little too easily and maybe shouldn't have, but considering the age group this is geared toward, I can let that slide. Definitely something everyone should read.

This book ripped out my heart, cut it in pieces, and then sowed it back together. It waS amazing. Definitely one of my favorite books. I'd get angry at how august was treated and I just wanted to hold him and tell him everything was going to be okay. I cried multiple times. Overall I loved this book! How it was written. The different perspectives. The character developments. This book was a breath of fresh air.

What a great story! Although I read this with 5th graders, I think it is a story everyone should read. Told from different perspectives, you read about the life of August, a young boy who has serious facial abnormalities, and how he gets through his first year of middle school (a feat for all kids). This book teachers great lessons to all ages, especially to kids in upper elementary/middle school!

Excellent. I would recommend this book to everyone. This is a book that could receive a Schneider award. I hope it gets nominated. It opens one's perspective on how we look at people and how we can be more accepting of those who are different.

Well... 
 This is a nice, heart-warming story, but let's be honest, it is totally unrealistic.
"Shall we make a new rule of life always to try to be a little kinder that is necessary?"
I loved this book. It was a wonderful picture of what it was like to live with a kid that doesn't look the same.

Amazing. I haven't loved a book this much since The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-time Indian. Funny, touching, heart-breaking, sincere, moving, what other excellent-review-type-words can I put in here? This is a must-read. Of course, I've got it pre-ordered for my library and I have emailed our middle school librarian and a couple other middle school teachers as well, to let them know that this baby needs to be on their list of purchases. I can't say enough good things about it. 
 August was born with a not one, but two genetic abnormalities that caused his face to be severely deformed. After a ton of surgeries he still claims that he doesn't look anything near "normal" and people still stop and stare when seeing him for the first time. Partly because of all of the surgeries and partly to protect him from the not-so-nice world, August's parents have homeschooled him for the first years of his life. Now, August (Auggie) is going to middle school, the private Beecher Prep, close to his home in Manhattan. This is a coming of age story and yet so much more than that. Auggie is such a brave dude, but he is also human and this makes the story so real that it is impossible not to cry and laugh thoughout the book. 
 The story is told from a few different points of view: Auggie's, his sister Via's, Via's boyfriend's, Via's former best friend's and the POVs of a couple of Auggie's new friends from Beecher. Each one of these characters is written so well, I wished that there could be a whole book written from each of their points of view. 
 There are many characters to despise, Ximena and Julian, for example, but other than those toadstools, is very easy to be sympathetic to each of the other characters, even when they do things that make one cringe. 
 I loved, loved, loved Wonder. This book HAS to be the Newbery. Seriously. It is that good.

Astounding! A Must Read! I picked this book up with the intention of reading it for about 10 min before bookmarking for the night. Three and a half hours later I finally stood up having finished the book and now have a new favorite book ever. Please, don't miss the chance to experience this book!

This book is an extremely important and powerful read for all ages, as it portrays the story of a young boy being accepted into the world for something other than the facial deformity he was born with. I loved how this novel contained multiples different POVs, as I think that really added to the overall effectiveness of the story. I know this may sound harsh, but I found this book too happy, too nice at times. With the life the main character leads, he most likely experienced more emotional turmoil than was portrayed, and I wish that would have been explored a bit more. Overall though, this story is very important for everyone to read and is a incredibly touching novel.
Wow-- one of my new faves. I'm going to miss this character and all of his friends. That's a true sign that it was a GREAT read. "Standing Ovation" for R.J. Palacio!

I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives 
 This story should be read by everyone and there pets because this book was just amazing and blew me away. This story has many valuable lessons to be learnt and i feel that everyone will walk away from this story with a new perspective on life because of this story. 
 I cried and i laughed throughout this entire book and learnt so many valuable lessons that this book put fourth. The writing was amazing and it impacted me so much that it managed to make me cry and that rarely ever happens in books for me. 
 Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness. 
 The story is a quick read and the POV change from multiple characters but you get a real sense of each character on what there feeling at different times in the book. Every single character was very well-written and fleshed out which made it enjoyable to read and there was no one character that i didn't like. 
 if you ever get the chance to read this book please do it because it has changed my perspective on so many things. Please be Kind and Think about your actions because they can have a lasting impact on someones life.

Perfect for fifth grade, but others (including this adult) will enjoy it, too. Different perspectives show kids' honest and personal struggles for acceptance.
Very fascinating and realistic book! There are so many things that I find relatable to the lead character also being in middle school.
Everyone should read this book.
I definitely wish I would have read this earlier in life. Beautiful book with a beautiful message. Definitely a must-read young adult novel.

This book is about a boy named Auggie who has a facial deformity. He has been homeschooled for his whole life until he started grade 5 where his parents decided whether to send him to public school. This book is told in one year (his 5th grade year) and told in more than one perspective. 
 I enjoyed this book very much and I loved how the story line played out. Auggie is a sweet little boy despite his facial deformity and gets bullied quite a lot because of it. Sometimes he's ashamed and sometimes he's not and this story basically shows the readers how one person can overcome something so big, something that causes other people to look at you in a different way. 
 Auggie is mature for a fifth grader and the fact that some of the students (the other characters) look past his deformity and focus more on his personality makes me wish that it would happen in real life. Nowadays, people don't really care about personalities, they focus more on looks and I think this middle grade novel really teaches a lesson! Especially with students at this age, it's great to teach them lessons like this at a younger age.

WHY CAN'T I WRITE HAPPY?? I just finished an inspiring book -- WONDER by R. J. Palacio -- a middle grade novel about a young boy, Auggie Pullman, with a rare genetic facial deformity and his first year in middle school -- and spoiler alert -- it all turns out okay. There are cool inspirational quotes along the way such as "You're gonna reach the sky..Fly... Beautiful child," from the Eurythmics "Beautiful Child." Different characters struggle with his deformity -- his own, his sister's, his best friend's -- and except for a handful of stock bullying bad kids -- they all turn out to be good, kind kids and see past what is obvious -- and to the inner self of Auggie. I envied his parents -- hard-working, caring, decent people -- a mother who said all the right things. At the end, his class gives him a standing ovation at the graduation ceremonies. Auggie soars. I loved this novel. I cried. I cheered. It's a novel to read with your kids. But I could never write it -- never, ever. 
 I think to write a happy novel -- one with characters that are essentially good people with decent values--one had to live a life filled with people who are essentially good. For the most part, I didn't have those kind of people in my life growing up except for my Pop. He was a good father, a good man, too often overwhelmed with being a single parent. His words of wisdom were blunt: the way you make your bed is the way you'll sleep in it. I love him still for trying. 
 I don't know if R. J. Palacio had a happy life or not -- but I know that mine was broken. One way I've put it back it back together is writing. Even so, the pieces are never as happy as WONDER. But I'm thankful there are writers like her that can write 'happy' -- a wonder to me. Caroline 
 look for my new novel: 
 BEFORE MY EYES 
 coming out in February, 2014 
 from St. Martin's Press 
 www.carolinebock.comLie

I loved this book it was so awesome we read it in our class and my teacher started crying at the last page because she loved it ;) I wish we could her from that meanie old julina's point of view though loved it

What a great little read.! 
 A touching tale of strength, childhood and bravery. I really loved that the story was told from multiple perspectives. It felt very real, as if the story was told from these people. 
 Look forward to seeing what the author releases.

Let me just say, if my younger sister didn't nag me to read this, I never would've. But I'm so glad she did because it was such a wonderful book! (See what I did there?) It was much more light-hearted than I expected, the alternating viewpoints were interesting and I really enjoyed how it ended on such a positive note. It kind of reminded me of A Silent Voice

Wonder is unquestionably a wonderful book. 
 "My name is August, by the way. I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probable worse." 
 Just a pinch of it, this is a story of a 10 year old boy who had an inborn genetic conflict that affected his face. Because of that, people looked at him differently. He was frequently judged and misunderstood. So damn hard for a boy who had no idea that he'll be born that way! No one likes what happened. It was inevitable, so he lived most of his life thinking low of himself because people don't even want to look at him, talk to him, and touch him. Much worse is that they don't even want to go anywhere near him. On the bright side, he has his family who loves him wholeheartedly for the way he is. 
 "She said soft words that I know were meant to help me, but words can't change my face." 
 Auggie isn't ordinary. He is special despite the way people see him, which made me think that we limit our minds on what the media and the modern environment tell us (like the standard of beauty, what is normal or different and what is acceptable or not). We judge based on our own standards and perceptions while we exclude God's other creations behind. 
 "I thought I was used to those kinds of stares by now, but I guess I wasn't." 
 It seems very difficult to be in August's shoes. All he wanted was to be accepted. It's hard to live every day when people call you names and look at you like you are a carrier of an epidemic. Well, he swallowed being mistreated for years. That's how strong Auggie is. Notwithstanding, Auggie is an enjoyable character. He is funny, intelligent, kind, and HE IS A NORMAL 10 YEAR OLD BOY. It's just that he is judged without knowing the real him. He's is viewed narrowly based on his outer appearance. 
 As I read, I was shocked that the POV changed from most of the characters of the story. Every person shed a light on August's life. This is good because I was able to know the perceptions of the other characters. It made me realize that everyone has his or her story. Everyone is different from each other. Everyone has a battle to face. Everyone has sacrifices to make. All people have their own burdens and feelings. We don't know each other's story, so why do we judge beforehand? 
 Indeed, this book is very inspiring, light and uplifting. Some parts made me cry (while I was riding a bus to school), some melted my heart, and some made me laugh. It can definitely move people of every age. This heartwarming story teaches a lot of values that are necessary in life that will let you look at things in a different light. It is an eye opener for us to choose being good ALL THE TIME to ALL PEOPLE. We must not let differences be hindrances. Instead, we must appreciate and embrace such. This has the power to change readers. 
 " 'Shall we make a new rule of life... always try to be a little kinder than necessary?' " 
 Thank you also R.J. Palacio for writing this book and for inspiring a lot of people including me. Well, especially for all of the wonders out there who are experiencing this. You are all great! :-) 
 Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world. 
 *Sorry for my crappy review. Economics sucked all of my ideas.* -_____-

This is by far one of the best books I have ever read! I think everyone should read it, August is a great character and i fell in love with him straight away. Also, the chapters are short which is always good!
Maravilhoso. Um livro com uma mensagem muito importante.
Great read. Would be perfect for a book discussion.
Best book ever . Stunning.
Son 4.5 estrellas para ser exactos
Destined to become a classic middle grade read.

** spoiler alert ** 
 Sad. 
 August has trouble at school so Palacio gives him loving parents. She nails the 'we need balance' thing perfectly. he has a sister who is very protective of him.But August's life is hard and Palacio introduces a spunky hero. 
 Told from six points of view, Wonder is an amazing novel, not one to miss. 
 It has a lot of dialogue but it makes the reader enter the world. 
 When Daisy dies, its got to be the saddest part in the book, besides Jack going behind Augusts back on Halloween and talking badly about him to Juian, the boy who was very rude to August. 
 Recommended to: Anyone who feels their life is unfair, to people who enjoy books filled with sadness but potent happiness and the power of friends. 
 *Wonder Rules* 
 Key Points: 
 -Justin is mean to August. 
 -If you touch August, you have the Plague. 
 -Julian is cool.(Not.) 
 -Summer is August's friend. 
 -Jack punches Julian because he asks the teacher to be Jacks partner because Jacks partner for the science fair is August. 
 SOunds good? It is.

Loved 
 Best book I have read all year...maybe in the last couple years. It has been a long while since a book has touched me so much. Simply written, but the heart behind the writing was felt in every word. I giggled, I growled, I bawled. (Yes these are the measurements I use to how good a book is...the emotional reaction it provokes in me.) 
 This is going into a top tier on my "to read again" list. It was amazing!

I really, really, really love this book. It's such a happy story and something "real"! (I mean something "real" as something you can relate to, because this isn't a biography of some boy's life and his "condition" isn't real, but it was based off a girl RJ Palacio saw at an ice cream shop.) RJ Palacio got the whole middle-school hierarchy right, and I can visualize the characters and the school. It's a feel-good story with lots of detail, greatly written and well thought out. One of my favorites. 
 Also, there is another Wonder story on iBooks called The Julian Chapter. It's about Julian's point of view and the story on how everything turned out in the end (this is me trying to be vague) and it's a really nice addition to Wonder.
An incredible story that leaves you with a good taste, incredible not to cry with the plot you will simply fall in love with this book.
Heart warming and funny.

Wonder is one of those books that I knew I would kick myself for not reading sooner. I meant to read it during the school year, while all my students were singing its praises and the middle school in our district was even reading it as a 1 book, 1 school project. Yet, I didn't. I read it right after school ended. I would highly suggest keeping a tissue box nearby. There are some amazing moments in this book and the book is from several points of view, giving insight into how Auggie, his older sister, and a few other characters felt throughout the book's events. I cannot imagine what it would feel like to be as brave as Auggie as he attends middle school, makes friends, is stared at constantly and even is bullied. It's an amazing story about a supportive family, a wonderful yet strange looking boy, and the friends that make him feel like he is more than just a weird face to look at. 
 Verdict: 
 A book you won't want to miss, tissues necessary.

The only reason this books gets 3 stars (and not 5 like everyone else's ratings) is because I wasn't that into it. Not because it wasn't heartwarming or sweet or had a great message because it did. Being nice to people, befriending those who are different are ideals I fully support it. But this book wasn't a page turner for me. Glad it was a quick/easy read. If you want to guilt trip your kids, have them read this and they can feel bad about not being friends with everyone.
Es perfecto, te ayuda a cambiar tu manera de ver las cosas.

An extremely easy and lovely book to read. However, I purchased this book based on its reviews and I must say that I was a little disappointed by the lack of events. I have a habit of not reading what a book is actually about so maybe I expected something totally different. 
 Apart from this consideration, it is a great read, never boring, and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a heartwarming story.

Children's books can be so heartwarming. That is what I felt when I read this one. It's just an amazing journey reading this book. Happiness, sadness, bravery and rudeness all rolled up into one. I can really feel everything that has been going on in this book. I can actually see myself as Auggie and imagine myself going through what he gone through in the story. One thing that is think is the major highlight in this story, never judge a book by its cover. No matter how ugly or deformed we look on the outside, it's the inside that counts. People need to know that. This is categorized as children's book, but I really think everyone SHOULD read this!!!

You know that feeling you have, when you think that all things are going so well in all facets of your life, but you have this sudden intuition, like you know something bad is brewing, and you just can't point a finger on it?. 
 That you positively want to tune out for the fear of discovering how right your instinct is, but you just can't get hold of yourself because curiosity got the better of you. That's how I can describe the feeling I've had while I was reading this book. And I don't even know why.
