 I guess that, a part of me, just want to envelop Auggie in a cocoon, and keep him safe forever, oblivious to all the pain that our world can possibly inflict on human beings in general. 
 Like, I was really smiling and crying simultaneously. It is one of those few books that makes you feel a lot of things, of which your brain couldn't possibly process individually, so you end up quitting, trying to unfeel all of it. 
 I wish that I could write a longer review, but my emotions are all muddled up right now. So, I will just give Wonder, the five star it deserves. 
 P.S. 
 That is the thing I like the most about reading. That it makes us feel things, it makes you WONDER about the crucial questions in life. And in this instance, of what kind of person we have become? Circumstances reveal, surprisingly, who we are, and what we are capable of as human beings. And goodness, don't we all need a good "sit-down-let's-have-a-serious-talk" time, reminding us that, no matter what situation we are in, we should ALWAYS take the time to be extra kind and compassionate towards others. Seriously, don't you think that the world would be a gazillion times better, if we'd only realize and practice that?
Wonderful

Wonder is a middle grade novel about a boy with an extremely rare genetic disorder affecting his face. In fact, his appearance is so shocking, that his mother has been protecting him his whole life from the reactions of the outside world. His name is Auggie, and he has been homeschooled up until the fifth grade, but is about to embark on his first year at school. On his first day visiting his new school, he learns that several students have been assigned to help him navigate this new world. The story tells about, not only Auggie's adjustments to his new school during his first year, but also how his classmates learn to adjust, and even to befriend someone who is so different, and thus initially frightening. 
 The book is told from Auggie's perspective, but also from the perspectives of those around him: his sister Via, her boyfriend Justin, Auggie's friend Jack and so on. The shifting perspectives didn't bother me a bit, because it really added to the narrative to see how those around Auggie were both constantly aware of him, and totally involved in their own universes. All of the characters are likeable, and I think that Palacio does an excellent job of capturing a variety of honest and human behaviors and emotions. She also doesn't place Auggie on a pedestal; he has faults, just like everyone else. 
 I definitely cried while reading Wonder, and laughed. I thought it was a wonderful book about friendship, and growth, and tolerance. Highly recommended.

*4.5* I really really loved this book. I took me a while to get used to the writing style and the characters but the end was amazing. Kept me grinning from ear to ear and even teared up. Knocked it a .5 just for the slow start and not connecting with the characters at first. 
 There were a lot of POVs and some I thought were unnecessary and I would have loved Julians POV. I think Vias boyfriend, Justin didn't need his own POV especially. 
 Overall, a fantastic read that touches on a sensitive subject but is written so well. This was the first book I've read about deformity and I'm excited to read more if they are like this one. I love how it was based in a middle school as well as children's perceptive on this topic is key in today's society.
This book is a really quick and easy read. It's a great "feel good" story for after you read a sad book. I loved it!
All the feels for this book. Some parts made me really sad and angry. Aw its just wonderful.

If every single person in this room made it a rule that whenever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." -Mr Tushman 
 This book is awesome. Made me teary eyed a couple of times, and I can swear, there were parts where fats tears were rolling down my cheeks. 
 Wonder is heart-touching and thought provoking. A tearjerker one second than humorous the next. Wonder is simple but awe-inspiring and one of my best reads so far for 2015. 
 August Pullman, a boy too horrible too be described by words. He knows it for a fact. He knows people are scared of him, and people mock him left and right. But what is amazing is how he deals with life. Despite being burdened by a face that is so gruesome and his lack of ears (i'm not trying to be mean), August remains to be a person so beautiful that it radiates through. 
 Wonder told in a little bit of everyone's perspective. Chapters are short. For an easy read, this book does pack an emotional punch. Brimming with values, it is a must read for every child and adult alike. 
 August Pullman, I love you. I feel as if you changed my life a little too. I also have a feeling I will not forget you as you have touched my <3. :)

You can't blend in when you were born to stand out. 
 10-year-old August Pullman is a sweet boy. He has a loving family and a dog who adores him named Daisy. But August's world is a small one. Born with severe facial deformities he is used to being gasped at when in public places. Small children point at him and adults quickly scurry away acting as thought there was some emergency "to do: they had forgotten about. Because of all of this, August has been home schooled. 
 Until now. 
 Now as August is about to enter 5th grade his parents think that maybe trying a regular school would be a good idea. August is not so sure but agrees to give it a try under the safety net that if he wants to quit he can. As anticipated, most of Augie's classmates can not get past his face. Augie is called names and noted are left in his locker. One boy Jack, seems to be a friend, and a girl named Summer (who likes that both of their names are seasons...) but one can never be too sure because peer pressure to agree with everyone else is a strong force in 5th grade. 
 In an age where bullying amongst kids is strong, can Augie survive the tests and the lessons of being the bigger person? 
 Why did I want to read this book? WONDER has been on my ""I want to read!" list since last year. In fact, it was on track to be my first read of 2012 and then at the last second I decided on another book and WONDER was set aside. Now, October being National Bully Prevention month, I thought I would give it a try to I downloaded it from audible.com to listen to. 
 Wonder is just that. A wonder. Narrated in the beginning by August, he tells of his childhood and the start of this school year. You do not get a clear idea of what his deformities exactly are - August mainly focuses on the reaction of the people around when they see him. It's actually heart breaking to hear it from his perspective... 
 for the rest of my review please go to my website: http://bookjourney.wordpress.com/2012...
Great book, I like the perspective changes. I appreciated that his deformity was not mentioned in great detail. Will read this to my students.
I hope this is required reading for elementary/middle school students.
Nicely written story for middle graders that everyone should enjoy about the value of kindness and acceptance of those who are different from us.
Omg read this in a day. Such a great book. I'm in tears

This book has so many brilliant reviews, everyone I know who's read this book absolutely loves it. Therefore I had to pick up this book...and I didn't absolutely love it like everyone said I would #unpopularOpinion. 
 I liked this book, don't get me wrong I didn't hate it. However for me a 5 star book is an absolute favourite 10/10 would read again...which I just didn't get with this book. 
 So let's start from the beginning...in this book we follow a young boy called August (Auggie), he has some sort of congenital face deformity and for his entire life has been home schooled, until now. Now he is starting middle school along with every other child has age, however as we all know kids can be pretty cruel. We follow the story through his first year at public school and as well as seeing it from his point of view we also see it from the views of others around him and what they think about him. 
 This was a really emotional book, I'm sure at some point we've seen someone with some form of disfigurement and we have done exactly what is described in this book - looked out the corner of our eye then quickly looked away hoping they haven't seen us staring. I've never actually thought about how it must feel for the other person, to know that they are different and everywhere they go people are going to stare, point and even scream. So this book really made me open my eyes and see the issues that people with deformities face every single day. 
 This book does focus on a very difficult topic however I think it was handled brilliantly. The bullying wasn't covered up or made less obvious, it was shown exactly as it would be in real life. People are mean and this book shows us exactly how mean people can be and how difficult life is. 
 Although I didn't love this book I think it is definitely a book that everyone needs to read. If every single person in the world read this book think of how much better people with disfigurements would be treated. They would no longer be treated as freaks or outcasts, people would understand that it is ok to ask what happened to them as long as they do so in a kind way and not just scream out "what the hell is wrong with your face!" 
 I would definitely recommend this book to absolutely everyone, everyone needs to read it and understand the message that is being portrayed in this book. It is a fast read and is such an eye-opener. Go read it right now! 
 I would give this 5 stars but as I said it was just missing something for me, I don't exactly know what as it was fast and kept me gripped however I just don't think I would pick it up again and so for that reason I'm only giving it a 4 (sorry). 
 Read more reviews on my blog at: https://bookgeek2015.wordpress.com/

'Wonder' is truly inspirational. It's an amazing and emotional read that made me cry so much but that also inspired me to be a better person and a kinder person and to never forget that you shouldn't judge someone by their appearance alone. 
 This is the type of book that you'll be dying to press into someone elses hands to read as soon as you've finished it. Instead of tucking it onto your shelves, share it with everyone you know. It's incredible. When I reached the last page I had tears in my eyes but I was also smiling after joining Auggie on his wonderful journey to best friends and happiness. 
 There is a lot of buzz surrounding 'Wonder' but it's not until you actually read it yourself that you understand what it's all about. When I received this book I wasn't sure initially if it was going to be for me. It's certainly not the sort of book that I'd normally choose for myself. However, like the characters I learned not to be so hasty in my judgements as I soon became immersed in the story and rooting for the inspirational August - a little boy who has to endure so much but is still able to enjoy life and teach other people a thing or two about being a better person. 
 This is the kind of book that doesn't come along every day. It's very special and it's one that will stay with you long after finishing it. You need to read this for yourself. It's a wonder of a book!

This book was amazing. It held my interest from cover to cover. I love that Auggie is relatable to middle school students everywhere. Though they may not look different like Auggie, all middle schoolers are insecure and finding themselves, just like Auggie did throughout the book.

This book was touching. August is a lovable character with wisdom beyond his years. I appreciated the shift in narrations from the protagonist to various secondary characters, as it provided more depth and richness to the story. It would have liked to see more of August's parents perspective but perhaps that is because as an adult that vantage point appeals to me. Overall, I liked this book but would not say it is one of the best YA fiction books I have read.
A heartwarming book that teaches us to always be kinder than is necessary.
This was recommended to me by a friend and colleague. What a great story! I will be using this book in my classroom.

At first I was not going to pick this book up because of what it said on the cover I was worried what it would contain!(I know stupid right) 
 I personal think that every child in school should read this great book to remind them its not about the outside but what's in the inside that counts.
A MUST READ!!!
Definitely a good reminder and a book that I will be having my children read as they get older.

this book was WONDERful. honestly, one of my favorite books ever. i couldn't put it down. even after i finished it, i was still crying and trying to understand all the mixed feelings. i. love. this. book. everyone should read it.

In a word...WONDERFUL (pun intended). 
 This is one of those rare books that is secretly amazing but no one can tell you just how amazing you just have to read it for yourself. Although this book is for children or young adults it is really written for anyone over the age of ten. 
 Written from the view of children the writing presents a perfectly readable and honest view of middle school and high school issues from different sides. 
 This book made me laugh out loud, cry, sigh with peace, and smirk with secret knowledge. Any book that can do all that is a classic in my mind! 
 Brava, R.J. Palacio you have provided a heart grabbing book for the world to fall in love with, thank you. 
 My two favorite quotes: 
 "Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world. - Auggie" 
 "When given the choice between being right and being kind, choose kind. - Dr. Wayne W. Dyer

*All teary eyed* Auggie you truly are a Wonder! 
 Auggie is the most adorable teen year old ever. This story is about him and the people around him, his parents, his best friends, his sister, his classmates. It follows the life of August as he is transition into middle school after having been homeschooled all his life. 
 I was not immediately sucked into the story, it did take me four or five chapters to adjust but I'm really glad I didn't give up on it because the truth is, I needed something like this in my life. I needed a story about acceptance and kindness and this book delivered that completely. The story line was interesting and funny more lighthearted than intense and I loved that. 
 One of my favourite things about this book were all the different POVs. They were all interesting and insightful and I got to know better some of my favourite characters. You could feel the difference when it changed from on perspective to another, it was like their personality flowed to the writing. It was wonderful to read. 
 "Children Literature" that should not stop you from reading this book because you might learn something important from it. 
 Fun Non-Spoilery Facts 
 - Star Wars References 
 - Different POV's 
 - Fart jokes 
 - Ten year olds being adorable 
 - A Mixed race main character 
 - A cuddly dog 
 - Jerks 
 "Au-ggie, Au-ggie, Au-ggie" 
 Favourite Quote: 
 "WHEN GIVEN THE CHOICE BETWEEN BEING 
 RIGHT OR BEING KIND, CHOOSE KIND."

Finally picked up Wonder 
 and started reading at 4am. Had to stop to write this. Holy Cow Batman, I thought I had read some good books this year but this one is just blowing me away. I am rereading entire paragraphs as I go. 
 Wow. I am going to Powell's today and buy a small stack to give as last minute extra xmas gifts. It's too bad this isn't on the list for World Book Night - what a life changer it could be. 
 Thank you Ann for the promotion. This is not normally a book in my wheel house. Thank you. Off to finish.
Such sweet book.
Amazing book. Definitely a book all of our 5th graders should read. Hard to believe it's a first novel -- exactly who we want writing for our middle grade readers.

Such a nice book! It took me back to my childhood through all its life lessons. Really very nice. 
 I would recommend it for people who want to read something light and easy. It's a very fun and quick read. :) 
 Well done, R.J.

Wow...this book...blew my mind. Everyone said it was sad so I was prepping myself for the worst, but luckily it did have a happy ending. Auggie is a 10 year old with a severe facial deformity and he's starting at school for the first time in his life. The book is told through multiple perspectives of those in Auggie's life and how they react to him and how this little boy has changed them. Not everyone accepts Auggie right away and reading about this boy's pain was hard to push through. He goes through a lot but never really whines about it. It was an inspirational read that I recommend to everyone. The prose is simple even when it switches to the older narrators, making it a quick read. It's the sort of story you want to share with everyone. Inspirational, touching, and yes, tear-jerking this is a book that everyone should read.
Oh my God, every kid in the world should read this. There is no book that will make you appreciate the phrase 'just be yourself' more.
It was really good and touching. I would really recommend it.

So good. I bought this for my son because it was highly recommended, my son is in fifth grade like the protagonist, and he was in need of a book after finishing both the Percy Jackson and the Maze Runner series. However, this book is not a fantasy/adventure like he usually reads so he immediately dismissed it. Soon after, I spoke with a mother whose son is friends with a Downs child in our kindergarten. She mentioned her son is one of the few children who regularly plays with that child. Then I saw a post on Facebook from a parent with an Autistic child. The "About Me," his child had filled out in school asked for the names of friends and the child had written, "None." I realized sometimes the problem is not that a child is mean, mine are not, but that kids aren't trained to recognize when someone is alone or being left out. I decided to read this book aloud to my kinder and second grader before at night. The book is about a boy with severe facial abnormalities who starts a regular school in fifth grade after being home schooled. It was so good even my fifth grader started coming in at night to hear the story. The would just complete their independent reading after I read some chapters to them (chapters are short.) I can not express enough how lovely this book was to read as a family. August, the main character, and his family, are so sweet. It is multiple POV so after one boy at school his mean to Auggie, the book switches to his perspective and my kids were given a chance to see why he was mean and how he felt afterward. It sparked so many conversations - not judging others based on appearances, how to stand up for others even when you're afraid, the importance of kindness. My kids laughed at me because there were so many nights when I would start tearing up. I had to teach them about how sometimes we cry not because we are sad, but because we are incredibly touched by something. This book was incredibly moving to me. My kids are ready to read the sequel, but I'm not sure I can do it. I loved it just the way it ended.

I adore this book for many reasons. I don't believe i've ever cried so much reading a middle grade novel. Yes, I'm a big softie, but I dare you to get through this thing without at least two tissues. 
 When I first heard about this book, I was wondering how the author was going to pull it off without making the story too "After School Special." She manages beautifully. 
 Told in multiple perspectives that bring a depth and authenticity to the work, it's still completely accessible and family-friendly, with no violence or vulgarity. If I were an elementary school teacher, I'd use this book in the classroom to discuss everything from feeling like an outcast to bullying. 
 It's not Augie's extreme facial deformity that kept him out of school. In his 10 years, he's had 24 reconstructive surgeries, and for the first time there's a long break from them, allowing him to attend a public school. He is small for his age as well and was not expected to live. 
 We start from Augie's POV as he's about to enter 5th grade. We then get pieces of the story told by his sister, two of his school friends (one who breaks his heart), his sister's boyfriend, and his sister's best friend. I love the chapters by Augie's sister Olivia ("Via") because she had to understand at an early age, that Augie's needs come first. She says she's not being noble, but that once you've seen your baby brother with his jaw wired shut and IV tubes poking out all over his body, it seems kinda dumb to get upset about not getting that new toy. 
 As August is entering public school for the first time, Via is entering high school and dealing with her best friends' shunning. She has always been protective of August, but now she feels guilty because she doesn't want her new high school peers to know about him. She wants an independence separate from him and doesn't want to be known as "the girl with the deformed brother." 
 The premise is simple, and the characters drawn fairly complex for a middle grade novel. The bully and his mom may be a bit one-dimensional, but that's also because we never get their POV. As a class exercise, I think I'd have my students write a chapter based on the bully's POV. 
 This is such a feel-good story at the end that you'll be crying all over again, but it's not schlocky or too bubblegum. It's both heart-wrenching and heart-warming.

Wow! What a wonder of a book. As soon as I picked it up and read the first page I knew I'd love it. Such a powerful and beautifully written story. It's one of those books I wish I had written. Thank you R.J for creating such memorable characters & for making us think about the way we look at the world.

This quote sums up the book for me-"If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary-the world would be a better place."

Sweet book with a nice message about the need for kindness and understanding in the world. I liked that we got to see events from different points of view, not just August. I especially liked Via and her side story.

What a sweet, sweet story! Rather than simply being a story of having empathy for those that may not be like us, Wonder allows readers to get into Auggie's head and understand how it feels to be different. Although Auggie's parents seem a tad "too good to be true" I really enjoyed this story and was rooting for Auggie throughout. This book also has parts that are told from other character's perspectives, which allows you to understand them better. What could have easily been a preachy book, this book was not and can be enjoyed by a number of readers.

It was shuch a heartwarming little story. I loved how you could see the story from many different prespectives. It's not the best book you'll read in a lifetime but, if you're just looking for a fun, cute and beautiful novel, this is it.

(Read this review and more at Pretty Bookmarks) 
 Wonder is one of those books that will stay with you forever. 
 I read Wonder in a span of 24 hours, a feat that doesn't usually happen and I became attached after reading the first couple of pages and this never happens either. That is how strongly this book has affected me. 
 I fear that this book review will not do Wonder justice. Wonder is something that needs to be read and felt and its hard to share these feelings with you in a coherent manner that feels sufficient. 
 Wonder follows the story of a 10 year old boy named Auggie (August) as he enrolls into school for the first time. Having being homeschooled prior to this, he's filled with worry about what will happen. Auggie is different and that leads to a yearlong run in with mean kids and unkind words. 
 Wonder is very character driven. The book is divided into different parts, each told from a different character's perspective. Although I expected more of Auggie's voice, I fell in love with the concept and seeing the same events through different eyes. It also allowed room for much character development. 
 Each character portrayed exceptional bravery and strength, that is beyond what you'd expect a 10 year old would face. Divorce issues, absent parents or being the sister of a boy with a birth defect. These characters were so compelling and grew into such wonderful caring children. 
 The story of Wonder goes beyond Auggie's struggle. It explores the topic of bullying, acceptance and kindness amongst others. It talks about important issues and doesn't shy away from reality (such as mean kids bullying the disabled etc) and it is done in such away that is thought provoking. 
 Wonder captured my heart from the start and it led to much needed self reflection of the way I treat people and how I present myself to others. To quote the book: "sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone". 
 Though Wonder is a middle grade book, I highly recommend everybody of all ages to pick this book up and read it. This is a book that is relevant and realistic; you will enjoy it regardless of age as the warmth of the characters will suck you straight in.
Amazing--can't wait to share with my grade schooler!

Review by Steph 
 I wasn't sure if Wonder was going to be as good as I hoped...I felt it was either going to be too sad with lots of crying and heartbreak, or they would skirt around the problems and make it too funny. However R.J. Palacio got the perfect balance and also managed to write from the point of view of a young boy and make it believable. 
 The Characters were so real, each had their own personality, and own point of view on the events unfolding. Of course my favourite character has to be Auggie. He was such a brave kid and I was torn between giving him a massive hug and cheering him on as he was doing so brilliant by himself! R.J.Palacio has done a brilliant job of capturing the mindset of young children and how they react to difference, some embrace the difference and others do not. The part about Halloween was the biggest show of children and how they can actually be when adults are not around (tissue alert). 
 Even though I have just stated Auggie was my favourite, all the other characters come a close second! Via, his sister, is such a strong little girl it is amazing. So is Summer...I started laughing when Summer was telling her parents what to do and how to behave. However the characters are brilliant because the story switched points of view. I have to say the majority of the time, I love books that switch point-of-view...I am very much a person who likes to see the different interpretations and the different situations that lead someone to make those decisions, and Wonder did not fail. 
 I do think that if we had not seen the other points of view, it would not be the book I have fallen in love with. The characters grew so much in my mind when we saw them individually and in a sense go to see their side of the story. 
 Each character had their own personality that came through the writing and stood out from the others. Justin's story, after he met Auggie for the first time, was written in a different style and at first this confused me (I had been reading non-stop for an hour by this point...) but reflecting on it, the change really made his section as it felt more like the writings of a teenage boy. 
 Believe me when I say have a box of tissues on stand by...Every time Auggie cried, I cried...and this lead to one point where I didn't even realise I was crying until it was pointed out to me. This is mainly due to the constant use of first person narrative, another favourite of mine, which always makes everything feel more real and emotive. 
 Wonder is an amazing book, and I don't feel I can advise what age it should be for...possibly for 13 + but I don't feel like there is an age too old to read such an amazing book. Wonder is released next month, and I advise people to read this.

Wonder centres on August who was born with a double dose of a faulty gene that left him with a severe facial deformity. He's ten at the start of the book and about to start school for the first time, a tough enough challenge for any kid, never mind one who is used to people gasping in horror when they first catch a glimpse of him. I love how this book offered such a unique perspective and I thought it was a nice touch that it didn't solely focus on August's point of view but reserved chapters for the other characters as well. In order to understand the wider picture, it's important to acknowledge the perspectives of those around August, especially his family whose lives were also changed by August's deformity. 
 Whilst August struggles to fit in with his classmates, most of whom have an aversion to touching or being anywhere near him, he is quickly befriended by Summer and Jack who don't care about appearances or the 'cool' points they will lose for hanging out with August. It was a sweet story, but the realist in me couldn't help thinking that Palacio was giving ten year olds way too much credit. Unfortunately, there aren't many Jacks or Summers in the world, especially at the tender age of ten. Most ten years I knew rarely bothered to spare a thought for anyone else and just wanted to fit in with the cool crowd, myself included. If I hadn't explicitly been told otherwise, I would have assumed they were closer to 14 years old, but I suppose I shouldn't have expected anything else from a feel-good story aimed at a young audience. It could easily have been a lot darker had it been aimed at an older audience, but I suppose Palacio decided there was enough misery in the world as it is. 
 I think any reader ten and up would enjoy this, and perhaps benefit from getting inside the head of a person most people in reality would automatically recoil from. This book leaves you with a warm, mushy feeling and inspires you to be less like the Julians and more like the Summers of the world.
Sweet, quick read. Realistic characters. Inspires both anger (at cruel people) and tears (kind people).

I'm sure at some point in our lives we've all made judgements about people based purely on their appearance, even if not as an adult (although I find that very hard to believe!) then most certainly as a child. Too short, too tall, too fat, too thin, dumb blond, fiery tempered red head, bad hairstyle, poor skin - the list of things people criticise is endless! As much as we've all made snap judgements I'd also be willing to bet that we've all been on the receiving end to some degree or another too so really we should know what it feels like being judged for something you can't necessarily change about yourself. 
 Remember that pain of being teased for not quite fitting the "norm"? Now imagine you're a 10 year old child, one who was born with severe facial disfigurements due to a genetic disorder, one who has suffered through the pain of multiple operations but still comes nowhere near close to looking like everyone else. Imagine that you've spent your entire life being stared at every time you step out of the house having people pointing at you, whispering about you, some even screaming in terror and running away from you. Now you have an idea about how Auggie has felt every single day of his life, not nice is it? How do you think that would shape you as a person? Would it leave you feeling bitter? How about depressed, miserable or insecure? I think I'd probably be all of those things but that is where Auggie is a much better person than I am! 
 Despite the problems he faces Auggie is one of the most positive characters you'll ever come across. He is absolutely beautiful in every way that is important and I dare you to read his story and not fall in love with him. Auggie has been lucky enough to grow up with a supportive and loving family and that shows in his bright and bubbly personality. He has always been home schooled but his parents think it is time he faced the world and learnt to deal with people's reactions to him. Watching Auggie bravely go to school and cope with the stares and taunts he receives is heartbreaking but seeing him slowly find a place and getting to know his classmates is beautiful. Inside he is a normal little boy who loves doing all the things other children his age do and as people get to know him they start to see beyond his looks to the person he is underneath. 
 Wonder is a stunning book and one that will stay with me for a long time. It is written mainly from Auggie's point of view but we also get to see things through the eyes of his sister and a couple of his classmates and discover first hand the effect Auggie has had on their lives. From the minute I picked up this book I didn't want to put it down. I was on a real roller coaster of emotions from sad to angry to proud and right through to happy. I adored Auggie, his family and his new found friends. I hated the students at school who teased him but I really loathed some of the adults for their attitude. It was easier to forgive a young child for a cruel remark made without malice than an adult who should know better. I was outraged on Auggie's behalf and wanted to climb into the book to protect him. 
 Anyone who has ever been bullied for any reason will automatically be able to relate to Auggie but what I think is even more important is that it will make people think about the way they act towards others. It will make you appreciate what you have and it will make you want to be a better person. If you're going to read one book this year make it Wonder, I promise you won't regret it. Whatever R.J. Palacio writes next will be going straight to the top of my wish list.
Highly recommended!

August Pullman was born with a faciocranial anomaly. To him it's just his face, but to everyone else it looks like he's terribly deformed. When Auggie turns 10, his parents decide it might be a good time to try to enroll him in school. He's dead-set against the idea, but after meeting some of his future classmates and visiting the private school he was accepted into, he thinks it might not be the worst thing ever. He knows kids can be cruel, and he's pragmatic about his future, but whether or not he'll be able to survive fifth grade remains to be seen. 
 I had known about this book for years before finally picking it up, and even then I returned it to library unread. But I decided it was finally time to read about August and his family, so I borrowed my sister's copy and actually read it pretty quickly. In some ways this book hit a little close to home, but in other ways it was so beyond my elementary school experience that I felt ridiculous even making the comparison (I don't know if it's worse to actually know why you're being teased, or to be teased for absolutely no reason at all). Either way, I think a lot of people can relate to Auggie, even if not for the same extreme reasons he has. I will say that in hindsight there's not a sweeping, dramatic story here, but the beauty of this book is how it tells a subtle story through big characters. The Pullmans are remarkable (but not inhuman), and the people surrounding their little solar system provide a lot of interest as they come and go, nearer to and farther from their sun. I felt like the writing was SO readable and authentic, especially as the narrating voice switched from time to time (which I didn't expect at all), and to see how people learned and changed. I think 10 years old is a hard age to write, and though August seemed a little too mature at times (though maybe he would be), it still seemed very genuine and he still generally sounded like a regular kid. Another thing that I really liked about him was that he wasn't overly unpleasant or snarky the entire time, which is quite refreshing for a book about this age group these days. The story is simple, but very effective and compelling. I didn't sob or get too emotional, but I felt kind of anxious the whole time, wondering what terrible thing might be about to happen -- most of the time it wasn't TOO terrible, which was always a relief, though there was definitely plenty of pretty terrible. Probably the most impressive thing about this book is that it was absolutely a message book, but it didn't feel preachy or condescending at ALL. Auggie was very pragmatic and understanding, all things considered, and while it might be a little overly sweet for some people, I think that's just exactly what it needed to be. I really liked how you gradually realized that, while the universe was not kind to August Pullman in some ways, it definitely made up for it in many others. 
 This was a pretty remarkable little book. It handled heavy issues without being preachy, it walked a fine line between miserable and delightful, and it made me examine some of my own feelings about appearances. I related to some of it a bit too much, but at the same time it was SO beyond my experience that all I could do was be grateful.

"Every child is born of God and will overcome the world" 
 That quote will stay with me for a very long time. Just beautiful. Choose kindness to all God's creatures.

Beautiful and has a strong meaning behind the story that not everyone is perfect but the imperfect is always enough. It was moving and fun and funny. Had a very interesting taste of writing too. 
 Check out www.xxeverlyns.blogspot.com for more book reviews !
This book is Amazing. <3
Great story about friendship and kindness and bravery! I enjoyed reading it with my 11 year old!

A book hardly ever brings me to tears, but this one certainly did. Beautifully written from the perspectives of different characters, the main one being August, a sensitive, insightful little boy born with a terrible facial disfigurement. I read this book in two sittings because it was such a delight and wonder.

This book was alright. I didn't expect it to be so kiddish but the storyline was strong. I felt the author may have made the characters act younger than the ages she stated them to be, however so much cuteness!

4.5/5 Stars. 
 This book made me smile and made my heart break. 
 It's a book that teaches you that you should judge people on the way that they look, that it's fine to ask a question and not to assume anything else, that you won't have "the plague" just by talking or touching someone who doesn't look like you. 
 I see that this book should be read by both the young and the old to teach them not to think like this and be scared of anything. Yes, when something you don't know comes you're Afraid but step up and ask! 
 Auggie, what a wonderful person you are and I really can't wait to see the movie when it comes. 
 I loved the small details that on the start of every part for the character there is a exert of a song of a quote XD! 
 Also it's a book that you can finish reading in one setting since I was reading it in the bookstore XD!!!!

What should read like a Hallmark after-school special becomes in Palacio's talented hands a resonant, funny story of a normal kid with an extremely abnormal face. Augustus, a mini-Joseph Merrick with a better support system, has a practical, no-nonsense approach to his disability that's guaranteed to make you feel like an utter heel for bitching about how tough your day was. Palacio uses a rotating first person narration that cycles from Augustus to those closest to him, which, while a bit aggravating from a technical standpoint, helps keep him from coming off like a saint or the people who struggle with the difficulties of being his friends from seeming complete assholes. Sweet without being saccharine, moving without feeling manipulative, Wonder leaves you just a little in awe.
This is a great, important novel for kids of all ages to read. And it is an easy, entertaining read that is consciousness raising.

Great story about being different. Really different. 
 Told in several voices, this novel glimpses the world of August (Auggie) Pullman, a 5th grader who's life has never been and many never be "normal." 
 Great story and a good message for all ages.

I actually purchased this book (which I hadn't yet read) as a Christmas present for my 11-year-old cousin. I've heard nothing but good things about it, but I'm not usually a huge fan of middle-grade stuff (tough, since 7th technically counts as one of those "middle" grades). However, out of curiousity, I cracked it open and started reading the first couple of chapters. I was hooked. I couldn't put it down, and (very carefully!) finished it within a couple of days. 
 Wonder is the story of August (Auggie) Pullman, who was born with a facial deformity that leaves him looking...more than a little different. As he says in the opening chapter "I won't tell you what I look like. Whatever you're imagining, it's worse." I kind of like that we don't get a description of his face right away -- in fact, I would have been fine with never getting a clear description of what exactly is "wrong" with Auggie. Since he's had numerous surgeries from the time he was born, Auggie has never attended real school. Yet at the start of his 5th grade year, his parents agree that he's ready. Auggie isn't so sure. 
 The novel takes place in Manhattan, and Auggie attends what is clearly an upscale prep school called Beecher Prep. This is totally the kind of school I would want to attend and teach at. Their 5th grade curriculum sounds more challenging than my own 7th grade teaching curriculum! Auggie has some fairly typical middle-school experiences -- he deals with bullies, he makes friends, he does awesome-sounding projects...he lives his life. Again, it would all be fairly normal-sounding if it weren't for the fact that Auggie is so different. All of his experiences are colored by his appearance. People are naturally predisposed not to give him a chance, simply because he looks "weird," and this is definitely an age where fitting in is of the utmost importance. Thankfully, Auggie eventually finds some true friends -- Summer, who simply does not care what others think, and Jack, who does care, but learns an important lesson of his own through his friendship with Auggie. 
 Palacio employs multiple narrators here, although Auggie's perspective bookends the novel, and he gets the bulk of the narration duties. There are 6 narrators total, and although I'm not 100% convinced we needed to hear from Olivia's boyfriend and her former best friend (Miranda? Her name already escapes me!), I loved the distinction between each character's narrative voice. I've read several books with multiple narrators this year, and I think Will Grayson, Will Grayson was probably the most successful primarily because it was written by two authors (although their collaboration is pretty seamless). Crossed was unquestionably the least successful, since both narrators sounded exactly the same (Reached was a little better...at least Xander sounded distinct and Ky was unconscious for a good chunk of the story). All of these narrators had their own voices, and although I thought the 5th graders sometimes sounded a little more like 7th or 8th graders, I could easily tell the difference between all of them. I actually wish we could have heard more from Jack -- besides Auggie, his voice felt the most natural to me. And his storyline is very realistic -- he's reluctant to be singled out to help the "weird new kid," but then he realizes that Auggie is actually kind of awesome. But he wants to be popular, and the popular kids definitely do not think Auggie is awesome. So for a while he gives in and acts like a jerk, which is completely believable. Kids can be a-holes. Most of them grow out of it, but almost every kid has gone through a time like this in their lives -- going along with the crowd even though they know they shouldn't. 
 I also really liked hearing from Auggie's sister Olivia. Her voice is the one that typically isn't heard in stories like this. We praise the kids like Auggie for their courage, and we praise the parents for their support (both totally justified!), but we rarely think about the effect all of this has on the siblings. Olivia has basically become self-sufficient, even though she's only 14, but she really does still need her parents and has to come to terms with the fact that she pretty much always has to come second to Auggie. Most of the time she's okay with that, but every now and then she's upset by how unfair it is -- because it's totally unfair. Olivia could totally turn into a sullen teenager or rebel to get attention, but she really just does her own thing. She has a couple of temper-tantrums, which again felt totally realistic to me. She's not a saint, she's a teenage girl, and sometimes teenage girls just want their parents' undivided attention. 
 Overall, I really adored this book. It did punch me in the heart a little -- I figured once they described the family dog as "old" that she wasn't going to make it to the end of the book. The scene was so well-written and heartbreaking (we see it from Auggie's perspective) that I had to have a good cry and hug my own puppy. The whole book felt very real -- maybe a teensy bit idealistic towards the end, when it's all a big love-fest and of course the bully just magically happens to be transferring to a new school. But who knows what will happen when they all show up for 6th grade. The kids actually sounded like kids (albeit, a little older than they were supposed to be), not like pretentious adults -- I'm looking at you, The Year of the Gadfly! At no point did I think Palacio was trying to ape John Green, as so many YA authors seem to be trying -- and failing -- to do. If anything, the overall voice reminded me a bit of Gary Schmidt's The Wednesday Wars, another book that does a great job with a young narrative voice that doesn't sound overly mature or pandering. And Holling would totally hang out with Auggie. 
 This is one of those rare books that I'd really recommend to everyone. I can't wait to buy my own copy to put on my shelf.

Told from the perspective of Auggie, his sister, and several of their friends, this is an amazing story about kindness and acceptance for middle grade readers and their parents. There are also a multitude of instructional strategies for educators to include in their planning. I think it would be an excellent read aloud for the start of a new year in 4th or 5th grade. However, it must be noted that the author has been insensitive and unkind to students with disabilities by placing a brief and unnecessary emphasis on the school not being an inclusion school and Auggie not having a disability. Why was this necessary? It wasn't. And even though I cried at Auggie's graduation, I decided to give this book a 3 instead of a 4.
Simply wow! Great story for boys and girls alike. Recommended grades 6 and up.

Auggie, the main character in Wonder, has severe facial deformities due to an extra chromosome. He has had so many surgeries that he was home-schooled until fifth grade when his parents decided it was the right time to start school. Auggie attends a private school in New York City where he is met daily with fearful glances. The teachers and some of the kids have learned to accept his differences. However, kids and even parents of the other students can be cruel. Auggie handles these challenges with courage. Middle school isn't easy for most but Auggie takes each day one step at a time. He has a small group of 
 friends but it isn't until he attends a school overnight camping trip with his classmates that he realizes friends and supporters may come from the least likely classmates. 
 Wonder is an absolutely fabulous book. Not only does the author present Auggie's perspective but she shows us the views of his sister, her boyfriend and Auggie's classmates. These perspectives show us how everyone has to deal with Auggie's needs. We all need to be a little more accepting. A little nicer. A little more caring. This world and especially our schools would be a better place. Although this book is geared towards tweens (grades 3-8), I would recommend everyone read it. Even adults. It might teach you a lesson that you hadn't thought about since grade school days.
Amazing!!!!!! What a wonderful book!!

I honestly didn't know this book was aimed towards children because if I did, I probably wouldn't have picked it up, regardless of the high ratings on Goodreads. I generally find children of all ages annoying, so powering through this book, which is told from multiple child perspectives, was quite an effort. That information is quite relevant to this review since people who aren't as averse to those creatures will probably enjoy it more since the story is somewhat geared towards pulling on your heartstrings and telling the story of a kid with a facial deformity going to school for the first time. 
 Even though it annoyed me, the fact that each perspective uses language that is consistent with the child doing the narrating was a nice touch and went a long way to making the whole story more believable. One issue with the audiobook version was that the narrator who did the protagonist's voice went all out in trying to replicate the gravelly voice the character had, which was especially painful to listen to. Regarding the multiple perspectives, I thought that while it was somewhat interesting to hear the thoughts of some of the fringe characters, those could easily have been left out since they didn't actually add anything to the story. 
 Now onto the main problem I had with this book. This is obviously aimed at children, so it tries very hard to get some moral lessons across, the main one of which is about being kind, especially to people less fortunate than you since they also have feelings. That's all well and good, but there were some other inadvertent lessons as well which were more disturbing. Firstly there was the case of the parents neglecting their other child because all their attention was spent on the one with all the issues. That can be somewhat forgiven, but not when the neglected child says she's ok with it (which I highly doubt any real child would be) and the parents keep ignoring her anyway when she needs someone to talk to. Then there's the issue of the parents being overprotective and not preparing their kid for the real world. What kind of parent doesn't talk to their child about the hardships they're likely to face due to the child's condition and give him some advice on how to deal with it? I could go on and on about all the dodgy lessons kids would pick up from this book, but I'll just mention one more that got on my nerves: happy endings. It's a bit of a weird one since this kind of book is guaranteed a happy ending, but it's very forced and unrealistic. The issue I have with it is that this could give hope to someone with similar issues that everyone will like them regardless of their deformity if they just keep being kind themselves. This is so implausible it's actually sad. 
 I suspect most children are probably too stupid to pick up on those inadvertent lessons and will hopefully ignore the ones they can tell are there to make the story have some drama. I honestly can't recommend this to anyone over ten and even then I'd feel the need to explain to them what the phrase "with a pinch of salt" means.
The feels you get from this novel. My goodness. It gave me tears. What can I say, bro?

** spoiler alert ** 
 Bien, dulce, entranable, pero lo de las ovaciones de pie en los libros juveniles empieza a cansarme. Tiene que haber otra manera menos obvia de mostrar que el protagonista es querido y aceptado.

I loved everything about this book!! 
 The way its divided into short chapters makes it easy and fun to read. 
 I couldn't put it down

Wonder is a heart-warming book aimed at grades 5 and up. The main character, August, has a couple of severe genetic defects which have resulted in him being home-schooled due to surgeries and such. Finally, at the start of fifth grade, he enters school. It is a learning experience for everyone. Auggie is forced to face the cruelty of kids, and the kids get their first experience with someone who looks truly 'different'. It's a tumultuous experience to say the least. 
 What I liked most was the fact that the main point behind the book was that Auggie was normal, even if it he didn't look it. He's very matter of fact about the way he looks, and the way people tend to react to them. Even remarking at one point on how people don't think they see him staring, but he does, and that he's mostly okay with it. He understands why they do it. 
 "Hey, the truth is, if a Wookiee started going to the school all of a sudden, I'd be curious, I'd probably stare a bit! And if I was walking with Jack or Summer, I'd probably whisper to them: Hey, there's the Wookiee. And if the Wookiee caught me saying that, he'd know I wasn't trying to be mean. I was just pointing out the fact that he's a Wookiee." 
 -- R.J. Palacio, Wonder 
 and he's definitely up for poking fun at himself. 
 "I think we're too young to be dating. I mean I don't see what the rush is." Summer says. 
 "Yeah, I agree," said August. "Which is kind of a shame, you know what with all those babes who keep throwing themselves at me and stuff?" 
 -- R.J. Palacio, Wonder 
 The quote that meant the most to me though was: 
 "the only reason I'm not ordinary is that no one else sees me that way." 
 -- R.J. Palacio, Wonder 
 The mini-reviewer and I spent a few moments discussing that one. How Auggie looks different, but it's only a physical presentation. How he's just another kid on the inside. It lead to deeper discussions later on, too. Like how Auggie didn't look nice at all, but was a nice person inside, whereas the one who was nice looking on the outside was ugly on the inside. 
 R.J. Palacio's book doesn't just give us the typical 'be nice to everyone' or 'people are all different' though. She also avoids the whole thing in literature where a character who is different serves as the springboard for some epic gooodness/understanding for the protagonist. August is the center point of this book. His journey isn't some Disney-washed version of a Grimm's tale. He can't just have more surgeries or get a magic cure to make him fit in with those around them. He has to make it on personality and persistence alone. That's not to say this isn't a happily-ever-after book, because in some ways, it is. But it's a kids book. Let them have their happy ever afters. They need it. 
 I dreaded reading this book all the way through, early on, with the kiddo. It gave us some serious discussion time. It was an emotional sap for me at points. I hated Wonder opening her eyes to the fact that people could be toe-rags. (There's a conversation Auggie and his mom have that made her so disappointed when she understood what they were talking about.) But in the end? It was a nice overall experience for us. I never had to prod her to read this book. She was always willing and eager to read at least a few pages. That says something. 
 Wonder is an extremely character-driven book. Apart from August, it's told from a few different character's perspectives. You only see the viewpoints of those who are affected/changed in some way by what they experience with or around August. Minor characters stay minor. It's also got a very nice, and strong, anti-bullying message to it. 
 Wonder is one of those books that will definitely affect parents more than it affects kids. However, it's definitely a book that both kids and adults can enjoy. 
 Mini-Reviewer's Thoughts: 
 Wonder is a really good book. I liked Auggie because he was really cool even though he had stuff wrong with his face like cleft palate. Even though he looked different, he still looked great. He was a good kid and he had a good attitude. I liked that he liked Star Wars, and I think he probably looked cool in his astronaut helmet. He wore it because he didn't want people seeing his face. Summer was a good kid throughout the book. She was nice just because. I was happy that the other kids finally learned they couldn't get Auggie's broken pieces, because its not a virus or something. You can't catch broken lungs or something. You are born with them like I was. I would give it 5 stars!!

Wonder is such a special book. Auggie has been home-schooled because of all of the surgeries he's had for his facial deformities. Now he's about to enter 5th grade and all of the potential embarrassment that comes with having a messed up face. Told from multiple perspectives, including Auggie's, this book will carry you down (though it's surprisingly upbeat) and then raise you up on a wave of inspiration. There's even a cool teacher who teaches the kids monthly precepts ("Your deeds are your monuments" ... ""Fortune favors the bold.") Such a phenomenal book! 
 "Her smile kind of hugged me." 
 "I loved hanging out by the campfire after dark. I loved the way bits of fire dust would float up and disappear into the night air. And how the fire lit up people's faces. I loved the sound the fire made, too. And how the woods were so dark that you couldn't see anything around you, and you'd look up and see a billion stars in the sky. They sky doesn't look like that in North River Heights. I've seen it look like that in Montauk, though: like someone sprinkled salt on a shiny black table."

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." - August Pullman 
 Going into fifth grade is a hard transition for any child, but for August (Auggie) Pullman, it is particularly difficult. Not only is it his first time in a traditional school, but Auggie has lived his entire life with severe facial deformities, and he knows firsthand how hurtful an offhanded look or comment can be, even when it's not meant to be cruel. So, Auggie understands that that middle school is going to be rough... "like sending a lamb to slaughter" as described by his father. 
 It's hard to imagine just how challenging such an experience could be, which is why this particular novel is so impressive. Palacio's biggest accomplishment with this story is bringing to light how Auggie's life affected and changed the lives of those around him. August is our first narrator, and through him we are able to get a firsthand glimpse at his struggles, thoughts, and experiences. But by offering multiple points of view, ranging from his friends to family, we are able to get outside of his head and understand how his life challenged those who loved him. Wonder is the story about a regular who kid who overcomes extraordinary challenges and changes lives in the process. He does all of this with integrity, courage, and compassion, leaving you feel empowered to change your own.

Okay, I'll admit it. I don't normally read middle grade fiction, even as I begin the process of co-writing a middle grades book with a darling friend of mine (and another book blogger). Maybe it was her insistence that MG had stuff to discover that drew me to try a MG book, or the suggestion of this book from a friend on a website I commonly visit. All I knew going into this was that it made some people cry and that it was about a little boy with a facial deformity. Not my usual reading fare at all, but this book really surprised me. 
 WONDER is about August Pullman, a boy beginning fifth grade and school for the first time. The reason? He was born with a genetic defect that left his face rather unsightly (according to most of the people he has encountered in his life). I did some research and, while never explicitly mentioned, I wonder if he has Treacher-Collins Syndrome or something similar. Google it if you're curious! Anyway, August is starting his first year of school at Beecher Academy, where the kids have never been exposed to someone like him. The story is about his trials and tribulations, along with the experiences of the young people around him, as he makes his way through this brave new world and the life that awaits him. 
 Auggie has never known any different than what he is. He was born with a strange face and grew up with it. People have always treated him like he was a monster, from little children to adults. But he is a strong character, powerful in mind and conviction. Being sent to school is something he is hesitant about, especially for the first few months, but he grows and changes - just as the people around him grow and change. 
 The story is told in a number of points of view - August, his sister Via, schoolmates Jack and Summer, Via's boyfriend Justin, and Miranda, Via's old best friend. From these people, the story of August is painted, from the friendships he has to the experiences of what it takes to know and love him. As the reader, we're exposed to every angle of the story, even though at least one POV wasn't really necessary (Justin). The differentiation between narration also ignored me. All six sounded very similar in tone, although Justin's POV was...weird. 
 What I had a problem with in this story was the fact that the story was neatly tied up in a perfect bow. I won't give things away, but the story became predictable in its message from page one. It's a MG book and of course MG isn't going to go down the dark road taken by adult stories. Oh, wait, does this spoil the story? Well, let me just say it's predictable. End of story. 
 This story did not shy away from the hard-hitting topics otherwise. Readers play witness to bullying, intimidation, fear, childhood drama, and medical conditions that drag the reader into the hard life our protagonist and his family has had. This story is touching, heartbreaking, and uplifting all in one. 
 Oh, and I should mention that I actually cried. But it wasn't because of Auggie himself. I won't spoil the story, but it really struck a chord with me (the event) because the exact same thing happened to me. 
 Even if you are not a fan of middle grade fiction, WONDER is worth a look. I believe most readers will enjoy this story through and through - the characters, the plot, the setting of a fifth grade full of turmoil. This was a great introduction for me into the world of MG fiction, and although I don't think I will become a HUGE reader in the field, I do plan on trying to read more into the lives of tweens entering the world of middle school, which I admit, I personally enjoyed a lot more than high school. 
 VERDICT: Touching and warming, WONDER is a unique take on something many fear to tread on. A must read for newcomers to today's middle grade fiction.

Middle school is hard for all kids, but it is especially hard for August because is different. He purposefully doesn't tell the reader about his deformity, only saying that think of the worst thing that you can, and his face is worse, but his older sister does tell us, and no child should have to go through what this little boy does. While reading the book, you want to protect little Auggie, but you know that he is strong and kind enough that he will make everyone in the school fall in love with him. 
 I love that the story of August's first year of school is told from so many characters' point-of-view. It makes the reader feel closer to the events happening, and it also makes the reader love the characters even more. I couldn't put it down, and I believe it will be a book that I choose to read aloud to my class.

I heard loads of people raving about this book, and I wasn't sure to read it or now.....however i picked up the courage and decided to see what all the fuss is, 
 This is a lovely read, Auggie himself is endearing, funny, believable, and most importantly he is deeply loved, supported and accepted by his parents and his sister. It could be said this novel is an illustration of the maxim that it is ultimately 'what is on the inside that counts', writ large. But maybe Auggie wouldn't be who he is without being as he is. He has had to learn to deal with peoples' reactions to him, on seeing his face, from shock or fear, to acceptance and friendship from some, or unkindness and taunting from others. He is a kind-hearted boy, who is so happy seeing those he loves enjoy success. On seeing his sister Via receive applause he decides; 'I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives. 
 The novel offers, through Auggie, a real insight into how it must feel to be considered 'different', and how a child might deal with this. At first when the narrator was no longer Auggie I wondered how well it would work, having gotten used to seeing things from his perspective and enjoying this, but I needn't have worried, as the other characters' sections all add to Auggie's story rather than detract from it. The story isn't just about how Auggie is different though, it's about all the things he experiences that are the same as anyone else of his age, such as not being sure he wants his mum to kiss him in front of everyone anymore, making new friends, getting used to middle school, and so on. 
 This novel is aimed at a children's and young adult audience but it wouldn't harm anyone of any age to read it and be reminded not to judge by appearances and to be a little kinder to others, and it will reward those who do read it with a moving, at times dark, but also uplifting read.

I definitely loved more about this book than disliked but too much of it did not ring true enough for me to give it 5 stars. It did end too neat. I have taught school for years, and yes, students can humble me and surprise me with their depth of goodness, kindness, and thoughtfulness. Unfortunately, in my experience the mean kid does not decide to just change schools as Julian did in Wonder, leaving the rest of the students to see the errors of their ways and embrace difference. 
 Auggie is a wonder. And I do think the world is a kinder, more educated place because his story was told. I enjoyed this book and would recommend it to readers of all ages.
Wauw, ik denk dat dit oprecht een van de mooiste boeken is, die ik ooit gelezen heb.

This book made me sad-cry quite a few times, but more often I found myself happy-crying. This was the second book I have ever read that made me want to stand up and clap once I had finished it. 
 Though upsetting at times, this book was an absolute joy to read. 
 Another must-read for EVERYONE. 
 Five stars!! 
 Side note: 
 My only issue with this book was the Justin section, just because of how it was formatted. The exclusion of capitalization and quotes to indicate who was talking drove me nuts. 
 ***Potential Spoilers*** 
 My favorite lines: 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind."- Dr Wayne W. Dyer 
 "You don't need your eyes to love, right? You just feel it inside you." 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 "I didn't destroy a Death Star or anything like that, but I did just get through the fifth grade. And that's not easy, even if you're not me."

I am hating myself right now for hesitating to read it asap. If I had known Wonder is too special, I would have read it the soonest. My eyes are wet with tears MOST OF THE TIME. yes you've read it right, most of the time, all caps. And my heart aches whenever Auggie feels hurt. I couldn't help it okay. It was just too moving. Auggie is an inspiration. The story is encouraging and uplifting. And maybe I am now entitled to become Auggie's sister because God knows how proud I am of him. And right now, I also want to hug him and say "You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder."

I started reading this book late yesterday and couldn't put it down. Auggie is an amazing character - aware, strong, loyal, and smart. Although this is a YA novel and different from what I usually read, I'm glad I picked it up. Palacio tells a good story, and writes realistically about life in the 5th grade. At times Auggie seems a little too mature for age 10, but then he's faced more tough experiences than most adults. Highly recommended.

This book was amazing to me, it made me cry, laugh smile oh and heart broken but the writer fixed me up with the beautiful ending . This was everything, I just hope everybody aka kids could just read this and be grateful, kind and just be good ... 
 thanks to the writer for writing such a good book.

I think this is definitely in my " most favorite books ever" category. 
 There are so many things you could do with this book in regards to teaching. I would like to use this during the first weeks/months of school someday :)

The beginning up to midway was heart-wrenching. I think it is because of the style of writing being so straight-forward, it didn't shy away from any feeling. I felt like August could have learned a bit more, and [spoiler] I didn't think he deserved the specific award he got at the end, his friend Jack probably did [/spoiler]. 
 I can understand why this would be a REALLY good book for kids, though I don't know what age. The different viewpoints is a wonderful lesson in empathy and people's hidden struggles. But as an adult it did feel heavy handed as the book went on, especially since August didn't have a lot of self-awareness even then about how others have problems too. Of course it's sweet and great that he made friends! Just not quite what I thought the author would do. 
 Agree with the other reviewers when they ask -- but do 10 year olds really date???? I sure didn't.

When I finished reading this book I simply couldn't help it - tears, runny nose, even sobbing! Yes, gentle readers, I can be sentimental and emotionally silly! Loved it though. 
 Stupid book. 
 :' ) 
 *ahem* 
 Ten-year-old August Pullman has been homeschooled since he was real little, but he has not been isolated. Besides his mom and dad, his grandparents and his big sister Via and his dog Daisy have been loving and kind to him. The small neighborhood children play with him without a second thought. He has lived as a normal kid in every way - video games, playground fun, ice cream. He adores all of the Star Wars movies! 
 But he also has survived twenty-seven painful surgeries on his face. He can finally eat normally and he has learned to keep his tongue inside his mouth. Still, he hides his face either by wearing a baseball helmet or by brushing his long hair forward. He is sort of used to the stares, the gasps of horror, and then the struggle of people to behave as if nothing is wrong. He IS normal except for his face. He was born with a couple of gene mutations, resulting in "mandibulofacial dysostosis... complicated by a hemifacial microsomia characteristic of OAV spectrum." "... multifactorial inheritance." 
 However, his parents feel it is time he attend a middle school. He has been placed into the fifth grade after taking a test. August is more than nervous about this. It isn't only that he might be academically challenged. He knows the kids won't want anything to do with him. There might be teasing, even bullying. Those bad things HAVE happened now and then. Will anyone be his friend? 
 August cries the night before his first tour of the school. During the tour with his parents the next day everyone does double-takes, and he meets three kids who were asked to show him around. Only one of them is not nice to him, but it is ok. 
 Finally, it is the first day of school. What is going to happen? What would his favorite Star Wars character, Boba Fett, do? After all, people always act the same. It couldn't be worse than what stuff has already happened, especially the surgeries he has had and the surgeries he knows are scheduled in the future. He is ten - he isn't really little anymore! Besides, he really would like a friend.... 
 August undergoes trials and triumphs, reader. 
 In the real world, middle-school kids can be surprisingly cruel and astonishingly kind - and they often do not seem to have any reason for their choice of behavior at all, much less choices made from that of seeing a really different-looking kid for the first time. Of course, kids this age have other dramas at home going on which affect what they do, too. Parental guidance is hugely important. I think the book quietly and intelligently handles all of these issues and more. However, the ending goes a little off the rails because the last third of the novel builds up to an over-the-top tearjerker finish, and the pacing was noticeably wrong as well , but by the time I got to the last chapter, it ultimately made emotional sense. There are multiple points of view included in alternating chapters from August's sister and others smoothly worked into the action which add depth, too. 
 Anyway, 'Wonder' wasn't written for cynical adults like me. Young middle-school kids are the intended audience, and for most it will be a read that induces thought and empathy. But parents should maybe read along, or a teacher. I suspect some boys will feel it is too preachy or girly, so, probably a little adult encouragement might help. (Emotional IQ is complicated by immaturity and dogpack instincts for some boys at this age, sorry to mention.)

I almost teared up at the end, awwww! it made me believe that the best things in life come when you least expect it. seeing the way everything has started you'd think it'll get worse, but no, everything turned into such an amazing experience for Auggie! it made me so happy! I enjoyed reading this book, it was a light read.
Pretty powerful.
"Wonder" is a children's book, but it should be everybody's book, especially in today's world.

This might just be my "Island" book. You know, the one and only book that you could/would take with you if the world was ending and you were stranded on a deserted island. I love this book! 
 From Goodreads Summary: "August (Auggie) Pullman was born with a facial deformity that prevented him from going to a mainstream school--until now. He's about to start 5th grade at Beecher Prep, and if you've ever been the new kid then you know how hard that can be. The thing is Auggie's just an ordinary kid, with an extraordinary face. But can he convince his new classmates that he's just like them, despite appearances? 
 R. J. Palacio has written a spare, warm, uplifting story that will have readers laughing one minute and wiping away tears the next. With wonderfully realistic family interactions (flawed, but loving), lively school scenes, and short chapters, Wonder is accessible to readers of all levels."
Very, very sweet. A must-read about acceptance, kindness, friendship, and popularity. I'm 27 and this resonated with me all over the place.

Great story with a great message. As it is meant for juveniles and told for the most part by a ten year old boy, it was an easy read and somewhat simple, yet was satisfying and had great concepts to think about. I always think a good story should make you laugh, cry, and think and this one did. I also loved that my own 10 year old soon and I both read it in a couple days and could talk about it.
So unique. So interesting. Love the unique perspectives. Love daring authors. Rule-breakers, RULE!

Excellent writing, amazing and heartfelt story. It took me back to middle school - both the good and the bad. The various character viewpoints really add to the storyline, and I definitely appreciated that they didn't jump each chapter, but allowed the characters time to tell their side of the scene.

"Shall we make a new rule of life ... always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?' " 
 Such a wonderful, heart warming book! It's a story of a 10 year old boy Auggie (August), who was born with multiple disorders that ended up disfiguring his face. But it's not just his story. It's the story of his sister Olivia, his parents, his friends Jack and Summer. It's the story of ordinary heroism and finding the courage inside yourself to face your demons. It's a story of love, friendship and overcoming the odds. This is the ultimate feel-good book that will leave you feeling all mushy and soft inside.

"Wonder" by R.J. Palacios is that unusual kind of book that begs to be read twice and even three times. Although the book is about a fifth grade boy, the book is a commentary on human nature and how we treat those who are different. 
 The main character, Auggie, is very different. Born with severe facial deformities, he has been home schooled by his mother. Fifth grade is the beginning of middle school, and it's time for Auggie to try to make friends and venture out into the real world. 
 Just one of the many things that the author gets right is the fact that often, parents end up on different sides of an issue. And in 'Wonder,' no sooner does one parent change sides than the other parent does also. Frustrating, but very true-to-life. 
 The characters in 'Wonder' are also very true-to-life: the school suck-up who makes all the teachers and administrators think he (or she) is wonderfully kind and generous, but who really is a miserable excuse for a human being -- enjoying the misery of others. 
 Read the whole review at: http://www.examiner.com/book-in-natio...

** spoiler alert ** 
 Wonder is the story of the first year of August Pullman in real school, fifth grade, with other students in a not-inclusive prep school. August's face is severely deformed, though he is not special needs: he can perform physically and mentally within the range of his age group (probably towards the lower end on the physical scale because he is little and not very athletic and towards the higher end in academics, since he is very smart and home schooled well by his mother previously.) He has a loving family, complete with a caring, protective (and beautiful) older sister and a great dog. He also is upper middle class, judging from him having a whole room to himself and an XBox and an iMac computer (the income difference is highlighted in a scene with his best bud, who complains he does not even has his own room, let alone a computer). 
 August hates his face. Understandable. August has a difficult start to the year, though from the very beginning there are people who treat him nice. He is, in return, a generally nice kid. His nemesis is the school popular (rich) kid, Julian, who thinks (like everyone else) that August is a freak and goes out of his way to make him unwelcome. Despite all of this and several set backs, August manages to develop friendships, overcome difficulties, and have a generally good year in fifth grade. All in all, it is a heartwarming story. 
 I am not sure, though, what the main point is, or that it is one that I agree with. Basically, August gets an award in the end for being courageous (or kind, but literal words of Mr. Tushman are more about courage, not being kind). As August himself says, he is basically given an award for having a deformed (or differently formed) face. I was thinking he would get an academic award, because he was one of the top students. That would have been great. And if anyone deserved an award for being courageous and kind and all those things the principal listed, it would have to be August's best friend, Jack Will, who had to overcome his own prejudices, his fear of the popular kids and his desire to be a part of the popular crowd, then had to stand up and defend August against seventh graders.
