 The message, to be kind, better yet, to be kinder than necessary, is a good one, I agree. But I am not sure if August is very kind himself. For example, when Julian asks August why his face is deformed, which I believe is the kind of question that should be encouraged and not considered rude (as August has the right always to tell him to fuck off or answer in any way he wants), August immediately has an internal rant about Julian. The other kids are embarrassed that Julian asked this question, whereas they are all thinking the same thing and later, they all call August freak behind his back. In the same scene, the first thing August says to anyone is to correct Julian's mistake in pronouncing a word in front of all the other kids. August appears, to me, as unkind and vengeful, not kind and understanding. August is understandably mean to Julian, no doubt about that. But he never really shows any indication (at any point) of being exceptionally kind to others. He has problems that preoccupy him and he is usually only concerned about himself (there are a few exceptions, like when he does not want to leave Jack Will behind when Jack is defending him against the seventh graders). He is so concerned with his own problems (again, understandable) that he does not even realize their dog is very sick and dying. 
 Perhaps the most problematic character in the book is Julian's mom. Her emotional reaction to August is probably not extreme, but her lack of tact and disregard of what is politically correct is unrealistic. No posh, rich American woman would be so tactless in expressing her discrimination of a small, deformed kid. It just does not make sense. Having been around posh, rich kids who have posh, rich parents, one thing I know is that they all know what is politically correct and try hard not to appear discriminating on the surface, if not genuinely non-discriminating. Why wouldn't they? They know the rules of the game and they play it to their advantage. Perhaps we're supposed to believe that her behavior is realistic, because parents will go to the extreme for their kids, but even then, a family that can easily send their child to some other expensive school would not bother with such petty business. 
 The choices of points of view were also a bit odd. August, his sister, and Jack are obvious choices and they make sense. Sister's boyfriend makes a lot less sense, also considering he is not destined to be a long-term character in their lives (unless sister is going to grow old with the first ever boy she dated). Sister's best friend, who consider's August family, is an OK choice, but still a bit off the mark. There are other, better choices, like Julian, a teacher or Mr. Tushman, one of the boys who changes sides and helps Jack and August against the seventh graders, even the dying dog! Perhaps the choices are related to the continuation of the story and will make more sense then? 
 Recommended for those who like ice cream, playgrounds, The Sound of Music, Star Wars, unicorns, and astronaut helmets.
Loved this book! Although this is a book for young readers, I really enjoyed it.

Having some personal experience with growing up and having a sibling with a disability, this book spoke right to my heart. 
 Its beautifully crafted and I liked that the author writes about Augusts Problems from different perspectives and angles. 
 He adapts his writing style, depending on the person who speaks, which was a very nice detail and gave the book a lot of depth. 
 It's an easy going, maybe a bit too hopeful story, about love, friendship and life. 
 Enjoy!
Read this book quickly over the weekend. It made me laugh, cry, and just hit my heart in all the right places. Just read it; you won't regret it.

This phenomenal book is about August, a fifth grader who is in a painful and challenging and clumsy situation. His face is deformed (from birth) and he has been home schooled. As a family, they agree that it is time for August to try fifth grade at a middle school. The chapters are broken down into the voices of different people in the story. However, of the eight parts that the book is broken into, August is the voice of three of them. This book deftly draws the social dynamics of families, friends, peers, and school. It reflects the good and the bad. We see August grow along with most of those around him! I really liked how activities are described such as the 5th Grade nature retreat. Such activities can be fraught with anxiety and excitement and that was palpable in this book. I liked the adult champions portrayed in this book. Mr. Browne, the teacher who teaches precepts such as "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind"; Mr. Tushman, the principal who advocates being "kinder than is necessary"; August's parents who express unconditional love. And, August himself--he is a wonder. I loved this line from him when he was feeling joy for his sister Via when she played Emily in "Our Town": "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life". :) This is just a terrific book about striving to be better to one another and learning from our mistakes. It is also a book about forgiveness.
RTC

August is a boy with health problems that make him stand out in appearance from his classmates. Wonder is about how August, his family, and his friends deal with the special attention his condition requires and often attracts. This book is told from multiple points of view, which are each captured very honestly. August's story is one that will definitely pull at the reader's heartstrings and leave them emotionally satisfied. I think this book would appeal to older elementary aged children and would also be a wonderful read aloud for adults to share with this age group.

The audiobook version of this has different voices for different viewpoints. I wouldn't have approached this story the way the author did, but in the end, I think he did it better than me! It was great that the characters all learned to be less self centered in very practical ways. It demonstrated very real social interactions/situations. For any child/adult that is having trouble accepting others, this book is a real winner!

By the time we're adults we've read several books where the underdog works hard and makes it to the top - everyone finding out that this character is a wonderful person. But when you read a book written for children, at a young person's level, you learn so much more and are refreshed and comforted by this type of plot all over again. Palacio has written a superb novel for children (and adults) teaching us all how fragile life can be and how important it is to learn to love and be kind to everyone. This story is told from the perspective of several young fifth grade children and a couple of older students. The adult teachers interact, but minimally. We see the growth of Auggie and his friends over the length of a school year. Even though Auggie knows school will be difficult because of his facial abnormalities, he loves school and perseveres with the teasing, cliques, and bullying. The ending is predictable, but still one that is strong and emotional. I'm glad I finally found time to read this great book; it has been calling out to me for a long time!

I am never a big fan of books with children protagonists. But this time, I just fell in love with every word, every page, every character and all other things. Highly recommend if you love reading some family-love story and about self confidence.

Second time I've read this book, and it is absolutely one of my favorites! August (aka Auggie) Pullman is what people say "deformed", as his face isn't exactly normal, and he's always stared at when he walks down the street or any where. But Auggie is a pretty normal kid in heart. His mother persuades him to go to school one day for 5th grade, and he eventually accepts. There, he is faced with new friends and enemies, and his adventure is absolutely amazing! <3
Great book for middle-schoolers
This needs to be read by everyone. Seriously.
Read it in a few hours ... Stayed up way late but couldn't put I t down! What a beautiful story and so well written. Missing auggie now:)
Kids should read this book. There's something that everyone can relate to, even me. So good.
Sent to Clara 8/2016. Rec. JYantz. Each character has a spin-off book.

This tells the story of August, a fifth grade boy who is going to normal school for the first time in his life. August was born with a genetic anomaly and essentially didn't have a face. He has gone through many reconstructive surgeries, but still looks shocking to most people. 
 The book focuses on his experiences meeting new kids and moving outside of his family's loving and protective shell. This book was beautiful. It's immediately engaging, funny, and heartbreaking. I would recommend it to all readers. Very touching.
Wow. Amazing. I loved this book.

 "Todos vencemos al mundo."
When a book makes me cry twice (once from sadness, once from happiness) I know it's good.
This book hits so close to home. I love it!

If you have kids- READ this book. And read it with them. We read this aloud as a family before bed and not only enjoyed Auggie's story- we learned so much about each other. It covered so many social issues that my kids are dealing with at school. This book made them want to talk about their own experiences with bullying, having boyfriends/girlfriends, cliques, and more. It also brought up a lot of family "fairness" issues that we were able to discuss in a civil way. I loved how this book told part of the story from different perspectives so you could empathize with each character and understand why they saw things the way they did. My eight year old loved this book as much as my twelve year old as they each got something different from it. And they all wish they knew what was happening in Auggie's story right now as he became to feel like a real friend of theirs. It was hard to let him go on without us. Bravo!

There are no words to describe this book. Heartwarming, charming, real.... We can all identify with August in some way. All should read this book - adults and children alike. What powerful conversations will arise from it. I for one will be reading it to my students this year.
This one will stay with me forever! Beautiful story and for once the majority of adults are total idiots.. Thank you for that!

Wonder is truly a wonder. This book could be cliche, or a little cheesy, and maybe it is but I still thought that it was beautiful. I understand why schools are recommending this, and we've been telling everyone at my book store to pick it up. Completely worth buying in hardcover.

It was beautifull , this book contains everything, literally, all the sadness when you lost someone you love and happiness when you remembered all the happy moments you have gone through together. and i love daisy and it hurt me so much when she died.
What a sweet, sweet book

I had to read this in order to teach it to year 7s and I must say it is a lovely way of introducing pre-teens to what starting at high school may be like. Some kids are nice and some aren't so nice, old friendships may come under strain and new ones may be difficult to come by in the first instance. Nevertheless even in the face of the most extreme adversities you find your way out to the other side, learning a lot and growing up along the way.

"My name is August, by the way. I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 August Pullman is ten year old and likes the same things every other ten year old boy likes; Star Wars, his X-box, ice-cream and his dog. On the inside, Auggie feels like an ordinary boy too, on the outside though, he anything but ordinary. August was born with an extreme facial abnormality and even though he has had numerous operations to "normalise" his features, he still looks anything but ordinary. 
 For the first ten years his parents have kept him at home. Initially because of all the operations and other health related issues, but also to protect him from a world that can't deal with his features. Now that he is ten though his parents decide that it is time for him to start going to school and to enter the world where he will have to deal with how others see him for the rest of his life. 
 August doesn't look forward to going to school. He is well aware of how people react to him and fears the worst. Soon, it seems that all his fears are confirmed. All most all the other kids ignore him, treating him as if he has some deadly contagious disease. Although there is one girl, Summer, who, from the very first day, accepts him just as he is, Auggie's time in school is lonely and painful, especially when Jack, who Auggie thought was his friend, appears to betray him. 
 Have Auggie's parents made a horrible mistake in sending him to school or will he manage to convince the others that he really is just like everybody else? 
 I'm not entirely sure what to say about this book, or even how to grade it. On the one hand it is a beautiful and well written story about overcoming differences and discrimination. The story deals with prejudice and bullying, tries to show the reader that a person is more than what you see on the outside and that it is important not to judge a person by their appearance. 
 And, I think the book almost succeeds in that. 
 My problem is that the very important message in this book is lost a bit as a result of the too good to be true, Walt Disney like fairy-tale ending. While I love a happy ending as much as the next person I think the anti-bullying and trust your inner strength message would have come across more clearly if the book had ended on a positive but not magically so note. 
 As much as I would like the world and the people in it to be and react as described in this book, I'm only too aware that just isn't the case. And that makes me wonder. This book will be read by kids who face their own struggles against prejudice and people who can't look beyond the obvious. Is it fair to parade a magical but ultimately unrealistic happy ending in front of those real kids facing problems in the real world? 
 Read this book as the wonderful fairy-tale it is and my grade would be a 5. Because I feel this book could, and maybe should, have been more I've settled on a grade 4. 
 "Here's what I think: the only reason I'm not ordinary is that no one else sees me that way."

8/24/2013: I wanted to read this YA novel when it came out last year, as it got great reviews and won a few prizes, but it slipped past me until it was assigned as summer reading this year for CCSC 7th graders. So glad I got back to it. Although it gets a bit preachy at times, and I was hit over the head by some of the themes, it's a lovely story. 
 10-year-old August Pullman, born with a craniofacial abnormality (his face is "deformed"), has been homeschooled by his mother, but his parents have decided that he should go to school for the first time as a fifth grader. It doesn't take much to imagine how hard this must be for everyone involved; fifth grade is hard enough for anyone to get through (as one character says late in the novel), but "the universe was not kind to August Pullman", and his first year of real school is rough. Luckily, he is smart and wry and very aware of how he appears to others, so it's easy to come to love him as much as his family does (at first) and his new friends do (later, after a lot of bumps along the way). 
 The novel is painful and poignant and funny and (mostly) realistic, and touches on lots of good YA themes. The writing is clear and uncomplicated, and does a great job just staying out of the way. I can't help but wonder how long it'll take for this to be made into a movie; it has just the right pacing, plot, and story tidiness that could become a good one. I HOPE someone makes a great one.
Un livre magnifique ! J'ai ete vraiment emue, et touchee par l'histoire de Auggie.
3 to 3 1/2 stars

Honestly I wasn't sure if this would make 5 stars. But in the end I decided not to let the writing get in the way of my emotions toward the story. 
 This book just touched my heart in such an unexpected way. It took me back to middle school and reminded me of how simple our problems were but how big they seemed at the time. It made me remember all my old friends and the happiness that I felt at the time. It also reminded me that no problem lasts forever. 
 I definitely recommend this book to anyone. Even if the writing is pretty simple, the story will blow you away.
Parece ser que es el libro que todos aman y a mi no me termino de convencer -.-" pronto resena en el blog :)

Middle school was the worst, and this book does a good job of showing why. If only there had been parents, teachers, administrators, and friends like this in my world - how different things would have been. There are hints of this in Miranda and Justin's stories. People on the outside of the glow who wish they had a family like August's. Kids who are quietly sliding between the cracks. 
 It's a feel-good story, tears and smiles and all that. A good book to read to a child. A sweet story to help us believe in the good in people. This would be an amazing choice for a kid's book club. 
 I think I'm too cynical for this, though. The lost star is because there weren't any hold-outs who refused to be swayed by the speech at the end combined with August's humor and charm and courage. And we all know, there would have been some, and August could have recognized that and been okay. 
 I liked the different parental viewpoints in the story. As a parent, I recognized myself in many of them. And, I liked that sometimes the adults behaved worse than the kids, because yep.

An absolutely wonderful story. A young boy, Auggie Pullman, has a severely deformed face, but the most wonderful heart and a great personality. When he first goes to school in the 5th grade, he encounters some who are kind, and some who are not. Wonder is a book which will remain with you for a long time. It is all about the impact one person can have on another, and what you see when you look at someone. Do you see the exterior physical appearance, or do you see the soul of a person? A wonderful book!!

This was an excellent book focusing on the importance of exclusion, specifically with students who may be different than you. Although it concentrates mostly on fifth graders, this is a book that all students of all grade levels should read, as well as their parents.
This book is summed up by two words. COOL BEANS!

4 1/2 stars. This was a charming little easy to read book. It felt like a very "natural" read, if that makes any sense - the story flowed very well and I got caught up in the story and just wanted to continue reading. Not because I was dying to find out what happened next, like in some super action packed fantasy novel, but just because reading this book was a very pleasant and natural experience. 
 Basically, Wonder is about a boy named August who is born with a number of unfortunate illnesses that end up in a very rare combination which leaves him with a pretty severe facial deformity. He's gone his whole life dealing with this and putting up with people's reactions in his own way, but at the start of this novel his parents have decided to try and have him attend school for the 5th grade, instead of being homeschooled like he previously was. And not surprisingly, going to middle school for the first time looking like Auggie has a big set of challenges. 
 August himself is an endearing character. He has his moments of "woe is me," but he's also funny and sarcastic. And he's not afraid to be himself, which is awesome. Not just in terms of owning his appearance, but in some of his opinions that his classmates might not always share, like the fact that he's not ready to even think about dating yet. He love Star Wars and while he tones down things like having a Star Wars backpack so he doesn't get known for just being a Star Wars freak, he acknowledges that he will always love it. He felt like a very real person. The other characters are well thought out too, especially his sister Via, who I would have loved to see even more of. 
 Despite his challenges, the book still has a really positive tone overall. It emphasizes the theme of kindness, with the message at the end to "be kinder than necessary." I think this is a simple but great lesson, especially to emphasize to middle school students. 
 In some ways, the positivity does venture on unbelievable at times - because August gets a happy ending where everyone in the school loves him (except for the one main bully, who luckily is transferring schools next year!). Even the kids that bullied him and made fun of him behind his back all love him. I dunno, in some ways it seems really far fetched and it would have felt more realistic if he had his close group of friends that he developed and the teachers that appreciated him, and maybe the rest of the school was indifferent to him rather than all trying to be his buddy. But on the other hand, this is a book, not real life. And books don't always have to reflect reality. Especially if we want kids this age to learn kindness, we should at least make it possible for them to envision what the world could be, even if it isn't always that way. 
 The only thing I had a major problem with was the fact that the story shifted point of view 6 times. We hear from August, Via, Via's boyfriend Justin, her friend Miranda, and August's friends Summer and Jack. All the shifting seemed a little unnecessary and I'm not sure why it was done, other than an "easy way out" to describe how a character was feeling about something. I think the book could have just alternated between August and Via's point of views and that would have been fine. 
 Overall I really enjoyed this one. I had super high expectations going in because everyone at the library raves about this book and we have like a million copies of it. I was thankful for the more positive spin on things and the fact that this wasn't just another big tear jerker of a story of a kid with problems. It had a little of everything - sadness, but happiness, and parts that made you laugh too. Highly recommended to everyone.
This is a wonderful book for middle school students!

I love this book! It's sad and happy and full of courage in the face of adversity. The characters are believable and some of them just plain loveable, especially the main character August. Palacio captures how cruel kids can be but also how loyal.

I've heard a lot of buzz about this book from librarians and book lovers. Some even say that it will be on a lot of awards lists, and lo and behold, it's starting to look that way. Your heart just leaks love for Auggie. He was born with a deformity and you know his life isn't peaches and ice cream. It's easy to cheer him on as he braves school for the first time as a 5th grader. Predictably, Auggie meets some not so nice kids and while you want to wring their necks for the things they say, you hope that there will be some sort of learning experience in all this. Luckily, not all of Auggie's new classmates are meanies. There are a few bright gems and the whole time I was thinking that I hope to gosh that my kids would like them. They didn't fall in line with the others when they would pretend Auggie had "the plague." It was sad to read when the kids were mean to Auggie, but when the parents jumped on board...I was livid! I think it's important for kids to know that grown ups make mistakes too, but some of those scenes filled with hate were difficult to read. 
 I was pleasantly surprised at the variety of perspectives in this story. I thought it would be about Auggie and Auggie alone. We get to peek inside the mind of Auggie's adoring sister, Auggie's friends from school and in the end we hear from 6 voices. Pretty daring for a middle grade novel! Personally, I enjoyed this aspect of the story. I did not care for Auggie's voice read by Diana Steele. It was a voice that just grated on my nerves and was painful. Diana read for other characters and I really enjoyed those a lot. There was just something about that 10-year old voice that I couldn't get past. I choose to read the book version for Auggie's parts. 
 That aside, this book is so full of heart! With the multiple points of view, I can see this being a great read-aloud for classrooms. This book should start conversations with young readers. What would you do if you were in Auggie's shoes? How can you make a difference in someone's life? Auggie's story can provide so many teachable moments for kids about empathy and friendship. Great librarians think alike - this will be on a lot of award lists!

Can I give this 10 stars? This book is literally WONDERful! Best book I have read in a long time. I borrowed this book but I have already ordered a copy because this book must be added to my bookshelf. We all know someone who might be a little different from what we think as "normal" so I believe that this is one of those books that everyone, young and old, needs to read and have on their bookshelf. Absolutely excellent!

4.5 
 So so so good! Everyone needs this in their lives. It's just so beautiful and it makes you kinda second guess everything around you. The characters were adorable (I especially liked the characters Justin, August and Jack). AND FOR A MIDDLE GRADE BOOK, WOW!!! 
 Only thing is that the characters Summer and Charlotte didn't stick well with me, and I didn't appeal to the chapter that Summer had to herself. 
 I did like Via Justin and Miranda though, they were just as good as Jack Will Summer and Auggie. 
 And the bullying was done so right (I feel just awful for saying that but it's how it is) especially the end part where Eddie attacks August and Amos and Henry, etc save him and Jack Will

I know it's probably been said a million times already, but I can't help myself: this book is a wonder. Seriously. 
 Great, now that's out of the way, I might as well get on with my review. 
 In Wonder, we follow the times and troubles of 10-year-old August Pullman as he begins his very first year of school. Due to the many surgeries he had to undergo because of the rare syndrome deforming his face, he has been homeschooled by his mother ever since he was a kid. Now his parents want him to go to school, in order to receive a proper education, but August definitely isn't happy about this. He is in fact very well aware of how people see him and has no envy whatsoever to become the school's laughingstock. But then, a meeting with the principal, and the right few words manage ti convince him. Needless to say, this isn't going to be easy. At all. 
 Now, what I loved about this book was that it was very simply written. And by that I don't mean it didn't have depth or it used too simple grammar: I mean it was written without complicated metaphors or absurd syntactic stucture, which I ally, really appreciated. Many books I've read lately have forced me to go back and reread whole paragraphs, because I couldn't understand their meaning, but not Wonder. R.J. Palacio writes clearly, simply, and with an awful amount of sincerity - especially when it comes to describing August's feelings and impressions. 
 I also really liked the fact that the book was split into different POVs, because that way I managed not only to see the world through August's eyes, but through the eyes of all those who are close to him, as well: his sister, who has been trying to protect him from harm ever since he was a baby, but suddenly wants to have a life of her own, and hates herself for being so "selfish"; his friend Jack, who gives up popularity and severs a lot of friendships just to help him out; Summer, a really pretty girl who ends up becoming August's best friend; and even Julian, the bully who will do all that's in his power to make August's life miserable. 
 It was especially nice, seeing how all these different puzzle pieces, coming from different minds, could fit together to form one extremely moving, incredibly deep big picture. I enjoyed seeing the characters grow and deal with their problems and smile through their tears. I loved its unwavering sincerity, even in front if things that people too often prefer to hide.

The book message is kind of don't judge with people their outer beauty!! I also like that august have awarded to being his sanity ! Just Love this book .

"whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary--the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 Actual Rating : 4.5 Stars 
 Wonder is about a ten year old August Pullman (Auggie) , a little boy born with a severe facial deformity . He was home_schooled because of his health and several surgeries . until now , he's to start 5th grade , a new school , an ordinary kid with an unusual face . 
 we read from several POVs including his Family and Friends, all these people who are sharing the journey with Auggie . Its a beautiful story full of compassion and its so well worth the time it takes to read it. 
 The tribulation little Auggie is being through at such a young age and his positive attitude and shiny personality in response is impressing . one would really feel for Auggie, 
 a ten years old boy ,through all that, is expected to be whiny ( no judgement , human can turn whiny when its too hard to withstand ) , gloomy , insecure and to push people away from him , but surprisingly , Auggie , the little dude , is such a fine character , too funny , too light-hearted. 
 He repeated through out the book that he's okay with people staring , he would think " I understand , I would be staring if it was me " , to describe the whole experience of it as if a barely noticed drizzle "I'm used to that by now. I don't let it bother me. It's like when you go outside and it's drizzling a little. You don't put on boots for a drizzle. You don't even open your umbrella. You walk through it and barely notice your hair getting wet." , a ten years old boy thinking this way is too enthralling , you can't but adore him with all of the bit of a heart you have , smart and funny and brave and understanding as he is . 
 And I really like that as The book starts with august's POV he wont be mentioning a frank description of his face when you're in his head. He simply mentions "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." but then when we got to Via's section she lays Auggie's looks on the line. Its makes all characters POVs too real , we can notice how different things seem in people's minds . 
 The whole story in fact felt real . The way Via felt shadowed by her brother and wanting to keep him a secret in her high school life , yet the way she loves him so much . Other things like jack explaining himself to Julian though he didn't really mean it , the way people are not totally good or bad , What I want to say is that it felt real because they all made mistakes but by the end it came to light that what one sticks to is what defines them , all of this has painted the book with a realistic light , except for the end , which is the sole reason its 4.5 stars instead of solid 5 , it was a bit too bright , though i have to admit that inspite of the logic suggesting this , it still made me all teary while reading it , it was emotionally absorbing . 
 Wonder is a beautifully written story , it is designed to be read by younger readers so yes it isn't as rich as it could have been otherwise. but its a positive point because it also means that children would have no problem reading it , children books to be served in a simple way is most definitely not a blemish in their structure . 
 This is a story to teach you about the good that humanity is capable of, the falseness of first impressions , the courage of some people and the way one little boy could win the hearts of so many . 
 'Greatness,' wrote Beecher, 'lies not in being strong, but in the right using of strength. . . . He is the greatest whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own.

OMG!! I loved this book so much. It was beautiful with great characters, and good lessons. I really felt that Auggie grew up so much during the school year, and I was in tears by the end of the book. I like that the book was broken into different sections and so we got to see the same events from different points of view. I will definitely be recommending this book to friends in the future.

There were a couple things I really liked about this book. I liked that the narrator changed and you got to see a number of different sides of what was going on. Sometimes this was the same scene from different view points, but sometimes it was person A narrating the winter and person B narrating the spring. 
 I liked that August, our hero, does not describe himself. You have to wait until the sister gets to tell her side to find out about what is wrong with him. 
 I like that, while things are not easy for August, they are not unrealistically hard either. Mostly, he deals with being a social pariah and struggling to find his place in middle school. Yes, there are some bullies and meaner than usual pranks, but no, his every day is not a living nightmare of harassment. 
 It's possible that the end was a little too unrealistically happy, but if I wanted realism, I'd spend time listening to my twins fighting instead of reading fun books like this one. 
 (Listened to the audio version about six months after I read it. Still love this book. They have different narrators for the different sections (which I like). Augie's voice is a little scratchy, but he also describes his voice that way in the book, so it makes sense.)

August's face is deformed and this is about how he faced the world when he started middle school after being homeschooled for a few years. The story is told not just from August's perspective but also from people in his lives, it was a pleasant surprise for me. His sister loves him very much but struggled with his existence whilst protecting him from the world. His friends who struggled being friends with him whilst being ostracised by the majority in school. While most of the people around August look absolutely normal and he wants to be like them, they are all struggling. An extremely heart-warming book with so much bravery and hope. I don't think the film is going to match up in terms of feels but am going to watch it. This book is such a weep fest.

I really want to give this book 3.5 stars but I'm going to bump it up to 4 rather than bring it down to a 3. 
 Wonder is a YA book about a young boy, Auggie Pullman, entering a public school 5th grade class after being home schooled his whole life due to a facial deformity. He's suffered through numerous operations and while he can function (eat, speak, hear), his appearance turns heads. Palacio makes the right choice by not describing Auggie's face and letting the reader imagine what he must look like. Right out of the gate you know there's bound to be tears with a premise like that. 
 In fact, I thought it would be a lot more difficult to read about Auggie's struggles but he is never put in a challenging situation without friends or support for very long. With Auggie going into 5th grade the writing is geared towards a younger audience than I think I usually read in the YA genre. The characters and situations were much more black and white - the good people were SO good and the bad people were SO bad. In reality, most people are going to be a very muddled mix of generous, accepting, selfish and insensitive. The character of Auggie's sister comes the closest to a real person, struggling to always put Auggie first and be proud of him in front of new middle school friends. 
 This is probably the right level of conflict and the right stakes for a reader at the 5th grade level. For my personal taste I would prefer my YA to be a little older and have more nuance to the characters and higher stakes for my protagonist.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I like it overall but the ending kinda ruins it for me with him getting an award just for being him, which is, from what I've read & listen, many people with disabilities are tired of. How his friends suddenly changed and started calling him "little dudes" for being picked on by students from other schools also leaves a bad taste in my mouth. It's as if August isn't a person to them, but since August is from the same school and he looks weak, so they have to protect him somehow. 
 At first I thought the story will be through August's eyes only, so I was surprised to see that the book switches to other character's POV. Though I really find Justin's POV to be distracting with no capitalisation and proper punctuation. I also don't feel like he's that interesting as a character. I mean, unlike Miranda, Via and Jack, he was never mentioned anywhere through out the story to make me interested enough in him, so it was surprising to see him as one of the POVs in the book. Still, it wasn't bad and I guess the book needs an outsider's perspective on the Pullman family. I really love the part where Justin talked about how the lotteries are balanced though. 
 4 stars because I can't say I don't enjoy it. It's just that around the last part of the book is kinda too cheesy even for me.

"Everyone born of God overcometh the world." 
 If you are the only one of something. You are different. 
 Like, if you are the only one in your class who can play violin, then you are different. But it's a good kind of different. 
 in my case, i'm the only one in my school (and in my neighborhood too) who has a genetic disorder called, Mandibulofacial Dystosis. Sounds cool,huh? Yah, i hope it's a disorder who can make me look cool too. But, anyway, i am different. and this time, it's not a good kind of different. 
 The thing about being different is, it'll determine people's action toward you. 
 If you are the good kind of different, you will attract people to you. Like a lamp attracts moths. 
 But if you are the bad one, it will keep people away from you. Like you're a skunk. 
 But, the worst thing of all, which sometimes i can't stand is, people always stare at you. Sometimes they do that when they think i don't see them and look away when i see them, but sometimes they do it right on my face. They make those horror faces while holding their breath. (Well, sometimes it does look funny though..) 
 That's why i always hate to go to the crowded place. The more people there, the more eyes are starring at me. 
 So, i really have no idea what got into me, when i said yes, i want to go to the normal school. It's like i am a lamb who voluntarily ask to go to the slaughter. 
 You know sometimes, middle school can be as cruel as the jungle (i'm in the fifth grade,by the way) 
 Everyone try so hard to be in the highest place of the food chain. You'll eat or be eaten. 
 In my case, i can't choose. Just say, i'm a permanent resident of the lowest part of the food chain. And in my whole life, i have to run in order not to get eaten. 
 But there's also a "hipsters" group, who choose to be in the low place of food chain although they can be in the higher place. Like my friend Jack and Summer, they're like a vegetarian lion. 
 The middle school was not EASY. Really, believe me it was damn hard. It's already hard even when you don't have any facial deformities and a genetic disorder. But when you do.. yah, just try to be one. 
 But, different from the jungle. In the human world, everyone deserves a second chance, even the cruelest one. Because sometimes we all loose our way now and then..i understand. 
 The good thing about being me (believe me, there's a good thing) is you can see clearly that miracles do happened. 
 i have several miracles around, like Jack and Summer. I also have my mom, my dad, via, miranda, and via's boyfriend, Justin. And of course i had Daisy. 
 Like Justin said, 
 "the universe takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see. the universe takes care of all its birds." 
 -------------------------------------------------------------- 
 I can hardly remember if i ever cried that much..well, okay i cried a lot when i read Five People You meet in heaven, and when i watched Facing the Giants, and don't forget the fault in our star and Marley and me.. and gosh, how could i forget how much i cried when i watch i am sam? 
 ... 
 geez,i AM that sensitive. 
 but really, i never knew that i could cry that much.. 
 this book tore me apart, crushed my heart and hurt me right in my lacrimal gland. 
 usually, i cried at the middle of the book when i already emotionally bound with the character or the end of the book which become the "most favorite times" for the writer to kill all lovable characters. (grr) 
 but, this time, i already wept a little at page 9. and cried hard at page 40 something..arghhh :'( so, brace yourself.. 
 I could say that i've been in almost all of the characters' position. 
 I've been the "anomaly" 
 I've been the one who hates the "anomaly" 
 and of course, like most of us, I've been in the neutral side who try not to take a side. Because that's the easiest. 
 so, when i read this book, i recall some names and emotions. and i realize that no one.. NO ONE deserves to be treated like that. Even if you and some people do deserves it, but you'll always be sorry one day and wish you had never done that. 
 actually, we all different from the other, that's how God created us. And i'm pretty sure the reason is not to bully each other.. #graahsusahnyagacurcolpasnulisreview 
 now, WARNINGGG!!! spoiler time!! 
 what i loved so much about this story is, there are several point of views so we can understand all of them very well but it's not as confusing as other multiple POV books. 
 and i don't know why but, in the middle of the book, i really look forward to hear from Miranda's point of view. And see? it's never been easy for her too. 
 i like that she didn't write from the mother's point of view. I don't know why, but i think i already can imagine how sentimental it will become. But, i do want to hear from Auggie's father side. 
 And i do love Justin's point of view. i don't know what's the purpose, but she wrote Justin's pov without any capital and direct conversation. But, i do like him with his Tic disorder. 
 ah, but all the characters are so lovable. I love Via, Jack, Summer, Miranda and mr. Tushman. Yes, i hate Julian, but yah, everybook should have a jerk like him..And yes, i hate his parents much more than him. 
 Among all those tearful moments, i found a moment which i cried much harder than the others. It's when Darth Daisy died. oh goshhh, i really couldn't stop crying. i'm a forever dog-lover, so it's a tear-tsunami moment for me. 
 but, there's also a really good moment here. I love when Auggie laughed at people's reaction when they see him, and his jokes with Jack. I also love the ending. 
 it's a really really great book, people.. you really should read it. It gives you the idea of how cruel life is but how nice a man should be. 
 i'll give it 5/5 
 and people ,let's standing here to congratulate ourselves, because.. 
 "Everyone deserves a standing ovation because we all overcometh the world."
SOOOOOO good! Great from page one all the way to the end.

Wow. Just, simply wow. There are no words that are even close to being able to sum up this book. I wish I could give it more stars. This is now my favorite book. You must read it. (More to come soon- I am sure I will be able to find words after my tears dry.) 
 2013 Newbery.

I'm not kidding when I say every single person from 10 years to adults should read this book. The blurb made it sound special, but how special I had no idea. I can tell you now it is one of the most special stories I have ever read. 
 August (Auggie) Pullman was born with a genetic defect that changed his face. He and his family are perfectly aware of the attention he attracts, and the decision to send him to 'outside school' for the first time in Grade 5 was not taken lightly. This is the story of Auggie's life through middle school, and it is an unbelievably inspiring, life-changing journey. 
 The narrative is told from different points of view, which makes the story more real for all kinds of readers. Not everyone sees Auggie in the same light, and each has their own way of coming to understand and love him. Via has been through a lot as August's elder sister, and though she's one of the most generous, loving sisters ever, the pressures of high school are taking their toll. But for her brief moments of weakness she more than makes up with a determination to start over that makes this story inspiring and relevant for every teen. Justin, Via's new boyfriend, is an easy-going, down to earth character, yet somehow his simplicity allows him to perceive things at a deeper level than most. I love his thoughts about whether 'the universe' was really unkind to Auggie Pullman, and his conclusion is perfect. That page titled 'The Universe' would make a profound stimulant for discussion. Summer is one of those extraordinary kids who observe with their heart and are not afraid to act. Jack is every kid who has cause to regret a friendship bungle, and who, in the process, learns so much about the kind of person he wants to be. Miranda, Via's old friend, perhaps has it hardest of them all, and her difficulties seem set to ruin her life. Yet she is one of the few who have always seen Auggie as the wonder he truly is, and because of him she finds her way home. 
 Others' points of view are interspersed with Auggie's own, and it's beautiful to see his character grow: what a transformation from the beginning to the end; what a lot he has to go through. Initially he shows us an excusable frustration with his condition and people's reaction to it, and his middle childhood growing pains are so much more acute than those of others. Like Via says, "My worst day, worst fall, worst headache, worst bruise, worst cramp, worst mean thing anyone could say has always been nothing compared to what August has gone through." But more than this, we see the strength of his loving family which nurtures in him the qualities that make him so special: courage, kindness, friendship, character, helping him become someone truly great, someone "whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own." Those last few chapters which include Mr Tushman's speech would make another inspiring discussion. 
 Somehow the genuineness of Auggie's situation naturalises all the advice the reader is given. There are references to all of my favourite books: The Little Prince by Antoine de Saint-Exupery, my favourite line from Shakespeare's Hamlet, and one of the most profound quotes from Lewis' The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, and all the quotes are meaningfully connected with the characters. I won't spoil the power they have in the story by relaying them here, you just have to read it. And then there are Mr Browne's 'precepts' which are a kind of motto for his class to follow each month, another great idea that is subtle but so effective, you'll want to memorise the full list at the end. 
 After reading the book I wanted to find out more about the author. Who is the person who can write something like this? What I learned from her blog only made me love the book more. Her last note of thanks went to "the little girl in front of the ice cream shop and all the other "Auggies," whose stories have inspired me to write this book." She said that there were passages where she cried while writing it, and gives a moving account of reading it to her own son. This is a person I would like to know. www.GoodReadingGuide.com 
 "That's how it is in heaven. It's just love, and no one forgets who they love." 
 "Do people look the same when they go to heaven, mommy?" 
 "I don't know. I don't think so." 
 "Then how do people recognize each other?" 
 "I don't know, sweetie. They just feel it. You don't need your eyes to love, right?" 
 "no, no, it's not all random, if it really was all random, the universe would abandon us completely. and the universe doesn't. it takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see. like with parents who adore you blindly. and a big sister who feels guilty for being human over you. and a little gravelly-voiced kid whose friends have left him over you. and even a pink-haired girl who carries your picture in her wallet. maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. the universe takes care of all its birds." 
 "The best way to measure how much you've grown isn't by inches or the number of laps you can now run around the track, or even your grade point average-- though those things are important, to be sure. It's what you've done with your time, how you've chosen to spend your days, and whom you've touched this year. That, to me, is the greatest measure of success." 
 "...your deeds are like your monuments. Built with memories instead of stone."

This is my second reading of this book. I read it 3 years ago and this month my book club selected it. I decided to reread it. I enjoyed it as much this time around as I did the first time. This is a must read for all upper elementary/middle age students. It is a wonderful story that helps all readers be more accepting of all people. My grandson just started 5th grade and he informed me today when he saw wht I was reading that his teacher is reading Wonder to the class. Kudos to that teacher.

Wonder is an amazing book of courage and quiet transformation in the form of August Pullman. August was born with a facial deformity and because of this, the universe wasn't always kind to Auggie. But despite this, August became the light of everyone around him. He struggled for a bit, trying to accept things the way they are, but he got there. 
 This is the kind of book that after reading, makes you feel light and content and happy with the world. This is the kind of book that changes your view of everything even for just a while. I was undergoing some...life issues while I was reading this book, and I have to admit, parts of it were sad. But, the book, in itself, spoke millions of positives to someone like me. It's the perfect pick-upper to a lonely or reflective soul. It's a Wonder-ful book that moved me, calmed me, and taught me how to look at things differently: positively, and with bravery and hope.

I LOVED this book. It's quite possibly one of the best books I've read for young readers in the past decade and definitely the best book I've ever read on the subject of dealing with physical disabilities and overcoming adversity. Simply fanttastic. I listened to the audiobook version and I love that each "voice" in the book was narrated by another person. 
 The premise of the story is simple. August has a facial "deformity" (bad term I know). A very bad one. His family and friends are able to look past it and see his radiant personality shining through but the same can't be said of everyone else. Kids call him a freak, parents stare, people run away. Needless to say, young Auggie has to deal with a lot. Especially, now that his parents are encouraging him to attend school for the first time in his life. Because of all the major facial surgeries Auggie has always been homeschooled by his mother, but now that he doesn't need any surgeries for a while there is no real reason for him to stay him. Obviously, August can think of a lot; kids will make fun of him, he won't make friends, people will say mean things, etc. In the end he decides to give school a try and it is nearly as bad as he thought it would be but he decides to tough it out. Slowly but surely he starts to make some friends. This is their story. Told alternately from the viewpoints of Auggie, his sister, his school friends, and others. This is a tale of kindness and seeing the best in others. It will make you laugh, cry, be angry, and view beauty in a completely different way. 
 A phenomenal, amazing read!

Beautiful. Everyone has something to learn from this read; whether it be Via's understanding and selflessness, Summers's kindness, Jack's courage and sense of right, or maybe just maybe you'll learn something about being an Ordinary Wonder from Auggie.

This was a fabulous book...made me laugh and cry at the same time. The story of a boy with a horrible facial deformity who goes to school for the first time in 5th grade--what would it be like to be him? What would it be like to be his friend, or his sister? This story is told by multiple narrators and is an unforgettable story. Even though it has the typical happy ending of a children's book, it's a story of a person of remarkable courage and how he impacts the life of those around him. Highly recommended.

Every middle grade & middle schooler MUST read this book.

it will hit you in the end

When given the choice between being right and being kind ; choose kind . 
 When I first read it , it reminded me of the Drs show , I've seen a similar case a to a girl , who had many surgeries , yet her face Was still the same but " better" . And she had been bullied by many kids in her school , hometown , and every place she goes to , so she took a pic , writing on it ,don't laugh at me ( a quote from a song ) ,, so yuh . 
 This book is really great , it makes you in a way or another think , of how can kindness be a powerful way to change someone's life ..

Nothing like a good cry while you're on vacation. To be clear, I'm not usually the person who cries during "feel good" scenes, but this book was just too much. Motherhood has officially ruined my stoicism. 
 This book was a beautiful example of how good Middle Grade fiction can be. Auggie's story was heartfelt and true to life. Palacio avoided the inevitable pitfall of turning him into a caricature and instead created a fully-realized, smart, funny, and sometimes (justifiably) angry young man. There was so much to learn from this story, but you absorb the lessons organically and without the notion that someone is trying to "convince you" of their validity. This is a story that I can't wait to share with my kids, and one that I truly believe will make them better humans after their read-through. 
 I'm officially on the bandwagon. :)

3.5 stars. Like Suicide Notes, this is a book that I didn't really find entertaining but am glad I pushed through. One of those books that's not fun, but important. 
 I do feel that the author could have made the book much more complex and nuanced. The subject matter was unique, but the story itself was relatively bland. Lots of reviewers have said they bawled while reading this--I didn't really find it to be that emotionally charged. I cry easily when it comes to fiction, and I didn't shed a tear for this one. 
 But it was a quick read, and I'd still recommend it. This one would probably actually work well with its intended middle grade audience as well (as compared to, say, A Monster Calls, which is brilliant but might be somewhat inaccessible to kids despite the supposed intended audience). The simplicity of the narrative, which bothered me as an adult reader, might be ideal for younger audiences.

 The second time reading this book was still pure magic. The lessons in this book are so important to know. With social media, in some cases, we have lost our ability to empathize with people. This story is such a safe haven for me. 
 This is a story for anyone who has felt marginalized for their identity, race, sexuality, etc.. It is a story showing the beauty and power of always choosing to be kind.

 This is such a beautiful book. 
 The writing is beautiful. The characters are fully realized and interesting. The way the narrative is structured is really unique. The story is told through multiple perspectives all set within one school year. 
 It was well done because there was never any confusing between perspectives and none of them were boring. In fact, I wanted more from other characters like miranda, summer, and jack. I love these characters and the message that this book has.

 Read this book! 5/5!

Maybe I am a bit too old for this. But I really appreciate that though Auggie's face is not normal, he was blessed with a loving family that other normal looking kids does not have. I myself has a killoid on my face, thank God I wasn't bullied when I was younger.

** spoiler alert ** 
 Wow. I think everyone needs to read this book. What does it mean to be kind? Auggie Pullman is going to school for the first time. Fifth Grade. Middle School. But he's not like other kids. He has a sever craniofacial defect. Auggie exhibits bravery and strength throughout this book. More surprisingly, he is able to change the way people think of him because he is kind despite the way he looks on the outside. 
 This is a great book. Every 10-12 year old should read this book, and adults too. I read this book after my rising 6th grader read it from his suggested reading list. Don't judge someone by the way they look on the outside. Give people a chance based on who they are on the inside. That's what counts. And even Julian learns his lesson in the end. So good! I highly recommend.

Wonder is a fascinating tale about a boy born with facial deformities starting school in the fifth grade for the first time. His story chronicles being the outcast to becoming the hero. Auggie Pullman is the kind of character you can and want to root for. 
 The book was written in first person and separated into eight sections. Each section focused on one character with the first, last, and 6th section focusing on Auggie. I liked the sections on the other characters, but I really liked going to back to August as the narrator. The other sections allowed the reader to see things from other characters points of view and how they related to Auggie. It helped form a bigger picture than just what was seen through Auggie's eyes. That worked best for this story. 
 Overall, it was a captivating story. I felt Auggie's pain as well as his joy and triumphs. He has to deal with situations in ways other kids don't. Due to his facial deformities he's an outcast. People stare at him. People treat like he's got cooties. They don't want to touch or be near him. But, he inadvertently shows them they're wrong. Some learn. Unfortunately, some don't. 
 The copy I reviewed is an uncorrected advanced reader's copy provided by netgalley.com.

This is one of those rare middle grade books that I would recommend to any reader between the ages of eight and eighty. It is easily one of the best books I've read in months, possibly even years. 
 Auggie was born with severe birth defects and craniofacial abnormalities making him a very scary looking little kid. After 27 surgeries, he is finally medically stable enough to begin school in fifth grade. In case it's been a while since you were in fifth grade, kids can be cruel. 
 Wonder is the best anti-bulling book I have ever read! Probably that I ever will read. It is one of the best portraits of diversity I've ever seen. I highly recommend it to readers young and old. Auggie is a wonderful character, and this is an amazing book!
Nice. Multiple POVs, each done very well. Lots of love. Cried once.

I just did not like this that much on either a regular or a Newbery level. I didn't think the dynamics of the school were very believable (most of the kids read too old to me, and the way it all worked out in the end was just TOO warm-n-fuzzy)--I think that was my main problem--and while this is way, way better than most guidance-counselor fiction, the writing did creep that way too often for my tastes. 
 The big action scene near the end didn't work for me. I'm assuming there really are environmental education schools in New York where one of the evening activities is getting together to watch a movie in a park, so while I thought that was really strange and it didn't make sense to me, I give that a pass. But... logistically... there were a bunch of things in there that puzzled me. 
 Perhaps most of all, the ending was both too feel-good and a little creepy. I was really uncomfortable with how we're supposed to think a school full of kids calling Auggie "Hey, little dude"--including kids his own age--was a great thing. Better than before? For sure. But so icky and condescending. All the kids thinking it's so great that Auggie won this school award? I mean, I don't think kids care about awards like that all that much, and even if they did, I would have expected more grumbling ("they only gave it to him because") than admiration. 
 I liked that Julian never came around. That felt real to me. But I didn't like that he just won't be in school next year, problem solved. 
 My favorite narrator, and the one that felt most real and natural to me, was Via's boyfriend Justin. I love that guy. I would like to say that I wish we'd gotten more of him, but I think it was probably a wise choice to give us just a taste and leave me wanting to know more. Likewise with Miranda. 
 The scene at school that felt the MOST real to me was the one where Auggie is in his Halloween costume and hears his so-called friend talking about him. The kids' voices in that seemed spot-on, and I took what Jack said quite seriously and alarmedly. But then it was never really dealt with. The scene was, sure. But it seemed to me like it was kind of passed off as "I didn't really mean it" when at the time Auggie notes that he sounds very serious. I mean, Jack says he thought a lot about what he would do if he was in Auggie's situation, and I think that IS the kind of thing a kid would think about. I don't think he made that up on the spur of the moment. Perhaps further talk about suicide would have made the book too dark for its audience, but I felt like it left me hanging with something very serious. 
 Overall: I think this has too many holes to make it a Newbery. And "Mom, thanks for making me go to school" (not an exact quote) sums up my philosophical problems.
This is one of these books can you smile, and a have a lot of feeling, you Should read this.
Read this with my 7 y.o. Gave us lots to talk about. Imperfect, but still recommneded.
a nice read. nothing more nothing less.

Very sweet and moving, definitely a must-read of 2012! The story follows August Pullman, a boy whose facial deformities have meant he's been homeschooled his whole life. When he decides to go to a regular school for 5th grade, it takes a lot of courage and adjustment for Auggie and everyone around him. I loved seeing not only Auggie's viewpoints but also those of his sister, friends and classmates. The voices of these characters were mostly unique and gave interesting perspectives on Auggie's first year in a public school. The rougher aspects of school were handled well and intelligently and I really loved the author's emphasis on kindness and understanding. Highly recommend it!

What a sweet and touching little book. I read it after my 12 yo recommended it after reading it this year in school. Unlike a lot of books written for kids, this one doesn't cheat. It doesn't think that kids are simple or stupid. It doesn't condescend. 
 My favorite part of the novel is the way the retelling of different character POV weaves together a tapestry that really shimmers like real life. Messy around the edges, complicated, but there is overwhelming beauty there is you take a breath, take a moment to see it.

Very interesting story, gives you a different perspective, and addresses important topics like kindness and bullying. I liked having the different character points of view to give you more insight into the story. Very easy and enjoyable read.

The story about August is told from several perspectives. Even though most chapters are through August`s eyes we also get to read the points of view of his sister, Via, her former childhood friend Miranda, her boyfriend Justin, and August`s new friends Jack and Summer. I liked most of these chapters, but maybe we didn`t need all of them. Especially the part with Justin seemed a bit redundant. On the other side Via`s chapter definitely brought an important layer to the book and most of the other chapters did too. It is so easy to judge everyone for their behaviour and reactions towards August but showing their points of view makes it a lot more difficult. 
 I think this book is important, well-written, easy-going, funny and beautiful all at the same time. As an adult reader I sometimes missed a little debth and severeness to the story but this is a book where older children are the main target group and it is also told through children's eyes. It certainly has it's tougher parts though where you get both angry and sad, but the heart, the smile and the hope is there all the time. For instance Auggies parents makes the story about his rather dramatic birth into a comedic story about a farting angry nurse and he wants to hear it over and over. I also did find myself thinking if children and some adults really could be this mean and ignorant and unfortunately they can. This is an important lesson for me as an adult and parent, to remember exactly how mean children can be without even realizing it or at least not thinking about the consequences. For children and I guess all of us this is also a story about the importance and value of being kind to each other. 
 These last few days after I read Wonder I`ve found myself really missing August. He is such a beautiful and strong character with the optimism and curiousness only a child can have. This little boy could definitely teach most of us a thing or two about life and what`s really important. He is a complicated character but not as broadened, cynical or deep as an adult nor should he be. None of the characters that tell the story are adults and inside these frames the story really works. When life is good, it is all happiness, and when it's not it's devastating. All that in between and ahead are for adults to think and worry about. 
 I read this book in norwegian as it was a gift from the norwegian publisher Gyldendal. I am happy about owning this book in norwegian because I`m looking forward to give this to my daughter to read when she is ready. The norwegian publisher has published this as more of a YA-book but I think it is mainly for older children. That being said this book could and should be read by a large group of people age not considered. I still think it's important to say that this is a book suitable for children from the age of 9 I think. The author says on her web page that adults have a stronger emotional reaction to this book because we know life is not going to be easy for little Auggie later on but children find the story mostly funny and uplifting. Despite it all Auggie has a family that loves him and gives him whatever they can and he also has friends that got his back, and that's more than a lot of "normal" children can say.
Wonder is everything and more.
Everyone needs to read this book. My son told me about it, They read it in his class. And I had several friends tell me about it. I don't want to give it away. Just read it

This is a very good book, almost a 5. It starts off well, introducing the characters and setting the scene and you soon have real sympathy for the main character Auggie. However, at the end of the first section, it started to become a bit obvious and predictable. It is at this point that the book really comes into it's own, because the next section switches to the story from another characters perspective and you get a brilliant change in how this other person is affected by events. Other sections then switch to various other characters. It is very well done and very insightful and yes also very emotional. ok so some parts are a bit simplistic and the ending is all very 'nice', but these are small gripes. I would definitely recommend it.

I read this novel in parts every night to my sons at bedtime, and what a memory it has created for us. Similar to the movie "Mask" (w/Eric Stoltz) but for kids, WONDER made us laugh hysterically and cry repeatedly (four times for me, even though books rarely make me teary). Most importantly, it prompted us to discuss the decency of treating other people with kindness, regardless of appearance. Thank you to everyone who recommended this book, which will have a permanent spot on our bookshelf.

This was one of the best reads ever. The writing style and how the writer elaborates the workings of the mind of a middle schooler is noteworthy. This definitely goes into one of my favorite books along with Khaled Hosseini's works! Brilliant read.

AMAZING! I don't know how can just pass this book without reading. It is a wonder. The strength... the courage... the friendship.. the love... the fear... everything it contains is just beautiful. The most beautiful thing about this novel was the kid Auggie. 
 "Everyone is deformed. Sometimes, one more than the other. The beauty does not lie on how deformed the person might be... but the strength they carry. We do not befriend someone because they are deformed but we befriend them because we are comfortable around them". 
 This story really triggers some emotions deeply.

** spoiler alert ** 
 A wonderfully touching story of August's 5th grade year - his first year in school. August's face is deformed, even after numerous surgeries... He is loved by his parents, older sister, and dog... and all things considered, has pretty good self esteem... 
 We see most through his eyes, though two of his friends, one enemy, his sister and his sister's friend all get a chapter or two from their point of view. 
 Palacio does a marvelous job of giving us insight into the emotions and minds of them all - the fear, the ordinary, the slow acceptance of getting used to the abnormal to see the real person, that people for the most part aren't mean or bad, just need a bit of time, the humor, the pain, the joy, the pleasure. 
 Though I cried at a few places, I cried the hardest when their dog died - hmmm.... the dog that loved and accepted them all just the way they were...

***This book review may contain spoilers.*** 
 It was a good, quick story about bullying and accepting yourself. The only issue I really had with it to be honest was that there wasn't one true storyline. It was just based on a year. The year was the first time Auggie went to public school (5th grade) after being homeschooled his whole life due to the multiple surgeries he had. Auggie's face had facial abnormalities that caused his face to be "deformed". 
 What I liked about the story was that you get to see everyone's perspectives. Auggie's perspectives. The people he met in school. Summer. Jack. His sister's perspective. Her boyfriend's. Even his sister's ex best friend Miranda. You know whose perspective I would have loved to see? Julian's. The main bully's. I'm pretty sure when I finished the book I saw that there was a book made with other character's perspectives that weren't included. Maybe one day I'll read it. 
 As we're talking about perspectives, I do want to admit that I had an issue with Miranda's. In some ways, I can compare her to Julian. Saying what she needs to say to get/be popular. I'm surprised her big fat lie that Auggie was her brother didn't get blown up, especially at the play. 
 I don't understand how the turn-around happened. But then again I can. Auggie is always and truly so authentically himself that that kind of stuff gets contagious. He wasn't malicious to anyone and never wanted to get anyone in trouble regardless of the wrongs done to him. And I think it was definitely cool how the guys who once used to talk about him and make fun of him were the ones defending him on their field trip. 
 It's easier to be kind and accept someone than to hate them. Kindness is such an admirable feature in anyone's personality and it takes so much effort to hate/bully someone. I think this was what R.J. Palacio was trying to show as well in her story. I couldn't quite tell if this was meant for a younger crowd. Any one of us could learn a genuine lesson in reading this book. 
 My Star Rating: 4 out of 5 Stars

I finished this book several days ago and have not been able to stop thinking about the story. The characters are fantastic and the struggles they face make this story so rich and relatable. A fantastic story with a great message for readers of all ages, especially those in middle school. Remember to always choose kind!
If I could give this book ten stars, I would.
What a GREAT read! Touching, heartwarming and real. I love the different point of views and how August (the main character) touches all these lives. One of my favorites so far this year!

While I felt it was a bit heavy handed at points and sometimes the dialogue did not ring true to fifth graders, I can't help but give this book 5 stars. I laughed. I cried. I smiled. I got warm fuzzies. This is a wonder of a book!

This is by FAR my favorite book of 2012! I realize this may be an over exaggeration on my part but I was deeply moved by it. I think reading is more than just lifting words off the page; it requires some sort of transformation and possibly even an action... If anything it has led me to recommend it to everyone I can. What I appreciate most about this book is the fact that although it is about August and his "condition" it is also about those who surround him: parents, sister, friends, strangers... The switch in the narrators allow the reader to view the same story from multiple perspectives and understand that no story is one-dimensional. I recommend this book for every student, teacher, parent, ect.
One of the best books I've read.

As much as I thought this is a well written story and a good intentioned one, I didn't connect much with it. at all. I found this review which summarises my point of view! thank you catie!! (contains spoliers) 
 Here is a review by Catie: https://www.goodreads.com/review/show...
A lovely and deeply moving book that should be required reading for 5th-graders.
It has really interesting points about being different and how everything is not how it seems how every story has two sides I really enjoyed this book.

A very inspiring and beautiful story about a kid named August who has a facial deformity, and because of it, has never gone to school before. When he decides to finally try it, he is filled with fear and doubt about his first day, and every other day after. 
 The characters in this book seemed so real! The events were very well described, and I especially loved the way the book was written; it had different point of views. August, his sister, his two best friends, his sister's boyfriend and his sister's ex-best friend. Like this, the reader can understand each character's situation very well, and they can also understand their motivations. 
 The only thing that annoyed me was the way it was written when it was the sister's boyfriend who was narrating because there were no capitalization and no quotation marks when someone was speaking, so although I understood, it took me a little while to adjust to the way it was.

I had high expectations for this book, considering how popular it is. And I must say, I wasn't disappointed. 
 Yes, it's cheesy and very optimistic and hopeful, but sometimes that's exactly the kind of story we need. August Pullman pulled at my heartstrings, yes, but I actually found myself enjoying the sections of the book where we get to hear others point of view. It is interesting to see how the thoughts and feelings of everybody contributes to the ways each of us feels every day and how we all need to "walk in each other's shoes." 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." - August Pullman
Overall, this was an enjoyable read. I just didn't find the characters relatable. I thought at the very least the adult characters would be, but they're all very simplistic. Meh.

This is the kind of book that people OF ALL AGES should read! I WOULD PERSONALLY GIVE THIS AS A GIFT TO EVERYONE. This is a beautiful story that makes your heart swell with happiness and moral lessons that are vital in your life. Every chapter is an inspiration. Reading Wonder is def a treasure. :)
Such a great book! Lots of great lessons and a wonderful speech at the end! Well worth the time to read!
I loved this book!!!!
My heart was my throat for much of this book, but I loved it
I'll quote my LIS 721 professor on this one: "If everyone read this book, the world would be a better place."

Right from page 1 I knew this book will make it to my "Best books I have ever read" list (which has only about 7 books till now).. 
 Really EVERYONE should read this book. 
 And I best recommend that you go into this book blind without really knowing beyond that August is a 10 year old boy with a special facial condition, which is what I did. 
 R.J. Palacio is truly an amazing writer and for the first time ever a book has made me want to thank the author for writing it.. 
 So Thank You very much Mrs. Palacio for giving us this wonderful book. 
 I have always believed that everyone in the world gets "100%" so even though some of us might get less of something, there is always more of something else in return, so that in the end it always balances out to 100%. 
 And I loved how the writer showed that in this story, that even though Auggie has "less" in looks, he has "more" in having a loving family, good friends, and a kind heart, which balances out to 100% :) 
 Thank you, and Happy reading :)

I love love love this book, I think EVERY middle school and older should read this. It has such a good message about kindness there is not a bad thing I could say about this book. Just everyone READ THIS BOOK!!

Absolutely phenomenal! Every fifth or sixth grader should be required to read this book!! A story of perseverance, strength and the importance of kindness. You will want to jump into the book and fix the problems and will not want to put it down to see what comes next! A true "feel-good" book for everyone!!

A good book. I really debated this one - which is odd, as I usually don't debate, just read. 
 Auggies story is unique - get similar. Pre-teens, teenagers, go through much the same, yet to different degrees and causes.... and this really pushes home the idea of kindness. A good book, right on target for the audience it was aimed at. :) 
 Going to read the three "mini chapters" next... and then...on to something else ;)

I'm so glad a friend suggested this book! It was a really great book and I feel like kids everywhere should read it. I know I will be reading this again to my kids when they are a little bit older to understand the concepts.

I enjoyed the multiple perspectives from which this book is written. The first time the perspective changed I wondered how the story would hold up to this change; however my "concern" was quickly alleviated, and I realised quickly that the story gained significantly by this change in narrative. 
 The story itself was a fascinating one, really interesting; I'd thoroughly recommend.

I liked the different perspective this book showed, as well as the simplicity of the writing and narration. The writing is easy to read, since this book is also offered to younger readers. I found that the short chapters reminded me of prose poetry and helped me to understand the book from a child's point of view.
