 I enjoyed the switching point of views, it really let me see how August's medical issues impacted the people around him. I loved the theme of change and adjustment throughout the book. I switched between schools a few times during my younger years and I remember how difficult it was to come into a new school and not be very good at making friends. Of course Auggie had it much worse but I found that I could really emphasise with Olivia as she struggled to find her place in high school. 
 The characters' struggles were realistic and I really liked that the author didn't gloss over the more difficult parts of their lives, such as Olivia's hesitance in being known as the girl with a deformed brother. 
 I think that this book would be really great for younger readers and honestly, there should be more books like this readily available to children. I really encourage teens and adults to pick this book up as well, despite it often being regarded as a children's book. I think everyone can learn something from this story, no matter what age you are when you read it.

I don't like the title of this book, but I did like the realistic look into the lives of an array of teenagers, all with their own personal problems. I did also like that this didn't descend into August being bullied, or is miserable in school, and distances himself from his family. There wasn't a major romance part played either, which tends to be a fixture in young adult novels. 
 August had never been to school before, but having had numerous surgeries on his face, it is going to be more difficult for him to fit in. 
 I liked The Cheese Touch chapter. I was shocked by the thought that people wouldn't touch August purely because of what he looks like. 
 The part where he overhears classmates talking about August, 'If I looked like him, seriously, I think that I'd kill myself.' was shocking too, at the cruelty of it. 
 Alien was also a chapter that upset me as well, as August again has to defend himself against the callous ignorance of children older than him, asking, 'What is that?' 
 With various narrators in parts of this book, it gives a total view of how people see those like August, including his sister, Olivia. 
 Wonder is a book that gives the reader plenty to think about, and will appeal to many, if not all, people.

From the very beginning, R.J Palacio has written words that let us know this isn't going to be an easy story to read. The point of view starts with a young boy of ten years of age who was born with a rare disfigurement and lets us know that he probably looks worse than we imagine. He goes by the name of August and he is strong willed and incredibly strong minded. I found myself crying so many times at how brave and strong this young boy was through so many trying times. He explains that he has never stepped inside of a real school, only to begin the journey soon enough. 
 As August goes through his days inside of the life of a real school kid, he learns to deal with the name calling and shunning that he knew would happen. What I didn't know was that we would get to experience lives through the eyes of many of Augusts friends and even his sister, telling their side of the story and sharing in their experiences and beliefs of August. 
 In the end, things came together quite like they should. Unfortunately, it was over certain circumstances that never should've taken place. Wonder is full of compassion, heartache, and love. Through many events in the book, you will want to wrap your arms tightly around August and hold him ever so tight. Many bonds take place, and many tears will fall.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I thoroughly enjoyed August's narration. He had a realistic approach to how people saw him. 
 At first, I was disappointed when the point of view shifted to his sister, Via. However, it was a good change of perspective, especially to see what it was like growing up with someone who commands so much attention. This goes for August's friends, Summer and Jack, as well. I didn't care for other points of views, like Via's boyfriend and Miranda. I would have liked to hear from a teacher or the bully, Julian, instead. 
 My main complaint is over the ending; it finishes too perfectly. The scene at their graduation seemed more fitting for a movie than a book. August is winning a medal for what exactly? The children in his class haven't learned kindness through him. instead, they've learned how to pity and protect the "little guy" rather than value who he is. August does gain the acceptance he craved, but not for the right reasons. And suddenly Julian is out of his life and Miranda is back in Via's and everything is peachy? I don't buy it. 
 Overall, this is an enjoyable read with a sympathetic, albeit young and therefore occasionally whiney, protagonist. The book would earn a 4.5 or 5 stars if it weren't for the ending.

This book has received a lot of praise this year, even many predictions as to its award-winning possibilities. I am not going to dispute that possibility because I wholeheartedly agree with all the hype. I loved this book. I loved Auggie and his courage in facing public school for the first time. The courage it took for his parents to send him to public school knowing he would likely face poor treatment by some. Auggie's sister's struggles with feeling overlooked and wanting attention for her own abilities and concerns rather than receiving attention simply for being Auggie's sister. The format of the story (multiple viewpoints) gives the reader more depth as far as what other people are thinking and feeling and what Auggie is thinking and feeling. For me this made for a book that was truly heart wrenching at times. There was more than one occasion where I wanted to hold Auggie in my arms and just love him. 
 I thought the way the author told the story from multiple viewpoints was brilliant and makes for a great book for teachers. The main theme of the power of kindness shines through bright and clear, and yet the author never says it directly, she just shows it beautifully through the words and actions of the characters. I've read a few criticisms that the ending is too idealistic and maybe it is to some degree, but then I think of actual news stories I've read about such things and then no, I don't think the ending is too idealistic. In fact, I love the ending. For me the really powerful part of the ending is not that Auggie's problems have all gone away, because they haven't and certainly unkindness can be found almost anywhere, but that Auggie has grown into a stronger person, as have those closest to him, and after all, isn't that what life is about? Being the best person we can be. I cannot recommend this book highly enough.

This book rivals some of my very favorite selections in children's literature. The various perspectives and the rich, dynamic characters stole my heart. I loved all of the quotes, especially the one about being kinder than necessary. Auggie and Via have tenacious spirits. I will be following this author from this point forward!
This book was "Wonder"ful!!

"Wonder" is really wonderful. 
 www.geekyjournals15.blogspot.com
A must read for everyone

"I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid." 
 This is very fortunate for the reader because an ordinary ten-year-old kid wouldn't have captured my heart the way Auggie did. While this is marketed as a YA novel, this should be on everyone's to-read list. I wasn't expecting this to be told through various perspectives, so when it jumped out of Auggie's point of view, I didn't know what to expect. Luckily, I fell in love with it. I feel that Auggie could have carried the story but, by using the others, more depth was added to the novel - much like real life. We often see things in our lives through our own lenses and struggle to understand others' motives. Sometimes we are lucky to read a book that reminds us that everyone carries their own struggles through life. We shouldn't be so quick to judge others because we never really know what they are experiencing that they might not want us to know- no matter how close you may have been to each other. Each person carries their own story until it blends into or out of Auggie's life. This story is so convincing that I wanted to walk into the school and meet Auggie. Great writing, beautiful story, and this review will never do it justice. 
 PSA NOTICE: Before you reach the end of the story (spoiler alert: Beware of the graduation scene), make sure you are well stocked in tissues. You'll need some to finish the story.

Loved this story of Auggie, a boy born with a severely deformed face. Due to surgeries, he's been homeschooled, but as the book begins he's going to 5th grade at Beecher Prep. We get the first year of his school experience from Auggie's point of view, and then it switches among other people in his life, returning to Auggie's perspective at the end. Wonderful characters, and wonderful evolution of the students who he meets at school and how they are changed as well. Excellent!
I had heard great things about this one and it did not disappoint. Having the story told from the perspective of several different characters was very effective.
This book was absolutely amazing! I sobbed, I laughed out loud, I even cheered! Touching and wonderfully written. It is one of those books that you just can't put down once you start, so be prepared!

This was a good story with some very important messages about kindness and bullying. I think it's something every parent should read with their child. I appreciated reading different perspectives, which created very real characters. I would have loved to have read the perspective of a teacher or parent, and I think the ending gave too much false hope that everything was perfect now. Some of the challenges the main character faces will follow him his entire life, and I wish the author had at least somewhat alluded to this. All in all, a "good read." ;)
daisy, auggie, miranda, and tears

We've all had to face troubles. It's in facing the troubles and struggles that courage is found. Auggie Pullman has had to struggle his whole life, whether it's surgery or the reactions from people who see his face for the first time. Now, though, he's going to school for the first time, and it's middle school, which is even tougher! 
 How Auggie deals with 5th grade, his differences and all the other struggles of middle school, being different and growing up is She connects the threads of each of the people who narrate the story by giving us a quote that pertains to the story. 
 It would be fantastic if this were required reading at the beginning of the first year of middle school! Maybe then, as the book quotes from J.M. Barrie, we will "....make a new rule of life....always try to be a little kinder than is necessary." 
 I recommend this book to anyone, and especially to teachers.
Every person should read this book.

"Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 In her astounding debut novel, Palacio's "Wonder" illuminates on the importance of acceptance and self-discovery at an age where we are still trying to determine who we are and where we fit in the world. Following the lives of Auggie Pullman and those close in his life, this coming of age novel truly uncovers the trials individuals go through when the world appears against them. A true work of art, "Wonder" will take you on a roller coaster of emotions within the first few pages of the novel. Will Auggie discover what true friendship is? How will the characters cope with their inner turmoils? 
 --May Contain Spoilers-- 
 I picked this book as part of the POPSUGAR Reading Challenge, for one of the challenges is picking a book which has a film coming out in 2017. I had a good feeling about this book before I even read it by the reviews, the aesthetic of the book cover, and the story it had to tell. 
 Palacio's "Wonder" impressed me far beyond my original expectations! I finished this in a day and was devastated when it was done simply because I wanted more! Books like this make me tremendously happy that I'm a book reader and that authors like Palacio exist! 
 This book touched me in ways that I haven't felt in a long time from a novel. One minute I was full of smiles... then I was in absolute tears...then I was furious...then I would end up hysterically laughing. There are so many important life lessons to take from this novel, I feel as though this should be a mandatory read in elementary or high school English curriculum's. I had a hard time staying objective in this review, but I hope that the little snippets of my own experiences further emphasize how wonderful this novel really is. 
 Okay, let's get on with this review. As a forewarning, this review contains minor spoilers... 
 The story is about August "Auggie" Pullman, a boy born with a facial deformity that is now entering school for the first time in the 5th Grade. Throughout the story, we are introduced to a number of obstacles Auggie must face. Bullying, discrimination, self-doubt and loathing, isolation...Auggie's trials are definitely a handful for such a young boy. However, it's through these battles that Auggie begins to learn more about the kind of person he wants to be and how beauty comes in a number of ways. His optimism and strength are such inspiration, you begin to feel a sense of encouragement to find the light in your own life. 
 However, Palacio not only focuses on Auggie's story but of his friends and family. His sister Via's strengths and weaknesses when it comes to the family dynamic, his friends Summer's desire to seek the beauty in the world and Jack's inner turmoil with knowing what defines true friendship, Via's boyfriend Justin's introduction to a world he is not accustomed to, and Miranda's struggle with family identity are just a few of the challenges the characters face in Palacio's extraordinary novel. When I say it's a roller coaster of emotions, I truly mean it... 
 In order to execute this properly, Palacio uses multi first-person narration to place us further into the lives of all these characters. I'm not typically a fan of multiple narrators, but I don't think "Wonder" would have been as remarkable if it was only in Auggie's point of view. It's through this narration style that readers are able to fully grasp how characters are feeling with their own challenges. 
 One POV that resonated with me the most is Olivia "Via" Pullman, Auggie's older sister. Via loves and accepts Auggie in the most beautiful and touching way imaginable, caring and protecting him in the best way she can...but she's not perfect. In her new high school, Via struggles with friend changes and for once wanting to not be the girl with the "facially deformed brother". She wants to be seen as a normal girl with a normal family, which causes her immense guilt and anxiety. Coming from a household with a brother who's been diagnosed with low functioning autism, I completely felt her pain and cried along with her. It's content like this that makes "Wonder" a magnificent piece of literature. Palacio doesn't sugarcoat it...she unmasks the truth, uncovering the good and the bad and the ugly sides of humanity. 
 What I found even more brilliant is the change in writing style as the narration switched. Each character has their own voice, making you really feel the changes in the characters. Palacio even went to extremes such as changing the sentence and grammatical structure to emphasize the character change. I felt so much more connected to each character's' story due to small details such as this - her writing is truly genius. 
 Palacio's "Wonder" is by far the best piece of new literature I've read in 2017. Personally, I find it so hard to read books about people with facial deformities or with special needs or with physical disabilities. It's not because I find these topics too much, but because I find many novels don't truly demonstrate what it's like to live in a life with one of these difficulties. Having Ty (my brother) in my life, it's hard to acknowledge a number of books as good pieces of literature for the stories are so pretty and happy. It's not always pretty and it's not always happy...everyday has a challenge to overcome and sometimes life just gets messy. Palacio acknowledges these parts; she demonstrates that even family members like sisters aren't always the perfect sister, parents don't always have all the answers, and people in society are not always nice and accepting... 
 But what I truly loved is the emphasis on how there is more beauty in the world than darkness. 
 "Wonder" shows what one small act of kindness can do, changing the motion of the world. Humans are funny creatures, full of grand surprises. Palacio highlights on this through the remarkable friendships Auggie makes and the beautiful family dynamic of the Pullman's. Life is truly beautiful, especially when we learn to look beyond ourselves and the physical world. This novel shows there's no such thing as purely good people and purely bad people - we are all imperfect beings in a very imperfect yet magically wonderful world. If the story alone doesn't pull you in, the abundance of beautifully written quotes regarding life lessons and inspirations will definitely provide you with joy. 
 If Palacio's "Wonder" is not already on your TBR list, I strongly encourage you to add it and read it as soon as you possibly can. It's a charming, fast-paced read that is a joy for all ages. 
 "The things we do outlast our mortality. The things we do are like monuments that people build to honor heroes after they've died. They're like the pyramids that the Egyptians built to honor the pharaohs. Only instead of being made of stone, they're made out of the memories people have of you." 
 -- R.J. Palacio, "Wonder"

Started and ended this book in less that 10 hrs.Well written feel good story. I can't wait for my 10 year old to read it! Hope he loves and enjoys it as much as I dodY~SdY$?PS. If you want an easy feel-good read this is it.It doesn't hurt to be reminded about kindness either.
MY HEART. One of my new favourite books of all time. This should be required reading.

I am going to love sharing this book with my students. It is about a serious topic, the acceptance of someone who looks very different from the average. It has a positive message about the importance of kindness. The characters are believable, and it is the rare young adult novel where the adults are supportive and intelligent.
Remarkable, wonder-ful, heartbreaking and heartwarming. This should be read aloud to every grade four class. No exceptions.

4.5 stars 
 So heartwarming
This book should be required reading for middle school students. If you can be unkind after reading it, you are a lost cause.

Para empezar me gustaria decir que esperaba mucho de este libro y casi me dejo satisfecha en todo aspecto. Este es un libro hermoso que recomiendo mucho a toda la gente de cualquier edad. Como puntos buenos puedo decir que es muy fluido y muy "masticable" esta hecho para que cualquier tipo de publico logre captar el mensaje que la autora quiere dar, que es basicamente: "lo de adentro es lo que cuenta". 
 Punto malo en mi opinion es que no es un libro con el que me haya sentido identificada con los personajes. 
 Aun asi la historia se disfruta mucho y es super recomendadisima si se quiere salir de un bloqueo lector o se quiere iniciar con la lectura. 
 Y sin duda alguna este libro deberia estar en todas las escuelas de primaria (5to y 6to ano) y las secundarias de todo el planeta.

Poignant tale of a 5th grader's search for acceptance amongst his peers. Auggie (August) has a facial deformity that he nimself tells the reader is worse then can be imagined. Due to the many surgeries and the obvious social implications caused by his birth defect, Auggie has never attended regular school, until now. How will he be accepted? Can people look beyond physical appearance to see the charming, shy boy underneath? 
 Told from various points of view, this story captivates and lifts your spirit. I highly recommend for anyone even though this is technically a children's novel. If you have small kids, read it with them. Far from a black and white tale, the various viewpoints help young readers see that no one has it easy, and everyone has daily struggles. 
 Love!

This is a cute book even though I have the idea that it was carefully planned, but like "The fault in our stars" by Green, there are arguments tearjerker that will continue to sell forever. In addition Auggie is also sympathetic, his vision of the world, even if at times in Star Wars version is fun and the story is well written. So it is quite possible that one day I read this book to my son, trying to teach him to go beyond appearances, especially in the case of someone with whom the universe, chance, fate or simply genetics, has not been so kind. 
 Questo e un libro carino anche se ho idea sia stato costruito a tavolino, ma come anche The fault in our star di Green, ci sono degli argomenti strappalacrime che continueranno a vendere per sempre. Inoltre Auggie e anche simpatico, la sua visione del mondo, anche se a volte in versione Star Wars e divertente e la storia e ben scritta. Quindi e piuttosto possibile che un giorno io legga questo libro a mio figlio, cercando di insegnargli ad andare al di la delle apparenze, specialmente nel caso di qualcuno con cui l'universo, il caso, il destino o semplicemente la genetica, non e stata poi cosi gentile.
Probably one of the best treatments of a character who has a deformity. Very authentic and heartwarming.

Hmm. I thought that I've had this on my to-read list for a long time, but it looks like it wasn't, although I've heard a lot about it since it came out. At church this morning, my minister (Hi Liz, who's on GR, if you see this!) talked about reading (and enjoying) this on the recommendation of her 2 god-daughters. I told Liz that if she liked this one, there were plenty of other children's and YA books that she would like!

As someone who grew up with a facial deformity I knew I had to read this book. Unlike August though, I began school in kindergarten (and attended daycare before that) so the students in my class were used to me. That didn't make my time at school any less difficult but it did mean that most of the students in my class didn't stare at me. 
 Palacio wrote Augusts' story from different perspectives (his older sister, her boyfriend, his friends from school, his sister's friend) and I felt like that was a nice twist on the story. I often forget that my older sister went through her own difficulties (well I don't forget, I just remember always being hurt when she wouldn't do things with me). 
 August has real concerns about attending school and he takes most of it the way I took it (I either ignored it or made a joke of it). I used to wear leg braces in my primary years and so on top of having a facial deformity, I wore leg braces so I totally understood why August was so upset about having to get a hearing aid. Something so insignificant can be a big deal. 
 The author did not spare the main character heartache and challenges which I think is so important because she knows his whole life will be that way. There will always be challenges to overcome and some will seem like the world is crashing in around you and others you will want to take a running leap at for all the excitement but the thing is, those challenges happen and you move on from them. Life goes on and that is what I took from this book. 
 I was lucky, I was able to have a surgery (I had to wait till I had stopped growing) and things were better. There are still challenges that make me want to hide in my bed but like August, I persevere. 
 I give Wonder 5/5 stars because it was a spectacular read. The author was able to grasp different sides of his story and I really valued the different perspectives.
An amazing story of love and friendship. One you really should add to your reading lists. I loved it!

I don't know why I didn't think this book was fantastic. The premise was solid, the voices are strong (but maybe they weren't so distinct as they could have been), and the plot was fine. Well, maybe it was the plot that bothered me. There was nothing original. Child goes to school, child meets difficulties, child overcomes difficulties, child is met with glory and friendship and love and recognition for all of the difficulties that they have overcome, we leave with a feeling that the hard part is all over for our friend Auggie and that he'll have smooth sailing from now on. And that's not the way it works. Life is hard. Not just in middle school, not just for August and his family. 
 I don't know what it was. Maybe it was the voice? Maybe I am just looking for a look at disability/difference that is unique. I kept feeling like I was rereading Out of My Mind by Sharon Draper. A facial disfigurement and cerebral palsy have almost nothing in common except for the obviousness of the special treatment, the physical 'difference' between them and everyone else. So why, why, why, why, did these two books read the same way? There is no reason for them to. Disability and physical scarrings are as diverse as people themselves are, there are millions of ways to tell that story. So find a new way to tell that story. The racial struggle of stereotypes and such has been told and retold thousands of unique ways, even if we narrow it down to black vs white in the United States. So find a way to treat this issue originally. What I really think the problem is twofold: 1-this is an under-covered, under-written-about topic, so the moral is still way to close to the surface, and that is getting in the way of the story. This read like a didacticism. 2-There's no personal element. I don't get the drift that this subject is personal to the author. I feel like the author was trying to write a book that would succeed because it is "important" and deals with big issues. Love and acceptance and nonjudgement and taking care of your own. Good, important wonderful themes, but they were elbowing their way in front of the characters and the plot, which is not okay. 
 Now off the literary stuff, and onto reviewing the actions of the characters: 
 My first problem was the self-dubbed "center of the universe" problem. Via, in her first sentences of narration, accepts the fact that she is living in a house that revolves around August, and that she, understandably, resents that in the tiniest portion of her self. Why did she keep backstepping and excusing herself. We understand. Those are completely normal feelings to have, Via. Anybody who has ever had a sibling, ever, understands you to a certain extent. Another case of the author treating this issues with kid gloves. Why isn't it okay for Via to feel a little resentful of her brother? Because he's Different-with-a-capital-D and Special-with-a-capital-S? He's a PERSON. It is okay for her to feel mixed emotions towards him. He's not a paragon, he's a person. And so is she. If the moral of the story is that Auggie is no different than anyone else and should be treated as such...wait. That totally wasn't the moral of the story. I nailed the problem. The problem is that August, and a lot of these other protagonists such as Melody in Out of My Mind, are put on a pedestal. "Their challenges are much much harder than anything any of us 'normal' people will ever experience ever, so they deserve a medal just for surviving." The end of the book put August up on a literal pedestal with a medal. (I love Auggie, I really do think he is a great character.) THe whole book acted like August was, not only the center of the universe at home, but also at school. THis author seems to think that the introduction of one student to a school will unalterable change everything -social structure, attitudes of teachers, everything about a school. August is adorable, but one person doesn't make that much of a difference on three hundred 12 year olds. A bullying war that lasts all year long based off of one person's behavior. It just isn't the way middle school works, sorry. (disclaimer: if Beecher Prep was meant to come across as a much smaller private school, this part would not be relevant. A class of fifty could definitely be impacted/divided/affected to such an extent by one person. I've seen it happen. But that would be the authors fault for not explaining that better) 
 Numero Dos Problema. I know it was the first year he was well enough, but the "at middle school, they'll all be the new kid, it'll be great" reasoning is seriously typical-adult flawed. Like, top six bad ideas. Can we all agree that the issue with August going to school is not that he is New, it is that he is DIfferent. This stuff is so much better controlled in elementary school. In elementary school, you have one cohesive class, one teacher who knows you and knows all the students and knows how the students work together. Any kind of "bullying war" or hostile group dynamic could be diagnosed and then lectured out of them (in elementary school, kids actually listen to their teachers) The teacher could have helped Auggie and just, everything would have been so much better. SO much better. It physically hurt me knowing that August just had the bad luck to live in a place where fifth grade is middle school (Seriously? where is that! I was in seventh grade and I was hardly ready yet. I'd like to speak to these fictional administrators) and to have his parents run on such flawed reasoning and lack of real (read: talk to children) research and infocollecting. It hurt me knowing he could have been hurt so much less, entering the already-hard middle school years with a support system. ah. 
 I am glad this is middle-grade viral. It is an Important book. I just wish it were also Well Written and Original. :(

I love everything about this book. I love Auggie's spirit - the gentle way that he embraces life. I love the way the story is told from so many different perspectives. I love the choose kind message and I cried like a baby through the entire graduation ceremony. Reading as Auggie received his award brought former students to mind and reminded me of that feeling of inspiration and pride that we get from watching children grow up. After "listening" to Mr. Tushman's speech, complete with book excerpts, I hope to work for (and with) educators that would choose to encourage kindness (rather than success or determination) at a graduation ceremony. Overall: heartwarming and enjoyable!

Such an amazing book! Ten-year old August is about to enter 5th grade, after being homeschooled his whole life. His face is severely disfigured, though, and he struggles to find acceptance. It is funny, sad, honest, and inspiring. I also love the shifting narrators, who often tell different sides of the same part of the story. Finished it and immediately started reading it aloud to my 8-year old.
realistic. love people as they are on the INSIDE.

"Sometimes I think my head is so big because it is so full of dreams." 
 Wonder, a middle grade book beautifully written by RJ Palacio, is the story of a little boy who was born with facial deformity that prevented him from attending schools or from having a normal life and so he was homeschooled. Even after numerous surgeries, that didn't change much, he still freaks out kids and makes adult uncomfortable. Auggie's parents wanted their child to feel as normal as they could, so they decided that attending school is their next step, and the book is Auggie's experience with being exposed beyond this parents' shield, just like a fish taken out of water and into the real world where people don't know him and already judge him by the way he looks. 
 Palacio wrote a masterpiece that years from now is gonna be taught in school just for the wonderful morals and message it send. As sensitive and depressing the main idea may sounds like, Wonder is actually a joyful, cheerful piece of art. The characters in the book were mostly children and shows the way children are pure hearted and haven't been polluted by the judgmental, brutal world around them, yet there are other kids who has already followed adults into wrong routes and inherited wrong morals. Auggie had to encounter people of both worlds. 
 As you progress in the book, you'll realize how, actually Auggie's look didn't matter to him or people he knows and love, because the see him for what he is and not what he looks like. Auggie was a smart kid and knew how people see him and knew how people avoided looking directly at him for too long and he perfectly understands how people reacts to his presence, cause he is a self-aware character. 
 Palacio drew a stunning novel with marvelous writing style that suit all ages. The characters felt so vivid and layered which added a lot to the divine plotline. 
 As for me, this book was a turning point in my life, it taught me a lot of morals that I still act upon, it taught me to never judge a person by the way they look because that's so irrelevant and cruel. That no matter how horrible one's situation is, by a little optimism and a sprinkle of hope that everything will eventually be okay as long as you believe in yourself and others. It showed me how beautiful it is for someone to reach inner peace.

I did not actually read, I listened to the audiobook with my 6 year old son. I LOVED it, the reading was brilliant, we both loved it so much and probably will listen to it again. A beautiful book to listen to with a sensitive kid, and have discussions about what kind of person you want to be in this world.

My nine year old son read this and loved it. He rated it 10 stars. I can only give it five here, but it is deserving. This is a story of August's first year of middle school, and the first time he has ever gone to school because of the many surgeries he has had to correct his severe facial abnormalities.
Loved it. I ugly cried.
Wonderful!
i wanted to hug this book close when i was finished with it. such a wonderful and empowering read.

Check out my video to see why i rated this book 5/5 stars 
 http://youtu.be/paodE0R2ZrE
triumph over adversity

My sister summed up this book perfectly! And I quote "everyone should have to read this book at some point." If you haven't read this add it to your "to-read" list immediately. Beautiful story and interesting realistic characters.

Middle School OBOB 2015. Amazing book. I loved every aspect of it, from the plot and characters to the writing and format. The subject was perhaps the best thing about it though. I think all middle schoolers (and maybe elementary kids too) should read this and learn the importance of kindness, being yourself and not judging people based on appearances. I would highly recommend the book.
Will read with my students over and over and over again!

Everybody should read this book because everybody in the world at one point in time is August Pullman. I laughed. I cried. I feel inspired to be a better person. Any book that can do that is worth your time! Promise! 
 Quote I'd like to remember which I don't think is spoilery- but if you don't want any info from the book at all-don't read-like I said it's for me- 
 ""In another book by J.M. Barrie called The Little White Bird...he writes..." He started flipping through a small book on the podium until he found the page he was looking for, and then he put on his reading glasses. "'Shall we make a new rule of life...always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?'" Here Mr. Tushman looked up at the audience. "Kinder than is necessary," He repeated. "What a marvelous line, isn't it? Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed. Why I love that line, that concept, is that it reminds me that we carry with us, as human beings, not just the capacity to be kind, but the very choice of kindness. And what does that mean? How is that measured? You can't use a yardstick. It's like I was saying just before it's not like measuring how much you've grown in a year. It's not exactly quantifiable, is it? How do we know we've been kind? What is being kind, anyway?" He put on his reading glasses again and started flipping through another small book. "There's another passage in a different book I'd like to share with you," he said. "If you'll bear with me while I find it...Ah, here we go. In Under the Eye of the Clock, by Christopher Nolan, the main character is a young man who is facing some extraordinary challenges. There's this one part where someone helps him: a kid in his class. On the surface, it's a small gesture. But to this young man, whose name is Joseph, it's...well, if you'll permit me..." He cleared his throat and read from the book. "'It was at moments such as these that Joseph recognized the face of God in human form. It glimmered in their kindness to him, it glowed in their keenness, it hinted in their caring, indeed it caressed in their gaze.'" He paused and took off his reading glasses again. "It glimmered in their kindness to him," he repeated, smiling. "Such a simple thing, kindness. Such a simple thing. A nice word of encouragement given when needed. An act of friendship. A passing smile." He closed the book, put it down, and leaned forward on the podium. "Children, what I want to impart to you today is an understanding of the value of that simple thing called kindness. And that's all I want to leave you with today. I know I'm kind of infamous for my...um...verbosity..." Here everybody laughed again. I guess he knew he was known for his long speeches. "...but what I want you, my students, to take away from your middle-school experience," he continued, "is the sure knowledge that, in the future you make for yourselves, anything is possible. If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary-the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." He paused and shrugged. "Or whatever politically correct spiritual representation of universal goodness you happen to believe in."" -pg.300
So optimistic and wonderful, I teared up more than once. Highly recommend!!!

Sweet book. An unusual story, no doubt. Ten year old Auggie, born with a facial deformity, is starting school for the first time. And the kids at school do not exactly make it easy for him. His emotional journey through the year is depicted beautifully from his and others' perspectives. 
 It reminded me somehow of Eleanor & Park, another beautiful book I read earlier this year.

After sleeping on it, I changed my rating to four stars. Wonder was hyped by many friends and others on social networking sites, so I was excited to discover it in the media center at the middle school where I work. I had some ideas about what would take place in the book, and most of my predictions were correct. As with any books, people are moved by many different things. As I read Auggie's story, I began to wonder if others felt the same way I did. As an educator and parent, I have always been moved to help students and my son become the best they can be regardless of situations that come upon them. This book reminded me that all my efforts have not been in vain. I especially loved August's relationship with Daisy and how she loved him unconditionally. I was very glad that the situations were resolved toward the end of the book. I just felt that it needed something more, but I can't quite put those thoughts into words for this review. Maybe in time they will make sense. :)

This is an incredibly inspiring, special, unique and engaging story. I truly enjoyed reading this book! I basically read it in two days!!!! I could just not put it down. It is a truly special story and has HUGE character development! I have never seen so much character development in one story. Getting to see the story through many different perspectives was wonderful! I didn't think I would like it at first, but it only enhanced the story more! This is a must read for everyone because of the messages it delivers and should honestly be a must read in elementary school, like To Kill A Mockingbird is in most High School's. I loved this book so much!!

Yesterday, I was reading this book at my kids' Taekwondo tournament. A tween girl and came over to me to talk about the book. She'd read it in her class and the author had come in. She was compelled to tell me what the author had said and who her favorite character was. I liked that she was so passionate about it, she climbed up the stands to talk to me. 
 Today, I just finished Wonder. It's not so often I'm this moved by a novel. The book makes me want to be a better person. Although I miss the characters already, I'll remember them always. 
 Masterful book about bullying, compassion, true beauty. The story is about Auggie, who has a facial deformity and goes to a regular school for the first time in fifth grade. But the story also follows other important characters' stories. Each person has a distinct point of view and a unique voice. Their stories overlap in a way to bring us a complex, thought-provoking, and beautiful book. 
 If everyone read this book, the world would be a kinder place.

I read quite a few children's and Young Adult novels and it's only rarely that one of them truly fits into the "crossover" category where I can truthfully say anyone of any age will enjoy this novel. Wonder fits that niche perfectly, its deceptively simple narrative veiling a myriad of depths and insights. 
 Wonder is mostly about August (Auggie) Pullman, a 10 year old boy with severe facial disfigurement. Auggie has already been through a multitude of painful operations but his latest experience could well be the most challenging - going to school. He's been home-schooled up until now and sheltered from the curious and insensitive eyes of society at large but hopefully the three mentors chosen by Mr Tushman, the principal, will ease his transition. 
 What follows, in a series of short chapters, is an account of Auggie's experiences at Beecher Prep, narrated by Auggie himself and, in other sections, by his sister Olivia, his friend Summer, Olivia's boyfriend Justin, her friend Miranda and Jack who was chosen to be a guide/mentor for Auggie. The language is simple but the feelings examined are complex - what does it feel like to be different in a world which has such a limited view of beauty/attractiveness? What is it like for the siblings of someone who doesn't fit the norm? Isn't it really difficult to tread the "middle ground" and neither ignore nor stare? Auggie represents anyone who doesn't fit in and all our associated hang-ups when we strive to be politically correct but fail miserably. 
 There will be those who avoid this book as it sounds like some preachy manifesto and I fully understand their reticence. Yes, there is a moral message, basically, "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind" and yes, I know it sounds didactic but this isn't Mitch Albom territory and there is no deliberate pulling on the heartstrings or straying into schmaltz. Having said that, we could all learn something by having this little peek into Auggie's life, and perhaps adult readers have the most to learn from it.

I've waited a bit to write this because I really couldn't formulate the "what this book is about" part of the review. It really isn't "about" physical disability or deformity though that is certainly a topic. I think it's really about acceptance of others and of ourselves. About looking deeply inside to understand who we are and deciding that, for most of us at least, there's a lot of room to be better. 
 Having both a disabled brother (deceased at 21) and disabled daughter (alive and kicking at 34), I could completely identify with the emotions and stresses of every character except Auggie. I suspect it will be a revelation for most readers. Wonder is painful in the growing way.
so good that it made me cry multiple times in public

"If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you wil try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 -- R.J. Palacio, Wonder

This book was so good. I couldn't put it down, and was thinking about it whenever I wasn't reading. It feels real, it's funny, and it's just a great story about people trying to be decent. It's also very well written. This was hands down the best book I've read this year. Read it and share it!
Finished re-reading this "Wonder"ful book for a tutoring job and also to reread before the movie comes out in November! If you haven't read this book yet, you should.
Wow. When the narration shifted from the main character to different kids, I was hooked. By the end, I was crying and wishing it wouldn't end. Fantastic!

Wonder is a highly enjoyable read that will remain with the reader well after they are finished reading. 
 This book is written mainly through Auggie's point of view however at times we are treated to the point of view of his sister and a couple of his school friends. We get to see how Auggie has affected their lives both in a positive and negative aspect. 
 I was unable to put this book down and read it in just a couple of hours. One minute I would find myself laughing along with the characters and the next moment I would find myself wiping away the tears. This book certainly takes the reader on a rollercoaster of emotions. 
 I found myself able to relate to Auggie in a sense. I was bullied throughout school, I was that awkward kid that wore glasses and liked to read and I feel that this is one of the many reasons that this book appealed to me so much. 
 Overall this book was an amazing read that I recommend everyone reads at least once.

A feel-good book for tween and teen readers. I only wish middle-schoolers were actually so self-aware and kind. Different characters narrate, though the first section is narrated by the main character, August (Auggie), who is born horribly deformed. I wish the whole book had been from his point of view. I kind of hate it when a book will have multiple narrators. I can deal with two, but more than that seems gratuitous and lazy. Anyway, he starts going to a school in 5th grade, and this is the story of his first year in school. As you can imagine, it's difficult and often unpleasant, but he makes some friends, and finds his place.

This is a very heartwarming and inspirational novel about a boy with a severe facial deformity entering the 5th grade. He's been homeschooled all his life and now he has to deal with the common stresses of middle school on top of the problems of his birth defect. I love that the theme of this book is to be kinder than is necessary. I also think that this could be a good book to illustrate point of view, as the author presents this story from the point of view of several of the books' characters. Be careful if choosing this book as a read-aloud, as there are several emotional moments in the book.

When I began this book, I thought I am gonna end up crying !! But thank God it is a happy ending book :) 
 Enjoyed a lot ! Glad I chose this book :)

Young Auggie Pullman is attending school for the first time in his life (after being home-schooled up to this point). The usual jitters of going to middle school and being the new kid are compounded by the facial deformities that Auggie was born with. Told with warmth, and, well, wonder, the book deals with the cruelty that kids can inflict on each other, and how some can triumph over it with grace and dignity. 
 Auggie can't help but notice and be hurt by how other kids, his teachers and total strangers react to how he looks. No wonder his favorite holiday is Halloween, when he can be treated like any other kid. 
 The book changes viewpoints as it moves along, giving the viewpoints of Auggie, his sister, the kids who befriend him, and others. Each character is written with depth and honesty and feels like a completely separate person with their flaws and observations. 
 By the end, I was overjoyed that I had come across this book. It is a story that will stay with me. I can't imagine anyone reading this and not being changed by it. Strongly recommended.
An unexpected gem! Truly wonderful.
I loved this book so much. The characters were so well written and I loved that everyone told their own story. It's going to be hard to find a better book that this one in 2013.
Story about a little boy who was born deformed his year at age 8 I think. touching couragous, cute

I read this to find out if I should have the kids (that I tutor) read this... Once in a while, I read something and realize that not all hope is lost for children's and YA literature. This book actually reminded me of the books I read as a middle school student just a decade ago, especially Paul Zindel's The Pigman or Hinton's The Outsiders. Do these books even exist anymore for the next generation? Few people even in my generation were still reading them. 
 As great as popular series such as Percy Jackson are to encourage kids to read, sometimes I think they need to start reading more fiction that doesn't pull any punches about how life can be - especially the kids who are already raised in a bubble where their parents see to their every need and they're only exposed to other kids who are similar to themselves. What I do see instead is books that you think are "realistic" because there's death involved, such as The Maze Runner, are set in such fantastic circumstances that most of the emotional impact seems to be lost on the kids. It's really good to know that there are still actual books like this that appeal to young readers, rather than what I see in the Scholastic catalog sent home from schools - Buy the mockingjay pin! Buy this Minecraft 72 page "book" with a toy! Buy this detective "book" that comes with a cheap plastic magnifying glass and invisible ink pen! At the end of the day, kids don't need gimmicks when there's a real story. 
 I wish all schools had teachers like Mr. Browne or administrators like Mr. Tushman. But even if kids don't hear it from the adults in their own lives, that's the magic of being able to pick up a book and jump into someone else's life. 
 "Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed."

It was a good book dont get me wrong but it wasnt very interesting. The message behind it was great but at no point did this book make me emotional. It stirred nothing in me.. There wasnt enough UMPH for me. 
 Also, a few things annoyed me: 
 The ending seemed rushed 
 Auggie ate his grapes after they'd been cut in half and mashed his food in the restaurant but ate a grilled cheese sandwich is three bites? 
 Auggies tone went from a ten year old to a sixteen year old throughout the book and lastly; 
 There was no mention of the way he spoke other than the fact that he mumbled when he was nervous. It just didnt make sense to me that he spoke so fluently yet had problems with his jaw.

Something rare and amazingly special, one of those treasures that shines brightly on a number of fronts. This is, at its basic level, the story of Auggie's fifth grade year. The characters are outstanding. Main character August (Auggie), enters a school for the first time as a fifth grader because of his facial abnormalities, is drawn brilliantly, one of those rare characters of thought and feeling and goodness that meld into a believable jewel of a whole boy. His support is also exemplary. He was physically challenged at birth but he was also blessed with a loving, supportive, and realistic family, his parents and sister Olivia (Via), who not only see and treat him as a whole person, but come to be treasured by Auggie's and Via's friends, too. The kids at Auggie's school are spot-on, real kids who say and do real kid things, and some, unfortunately, who display less than kind responses to Auggie's appearance's oddity. The school's adults and Via's friends also are nicely written. 
 As an adult who has long worked with youngsters around Auggie's age, and having first-hand experience with unique appearance and with children with unique appearances, I came away from this not only having loved it myself, with the firm conviction that Wonder is a terrific story on its basic level, but more, a book of values underneath that youngsters will absorb to their benefit, values like the role of externals in seeing another person, the role of kindness, the roles of patience, authentic love and caring, and more than a bit of what goes around comes around. Placed firmly in the top ten books for young people that I've ever read.

How is it possible for a book to be so simple, deeply touching, terribly painful yet exceedingly hopeful? 
 This book is a wonder! :')

I wish that I read this in middle school, along with everyone else in my grade! Very sweet & endearing, gives insight to those few in your class that don't blend in as well as others. Always a good reminder to be kind:)

Spent all day reading this YA book. Made me cry like 10x. People kept asking me what was wrong. I'm weepy bc this fictional book with these fictional characters and fictional conflicts are making me fucking emotional. BYE.

Very entertaining young adult novel, told from multiple characters' viewpoints. At the heart of the story, and getting the most pages, is Auggie, a boy with a genetic condition that has affected his face in very noticeable ways. The novel covers Auggie's first year of middle school - his first year of school, period, as he was home schooled before. He goes through many interesting ups and downs, ultimately learning a lot about himself and others. The characters are compelling, if a little simple/stereotypical, and the setting of New York City is a good backdrop for the story. All in all, a good reading experience.

A very light read compared to the subject it is handling. Good start but right in the middle loses track due to some unnecessary characters. Close to end, it simply becomes a bit unrealistic. Everything goes right for boy in very predictable ways. 
 Some parts of book stay with you even after it is over.
Choose kindness.
Amazing!!!

Parents, please get this book for your kids. And then read it yourself because I can vow that adults could love and learn a lot from this story too. 
 It's books like this that can inspire an empathetic world. It doesn't have you connect with the main character alone, but it shows you how deformity affects everyone around them too. ...I wasn't expecting that. But I'm glad it did. The main character wanted nothing more than to be normal when no one could see him that way. It shows how too much kindness and coddling can be almost as bad as fear. It mainly focus on fear of course, but it will have you analyze what is appropriate. Kids aren't stupid. They know when you are overcompensating and that knowledge can help everyone take that step further into open-mindedness. 
 The only downfall was that the humor was a bit too young for me, but it's hits the demographic head on and that is far more important - so I'm not letting it affect my rating. Plus it's still cute, I just felt that the main character got more laughs out of it then I did. 
 Honestly, if that is the only criticism I can find, then that is a wonderful sign. 
 This book will make you a better person.

Everyone seems to love this book all over the place - apparently for very convincing reasons, as it deals with what a deformed little boy has to go through in school when his new classmates are confronted with his face for the first time. This is a book about bullying, but also about hope, friendship and family. And it's a good book, featuring a believable and interesting protagonist you simply can't help but relate to. 
 August ,,Auggie" Pullman has been born with a cleft palate which left him with a facial deformation, influencing his hearing abilities and scaring a lot of the people he meets away. After being homeschooled for quite some years, at the age of ten, Auggie's parents finally decide to allow him to enter middle school - leading Auggie into the beginning of a new chapter in his life, a chapter in which he is going to be confronted with friendship and the darkest sides of bullying alike. Entering this novel, I didn't know that cleft palates occure in 1 to 2 per 1000 births in the developed world - the subject of the novel is certainly a very strong and important one, a subject people should be confronted with because, after all, there is still too much bullying in this world. 
 Palacio structured her book in a very interesting way by including the viewpoints of several characters. After allowing the reader to get used to Auggie's voice, we meet his sister Via, then one of Auggie's friends at school, Summer, afterwards another classmate called Jack, then Via's boyfriend and finally an old friend of Via, Miranda. All of them were characterized by unique voices ... a method I didn't approve of at all. Why does an author need to write entire chapters without capitalization and in fragmented sentences just to underline that the character doesn't seem to care about grammar and how to express oneself properly? It was annoying and a struggle to read, as were the Facebook chat messages between two characters, which mainly consisted of messages like ,,can we b frenz agen?" or ,,awsum!!!!" by characters who talk in their own point of view chapters sophisticated enough to appear capable of using the English language without butchering it. It is simply contradictory when the author writes about one character in his very own punctuation, but then writes inconsistently about the voices of others. 
 If you don't want to be spoiled about the ending, then please don't read the parts I marked as such. Don't say I didn't warn you. 
 The ending is happier than a novel with such a dark and depressing topic should be allowed to be. Reminiscent of successful movies like ,,Shawshank Redemption", this tale dealt with serious topics and then allowed the topic hope to take over the style of the story. But in comparison with Shawshank, ,,Wonder" didn't conclude on a bitter-sweet and realistic note, it simply cried out ,,Here is your happy ending!" and ,,Be happy about it!" I did care for Auggie and was happy to realize that in the ending he had his own touching and amazing moments. But it took away a lot of the realistic aspects from the beginning, because when does a story actually end on such a happy note in real life? Remember that this is simply my personal opinion, but I thought that a more subtile conclusion would have been more memorable. The way it was written, this simply appeared to be like another school drama, even in spite of all the serious topics which were attached in the beginning and the middle part. 
 Some time after the release of Wonder, R.J. Palacio published another chapter with the point of view of Julian, one of the kids who bullied Auggie in school. Not even Goodreads seems to know how to deal with this story, as there is one edition of Wonder with more than 160,000 ratings (the one I am reviewing right now) and then another edition with 110,000 ratings which includes the ten pages from the Julian chapter. Until a few weeks ago, those two editions were combined in a single book, yet now they have been divided into two different books on GR - which is confusing as hell. (Edit: As of October 2016, the two editions are combined as one single edition again.) Anyway, I gave the other edition two stars because of the way Palacio tried (and for me, obviously, failed) to excuse bullying. Julian was revealed to have suffered from nightmares about scary faces in his childhood, which made him feel like Auggie is just another monster - thus his awful behavior towards him. I don't doubt that something like this might happen in real life, just as, after all, there is no excuse for bullying. It was the way Palacio sounded as if this was to redeem Julian's character which confused me and ultimately made me feel like having some negative experiences in one's childhood makes up for plaguing someone who isn't even responsible for the way he looks. 
 This is a book loved by almost everyone, and they are all right. Believe them. I'm just this weird reader who almost never likes those books which have received all the attention in the universe. 
 Buddy Read with Anne. Click here for her review.

People have been raving about this book for a long time, but many reviews and comments that I've read mentioned that it tackles tough subject matter and has some disturbing scenes. My just finishing second grade daughter chose it at a book swap last weekend, so I swiped it and read it in a couple of hours to make sure that it was appropriate from both reading level and thematic perspectives. The reading level was fine for my precocious reader, and I didn't find the book disturbing - instead, I found it, on the whole, to be very sweet. The premise of the book (horribly disfigured boy named August enters fifth grade at a nearby private school after being homeschooled his whole life) is, of course, sad, and August has to grapple with identity issues and some bullying, which some parents might find off-putting; I did not. It's written well, and Palacio integrates multiple perspectives into the book by switching up the narrator a number of times - a stylistic approach that, in my opinion, is difficult to pull off successfully. There is a strong cast of vibrant characters throughout the work, and the love and affection within August's family was touching. 
 Overall, this is a solid novel for mature elementary school audiences and beyond. It offers lots of opportunities to talk with your child about the importance of compassion, empathy, and love; it doesn't shy away from the fact that there are many painful elements present in children's lives, which I appreciated. I strongly recommend it for its target audience but didn't find it particularly illuminating as an adult, although I know that it has been on the best seller lists for ages and touted as a book that adults and teens will find engrossing. The three stars are my reaction to the book, which might be a bit unfair; a kid would likely give it at least four stars. For me, though, not surprisingly, I felt that the novel lacked sophistication and had an altogether too tidy happy ending.
Great read. A little repetitive but the message is perfect.

Great voices - I liked the way the author alternated points of view so we saw how others were experiencing Auggie's world too. The story is so believable and feels honest. Great lessons about acceptance - both self-acceptance and accepting others. This book is definitely deserving of all the accolades it's been getting. I'm glad I read it!
What a terrific book. Voice was authentic, story was interesting and well written, theme was challenging and ultimately uplifting. A good book for mid-graders who think about the world.

This work of art is instantly going into my bin of favorites. It made me stay up too late and get up too early because I had to know Auggie's story. 
 Wonder, by R.J. Palacio, is a beautifully written story proving that kindness should be given to all and integrity is earned through consistent actions; that the greatest courage can most definitely come from those from which society may least expect it. 
 Multi-layered, complex characters offered their unique point of view into a variety of situations. Through Auggie's strength, others blossomed. Palacio developed her secondary characters beautifully, allowing them to gradually become more comfortable with Auggie. She did not pretend that they were perfect, but instead made them real. Individually, they made mistakes, but grew together. 
 I thoroughly enjoyed everything about this book; the characters, the plot, the writing style, and the format. This book will instantly catch fire in room 107!
I would recommend this for young teens! And pediatricians!

Wonder is the best new book I've read in a long time. The characters, the book cover, the story totally won me over. Auggie was born with facial deformities that required much of his young life to be spent in hospitals. Not that he wasn't smart, but he just was never able to formally attend school since he was in and out of hospitals having multiple surgeries. Now he's entering 5th grade, and the middle school he is attending has never seen anyone like Auggie. Yes, he's smart and kind and funny, but many people have a tough time getting over his physical deformities. Even his sister, who loves Auggie, is afraid to admit that he is her brother because she is afraid of what her friends might think. Auggie knows he's just a normal middle school kid (aside from his face), but it's tough to get other kids to understand that and get beyond his physical appearance. 
 Readers will love Auggie and will be rooting for him and for others in the story to get beyond his physical deformities and see him for who he is. Such a well-written and thought provoking story. As angry as I got at the bullies and other who gave him a hard time, I fell in love with the fellow students and principal and others in the story who were able to get past what Auggie really looked like and saw him for the great kid he was. Each chapter is told from a different person's perspective, and really gives insight as to how each person in his life is thinking. I highly recommend this story for girls or boys in grades 4-7. See the Random House book trailer at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fgB7_K...

This is the best book I have read in a very long time. It may be in the top 5 books I have been blessed to read in my whole life. 
 This book is important, moving, funny, sweet, sad and so so special. Told from the point of view of a very unique young man and the people who love him, this book is different and unlike any other in all of the best ways. Just like it's main character. 
 Completely appropriate for kids, 4th grade and up, but not just for them. I suspect the adults around kiddos of that age and up need it even more. 
 I can't wait for my kids to read this book. I hope their friends read it, and their teachers too. I hope their school administrators read it, I would like everyone to read this book. 
 The author quotes J.M.Barrie, from his book The Little White Bird: "Shall we make a new rule of life . . . always try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" If we could, each of us do this everyday, think of the world we could make. 
 I ask you to read this book, and then together, we can change the world.

Absolutely loved this short book. The voice in each chapter changes so the reader is offered multi-perspectives to the same situation.The situation being a boy being born with major facial deformations. He has a loving supportive family consisting of parents and an older sister. When he is 10 years old, it is decided that he will attend public school instead of being home schooled. The story focuses on his grade 5 school year. As expected he faces many social challenges. In the end we see how those that have met him and taken the time to get to know him have all found a wonderful human being with a fantastic sense of humor. A wonderfully sweet read! Would be excellent for grades 6-8.
Great read. Wished for a less cream and sugar in this cup of coffee.

Per my review at Baltimore Reads: 
 The first day of school can bring forth many feelings - excitement, anticipation, dread, nausea, etc. It is especially difficult to walk through the hallways if you're the "new kid" with the added pressure of adjusting to new environments, teachers, and classmates. Now imagine having to go through the "new kid" initiation as a ten-year-old boy normal in every aspect except the one that counts the most for first impressions: appearance. 
 R.J. Palacio's Wonder stars August Pullman, a boy born with a genetic mutation that has resulted in various facial deformities. Homeschooling was the only way to keep August on track while he had countless surgeries to correct these deformities, but as the first day of fifth grade draws near, his parents agree that it is time to give mainstream schooling a shot. August is understandably against this decision at first, but after a visit to Beecher Prep, the local middle school, he accepts his fate and shows up with the rest of the boys and girls his age on the first day of school. Wonder chronicles August's experiences during his fifth-grade school year, which span from extremely heartbreaking to incredibly uplifting. 
 Despite his abnormal experience, August is just like any other ten-year-old. He loves Star Wars, video games, and his dog Daisy. Mentally he is just as capable as other kids his age. Yet gaining the acceptance of his classmates is complicated by the fact that it is almost impossible to initially see past all his facial deformities. Kids are afraid to even touch him (a horrible game called The Plague spreads which requires anyone who comes in contact with August to immediately wash themselves). And yet, as the school year progresses, so does the maturity and humanity of August's classmates as they begin to see the real August beneath his mask. 
 What I enjoyed most about Wonder was that Palacio approached the situation from various perspectives. August's voice is obviously given a large chunk of the narrative, but readers also hear from his sister Olivia, his friends Jack and Summer, Olivia's boyfriend Justin, and Olivia's friend Miranda. While August has to walk around with his deformity every day, other people are also affected by his misfortunes. His sister's needs have been constantly overshadowed by her younger brother's. His friends take a big risk by accepting the school "freak." These alternate voices add even more depth to the emotion that August's story produces. 
 Children and adults alike could learn a lot from Wonder. It is a story of facing your fears, standing up for those you love, and learning to accept those who are different from you. August Pullman proves that it is never easy overcoming obstacles, but it is possible with a little bit of courage and a lot of help and support from those around you.
I loved this book but the writing style was kind of hard to get into so I ended up giving it 3.5 out of 5 stars. Full review: https://abibliophobe1989.wordpress.co...
Very moving story! Loved reading it and hope to recommend "Wonder" to readers of all ages!

They did recommend this book a couple of time to me and I was finally able to read it. It was a good recommendation, I totally I loved it. 
 Wonder is a beautiful, emotional, funny story about a boy that find his place in the world 
 We are introduced in this story with August, who loves star wars, playing at the playstation, reading fantasy books, sound like a normal kid. But what makes August different or extraordinary, is his face. He was born with a genetic anomaly, that caused a deformations of his facial characters. Even after a lot of surgical operations, he still doesn't look "normal". August knows that, he knows how people avoid looking at him and stare when they think they are notice, he knows they call him monster, he knows that people will always judge him first for his appearance; what it doesn't expect is to now people who will see beyond it. 
 When August as to face his first year of middle school, leaving the protection of his parents and home, he will be pushed out of his comfort zone, having to face the stares, whispers and ostracism that comes with been the new kid - only ten time worse. 
 The story is well written, having a simple style and good peace, changing the different point of view. It tends to be a bit too simple-minded pushing to an happy ending that in the reality of things could have been just slightly done. The kids in the book feel at times unrealistic, their behavior is to mature for their age. But given the light and funny mood that the writer wants, it's quite understandable. It reads on his own, it would do for a great middle-school read. 
 For me it was the first time reading about the Treacher-Collins Syndrome, I was happy to find an entertaining book that could also push me to be more curious about a subject that we don't commonly discuss. 
 I would highly recommend it to any middle and high school kid, but also adult, we are able to be worse than kids sometimes, we should stop be afraid of what's different and start trying to better understand it. 
 They are also going to do a movie adaptation of the book, to be released around april 2017 in the U.S.A 
 4.5/5 STARS
