This is such a sweet little book. August is born with severe birth defects and is going to public school for the first time. This book is about the people he meets there and the ways they react to him. Many of the reactions are what you would expect, but there are a few that are rather surprising. The messages to the reader are sweet and great reminders of things that most people need reminded of. 
 Even though this is a book for children, it would be a great read for the whole family. I would especially recommend it to children with some sort of a disability or to someone going to school for the first time. 
 The ending makes you want to hug everyone you see because of all the feelings that are evoked. There are good and bad crus in this book, but it is mostly a feel-good story.
Wonder is a stand alone book. Hard to compare with others. A story that is needed. I think in it's own way, Wonder is a new generations Flowers for Algernon.
One of the most incredible books I've ever read. Funny, heartbreaking, touching, bittersweet...a must-read.

This book is a must read no matter what your age is! It would be an especially important book for young children to read in an age where there is so much diversity in the world but not enough kindness. 
 This book has gave me so many feels, apart from August the main character I empathised most with was Via, his sister. The fact that she feels that she is put to the side since August was born and how she can never feel like her own person. 
 This book is more than just about a child with a facial disfiguration, it's a book about family, friendships and how everyone views the world differently and everyone is unique. The book addresses bullying in the best possible way, making it easy to see who the bullies are and how you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt them. 
 I completely recommend this book and wish that it was required reading in schools as it instils such a feeling of how humans should be.
Love! Couldn't put it down. Neither could my 11-yr-old. A great book for kids 10 and up.

This was a tough book for me to read since one of my close friends has a little girl who was born with craniofacial abnormalities. I think this book should be required reading for all students in middle school. It's really wonderfully written and tells Auggie's story from many different perspectives. Great lesson... it's tough to be different and sometimes it takes courage to be friends with those who are.
Loved it! But i really need to keep reading books in english, translations just dont make it coherent
I loved this story. Auggie and his family broke my heart but reminded me that although life can be painful it is also joyful.

Loved, loved, loved this story of a young boy with a facial deformity, August, who is attending public school for the first time as a 5th grader. August acts with courage, patience, kindness, and frustration as he tries to get his classmates to look beyond his scary face and see the person underneath. Would make a great read-aloud.
Oh my god. This was an excellent use of my morning I ugly cried.

Wonder is one of those books I've heard a lot about, and knew that people really loved, but never got around to reading until now. I liked Wonder, but not as much as I thought I would. 
 I really liked the family dynamic, and I really felt for his sister Via. We don't get a lot of her, but we see how the attention Auggie gets affects her, and I really liked seeing that. I'm not sure if I could have handled an entire book from her perspective, but I did like the small bit that we do get in the book. 
 I also liked how real the characters felt. How they acted- what with The Plague thing, and the stares and stuff, I can see that happening in real life. How one of the moms acted was horrible- she photoshopped Auggie out of the class photo, and acted like he didn't belong in school, just because of how he looks. And it was really hard to read, because, theoretically, she should know better. But clearly not, and it makes me wonder if her son acted the way he did because he learned it from her. In the end, the other kids ended up being pretty okay, except for the one. 
 There is something I have mixed feelings about, though, and that's Auggie himself. I liked that he sees himself as a normal kid, and that he's not special or extraordinary, just because of how he looks, even though people around him probably think he's special because of how much he accomplished, and all of the surgeries he's had to endure. On the one hand, I liked that the book mentioned the fact that he was born with a cleft palate, which led to a lot of other health issues for Auggie, but didn't focus too much on it. But at the same time, I wanted a little more about it, because the book hardly goes into it. 
 Another issue I had was the fact that the characters seemed a lot older than 10. The way they talked and acted...it didn't mesh well with the fact that it's middle grade. It was really disorienting, and if 10 year-olds are, in real life, dating the way some of them seem to be dating in this book, I'm a little worried. 
 The book was also super-positive, which I get, considering the target audience, but it made the book feel too perfect, like nothing gets to Auggie (even though it must), and that everything will work out just fine, no matter what. It felt too simple, for something that could have had even a little more complexity to it. It's not for me to say that Auggie is too well-adjusted, because I've never experienced what Auggie has, and I have no idea what it's like to be in his position. But it was also something that was a little off-putting, just because I wanted something that seemed a little more realistic. 
 My Rating: 3 stars. I get why people loved this book so much, and I do like the message of not judging people because of how they look, and that you should be kind to people. But it was too simple, and too perfect, and I wanted something a little more complex and something that was a little less perfect.

I have no idea why I don't read Middle Grade books on a more regular basis. Starting WONDER I expected an emotional story - and emotional it was. It is the story of August Pullman, a boy with an unique facial deformity. 
 So far he's never attended a regular school, but his first day of school in 5th grade is nearing. It was interesting to witness the process of socialisation and integration of Auggie into the class and seeing how other children reacted to him. 
 WONDER is told from Auggie's perspective, an utterly honest and brave little voice. Auggie's sister Via, his best friends and Via's friend share their views and reactions on current events and their relationship to Auggie, too. Overall WONDER is written in a very easy and authentic language. 
 Chapters are rather short and are oriented at Auggie's events, realisations or experiences. Familiar episodes alternate with Auggie's experiences in a new school environment, daily life scenarios and the blooming bonds of true friendship, acceptance and respect. 
 5/5 ***** WONDER - This is a story about many first days of school, moments of bravery and a small boy who shows unbelievable greatness. 
 Auggie is a truly wonderful boy. What he lacks in conventionally good looks he has in integrity and natural sense for other people's feelings and intentions. He is one of the most adorable MG characters, one who earned my trust in his strength after only a few minutes into his story.
Everyone should read this and then read it to their kids, and then, when their kids are old enough to read, they should read it themselves. [?]
This book was adorable but almost a little too cutesy for me. It felt unrealistic but I still enjoyed it.

Fantastic book, a must read for all middle-schoolers (and teens and adults). I read it a few years ago at the recommendation of a friend whose son has facial anomalies, and I couldn't put it down. I'm hopeful the coming movie will have even more people reading the book; it's an amazing tool to teach empathy, something sorely lacking nowadays, it seems. I'm rereading it for book club and look forward to the discussion next month.

I had given up writing book reviews a long time ago simply because I have read some reviews that are far better than I could ever write and I see no point in writing something that is not going to be useful to anyone. But after I read this book I felt that I HAD to write about it. 
 This is the kind of book that makes you laugh and cry. It kind of reaffirms the faith on humanity. This book is about a eleven year old boy, August, who has severe facial deformation and his journey in a new middle school. The author employs a off handed, relay-type, multiple POV style, starting from August himself and it includes 6 different people. Although different fonts and the No-capitalization used in Justins's POV were a bit distracting, it made a great read. Funnliy enough I connected to Via's POV than August's himself. She is August's elder sister who sort of lives in August's shadow and starts repenting it. But at the same time she feels bad for feeling so. Olivia's POV made me connect to the story further. 
 Another character that is worth mentioning is August's English teacher Mr. Browne, who sorts of plays in the back ground. I think the precepts that he gives, shapes and uplifts the overall story. 
 Do I think the book is a bit too sweet, too preach-y at times? Yes. Do I think the villain is portrayed a bit too villain-y and August a bit too sweet, his parents and Mr. Tushman a bit too understanding? Yes. But it is the book which make me happy that everything ended well for Auggie, even though I know it might be a bit too far fetched in real life. This is the book that you go to when you feel a bit down. 
 Also my copy contained an extra segment containing Julian's POV which sort of tied up the story together and gave me a closure! 
 A solid four! 
 My favorite Quotes from the book: 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives" 
 "If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God."

I ... I liked this a great deal, but didn't love it. I wanted to love it. But as great as I think the bulk of the book was, as realistic as it was that August found a couple of good friends and many classmates were still jerks, it took a turn for the twee toward the end. 
 I liked the multiple POV, though I'd have been happier if it had just been August and his sister, but this may be because I'm more interested in the high school experience than middle school/middle grades.
3.5 stars

Buddy read this with my 9 yo son and he loved it, I really enjoyed it and think all children... adults as well should read this. You will be surprised how much an adult could learn from a children's book.

Auggie Pullman is starting school for the first time -- as a fifth grader (which is middle school, in this book). This is a big deal for a kid who's been homeschooled his whole life due to severe facial deformities and many surgeries. The book chronicles his fifth-grade year and how it changes him, his family, his classmates, and his community. 
 More than writing sensitively about a difference or disability (which it does well, a la Out of My Mind), or showing the effects on family members (Rules), this story became magical to me the first time it changed point of view. You hear overlapping versions of events to reveal the reasons that characters act as they do; or, as the school principal says, "there are almost always more than two sides to every story." 
 It was strangely thrilling to read a story with so many modern details (Bone, Star Wars, the Cheese Touch, KidzBop, UglyDolls, iPods, cell phones), but I wonder if these will date the book too quickly. (As an aside, when a character uses her phone to call her mom from the bathroom for a ride home from a bad party, saying 'don't ring the bell, just text and I'll come out,' I spent several minutes thinking about this and how getting out so gracefully would have been impossible pre-cell phones.) I loved Auggie's strong, loving, functional family. So many kids' books are about dealing with one's crappy family that this was refreshing. Also, the depiction of bullying in middle school seemed dead-on. This, plus the short chapters, unique format, unusual protagonist, and (perhaps slightly too) happy ending, make this a "tolerance" book with actual high kid appeal -- a hard balance to strike, for sure. 
 Favorite quotes: 
 "I don't know if the three of us found each other because we were so alike in so many ways, or that because we found each other, we've become so alike in so many ways." 
 "My mother is the kind of person who has a happy face for the rest of the world but not a lot left over for me." 
 "'Shall we make a new rule of life...always try to be a little kinder than is necessary?'" --J.M. Barrie

'Wonder' is a great book and a good story well told, aimed squarely at the 'young adult' market. Like many other great novels - due to its strength however, it transcends and easily surpasses the confines of its genre and limited target market. The characters are well developed and not stereotyped, the plot line well-constructed - nice character illustrations too. 
 The main character Auggie has a condition - a rare medical facial deformity (variously described as a facial anomaly, craniofacial difference, mandibulofacial dysostosis) and whilst this is central to the story, on another level that particular issue is almost incidental. This is a story about growing up; it's about being different, lunchbreak and classroom politics. It's about self-acceptance against all the odds, it's about perceived 'otherness' and the consequential bullying. So when I say that Augusts' facial anomaly is almost incidental, what I am trying to say is that this perceived otherness and the associated challenges as a theme for the novel could have been one of many things chosen from a sadly all too long list encompassing so many other aspects including - race, gender, size, sexual orientation, disability, appearance, religion, culture, nationality... 
 The message from this story - being that growing up is hard and that otherness or being 'different' can make things much harder. An important issue also raised here is concerning 'deformity' being misunderstood and wrongly equated with disability or 'special needs'. Often and as in this instance - Auggie has no disability and no 'special needs'. 
 This is an important and thought provoking story. Palacio tells us that 'Wonder' is a "meditation on kindness - on the impact and transformative power of kindness". 'Wonder' is a moving and uplifting story of kindness and acceptance - sadly though there will be many out there in life that aren't so lucky and so subject to both. For me though, ultimately and overall - 'Wonder' is about hope, faith in humanity and faith in the human spirit - there is good in us. Leaving us with the simple but obvious and important message that - it's not what you're like on the outside, but you're like on the inside and how you behave that counts. 
 When considering the current political climate on the world stage, where those with perceived 'differences' or otherness are all too often, far from being embraced - but on the contrary are being marginalised and demonised - to me this makes this kind of story is all the more important. 
 I will finish with two of Mr Browne's precepts: 
 'When given the choice between being right and being kind - choose kind' 
 'Be kinder than is necessary' 
 A random precept that has always stayed with me: 
 'Never judge a man until you've walked a mile in his moccasins' 
 And one of my own: 
 'Everyone is different, everyone is the same, different but equal'
I cannot say enough good things about this book!!

Well done! A story about kindness...how hard it can be to do the right thing, even if you are uncomfortable, afraid, and don't want to make the effort. What I liked about this story is that it may help young people realize that not everyone will look "normal", but inside we are basically alike. The kids in this story evolve into better people when they get over the superficial aspects of a peer born with a rare condition that seriously affects his face. What I did not like about the story was that it did not seem plausible that all of the characters, except one, reach this revelation.

Auggie (August) really wants to go to school with kids his own age, but that won't happen because he doesn't look like the other kids. Born with facial deformities, Auggie has always dreamed of being normal because normal is average and normal is "nothing special." When Auggie's parents tell him that he has been accepted Beecher Preparatory, Auggie is terrified of the idea that he will go to school with kids he doesn't know; according to Auggie, it was one thing to meet kids when he was much younger since they didn't know any better, but, now, kids will know that he is different, which means he will be open to ridicule. Although Auggie and his father are against it, Auggie's mother believes it will be good for him since she is terrible at fractions and it's time that he gives middle school a chance and make new friends. Reluctantly, Auggie agrees to meet with the principal (Mr. Tushman), but he wasn't counting on a tour and meeting students from his class. Although everyone seemed really nice, Auggie knew they were freaked out about his face except for Jack Will. Charlotte was really helpful, but it was Jack Will who seemed genuine. When the first day of school arrived, Auggie was nervous and he new that people would react to his appearance so he kept to himself until Summer joined him at his empty lunch table. Is it possible that there are kids out there who don't mind his face? Even Jack Will joined them at their table so Auggie, for the first time in his life, had friends. Told from alternating point of views between Auggie, Jack Will, Via, and her friend, Justin, readers will learn how Auggie is not just special because of what he looks like, but how he makes people feel and just how challenging that can be for those who torn between wanting to be his friend, but are worried about what others will think. 
 What makes this story amazing is that it's a story for everyone. All of us, at one time or another, have known, or seen, people like Auggie and Julian. I have an older brother who has a learning disability so when Julian, and company, would say awful things about Auggie I wanted to throw the book across the room because I was soooo mad! I also wanted to cry my eyes out because all Auggie has ever wanted is to be normal, but, what also angers me, is that he IS NORMAL! This story conveys how fear of the unknown can have a very negative effect on people, especially when we don't teach our children to accept people for who they are and not what they look like. Honestly, who cares that Auggie's face is different, but, to a child, this is a life changing experience. If readers have the opportunity to check out, or buy, the special edition of Wonder (that has a chapter from Julian's point of view) it makes sense why he behaves that he does. However, his bullying is not at all acceptable and it's obvious where it comes from when his own mother demands the expulsion of Mr. Tushman for not following "protocol" in regards to Auggie's admission into Beecher Prep. Moreover, when Julian's mother said that Beecher Prep was not an inclusion school, I wanted to ring her neck. Another reason why this book is amazing is that Auggie has the most amazing support system, which, sadly, not all kids (like Auggie) have. Even with Via's outburst, she realizes that Auggie needs his family because everyone is so quick to reject him because of his looks. Lastly, I loved the dynamics of Auggie's friends and how most of the kids had evolved after the "incident" and how they got tired of Julian harrasing Jack and Auggie. This is a great story where adults and children can come together to not only talk about real tough issues like bullying, and tolerance, it is also about teaching, and learning, the power of empathy and kindness. This book is timeless and I can't wait to read it to my own children some day.

I won't lie - I've never had an inclination to read wonder - It was kinda forced on me. But I'm ever so glad it was, because it was such an amazing read. Books like Wonder simply reaffirm what I want to do with my life - be a teacher. sometimes it can be a simple as a kind word which helps a student get though their day, and that's what I want to achieve. I want to help my students through school, because no matter what year, grade or age a child is, school is a trial. "Kind words do not cost much. Yet they accomplish much" - Blaise Pascal precept.
Great book for discussion with a class. Shows many different viewpoints.
I really enjoyed this book.

This was such a feel good, life-affirming story and I loved every second of it. 
 August (Auggie) Pullman is just an ordinary kid (on the inside), who lives with rare facial deformity. All he really wants is to fit in, but when the first thing people do is judge you because of what your face looks like, it makes that wish almost impossible. 
 I was moved by Auggie's story - despite the challenges he'd faced at such a short age, he managed to remain sweet and kind. His perseverance and humor filled me with hope. His family unit, and eventually his friendships were so heartwarming that they made me believe the world is filled with people who care and support one another. 
 I laughed and cried, but most of all I loved.
Loved it!

I'm being completely serious when I say that I think everyone should have to read this, regardless of age. As the story is broken down into sections told by different characters surrounding this little boy with a severe medical condition and an unusual face, I feel certain that EVERYONE can find bits of themselves in these chapters. My own extreme case of ezcema and a host of other medical "abnormalities" and eight moves as a child meant that I could identify with Auggie as he faced a new school and had to answer loads of questions about his condition from friends and strangers alike. But I found myself understanding and even identifying with parts of other characters' stories as we'll, including Via, Jack and Miranda. 
 I will admit that this book took me a good 60 pages or so to really get into. The text is written like a ten-year old boy (or whoever is speaking, all of whom were children) speak and the chapters are only a page or two long. I found it jarring at first and difficult to really get into the story. Once I got over that, I opened up to learn the many lessons this book has to offer about empathy, perspective and kindness. I wish the author had done a chapter from Julian's point of view as Miranda's gave you an inside look at why she had been acting the way she was and helped you see that her meanness really was out of insecurity (a valuable reminder for kids and adults alike!)
Really enjoyed this--it used to be that all kidlit had to have dead or absent parents. Auggie's parents are real and wonderful.

I'm dumb and deleted this from my shelves entirely. So, i'm reposting this review again. 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 I'm just going to start off with I don't ever read middle grade contemporary, let alone middle grade at all. Usually, if i'm reading middle grade, it's a Rick Riordan book. I don't think I would've picked up this book if it weren't for book club. Now, I understand why this book was always around on the internet and on displayed in any possible bookstore I'd go into. This book is talked about online entirely by all ages and I finally understand why. Wonder is a novel hat deserves a standing ovation for it's gift of letting anyone understand a young protagonist with Treacher Collins. It makes me so happy to know that young children can read this and learn so much from it. If you're not familiar with Treacher Collins, it's when the face tissues and bones aren't fully developed and so on. I'm not sure if my definition is entirely right, but you can always look it up. Our main character, Auggie, struggles with TCS and has had over 20 surgeries in his life so far. Due to that, he's been homeschooled all of his life and is finally going to public school in the 5th grade. This novel is told is the point of views of him, his family and his friends. It gives you a chance to experience the things that might go on in the heads of someone with TCS and their family and friends as well. Now, i've seen some pretty poor reviews on this site and I don't quite understand why. This novel is middle grade and is written for a younger audience so of course, the writing isn't going to be top notch and it's not going to read like a YA or adult. But, you still getting something out of it and I find that really important. I'd easily recommend this book to anyone, it had a heart warming message and easily made me cry of happiness near the end. It's one of those books that's going to sit in my heart. 
 "Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed."
Very simple book with short chapters, but with a wonderful story. I wish this were a real story so I could meet him.
Beautiful, poignant but never cloying , this was simply a really wonderful book

I can't get over how strong this story is. I've never cried because of a book before (Not even Neverseen, although my heart hurt. A lot.) but Auggie's story almost made me cry. Almost. There are so many things to love about this book; from the story to the characters to the symbolic cover. It's really well written and is now one of my favorites. 
 Here are a few things that caught my attention throughout the book. 
 The symbolic cover. When I first picked up this book in the library, the cover made had me thinking that the cover artist was aiming for something artsy. But it wasn't until I read the summary (and the rest of the book) that I understood the concept. The boy on the cover is Auggie and he was born with facial deformities. I love it! 
 The characters. The two things I look for in book characters are diversity and flaws. (I'm not a terrible person, I swear!) But Auggie's character is taken to a whole new level. Auggie's never gone to school before (because of all the surgeries he's had to have) and well, he doesn't want to. He knows that people can be cruel and judgmental and he doesn't want to go through that. I liked how the author included character development that really helped us understand Auggie better. The situations and problems that Auggie are put through are heartbreaking, but realistic too, so it makes the story much more powerful. 
 The other characters, his friends, his parents, his sister, they're all supportive of him and go through a lot too, which shows that they really cared about him. 
 There was one character I didn't like though: the bully. Yeah, no one liked him, because well, he was MEAN! You can guess how he reacts when he meets Auggie. *grumbles about bullies* 
 Short chapters! If you're like me and you're busy all the time, books like this are for you! With its short chapters, you can sneak in a page without having to stop in the middle of the chapter and having to re-read it because you forgot about everything. Another pro to this book! 
 In general, this book is a great read, whether you like short chapters or long chapters or different points of view or not. It's a great story with a great lesson. The characters are really diverse and unique and the character development is great!

This was such a heartwarming story that touched my heart in all the right ways. The only thing I found annoying was Justin's Chapter when the author stopped using capital letters for some reason.. But overall, this story made me cry and makes me want to be a better person. Sooooo good.

"Shall we make a new rule of life... always try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" - J. M. Barrie. 
 Wonder is no doubt one of those books that make your heart softer as you go on through its pages. I have went through a bundle of emotions during the short period of time I spent reading this heartwarming story. I cried, I laughed, I wondered, and I got mad. It was not only interesting because you were reading about everyday life and school battles through the perspective of a special kid; but you were also reading the perspectives of the people surrounding the special little dude, August. One of my favorite things about this book is that it gives you hope in people. It is true that this is a fictional story but I am quiet sure that there are people around just like those kind-hearted characters in this book. So reading a good story about those invisible people is like an affirmation that fills you with hope. 
 I loved the meanings that you get from the story either while reading and deciphering as you go or while you sit staring at the ceiling thinking about the last passage you just read. Again, this book fills you with hope and happy feelings, and my happiness increased with how the writer was successfully able to convey her own thoughts of how people change when they know people better or when they give things a second chance. It was clear in the way the writer talked about how the school environment "shifted" as the year progressed and as people got to know more about this weird looking little guy. 
 This book tells you that it is okay to stare because we are only humans and our eyes are only used to average looking scenes, we are not equipped with a set of eyes that easily and instantly adjust to the extraordinary. But, once you notice that peculiar individual be kind and weigh your actions and words. Always get to know the inside once you bypass the outside, don't fixate your mind on what you see without exploring the universe that is inside these extra special people.

WONDER is a warm-hearted fiction story about a boy named Auggie Pullman beginning middle school. Auggie was previously homeschooled due to facial abnormalities requiring many surgeries throughout childhood, so it's a big transition for him. As you can imagine, society very rarely reacts initially with grace. Strangers on the street are routinely terrible, and the kids at school are mostly awful. But Palacio also narrates from the POV of the Pullman family and friends, who share their very honest experiences meeting and befriending Auggie - keeping the reader challenged with their own uncomfortable feelings as well. 
 Fun story: I definitely squeezed this onto my April TBR thinking the movie adaptation was still coming out today - but it seems the date was pushed last month to November. Sooo here's looking at you, future holiday feel-good!

I am so glad that I read Wonder. Do I remember what I was like in 5th grade? Would I have been nice to a boy like Auggie? Oh, I hope so. Mr. Browne, here is my precept, "We are all wonders. Let's celebrate, acknowledge and love who we are. But most importantly, celebrate, acknowledge and love each other!"- Carrie

I read this with my 10 year old son and my 8 year old daughter. We all loved it. This novel was a great platform for us to discuss accepting others and inner beauty. I hope the movie does the book justice!

Finished this,loved it and am recommending others check it out. 
 Very well done. 
 I want allschool kids to read this because itdoes a great job of dealing with bullying and stigmatizing of peoplewholook different,in this case because his face is deformed. 
 Reading this for my school's book discussion group - but i also voted to make this one of our books to read because it seems up my alley as far as helping those with certain special needs.

First of all, this made me cry like a fucking baby. It reaches out to a younger demographic being that the characters were 5th graders and the way it's written was so light that younger kids could appreciate it. But even when that's the case, I think a lot of us adults could learn a thing or two from August's story. 
 A little bit of kindness could go a long way, especially for someone who has not received a lot of it from people. 
 I'm giving this a 4 only because I was yearning for more but as a whole, I think this book is wonderful.

I read this book after an intellectual book podcast I listen to recommended it at the best children's book of 2012. I don't read that many children's books to comment on that, but this book can easily have broad appeal to all age groups, even adults, so that is saying something. 
 I don't write plot summaries in my reviews unless there is a point to make about the plot. This novel is much more character based. The points of view of about 8 different people in the main character August's life are presented and this never gets messy. One character's section is written without any capitals to help distinguish his character as a young man trying to establish his identity. I don't like this kind of style but the section is short. August is a character that you almost wish existed so you could throw your arms around him and hug him. It's so refreshing to see a child who has tons of problems to face but faces them with the tremendous love and respect of his highly functional (!) family. They aren't perfect but this is a together family of the type that I think many people don't believe really exists today. (They do!). I almost hope the author will write a sequel about August dealing with the teenage years. 
 The central message of the book is an important one to bring out in these days: that it is important to be kind to all and that if you are kind, the kindness will eventually pay off even if it exacts a price in the present. IT's a good lesson for kids to learn and for adults to be reminded of. 
 The age recommendation on Amazon is 8-12 and while I don't see any content reasons why it would not be appropriate, the age range seems a little young as I would say the book is a little more sophisticated than that. August is 10 and in fifth grade but comes off as older than that. A mature eight year old with excellent reading skills, maybe but not all. 
 The ending is a little too convenient and that is the reason for the four stars instead of five.
Touching & moving, but not sentimental.

I was disappointed. I thought the concept of he book was very interesting and thought provoking. That being said I didn't like the voice she gave her characters and the story felt very forced especially near the end.

This may actually be a 4 rating, I'm still struggling with differences in YA literature and adult fiction. All in all I found this to be a compelling story. I was especially impressed with the story being told from the viewpoints of six different characters including friends and family. The message was powerful and there were some real tear jerker moments for me. Good read.

What a sweet book and I'm glad that I ended up liking it as much as everyone was saying in their reviews. 
 August is one of those characters that I will probably never forget. I loved how he was kind of a Star Wars geek and when he was talking about certain characters or situations, I totally knew what he was talking about. 
 I was surprised that the book had different POVs because you usually don't see that in books that are geared for the younger crowd. I really enjoyed it because I loved hearing the same story that August was telling but from the other points of view like his friend Jack and his sister Olivia. The only part that was kind of weird and I tried looking online about it was the section from Justin's POV. It was the only part that had no quotes when someone was talking and it was written in all lower case. I loved all of the educators in this book, great role models. 
 Even though I work in a high school, I still bought this for my library. Yes, August is in 5th grade but I think this is a story that all grade levels need to be exposed too especially because of the whole concept of bullying. 
 The only part that I was emotional during was when August's dog Daisy died . 
 Overall such a great story and message too. I was rooting for August throughout the whole book.

I had high expectations for this book after having heard nothing but praise, but I was disappointed. 
 I got about 25 pages in and couldn't stand it at all so I abandoned all hope of ever finishing it.

I think this book is slower than the first and it do to be more difficult to read. The story is great and interestin but in mu opinion, I take 6 months rading it because I didn't achieve to engage the book.

This book is a wave of feels. Not just a wave, actually, it's a whole feel-tsunami. (a feelnami? nahhh) 
 It is both sad and happy and comforting - it both gives hope for humanity and destroys it. Kids can be as mean as they can be sweet when they are confronted with something they don't know, like August. 
 August is an extraordinary character, all while being ordinary. I'm not saying that because he has a mutation that made his face mal-develop. He is genuinely a sweet and fun kid! He has a Star Wars addiction, a few good friends, a loving family, and a good sense of humor. But people judge the kid by his cover and treat him differently because of it. Some people bully him mercilessly, while others befriend him like a normal person. 
 The book was written very simply, in a 'he-said she-said' way that made it a quick an easy read. It can really be read by anyone 10 and up, but with different understanding of the book, I think. 
 One thing I loved was the fact that there were 8 parts, most of which were told by a different point of view. His friends, family, and acquaintances tell their story about how their lives entertwined with August's, and how it changed them. (there was one part I didn't like much, which was Justin's, just because there were no capital letters or quotation marks... ;-; ) But they really each brought a new perspective to the story in a perfect way. 
 All of the characters were so unique and well thought-out. However, their backstories weren't what was important for any of them, it was really who they were as a person that was brought to attention the most. The little things they did for August, the way they acted with others, who they were as individuals... and I think that that's the main message form this book - people may have different looks, stories, and experiences, but it's who they are on the inside that matters most. 
 I'm so giving this a 5/5 feathers!

I can't say enough about how sweet this book is! I thoroughly enjoyed it. Destined to become a classroom classic. I think everyone from 4th grade on should read this book. It brought both sad tears and happy tears to my eyes. I love that the Pullmans are such good people and that Auggie's condition has really developed in-depth kindness, patience, and love in each member of that family. Everyone around them notices it. I also love that the author captured well that struggle kids face in their older childhood years and early teen years to understand what it means to be a good person. A must read.

I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse. 
 August (Auggie) Pullman was born with a facial deformity that prevented him from going to a mainstream school--until now. He's about to start 5th grade at Beecher Prep, and if you've ever been the new kid then you know how hard that can be. The thing is Auggie's just an ordinary kid, with an extraordinary face. But can he convince his new classmates that he's just like them, despite appearances? 
 August Pullman is a typical ten-year-old boy. He likes sports, video games, and Star Wars. He is an intelligent kid. Like some kids these days, Auggie has been home-schooled by his mother, but his school year, Mom thinks it is time for Auggie to go to a real school. Dad does not agree saying sending Auggie to school would be like (sending) a lamb to the slaughter. 
 Mom and Auggie go to Beecher Prep to meet the principal, Mr. Tushman. Auggie ends up on a school tour with three kids that would be in his fifth grade class, should he attend. Julian, Jack Will, and Charlotte are nice and show Auggie most everything including the science lab, gymnasium, and cafeteria. Beecher Prep is an exclusive and demanding school. Kids take entrance exams just to be a student there. Unknown to Aggie, he has already passed the tests. 
 Fast forward a few months, Auggie is attending Beecher Prep and in Ms. Petosa's homeroom. Lucky for him, Auggie sits next to Jack Will in nearly every class. They get along great . . . until Halloween. However, Auggie did make a true friend in Summer, his lunch table mate. Fifth grade has its ups and downs. Most kids will not touch him, acting as if he has the plague or some other awful contagion. Aggie makes it through fifth grade and returns for sixth grade. This year will be the most trying year of his young life. 
 I really, absolutely, loved this story. Wonder is the debut novel from R.J. Palacio and she entered the children's lit world with guns a blazing. The characters are well developed and have distinctive voices. Nearly everyone has changed in some way by the end of the book, including the reader. She must have spent her days and nights around ten-year-old kids because the dialogue is spot-on. Good kid, bad kid, parent, teacher, or "extras," Ms. Palacio has the correct, believable voice. 
 When I first saw the cover, I wanted to read this book. The pale blue background of a young kid with one eye had a way of drawing me to it. After reading the book, I think the cover is wrong for the book. Auggie has severe facial abnormalities including a cleft palate, eyes much to low on his head, and ears that are nearly non-existent. If the cover is suppose to be of Auggie, the designer missed it, big time. 
 Auggie is 10 when the book opens, having survived more surgeries, treatments, and therapies than most of us will ever experience, and is about to go to school for the first time. I remember middle school to be a game of who's popular and who isn't, only notched down a degree from high school. Add parents that are often as bad as, if not worse than, the kids and middle school becomes a place not for the timid . . . or the new, and definitely not for the noticeably different and possibly scary. 
 I think Auggie represents anyone who is different. He is the child fighting cancer that lost his hair, the kid in a wheelchair, or the one attending special ed. He is the fat kid, the nerd, the shy kid, and the kid without friends. Auggie represents all of us at some time or another. We all have or had a blemish or two, felt excluded, talked about, maybe even feared. August Pullman endures all of those, at the same time, from kids at a cruel stage in life, when being accepted and part of the group is extremely important. I think Ms. Palacio captured this realistically without being maudlin 
 At 320 pages, Wonder is still within the reach of middle grade capabilities. The chapters are short, easy to read, and the words simply flow making the turning of pages a pleasure, not a chore. The point of view does change every now and then. We get to read about Via, Auggie's sister. She tells us what it's like having a brother who rightly demands all of mom and dad's attention. Jack Will, who unknowing crushes Auggie with his sharply barbed words, tells us the friend side. Mostly though, it is Auggie we hear from and his trials being "that kid." 
 Wonder is easy to read, difficult to put down, funny, and sad. If you can read this story without shedding at least one tear, you did not pay attention to what you were reading. Do not let that scare you away. This is not a tearjerker; it is a thought-jerker. I think Wonder should be required reading for every middle grader and teen. Awards will accumulate and by the end of 2012, Wonder will be be one of the top ten middle grade books of this year. 
 Note: I received the digital version of this book from net galley, courtesy of the publisher, Alfred A. Knopf Books for Young Readers. 
 Orinally reviwed at Kid it Reviews http://kid-lit-reviews.com/2012/03/03...

This book was so beautiful and heartbreaking and thought provoking. I can't wait until I can sit down and read it with my children. I think my oldest is just about ready to hear this one. He's 8-years old and I think he's just about the right age to sit down and read this with and talk to about what goes on in this book. I really loved this book. It is a book young and old should read. We all need to be a little more compassionate and considerate and caring. In the words on Auggie's teacher, (who quoted the words from a much more famous man) we should all be kinder than necessary.

Realistic, well-written, not for the faint of heart. Why? Because there's no "fixing" August's problem, at least not the physical one, no matter how much he and his loving family try. But the author does a fine job of showing him bravely dealing with a situation that most readers will barely be able to imagine, perhaps rendering their own difficulties with fitting in socially at least a little less daunting in comparison. The characters are well-rounded and memorable. They're not perfectly good or perfectly bad, they're just kids (and adults). If it were possible to do so, I'd give the story a four-plus in the stars department--not quite a five, but close.

Review published on http://ringothecat.wordpress.com/ 
 Hailed as the next The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time, Wonder is NYC-based author R.J. Palacio's debut novel about a 10-year-old kid, Auggie Pullman, born with facial deformities caused by a genetic disorder, and his everyday attempts to defy the odds. You'd have to be a brute not to sympathize or at the very least root for Auggie. Of course, this assures that this book will be (and is) a real crowd pleaser, and reaches an audience that is broader than at first intended (Middle Graders), which in turn is very much like what Haddon achieved with his Curious Incident ... Very clever marketing indeed! 
 Both books of course, are sort of like the definite safe Oscar winners playing on everyman's sentiment and heart. That is not to say, however, that Wonder is a bad book. Not.At.All! But an honest reviewer looks past the sentiment and the cat, for one, thinks that Wonder is actually a good book but with definite shortcomings as well. 
 Up till now - the beginning of 5th grade - Auggie has been homeschooled by his mom. Now, though, his mom thinks it is time for Auggie to go to a real school (like "a lamb to the slaughter" his dad claims). At school Auggie is confronted with the myriad of ways in which the kids and the grown-ups look at him... the story of his life, unfortunately. As if starting (Middle) school for the first time ever wouldn't be bad enough in itself, Auggie has to deal with people having all sort of emotions when they see how different he is: from sympathy to pity to hatred even. Only a minority doesn't care what Auggie looks like and is friends with him regardless. Wonder is told from the perspective of 6 kids and Auggie's voice - clearly the focal point - is only one of them. The other 5 voices are often interchangeable, though, which is the cat's biggest reservation when it comes down to narration with multiple points of view. 
 R.J. Palacio - who in a former life was the designer of Paul Auster's book covers - hasn't written an earth-shattering novel with Wonder, but she deftly plays upon a human's capacity to care and to be outraged at the same time. As is demonstrated in the book, often it's not really the kids who judge a person's looks, but rather, the kids just have questions, and it's the adults in their lives who label and judge. Favoring kindness as the ultimate human value, "when given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind," is actually the most important precept of this book - a precept the cat does not agree with, btw. If your book is written from that perspective, obviously criticizing it from a non-kind perspective, will make you seem...well, like a brute. 
 But favoring truthfulness over kindness, for the cat Wonder was a book about an incredibly important topic but the way this is dealt with is a bit too sugary and Disney for my liking. Everything wraps up too neatly. Characters also fall into the good-bad categories a bit too conveniently. And this is not cynicism and not about believing in the fact that literally everyone gets a happy ending.

My book club chose Wonder by R.J. Palacio and invited our elementary aged kids to join us in a family discussion. Turns out it was one of the best book clubs we've ever had! The kids (ranging in age from 6 - 10yo) couldn't raise their hands fast enough to talk about the main character, August (or Auggie), his loyal family and his adventure in his first year (5th grade) in public school. 
 Told in first person from varying points of view, Palacio deftly brings us into the fold and sets us on a roller coaster of emotions as we feel Auggie's brave struggle to belong in a world that desperately wants to look away. The reader knows he's deformed from a birth defect with an unpronounceable name, but the author never truly describes what he looks like. This book is about being brave and taking chances, embracing differences and seeing beyond the surface of things. 
 I can still tear up when I think of some of the scenes. This is one of those important books that all children - and adults, for that matter - should read.

Since the movie was coming out, Wonder moved up to slot #1 on my TBR pile. It was cute and sad. Happy at the end of course. I liked how, when the perspective changed, the style of writing changed. Some authors can't successfully pull that off. 
 Only section I didn't think fit was Via's boyfriend. He was a yawn.

This book was a wonder. 
 I was swept away by the characters and plot. 
 I was impressed with the utter rawness of this novel. 
 Honestly, I don't know where to go from there. I suppose that I could line it point form, in my classic way. 
 Pro: 
 1. The theme. It was amazingly well executed. In many more serious novels, the theme gets in the way of the story. In this case, the story is solid, and the theme builds it up. I loved that. 
 2.The characters. Auggie was darling. His humour, the lightness with which he took himself, and his general personality and cleverness was refreshing and charming. 
 Summer, as well, was a good character. 
 Jack. 
 Via. I loved her, actually. She seemed very real to me. It can't be hard having a younger brother with a craniofacial abnormality. 
 Those two things really sum up this novel. The only negative thing about it was the style in which it was written... at first. I didn't enjoy the seemingly sloppy formatting, but as the book continued, I gained an appreciation for the style. I wouldn't say it was my favorite, but it didn't ruin the book either. 
 I will admit that this book reads bit younger, but it's still a good read for youngsters, teens, and adults. Recommend it? Yes, I would. Highly.

What I actually liked more than Auggie's unique situation was that the writing was so readable and true. I liked the characters and their various perspectives (it could almost be shelved in the teen section). This isn't exactly a spoiler, but could change someone's expectation...Based on the hype, I sort of expected there to be an event that was more shocking or with a deeper meaning, but the book is perfectly great without it. I was just nervous until the end. 
 This would be great for kids who liked "Out of my mind" and would be a good bookgroup/school read.

R. J. Palacio did an admirable job fictionalizing the life of a fifth grader whose lottery in looks make experiences outside of his tight family unit gut wrenching. Some of the hardest chapters for me to read were the ones not from Auggie's perspective. Wonder is a good title because curiosity about others is supposed to be a good thing.
This is a wonderful story of a young boy born with a face disfigurement. It tells the story of how he feels through his words as well as his family an friends. Well worth the read!
Simply wonderful. Everyone needs to read this book.

Students have been lugging this book around for two years now. It's never on the library shelves... until last week when I was able to catch it before the students did. Lucky me! 
 I loved this book. I can see so many possibilities for teaching it. I'd never heard of precepts before (I think they call them truisms in 8th grade); they'd make a fine teachable moment. The ever-changing points of view are great to teach POV. Friendship, family, identity, etc. could all be taught from this book. 
 I have to admit that I cried at one point. I also have to admit to being angry at other points. This book touched me and I know it touches my students, too.

I'll resist the urge to recap. 
 Here's the thing: my sister is a 5th grade teacher. She is always resistant to my recommendations, either for her, or for her students. (I know, I have impeccable taste, I don't get that either.) 
 She has not read this. 
 I will be completely obnoxious and consider myself a failure if I'm not able to influence a classroom full of 5th graders this year by forcing my sister (by sitting on her, if necessary - I've done that before) to read this. It should be required reading for kids that age... that age when they're still forming into perfect humans and you have a chance to grab them and teach them a beautiful lesson that will hit home. 
 I appreciate the beautiful lesson this book offers, and I'm already a fully formed human.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I'm not sure exactly how to rate this book. I bought it for my ten year old to read and when he couldn't get into it, I picked it up. Obviously it's a young reader novel and has good moral messages in it-which as a parent, I'm a big supporter of. I agree with several people's reviews-that the characters all sound alike-but isn't that true to life? Kids in the same school/social circle/families will pick up the same slang. I do have to say my favorite part of the book was Julian's added chapters. The stories from his grandmere and when Julian finally understood remorse. His "oh I get it revelation. I was wondering how the writer was going to turn Julian around and make me dislike him a little less. And she succeeded-I don't dislike him as emphatically anymore...but can't forgive him quite yet either. 
 So to sum up my four star rating...I would absolutely recommend this book to young readers...with the hope that they may take something away from it. Nothing is ever lost bye reading a book!! ;)
This book was delightful!
Definitely think this should be a Beehive next year!

Do you remember your first days at middle school or junior high? It's a pretty intimidating experience for all, but image Auggie's plight of trying to fit in, facial deformity and all. This excellent book explores what makes us alike, and different, how we make friends and how we cope with adversity. A great read for children, teens and adults! 
 -- Louisa A. --

My ten year old son insisted more than a few times I read the book Wonder. Honestly, I "wondered" what all the fuss was about. 
 When I read the first few chapters, I could understand his attraction. In fact, my ten minutes of reading time turned into 50 pages, then a hundred. I became a Wonder addict! 
 R.J. Palacio includes popular culture such as Star Wars, X box, and Diary of a Wimpy Kid. In other words, the author "keeps it real." 
 Wonder is not a book written for adults packaged as YA. Wonder is a book written for today's kids, without alcohol, drugs, sexual references, or serious authority issues. 
 Kindness is one of Wonder's most endearing messages. In today's media kindness is not always relevant. Kids and teens grow up seeing the angriest voices, the richest voices, or the voices with the most Twitter followers get the spotlight. 
 Wonder will leave the reader feeling better about themselves and wanting to make a difference in other's lives.
This is truly a wonderful book! One of the best I've read this year; possibly one of the best I've ever read.

Me siento muy feliz de haber leido este libro, no se que me esperaba, pero definitivamente, esto no. Es de esos libros que te dejan un buen sabor de boca al terminarlo y con un buen sentimiento en el alma. Ademas, el hecho de que sean capitulos cortos y una lectura rapida y dinamica hace la lectura mucho mas entretenida y amena.

You could not pay me enough to ever relive middle school, and luckily that is not an option. Middle school is bad enough. Wonder explores middle school through the life of August (Auggie) Pullman, a boy with an extreme facial deformity attending school for the first time. 
 Unsurprisingly, days after I finished this novel (which has been getting some fabulous press for a while now) a screenwriter was announced for a movie adaption. I think this is a very strong and important story to reach a potentially larger audience. I also think the source material provides some inherent challenges for that adaption. For one, Palacio is purposefully vague about the exact nature of Auggie's deformity. This is a powerful tool. The descriptions are specific enough at times that it becomes clear the author has a vision. It's not a matter of half-formed ideas. Rather, our own imagination conjures up what is worst for us. 
 Wonder doesn't sugar coat things. There are always going to be Julian's (a particularly nasty bully) in life. I give Palacio extreme credit as well for exploring the idea that the parents of the Julian's of the world are the ones that help foster these ideas. Kids can be cruel. This is evidenced by Auggie's initial reception at Beecher Prep, including the idea that any student that comes into physical contact with Auggie has to wash their hands within a certain amount of time. This detail pulled at my heart and sickened me. It also forced me to attempt to recollect if anything similar went on in my time in middle school, because it didn't sound all that foreign. Did I miss the opportunity to stand up for someone, lost in my own loneliness and angst? And I think that's exactly what this book is supposed to get us to think about. 
 I did have a couple nitpicks with the book. I understand why Palacio used multiple POVs to tell the story, although I may have left some out, including the narrative's of Auggie's sister's boyfriend and best friend. Overall though, this seems like chump change to what I took way from Auggie's story. 
 Does Wonder pander to our sentimentality at times? Yes. But even Auggie recognizes that. More importantly, I would challenge almost any middle schooler to get through their 3-4 years with the strength and courage that Auggie demonstrates. He is an example, to those of all ages. What a beautiful reminder of what strength, character, and kindness really are, as well as the fact that we all can get through middle school. I can't think of a better time than middle school to attempt to put a little more empathy into the world. I would not be surprised to see this become an English class staple over the years. 
 And never forget, everyone deserves a standing ovation in their life at least once. 
 http://teaandtomes.wordpress.com/2013...

When I discovered that August loves Star Wars, that he has a tiny padawan braid in his hair, and that he's going into fifth grade, I fell in love. I told my boys about it at dinner, and they couldn't wait to read about August, too. 
 And yes, I hated Julian Albans with the fire of a thousand suns at first, but I found his postcard to Mr. Browne a revelation and a benediction that only a book this beautiful and redemptive could ever have managed without a deus ex machina. 
 Hats off to R.J. Palacio! The story is honest without being ugly, and I can't recommend it enough.
I loved this story. The emotions of the family were so well presented, and I'll always remember August's brave and humorous point of view. I for one would love to see a sequel!
This is a really easy read but one I think every person should read! Great story of friendship, kindness, and triumph. Should be a required read for all 5th graders!!!

"Kinder than is necessary." 
 This quote in Wonder made me think of the book, Team Of Rivals. I know... your going...huh? Kindness and politics? Civil War? Slavery? Huh? Not really an era one would mark with kindness. Strife, yes, but kindness? No way. It's not the plot that reminds me of the book, but the character, Abraham Lincoln. Lincoln said that he valued kindness as a virtue in a person above all else. And he showed kindness to others. Sure he had other qualities. He was courageous. He knew that signing the Emancipation Proclamation was signing a death warrant. He was a storyteller. He had empathy. His kindness extended not only to friends, but to his enemies as well. He brought out the best in people. He chose kindness, when he could have chosen hate and power. He risked everything to do the right thing. 
 Meet Auggie Pullman. He too, is kinder than necessary. He too, chooses kindness over meanness, kindness over revenge, kindness over anger. And he's courageous. He stands up for what is right. He forgives his friends when they wrong him. He's a hero. But not your typical one. 
 Auggie was born with a birth defect that is so horrible he won't describe what it looks like because "whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." He is going to go to middle school for the first time. He knows it won't be easy. He knows he has to be brave. He knows the kids will be afraid of him. But as his mom says, "I really believe... there are more good people on this earth than bad people, and the good people watch out for each other and take care of each other. 
 Auggie doesn't meet very many good people at first. He meets a bunch of scared middle schoolers. In fact, they are so scared of him they have a game called, The Plague, where if they touch him they have 30 seconds to wash their hands. Auggie ignores most of it because he does have the two friends Jack and Summer. When Auggie overhears Jack say something mean he has to decide if he still wants him as a friend. As the students get to know him, he tries to ease their fears by joking about his looks. They find out he's a normal kid like them. 
 The story is told from several different viewpoints: Auggie, Via, Jack, Summer, Justin, and Miranda. For the most part this worked for me but I got pulled out of the story when Justin was speaking. The author uses him to make a minor point about Jack. This is the only time I set the book down and was able to walk away from it. When I started to read about Miranda, I thought, oh no... another Jack. But there is an interesting twist with her. I would have preferred Amos viewpoint over Justin's. Or Julian's viewpoint. Julian fizzles from the story at the end. I thought he should have gone to camp and something should have happened to give more insight into his character. He's pretty much the one-dimensional villain. If he had gone to camp the tension would have gone up a few notches. 
 Auggie has an amazing support system. When I first started this book I wondered if it would follow the story of John Merrick known as The Elephant Man. I remember watching this as a movie and Merrick suffered unloving parents and abuse. This story doesn't follow that path. This family is loving and struggles with Auggie's special needs. The mom and dad force Auggie to go to school and support him. Auggie's dad is funny. I love the humor he brings to the story. Via doesn't get the attention Auggie gets from her parents, but she's pretty accepting and understanding about it. It isn't until Via starts a new school that she has a problem with Auggie's face. She doesn't want to be known as the sister with the deformed brother. She just wants to be "normal." When she asks that Auggie not go to school for a play, Auggie blows up at the dinner table. 
 Some of the plot is predictable such as the camp and award ceremony. What isn't predictable is what happens during these parts. The ending has a great message about kindness and courage. We work to build kindness in ourselves, our students, our children. But it isn't always easy. Sometimes our paths will cross with jerks. Sometimes our choices can lean toward selfishness, power, or meanness. This story is about growing to be a better person. To be a kinder person. To be a braver person. To stand up for what is right.
A little too old for my 3rd graders, but this book is wonderful. Teaching kindness.

Wow. This book is really amazing, and life changing. The way Auggie looks at the world is in such a cruel and sad way, but there is still a hope in the darkness. The theme and lessons in this story are very impressive. One of the best reads of the year!
Aww this book was so good! I will definitely be using it for a read aloud with my fourth graders this year!

Grades 5 and up 
 A great story of a boy, Auggie,whose health due to facial deformities at birth has prevented him from going to school. Now entering the fifth grade, Auggie's parents have made the decision that it is time for him to go to school. The story follows Auggie, his sister, his friends, and several other characters as Auggie faces the ups and downs of going to school for the first time.
Wonder was one of many poignant stories I've ever read. It's so hard not to cry, tbh.

Although it was a good book, and I enjoyed the stories of Auggie, Summer, and their family and friends, I am torn about the way the material was "written" overall. Although Palacio seems to have first hand knowledge of the response of individuals to people with deformities, it doesn't seem to play well in the book. Auggie comes off as a bit narcissistic and whiny, while his parents are the most overbearing individuals EVER. 
 Unsure about this one.

I'm wavering between giving this 3.5 or 4 stars. But either way, it's a good book that I wouldn't hesitate to recommend to any adult, high schooler, or student in 7th or 8th grade. Honestly if I was still a 6th grade English teacher, I would highly recommend this to my students. 
 However, I've read posts in which readers are highly recommending this for upper elementary grades, as young as 8-year-olds. Let me address that first. The book starts with a 10-year-old Auggie, preparing to enter 5th grade, the same as my oldest son. The book starts off with potty humor and Star Wars references, so I thought, "Yes! This is spot-on. My son will love this!" And just as I was about to hand over the audio book to him and encourage him to read it, the tone of 5th grade dramatically changed. Star Wars was out. Hot girls were in. Dating, being popular, and an unsupervised party were the hip things. Whoa, I'm not denying that these things happen, but firstly I'd like to believe that they happen less than this book proports. Secondly, whether they happen this frequently or not, I'm going to choose to let my son live on in his sheltered perspective that 5th grade is for learning, having friends, and being a kid. 
 The only other "problem" I have with this book is slightly a spoiler. So I'll just say, it was more hopeful than a realistic story would play out. 
 One thing I quite liked was the book's references to other literature. 
 Oh and there's another thing that bothered me about the book. When Auggie is born--so deformed and fragile that the doctor faints-- the nurse proclaims to his mom, "Every child born of God overcomes the world." The quote is a Bible verse, I John 5:4 and the "every child born of God" refers to every person who "believes that Jesus is the Son of God." (I John 5:5) And in context of Scripture, it appears "overcomes the world" refers to obeying God's commands. (I John 5:3-4) In other words, this Scripture has nothing to do with Auggie's chance of survival. When Auggie reuses this quote at the end of the book, it is even more taken out of context.
Most amazing book. Loved every second of reading it.

This book was real good - I loved how this book had a unique topic, and I loved how it had a happy ending. I also really liked how there were always conflicts, to make it more interesting, and I loved the power shifts. Ahhhhh sooooo good!
Perfect Read!!!!
Actual rating 4.5 stars.
