I recommend Wonder. 
 ***** 
 For parents who are expecting a child (whether their first or not), normally what would they fear at that stage? 
 Me? When I was pregnant, my big worry is that my baby will be abnormal. deformed. I did not wish for a beautiful child, I only wish that he will be healthy when he's born. When I saw my son, not only is he perfectly healthy, but he is beautiful. whole. normal. so much more than the things i prayed for. 
 Auggie's parents were not so lucky. But despite his facial deformity, Auggie is as normal as it gets. he's smart, witty, and hilarious. I love Auggie! His personality just leapt from the pages and tickled my fancy. I thought this is a depressing story. It's not. Just a lot of reflections from a boy who just want to be remembered (and loved) but not because of his horrible-looking face. 
 I want to embrace his Dad! The most striking scene he has with Auggie is this. In two years, Auggie wore a helmet and never took it off. one day, the helmet has gone missing. 
 Oh, Auggie, don't be mad. I'm sorry. I just couldn't stand see you wear that thing on your head anymore, you know? i didn't think it was good for you. 
 Come on, Auggie, please try to understand, you were wearing that helmet all the time. and the real, real, real truth is: I missed seeing your face, Auggie. I know you don't always love it, but you have to understand... I love it. I love this face of yours, Auggie, completely and passionately. And it broke my heart that you were always covering it up. 
 What a WONDERful father. :) 
 You're gonna love all the characters here (well, except Julian, maybe). Wonder is heartwarming, heart-wrenching, heart-everything! 
 People can be cruel to Auggie almost every time. But he found comfort, love and triumph in his family, and his new friends. He never expected the universe will be kind to him. but it did.
"Shall we make a new rule of life... always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?"
best book i read in a while. it is cool how it is written and I like the ending
This book is precious. Such a wonderful read to help build compassion & empathy. Can't wait to read it with my kids some day.
No need to wonder if you should read Wonder. You definitely should!
Wow! Great book!
A really good read - although marketed as YA, I think it's suitable for much younger readers too.
Stunning. Absolutely wonderful. I adored it and it made me laugh and cry so much
Nothing but love for this book at any age! Don't just be kind but be kinder than necessary. It's one of the easiest things to do and yet so many have the hardest time doing it.

R.J. Palacio's beautifully written novel, WONDER, will entertain as well as inspire you. The story is compelling; the characters are believable in their capacity to do harm as well as good. A spectacular read aloud between parent and child or as a whole class read aloud (3rd/4th grade and up). As one parent shared with me " Wonder is one of those books that invites you to walk in the shoes of others and understand different perspectives of the same events. It shows us how kindness, courage, and understanding can go a long way towards making the world a better place for all. Growing up is not about fitting in, but about doing the right thing. An important lesson at any age."

Really heavy-handed, especially the whole 'he doesn't have special needs/this isn't an inclusion school' thing. So what if he did? Why wasn't it? 
 Forth star given for personal perspectives that I brought to the book, which had little to do with the book.

This is an amazing book for all ages. It truly teaches an important lesson that everyone needs to know no matter how old you are. This is a touching story of tolerance and inclusion. I flew through this heartwarming book and would definitely recommend. It really made me think and I know it will change how I view other people moving forward.
Every reader, no matter the age, will learn something from this book. It is filled with great kindness.

If you haven't read a children's book in a long time, choose this one. If you read children's books for a living as I do, read this one for the sheer joy of discovering a new author with great talent and potential. Auggie is a memorable character with an indomitible spirit. It isn't often that an educator is portrayed as noble and heroic in modern fiction. Children are often charictures and so much of children's literature is contrived. Palacio bucks the trend of endowing children with the wisdom of adults and retains both the charming innocence and unthinking selfishness of her young characters. Treat yourself and your children (ages 10-15) to a well written, engaging, and memorable read.
one of the best books I've read. It will open your eyes to many things, especially how you treat others.
I don't think this book is just for children, at any age you can read this book and see the world in another way.

A great read for all ages. I did feel it was a bit slow in the beginning but was very quickly drawn into Auggie's world. I laughed, I cried and I felt anger at the cruelty children can inflict on someone who is 'different'. A very fast, emotional read.

Review also posted at Ja citam, a ti? 
 Few days ago I put the quotes from this book as my Quote of the Week and a lot of my friends here told me how they wanted to read the book. I was like...wait a minute I haven't even told you how lovely and heart-breaking this book is. So be ready to hear all about the greatness called - Wonder! 
 From the blurb you can see the story. We here have a story about August who well has a facial deformity and for that he has been noticed and looked at wherever he goes. Of course he knows that people are scared of him so he tries to spend a lot of time alone with his family. The things change when he starts going to the school. You can imagine how it is for a kid like him to enter the class full of "normal" kids for the first time in his life. Of course he is noticed not just by the kids but also by the teachers. He tries to cope with all that but at the end of the day he is just little scared kid who is too young to goes through all this. 
 I should point out few things about this book. Firstly there are multiple POVs in this book. But don't give up on this book in case you don't like them, cause here it's done perfectly. You see the world through August's eyes and also you see how the world sees him through other characters. Another thing is prepare your heart cause some of the thing here will break it. Even thinking about this book makes me wanna cry. Don't run away if you don't want to experience that, cause everyone should read this book. A lot of people tend to judge others by their look, appearance or what not. But have you ever though how much that hurts. Cause you can't be strong enough to survive that without a scratch especially if you're just a kid. 
 But you wanna know what's the most interesting thing about this book - while reading it and after that I still imagine August as a little lovely kid. With beautiful eyes and adorable smile. Even though the books starts with I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse. I have met the August's personality and what a brave, shiny and beautiful character is he. You have no idea. 
 Of course there is the five stars for this book but quite honestly my views of the world and my thoughts have changed and there is not enough stars to give for that. So thank you (Wendy especially to you and your review)!
WOW. I had so many mixed emotions reading this (all great!). I LOVED IT. Everyone should read this. This book definitely gets a standing ovation! hehehe
Every single human being who interacts with other human beings needs to read this book. Love. This. Book.

Such a long time ago that i've read a 5 star book. 
 It's so wonderfull. Review to come!

This book was amazing! Just when I was starting to think where this book was going it switched perspective and I loved it even more. Even though this book is geared more for 3-5th graders there is a lot that teens going into high school would like from this book! A wonderful read! Highly recommend!
A very sweet And heartwarming story on what it's like to be different.
Loved it. Cried buckets. But they were happy buckets.

I cried and cried. Many have used Wonder in discussions about bullying, but its a wonderful (no pun intended) story in its own right. I particularly enjoyed the multiple points of view and how it's used to give a more complete picture of Auggie. Some argue the other characters are not fully developed, but I see this as Auggie's story.

I think this is one of the more "perfect" books I've read. 
 The main character is wonderful. I love how he's just like everybody else. And what makes this read more interesting is how the author skilfully evolves us in the ten-year-old world and makes us feel like we belong. I remember what I was like when I was August's age. And many writers get it wrong by making the ten-year-olds be immature, whiny and stupid. 
 But not this book. I love how this book displays the accurate description of how fifth grade is where everybody starts maturing, having crushes but also care about popularity. I remember what it was like in fifth grade, and also how August makes it so simply written. 
 My complaint is mainly Justin's point of view, which was painful to read. No speech marks in dialogue, no capital letters. Why, oh why did the author think it'd be a good idea? It almost made me put the book down! 
 Overall, I still loved this book. And Via is down as one of the greatest female characters (in my head). 
 Long live August Pullman! And this is a book everybody will enjoy -the young and the old- so pick it up today!

I really loved this book. It brought on so many emotions and I wished so many times I was there and could help August. He's an amazing boy (and his whole family is incredible too), I can't wait for the movie to come out this year.
A fantastic book and an incredibly moving story. Great for readers of all ages but I definitely think this should be required reading in middle school.
A great read and a must read for all middle graders.
Seriously moving. I cried so many times. Both happy and sad tears. MUST READ!

"There should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives," thinks August, a fifth grader from Beecher Prep, outstanding student, a sworn fan of Star Wars and adores his dog, Daisy. August is an ordinary kid in almost every aspect, besides the fact that he was born with a facial deformity - which obviously makes him anything but "ordinary". He knows he doesn't have the same chance to be standing on a stage, with thousands of people in the crowd, and receive those desired applause - because when people look at him they flinch, avoid him, and even hurl cruel insults at him. Unlike the other kids, who could grow up to be presidents or movie stars, or simply become the valedictorians at their graduation, August must limit his dreams and expectations of life. 
 August wishes for the day he could walk down the street and assimilate among everyone, to have an entirely ordinary face, one that people won't even remember - which puts our whims to become more beautiful and desirable into perspective. After all, when have any of us wished for a face that no one would notice? 
 The story is very well written, filled with humor and wit, which only enhance its original plot. It is so easy to be swept away with the pages and so it happened that from the moment I have started reading this book I just couldn't stop and finished it within a day. Not once have I wiped a tear, at times of sadness and at times of joy, over those small and simple moments of happiness in life - the happiness of a ten-year-old, no matter how they look like. 
 This book has an important message to deliver, and it does it in a fantastic way. I can guarantee that once you start reading, you won't be able to stop, nor want to.
little too sweet for my taste

It's 5AM, but I couldn't sleep without finishing this book (and shedding a tear or two). Wonder is one of the most beautiful things I've ever read. Quite simply, read it! 
 Read as part of my reading challenge.

I read this because it's my students' summer reading book, and I absolutely loved it. The story brings you back to middle school, when things are so unknown and scary, but also when you can figure out who you are or the type of person you want to be. I laughed and cried, and I am so glad I read it!
So perfect it was funny and sad and happy and it just makes you feel so many different things would definitely recommend it to anyone who likes funny great stories
Not exactly unpredictable but a great story.

What a sweet story. I am not a huge reader of young adult lit, but this is the Vermont Reads book this year, so I picked it up and got through it in a day. Unless you've been living under a rock, you know that this is the story of a 5h grader with severe facial abnormalities, who goes to school for the first time, having been homeschooled previously. 
 It's also the story of his sister, Via, and a few of their friends and classmates. Each of them changes, and each of them realizes the wonder of normal everyday living, as they wend their way through the school year. Throughout the book, characters misread each others' intentions and reactions. They think, as kids and many adults do, that the world revolves around them, only to find that each person is fighting their own battles, and may have motivations that are completely other than what they appear to be. One of the central actions in the book revolves around a performance of Thornton Wilder's masterpiece, "Our Town," in which the characters reflect on how easy it is to miss the wonder of everyday life. It is really the point of this whole book. Not just about some kid with a messed-up face and being kind to people who are different from you. It's about seeing beneath the surface. The quotes from The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe about "the magic beneath the magic" are also there to reinforce this concept. If you miss this theme, you don't understand the book. 
 It is also somewhat ironic, that the only happy, "normal" family in the book is the family with the kid with the messed-up face. This is a children's book, basically. But it is pretty damned wise for the rest of us. 
 Few books make me cry, but this one did.

"It's not enough to be friendly. You have to be a friend." 
 I am so glad I read this book. It is a terrific story of a wonderful kid - August Pullman - who is born with multiple defects on his face due to a rare genetic mutation. It is equally the story of his family, his friends, his school, his teachers and his pets. But more than everything else, it is the story of growing up and all that comes attached with it. 
 This book also establishes the fact that you don't have to have a sad end to a story to make your readers choke. Even a heart-warming, happy and bright ending can do wonders. Because it made me choke and because it has the power make your eyes wet too. 
 Strongly recommended for everyone of all ages who can read English.
Heart-warming but somehow predictable and naive. (still one of my favourite books I've read this year by the way)
A book that an adult can appreciate, and is a must read for youth. The core theme in the book is kindness. Just finished reading this book in a hammock at the cabin. The end brought tears to my eyes.

"I'm beautiful in my way, 
 'Cause God makes no mistakes 
 I'm on the right track, baby 
 I was born this way..." 
 In Wonder, 11-year old August is your average kid. He has a Star Wars obsession, wants to be a scientist when he grows up, and loves playing with his dog, Daisy. He has eyes, ears, and a nose- just not in any of the right places. 
 August was born with a rare birth defect that resulted in a face deformation, a hip bone replacing the jaw he never had and his ears squished to the sides of his head. His eyes are lower than they are supposed to be and the shape of his mouth makes it hard for him to eat. Other than that, he's a totally normal kid- he just wishes everyone else would see him that way. 
 He's learned to deal with the stares and the whispers, but when his parents decide to enroll him in real school for the first time, he faces a new challenge. Seeing the school, he's excited to go, but immediately encounters but a smaller model of the world he already knows exist- those who have trouble accepting him, those that refuse to accept him, and those who wholeheartedly welcome him with empathy and make his life worth living. 
 "Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." 
 At first, this book seems like the kind of tearjerker meant to make the reader feel emotion through guilt- "Why did I used to bully that kid in eighth grade...?. A kinder way to say this is that it's meant to show us the world from the eyes a kid shunned by society and the political correctness that has those unaccepting skirt around it in cruel ways. Basically, it shows us another perspective. 
 But the book isn't just about August's story- the story is shared by multiple characters, his sister, her boyfriend, and August's friends. That's when it hits you- this isn't just a story about an unexplored perspective- it's a book that explores the pure nature of perspective. We see how dfferent types of people learn to look past what's on the outside and how they do it. Wherein they learn that sometimes what seems otherworldly is really just normal- and that's what's spectacular. 
 The book is well written although occasionally it seems like the author tries too hard to make August seem like a "normal" kid and so his use of slang seems forced. But the book's sense of realism is more pronounced in Palacio's unabashed allegorical use of pop-culture references. 
 The beginning is more promising than the latter half and the ending feels a tad maudlin, but the novel more than makes up for it in is vibrant humanism and assured characterizations- and what more can you ask for from a surefire Newberry book?

I felt the voice was inauthentic, although most of the reviews on here disagree.
This book was so heartwarming I just couldn't put it down I'm so glad that I got to read it

[(Likes)]

But it's not like every pitiful person deserves to be praised for nothing other than being pitiful! I think it would be cool if Augie actually did something nice to everyone no matter how much they hated him, and eventually everyone started to love him. That would be a better story.) 
 Some short stories (which were totally unrelated and boring)

This book. Geez. 
 The story is not extra ordinaire. It won't make you jump out of your bed, or will keep you up at night but will surely bring you wonder. :) A lot of joy and happiness. In the book it says, universe has a way of making things balanced for us in everyway.. this book was so balanced, so intriguing and gripping. I love the fact that it was written from different POVs of the characters in the book, also applauding for that because the writing style changed for each of them and it actually felt I am in their head experiencing and feeling what they are feeling which is remarkable. Different views gave me a greater perspective of the story and not just made me empathize majorly with one character but all of them, I understood, I felt them and the whole experience was just fantastic. 
 The characters are just lovely and dealt in depth, I was able to actually relate myself to a lot of situations and feel all the feels, I could actually put myself in there and see myself making those decisions. A must must must read for everyone, it's important for people to understand the power of kindness, the act of kindness.
The book wonder shows us that we shouldn't judge people by the way they look.

Loved this! August and his family are a wonder! Song references were great, characters felt real, highly recommend. Although a common device, it was really effective to switch narrators throughout the book. Perspective was really useful in describing social and medical challenges.

The ending was happy, and I think appropriate if your audience is 5-6 graders or lower. However, I personally think Julian's precept at the end was too unrealistic. People don't always change, and I think that's also a good lesson to learn.

3.8 stars

This review was written for The Review Diaries: http://reviewdiaries.blogspot.co.uk/ 
 I had heard amazing things about 'Wonder' before I started reading it, and they truly didn't exaggerate. 
 I was very wary going into the book, after all, you never know with a subject that sometimes requires delicate handling whether the author will handle it or drop it on the floor... hard... 
 Fortunately R J Palacio tackles it beautifully. The book offers several different viewpoints so that we get to see not only Auggie's view of himself and the world, but how other people view him to. It also offers us an insight so we see situations from various different angles so what from one person seemed a terribly mean thing to do, would suddenly be seen from a whole new angle. 
 The different view varied from seeing how Auggie's sister copes with constantly being pushed to the side in favour of her brother, to how his new friends at school felt about him, to his sister's boyfriend. It was fascinating and offered a whole new perspective which kept the novel fresh throughout. 
 Of course the largest sections were from Auggie's point of view and he was a fascinating narrator. He truly was extraordinary, with his view of the world, of himself, his strength, his kindness and his determination, particularly in the face of some truly horrible taunts, fights and unkindness from those around him. 
 It was a thought provoking story handled very delicately and I found myself totally enthralled with Auggie's story. How it feels to be on the inside of a perfectly normal boy who just drew the short straw of the gene pool. He's not pampered or spoilt, nor is he frustrating, he is an incredibly fresh narrator and I loved sharing his story with him. 
 It was heart breaking at points to see the cruelty of those around him - not just kids, but adults. There are a series of emails part way through the book that quite literally made my blood boil, and some of the awful things the kids said made me want to reach in and wrap Auggie up in a hug. 
 My only complaints were that there wasn't a vast amount of difference between the voices. They all read very much the same, and if I hadn't been told at the start of each section who was speaking it wouldn't have been particularly obvious. 
 It was also, I have to admit a decidedly cheesy ending, but actually, I like happy endings to it didn't really both me - I know that some people might find it a little too sweet after the trials of the book though. 
 It does come across as one very decided, white middles class view point of the world, which may be frustrating to some, but because that is the only view point Auggie really has, I didn't find it too grating. 
 This truly is a wonderful book - thought provoking, funny, incredibly hard to read at some points, and joyful at others. I would recommend reading it with a box of tissues though...

Recensione sul blog: http://thereadingpal.blogspot.it/2017... 
 When given the choice between being right or being kind, 
 choose kind. 
 August Pullman e un ragazzo come tutti gli altri: e ossessionato da Star Wars, gioca ai videogiochi, legge, ha una famiglia che lo ama e un migliore amico con cui passa gran parte del suo tempo. Se non fosse che August e nato con una deformazione facciale che anche dopo parecchi interventi e migliorata di poco, che all'inizio non gli permetteva di mangiare o parlare e che pian piano gli sta portando via l'udito. E se non fosse che August, proprio per questo motivo, non e mai andato a scuola. Ora i suoi genitori hanno deciso di iscriverlo alla scuola media, dove ci saranno un sacco di altri ragazzi, e dove, August ne e sicuro, gli altri studenti gli renderanno la vita un inferno. 
 Sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone 
 to hurt someone. 
 All'inizio devo dire che il libro non mi aveva presa molto, forse anche a causa del blocco del lettore. Comunque, sono stata felice di averlo letto. 
 August e un ragazzino intelligente e sveglio, che non si prende molto sul serio e sa come divertirsi. Certo, ha un problema non di poco conto, visto che senza gli interventi non avrebbe neanche potuto mangiare, ma alla fin fine ha tutti gli interessi di un ragazzino della sua eta. La sua crescita nel corso del libro e immensa, mentalmente ed emotivamente. La famiglia, soprattutto la madre, e molto protettiva nei suoi confronti, anche troppo, tanto che August a volte sembra un bambino piu piccolo. Attraverso le nuove esperienze e i nuovi ambienti riesce a "staccarsi" da questo nido un po' soffocante e comincia a vivere una vita "normale": ha delle disavventure, ma trova anche degli amici. 
 Summer, Charlotte, e Jack (sopratutto quest'ultimo) crescono con August, cambiano il loro modo di atteggiarsi e scoprono cos'e davvero importante. Summer mi e piaciuta fin da subito. E lei che davvero e diventata fin quasi immediatamente amica di August e che ha capito che non e affatto diverso dagli altri ragazzini. Jack ci ha messo un po' di piu, forse, ma alla fine ha preso la strada giusta! 
 Quello che davvero non ho sopportato e stato l'atteggiamento dei ragazzi in generale, che evitavano August come se avesse la Peste e gli sparlavano dietro. Due sberloni per uno glieli avrei dati, se fossi stata uno dei genitori. E mi sarei chiesta dove ho fallito, per insegnare ai miei figli ad essere cosi cretini (per non dire altro). 
 Julian in particolare ha portato il bullismo ad un livello piu alto, rendendomelo antipatico e facendomi sperare per tutto il corso della storia che si beccasse una bella lezione. Anche i suoi genitori non sono meglio, quindi non c'e dubbio da chi abbia preso. 
 Comunque, in Wonder non seguiamo solo August mentre ha delle nuove esperienze. Ed oltre a Jack, vediamo una bella crescita anche in Via, la sorella maggiore di August. Non vuole ammetterlo, ma le da fastidio che tutto giri intorno ad August, che lui venga prima di tutto. Lo capisce. Lui e quello tra loro due che ha piu bisogno... Ma non significa che debba piacerle. Da una parte la comprendo, ma penso che debba anche capire le priorita di un genitore che vede un figlio che ha molto piu bisogno dell'altro, pur non essendo totalmente d'accordo con la condotta della madre. 
 Quindi, in generale, il libro mi e piaciuto molto e spero che possa piacere anche a voi!

I LOVE this book and just want every middle schooler to read it. I could not put it down and read until 5 a.m. Like Diary of a Wimpy Kid, I felt as if I were a sixth-grader again, with all the woes and awkwardness of that age. At first I didn't want to have the multiple POVs, but Palacio does an amazing job (similar to Game of Thrones, actually) of making you empathize with characters you thought couldn't stand. Most of the characters are wonderfully fleshed out, except for Summer (who seems like a manic pixie flower child akin to Stargirl). I cried and laughed equally. This novel is grounded in that important message of kindness that I've heard a million times, yet the fact that it's not delivered in a conventional style makes it incredibly powerful. Truly a delight to read.

One of my best friends Rieko recommended this book last year! It's been on my wish list and I have finally read it! It was AMAZING!!!! The characterization of August, his sister, his best friend, and others told through 1st person POV's made this story so powerful. We must learn to tolerate and stand for those who are different than we are. We have so much to learn. I will not forget this tale anytime soon!

I don't always take the time to write a review for the books I read. "Wonder" was a beautiful book about courage, love, and kindness. Auggie's story is one that will stick with me for quite some time. I loved getting to read about kids learning what it means to be kinder than necessary. We all need a reminder in that lesson from time to time. 
 I would recommend this book to any kids third or fourth grade and up. And for the parents of those kids. We need to do whatever we can to show our kids what true love looks like.

This book is just as the title suggests - Wonderful. It will leave you looking inwards and asking yourself important questions. I will be passing this book on to my little boy to read. I'd recommend it to everyone of any age.

A friend recommended this book to me and it did not disappoint. This story is another prime example of good writing crossing age groups. I find a lot of my favorites as of late fall into the "young adult" genre. In fact, this book in particular is categorized as children's on Goodreads. But that just goes to show you that good writing, and a good lesson, is important to remember at any age. 
 Part Mask, part Lucas- Wonder is the story of isolated teen, August Pullman. Up til now, Auggie has been home-schooled by his mom due to a birth defect he was born with limiting his involvement with the outside world. But all of that is about to change as the Pullman family broaches of the subject of enrolling Auggie into school with other kids his own age. In many ways, the cons outweighs the pros, but everyone agrees Auggie should try it before giving up anyway. 
 As to be expected, Auggie is the subject of ridicule, bullying and fear- all born out of the ignorance of the outside world. But as many of us can attest too, kids can be cruel- ESPECIALLY middle school kids. Wonder manages to paint Auggie's real world experiences as authentically as possible without making us feel too sorry for Auggie. Walking this balance is important, I believe. 
 In an interesting turn of events, many of the chapters of Wonder are told from varying points of view. I'm still on the fence about how I feel about how this played out in the context of the story itself, but I did appreciate the concept of seeing the same situation from varying voices. And in a way, that's really what the story of Wonder is all about- putting yourself in someone else's shoes, if only for a moment or two.
Fantastic!!
Amazing! I loved the story. I loved the way it was written. I can't wait to discuss the book with a class of 5th graders who have been waiting for me to finish the book.

This is a middle grade book about a 9-year-old boy who has major facial deformities. The story follows him through his first year of public schooling and the challenges that come with entering a school full of children who respond in different ways to the arrival of a new student with a malformed face. It gives great food for thought about how we treat others and is an especially wonderful read for children (I think) because it provides a wonderful opportunity to contemplate what life would be like for anyone who suffers any kind of physical limitation. This is one I will definitely insist upon my children reading and will look forward to the discussions it will initiate about how we look at and treat those who are different than us.

"This really is a remarkable book" -- one of the reviews on the back of Wonder that perfectly describes how I felt about this book. It made me laugh and it made me cry. It was truly a delight to read and had so many important life lessons embedded in the story and was just such a sweet story told mostly from the perspective of a 10 year old boy. I highly recommend reading this book.
Great book. Well written and engaging. It's hard not to fall in love with the characters. Great message about choosing kindness. Very relevant with bully issues with today's children and teens.

Wonderful book. I read it in two sittings, really glad I finally picked this one up.

Oh my gosh, what an amazing book. This poor boy over came so much and I am glad it ended happily. Makes you realize how we treat people different from ourselves. 
 Reading challenge- book that made me cry- (more than once!!) ;)

** spoiler alert ** 
 You'll love cheering for Augie in this story of an underdog. Ten-year-old Augie is attending a traditional school for the first time in his life. How he becomes accepted as an equal by his peers instead of being that odd kid with the extreme facial deformity makes for a fast-moving read.

I went into reading Wonder expecting to fall in love with it. The subject of a young boy with facial deformities entering middle school for the first time was intriguing and I felt sure that this would be one of those reads that tugs on your heartstrings and makes you think about life in a slightly different way. Unfortunately, I found this book to be overly sweet and unrealistically happy. I get the feeling that people are blinded to the issues this book has by the pity they feel for the main character. I know this will sound cold and snobbish, but I truly feel that this book is completely overrated. 
 As others have mentioned in their reviews, Wonder is told from multiple points of view. We hear from Auggie, the main character, and we also hear from his sister Via, her boyfriend, one of her friends and some of Auggie's friends. For me, the vast majority of these viewpoints are unnecessary, sound the same, and add nothing to the story. I would have preferred the narration to be split between Auggie and his sister: Auggie, because it's kind of necessary to see his perspective and Via because she is the only interesting character. 
 Indeed, Via was the high point of the story for me. She speaks of having live constantly in Auggie's shadow and struggles with feelings of guilt for feeling that way. I could completely see her viewpoint and I felt for her. 
 I did not relate to Auggie at all. I actually found him to be quite annoying, a total brat, and not realistic in his thoughts or actions. I am a teacher. I teach kids the same age as Auggie. I thought he was portrayed as too simple-minded. He read more like a 3rd or 4th grader to me. Also, kids do not say "dude" to each other like the kids in this book do. I promise. I just couldn't bring myself to care for him. 
 My biggest issue with the novel was the ending. As I said before, I found it to be unrealistically happy, but it was more than that. At the end of the book, Auggie gets an award at his middle school graduation ceremony for basically doing nothing except "being strong." In the real world, people don't get awards for being born with birth defects. I found this to be just ridiculous. If anyone deserved an award, it was Auggie's friend at school who sacrificed his own popularity to do the right thing and he kind to someone in need. I just hated this ending. Seriously. An award. 
 The message of this book is undoubtedly important and in spite of my issues with it, I would still recommend it to my students. I, however, just didn't find it to be as great as all the hype. Maybe it's my blackened heart, but I thought this saccharine mess of a story was badly in need of a reality check.

I like the idea of this book more than the execution. The parts of the novel that focused on Auggie and his struggle for acceptance and inclusion were well done, and I'm hugely in favor of the way that Auggie was shown to be an ordinary ten-year-old despite his face. 
 But the novel suffered from Palacio's need to give everyone a voice. I have a love/hate relationship with multiple perspective voices in a novel; it has to be done really well to get me on board, and here it just wasn't. There were too many, and they didn't evenly share the weight of the narrative. Also, the voices weren't distinct enough to be easily differentiated. 
 I also found the sister's subplot to be unnecessary, overly dramatic, and inaccurate (high school theatre programs don't work as presented here, and the minute Via was cast as the Understudy, I knew she would be performing the role in the end. That's a massively overused cliche and it always bothers me. I know that most of my irritation of this point comes from being in the business of high school theatre, so it's a minor point, but it's a huge pet peeve of mine.) 
 I wish this novel had stuck to Auggie's story, and kept the perspectives down to Auggie's and maybe his sister. The concept and message are solid. The execution needed work.
Such a good book and has such a great lesson behind it!

Wow, this book is a game changer. I know that if I were an educator of middle school aged children, I would without a doubt make it a mandatory part of the reading curriculum. That being said, any aged person would benefit from reading this book. With "choose kindness" at the core of it's message and our world in desperate need of more kindness, I will make the bold statement, that I doubt anyone can read this book without being changed by the wonderful character of August Pullman. August is a 5th grade boy going to school for the first time after being home schooled for his education due to the fact that has a severe craniofacial abnormality. He would now face the often unkind world of middle school and the students that he was now about to join were completely unprepared for his presence in their lives. We see their growth and "Augie's" great courage as he wins them over with his "normal kid" ways. I don't think that you can finish this book without a tear or two streaming down your face. I absolutely loved this book; its the type of book that you save one for your own shelf and then go out and buy a copy to always have on hand to give to someone else. SO GOOD!! 
 5 STARS

The best book I have read in a long time. The problems and dilemmas are real. This book deals with a very disfigured boy and how he copes and sometimes doesn't cope with his challenges never ending challenges. Interesting are the chapters in the first person by others in his life. Even though the issues are real and each character has their own problem dealing with them, it turns out well; as well as one would hope but without being cheesy. I like happy ending and they don't have to be cheesy and they can really happen in real life when there is enough goodness to overwhelm the bad in some people.
My fifth grade daughter brought this book home from school. I started reading it one night while she was at a sleepover and finished it the next day. An excellent book for kids or adults.

This book was written for the age group 8-12 years, so my rating is from the perspective of a child of that age group:

You get to see the POV's of 6 different characters which I thought was very cool. The way August goes through his first year in school was well described. Friendships, misunderstandings, bullying, he goes through it all just like any other 10 year old kid, except maybe he goes through worse because of the condition he was born with - mandibulofacial dysostosis. A touching story that will make you laugh and cry, if you are a 8-12 year old and haven't read it yet, it's time you do.

This was one of the most amazing books I've ever read. It is about a boy named auggie who has a facial deformity and how he tries to settle in school and make friends. It's basically about his life, where children constantly bully him but he tries to ignore them and spend time with those who really love him. This book is so wonderful, it actually changes the way you think about different people in your daily life. This is one book that I know I'll never forget and I really want to recommend it to every person that they should read this at least once in their life.
This is the kind of book that makes me want to teach! I do believe I have found my first middle school book club read. Definitely should be required reading for middle school students.

** spoiler alert ** 
 This book is excellent and should be read by everyone, young and old. The story grips you from the beginning and the ending is uplifting. I think a lot of people just don't know how to behave when confronted with someone who is different. This book realistically portrays multiple perspectives and provides an opportunity for people to reflect on their actions and an opening to discussing how we treat people who are different.

Aw, this was a sweet one. The kind that makes you feel all mushy inside. But, it also makes you think about how you react to people with deformities. Yes, none of us think we are being obvious in our quick "look away and then I won't be staring" avoidance. But we are obvious, we know we are obvious. Kindness, people, lets work on finding some.....

Auggie Pullman has been homeschooled his entire life, but he is now going to be going to fifth grade at Beecher Prep. Auggie is not like the other new kids at school; sure he is smart, he wears the same kinds of clothes, and he likes the same kinds of things as the other kids, but Auggie looks different. Auggie has had over 20 operations on his face to make it more "normal" but it is never going to look like the other kids. He has been called freak, freddy kruger, told his face has melted and lots of other mean things. Will he ever make friends at school? will he ever have a normal life? 
 Auggie pulls at your heartstrings. His story is touching, heart-warming, sad, joyful, makes you want to cry; I could go on and on. He is such a little trooper through everything he goes through in this book. You can imagine the horror he has to face every day just trying to fit into a world that doesn't accept him. I think this is a good story about bullying and seeing the good in others and accepting people for who they are not what they look like. The book has a great message. 
 The book is told not just through Auggie's voice but through the voices of those around him. We hear from his sister, his friends, her friends, etc. Some of these work better than others and some seem pointless, but they all show what life is like around Auggie. It is not easy for anyone. 
 I guess my one nitpick of this story is that it is almost to simplified. This is almost a fairytale version of what someone in Auggie's situation would go through. We do see the hardship and the bullying, but then things turn around and he has his happily ever after kind of moment. Doesn't make it a bad book (because it isn't); I just think it simplified things way down. Still the book is a delight to read and I would definitely recommend it. 
 I received an ARC of this book from the publisher at PLA 2012. Thank you!
Just lovely.

** spoiler alert ** 
 3.5/5 
 I really want to give this a perfect 5 stars, really. Most of August's stories and adventures were really touching and brilliant, especially when those stories were told from different points of view. 
 I guess I'd start by saying that I enjoyed August's transformation, his thoughts, and his obstacles--it was as if I experienced it myself. The fact that the writing is simple, like fifth-grader simple, makes the book beautifully written. Also, the nostalgia! 
 I really loved August. Let's just start from the fact that he's a really tough kid despite he's really sentimental and he cried a lot of times (I think this is really accurate for a fifth grade). I liked how he narrates his own story from the first person POV. 
 I was mad when I found out that that little bastard Jack Will betrayed him. Seriously. And I hated Julian and his shitty attitude. That's how much I loved him for being an ass. I also expected more of Julian's side of the story, but what the heck, he's an asshole. Perhaps he'll change someday. 
 It's a book about family and society, too. The way August's family treats and raises their two children, particularly August? I think it's splendid. They're like actual real parents. I'm going, to be honest here: August's family is the most loving and caring family of all the family history I've ever encountered, especially his mother. 
 I just didn't quite enjoyed the other chapters as much as I enjoyed August's. Perhaps the story just went on a different way (but they connect anyway). I was so focused on expecting more of August's story, but I think it wouldn't be great if the chapters weren't split into different POVs, though. 
 I am absolutely looking forward to reading the next book. I hope the next book will be set in the future, especially when he's a teenager or even an adult

oh wow. this book has stolen my heart; it will make you laugh, cry, sweat, cringe in anger, and then laugh and cry again. it is a must-read for all ages. I cannot wait to read it with my 5th grade students next year.

4 Stars 
 Overview: 
 "When given the choice between being right and being kind, choose kind." 
 I don't read a lot of middle-grade, but this broached an assortment of complicated topics with more sensitivity than most 'adult' books and really surprised me. 
 The main character, August was born with a facial abnormality that not only resulted in dozens of surgeries, but prevented him from attending school until 5th grade. This story revolves around his first year at his new school. 
 Pros: 
 The narrators range in from 10 year-olds to highschool-students and the voices reflect this. The kids sounded like kids. The teenagers sounded like teenagers. Everyone had a distinct voice that wasn't limited by age. 
 The message here is important. I strongly believe this book would be a great gift for a child around August's age, because it opens all sorts of conversations about empathy. It encourages them to think about the ramifications of their actions and the way they view each other, without being overwhelming or needlessly dark. 
 Via's story was my favorite and I wasn't expecting the switch to her POV, but I'm so glad it was there. It's easy to get wrapped up in August's story and how it affects him daily--but R. J. Palacio doesn't let you forget it's the same for his family. This was a more complicated approach than I expected from this book, and I think it was handled with care. 
 I appreciated that August's classmates were of all different races, socioeconomic backgrounds and religions. 
 August was a very precious and loving kid, and it was incredibly easy to root for him. 
 Cons: 
 Probably because I don't read a lot of middle-grade, I didn't fully connect with this the way someone younger (or more willing to enter that mind-set) might have. This story is very wholesome and upbeat, and looking through cynical-adult glasses, I couldn't help but feel it lost realism because of it. 
 Via's boyfriend has his own POV... told without punctuation or capitalization? It was incredibly frustrating to read and actually made his chapters harder to understand. I couldn't understand why Palacio decided to do this, until I found this quote from her website: 
 "I remember thinking back then, especially when I would get into the really low notes, that notes on a musical staff looked a little like lowercase letters of the alphabet...Maybe it's because I've been a graphic designer for so many years, but I'm trained to see typefaces and fonts not just as communication devices, but as visual cues for other things. So when it came to writing from Justin's point of view, because he's a musician, someone who thinks in musical terms, it just seemed natural for me to use lowercase letters to represent his thoughts in a very visual way. He's the kind of person who doesn't talk a lot, because he's naturally shy, but has a lot going on inside. The running monologue inside his head has no time for capital letters or punctuation: it's like his thoughts are streaming inside his mind. 
 ...so I understand. But personally, I still didn't like it. I think there were better ways of communicating Justin's character without font-tricks. 
 I'm totally nit-picking here, but why did everyone talk about 5th grade being the first year of middle school? Because where I'm from, middle school is grades six through eight and 5th is still elementary. 
 In Conclusion: 
 A sweet Middle-Grade story that showcases the importance of empathy through a diverse cast of characters and one adorable little boy.

August Pullman is a tween with a severely disfigured face. He was home-schooled and sheltered up until his early adolescence, when his parents persuade him to begin attending school. August is, rightfully, terrified: what will the kids say? Think? Do? How will he be treated? Despite his fears, he takes the leap and starts school. Angsty, terrifying, adolescence. August is the protagonist, and often the narrator, but there are several other characters who take the storytelling helm. 
 August has an older sister, Via, who is protective of her little brother, but also worried that his deformity will affect her reputation. She struggles with the unconditional love she feels for her brother and her own difficult transition into teenage-hood and a new school. 
 Miranda was Via's best friend. That is, until they hit puberty. While Via and Miranda struggle, Miranda continues to love and support August. Miranda uses August's story in a way entirely contrary to Via's, but you should read it for yourself. 
 And then, there are August's new friends. The ones he makes in school: Summer, Jack Will, and others. Each shares what it's like to be the friend of a boy with a face like August's. And the ensuing social fallout so closely linked with friendship to a pariah. 
 My favorite piece of the book: Mr. Brown's precepts. Mr. Brown is August's English teacher and he insists that the students record his monthly precepts and then develop their owns. The chapter Choose Kind explains the process, and I feel I should adopt it for my own. Check out the appendix for a list of the year's precepts and those mailed in by students in August's class. 
 I read this book at the recommendation of my mother, who raved endlessly about it. She works in an elementary school and many of the teachers were being encouraged to read Wonder. I must admit, I'm less enthusiastic about this YA novel than she is. It was good, but I don't think it was great. I believe it is always valuable to explore differences, disabilities, and how we treat one another; Palacio does a fine job, just not an exceptional one. 
 Favorite quotes: 
 "Shall we make a new rule of life... always try to be a little kinder than is necessary" (299). 
 "Everyone is the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world" (313).

Reading about bullying is always hard, but in Auggie's case, the fact that he has a deformation that he cant "fix" made it a little sadder. WONDER, by R. J. Palacio is an important book. It addresses the inside life of Augustus, a severely disfigured young boy. Specifically, it follows him through the fifth grade, his first year in a public school. It deeply explores his emotions, as well as those people close to him. 
 WONDER is well-written and extremely touching. I challenge anyone not to get choked up at the end of this story (and possibly several places throughout). Palacio chose to give Augustus and several other key characters their own (First Person) chapter, thus getting inside each person's head one by one. This was probably the right decision, as it would have been tough to pull off an Omniscient point of view for all characters at the same time. My problem with this choice, however, was that it slowed down the narrative and made the story a bit tedious. So that Palacio could illustrate specific events through multiple characters' eyes, she had to repeat these key scenes multiple times. I also felt the narrative was a bit preachy at times; a little more subtlety might have made it a stronger book. 
 Everybody has at one time or another encountered people with visible disabilities--whether it be a bald head due to chemotherapy, someone in a wheelchair, or someone, such as Augustus with a birth defect--and this book truly, deeply addresses that awkward moment. Because of this book, I will be better able to see these people as PEOPLE, not as their disability. 
 I am very happy to have read WONDER. I recommend it. 
 Four Stars

This book moved me. As a person, mother and teacher of small children. This book teaches us how to really judge a person. It teaches all of us what it means to be a good person, to be a good friend. I loved this quote: "I think there should be a rule everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives". This is only one of the many great quotes in this outstanding book about so many things...bravery, family, love, friendship, self confidence and strength under pressure (just to name of few). All kids need to read this book with their parents and then they need to sit down and discuss it together....you and your children will be better for it!!! 5 stars!

Although this book is most definitely for middle schoolers there isn't a doubt in my mind that anyone who reads it will take something from it. Wonder starts with Auggie. Auggie was born with a severe facial deformity and has spent his life hiding out and being homeschooled. This year however, Auggie is starting the 5th grade. Middle school can be brutal for anyone but for Auggie it could be terrifying. The story is told from different perspectives as you ride on the adventure of his fifth grade year. 
 I rotated between wanted to smack some of the kids and wanting to hug others. Children can be brutal. Their parents can be brutal. In the end though, this book is positive, life-affirming and full of love.

This book brought me to tears, but it opened my eyes. There are so many things in life that we take for granted.  The other day I went to a library (only to see what's new) I didn't consider to buy a book but especially one got my attention so I decided to buy it "Wonder " by R.J Palacio was the one , I didn't expect I will loved this book so much! :D "Wonder" is one of those books that everyone should read, it's absolutely AMAZING!; Palacio wrote an incredible story, in every page she show us how important kindness is, no matter your age. Wow! I've added this book to my Favorites--a dozen books that I loved and that have had a huge impact on me. 
 Wonder broke my heart then repaired it and gave me hope then broke it again and repaired again. I cried for Augie, I cried for his sister Via and his friends. They were tears of hurt and tears of despair and tears of happiness. 
 This book is special and so are all of its characters. And you see the events from not only Augie's point of view, but also from his friends' and sister's. Real life is not black and white. There aren't purely good and purely bad people. Seeing the events in all of their colors and how they affect the main characters was fantastic. 
 I've been lucky lately to read great books that I want to recommend to all of my Good Reads friends, but Wonder stands even taller and more beautiful than the rest. 
 5+ stars for Wonder. Enjoy!
What a lovely story. I won't try to write much of a review since many people before me have reviewed this and probably done a better job than I could. I'll just say this book was indeed wonder-full

What a wonderful book. This book actually gave me a little faith in humanity. I realize that the characters in the book are fictional, but it still made me remember that people can rise above their prejudices. I think one of the things this book spotlights is that assumptions about people can be just as hurtful as words or actions. This book was extremely heart wrenching at times. The book is broken into different characters view of different parts of the story. I was worried at first it would feel redundant, but it actually was done very well and moved the story along in an artful manner. It actually felt a bit like a Canadian show that we like to watch.

 Oh Wonder. I was sure I wouldn't like you, was sure your narration was going to rile against me rather than go along side by side, and I thought "oh dear, this is not for me" as I read the first few pages, possibly even a little glad because my pile of books to read was so huge already. But then I looked up and I was 20 pages through, and I hadn't realised. I had got so caught up in Auggie's voice and story, and even if it sometimes felt a teensy bit juvenile for me it didn't matter because it was him. And then I was seventy pages. Then 120. And I kept reading in massive increments, finishing the book in a single day, I loved it so much, got so caught in it. And it was one of the most wonderful experiences a book has given me in quite some time.
