The Boo's review (10 years old)...the whole book is really good but I especially like that it's told from different views. I liked how he didn't start off going to school but then he did...he was brave to do that. I liked that they showed how his face was the cause of a lot of the events but in the end, it didn't matter. My favorite part was the camping...one because I like the Sound of Music and two..because life is kinda like that...things are going along just fine and boom....trouble! My favorite character was Auggie....mostly because he was different...I think it's kind of cool that he is one in a billion and no one could be just like him. He's the kind of kid I think I would want to be friends with. I think it's a good book that everyone should read...and I think you should read the other wonder books. I really liked the graduation part, because even though there were parts that were predictable there were also parts that were a surprise. Reading the book makes you feel a lot of different feelings because it bounces from good things to bad things, but in the end you see that it's good...life is good.

Pretty much everyone in the world except for me has already read this book. But for those of you who haven't... You're probably like, ew, a middle-grade novel about a boy with severe facial deformities who has to deal with bullying? I can feel the sap oozing from between the pages. No thx. I would like to let all of you know that it is not at all sappy. The characters (Auggie, Jack, Summer, Via, Amanda, Justin) all have very realistic tween and teen voices, Auggie especially reads with a very dry humor. I enjoyed the dynamics between the characters in the central family unit. Great book, loved it.
Great coming of age tale of a kid overcoming his fears and birth defect by entering public school for the first time in the 5th grade. Loved the writing style and point of view changes RJ employed.
What an amazing story! This book should be required reading for all middle school aged students, but the lessons on kindness and humanity span all ages.
I can see why my 5th grade son loved this book. Sweet and funny characters combined with great storytelling. If you like YA that skews on the "Y" side, this is a must read.

Just amazing! If you do know me personally, you would know that this story of August Pullman is very close to my heart. Reading this felt like having a conversation with someone like myself although by no means I would say that our case is similar. August Pullman is much stronger and optimistic than myself, he easily puts me to shame although he is just a fictional character. 
 Saying that, I consider he is real which is somewhat true because I am aware of just how many Augusts in this world, battling society's cruel treatment and perception everyday and I would like to borrow that strength. 
 It's interesting how I started reading with a mindset that this book will be a heart-breaking, depressive tear-jerker. Instead, I smiled, I laughed, I shed happy tears, I shed sad tears (unexpectedly because the dog dies :'( 
 The only drawback was when the book was narrated from Justin POV. I just couldn't stand the lack of proper punctuation. Other than that, I'd say that 'Wonder' is a gift to humanity.
This book was sad and inspiring all at the same time.
I *LOVE* this novel. Great characterization and really sweet ending.
Whoa. Great story. I also really liked the changing perspective of different narrators. Would be an interesting book to read aloud. At times it was a little predictable.

DNF--I would've stopped earlier than page 185, but unfortunately school required that I had to read up to that point. 
 Our main character--a pathetic mess of one, at that--August, practically wallows self-pity throughout the length of the book. He constantly mourns the product of his condition. I might have liked him more had he not been so babied and childish as well. 
 I question the accurate level of maturity in the characters of the book. Forgive me if I'm wrong, but in my experience, 11 year olds are not as immature and do not have the simplicity of a 7-year old. I quote you with this paragraph: 
 "Um, no," I answered. "Oh, well, actually, yes. Is your name Jack or Jack Will?" 
 "Jack is my first name. Will is my last name" 
 "Oh, because Mr. Tushman introduced you as Jack Will, so I thought..." 
 "Ha! You thought his name was Jack Will!" laughed Julian." 
 You couldn't get any more childish than that. 
 I also had many problems with August's narrative. To describe it in a phrase: John Green wannabe; the type of writing that reads kind of aloof and distant, but instead of thoughtful prose that perfectly executes this kind of writing, the sentences are extremely ridiculous, make no sense, and are absolutely cringy. Refer to the paragraph below: 
 I have other friends, too, but not as good as Christopher and Zack and Alex were. For instance, Zack and Alex always invited me to their birthday parties when we were little, but Joel and a Eamonn and Gabe never did. Emma invited me once, but I haven't seem her in a long time. And of course, I always go to Christopher's birthday. Maybe I'm making too big a deal about birthday parties. 
 The comment about the birthday parties at the end is completely unnecessary and it feels weird reading it. 
 I did enjoy the other perspectives greater than the barren swamp I struggled through that was August's perspective brick by brick, but as a casual reader and not a student required to read this book, it was not enough to garner enough interest to finish the rest of the book. Most of the characters are one-dimensional, their dialogue highly unrealistic, and overall a general mess. Highly would not recommend, not even if you're looking for a book with simple imagery and themes to get out of a reading slump.
Amazing!!

I read this book a few years ago when it first came out and was thinking of reading it again recently. I am studying Education and Special Needs at university and when this book was on one of my reading lists it really encouraged me to read it sooner rather than later. The book details the life of Auggie Pullman, a young boy with a facial disfigurement, the book is inspiring and encouraging as you hear from the perspective of others in Auggies life. I found it interesting to consider the challenges he faces, particularly with regard to Jullian and his mom who says that the school is not an 'inclusion school' which is crazy as surely every school should be in promotion of inclusion? It is an interesting book that will benefit anyone and everyone that reads it, it should be studied in school In my opinion. Fantastic- I can't recommend it highly enough.
Amazing book that I would recommend for everyone to read at least once! If it was possible I would no doubt give this book six stars!
This book was amazing. Not about a kid w a deformed face. It's basically about surviving middle school. You see from the multiple point of views that not just Auggie gets bullied. Newbery?
no, really... everyone needs to read this book. have a tissue or 12 handy. <3
My kids are too old. They put their headphones in when I tried to play it over the car radio.
EVERY SINGLE PERSON SHOULD READ THIS!

It's a rare and beautiful feeling when I close a book with a sense of completion. That's what Wonder is: rare and beautiful. 
 The language is simple, at a level that a ten-year-old child can easily read. It suits the book not only because that's how old Auggie' is but also because it lays everything bare to the reader. It isn't hiding anything. All the characters' emotions and actions are laid out for us, from superficial behavior to their innermost thoughts, from their doubts and guilt to their happiness and bliss. After all, it's not easy being around someone with such an obvious disfiguration even if it's someone as sweet as Auggie. 
 Auggie is a funny character. As in he's witty and says the funniest things ever in a matter-of-fact tone. It makes me wish I were his friend, so I can banter around with him. He lacks courage and self-esteem at the beginning of the novel because he knows how bad his facial deformities are. It's to the point that he grows out his bangs because if he can't see people's reactions, then he doesn't feel so bad. At least, that's what he tells himself. In truth, he can guess at what people think about him; he sees the whispers, gestures, and furtive looks. Then he makes friends--real friends that stick up for him--and he's able to open up and show his peers just what a wonderful kid he is. And it's so wonderful to see people grow to accept him. 
 I hadn't expected the multiple perspectives, and it was a wonderful surprise. I was glad to see that Auggie's perspective kep reappearing, but other people whose lives he touches jump in from time to time. And it's a great way to introduce things that we wouldn't have known if only Auggie's perspective was given. There is Summer, who joins him at lunch out of pity and grows to like him as a person. Jack, who first talks to him at the Mr. Tushman's request but also grows to cherish his friendship. Auggie's older sister Via, whose fierce protection over her little brother is something I can relate to. Her boyfriend Justin. Her friend, ex-friend, friend Miranda who loves Auggie as if he were her own brother. Auggie is surrounded by many loving people, and though his deformities make him look like a "freak," to quote idiots in the book, he has one of the kindest hearts out there. He makes me feel like I can be a better person. 
 This book really hits home because it makes you wonder what you would do if you went to school with a kid like Auggie. Would you go against the crowd to sit down with him and have a nice chat? Would you jeopardize your 'friendships' with other people to stand up for him or her? It's a lot easier for us when we're older to stay true to ourselves, though it's still not effortless. I don't want to admit this, but the ten-year-old me probably would have stuck with the neutral camp. I wouldn't want to be mean to him, but I wouldn't stand up for him either. Heck, the teenage me may not have had the courage to try to talk to him like a normal person. And that's why it's so horrible. 
 When I think about it, a bully is someone you can stand up to. Someone who ignores your existence is harder to push away because there's nothing there in the first place. I wouldn't want people to treat my existence like the Plague. What we need to remember is that sometimes it's not what we do but what we don't do that really hurts. Auggie wants to be accepted for himself, but there are kids who won't spend more time than necessary with him even if they're neutral and it really hurts him. At the same time, courage is necessary because Auggie needs to make the first step to help people acknowledge that he's a person--and a cool one at that. It takes going to middle school, speaking up to people, and standing up for his friends like they stand up for him. 
 This easily takes the spot of the middle grade book of the year for me. I recommend this for everyone. 
 -- 
 For more of my reviews, visit my blog Imaginary Reads.

I've heard absolutely rave reviews about this book so my expectations were very high. I didn't dislike it and at times I was completely captivated or shocked by plot twists and turns, but overall I was kind of disappointed. It was interesting to hear about life from August's perspective, but at times he drove me crazy. I liked Jack and felt that he was very relatable. Usually I like hearing from multiple perspectives, but the number of people seemed excessive. Maybe my expectations were too high, but I wasn't blown away.
Eyes welled up a few times and made me want to be a better person. I also loved reading from different character perspectives, I think it worked well for this book.

This was a great book for EVERYONE- not just readers of YA. August is a 5th grader who suffers from a rare facial deformity and he is about to enter public school for the 1st time after only being home-schooled previously. He enters 5th grade and readers get a sense of just how hard it is to be 'Auggie', constantly feared and made fun of. The book begins with 1dt person narration from Auggie, then branches out with chapters narrated by almost every character in the story, from his sister to his friends, even one chapter from the POV of his sister's boyfriend (which for some reason was written entirely in lower case, anyone else have any ideas why THAT was done?) A fast read and a heartwarming one at that.
Suntoma kai periektika: Ap'ta kalutera Young Adult biblia pou ekho os tora diabasei.

I am a teacher of a Year 5 class. I have just finished reading it aloud as a class novel. In my 30 years of teaching I have never read a book that absolutely engaged and enthralled my students as much as this book. The connections and life lessons to be discussed and taught throughout the book were incredibly valuable. It is heart breaking, funny and inspirational. Can't wait for the movie to come out in November- my students are already begging me to take them on an excursion to see it. I highly recommend this book to anyone old enough to read.

A must read book! 
 I was not sure about this book...judging the cover without any idea of what was inside. The inside is filled with a sweet story about a boy who was born disfigured. After multiple operations, his parents decide that he should start school - in grade 5. How will he get through the day with people staring at him? Mocking him? Generally being mean to him? With friends who are there for him. 
 A truly inspirational story where people can succeed with huge obstacles in front of them. 
 Recommendation: Run, don't walk, to the bookstore!

Different and out of the box. Read it in a single Day. 
 Auggie Pullman will wrap you in your world and will give you a real insight into the world of a kid with a deformed face. He'll have you laugh and cry with him. 
 A coming-of-the-Age book for sure. 
 Apart from Auggie's story it was Olivia's patience and innocence and unselfish need to be noticed, that moved me the most. 
 Most of all, it let's you know that it isn't just the bullied kid that needs to be sympathized with but also the Bully, himself :')
Just as good on my second read. I just love this book, everyone should read Wonder!

I liked this book. It was a very quick read and I had a hard time putting it down. I love that the author wrote from different characters' perspectives. It showed the struggle that a lot of people had throughout the story. August's struggle of starting 5th grade - his first year in school. Via's struggle with being August's sister. Jack and Summer's struggle with making the right choice. Miranda's struggle with home and starting high school. I think a chapter from Mom's point of view would have been interesting, she did a LOT for August and Via. I think the principal was amazing - especially when he stood up to Julian's mom. I was like "Yeah! Tell her!!" :) I'll definitely need to watch the movie!!

MY FAVORITE BOOK OF THE YEAR SO FAR! I loved, loved, loved Wonder. I didn't know what to expect. I had seen the book around and was familiar with the cover but not the content. It was my son's summer reading assignment so I read it too and was blown away on every level. 
 The book is told from various character's points of view. August (Auggie) Pullman has been home-schooled his entire life. He was born with a facial deformity and has undergone numerous surgeries to help correct it but he still looks different and his parents felt it was best to be schooled at home. Now that he is about to enter the fifth grade they feel it would be best for him to enroll in a private school where they can better take over his education. You know that there will be problems to overcome and Auggie's story is told in a way that touches your heart. 
 This book approaches special needs, bullying, friendship, love of family and acceptance perfectly. I am the parent of a special needs child and even though my daughter doesn't have a facial deformity, we as a family have experienced so many similar things that are touched on in this book. The gratefulness that I feel for any other child that has patience for my child and befriends her and is kind to her means the world to me. When I finished reading this book I cried and I also wanted to stand up and cheer for Auggie. R.J. Palacio has done a phenomenal job of conveying a story that is so inspirational. Everyone should read this book and hopefully it will teach every reader to think twice before dismissing anyone who looks or acts differently from the norm.
A quick read that will touch your heart.

I was set on giving this 4 stars pretty much the whole book. Then the heartstrings tugged, the emotions pulled, and I bumped this up to 5 stars. So far my first 5- star read of 2017! I didn't realize going into this fully what it was about, it fit a challenge, and is becoming a movie this year so I wanted to read it (sad/happy news- the movie release date got pushed from April to November in hopes of higher viewership). I was met with relatibility I wasn't expecting, a unique perspective, and a heartwarming moral of the story. 
 This follows Auggie, a boy starting the 5th grade in public school for the first time because he has a facial deformity. It's about bullying, it's about courage, it's about coming of age. The book has shifting perspectives between Auggie and his sister and classmates. This gave a different perspective from teenage minds and how actions can be perceived differently- a great look into how other's think. Especially for a young adult reader. But it isn't a depressing story- yes, Auggie is bullied. But it's more the positivity about how to handle, recover, and "be brave". I'm realizing how corny this sounds, but hey. If it works- it works. 
 The only things that bugged me about this- which clearly I overlooked where Justin's chapter- HOLY CRAP. It was written as he would- so there was incorrect punctuation, spelling, captivation, generally written as a teenager- it was SO hard to read. Also what kind of school has a graduation every year for every class? Seems a bit much... 
 What I didn't realize going into this was that Auggie has a cleft palate. Pair this with multiple other things, that is why Auggie's face is "different". The main reason this got 5 stars from me? Ding ding ding! I had a cleft palate when I was born too. Luckily, I had multiple surgeries as a kid to get all that stuff fixed, and my face is and has been completely normal since I can remember- but this really hit home for me. I'm so grateful for everything that I had- and Auggie did not. Craniofacial difficulties is real, it's hard, and it's something that despite "looking normal" it doesn't mean it doesn't effect other things. (dental issues, scarring, speech and language issues, orthodontia, the list goes on). I totally take for granted what Auggie had to deal with in every page of this book. 
 Just take my 5 stars, my tears and emotions, and let me linger on this book for a while longer.
One of the best books I have ever read. It puts so much into perspective and really makes you appreciate the things you have.

Author R. J. Palacio's debut middle grade novel Wonder tells its story with short chapters sectioned into the voices of Auggie, his sister, and some friends. Auggie was born with severe facial deformities and agrees to go to school in fifth grade after having been previously home-schooled. This touching story tells how he, his family, friends and some not so sympathetic schoolmates deal with the various reactions to how he looks. Auggie is also small in stature, but otherwise appears to be a normal fifth-grade boy. This was such a good book and the happy ending was satisfying, if somewhat unrealistic. Young readers should find the book very readable and maybe even learn some lessons about kindness.

This book really makes you consider the value of kindness and how your actions (both intentional and unintentional) affect people around you. I love it simply for the message it gives. Be kinder than necessary!
Such a strong and powerful message for all ages! AMAZING BOOK!!!!

Auggie Pullman is about to start fifth grade. It's his first day at school having been homeschooled all his life. Auggie has a severe craniofacial abnormality. As he puts it, "Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." This is his story. 
 You can probably imagine the rest. Any synopsis would read like the plot of a saccharine after school special. You've got all the usual suspects. The sneering bully, the tentative best friend, the supportive family, the pretty girl who sees what everyone else can't. Ugh - I've just thrown up in my mouth a bit. I'd also argue that while several sections of the book are told from alternate viewpoints, they all read the same. Their voices are not distinct. 
 I loved it. Hope, friendship, love and above all, kindness. Loved the punchy chapter arcs. The frank narration and warm tone throughout. Even the outright manipulation of heartstrings (you can all but hear the swelling tones of the soundtrack in your head as you read) can't dissuade me that this was anything other than a beautiful read.

I will always remember the experience of reading this book. Augie a fifth grade boy with a grossly disfigured face from several birth defects begins middle school-- the first time he has gone to a regular school because his mother has been homeschooling him. The author puts you in his shoes as he struggles to fit in and also puts you in the shoes of the kids and parents reacting to him. Will they befriend him or ignore him or bully him? Of course this all plays out in the tension and cruelty of middle school where even kids with no handicaps must face kidding and teasing. Several communities have chosen this book as a community read and I think it would be a good choice. You really understand how it is to be Augie.

4,5. 
 What an extraordinary book! 
 P.S. I think it's kind of convenient that this is the first book I read in august.

Wonder is a surprisingly emotional book about a young boy with a severely disfigured face. He goes to school for the first time in fifth grade and deals with all the ups and downs that come with being different in middle school. He suffers some heartbreak, some embarrassment, and some betrayal, but over the course of the year, August begins to change. As he changes, so do the kids around him. 
 This book is so beautiful for so many reasons. August puts his best foot forward as he bravely faces the challenges that come each day. He has a wonderful support group in his family and the friends he makes. I loved the different points of view the book is told from. It gives us not only August's experience, but those of the people he is around and the way they see him. 
 It's a wonderful story about bravery, kindness, and hope. Everyone should read this book. 
 Content: Bullying and a few instances of taking the Lord's name in vain. 
 My blog: Batch of Books
Absolutely exceptional. I loved that the book offered brief insight into the lives and perspectives of many of the background characters it added warmth and depth to August's story.

Initially, I thought this was going to be a youth book, but that's not the case. It's a story about choosing kindness and friendship; courage and character. I finished the book feeling hopeful and happy. Definitely a worthwhile read. 
 "'You don't need your eyes to love, right? You just feel it inside of you. That's how it is in heaven. It's just love, and no one forgets who they love.'" (227) 
 "'Shall we make a new rule of life . . . always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" (299) 
 "'Greatness lies not in being strong, but in the right using of strength . . .He is the greatest whose strength carries up the most hearts.'" (304)

I loved this book. I don't even know what to say about it, I just need to write about it right now (the sign of a great book, right?). This book tells the story of Auggie, a kid with a facial deformity, and his first year of middle school, which is also his first year in school, ever, as he was previously homeschooled. And, wow. I could go into the writing of the story (which was great) and the technical aspects but when it comes down to it, this book has a soul. Its characters are alive and they're tugging at your heartstrings. I plan on reading this to my children one day; until then, I'll just have to push it upon my husband and brother and anyone else I can get to read this book!
Really awesome book.. everyone should read it atleast once.. very well written... loved it..
Great book about kindness and the impact of our actions. Very appropriate for kids to read... no swearing, sex or drugs. The first 100 pages it was good/decent, the remaining 200 were great!

"Shall we make a new rule of life ... always to try to be little kinder that is necessary ?" 
 The Little White Bird - J. M. Barrie

I don't give out many 5-star reviews, and when I do it means the book has received my highest recommendation. "Wonder" is just such a book. This is the kind of book that I will talk up to my students and encourage them to read because I know they'll love it, too. 
 Usually I don't enjoy books that are told from the perspectives of different characters all that much, but it's a perfect choice here. It really adds to the story to hear not just from Auggie but also his sister Via, his friends Jack Will and Summer, and Via's friend Miranda and her boyfriend Justin. It made the book better. 
 My favorite line in the book (courtesy of Justin) really encompasses how reading it made me feel: "if it really was all random, the universe wouldn't abandon us completely. and the universe doesn't. it takes care of it's most fragile creations in ways we can't see. like with parents who adore you blindly. and a big sister who feels guilty for being human over you. and a little gravelly-voiced kid whose friends have left him over you. and even a pink-haired girl who carries your picture in her wallet. maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. the universe takes care of all its birds." 
 Do read this book. You will be so glad you did.

This book is about a boy named Auggie who has some congenital malformation of his face. Auggie has always been home schooled but is now transitioning to regular middle-school in grade 5. 
 As you can imagine there are some awful reactions, some horrible bullying but there is also kindness and acceptance. 
 While I enjoyed the story and it did tug at my heart, I found it to be very hard-hitting. I know kids are mean but this seemed very full on for such young people. I think this would be a good things for kids to read as it emphasises the feelings such awful behaviour can have on the person affected, but I, as an adult, was kind of horrified that so many people got away with such nastiness (yes I'm looking at you Julian and family!). 
 The story is told from multiple perspectives which really worked, making it easy to see the multiple points of view. From Auggie to his friends, and family, it painted a picture of Auggie's journey. 
 I only cried once - and that had nothing to do with Auggie (you guys who have read it will know what I mean - but no spoilers!).

I saw the film adaption's trailer first. It looks to have a wonderful cast. I really enjoyed reading the book. It details the main character; August's navagation to find his place in a new environment & social situations. With a facial deformity he deals with being judged & bullied. The book has sad & uplifting chapters. I enjoyed how the different chapters had other character's views on different events; told by their character. Great book. Can't wait to see the film.
Loved this book! Can't wait to see the movie!

Cormac's Review (aged 10): 
 "This book is about a kid who was born with a cleft palate and a badly disfigured face. His parents make him go to a normal school for the first time when he's in Middle School. At first he doesn't want to go because he's scared of what people will say about his face. But he does make some friends, Jack Will, Summer. He also makes some enemies, like Juian and his friends. What I liked the most is that it wasn't just from August's point of view. It was also from the point of view of his friends. You should read it." 
 Mum's 2 cents: 
 Great book to read-aloud; really takes you inside the mind of a child who is "different", a concept which will likely appeal to all kids. Really highlights the issue of empathy, by giving kids the chance to "see what it feels like". And when the going gets tough with the inevitable bullying that comes when August starts school, it has the desired effect on the reader - we felt bad, really bad, for August. The first part of the novel has great pace (and chapters are extraordinarily short which gives the impression you're zipping through it), but I felt it lost its way a bit after the first half. Having said that, I don't think it was the intent for the book to have a climax at the end, as with a traditional novel, rather there were a series of ups and downs throughout, perfectly mimicking how an actual school year goes. Highly recommended.

Wonder is an emotional, heart-warming story full of surprises that is bound to make you want to give Auggie a hug at least one. It's the story of Auggie a young boy who was born with a facial deformity and at the age of ten is about to start school for the first time. It's the story of his journey through socialisation and the horrible world of middle-school where kids say exactly what they think and will stare without a thought. It's the story of friendships; both new and old and what it takes to test, break and fix these. It's the story of family; the glue that holds them together and the strains ones family has to overcome when presented with a disability. It's the story of Via, or Olivia as she wants hence to be known as, who for the first time in her life is able to have an identity other than 'Auggie's sister' and her guilt that comes along with that. 
 In other words it's a beautiful narrative about life. About hardships. The writing itself is rather frank and brutal in its honesty but it does so with humour to dispel any discomfort. For example, Auggie's school principal is Mr. Tushman. It's told through a number of perspectives and at one point through the use of modern 'social' communications (facebook, email, etc..). It's a novel that will put you in the shoes of a number of people and make you think about your past, present and future actions. 
 Although its aimed at a middle school audience, Auggie's story is suitable for anyone who can read. Especially Adults. Its poignant and beautiful and I'm glad that I ha the chance to read it.
Such a sweet story about the power of kindness. Full review at TheYoungFolks.com soon.

Good book, though I wish we got more of the story from the three girls who told their bit of it. The story was told from about six or seven different POVs and only three were told by girls and their sections felt the shortest of the different sections. I guess the girls got half of the sections, but they felt much shorter than the boys' sections. 
 Other than that and Justin's lack of capitalization, not bad. It is definitely a thought provoking book. An interesting concept and way to look at different issues people have. Not everyone has an issue as obvious as August, which was slightly touched on when Miranda and Justin compared their family and home life to August's. It's important to remember that we all have our cross to bear. Some just hide it better than others. But we all need love and kindness, regardless of how obvious our problems. 
 I think this would be a good book for middle readers. It broaches some important topics in an engaging way for children. Good read.

This book was so amazing. It is written primarily from the point of view of a ten year old boy, August, who has severe facial deformities. While he is extremely bright and sweet, the fact that he looks like his face melted off in a fire completely defines him. He's used to the staring and the gasping and the judging, though. He's been homeschooled all his life and then his parents encourage him to attend fifth grade in public school. This is the story of that horrible and wonderful first year. 
 There is so much story to this book and so much that happens, that I can't go further without giving the whole thing away. I will say that this is a story of courage, triumph, acceptance and kindness that everyone, particularly children in the upper elementary grades and miffle school MUST read.But even more importantly, their parents should read it as well. The lessons learned are invaluable and seeing life and how bad (and good) it can be from the point of a child who has never fit in is extraordinary.

FIRST THOUGHTS: 
 4.75 stars, because this book is just WONDERFUL. 
 REVIEW: 
 It is a wonderful thing to be surprised by a novel. That was my experience with Wonder, a middle grade novel I've been meaning to read for quite some time and finally got around to. The novel tells the story of August, a boy born with a misshapen face who is finally going to a real school for the first time in his fifth grade year. I was delighted, appalled, angry, sad, and hopeful in equal measures, a testament to the author's ability to write her characters so that they leap off the page and come to life. 
 August has had a rough go of things, and has lived a mostly sheltered life with the family who loves him dearly. The challenge of attending a real school, where there are children his age that might not necessarily treat him nicely, is daunting. But August makes a brave choice to attend classes, and be among these people who act like he's got the "Plague" (initially anyway). 
 Eventually, August is revealed to be smart, funny and kind - and perfectly normal, in spite of the way he looks. He accepts the way he is, learns to interact with others and basically, teaches all of us - his classmates and readers alike - that it's not about how you look, it's about how you act. 
 This, essentially, is what makes the novel excellent. Using not only August's point of view, but that of the people who surround him - his sister Olivia, his sister's boyfriend Justin, his friend Summer, his other friend Jack, his sister's former best friend - Wonder takes readers on a journey that will break your heart, and put it back together again. 
 There are plenty of ways to react to someone who is different, ranging from kind to not-so-kind. And different perspectives are touched upon in the novel, embodied in a variety of characters. Wonder is about how each person, no matter what they look like, should be treated with respect, kindness and consideration. But what the novel showed me, in the end, was how our actions towards others have consequences and we can choose whether or not to act in a way that is good. It's a simple life lesson, but an essential one, and Wonder tackles it beautifully. 
 Honestly, I'd recommend Wonder to just about anyone. It isn't a long read, but it's the kind of story that'll punch you a little bit in the gut and make you reevaluate how you see and treat other people. With a main character that's easy to root for, some great secondary characters and a pretty simple but awesome story, I'm sincerely glad I finally took the time to read Wonder. 
 {If you liked this review, check out Alexa Loves Books for more!}
3.5 only because YA just isn't my thing. Very good book but it wasn't one I was excited to sit down and read at night.
I want to read this book out loud to a fifth grade class. I need my Tomoka portable back!
Such a WONDERFUL book!!! I LOVED it & highly recommend it!!!

Until fifth grade, ten-year-old August "Auggie" Pullman has been home-schooled. Twenty-seven surgeries have improved the appearance of his facial deformities but according to Auggie (and reactions from strangers) he always stands out like a black sheep in a heard of white. In fact Halloween is the only night of the year where he blends in. "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever your'e thinking, it's probably worse" (1). Wonder tells the story of Auggie's fifth grade year through alternating viewpoints: Auggie, his older sister Olivia (Via), friends from school (Summer and Jack), his sister's boyfriend (Justin) and his sister's ex-friend (Miranda). It's hard not to fall in love with Auggie's character- he's courageous, kind, sarcastic, funny...he's the type of kid who makes people better for knowing him. Via describes her brother as "the Sun. Me and Mom and Dad are planets orbiting the Sun. The rest of our family and friends are asteroids and comets floating around the planets orbiting the Sun" (85). Via is an empathetic, altruistic sister and daughter but everyone yearns to be the center of the universe, at least once in a while; and at her new high school, she has a chance to be more than just "Auggie's sister. "Because like Auggie pointed out, "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." When Via's boyfriend lands the lead role in the Our Town play and she makes understudy for another main character, Via doesn't tell her parents or Auggie which causes obvious turmoil within their family. But sometimes conflict is necessary for change to take place. 
 Check out the trailer: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fgB7_K...
Re-read. Such a wonder - ful book.

Okay, I loved this book, but for me it didn't live up to the 5 star/one of the best books I've ever read hype that it has gotten everywhere. 
 It was a a pretty simple story, but the characters are so lovely that it really is a page turner even though it's not suspenseful. :) I read it in a day because I just honestly wanted to keep reading. I got teary a couple of times, but it wasn't a sob-inducing story. I didn't realize when I first started reading it that it would switch perspective several times. At first I was disappointed because I wanted to keep reading from Auggie's perspective, but it ended up being done really well, and now I can't imagine it any other way. 
 P.S. It did throw me off a bit that sometimes the kids sounded and acted a lot older than they were. Auggie's ten, right? And the kids in his class are "dating"? It was weird. And Via seemed like she should be a bit older than what...fourteen?

Truly a five-star children's book...A remarkable story, filled with fully believable characters, especially Auggie, a ten-year-old that you will want to get to know. Palacio's method of having each major character share from their perspective was brilliant in this work.

August "Augie" Pullman was born with a severe facial deformity. He decides to attend 5th grade, after being home-schooled by his parents. This is a beautiful story about a kid who just wants to be treated like everyone else. He is smart, funny and a Star Wars fanatic. 
 Yes, this story can be heart-rending and cruel at times at times but it is also heart-warming and winning. Guaranteed, you will find yourself falling for this special little boy.
Started and finished it on the same day. It's a must read!
Every person young and old should read this book so inspiring and thoughtful.
This book was genuinely stunning and I already want to reread it. Easily one of my new favorites.

"When given the choice between being right and being kind,choose kind." 
 I LOVE this story. I LOVE these characters. I have SO MUCH SYMPATHY FOR ALL THESE PEOPLE *coughs* *characters* that my heart just broke so many times! I'm so glad the chapters are super short. Everything is explained to the point, no unnecessary story time wasted and no random info. I could put the book down and feel sad, think about it, do other things because life. This book probably would've been unputdownable if I had the time and the attention-span. 
 The book is told from multiple POV's which can sometimes be annoying (in other books) but Palacio did such an amazing job! It just made the book feel so well rounded and just made me love everyone way more. I swear, these characters are now my friends and I would like to know what's happening in their lives. 
 I don't really buy the ending, but I guess that's the wonderful world of fiction for you. Or maybe things like that do happen irl to some people sometimes, I don't know. Overall I really enjoyed this. I've been in a terrible reading slump this year and somehow I felt like a MG book would be a good change. I definitely recommend this. 
 For anyone who doesn't know, and wants to know, this book is about August Pullman, a young boy with... I don't even know what kind of fancy medical words to use, but basically his face is not like something anyone has seen before. This book takes place during the time he's in the 5th grade, his first time ever in (traditional? normal?) school, and his experiences (more of a focus on his experiences with people than actual school work). 
 Personal perk: it's told in first person narrative! Like the characters are telling you their story! I love that.

Everyone should read this book! Auggie may look strange but you soon realize that what he really is is an ordinary kid. As you read you'll feel sorry for Auggie, cry for him, and cheer for him as he adjusts to attending school for the first time. After reading this book, I wished that I could give Auggie a high-five. He is an amazing kid!

"I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." (Favourite quote of the year, so far.) 
 August was a complex, adorable, sometimes grumpy, and memorable little boy. I'm so glad I finally read this. 
 Happy reading!

Very powerful book, for everyone but every teen, should read this! 
 Loved it, it is a tear-jerker.
Excellent story ... quick and easy read, but not an easy subject ... yet filled with lots of good feelings (mixed in with the not-so-good). Very uplifting

What else can I say about this that hasn't already been said. It's a lovely look at what it's like to be more than different, not just for the one with the differences, but those around him. I loved it.

Wonder is one of those books you are glad that somebody wrote because the subject matter is important. 
 August is a boy who is about to enter middle school and as everyone remembers - middle school separates the men from the boys, the strong from the weak and the popular from the kids last to be picked for kickball. With all of this pressure to fit in August has a lot to worry about but his real fear is that he will be pointed at, picked on and will not have any friends because of his severe facial deformities. His parents are worried, his older sister Via is worried and August is worried. Despite the natural meanness of middle school age kids, August does make friends but his story is not without cruelty and kindness found in unusual places. We all judge a book by its cover and the person by how they look but I hope kids will read Wonder and take away its message.
Absolutely loved the story and characters! It's a feel good and unique tale that I encourage everyone to read.
Doing this for a book club, this is my second time reading it
it quietly teaches you rather than slamming meaningful quotes in your face. truly an amazing book.

"Funny how sometimes you worry a lot about something and it turns out to be nothing." 
 4.5 stars 
 August Pullman is just an ordinary boy, but with a not-so-ordinary face. Persuaded into attending public school for the first time, Auggie has a lot of new things, both good and bad, to learn about. 
 Wonder is a book that I didn't expect to ever read. I'd see it many times wherever books are sold and heard it was good, but it was a middle grade novel so I thought I wouldn't enjoy it much so I skipped part it. In January, my school's Book Club chose to read this book. I was glad we did, because I really enjoyed it. 
 I adore all the characters (except Julian of course). The book is written mostly through Auggie's pont of view, although it does switch it up a few times. Auggie sounded like a genuine fifth grader. I did like Via's, Summer's, Jack's, Justin's, and Miranda's chapters. There is a lot of character development, which is good. I just wish the end had went a little more in depth about what happened to each character. 
 Another thing I liked about this book was all the references to movies, songs, etc.. I'm a huge Star Wars fan so I was ecstatic with Auggie being a huge fan and having many things relate to it. 
 Wonder is definitely an amazing book that everyone should read despite their age. It's really one of those books that make you really think about your life compared to others. I can't wait to see the movie adaption coming out later this year!

I wish I could give more than 5 stars to this book. I love, love, LOVED this book. It was, by turn, funny, poignant, heartbreaking, nostalgic, and triumphant. There were parts that made me laugh out loud, and a great portion of it had me crying my eyes out. I read it in less than a day, staying up till 5am so I could finish it. 
 The book tells the story of August Pullman, a young boy born with severe facial deformities who starts attending middle school after being homeschooled until that point. It deals with his experiences in school, both from his perspective, as well as from the perspectives of some of his friends, classmates, and family. I really liked the multiple-voice perspective as it really enriched the story and gave it a lot more depth. At times it was so painful to read about the bullying and abuse Auggie endured that I had to put the book down and walk away for a couple hours before I could go on. Middle school can be a horrible time for many kids, and kids can be so mean. Most of us who have survived middle school were not as badly bullied as Auggie, but for many of us who were different in some way probably faced it in some form. Even 20+ years later, that can be a painful time for many of us to look back on. 
 Although written as a "young adult" book, this is one that everyone should read, whether you're nine years old, or ninety-nine. The lessons it teaches about friendship, love, loyalty, and kindness are ones we can all stand to learn. And, to paraphrase one of the characters, we should all make it a rule to be kinder than needed.
Ugh. It's one of those.
A great read! Full review to come at storycarnivores.com

Wow. I haven't cried that much whilst reading a book in a long time. I loved this story, and I loved all the different characters we got to go along with throughout. I don't always love POV changes, but I really liked the way these were handled. I felt like the voices were really authentic, especially for Auggie and some of the other younger kids -- they really thought like fifth graders, which was refreshing. I thought there were a few ... I wouldn't call them errors, but just a few things that bothered me throughout, such as the repetitive use of names in dialogue, which pulled me out of the story, because no one says another person's name THAT much. It got a little grating. Some of the adults seemed too indulgent toward the kids, and they were a little flat, as well. Overall, though, the story and the main character were just so, so engaging that I couldn't put this book down.

This is such an amazing book. I utterly loved it and cannot wait to be able to read it to my daughter when she's a little older. I've recommended it to every 5th grader and above that I've come across because I think it's one of those books that's so important. We could all use a reminder about the value of kindness and this book is one that will stay with you for a long time after. 
 Really fabulous.
A real eye opener! A really touching story so if you're looking for tear jerker this is it!
Such a marvelous concept, so well done! Great for all ages!

The world needs more books like this. 
 I rarely cry when reading books, but I could taste those salty tears when I read the scene with Eddie on the school trip. 
 Auggie's voice, and everyone else's, was so pure and honest. I fell in love with all these characters. I felt their pain and their struggles and their happiness as well. I understood their jokes and their words and their actions. 
 Wonder was perfect.
really enjoyed this book. I cried in some parts. be kind to all no matter the situation

This book was amazing (or perhaps "soul-shaking" is a better description). 
 The author accomplished things in this book I didn't think were possible. As a writer, it spun my head, inspired me creatively, and helped me set loftier goals for myself. As a reader, it exposed my human vulnerabilities in a way I'm not accustomed to (because we adults have learned to shield ourselves quite well, thanks to experience and previous pains). 
 "Soul-shaking." Yeah, that's a good way to describe it. And don't be afraid of it; it's not a perpetual downer, I promise. It's surprisingly positive and optimistic, given the main character's challenges. 
 This book almost replaced To Kill a Mockingbird as my "Favorite Book of All Time." 
 Almost. (And that says so much.)

"You're beautiful no matter what they say , words can't bring you down" -christina aguilera

 what a Fantastic book !! !i'm so happy i read it ,i felt every part of it !! and it even gave me goosebumps. 
 this story is about a 10 years old kid named auggie , who has a magor facial deformity . he has been homschooled by his mom until one day he decided to go to a regular middle school . 
 i love this little auggie , he his so funny and smart ! and he is just like the other kids ! but not everyone can see that !

It's obvious why people of all ages are crazy about this novel. It hits you over the head with all the feels. Literally every feel. 
 "Now that I look back, I don't know why I was so stressed about it all this time. Funny how sometimes you worry a lot about something and it turns out to be nothing."

While it's important to have books like this, I wish this book were less cheesy. 
 I found the motivation to go to school and the way homeschooling was represented irritating. 
 I also found the characters and plotlines cheesy and unrelatable. And while the scenarios were plausible, the character's dialogue and reactions were over-done, and the character was very two-dimensional. 
 Auggie is a sweet but occasionally whiny character. 
 Summer was a sweet, accepting girl who wasn't perfect. (Except she is) 
 Jack seems to be nice, then isn't, then is. 
 Julian is a typical mean boy, who then turns nice, to no surprise. 
 Yeah, the author apparently wanted to create three-dimensional characters who are realistic, except they're not. They have a few personality traits and a few duties for the plot. They're all flat, annoying characters. 
 I know this book is well loved, so many people disagree with me, I just wish it was done better.

This book is wonder-ful! I laughed, I cried, I was angry, I was frustrated, I was happy. This book may be written for preteens, but it's a must-read for people of all ages. Thank you, RJ Palacio for writing this beautiful gift to humanity.

For starters, I can see why people like this book. BUT, I am not one of those people. 
 Before you read on, I feel obligated to say that if I sound like a snobby jerk, apologies in advance. 
 So, Wonder is a childrens story about Auggie, a fifth grade boy about to go to public school for the first time. The first time?! Why? Well, Auggie was born with a facial deformity, and has always been home-schooled due to his unfortunate circumstance. Of course, he gets stared at... and not every stare is friendly. 
 "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 Is it just me, or does that sound a tad bit like self-pity? Sorrry, Auggie, but I really can't bring myself to connect with -- or even like -- your character. 
 I am not one for touching stories about kindness, or how to prevent bullying. I know what you're thinking. Well, maybe you shouldn't have picked this up, then. You are absolutely right. 
 ..... 
 Except reading Wonder.
This book! I loved every word. A must-read for people of all ages.
"Always try to be a little kinder than is necessary". Beautiful book. Loved every page. I am glad my son also read it and loved it. I hope we all can learn to be kind always.

Just finished again...just as good as the first time...now I need to read the Julian chapter again...a must follow-up read from the only main character we didn't hear from in Wonder and his side of the story. 
 Reading again...I love this book so much. I read it not long after it came out and knew it was going to be a winner. Everyone of all ages needs to read this book and the sequels. It gets five stars this time, just like it did the first time!
So heartwarming and sweet- I love the different points of view and the concept about kindness.

What an amazing book. It is indeed a "wonder". August Pullman was born with a rare genetic disorder and has cranio-facial abnormalities. He has been homeschooled, because he has been in and out of hospital for most of his life, but his parents have decided to send him to school for fifth grade. This novel is the story of his fifth grade year. 
 The book is told in the voices of Auggie, his sister Via, his friends, Jack and Summer, Via's boyfriend Justin and her friend Miranda. There is one chapter told in emails and text messages, which gives us further perspectives on an incident. This is interesting, because Auggie says at the beginning that he doesn't want to tell us what he looks like; this information comes from Via most strongly. 
 What I really liked about the novel is that Auggie has to constantly deal with the reactions of other people, again and again, and this is not glossed over. Neither is the reaction of adults: we learn that some parents have photoshopped him out of school photos, for example. However, Palacio also lets us know that all of the young characters have difficulties, whether that is Via having to always be the good girl because Auggie needs care, or dealing with the death of a parent, divorcing parents or trying to fit in in a private school when your parents aren't wealthy. The reader empathises when the characters don't behave well. 
 I'm not keen on using books to point moral messages, but I do think the message of Mr Tushman's end of year speech is important: we should try to be a little kinder. A great book to read and discuss with children in Y5 or 6, perhaps alongside materials from Changing Faces charity www.changingfaces.org.uk. Highly recommended for teachers with an interest in inclusive practice.

One of the things I really appreciate about this book is how real the characters are. All the kids act their age! 
 Personally, Via's point of view really resonated with me and I will never forget this story. 
 This story also reminds me that it's the little things in life that make it good, and a lot of people try really hard just to get through the day.

It's a really nice book that you can plough through on an afternoon. It is really a book for teens, but you will not be dissapointed as an adult. I liked the characters, although it was sometimes somewhat annoying that you switch to many perspectives. Only August and his sister would have sufficed.
To say I love this book would be an understatement, but I LOVE THIS BOOK!

Although I did like this book, I feel as if it is overrated. 
 About ten different people told me this was a brilliant, fantastic, wonderful, amazing book, and so that is what I expected. But it didn't live up to my expectations. 
 I prefer One by Sarah Crossan, which has vaguely the same idea (conjoined twins who start school for the first time). 
 Overall, I like it, but it's not as good as everyone says it is.

I liked this book. I don't think that it will win the Newbery, even though that it the murmer among many children's libararians. It is a story that has been told before. I did enjoy it, he is such a strong character. I would be happy if it wins. That means I would like a Newbery winner for a change.
My heart, it aches. Not only was the story in this book amazing but the writing was really exceptional. I enjoyed this so much, even though it made me cry more than once

i cried when Auggie's face was being described. the writing style of this book isn't the best- it isn't very unique or detailed because it is a story told from the perspective of a 10 year old boy but I would highly recommend reading this book because of all the lessons that it teaches. the way Augguie is struggling to fit in and he finally finds love and self acceptance is truly beautiful.

*I highly recommed this book to anyone, anywhere.* 
 I'm so glad I finally managed to purchase a copy of this book. I've been wanting to read it for months. 
 I really have no negative criticism to add, for it offered me one of the most wonderful and touching readings I have memory of. This is a very simple story, the story of August, the story of all Augusts, and a truly powerful one it is. 
 The writing is extremely simple, therefore it can be understood and read by anyone of any age, for its message will never be lost. I think it is also a terrific book to be recommended by teachers, or read aloud by parents to their children. This is, all around, a book that must be shared again and again, because it has a rare power to touch hearts and change minds. 
 The whole way the story is presented and the plot is unvailed before our eyes, is extremely clever, yet again, also terribly simple, which by all means, I believe it is the true strength of this work, its apparent simplicity. 
 You can feel the love that was put into this book in every single page, sentence and word. There's this aura around it that just caresses your heart. I don't know how to explain it properly. 
 I couldn't put it down all night, and even though it made me cry again and again, it also made me smile, it made me laugh, and reminded me of how precious and beautiful life is, and to never give up on people. There's always two sides to every story. 
 I loved this book so, so, much. And if I ever have children, this is one reading we will do together. 
 What a beautiful, inspiring, treasure of a book this is. Do not miss it!

Cute story told from the perspectives of fifth graders. Enjoyed the simplicity of the storytelling and the messages shared about the importance of treating others different from oneself with kindness. Lots of warm fuzzies in this one!
Fantastic and charming. Love the alternating voices and viewpoints. A great read for any age!

I like the idea of being a little bit extra kind. Magnanimous. 
 This story was very well told. The horrors of middle school are brought to light in a totally new way. I like the choice of different narrators.

The funny thing about writing reviews is that sometimes it's excruciatingly difficult to write a review about a book that you didn't enjoy, but sometimes even harder to write a review about a book that you loved with all your heart. Wonder is one of the latter types of books. I finished this one in a day last weekend, and have struggled to find the words to review it ever since. 
 I first read a review of this book on GoodReads, written by the wonderful Wendy Darling, whose opinion on books I hold in high esteem. At the time, my library didn't yet have this book on order, since it was so new, but I immediately added the book to my TBR list. Once my copy arrived in the library, and I devoured it in a single day, I will definitely be purchasing a copy of this book, since I think it's a must-have for any library. 
 Wonder is a middle-grade novel that would appeal to any age group. I recommended it at work to a woman with an eight-year old son and to some of my much older coworkers. As Wendy so eloquently put in her review, this book can be recommended to anyone with a beating heart. It'll warm your heart, break it a little and then leave you with a feeling of absolute satisfaction and euphoria. After finishing this book, I immediately told my husband that all elementary schools should have this book as a novel study. If more kids read Wonder, I sincerely believe that there would be no more bullying. It's the kind of book that touches your heart and makes a difference. The kind of book that sticks with you long after the final words have been read. The kind of book that makes your soul sing and makes you happy to be a reader. The kind of book that comes around once in a while and reminds how profoundly we have an impact on the lives of one another. 
 I won't write anymore, since the slightest thoughts about the plot of this book have me tearing up all over again. But let me leave you with this: YOU MUST READ THIS BOOK. If you read nothing else this year, read this one. It's, hands down, the best book that I've read this year. 
 Review also posted at: http://writergrrlreads.blogspot.ca/20...

Wonder by R.J. Palacio is an inspirational middle-grade novel with well-developed and authentic characters that should be at the top of your TBR pile. 
 Wonder follows fifth grader August "Auggie" Pullman as he enters school for the first time. Auggie never went to school for medical reasons due to severe craniofacial anomalies that cause other people to stare or even scream at him. While Auggie sees himself as a normal fifth grade boy, many of his classmates do not-they refuse to be near him and are even afraid to accidentally touch him. Told through several points of views, readers learn about Auggie's story and how it affects every one around him. 
 There are so many reasons why I love this book. I love how the author uses multiple characters to tell the story so we can see how many different people react to Auggie and how they change because of his story. All of the characters are unique and none of them are perfect, which makes each character very authentic. Initially, I was disappointed that Julian didn't have a chapter, but after reading the author's reasoning on her website, I'm glad that she didn't (read her reasoning here). 
 Even though we don't get a Julian chapter, I think the emails from Julian's parents contrasted with Jack's story with his babysitter help us understand Julian's actions, even if we don't agree with them. It shows the large role that adults play in shaping children's opinions. I'm studying special education in college and whenever I tell people this, they automatically assume that I'm working with students who have no ability to learn any school content. In this book, Julian's parents just look at Auggie and assume he can't be learning the same material as their son, even though he outperforms many students in fifth grade. On the other hand, Jack experiences something completely different, which affects how he treats Auggie. All of the little stories in this book were so realistic and helped me better understand the character's motivations and actions. 
 I also enjoyed the precepts at the end of the book that were submitted by the students over the summer. I liked how they really showed each character's personality and for some it showed their growth. I was expecting the precepts to be part of the big moment at the ending, but I'm actually glad they weren't because it made the book less predictable. Also, the big moment at the end better suits the book. 
 Overall, Wonder is a wonderful story with a great message, so I give Wonder five out of five stars. 
 Originally posted on Beauty and the Bean Boots
I am very disturbed by books that involve bullying. Did everything work out in the end- yes. Because mainly the kids were real.
Loved this book! An easy read, this book took me only 2 days to finish. It was overall a feel good book and I'll admit, I teared up during at least one happy part. Can't wait to see the movie!

"My name is August, by the way. I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 By the end, when I shut the book, I actually wrapped my arms around it like I was hugging a very close friend (or would that be friends? haha). This review will not have any spoilers, so don't worry! Anyway, August is a 10 year old boy with extreme facial abnormalities. As the official summary states, he was not expected to survive. Over the years, he has never attended school due to numerous surgeries and it shocks him when he finds out that he was accepted into Beecher Prep. August was born into a very loving family, with a comedic father, a doting mother and a pretty protective elder sister. His sheltered life seems rather distant when he enters school. August knows who he is and what he looks like. He knows how he effects people and he is use to how people react to him, but in school, they really test his limit. 
 But there's always more to a face. 
 "Wonder" starts out with August's perspective, then moves to his elder sister, Via, then to a friend, and so on and so forth, but by the end of the book, it moves back to August. When I borrowed this book from my local library, I didn't know that the perspectives switched and if I knew, I don't think I would have read this. I'm always reluctant to read another person's point of view and I do hate that I'm like that because it is rather silly of me. And, now that you know this about me, you might be surprised that I actually read through everything without trouble. As each perspective transitioned to the next, I was introduced to new, wonderful characters. And these characters that Palacio writes so realistically, I can't tell you enough how much I fell in love with this book. It's the kind of story where you're left with this empty feeling and you're seeking for more, but you know that on your own, you can picture the character's life ahead. You can play the ideas, juggle all the roads the characters may possibly take. 
 These characters will touch your heart, and the kindness and meanness of the people that August comes across will both warm you and horrify you. This truly is a remarkable book, and I promise you, by the end of the story, you will learn something. 
 August truly is a wonder.

To this book I say one thing. 
 "To be beautiful is to be good. And to be good it is to be beautiful."

What a WONDERful book! I'd heard so many good things about this YA book, and had to check it out. As a mom, I can't even fathom what was going thru Isabel Pullman's mind when August was born with the severity of deformities he had. Granted, this is a fictional book, but it happens to be some people's realities. 
 "The universe hasn't been kind to August Pullman" was an understatement made by his friend Jack. No joke. Auggie's odds were 1 in 4 million. 27 surgeries before age 4. And a life time of horrified looks from strangers. How anyone keeps from tearing up during this read is beyond me. I found myself extremely grateful for my "perfect" babies, and wondering how exactly you can teach your children to be compassionate, as well as "kinder than necessary" like Summer, when there are so many Julian's? Everyone should read this book, if not just for the fact that it humbles you, as well as gives an excellent message.

I doubt that there are many children who want to be the center of attention for being different, for looking different. Auggie is different. His family was always very protective of him because people can be mean, children can be mean. Starting school in 5th grade is a tough time. Children are finding their place in the group. Trying to fit in. Auggie does not fit in, physically, and forces the other kids to look past the exterior and into his soul. There is value to reading this book for both children and adults. Do not judge a person by their physical appearance, get to know him or her, listen. You might be surprised at what you hear.
What a fantastic read, and one I know I will want to read again. Uncomfortable at times, touching and eventually feel good, I loved it.

Cute and uplifting book that I think any kid starting middle school should read. It can teach a child to get to know someone based on their character and not the way they look. I did choose to listen to this as an audiobook, something I rarely do because I don't always enjoy books being dictated to me. With all the characters and different narrators it really brought the story alive. Since I saw the previews of the upcoming movie I kept picturing Owen Wilson and Julia Roberts as the parents. I think they were both cast well, but knowing the mother is Portuguese (or is it Brazilian?), then maybe a more ethnic actor would have been better like Selma Hayek. Time will tell and this is definitely a book I'm happy has a movie to go see.
This book has an important message and I appreciated the mutiple POV's, but I wasn't as impacted as I expected to be. It was still a great story and I'm glad I read it :)

** spoiler alert ** 
 Perfect middle school book. Lots of perspective and authenticity. Glad I got to read this with my 10 year old

We all deserve a standing ovation. 
 Wonder has been on my shelf for a long time- I happened to read a page of it while waiting for an email and two hours later I was still going. It's a joy of a book to read, super quick and easy but full of sweet messages, sadness and moving characters. 
 The book is split into different POVs, ranging from our main boy August, his sister, his best friends and Via's boyfriend. This worked incredibly well as we not only saw how August saw himself, but how the world around him saw and felt for August. 
 We start the book with August, and we end the book with August, who has a different look to him than the other boys and girls around him. Handling physical conditions such as this is extremely hard to do but Palazio handles it with great tenderness and delicacy and definitely shines truth on the reality of those involved. His journey involves him going to middle school for the first time, and learning to get on with children his own age. 
 Our little party of characters are truly real and representative of children who struggle not only to follow what they believe in but not to be led astray by others. 
 A lot of moments in this book touched me, I felt close to tears on a number of occasions, and had to hold my dog close - A LOT while reading. 
 It's a super quick read, - a great choice to get you out of a reading slump if you're in one. And it's a meaningful story I feel should be spread around - it'll touch your heart, warm your soul and make you realise how such small actions make the biggest difference. 
 I highly advise tissues. Man Size.

5 and more rating

Wonder is about "Courage. Kindness. Friendship and Character." 
 When I first heard about this book, the first thing that came to mind was the movie Mask. It is a favorite of mine, and I couldn't help it. I had to purchase this book. 
 It surprised me to see how strong Auggie was, even if he sometimes doubted himself. It must be so hard to be different, when you aren't different. Auggie wasn't an alien or a horse but a little boy like all the others. And although not everyone was able to realize that, I'm glad some did. 
 Be prepared to switch P.O.V as the author jumps from August, to his sister, her boyfriend, and some friends.
4.5 stars, great book!

** spoiler alert ** 
 It's the story about Auggie, and basically about his first time in public school. Like the synopsis told, Auggie is just an ordinary kid with an extraordinary face. You can imagine how hard it is for him. To start something so new, in a very new place, full of people who want to know you, not because any great things about you but because they curious about your face and your story. I should say curious because sometimes people didn't care, they just want to know it. They didn't really want to help you, they just need something to talk about with their friends. Another factor why I really like this book is because the writing style of the Author. It a light book I should say, and don't make me tired to read it even in a long time. I feels like this book should be categorized as children book than a young adult one. She write this book perfectly, from any different point of view of the characters in this book. The way she write in this book, explicitly told us that sometimes the way we saw something was different from the facts, the way we thought about something is different from what the other think, and the way we judge something is somehow not same at all with what it actually is. Prejudice is not a good thing at all. Stop act like you know it so much, when you actually don't know the reason other people did and feel about something.
