Such a sweet little book. Charming and simple, but it just tugs at your heart.

At some points during my reading of Wonder I kept thinking what people on Heavy Medal would say about the book. It felt like I was looking for the book's weakness. Probably has something to do with the fact that I read it Newbery weekend. Thankfully, I was able to remind myself that Newbery really doesn't mean as much as some(me) make it out to be. My job isn't to look for faults in a book. My job is to enjoy the story, savor the message, and fall in love with the characters. 
 This book if amazing, and everyone should read it. I had to stop with 3 pages left because I was sobbing. The thought of the book ending broke my heart. Three days later I was able to finish this 5 star read.

A lovely book about acceptance and being kind, written from a number of perspectives including the main character Auggie. Details his first year at middle school, the reaction and everyday struggle that can occur when you're different. 
 Written well with both funny and poignant moments.

What do I even say here? Perfection. I am ridiculously upset with myself that I didn't pick this one up sooner. What was I waiting for? 
 I want to start a campaign to get this book in ever classroom across the country. It teaches a beautiful lesson, is a roller coaster of emotion, and is exquisitely written. 
 I am in love.

There were so many places this book could have gone wrong -- been too sentimental, too formulaic, too something -- but it didn't. I especially liked how well-drawn the adult characters were. Too often the parents in middle-grade or YA come off as stereotypical or cardboard or just plain absent, and here they're as sensitively and fully portrayed as the kids. The various viewpoints illuminate different facets of the story, the voices are believable and true, and the ending hits just the right note. I barely put this one down before I was through, and I'm sure I'll be re-reading it in the future.

Cool beans" - Auggie Pullman 
 Hello Bookworms. I'm back with a special read to my heart, as I'm certain that you'll fall in love with it just like I did (or not). The lovely baby blue book up there is actually from the children's gender. Though it seems childish of me, but some books are just timeless. 
 I first spotted Wonder while I was skimming through some bookish themed Instagram accounts. The cover attracted me, mainly because it contained a half-faced boy. It reminded me of a Picasso painting too. This accord probably a year or two before I actually ordered it. I kind of regret my poor decision on not getting it sooner ( I always make poor decisions. But that's not the point here.) 
 The story takes place in the lives of the Pullmans. Normal parents, a normal daughter, a normal pet dog, and an extraordinary son called August. Auggie is a typical geeky child. He loves Star Wars and video games. August was homeschooled too. But why? well, let's just say that Auggie Pullman had an interesting face. Everything was going well for the little one, until one day his parents decided to enroll him into a normal middle school and make him have a taste of an ordinary school life. 
 He freaks out at first, but soon comes in terms with it. The boy meets new friends, and learns the meaning of true friendship. Auggie learns that sometimes enemies can be friends, and friends could be potential enemies. He faces challenges, bullying and loss. But Auggie Pullman smiles again, and gives a thumbs up. 
 Auggie's big sister faces some problems too, and most of them are unfortunately linked to her little brother. It is not easy being Auggie's normal sibling. 
 This book will make you laugh, cry, and laugh again. But most of all, it will make you walk away wishing you had your own Auggie. I practically fell in love with this fictional child. 
 Cool Beans! 
 From my book blog: https://fridayread.wordpress.com/2015...

August Pullman is not your typical 5th grader. For one thing, he was homeschooled until the fifth grade. For another, he doesn't look like your typical child. August was born with chromosomal differences, which means he has a deformed face. When his parents enroll him in a private school for the 5th grade, August (Auggie to his friends and family) is terrified. He is afraid that people will stare. They always stare. He is afraid of not making friends; of being picked on; of just being different. As if becoming a teenager isn't bad enough with hormones taking over, going to school while being different is just plain torture. But with humor and a lot of heart, August learns who his true friends are, and what Kindness really means. 
 This book is told from the points of view of August, his sister Via (Olivia), his friends Summer and Jack, and Via's friends Justin and Miranda. While this book was a little too lovey-dovey toward the end, it was realistic enough, and the message came through loud and clear.

R.J. Palacio has created a character to love and admire in 10 year old Auggie - and his loyal friends. You will laugh and cry as Auggie navigates a new world that is often cruel and embracing. As the mother of a 10 year old boy, I so felt the pain of Auggie's rejection and the pain of not being able to make his world free from this pain or of his unfortunate disfigurement. I was horrified trying to piece together just how awful Auggie's face is and wondered how I, or my son, would react in such a situation. A great topic for discussion between me and my son. 
 I would have given this 5 stars except for 2 issues for me. The author alternates in first person between multiple narrators and this works - but there are too many voices. I felt if she had selected 3 (Auggie, a friend, Auggie's sister) we would have enough of other points of view to see Auggie's world full circle. Also, the kids are 10 year olds in 5th grade but they seemed like 6th or even 7th graders with much older conversations than I hear 10 year olds having and especially navigating the dating world. I just couldnt suspend disbelief over that and kept thinking they were 12 or 13. 
 Overall, this book is a "wonder" and so is Auggie.

Amazing, outstanding, WONDERful! This book will end up with medals on its cover. This is a nice clean book that middle school 
 and upper elementary students should read. It is the story of a 5th grade boy's courage to attend school for the first time after having several operations to his abnormal face. I have one concern when I consider this book for its passing the test of time, a lot of modern day mentions like facebook.
I think this is as good a YA book as it gets and totally sets the standard. Puts ''Looking for Alaska'' and ''The Perks of being a Wallfower'' to shame.
This is a beautiful book; I cannot wait to share it with my book club (and anyone else) that might need a positive, feel-good read!

I got to see R.J. Palacio at Michigan Reading Association last week. She has wanted to be a writer since she was a young kid. She began to write the story of Wonder when she saw a girl who was disfigured. 
 Wonder is being read by fourth graders in Grand Rapids Public Schools. I have kids telling me they loved the book. 
 I feel I'm a little late in reading this. I liked the story too. And what a wonderful message to "choose kindness."
Wow. This book. I teared up quite a few times while reading ths. It's really heart warming.

This is easily a book I've been putting off for YEARS. "It's just a middle grade book, I'll get around to it eventually..." 
 I don't know how to review this book. I've read a lot of books that are about sensitive subjects that I can't review. The books are an experience. This one is a good experience. 
 Okay, but let's be real. I think EVERY student in middle school should be required to read this book. This is one of THOSE kinds of books. I already consider myself a kind enough person, but kids are learning and up until they start thinking for themselves, they learn behavior from their parents. And not all kids have good parents. 
 August Pullman is blessed to have amazing parents, a kind sister and open minded classmates. All his life he's known kindness, he's known exclusion.... and it didn't harden his heart. Because of his family, the love and support he received from them. 
 There's a lot to take away from this book, no matter what stage of life you're in. But the most important of all is: be kind, be loving, be yourself.
This book should be required reading. Like, for human beings.

August (Auggie) is about to start fifth grade and will actually attend a real school for the first time. Up until now he has been home-schooled by his mother due to the number of surgeries he's had to endure since he was a baby. Auggie was born with a severe birth defect requiring him to undergo 20+ surgeries in just under ten years. He knows how people look at him whenever they go out, and he's afraid of what will happen when he goes off to school - he won't know anyone there. What if the kids are scared of him? What if they talk about him? Will he have any friends? When Auggie's parents take him to Beecher Prep, just a few blocks away from his home to meet the principal, Mr. Tushman, he decides to give it a try. Besides, if it's too horrible, he can always go back to being home-schooled. 
 As if middle school isn't hard enough, imagine having to deal with Auggie's problems on top of the cliques and all of the pre-teen angst of middle school. This book is funny, heart-breaking and inspiring all at the same time. It's told from multiple viewpoints, and not once does it feel disjointed. In fact, the multiple points of view help round out the novel very well. I've read plenty of books about outcasts, but I don't think I've ever wanted to jump in and rescue someone as badly as I did with Auggie. This little guy has so much heart the reader can't help but love him. While this is a middle-grade novel, it's perfectly suited for any age. In fact, I would urge teens and adults to read it. It's powerful, well-written and has a message for all of us. I will be very surprised if this book doesn't win a few awards this year. 
 (Review based on an Advanced Reader's Copy courtesy of the publisher via NetGalley)
Best middle grade book I have read all year! A must read for middle school and YA readers.

Our book club selection this week. What a great story! Actually, several great stories when you think about it. 
 Auggie is a 5th grader who tries to believe he's normal. But, he has extreme facial deformities from a genetic condition and he's been home schooled until now. So, there's the story about trying to fit in when everyone can't help but stare at you. Then, there's the story of just growing up and trying to fit in as a kid. 
 The different first person perspectives from the different children helped flesh out the story. Not only did I feel for, and like, Auggie a lot, I sympathized with his older sister, Olivia. It's not easy being the other sibling when your brother has been through countless surgeries and therapies. 
 Fair warning, if you're like me and cry while reading, you will cry more than once. In fact, I found myself nearly sobbing at one point.

My 5th graders were begging me to read this book because they LOVED it. And I had been reluctant at first because after teaching middle school for over 10 years, I thought it wouldn't hold my interest like a YA or Teen would. 
 I was wrong!! 
 I LOVED this book! I liked how the point of view would change to the different characters. It was nice to see what the other characters were feeling. 
 I would recommend this book to anyone who is looking for a wholesome realistic fiction. My own child read this and loved it too, and he's a boy!
I loved the story of August and the courage he displayed throughout different events in his journey. A must read for all. It should also be added to upper elementary teacher's read aloud lists.

Being a teacher this book hit straight at my heart strings. Such a sweet yet sad story with real events that can make u want to reach out and hug every child that had ever been bullied. I had tears in my eyes at the end but they were tears of happiness! definitely recommend this quick read if u love children!

THIS REVIEW IS IN FRENCH AND IN ENGLISH. 
 EN : Well this book was beautiful. 
 It's a realistic, sweet and sad look into being unique, not looking like other people and how you and the people surrounding you live with it. It is a reminder that this world is full of mean people, people who bully and make fun; but that it is also full of amazing people who love life and love people and make living a difficult life so much better. 
 I loved every single character. 
 It was great to see not just Auggie's POV but also his friends' and family's. And I just loved every single one of them. If I could hug them all I would. 
 I think I'll just hug it after I've wiped all my tears away. 
 FR : Magnifique. 
 C'est un livre realiste, adorable et triste a la fois, qui montre ce que c'est d'etre unique, different des autres, comment on est notre famille le vit. C'est un rappel que le monde est rempli de personnes horribles, mais qu'il est aussi rempli de personnes merveilleuses qui rendent vivre une vie difficile, tellement plus simple. 
 J'ai adore absolument tous les personnages. C'etait super de ne pas seulement voir le point de vue de Auggie mais aussi de sa famille et ses amis. Et j'ai craque pour chacun des personnages. Si je pouvais tous les embrasser je le ferai. 
 Je crois d'ailleurs que je vais prendre un moment pour faire un calin au livre, une fois que j'aurai fini de pleurer.

I love this book. August was born with a deformed face. He has a loving and supportive family that home schools him til the 5th grade. Then his parents decide he can now longer keep learning all he needs at home so he goes to public school. This book was very real for me. It shows the awful cruelty we are capable of but also the love we are capable of and the beauty of the human spirit. A tear jerk-er and a must read. I would recommend to boys and girls 4th grade and up.
A wonderful book about a young boy who has a face deformity and how he is treated by people.

4.5 
 I could relate to so many things in this story. 
 It was heart breaking and heart warming, beautiful and inspirational. I loved it! 
 Sometimes the switch in characters threw me off, which is the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars. Fantastic book.
This was one of the best books I read this year. Funny, sad and "wonder"ful.
I devoured this book. It made me laugh and cry and gave me faith in humanity. The friend who told me I must read it was right, I'll be telling others the same.

This is a sweet novel about being different and how it can be both good and bad. As a book, I think it's pretty great! Augie's relationships with his friends and his sister are touching and interesting. The multiple POVs are sometimes too much. Summer and Olivia's chapters are especially great, although characters like Justin didn't need points of view here. To some degree, I think I would have enjoyed this ten thousand times more if I hadn't read it in middle school with a not-so-awesome english teacher. 
 Unfortunately, some of the issues are glossed over to a point where the novel loses its emotional heart. The book is too happy. The ending felt unearned, and moments of darkness feel out of place. For example, and this is a BIG spoiler, the dog dies and it's glossed over. 
 There's something about the message of the book that doesn't totally gel for me. It's not a negative message, per se, but it's not totally accurate either. This review says it better than I ever could. Books like Out Of My Mind by Sharon Draper focus on the fact that people who are different just want to be treated like people. And I'm not entirely convinced that any of these characters, besides maybe Summer and Olivia, treat Augie like a human being. In the end, he's still considered romantically unappealing and someone to be pitied by something like half their school. I'm not sure this is what the author was going for, but because of his classmates' dehumanizing behavior, Augie's happy ending rang slightly false to me. Obviously not all disabled people think the same, but it definitely contradicts with my thought process and at least a few reviewer's as well. 
 I still enjoyed the book, though, and I think many will.
Excellent book. The story of a 5th grade boy with a facial deformity, told from his perspective and that of some of his peers.

Read this in 1 1/2 days and promptly gave to my 9 year old to read. Excellent book. I think I've seen a few people that believe this should be required reading in school, wholeheartedly agree. Loved the different points of view!
this is not a surprising book, but its cliches still give wonders.

If you have kids in the 8 - 11 range YOU MUST READ THIS BOOK and so should they. I finally got around to reading this after my kids kept putting it on the top of my pile by my bed. I can't believe it took me so long. And we had the best discussions about it. 
 This book addresses so many tween/middle school social concerns in such an engaging way and I fell in love, not just with the main character, August, but so many of his friends, teachers, parents. And I sobbed at the end. Sigh. Such a good read.

"They just feel it. You don't need your eyes to love, right?" 
 I regret not reading this sooner. 
 Wonder is such a beautiful story. A story about appearances, first impressions, and the effect that one person can have on everyone around them. 
 "Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 I loved that the book changed perspective as much as it did. It showed so well how there is more than one side to a story. One person's point of view isn't the only one. It's a book that can change your perspective. 
 We all have a tendency to judge others based on their appearance. Do we let ourselves look past that to see the person? 
 The characters were all so sweet and I loved them all. They all had more to them than meets the eye, which is usually the case. It showed very well that, "sometimes you don't have to be mean to hurt someone." 
 This book is very quotable. 
 I don't really want to say much about this book. I would rather see people read it for themselves. It's worth it. I definitely think that this is a story that everyone could benefit from. 
 "the universe takes care of all its birds."
Perspective at it's best! My precept : honesty will carry you further. This book is a realistic view of life whether you are young or mature. Thanks R.J.Palacio.
Absolutely BRILLIANT!!! I cried hard, and I fell in love with the characters. Completely flawless, beautifully written. A real treasure!
This is one of the most amazing books I have ever read. I think everyone should read it!

A really lovely read, one that all parents should introduce their children to. Augie was just adorable as was Jack and Summer. Kids can be cruel but as this story depicts they can be kind and considerate too. It is all about their upbringing. If people could love each other as dogs love people, the world would be a better place.
My English teacher and my brothers friend who's 9 years old both recommended this to me so it really is a great book for everyone!

Amazing. I laughed, cried, and would have cheered out loud if I hadn't been holding a sleeping baby. The characters are all very believable, and it was easy to root for them. I really liked getting the perspectives of multiple characters, especially all their different perspectives on Auggie's family.

I enjoyed the book and would recommend it to more mature third grade readers. Not all elementary aged students will share the value in the struggles described in the story and be able to understand them. Most kids have not been exposed to this type of physical deformity. Possibly one of the best books of the best books of the year. I love this book for so many reasons. The writing is excellence. The characters are genuine and reflective. The story is believable and meaningful. This book is meant to be shared with kids and adults alike! An amazing journey that will leave you wanting to read it again!
I cried! Heartwarming book.

This review, and many more, can be found on my blog, The Baking Bookworm (www.thebakingbookworm.blogspot.ca). 
 My Thoughts: Often times when a book is so critically acclaimed I'm a little hesitant to pick it up because more often than not the book just doesn't live up to the hype created around it. Yes, I've become a little cynical in my reading. 
 This is not the case with Wonder. Not by a long shot. 
 In fact two words that I initially wrote down after reading the first few chapters of this book were: 'touching and emotional'. It's because of the emotion and message behind this book that I'm so excited to share it with you. 
 First of all, I'm shocked and more than a little impressed that this book was written by a first time author. I think that a huge part of the success of this book is that Palacio has given Auggie (and the five other people who provide the narration) truly authentic and believable voices. 
 Auggie is an inspiring, funny and strong main character who will definitely stay with me for a long time. Palacio has created a sympathetic main character in Auggie who is a normal Star Wars loving boy with an extraordinary face who you can't help but root for. He's got a great support system at home which has instilled a strong sense of self and he uses his humour to deal with other people's issues with his face. He is exceptional in that he feels normal even though other people have more of an issue with his face. 
 "I know I'm not an ordinary ten-year-old kid. I mean, sure, I do ordinary things. I eat ice cream. I ride my bike. I play ball. I have an XBox. Stuff like that makes me ordinary, I guess. And I feel ordinary. Inside. 
 But I know ordinary kids don't make other ordinary kids run away screaming in playgrounds. I know ordinary kids don't get stared at wherever they go. If I found a magic lamp and I could have one wish, I would wish that I had a normal face that no one ever noticed at all. I would wish I could walk down the street without people seeing me and then doing that look-away thing. 
 Here's what I think: the only reason I'm not ordinary is that no one else sees me that way." 
 This book could very easily do a tailspin into a very woeful read about bullying. Sure it has it's emotional moments but it doesn't have a generally sad feel to it. It's actually a very uplifting read and has a much more simplistic and innocent approach to it that I wasn't expecting. If you're looking for a gritty account of what life is like living with a severe facial deformity then this won't be the book for you. 
 While there is a strong moral message in the book it never felt like Palacio was pontificating or shoving the moral down the reader's throat. It's a simple lesson: be kinder than you have to. I would hope that we all realize that we should be nice to everyone (even if we don't do it enough) but this book clearly shows the reader that the negative effects of 'looking away' or pretending we don't notice someone with a noticeable deformity is just as damaging as saying a mean statement. It was an emotional read at times (I even shed a tear or two!) but never had a saccharine or overdone feel to it. 
 It's because of the moral message that I think that this book should be read by middle school kids. I honestly think everyone should read it but kids in middle school would get the most out of it because I think it accurately portrays the effects of bullying, of ignoring someone based on their looks and shows how little it takes to just be a friend and uplift someone. To do what is right, not necessarily what is the easiest, or what others think you should do. Those are some pretty big lessons that I think ALL of us need to learn or get a refresher course on. 
 Overall I truly loved this book. I was fully emersed in Auggie's world from the beginning to the end and found it to be a very touching read. The story is told by these six characters with the use of short chapters that really helped to keep the pace moving. But what really stood out with me is the ease and success that Palacio had using various points of view -- Auggie and FIVE others -- to tell the story. This could have been a literary train wreck with the number of POVs but it was done extremely well giving the reader insight into those around Auggie and how he and they experienced things differently. 
 I especially loved his sister, Via's, point of view and her conflicting feelings towards her brother and all of the attention he gets from their parents. She adores her brother but the effects of his facial deformity, his numerous surgeries and how others react to him greatly influences her life. Palacio also shows how other people in Auggie's life, namely Jack and Summer, deal with other insensitive and downright cruel people who judge them for hanging out with Auggie. 
 I did have a couple of small criticisms about the book. One thing that did strike me as not quite right were the language and issues that these Grade 5 kids had to deal with. As a mom to kids in Grade 4, 6 and 8 I'd like to think that I have a handle on the voice and development of tweens. Based on that experience with my Small Humans I think that the social issues that were dealt with in the book are more in middle school (Grades 6-8) than in an elementary school setting. I don't think that Grade 5 students are nearly as developmentally advanced as Jack, Auggie, Summer etc were portrayed in the book. I think having the kids be in Grade 7 would have been a more realistic age where they would have experienced the peer and social pressures dealt with in this book. 
 My other issue with the book is that perhaps because it had a lighter feel to it the ending was also more uplifting and a little too tidy for my liking. The 'bad guy' got his comeuppance and the good guys all rode off into the sunset. These are small beefs about the book (wee 'moos', if you like) but they were noticeable and may bother some readers who were hoping for an edgy ending. 
 Overall, I loved this book and found Wonder to be truly wonderful. I adore the moral of the book that encourages people 'to be kinder than necessary' and that people have not only 'the capacity to be kind, but the very choice of kindness'. Hopefully, after reading this book people will choose to be more respectful and kinder to others even when it's not convenient for them or when it makes them feel uncomfortable. To give others dignity. Imagine the kind of world we'd have if we all did that. 
 "Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. 
 One should be kinder than needed." 
 Highly recommended. 
 My Rating: 4.5/5 stars

I know that it's only May but this book is a contender for the best book of 2012. It is heartbreaking and I winced turning every page until I got to around page 70something. Then it becomes hopeful. Everyone should read this book.

I don't remember the last time I stayed up until 12:30 in the morning to finish a book. Most nights I crash on the couch at 9:00. But this book kept me going well into he night. The characters, who all have their own realities hidden under their appearances, are complex and real. The deceptively simple idea of kindness and courage provides for emotional and beautiful storytelling. This book, quite frankly, makes me want to be a better person.
I'm making this one required reading in my family. So many great topics for discussion with my kids!

"Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 I really wasn't expecting to love this book so much. I found myself being quickly swept up into the emotions of all the characters and ending had me smiling with tears in my eyes. This book taught a very powerful lesson though the eyes of ten year olds, which is really saying something about the author's writing skills. Wonder will be one of only a handful of books that the lessons it taught will go with me & really has left a lasting impression. I hope to always remember how important it is to be kinder than is necessary .

This book is truly spectacular. You really get attached to the characters: August, Olivia, Summer, Jack, the parents... This book really takes you into their minds and emotions. The story itself really takes you into this family, as well, and you really start to feel as if August is part of your own. I read it very quickly over the course of 2 days. I just couldn't put this book down. I highly recommend this book to anybody, though beware that you may get teary at times.

EVERYONE, YOUNG AND OLD SHOULD READ THIS BOOK. One of the best books ever written, told in such a sweet, utterly easy to relate to, and honest way. For anyone who has ever had trouble with self confidence, friends, bullies, fitting in at school, or coming to grips with you are. You can't help but cheer for Auggie every step of the way, and sometimes see yourself in his shoes. 
 Maybe have tissues ready, as this book will tug at your heart strings. Bittersweet and wonderful.

Just... wonderfull!

This was so beautiful and heart warming. Absolutely a must read.

"Thank you, Auggie," She answered softly. 
 "For what?" 
 "For everything you've given us," she said. "For coming in to our lives. For being you." 
 She bent down and whispered in my ear. "You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder." 
 My favourite read of the year, so beautiful! :)

This book is not only for kids but for adults as well since kindness is a lesson that should be reminded every single day. I don't know where to start on reviewing this book since there are so many details that warm my heart and soul. Despite their shortcomings, each characters shine in their own ways and make me believe in a world where there is still kindness and courage in tiny little details. I cried a little at the last scene of the graduation ceremony as it felt so rewarding and satisfactory for Auggie just like what he said in his precept.
I am overwhelmed by how much I LOVED this book! It was funny, sad, and so well written. It is impossible not to be touched by this book. I think it should definetly be this years Newbery Winner!
The best higher elementary book I've read since Esperanza Rising.
Every student needs to read this book!!! This has to be one of my favorite books, and I will be reading it next year to my classes!
This is so sweet.

This book was perfect for what it was and completely heartwarming without being sappy. The 5th grade graduation at the end brought me to tears, and I loved what the principal said, because I truly believe that small acts of good can overwhelm the world: 
 "If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God."

August Pullman has never gone to a real school before when his parents enroll him in the fifth grade at Beecher Prep Middle School. Because of his rare and severe facial deformity, his parents have always home schooled him. August has a lot of anxiety about starting school with other kids. What if they all stare at him? What if he doesn't make any friends? Wonder follows Auggie's first year of middle school, with all its ups and downs. It is a funny and heartwarming novel about overcoming fears and making true friends. 
 I read this book very quickly, and I suspect a lot of kids will as well. Auggie's story is pretty unique, but middle school-aged readers will relate to the story. Even for "normal" kids, Auggie's awkward, stressful, and transitional middle school experience is pretty universal. I found myself reflecting on my time in middle school while reading this book. The characters and dialogue in this book very realistic. Kids and adults will take away a lot of ideas and lessons from this entertaining novel.
wonder is WONDERFUL

It was a "Wonder" of a book. Definitely a book whose messages are loud and clear: " Don't judge a boy by his face"- get to know someone before you decide if you like them or not. Strive to be who you are meant to be; strive to always be kind. A nice, heartwarming book-yes for middle graders but we can all learn from this book!

I liked it and I think it has high appeal (especially for school and classroom settings), but I had some problems with the execution. Definitely worth a read. This is a special book that already has people talking. More coming on the blog.
Wonderful book!
Highly recommend this touching story of courage, friendship and family. I don't want to give any of the story away but encourage all to read Wonder.

Absolutely loved this book! Seriously, could not put it down. The character this book is centered on is a great narrator, but you also get the point of view of other characters in the story. These are great characters, and this is a pretty awesome first novel by the writer. I look forward to more.

I loved this book so much! I think everyone should read this book to be reminded of what matters most in life.Lessons I learned from this book were: Be kind to everyone no matter what they look like, Everyone needs a friend; even people that may be different, I really need to watch Star wars again, and always stand up for those you care about.

"I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 I'm very confused because I've read this like 5 times and haven't marked it as read???? And also it's my favorite book ever???? 
 This book was enchanting and eye-opening. It changed the way that I see the world, and I love when books do that to me. I think that everyone should read this, either old or young. 
 Wonderful.

Pense que este libro era mas dramatico, porque a decir verdad el tema que trata daria para todo un dramon. Pero lo mejor es que de eso no se trata este libro, mas bien se centra en el impacto que tiene August en la vida de quienes lo conocen. Y el impacto que tiene las reacciones de los demas en la vida de August. Me encontre con una lectura sencilla pero muy rica en ensenanzas, es de esas lecturas que desearias fuera obligatoria en todos los colegios. 
 Y hablando de impactos, creo que es una lectura que tiene un impacto positivo en todos aquellos que la leen. August tiene un efecto positivo en los lectores por su manera de ver las cosas y el buen humor con que afronta todo. A pesar de que hay momentos dificiles, su familia y amigos le dan la fortaleza para afrontarlos. Es una lectura que nos ensena a no tratar diferente a aquellos que no son iguales que nosotros y a tomar siempre la decision de ser amables. Ser amables no nos cuesta nada pero puede hacer una gran diferencia en los demas. 
 Me encanto que no solo podemos ver la historia desde el punto de vista de August, tambien podemos ver capitulos narrados por su hermana y sus amigos. Es ahi donde conocemos como ven los demas a August, que sienten respecto a el y por que deciden ser sus amigos cuando nadie mas quiere serlo. Lo que mas me gusto es poder leer como un nino que puede ser rechazado tan facilmente, tiene una influencia tan bonita en aquellos que lo conocen bien. Y aquellos que evitan compartir con August solo por ser "deforme" nunca conoceran los buenos y bellos sentimientos que tiene. 
 Una historia conmovedora, que tiene un ultimo mensaje: ser amables. En realidad August no es el del problema, son los demas. El es solo un nino como cualquier otro, con la particularidad de tener un rostro diferente. Es un nino hermoso, valiente, sensible, ama a su familia, valora a sus amigos, es AMABLE, aunque los demas no lo sean con el. 
 Yo de verdad empezare a recomendar este libro a todo el mundo, grandes y pequenos, empezando por ustedes. Todos pueden sacar de el un mensaje muy positivo que incluso puede cambiar totalmente la forma en que ven las cosas. A mi me paso. El final de este libro es hermoso, lleno de conjeturas que no hacen sino ensenarte lo valiosas que son esas personas que han llegado a este mundo luciendo diferente o con alguna enfermedad en particular, el verdadero sentido de "Wonder" o "Maravilla". Si todos tomaramos la decision de ser amables, no existiria tanta intolerancia, rechazo y discriminacion. Nadie es mejor que nadie, mucho menos por la forma en que se ve fisicamente. 
 Wonder es de esos libros que tienen un significado claro. Vale mucho la pena conocer a August, el hacerlo te permitira descubrir un poco mas de ti mismo. Si te gustan las historias que te dejan algo, este definitivamente es tu libro.
Full review later.
I loved this book! So touching and lovely.

Genre: Realistic fiction 
 Plot: Auggie has multiple physical disorders that make him look different from the other children. After many corrective surgeries, he's finally healthy enough to attend middle school with other children. The book follows this transition, from friends who support him to bullies that do not. The book switches view from person to person, emphasizing a need for empathy and understanding. The eBook of Julian's POV is worth checking out (my version had it included, and it sheds an interesting light on the story). 
 Reader's Advisory: Death, bullying 
 Recommended Age: 9-12

I read the updated edition with the added "Julian" section, which has a wonderful story told by Julian's Grandmother. So worth reading the new edition! This book should be mandatory reading for middle school kids, and, really, for all of us!

I rather enjoyed this book. Even though there were a lot of pov changes, they made sense in the book and I could wait to get to a new person each time. I love the theme of kindness in this book as well. I feel like you really got different perspectives in this book. What I appreciate about it is that when one person struggles like August, really there are people connected to him with their struggles. Seeing their different strengths come out in the face of relentless persecution can be uplifting.

I listened to this while working and driving. I cannot recommend this enough, particularly for middle grade aged readers. A young boy with a severely deformed face, who has been taught at home, enters a private middle grade school for the first time. There are so many lessons here. Number one is that most of us, especially kids, just don't know how to talk to, approach, or treat someone who looks so different. The book is about friendship, hardship, courage, bullying, adolescent misunderstandings, and ultimately hope and love.
The Best.
This was a moving book about the power of kindness and the impact we have upon others. A great book for demonstrating point of view.
I like the characterization of the book above all. Yet I'm not satisfied of the lack of proper climax. Totes gonna recommend to people. Palacio made a heartwarming tale of it's own kind.

I picked this up and looked at it when I was processing new books at the library, and accidentally got sucked right into the story. I was five pages in before I even realized I was reading it. But I'm reading a bunch of other books right now, so I got the audio version. And I didn't want to get out of my car when I got home. So good! I'm only ten minutes into it so far, but at dinner I had to tell my family about the part I listened to already.
This book broke my heart. I cried all the way through it. I just wanted to hug and protect Auggie all the time. Everyone needs to read this. It'll really put things into perspective.

The book tells the story of Auggie, a boy born with extreme facial deformities. Auggie has been home schooled his entire life, but his parents decide the time is right for him to attend school with his peers. While the book is Auggie's story, it is also the story of all of the people who are part of his life. I LOVED this book and can't wait for the movie in April!!

I suggested this book to Cooper after seeing it on Twitter with the recommendation that "every 5th grader should read this book." After finishing, I think that every PERSON should read it. I loved the different perspectives and how it made me re-think my own actions as a teacher, mother, and friend. Wonderful book.

I liked it but it wasn't that amazing. 
 "My name is August. 
 I won't describe what I look like. 
 Whatever you're thinking, 
 it's probably worse" 
 Ok, it's about a boy called August Pullman and he has a disfigured face. It's his first time going to school after being home-schooled and he hates it because everyone avoids him because of his face and he's trying to make friends but it's not working because nobody wants to look at him because of his face. 
 Interesting book but not what I normally like to read. I know I rated it 4 stars, so it seems as if I really like the book, but to be honest it's not too amazing. 
 "When he was a baby, the doctors didn't think he'd live" 
 CHARACTERS: 
 August: Gets grumpy a lot and doesn't like his face. 
 Olivia: Doesn't like people staring at August's face. 
 Summer: Doesn't care how August and is very friendly. 
 Jack: Likes August, thinks he's a good friend. 
 Miranda: Worries about friendship with Olivia and adores August. 
 R.J. Palacio 
 NICKNAMES FOR THE CHARACTERS: 
 Olivia-Via 
 August-Auggie 
 Wonder

I decided to read this aloud to my 9 year old, just to relive those night time shared reading sessions. We are both enjoying our reading time with giggles and questions about what might happen. We are still in the very beginning stages and wondering.... 
 Well, now not so many giggles as we have moved on to more serious things. I love this book and my son will not let me skip a night reading, so I would say he is enjoying it just as much.... 
 This is a great book for middle grades. The message of kindness is one our kids should visit in this day of bullying. Highly recommend!
mock Newbery lists

How do you handle life when you are so very different from everyone around you? How do you handle your peers constantly bullying, making fun, or worse ignoring you completely, especially if you are in middle school? This award winning novel asks these questions and more, done in short chapters and a readable writing style. Palacio wants to make her readers feel uncomfortable and question their own behavior when faced with unique/different people. She accomplishes this easily and makes this book a great conversation starter with any age.

I read this book in part as a recommendation and in part because of all the buzz there has been around it in kidlit circles. I think it is good, but I think that the level of both the writing and the voices of the characters is older than I had been led to believe. I would be comfortable with it for middle schoolers (say, 7th graders), but I think that it is too difficult in language for much younger than that.
I read this book for school and I loved it. 100% recommend
I laughed, I cried. What a beautiful book!

4.5/5 stars 
 Wow I really love Auggie, his family, and friends :')
This was such a beautiful book. I'm at a loss of words. Easily one of the best books I've ever read.
amazing book. really enjoyed reading it. looking forward to seeing the movie.

This is a really good read and a great book for young people. It's hard to find something about the book that I didn't like. It has won several awards and rightly so! It's an easy read for middle school-aged students. It is very approachable, and not heavy-handed or preachy with the subject matter. 
 The main character is August, a boy who has always been home-schooled but who enters school in the fifth grade. While that would be enough of a meaty plot, August has severe facial deformities due to a genetic condition. Some description of this is given but, August, like the rest of us, seems to be his own worst critic. 
 The book is told from alternating points of view and this makes the story so much richer. (Dear teachers, this would be a great point-of-view lesson having certain groups read only one character.) I though Auggie's sister's (Vi's) chapters were the most powerful, but I really loved how all the different character's point of views painted a whole picture of August and his situation. I love that Palacio didn't pity her character or cut him any breaks. The brutality of the story made it seem more fair. 
 It is a book for either a boy or girl of any age. It has a universal appeal even though it's a situation not many can connect with, at least not initially The story shows the very best of childhood innocence and forgiveness. This story is also about the important topics of bullying and being a true friend, but also about acceptance, kindness and humanity. It's about looking beyond our own concept of outward beauty to see the true beauty within.
This was terrific! I loved the quote in this book, quoting by J. M. Barrie - "be kinder than necessary."

It is time to write a review. 
 I read this book with no proper knowledge what to expect. I think that's the reason why I enjoyed this book so much. There was barley any info, so you have no choice other than to let yourself be surprised what story Palacio wants to tell. 
 The minute Auggie came into the picture and described how his every day life looked like, I was smitten. Sad, of course but eager to know more. And I got more. I got an insight into Auggies life, how he struggles and survives. How everyone around him reacts or handles what happened to him. Different point of views offered different kind of opinions. 
 And I was surprised how relatable they all were. My sister used to have a friend in primary school who had similar issues. She was a wonder, too. And I remember how insecure she was around us and how insecure I was. It was hard but once you saw through that "wonder" (I don't want to give any spoilers away so I just use this word) and really get to know this person there isn't really much to be insecure about. Every human looks different. Some more some less. That doesn't make them any less human. At the end of the day it doesn't matter how one looks. Because looks won't bond people. Looks can be deceiving. The way someone looks is like holding a colourful box. What really matters is the content in this box. And don't we all want to see, what's inside this box?

I had heard great things about this book, and I think that my expectations were too high. Auggie is a great central character, but I wish that they had stuck with his perspective, none of the other voices were as compelling to me. 
 Side note: Why is Julia Roberts playing the mom in the upcoming film? Don't get me wrong I like her, but this character is Brazilian! Thanks for the whitewashing Hollywood.
A beautiful story of courage and strength. Shows the value of kindness and the importance of standing up for what's right. Cried tears of sadness and then tears of joy.
I loved the different POV's, and how the author managed to make everyone's voice sound so different from one another!
Yeah, I know it took me a while to finish this, but it's not related to the book's content, it was certainly beautiful.

"Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a hard battle." 
 "Always try to be a little kinder than is necessary." 
 "It's not enough to be friendly. You have to be a friend." 
 Wow. Such an insightful read. 
 I have read a lot of books with multiple POVs but I have never liked or read a better one. There was so much that was gleaned just because we were given a peep into the heads of all these different characters. 
 This wasn't a book that kept me up late into the night reading, no it wasn't unputdownable or thrilling . It did not have a well crafted story that provided intrigue, No, it wasn't any of those things. It was a simple story about the everyday simple things that happened in the life of a simple boy. An Ordinary boy. I do believe that more than anything else this is the thrust of this book, to see and treat everyone around you as ordinary and normal. We sometimes forget and take it for granted how being just like everyone else could be a luxury. 
 Developing Kindness, understanding and perspective is what this book is all about. A story that might not have had me racing through the book just to know what would happen but one that would definitely stay with me for a long long time. 
 The chapters from Via and Jack's perspective were my favorite. And even though I wasn't a fan of the Julian chapter it is something that everyone should read, the end would be worth it. 
 You could love someone and yet at times be selfish and not like them for who they are, it did not make you evil it just made you human. And so long as you can pull through, hang on to the love and kindness you would be fine. 
 Wonder and Auggie will stay with me, for sure and whenever I see someone like Auggie I would remember to treat them just like I would treat anyone else. 
 An insanely important lesson, in a surprisingly simple way... What more could you ask from a book?

I read this with my Grade 5 class - normally it takes us about a term to read through a 200 page novel. This 300+ pages took us less than 4 weeks! We couldn't put it down - I bought the ebook as well and had it up on whiteboard so the kids could read along, and it prompted so many amazing class discussions. We've used the example of August and his friends, and also of Julian, both in whole class chats as well as when addressing individual student conflicts. When we finished the book they even all wrote their own precepts! 
 Highly recommend for any Grade 5 class :)
Great book, that made me smile, laugh, cry, and hate people, that did'nt exist. Great and wonderful book
This was a wonderful book and should be required reading for Children and adults alike. So happy it was recommended to our book club!
Yes it is that good. Buy a copy of this book, read it, and then loan it out to as many people as possible.

This book was a very easy and quick read. I don't think it was written very well, but I enjoyed it. I keep going back and forth between whether I think it deserves two or three stars. 
 It's hard to imagine what it must be like to live with a deformity that everyone can see. I thought Palacio did a great job to try and get the reader to see what it's like for family and friends who have someone in their lives with an obvious deformity.

I read this with my 10 year old son and he about cried when it was over. Not because the ending was sad, but because he was sad it was over, and he was going to miss these characters. He initiated every moment of reading this book. Whenever we had a free moment, he wanted to read it. This story has so many teachable moments and life lessons. I enjoyed it just as much as he did. I highly recommend reading this with your child.
A very very touching story. :')

Really, 4.5 stars. The .5 loss comes from the perfectly happy ending. Probably perfect for the intended age group, but a little too perfect to my jaded mind. I do highly recommend it for kids in late grade school and middle school.
Outstanding! Loved every bit of this book. Appropriate for kids. Great story about the power of kindness.

Such an amazing book. Definitely a book worth reading for any age group, even though it is technically a young adult book. Everybody can learn something from reading this. The last two hours I was reading it, tears were spilling down my face. There was a paragraph that really spoke to me, "I wasn't really sure why I was getting this medal, really. No that's not true. I knew why. It's like people you see sometimes, and you can't imagine what it would be like to be that person, weather it's somebody in a wheelchair or somebody who can't talk. Only, I know that I'm that person to other people, maybe to every single person in that auditorium. To me, though, I'm just me. An ordinary kid. "
I loved this book and I really hope it never gets optioned to become a film. The reader must conjure his or her own image of Auggie's face and I think Hollywood would get it totally wrong.

This book was recommended to me by my 10 year old daughter! I'm so glad she did, it's a beautiful heartfelt story, which reminds you how harsh & kind life can be. 
 dY~S

Ok so this book was required reading in 5th grade. I was expecting not to like it because usually when books are assigned to me I feel like I enjoy them less. This book was not a disappointment. This book has honestly changed the way I think. It has taught me so much on how we don't know what's going on in the minds of those we judge. This is one of those books that have stuck with me and I feel like will stick with me forever. I recommend for everyone to at least try to read this. Xoxo-Dani

A book about a boy with a severely deformed face who starts attending school for the first time in fifth grade could easily be a heavy handed anti-bullying platform. This book is much more nuanced than that. I enjoyed the varying POV that changed from chapter to chapter. I ached and rejoiced with Auggie without feeling manipulated. None of the characters were completely good or bad, but were treated with a subtlety that reflects actual people. The underlying theme is: be kinder than is necessary. 
 I will definitely urge my children to read this one. Highly recommended.

Amazing story. I especially enjoyed the way each of the characters spoke in different sections of the book about the same events. Remarkably perceptive to explain the feelings of all the main characters. Selected for the Texas Bluebonnet Award Master List 2013-2014. Truly worthy of recognition.

This is a really quick, easy read. It was so enjoyable that I didn't want it to end. If you have children, you should have them read it. There are lots of life lessons for them to learn. Be kind to one another!

Enjoyed the novel overall. Would have liked the ending to be a bit messier/unpredictable. Nonetheless, had several uplifting, readable, and insightful moments.
One of the best books of this summer! If you have a heart and you teach tweens you need to read this book. I cried twice but I bet some people will cry more reading this story.
The sweetest,ost heartwarming book I have read in a long while!!Video review soon!

**spoiler alert** 
 I wanted to like this book more than I did. I suppose I was hoping it was more like "Anything But Typical" by Nora Baskin, but it read a little more like "Stargirl" by Jerry Spinelli with a touch of "The Fourth Stall." 
 I didn't like the ending. 
 When we meet August (Auggie) Pullman at the start, he tells us his mama's story of his birth - the hospital doctor fainted at the sight of him, but a large "farting" nurse whispers into his mother's ear, "Everyone born of God overcometh the world," and she yells at the doctor, flat on the floor, "What kind of doctor are you? Get up! Get up!" and her last fart wakes the doctor up. 
 Auggie was born with severe facial deformities and has had 28 surgeries up until his current age of 10 years old. But... "My mother is pretty. My father is handsome. My sister is beautiful. IN case you were wondering." He states. 
 Auggie's parents decide to take him out of homeschool and put him in 5th grade at Beecher Prep, a private Manhattan school, mostly because Auggie is smart and his surgeries are not precluding him from attending school anymore. 
 On his orientation day, Principal Mr. Tushman assigns 3 kids to take Auggie around the building - a girl and 2 boys, Jack Will and Julian Albans. Julian turns out to be a phony, but Jack Will seems to be a genuine friend, sitting next to Auggie in every class and joking with him. On Halloween, however, Auggie was supposed to arrive at school dressed as Jenga Fett. A last minute change of mind causes him to arrive as a "Bleeding Scream" and so no one sees him when he enters homeroom, and he overhears Jack talking to some other boys, saying "If I looked like {Auggie} I think I'd kill myself." Auggie rushes out of the room and goes home. 
 The friendship is eventually healed and the climax of the story comes at the fifth grade camping trip. The kids go to an outdoor screening of "The Sound of Music" at night, and Jack and Auggie go to find the restroom. With the line being unbelievably long, they head to the woods, where they are discovered by 7th grade bullies from another school. A fight ensues, and some of Auggie's classmates defend him, and the book ends with Auggie being applauded at the 5th grade graduation ceremony (5th grade graduation ceremony???) and receiving the award for best character. 
 Slightly suggestive material - his sister Olivia's boyfriend kisses her twice, and boys mention a girl being "hot."
Excellent excellent book! Would recommend it and especially perfect for middle school readers
Great book! Go Auggie!

For those who've ever had the desire to fit in: Auggie is a sweet ten-year-old boy who was born with distorted facial features due to an anomaly in his DNA. The book opens as he enters a mainstream school for the first time. He doesn't describe his face because, "Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." Auggie wants to convince his new classmates that he's an ordinary kid, just like them. Easy to say, much harder to do. 
 If the grounding point of the story is Auggie's parents, who are warm and loving, then the heart of the story is Auggie's classmates, who are portrayed with such convincing realism, I figured the author must have a child that age at home. Bringing to life a bunch of fifth graders who have distinct personalities takes a lot of skill. (Also easy to say, much harder to do.) 
 I loved this interview with the author at NPR's All Things Considered. http://www.npr.org/2013/09/12/2210057...
http://sophiawhitfield.blogspot.com.a...
An instant 5-stars-read. I love how the story is told not only with Auggie's voice, but we can also see what's inside the head of people whose paths intersect with him and are moved by him.
I love this but I think it showed how much the characters are human and it also gives you a really good idea what it's like to be like Augie.

It's nice to know that there are really 'kind' people still living around when we're in a world full of people not worth trusting (don't take it personally, it's just a saying). 
 Unrelated: 
 "You are a wonder." - last sentence of the book. I've heard this sentence being told to many, including myself. After reading this book I guess I figured out what it means. 
 I'm happy that I got the chance to read this book and I'll make sure to "choose kind".

This book was really good, it showed what kinda reality is like in different perspectives in the book. Auggi is so inspirational, in the real world a lot of people are complaining about, how they look, Auggi has to deal with heaps more. This book make you think about others and not just the media or your self. Great book! I recommend it

In a nutshell: legitimately one of the best books I have ever read in my entire life. It will quietly, and maybe without you realizing it, change your life. 
 Sometimes you read a book and it doesn't seem like it will be groundbreaking or revolutionary or life-changing, but it's one you pick up simply because it looks interesting. That's what this book was for me-it has a lot of hype and is being made into a movie, so I wanted to see what the fuss was about. Plus it's more of a children's book, so I was just expecting to pass the time with a nice story. I wasn't wrong, but I couldn't have been more wrong. 
 One of the best things about this book is that it isn't the story itself (though that was amazing). I don't have to risk spilling spoilers to tell you about the book. The plot is straightforward and uncomplicated, and that's part of its beauty. 
 It's the way the story is told that will have you turning the last page while shedding happy tears. The switch between points of view, while remaining mostly from August's, enhances the story just enough. You're going to easily, and possibly without even realizing, fall in love with Auggie and his entire family. You'll see yourself in Jack, possibly Julian, and hopefully Summer. 
 I can go on and on about the simple beauty and quietly perception-altering qualities of this book, but I'll refrain and just tell you this: This book has already changed how I treat others. Your life will be better for having read it.
Summer, Justin and that damn dog <3
This is awesome
Narrative was too young for me, had to read for grad class. Interesting read, though.
Wow. Oh wow.

When you don't know what to do, choose kindness. That is what this story teaches you and by you I don't just mean young people; adults should read this story too. I love that it's so much more than just Auggie's story, but is told from all sides and all perspectives. The voice in which Palacio writes is amazing! Each character is believable and important! 
 My only negative comment is that the students seem more advanced than 5th grade (speaking as a middle school teacher). And, I would have liked to read a chapter from one of the parent's POV. But other than that, I'm so happy I read this, especially right before school was starting. It reminded me that all my students are going through something and when you aren't sure how to reach them, just choose kindness. Choose kindness with everyone you come in contact with.
Reminiscent of Stargirl. Satisfying read.
Just finished reading this to John. Should be required reading for all kids.

I read this out loud to my son, and I was afraid it would be too much about feelings and not funny enough for him, but we both loved it. I wish every 4th-9th grader everywhere would read it and take it to heart. 
 August is 10, and he's always been home-schooled, partly because he's had lots of medical procedures in his life, and partly to shield him from stranger's reactions to his face, which is severely deformed due to a rare combination of birth defects. At the beginning of the book, his mother wants him to try going to middle school, which he is at first opposed to. but then bravely embraces. Narration of the book is shared between August and other characters, his sister and about six or seven other young characters in the story, which was a brilliant decision on the part of the author. As a reader, you get to watch a whole community emerge, and you watch that community start to accept and then largely embrace him, after a few bumps. It was lovely and inspiring, a book with a huge potential for saccharine that wound up dodging it almost completely. We laughed, we cried, we talked about it. My son is a pretty kind person, but with middle school ahead of him, I'm really glad he experienced this book, and you know, I can use a reminder about the importance of kindness and bravery myself.
What a heart warming book. My daughter and I read this together. Highly recommend!

"Wonder" ini salah satu novel yang belakangan nge-hits banget. Tokoh utamanya adalah August Pullman yang saat di kandungan mengalami mutasi gen, sehingga dia terlahir dalam kondisi berbeda dari orang-orang lain. Buku ini mengisahkan tentang bagaimana August harus menghadapi "dunia" dengan kondisinya yang berbeda. 
 "Wonder" ditulis dari beberapa sudut pandang. Ada sudut pandang August, Olivia (kakak August), Summer, Jack Will, Miranda, dan Justin. Saya paling suka cerita dari sudut pandang Olivia dan Jack Will, karena di situ terlihat bahwa setiap orang, sedekat apapun dan sebaik apapun, tetap punya kelemahan juga. 
 Buku ini tampaknya ditujukan untuk anak-anak atau remaja dewasa, jadi ya lebih banyak optimisnya ketimbang pesimisnya. Coba kalau ini untuk dewasa, kayaknya bakalan lebih banyak pesimisnya :p Karena keoptimisan yang terlalu berpendar-pendar itu *tsaaaah* saya kadang merasa buku ini "too good to be true." Tapi, mungkin memang ada yang semacam itu kali ya. 
 Oh iya, belakangan ini saya nyadar kalau hampir di tiap buku yang saya baca pasti ada tokoh guru yang menyenangkan. Kalau kemarin-kemarin di The Perks ada Mr.Anderson, lalu di Looking for Alaska ada Mr. Hyde, maka di Wonder, saya jatuh hati pada Mr.Browne dan monthly excerpts-nya. Semua guru tersebut membuat saya berharap saya pernah memiliki mereka di masa sekolah saya, yang sayangnya tidak :)

August is a great character. I like that we see him from his own, and others' points of views. 
 Maybe the ending is a tiny bit over-the-top, but I didn't mind too much. 
 Glad I read it.

Shvacam zasto jer ova knjiga osvojila svijet, moram priznati osvojila je i mene, procitala sam je u jednom danu. 
 Jedna od onih neodoljivo optimisticnih knjiga koje su tu da nas podsjete sto je zapravo vazno u zivotu i koliko smo mi kao ljudi zapravo povrsni i podlozni utjecaju drugih.
Wonderful! Every child should read this book.

I love children's novels because of their simplistic beauty - Wonder is no exception and was a profound exploration of how we- children, teens, and adults-handle and reconcile superficial differences with the human beneath the surface.
Yay kids getting along and loving each other

I read few books these days that really get under my skin, which is less a harsh comment on modern fiction and more to do with the fact that I buy old action thrillers from charity shops. Nevertheless, I'm looking to branch out and get my head into other things. I shall freely admit that I read Wonder and sobbed like a little girl. It's a pretty great book. This is all.

Wonder-ful. (see what I did there?) 
 I'm exceedingly jealous of my teacher friend who gets to go through this book with her sixth graders. 
 I closed the book feeling better about my fellow human than when I picked it up, and with the resolve to always try to be "a little kinder than is necessary." 
 It's an issue book. It has the beloved family pet and the kid with the facial deformity and a whole bunch of things that make some people think they know what this book is going to be like. 
 And maybe they're right, in some ways. But they are wrong in so many others. 
 Pick this book up, you won't regret it. 
 It was just amazing.

Children, teenagers, and adults will all enjoy this story. I thought I would be crying again and again throughout, but lucky for me it only happened once. This isn't a feel sorry for the underdog kind of read. It's a story that makes you realize how strong people can be. Sometimes we need some help and protection from other people, but sometimes we find that we are strong enough on our own to overcome any obstacle we put our mind to. 
 I listened to Wonder which had wonderful readers and couldn't get enough. While there are very low moments, there are highs as well - and the fact that everything that happens is totally possible, that makes it that much more touching. This is definitely a read that everyone can take something away from.
Maybe a little cutesy and saccharine toward the end, but a wholly worthwhile read.
How can u not reread this book over and over again?

I really loved this book! There were times I was cheering Auggie on, cringing because i knew what was about to happen to him, or crying right along with him. 
 At first I was a little turned off by the change in which character was telling the story, but I came to see that this gave a new perspective to a touching story. The only voice I felt was unnecessary was Justin's. I didn't think his narrative added to the story. I also disliked the shift in grammar that was used only for his character. 
 Overall, a wonderful read!

What an amazing book. I couldn't put it down! I love the insight into all the different characters.. you kind of walk away with the feeling that we all struggle at times and we're all in this together.

 I also host contests(not just for books, but fashion and makeup contests to!!!),hunt down freebies/discounts for my readers,do authors interviews, cover reveals and all sorts of other fun things.

August Pullman was born with a severe facial deformity and multiple health problems that resulted in his having 27 surgeries in his ten short years of life. They also led to his being home schooled for his grade school years. As he prepares for fifth grade his parents decide it is time for Auggie to face the world, but is the world ready for that face? The Pullmans have enrolled Auggie at Beecher Prep, a small, private middle school with a good reputation. The principal, Mr. Tushman, is kind and welcoming, but the same cannot be said of everyone at Beecher. Auggie is used to the shocked looks, the eyes that veer slightly away from his face, the forced smiles, and the overly-cheerful conversations that most adults use when they meet him. He has come to expect the taunts from other young people, but he hopes that going to school will give him the chance to show others that he is a normal boy despite his abnormal looks. 
 Shifting points of view elevate this book above the typical unfortunate protagonist sob story. Auggie opens the tale and proves himself to be bright, funny, and surprisingly well-balanced... a normal ten-year-old boy who just happens to have a severe facial anomaly. The situations and relationships that develop have the right feel, and the dialogue is realistic. Readers will laugh and cry with Auggie and then get a chance to see how others feel and think about him as the point of view shifts to his older sister Via, his pretty friend Summer, his supposed best friend Jack, and others. These contrasting perspectives reveal undercurrents and causal relationships that are missing or only hinted at in Auggie's telling. There is one narrator who seems ill-chosen... Justin contributes little or nothing to the plot and tone. It would have been a welcome substitute to have heard from the villain of the piece instead. But that is a small quibble, and perhaps it's asking too much of a writer to humanize the bully by sharing his thoughts and emotions with readers. 
 Bullying is of great concern in our schools and society. Despite many well-meaning programs, bullying continues, and adults often feel powerless to combat it. My mother used to tell the story of a little girl who prayed, "Dear God, please help the bad people to be good, and help the good people to be kind." Those words echoed through my head as I read Palacio's remarkable debut novel. This book deserves to be read and discussed in intermediate and middle school classrooms. Hopefully it will go a long way toward making that little girl's prayer a reality.
Loved it! Fun, quick read with great characters. Highly recommend!
Charming. I'm not entirely sure how I felt about the end, but it *is* a book written for young'uns, so I guess it's fine.

WONDERful read. Highly recommended. 
 Renews your spirit, honestly.

Beautiful, quirky, engaging, innocent, takes one back to the horrors of middle school 
 and how those who don't fit into the norm are treated terribly. 
 A lovely lesson about kindness and to look beyond appearances.
He's really a wonder! <3
This book is WONDERful (ha ha). A beautiful story, with lovely characters.

I know it's a good book when I'm willing to put off another good book to read it :). This book is about a fifth grader who has facial deformities. The book takes place during his fifth grade year, which is his first time going to a school and not being home-schooled. Auggie is a very likeable character but I loved that the book was told through multiple characters so it was not just a journey of growth for Auggie but for everyone around him as well. This is a heart-warming story that will inspire you to always "choose to be kind."
A children's book written with adults in mind. Putting a face (literally) on the insecurity and latent goodness that defines most of us. Everyone should read this book!

I absolutely loved this book! One minute you'll be laughing and the next you thing you know the tears are flowing. Lol I really fell in love with this "little dude" :D I think this should be a required read for all middle school children because it really does teach a meaningful lesson that is often times overlooked in school.

I LOVED this book!!!!! From Auggie I learned the importance of perseverance, true friendship, and forgiveness. I also learned the need for having a sense of humor. I don't think he would have made it through life at school without one. This book will certainly have you crying.
Outstanding story and characters. The best book I've read in years.
I am in emotional ruins. Full length review coming soon, after I clean up whatever is left of my emotions.

This book is officially now one of my favourite books in the whole world (next to 'The Lord of the Rings Trilogy' and 'Pride and Prejudice'. 
 When I first saw 'Wonder' sitting on a shelf at my local 'Kmart' I just knew I had to read it. But because I didn't have any money to buy it at that point in time... I had to leave it there, hoping that it would still be there in the next few weeks when I returned to buy it. But when I eventually came back... it wasn't there. 
 It took about a month to find it. But I believe it made me more than ever excited and determined to read it. 
 Okay so enough about me... 
 So 'Wonder' in my opinion is an extraordinary novel about a courageous young boy who has to live with a deformity. The way the novel is set out is in one word - perfect. I'd love to see a brave person make this into a movie one day... but leave the story exactly how it is. 
 This book made me laugh, made me cry (both happy and sad tears), made me angry (at the cruelty dished-out upon the main character) and my heart soar (expecially at the last few chapters). This is a beautiful book and I'm glad to see that there are authors out there that write with such honestly, understanding and love about any human being that struggles with a deformity or disability.

Uplifting story about a boy who faces bullying and ostracism because of his severe facial deformity, but shines through it all. Nicely told through not just his point of view but also that of his older sister, who's always supported him, and the new friends he makes at his school--he's going to fifth grade in a public school after being homeschooled for health reasons up til then. Auggie is a great character you'll love to root for.
This book was amazing. reading it should be a prerequisite for living, and at the very least required reading for every middle schooler ever.
I loved this story of strength and the power of love and friendship, quite different than most of the YA books I read.
Awesome, excellent, great, fantastic!
Wonderful insights to life and human nature. I usually read books for older students. This definitely was a book for fifth or sixth graders.
This is one of those books everybody should read.
It was a perfect, well developed, well written, full of emotions, beautiful book! DROP EVERYTHING YOU'RE DOING AND GO READ IT RIGHT NOW. GO.

I understand wanting people to be kind. I try to choose kindness for myself, but this book is so hit-you-over-the-head with this message, it's too much. Too on the nose. I wanted August to move beyond worrying about his looks and do something extraordinary, but he never did. It was interesting to get the perspectives of the other kids in the story and it sounds like the story works well for younger readers, but I found it lacking.
what a beautiful, heartfelt and inspiring read. So glad I went back to finish it.

"Wonder" Really is a wonderful book to read. I'd give a 4.5 almost perfect rating for this book. A lot of funny, "shed-tears", "Aww" moments intertwined with family, friends and school community bring this book feels really close to my heart as an educator. I think every students, parents, everybody! Need to put this book in the "Must Read" Section. A little quote from the main character of the book, Auggie, "Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world."

To describe my feeling on this book I am going to quote John Green: "Sometimes, you read a book and it fills you with this weird evangelical zeal, and you become convinced that the shattered world will never be put back together unless and until all living humans read the book." 
 I would love everyone from the age of about 10 to read this book as I really think it can be enjoyed by almost anyone. Great story with a great message!

Read this together with my 7 year old son. He loved it because it shows how the human spirit is triumphant even when you are stared at and made fun of your entire life. A great read to share with your child.

Wonder places you in the shoes of a boy with a facial deformity as well as the shoes of everyone around him - his sister, his schoolmates, his sister's friends etc... An eye opener for those of us who are physically normal and never actually thought about what it would be like to be not. What is special about this book is the indomitable human spirit that shines through and that behind every face is a person waiting to be discovered. 
 Although the target audience is for primary school kids, it is a refreshing and uplifting read for all levels of society.
Loved it.

Wonder is the uplifting, moving and inspiring tale of August Pullman, a young kid who suffers from a rare facial deformity. The story centers on the various experiences, pleasant and unpleasant, he makes in his first year of middle school at Beecher Prep. How are the other kids going to treat him? Will they accept or make fun of him? The story is told from different perspectives which I enjoyed. We get to know the protagonist's point of view but also the other character's feelings and outlook on the situation, Via, Auggie's big and feisty sister, Jack and Summer who immediately befriend him. The principal's speech at the end of the book really stood out for me: "Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness." A truly inspiring story about acceptance, courage and kindness with a protagonist who despite all the difficult circumstances he faces rarely gives in to self-pity.

I bought this book for my 3rd grader and I wanted to read it before she did. I am so glad I did! It made me laugh and cry and ran my emotions up and down throughout. It was excellently written for the reading level and I'm excited for my daughter to read it. 
 I've spent a good deal of time teaching my girls that hurting people's feelings and repeating negative gossip is never acceptable. I think this book will help show them how it feels from the other side. 
 Perhaps the ending is a bit too pat and happily-ever-after, but I like my books that way. And I don't think it goes too far into the realm of make believe. Wonder is definitely worth the 5 stars I gave it.
I just watched the trailer for this book tuned movie and I can only possibly imaging how AMAZING this book is going to be!
Really easy, fast read. A sweet story about how folks should be kinder than necessary, particularly through the rough period that is middle school. Would recommend to anyone!

I've spent most of my life reading or being read to. Books have had a profound and irrevocable impact on my life. I'm talking about the whole spectrum of words here: textbooks, dictionaries, fantasy, sci-fi, newspapers, magazines, diaries, emails, love letters, facebook status updates - the whole deal. 
 In in the many years I've been reading, I've been influenced. Influenced to love, to hatred, to sympathy, and sometimes, to tears.
