 'Wonder' by R.J. Palacio is, singularly, one of the best books I have ever read. It's not a literary masterpiece - no. It is a GOOD book. It resonates kindness and love and overcoming our fears, and so much more. Now, I won't give away anything from the plot. All you need to know is this: 
 'Wonder' is the story of a boy, August, who goes to school for the first time in the fifth grade (having been homeschooled before then). We follow August, or Auggie, as he is affectionately named, through his year at school - through the turmoils and troubles of a young teenager. 
 The catch is that Auggie is "deformed" - as the meaner kids in school call him. He suffers from multiple genetic mutations that have resulted in him having a very unusual face. So, dear, reader, be prepared for the bullies, the name-calling, the self-loathing. It's all there, and it's all extremely powerful stuff. 
 R.J. Palacio has done an immaculate job with this book. I am so thankful to have stumbled upon it. I recommend this read to any and every person. It has changed me. It has brought me to tears. 
 My personal favourite part of this book is Auggie's English teacher, Mr Browne, who has a precept for every month. I'm not going to put them in here, for fear of spoiling the thrill of uncovering them for the reader, but if you're interested in reading 23 statements that will make you laugh, make you nod your head in assent, and if you apply them, make you a better person, click through to my blog here: http://geishahouse.me/2013/07/16/revi...

One of the best books I've read, dealt with so many different issues that we don't always think about. I think we needed this book, especially during this new society and the increasing instances of bullying going on in schools. Overall, very good book and I enjoyed reading this and recommend everyone to read and see that kindness goes far and touches more people than we think, and that just because there are differences out there it isn't something to be scared of and creates a strength you wouldn't think due to the challenges individuals may face.
A good book about acceptance and the challenge of being different in middle school.

There is so much hype surrounding this book that I was worried going into it. At first it felt a bit simple and emotionally manipulative, but as the story progressed, I slowly fell in love with the characters. I loved that each character had more back-story and deeper reasons for their actions; not everyone reacted solely to August's facial deformities. I didn't care for the short chapters, but the format was ideal for a middle school reader. I also recognize that Auggie's experience came from one of white, wealthy privilege so his story was quite different than other perspectives may have been. I also wasn't crazy about how everything wrapped up in a perfect bow, yet sometimes it is nice to have a nice, happy ending. All this I could overlook. My biggest complaint was that, while Auggie maintained that he was just a normal kid who looked abnormal, other people around him succumbed to the idea that those who struggle are inherently better/more special than everyone else. It's an annoying and condescending.

This is one of the best books I have ever read! 
 So touching, sweet and funny at the same time. I love little Auggie to pieces.
this is one of the best books i've read so far this year and i can't wait to recommend it to kids. it's an inspiring story that makes me want to to strive to be "a little kinder than is necessary."

Ten-year old August (Auggie) Pullman was born with a facial deformity and as he begins fifth grade, he transitions from being homeschooled to attending Beecher Prep. Auggie struggles to find acceptance among his new classmates, but through the compassion of true friendship, he wins over the hearts and minds of his peers and the community. Palacio's book will continue to be an important read for all ages, for years to come.

This book...so good! Hands down one of the best I've ever read! I love it because there is always two sides to ever story, we have no idea what is going on with people and this book reminds to try a little harder to be a little better and kinder to others. Read this with kids, on your own, it's worth it!

Wonder is a fantastic book that tackle hard subjects. I loved reading from all the perspectives, especially Auggie's point of view. This book is a tribute to kindness and how far a little can go. 
 Everyone should read this book!

A very touching story of a funny ordinary, at least he wants to be, 5th grade boy, who by just being himself allows other characters to see beyond his physical deformities. This is a wonderful reminder of the superficial means in which we judge others. It will remind you what is important as the character's first hand accounts touch your heart. Can be read and enjoyed by the young and old.

To be truthful, I've been quite disappointed at first because of the way the author wrote. But as I read on, I realized it wasn't a kid novel with a simple meaning. This books includes lots of analogies and makes me so deeply touched. Absolutely loved it.

Been busy, review coming soon! Since this is 5 stars, and one of the best book I've read for this year, I liked to write something before I fully reviewed it - 
 TQ R.J. Palacio for making such a heart warming, wonderful book. This book makes me think, really think, about life and other important things. It touches my heart, as it will to yours.
I LOVED this book. In fact, I can't say enough how breathtaking it was, except that I want to buy it for everyone I know.
4.5 stars. So wonderful! Read it to my girls and discussed afterward

11/11/2017 
 Reread for my college's book club. 
 Just as WONDERful as before. ;) 
 7/15/2017 
 I feel...beyond blessed to have been able to experience this story of wonder. 
 Thank you, RJ Palacio, for penning this tale of courage and kindness. 
 Recommended for everyone.

Such a great book. I can see why my friends have read it to their classes. Lots of lessons to be learnt. I loved the perspectives from different characters. It was a real challenge finishing this in the cafe this morning!

A touching book that has some serendipitous twists but I think the heart of it rings true. I've found myself thinking back to the book fairly often this week. I had major facial trauma a few years ago and had my entire face reconstructed. One of my eyes will never look ok and my face is scarred up but there are people with deformities that are a lot more striking. It takes so much courage to go through life with the type of facial differences Augie has. I enjoyed hearing the stories from different perspectives. This is a story that could easily have turned soppy but I don't think it did. I pray that noone tries to make a movie out of it, even though it would work well as a screenplay. Augie says near the beginning that he won't describe what he looks like, "Whatever you're imagining it's probably worse". I want to keep my own images from the book and I hope that everyone else who reads it gets that chance too.

AMAZING. Makes you want to hug each 5th grader and forgive all their faults. Brave and courageous characters who conquer the world by just being themselves. We could all learn so much from this book- the perfect choice for a class discussion. Makes you appreciate your faults and your friends and try harder to be kinder than necessary.

I've been hearing a lot of buzz about this book and since I had received the ARC at PLA I figured I should start reading. The protagonist is Auggie a young boy who suffers from severe facial deformalities. He is going to be enrolled in a public school for the first time ever. Auggie is used to stares, but school puts him in a whole new spotlight. Auggie struggles to make friends and deal with the casual cruelty of his peers. Auggie's first section ends with him understanding that his parents love cannot save him from people. The book switches narrators and includes Auggie's sister Olivia (Via) who while blunt is honest. She explains how their parents have always overprotected Auggie and how it feels to play second fiddle to a child with special needs. Other narrators include Via's boyfriend, Summer the beautiful girl who sits with Auggie at lunch and becomes his friend, and his friend Jack. The narration always returns to Auggie as it is his story, but the format really works and allows readers to get a full picture of Auggie. For anyone who has been a victim of bullying- read this book! A great moving read!
Fun, quick read. My daughter recommended that I read this book. It was great to read it and discuss it with her. So much joy is wrapped up in such a little book :)

THIS WAS SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO GOOD. 
 This book is relevant to all humans, of all ages, of all interests. Highly recommended. Caveat: it will probably make you cry. It definitely made me cry--on the stationary bicycle I was riding at the gym. No shame.
Life lessons from a children's book.

This book was a beautiful introspective story that I read to my kids. There were many lessons to learn from multiple character viewpoints, which is fantastic for kids to read about. They find themselves asking questions about the nature of kindness, friendship, and perspectives.

Authentic characters as if in a real middle school make this novel highly likable. Auggie Pullman has something to offer everyone. There are a great deal of memorable moments and important lessons to learn. Several times I had tears in my eyes, and they definitely overflowed at the end. I would love for my students to read this book. I'm adding it to my classroom summer reading list!

Shall we make a new rule of life....always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary? - J.M. Barrie 
 Great book for any age.

I've been hearing great things about this book all year, and it didn't disappoint! I enjoyed reading about August (Auggie), and how he overcame adversity in such a gentle way. Auggie was born with a severe facial abnormality and, having been home schooled his entire childhood, is attending school for the first time. Auggie challenges his fellow fifth grade students, teachers, and parents to look past appearances and instead focus on what's underneath. But what I especially appreciated was that Auggie grew through the book too, learning to trust others and not hide his face. The story is told in multiple POVs, each authentic and well-developed, which add a depth and richness to the tale. Overall, a heart-warming read and I highly recommend.
Truly a wonder. I loved this book from start to finish. I also loved the way it was written from the perspective of the book characters. A must read.

Wonder 
 Oh little auggie, you indeed deserved your standing ovation! 
 - 
 Adorable story with an original idea, I LOVED the diverse characters perspectives narration, I felt every single one of them, I laughed at occasions, and I shed a whole liter of tears at others ! 
 - 
 Truly it was a pleasant trip with a lovable touching story. 
 - 
 Let your kids read it, and read it youself, you're NEVER too old for a cute inspiring book!
Fantastic and heartbreaking but heartwarming as well. Well-written, all of the voices down. Each character distinct, telling a different bit of August's story.

I loved this, and I love the OverDrive system at our library where I can just check out a book that looks good immediately, and go browsing the shelves anytime, even at 3:00 at the morning, without ever leaving my bed! I'll never run out of books again.
This has been on lots of book club lists and was a part of our workshop and is definitely a children's book worth a read by any age. A heart felt story well told.
It's really awesome!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Interesting story, well written, fast read. Also great for 5th grade and up.

I am ashamed that it took me so long to finally start this book. I've had it on my tbr for a long time, but put off reading it, because I thought it was overhyped. It's definitely worth all the praise it's gotten, and so much more. One of those books that everyone should read. Remember, choose kindness.
So sad! It made my heart break!
Definitely something you need to read with your children or to your classes. Must read.

** spoiler alert ** 
 How do I start? How about with the fact that this book pulls me to tears every time I read it...? Or with the fact that I can't choose a favorite character because they're all so perfect?!? 
 This book is AMAZING! I have no words for it. Um let's see what do I say now? Oh I know! I'll start with characters! Because those always a good place to start. ;) 
 Characters: 
 August (Auggie): For some reason August is one of my least favorite characters. I don't know why but I don't like him as much... But I still love him a lot. He's so brave and when the whole school is against him (well, except Summer) he is still willing to go to school, even if it takes convincing) He's funny and is willing to laugh about himself. A lot of people is this world are so insecure that they take everything too seriously and only laugh about others and never about themselves. This is an important part of August that I love. 
 Olivia (Viva): I really like her. She's human. Viva is a really cool human being, she's learned how to get by on her own. She's trying to be strong and trying not to cause any more problems for her family. And yes sometimes she breaks down but that's because she's a real person! And she needs confront and someone to be friends with her! I totally get what happens to her and Miranda. Friends change. And it's confusing sometimes. So you find new friends. And sometimes they're not as good as your old friends. So basically, life's complicated, and she has no one to help her through it. 
 Summer: Summer is a beautiful human being. She's what I wish I was. She dies t care what people think, she defends her friends and she's fun. She is kind and wonderful and I don't have any more words for her... 
 Jack Will (or just Jack): OH MY GOSH I LOVE HIM. (Ok so maybe I do have a favorite. Sue me) So at first I was like: Eh, nothing super special. Then I was like: I LOVE YOU, YOU ARE MY BABY MUFFIN. Let me explain why: 
 Jack is a normal kid, he's scared of judgment. I am too. I get it. At first I didn't like him as much because he didn't even want to give August a chance. Then he learned how cool August is and became friends with him. And when Jack Will said those awful things about August, I cried. A lot. But then he punched Julian and I loved him all over again. So there's that. 
 Ok so I realized I can't do all the characters because there are like sooo many... So I'll just wrap up here. 
 So overall this book is great and you should read it! And also, this review was written with a ton of feels so it's kinda biased... As most of my reviews will be. Anyway, I hope you guys have a good day and have some ice cream or something?

Actual rating 3.5 stars. 
 When I picked this book from the library shelves a couple of days ago, I had no idea that this book would turn out to be such a compelling read. Since my classes started at 2 PM and I was preparing my computer for an upgrade, I had some time left over and decided to read a bit of this book while waiting. And I even forgot myself at times because it really was that engaging. 
 These 315 pages flew by in a blur and actually, I'm kind of in amazement that I finished it so soon. For some odd reason, I thought that I would get to read it for several nights, but no such luck - this book simply did not allow me to read it for so long. 
 I read this book as a part of my reading challenge for 2015 and the rest of my thoughts can be found HERE
Loved it. Every child should read this. Would have given it five stars if it wasn't for the annoying 'Justin' chapter. Other than that, wonderful book

Alison for www.bigbooklittlebook.com 
 Wonder is quite frankly an amazing book that well and truly deserves its place on the Carnegie Shortlist. I read the book in a night and needed copious amounts of tissues as I neared the end. It should be made clear however that this is not a sad book, instead it is one that highlights the better side of human nature. Although the darker side does raise its ugly head from time to time, this book shows how human kindness can overcome it. Yes there are parts that are quite corny and twee, but I was left with such a feeling of hope after finishing the book, so much so that the corniness didn't really seem to matter. 
 Auggie is the main character in the book, even when we read from the point of view of other characters. Born with a severe facial deformity he has had a lot to overcome in his 10 years. Previously homeschooled his parents decide to that now is the time he should start at mainstream school. Auggie is apprehensive but decides to give it a go, it's not like he isn't used to the way that people look at him. Initially ostracized there are a couple of pockets of light in the dark. In the end, despite the wishes of a boy who is obviously scared of being different, Auggie gains the acceptance of his classmates by showing a incredible quiet strength. 
 Wonder is written from the perspective of a number of central characters, all people whose lives have been touched by Auggie. I did miss the perspective of Auggie's parents but at the end of the day this is a book for pre teens not for adults and the characters that they would wish to hear from are all covered. All points of view were written in the first person, but I always knew whose voice I was hearing. I liked the way that this was done, I don't think that the book would have had nearly as much impact has it all been written from Auggie's point of view as a large part of the storyline was how he, as a person, affected the lives of those around him. I also think that the decision to write the book in the first person was a good one. It is a very emotive book about a very emotive subject, the first person narrative reinforced this as the reader feels an intense emotional connection to what is going on. 
 I also liked the fact that although this book focuses on the better side of human nature, the 'good' characters weren't perfect. Via sometimes resents her brother for taking her parents attention away from her and whilst she loves her brother doesn't always want the hassle that being seen with him brings, their parents disagree on Auggie starting school, Jack gives in to peer pressure and talks about Auggie behind his back and Auggie does feel anger and resentment at the lot that he has been given. Had these characters not had these little imperfections then Wonder would not have seemed as real and I don't think it would have succeeded in putting across the message that we should all take time to look at who a person is as that is what counts. 
 I'm not sure that it will win Carnegie, I think it may be a little sentimental to actually win the prize. It has however been a welcome break from the heavy darkness that can be found in some of the other books on the shortlist. And although I don't think it will win part of me wishes that it would 
 Verdict: A beautifully written, emotional book that give me hope for the nature of human kindness.

I wish every day could be Halloween. We could all wear masks all the time. Then we could walk around and get to know each other before we got to see what we looked like under the masks. 
 August "Auggie" Pullman started the fifth grade. This story is about his experience going "mainstream" after being home-schooled. This can be the usual YA/coming-of-age fiction except for the part that Auggie was born with a congenital defect that distorted his face, thus, earning him several rude nicknames from other kids. "Wonder" tells how Auggie faced (no pun intended) the challenges of meeting new people and learning (the hard way) who among those are true friends. We have all gone through that challenge at least once in our lives. 
 This book is well-written. There are chapters that show other characters' points of view. It's fun to read through them while keeping in mind the personalities of these characters. This story inspiring. Those who have been bullied or judged because of physical appearance can relate to Auggie's experiences. Surprisingly, I was touched by the ending. I didn't expect this book to make me cry, but I guess a little bit of kindness and a lesson on kindness can go a long way.
Amazing! I've heard the new version of the book has Julian's POV...

10/5 stars 
 This book.... It's unbelievable! I honestly would've rated it 10 stars if I could. it was that good. For anyone who has the chance to read this book, TAKE IT!! You absolutely won't regret it!
Beautiful and heartwarming book!! :) "always try to be kinder than is necessary"

I registered a book at BookCrossing.com! 
 http://www.BookCrossing.com/journal/13892980
http://www.examiner.com/review/the-wo...
Well written, kept me engrossed. It made me want to have hope in the goodness of humanity.

Much of Auggie's story is told from his perspective, but the true depth of the story (and characters) materializes as other significant characters come forward to share their perspectives regarding their lives with Auggie. They bare their souls and allow us as readers to share in their joy and pain and blindingly honest truths. 
 Wonder is not a "woe-is-me" book. It is not a copy-cat book. It is not a book you'll read and then shake your head thinking that you've read this story somewhere else before. 
 Wonder is full of rich, well fleshed out characters that will make you laugh, cry, sympathize, feel outrage, and ultimately feel blessed. The tears you shed will be both heartbreaking and of joyful triumphs. 
 Auggie is a character you will not soon forget.
This book truly shows the struggle of physically not fitting in and how your looks affect how people perceive you. Wonder drives home the message to never judge a boy by his face.

It took me a couple of tries to get into this one, but I'm glad I made the effort. Warning, though: read this with a box of tissues by your side. 
 I think readers from 8 to 98 would enjoy this book, but fifth and sixth graders will probably relate to it best of all. 
 The characters Palacio creates in this book are my favorite part. It's hard not to love them, even when they're doing something just awful. 
 I would recommend this book to nearly anyone; it's one of those books that makes you feel like a better, more empathetic person just for reading it. You just might find one of Mr. Browne's Precepts, or Mr. Tushman's quotes popping into your mind someday, after all. 
 Choose kind!

Loved loved loved this book. It's aimed at the juvenile market, but I picked it up because my library wants to do some programming on bullying and i was looking for ideas. Wonder is a remarkable book about a remarkable family. It should be required reading for middle school grades! August, the main character, has a giant heart and a lot of courage. Middle school is hard for everyone. Imagine going to middle school with a facial abnormality. It's very rewarding to see how he perseveres. Go out and get this book now!
A lovely book.

Wonder is truly an amazing story! The life of Auggie, his parents, his sister, and even friends were definitely not easy. This book really shows the reader that there are good and bad people in the world. There is truth in the line from Auggie's mom, "There are always going to be jerks in the world, Auggie. But I really believe, and Daddy really believes, that there are more good people on this earth than bad people, and the good people watch out for each other and take care of each other."
Beautiful story. I want to put it into the hands of everyone now! We may choose this one for mother-daughter book club. Lots for the girls to discuss here.
I read this book in 10th grade and I thought it was really good.
Great book!!
Love this book!
Emotional, amazing book for anyone who wants to read it. You will love and hate this book at the same time and that is a good thing.

Fantastic. Just the right blend of the cruelty/kindness of kids. Written in multiple POVs, all of the voices really added to story---the only one I really didn't care for was the the sister's boyfriend. 
 Also, this quote popped out at me at the right time in my life: "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." It's a great reminder to go the extra mile to understand other people.

Such an easy read, which is uplifting and inspiring. I love a good book that can be read in a day! 
 - "Be a little kinder than is necessary"
Not quite perfect, but so evocative and sometimes simply brilliant! In a world that needs more kindness, this is a must-read for everyone from 10 to 110!

August is going into fifth grade at a new school; he's been homeschooled because of a facial deformity that he was born with. Needless to say, it's not been easy and this year won't be an exception. 
 What was exceptional about this book, however, is that the story is told from multiple points of view. August starts us off giving us background to his life and surgeries as well as his own reflection of how not being "normal" or at least looking "normal" has affected him. Then we hear from his older sister, Via, who is starting high school and has issues of her own. I like how the book spans these these grades. Next Summer, one of August' new friends, adds her own voice followed by August's newest best friend, Jack. There' a lot of drama with the boys in this grade and I like that this book first of all sounds like the age group of the kids (versus an author trying to impress the reader) and that boys have social issues just as girls do. Other characters also speak up. Multiple conflicts and real life situations in the course of one year. Would be great for upper el and MS. 
 Could be paired with children's books Chrysanthemum, The Junkyard Wonders, and Each Kindness.

This book was just so beautiful in almost every way but especially in how it showed the importance of kindness. 
 There were two quotes that particularly stood out for me: 
 Mr Browne's Precept: 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." 
 and from Mr. Tushman's (the school principal) speech: 
 "...kinder than is necessary. Because it is not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed...that concept reminds me that we carry with us, as human beings, not just the capacity to be kind, but the very choice of kindness..." 
 When I read that I just had to stop and think about that particular quote for a moment. It is so true, kindness is a choice. This book showed that although we may not get to choose what we are, what we look like or even who are family is, but we do get to choose WHO we are. And we can choose to be kind. 
 This book is written for middle grade students, or upper primary, and it is done so beautifully, but I think that everyone should read it. It definitely goes under the Must Read category. 
 So if you have the chance to be kind to someone, even if it's just giving them a smile, please do so. Please choose kindness.
if you have a choice between being kind and being right choose kind
Beautiful and touching. Many good uses for this book for schools.
One of the best books ever. Should be required reading in middle schools.

What can one say about "Wonder"? 
 The story starts with a little boy named August. He loves Star Wars and lives with his mom, dad, sister and dog. It's time to start fifth grade and he's going to school for the first time. Auggie's been home schooled the rest of the time due to his many surgeries. Auggie was born different. 
 I'm blown away by this book and the different points of view. Each character around him provide a different perspective on his experiences and how he shapes them. It's a powerful book on kindness. 
 As a parent, it was perfectly timed. My oldest is pretty reserved and has a hard time making friends. She told my husband the other day that no one sits by her at school. It hurts my heart, but this book gives a little window into reality. I can't coddle her and friends will find her. Teach her kindness and love and all will work out.
Quick read, as you would assume being a young adult novel, but a wonderful message.
Far and away the best book I have read in ages. Beautifully and brilliantly written.

It is totally inspiring and deserves the literary praise it is getting. Please don't forget this as I analyze minor details. 
 My main question is this: in a work of fiction that doesn't claim to have done any research or be based on one individual's true experience, why is it being considered a good example of how disabled or disfigured people feel inside? It's being hailed as a key to understanding what people with disabilities feel like so we can respond better. And I totally support that. 
 But how do we know that it's what they feel like? The book is fiction, with no citations or reference to any explanation of a real-life source. The kid is an invented person, with invented thoughts and feelings. Also, if there WERE a real-life basis why would we assume that most people in that situation would feel the same as he does, in a way that could be represented by one character? 
 I think it is very worthy of praise and I loved the story, but to me it is an eye-opening story that makes me feel more compassionate and aware of my own reactions and behaviors. Not a sneak-peek into a specific group's mind or feelings. 
 I am also one of those people who is uncomfortable with "disability tourism": holding people with disabilities up as a source for pity or inspiration. Not that they can't ever spark those feelings, but that emotional entertainment is not their main purpose in life. I'd rather let the person tell me what role they'd like to play in society, just like anyone else. I thought the book wasnt the biggest offender I've ever seen, but invited the reader to take it to a new level if they wanted to.
This was such a pleasant read. I picked it up because I wanted to see what the fuss was, and I'm glad I did! It's so fast and easy.

What a great Young Adult book (and great for Adults too). So glad our school had our 5th Graders read this book - about fifth graders and the issues they ALL face at school, whether you are a "normal" kid or not. Covers GREAT moral messages we all face. Love the writing style from various narrators' perspectives. Highly recommended. Kleenex suggested.
Okay, so this is my favorite book so far, let's see if anything else even comes close.

Just a wonderful story that I hope to share with my kids someday. I loved how it was told from the perspective of each of the children in the story and, although Auggie is the main character who is unfairly judged by his deformities, each of them has something going on in their lives that can't be known by appearances. Whether we are 'normal' looking or not, we can never know what it is like to walk in someone else's shoes and should treat everyone with kindness and respect. The book is a bit heavy handed with this message, but it doesn't make it any less worthwhile. I also have little faith that kids exist like those that befriended Auggie, but I can hope, and hope this book might make a difference.

I really can't say enough about this book. I was thoroughly entertained as I went on Auggie's journey into 5th grade; there were a lot of ups and downs and quite a few heartfelt and heartwarming moments. I really liked how the point of view changed several times, and it really moved the story along. As I was reading, I came across a passage that was memorable to me: "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." (p. 231). This sentence really stuck with me; as I thought about the meaning of this, I realized how true that was. I was thrilled to find that this theme came back at the end, so it was neat to see that a passage that I had picked out was important to the overall story. What is not to like about a book with interesting characters, great writing, and a theme of kindness?

Every book in the Wonder series is insightful and provides a teaching moment on topics related to bullying, peer group pressure, diversity and acceptance. Worth reading by every parent, teacher and child.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I was worried when starting this book because it's a middle grade. And although there are plenty great middle grade books out there, as a 24 year old it's hard for me to fully appreciate the book because I'm not the right age demographic. However, Wonder is a great exception. 
 This book had me tearing up a few times. It was so heartwarming and real. I really liked that most of the characters were very realistic. Sometimes with middle grade books the "popular" kids are just mean without a realistic explanation or the characters feel flat. But with Wonder you get to understand why the kids who are mean to August are the way they are. You see it with Julien and his parents. Because he was raised and surrounded by such negativity and judgmental behavior it's what he mimics. 
 The characters were great. August was such a sweetheart, Jack was super adorable, Summer was this little sweetheart. I loved it. 
 I would recommend this book to anyone with kids (especially in or about to be in middle school). This is a great book to help kids understand how to be compassionate and kind to people even if your first instinct is to be detached or judgmental because someone is different. I think more kids need to read more stories like this, but also more parents. This book does a great job showing that sure, kids can be little jerks, but if that behavior isn't corrected they turn into adults who are jerks. 
 The whole Daisy part had me in tears. I'm a blubbering mess when it comes to dying dog stories. And for stories where someone gets a new dog. Gah. You best believe I cuddled my pup for ten minutes after Daisy passed. 
 My only con is that Justin's chapters drove me nuts with the weird lowercase format. Olivia was capitalized once (but all the other times it wasn't) and the rest of it is lowercase. I kind of hated it. But I enjoyed the content of the chapters. 
 Quotes I enjoyed: 
 "Sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone." 
 "Funny how sometimes you worry a lot about something and it turns out to be nothing." 
 The entire section of Mr. Tushman's speech about kindness (page 299-300) 
 "You don't need your eyes to love, right? You just feel it inside you." 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives."

This is a sweet story about a young boy with severe facial deformities and the difficulties he encounters when he starts going to school in fifth grade. It's a heart warming story that shows there really are good people in the world.

If you've never been on the side of teasing and bullying in school, then this book would definitely show you what it feels like to be on that side. August has a disfigurement that has caused his face to look lopsided that no amount of surgery can fix. Yet on the inside, he is just your average ten year old boy obsessed with Star Wars and playing video games. Here's a story where people matter, and where the boy wonder is as intelligent as any adult. 
 I can't help but smile at the tenacity and strength that August has. No matter what brought him down, he was right back up again. At times he felt like a punching bag, where kids would bring him down just for the fun of it. Yet August didn't let it get to him. He knows he may look different, but just because he does, doesn't mean he is. His whole personality is reflected in the eyes of the rest of the characters in the latter half of the novel which I enjoyed immensely. Considering there are a couple of characters, it didn't feel confusing, it just felt real. You felt what they felt, especially in August's point of view. 
 Look for a fun and light hearted read, RJ Palacio writes the truth, be kind to people, no matter what they say about you.

I realize that my opinion will be hugely unpopular. For the record, I do understand why people love Wonder. There is a lot to love about this book. It just isn't my type of book. It reminds me of cake. One piece of cake is great, but if you try to eat an entire cake by yourself, you'll get sick. This book is so sweet that it made me a little sick. I know that it's a middle grade novel, and those are supposed to have happy endings, but even as a child, I would have had a hard time with all the crying and hugging at the end. I was hoping that this book would be grittier, more realistic, and more honest. The premise is intriguing, but the book is unrealistically sweet and a little simplistic. 
 Wonder is about ten-year-old August. He is born with a genetic disorder that deforms his face and requires him to have dozens of surgeries. As a result, his parents homeschool him until it's time for middle school. August looks different from other children. At middle school, he faces bullying, discrimination, stares, and whispers. Over the course of a year, August grows up a lot, and the other children learn to be kinder. 
 The story is told from multiple points-of-view. I like this because it allows the reader to see August from different angles. My favorite narrators are Via and Jack. They feel the most honest to me. Both of them care about August, but they acknowledge that having him in their lives makes life more difficult. This is especially true for August's sister, Via. August requires so much attention that Via feels neglected by her parents. Via and Jack's points-of-view are very well done. Some of the other narrators have voices that sound very similar, so I would have liked them better if they were more distinct. 
 The sweetness is my main complaint about the book, but I also started to question the motives of August's "friends" as I was reading. The adult characters often tell the child characters to be kind to August. Are the other children friends with August because they like him as a person or because they have been told over and over to be kind to him? I question if the friendships in this book are real friendships. The older girl, Miranda, feels like an authentic friend to August, but I'm not sure about the others. To me, they seem like pity friends who are being kind to August because it's the right thing to do. Kindness is great, but wouldn't August want actual friends and not just people who are kind to him? It really bothers me that August says that he feels like a "mascot" to the other kids. He shouldn't be a mascot to the other kids; he should just be one of the kids. 
 Then there's the dating thing. Ten-year-olds do date. When I was ten, I remember that there was a lot of pressure to have your first kiss, bring a date to the sock hop, etc. The fact that ten-year-olds date in this book doesn't bother me. I'm also happy that some of the ten-year-olds in the book don't date. When I was ten, I thought that something was wrong with me because I had no interest in dating. I would have loved to read about characters who were similar to me. 
 This is going to sound hypocritical: it bothers me that August has very few thoughts about dating. He doesn't seem to have any crushes. He doesn't seem to feel any pressure to date. He doesn't seem to have any opinions about his friends dating. He doesn't seem to give much thought to possibly dating in the future. The author puts the other characters in relationships and totally ignores August's romantic life. I didn't like that. 
 This book is an uplifting, feel-good story with a nice message, so I can see why so many people love it, but it's not my type of thing.

I completely second Brandi Rae's review, and rather than trying to paraphrase, she said I could just use it for mine: 
 "For the most part I really enjoyed this. Auggie was born with many extreme facial deformities. After extensive surgeries, he is starting 5th grade; attending a public school for the first time. This was thoughtful, funny, touching ... the rotating points of view were varied enough that upper elementary would like it as well as lower middle school (good 5-7 book). There were some flaws (I did find the ending ridiculous). But overall, a good book ...."
Beautiful read with humor, sadness, and love.
Amazing.
Remarkable. Should be required reading in every middle school and for all parents!
Wonder is a very special book. The author has tackled a confronting subject with humour, empathy, varying perspectives and great sensitivity. I cried and laughed and cheered for Auggie. Loved it.

What I loved about this book? Everything. Except how much it made me cry. Everything else. What stood out though, is how August had these sweet, loving parents; kind of on the rare side of things. And the dynamic nature of the relationships between everyone in the book; it felt so authentic. And not to cause anyone any spoiler-related aneurisms, but I appreciated that the book ended on a happy note. That does happen in real life, too, you know. It doesn't have to be gut-wrenchinly sad all the time. And I'm usually really annoyed by switches in who is narrating, but it really worked for me this time, seeing everything from the different perspectives. I kind of wish the parents would have had their say, come to think on it. Anyway, this a quick read, and I really think anyone who reads it will love it.

i think its good for kids. Reminds us to have compassion and that trying to hard to be cool and popular can be detrimental. And that its okay to be human, none of us are perfect. We can think and feel selfish thoughts, that doesn't meant we are bad.

Wonder is such a heartfelt story that leaves you feeling there is hope for mankind after all. A story for young and old, but should probably be required reading for the middle school age. The most wonderful part of the book was that the story was told from the different viewpoints of the people in August Pullman's life. Honest reflections from each character woven together to leave a life motto for the reader to always try to be "kinder than necessary."
"i think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives."

I've only ever cried at three books: Charlotte's Web, Harry Potter 6 (DOBBY!) and The Road. To that list, add another: Wonder. It's beautifully compassionate about the ways in which children with physical handicaps affect everyone around them--while giving little Auggie Pullman his due as the hero, we also hear from his sister Via, who has learned that 'the worst day, the worst cramp, the worst thing anyone had ever said to me is nothing compared to what Auggie's been through'; from her boyfriend Justin and best friend Miranda, both of whom wish for the kind of love and stability in their own families that they see in the Pullmans; and from two of the friends that Auggie manages to make in the fifth grade. It's also very competently written, articulate and emotive without ever feeling manipulative. Read it.

This book was amazing. 
 I'll start off by saying that the writing in Wonder was so breezy and effortless. It was such a simple read that packs such a strong message. I think this book perfectly captures that kids can be cruel and they can also be a lot stronger than they seem. 
 I liked reading the different perspectives within the novel. I liked reading from August's perspective the most but I also enjoyed reading from Via's. I liked being able to see the whole impact of August's condition, not just on Auggie, but on those around him, too. 
 Via's POV was really insightful because you were able to get a better understanding as to where she was coming from with her anger and it was nice to see the story from her side. I also felt like the changing perspectives helped with the pacing of the story. 
 The character development in Wonder was great; you watch August go from this shy self-conscious kid as he grows to find himself and become more comfortable around the other kids in his class. Jack Will and Via had some pretty nice character development, too, with both of them dealing with the effects of August in different ways, while also navigating their own lives. 
 This is a great book for all ages. I thought I would have a little trouble connecting to the characters because they're all 10 but it surprisingly wasn't an issue at all. I actually found Auggie's friend Summer to be really relatable. 
 There were times where the book made me laugh, made me angry, and even made me sad. But, all in all, this was a fantastic read. 
 I definitely feel like this book opened my eyes to just how cruel the world can be and why it's so important to remember to choose kindness.

** spoiler alert ** 
 Clearly I'm a heartless biatch for not loving this book nor crying. I was honestly more sorry for August's sister.. 
 It's not this book's fault because it's meant for kids but not everything in life ends happily. The ending just felt forced. Why would he suddenly be happy to win a pity price because it's clearly what it was. Again it's a kid book more meant to teach them empathy but it just felt flat for me!

Simple, Loving, fantastic book!! 
 the book is really simple and yet very nicely written!! i just love the ending <3 can't wait for movie.
I found Wonder to be an exceptional read, and I'm happy this novel has won so many awards. It is a great read for children, touching on serveral issues without being too heavy.

I think this was a great book for the age range it was intended for - ten and up. Inhabiting the mind of Auggie would probably really change the way some kids look at differently-abled people. It's a good illustration of how bullying can be a passive behavior as much as an active behavior, and the things you don't do can hurt as much as the things you do. 
 I was not a huge fan of the shifting narrations of this story. I didn't find any of the other points of view interesting or particularly relevant. Because there was such an imbalance between the amount of time spent on them and the amount of time spent on Auggie, it felt really jarring whenever we shifted to someone else. I feel that Palacio did a fine enough job illustrating how the other characters felt through Auggie's eyes, and those chapters probably could have been cut, and the book could have been shorter. It felt a little long and rambling. 
 That being said, my favorite section definitely came from Justin, Auggie's sister Via's boyfriend. I would have easily read a book about him. He parallels Auggie so well, a teenage version of him.

I loved this book. It captured that hard transition from elementary to middle school and middle school to high school so well. I loved Auggie and his family and the great friends he made along the way.

I'm quite tickled that I managed to relatively accurately pinpoint Auggie's diagnosis of Treacher Collins syndrome based on the written description of his appearance (though Via names it through the specific name of: Mandibulofacial Dysostosis). Guess that means that I A) Read too many blogs about kids with special needs (true) or B) Work with that population -- both true!
Absolutely beautiful
I am more in love with this book than I can begin to say. It is so exactly the way it goes with kids and differences and school and life with a not so typical standing ovation. Go Auggie!

Wonder is a wonderful book. I laughed, I cried (several times), I read parts of it aloud for others to share. August is a fantastic main character but the power of this story is in the supporting cast. I loved the switch of viewpoints into those people. The story would not have been as powerful without it. If you are looking for a feel good book about dealing with disability this it. As Auggie would say, not sure why everyone is making a big deal " I'm just me. An ordinary kid."

March book club read. 
 Really enjoyed this, super quick read. I'd say I probably enjoyed the first half with the different narratives a bit more than the second half. 
 The end of the school year was slightly over the top and sort of felt at odds with the rest of the book, I don't know, I'm being over critical I think! 
 Lovely style and well worth a read.

To be honest, I haven't read a "normal" book in a while--and by "normal," I mean "general fiction that has nothing to do with science fiction, fantasy, or comic books." 
 Now, this book is so highly praised, that there isn't anything more I can really say about it except that I like it the more I think about it. However, I do have a few things to point out. 
 1. August's family reminds me so much of my family. We aren't small (there is like 10 of us), and we don't have as much drama as the Pullman family (because my mom won't put up with crap). But when it goes into the perspectives of people like Jack and Justin, they marvel at how comfortable they feel around the Pullman's. They describe them as always telling each other that they love each other and finding fun in most situations. My family is a lot like that and I've had all my friends tell me they wish they had my parents and lived in my family because we spread the love. I really appreciated that in this book. 
 2. What I 
 didn't 
 like about this was how the children didn't tell in anyone what was going on! I was home schooled all the way through high school so I have no experience with a public school environment, but do kids really NOT TELL the teachers, or even their parents, what's going on?! It's ridiculous! 
 But that personal hiccup isn't enough to knock off a star for this book because it is such a gem. I loved it, everyone else here loves it, so go read it.

My reviews can also be found in https://lilisblissfulpages.wordpress.com/ 
 Here's what I think: the only reason I'm not ordinary is that no one else sees me that way. 
 ---Auggie Pullman 
 August or Auggie isn't ordinary. His face is deformed due to a certain genetic mutation in which made Auggie underwent numerous surgeries since infancy. Those surgeries and operations are also the reason why he was homeschooled by her mother. Yes, it wasn't because of his physical appearance that he's forced to not go to school 
 So now that he wouldn't have to have any surgery in the near future, Auggie can go to school. And he's not excited about it. His parents thinks he's extraordinary, his sister thinks the same (or that's what she said). But in his new school, he was branded by numerous names possible that somehow associated with his physical appearance. 
 We'd see Auggie learned a valuable lesson about life and how hard it can be (not that it was easy for him before). He'd learned how cruel people can be, but he'd also meet good people. And he'd learn that no matter what people see in him, good or bad, doesn't change the fact that he is a WONDER. 
 Intriguing and brilliant. Simple yet with deep meaning. Excellent illustration of the treasure hidden beneath the covers. 
 I am conflicted, to be honest. Here's the thing, I looooooved the book. It made me cry, sob, sniffed a lot, pray and think about things. So if I'd rate it because of that, it's FIVE PERFECT TEAR-JERKING STARS but I know I shouldn't based alone on the emotions it awoke in me. (especially that I sometime get emotional over petty things) So if I'd rate it, forgetting that I cried over it, then I'll give it a three. 
 There's a great plot but then where is it? Intriguing? The thing is I praise the author for having this very unique idea of a plot. By the way, I wouldn't explain about it much because (1.) I don't understand it that much. LOL :) 2.) It's somehow hard to spell. LOL again, :) 3.) You have to find it yourself because it's amazing to learn about something new by yourself. I was like 
 'wows' 
 and 
 'aaahhh' 
 , along with nodding and eyes-widening.) 
 But as I said, the plot that I was hoping I would find wasn't there. It's like we're just given a glimpse of Auggie's life-a very important part of his life where he is beginning to deal with real world outside his home. It wasn't that great as a plot, but it was a great story. I know I'm not making much sense but READ IT. There were no surprising scenes or anything. But it deserves the hype, the praises, and all other glories it got. :) 
 The character are pretty predictable. You know they'd do it when and where. You know they'd feel it, how and why. But isn't it amazing that I still find myself rooting for each of them despite that? 
 Auggie broke my heart and I wanna adopt him someday. And made him feel that he is indeed a wonder. But then again his parents, sister, sister's friends, friends, teachers are already doing that job for me. And seriously, all of them deserves a medal too. 
 Especially JACK, Auggie's friend. Honestly, he's the one who I think has the best character development. 
 His sister, Via, reminded me of MY SISTER'S KEEPER by Jodi Piccoult. She was often neglected that had learned to just take care of herself. Her one outburst was really understandable and made me really cry. She's a very loving sister. 
 And I should mention Mr. Browne and his Precepts: Brilliant and helpful. 
 This is a story of an ordinary boy, who has an extraordinary heart and courage; of a boy with deformities yet can form strong bonds with people around him. This is an uplifting and heartwarming, yet heart-wrenching story of family, friendship, hope, acceptance, courage and beauty. This reminds me of a cup of black coffee, strong yet warm and comforting. Wonder is a story I will reread someday, maybe when I need to cry, or when I simply need a reminder to be good. And when I lose hope with humanity. (dang, that matters a lot) 
 Except for the obvious which is to be good and don't based on physical appearance, I think the author wanted to show us that no matter how much we find it hard to deal with a certain phase our lives(say teeanage), it's way even harder for others. It takes courage to conquer life. The following quote from Auggie says it all: 
 But hey, if they want to give me a medal for being me, that's okay. I'll take it. I didn't destroy a Death Star or anything like that, but I did just get through the fifth grade. And that's not easy, even if you're not me. 
 Happy Reading....

Another important book that needed to be written and story that needed to be told with a theme of a young boy living with a facial difference. The imagery, description and settings used really put you in the shoes of the main and supporting characters. Using multiple character perspectives of the main characters story helped explain different models of disability. A must read for all ages. A story readers of any age can take something away from.
I loved this book!
Amazing story. A MUST READ for children.

Loved this book. It's a touching story that will evoke so many emotions. This book was a great reminder of the value of basic kindness. As quoted in the story, "Always try to be a little kinder than is necessary."

What a truly amazing, heart-breakingly sweet story. August is a typical 10 year old boy. He adores Star Wars and video games; he loves ice cream and his family. And yet, August has never been to school. One day his parents decide it is time for him to attend; the last of 27 surgeries to recreate his face have been completed. This is the story of August's first year at school; the challenges, the heartaches, the laughter, the camping trip, making friends (and losing them). His bravery and inner goodness are inspiring.

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in your life because we all overcome the world" 
 "Shall we make a new rule of life...always tried to be a little kinder than is necessary" 
 "Sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone" 
 I love this book it was cute and daring and tearing and well written. I love August everyone grow up a lot like Jack and Via, I loved them too with all their imperfections only summer was always a sweet cinnamon child. The family parents were dreaming SPOILER why daisy had to died :( maybe it symbolise the end August childish like growing up or maybe "a duck is just a duck" ... I love it!!!

I know, I know; I'm super late to the Wonder party. I've intended to read this for forever. It's the upcoming movie (featuring Daveed Diggs from the original cast of Hamilton!!!!) and nagging from my work wife and co-librarian that inspired me to finally give it a listen. And to say I'm glad I did is the understatement of 2017. Ohmygoodnessgracious, this book is absolute preciousness and one that everyone must read. Yes, its target marketing audience is upper elementary but its emotional audience is everyone with a beating heart. I highly recommend listening to this one as the audiobook is expertly and so, so sweetly narrated by several different and highly talented narrators who brought the story to life and made big, fat tears roll down my face many, many times while driving in my car (some were sad tears, most were happy ones). Although it can't possibly measure up to the book, I'm looking forward to seeing the movie (I'll be the one wearing no makeup and openly and loudly sobbing).
This is an amazing book. Recommend it highly and feel it should be on all middle school reading lists.
Great book for young adults, especially those with disabilities or siblings of those with disabilities.

"You are a Wonder" 
 4.5 Stars.

** spoiler alert ** 
 "Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a hard battle," said someone or other (probably Ian McLaren and not Plato.) Whoever put them together, those words kept coming to mind as I read Wonder - and not only for the most obvious reason. 
 Clearly, Auggie (August) Pullman is fighting a battle. His facial deformities and their associated medical complications have kept him out of school for the first ten years of his life. As the novel opens, he is set to enter fifth grade at a small private school in New York. This is a recipe for disaster, both interpersonal and literary. As many reviewers have noted, it's not easy to write a "kid with a conspicuous medical problem" novel and have it turn out anything but lurid or preachy. 
 Part of what keeps Wonder from that fate is the broadness and universality of its themes. At first, we see the world through Auggie's eyes - we are immersed in his battles. Then the perspective shifts, and we are in the head of his older sister, Via. Then Auggie's schoolmate, Jack. Then several other characters. With each one, we become aware that though Auggie's problems are the most conspicuous ones, he's not the only one struggling. Everyone is fighting a hard battle. Kindness given and received; courage in the face of social pressure - these themes are woven so tightly into the fabric of the book that it transcends the "problem novel" genre and becomes, like the very best books, a meditation on the nature of humanity. 
 That makes it sound heavier than it is, though. Palacio makes her point with humor, Magnetic Fields lyrics, and an impressively light touch. Short chapters, direct language, and skillful pacing make the book seem much shorter than its 320 pages. And the dialogue and social interactions ring true. I've taught fifth graders - in a private school, at that - and this is how they talk. This is how they act. It is also, without giving too much away, the way certain private school parents act. 
 Some people will say that the resolution is too neat, but I think it's appropriate for a middle-grade novel. I think the turning of the social tide is believable, and I think Auggie and Palacio earn their happy endings. 
 It's early in the year still, but this is at the very top of my Newbery list so far.
Read and enjoyed a year or two ago.
this book made me laugh and it made me cry. well done, rj palacio.
Great book intended for teens but definetly spoke volumes to me as an adult as well.
I was bored by some of the characters but thought the Julian chapter was important. Auggie sounds like a neat kid. Bit long.

Read my review here! 
 http://areadersrapture.blogspot.ca/20...

This is a wonderful debut novel about a little boy with a facial disfigurement and how the world reacts. Touching and heart-warming, it is beautifully written and will stay with you long after the last page.

My memory of this book is a little rusty because I read this in December of last year but I clearly remember enjoying it and getting through it quickly. It's one of those coming-of-age stories that tackles issues of prejudice, self-discovery and morality which has the potential to be dull and cliched, but it has several moments that make you want to whoop and punch the air. 
 There are many different voices speaking around the issue of facial disfigurement but it's really August, the protagonist of the story that keeps you turning the pages. He's witty, brave and understanding of his situation. Best of all he's understanding of the struggles others have with his physical appearance and shows so much resilience and patience that he is a central character worth investing in emotionally. Love 'im. 
 Surrounding August, there's pressures of society and the war of intolerance vs acceptance being raged around him (look out for the right honourable Headmaster and Julian, the vile classmate - not to mention his equally as vile mother!) but don't be fooled into thinking this is a simple story of heroes and villians. It's great for young people because the author gives us characters still making their minds up (like the readers) and showing several of the personality 'tropes' that you will probably find in any school. 
 It's all what you would except from books of this genre, but it's well written and highly uplifting. A hearty recommendation from me!

Marvellous book! Beautiful story! 
 This book, to me, is a celebration of the human spirit, reminding us to: 
 - Be yourself. 
 - Be courageous in life. 
 - Be compassionate and kinder to others. 
 ... And, confirms the age-old sayings: 
 - True beauty shines from within. 
 - Goodness always prevails. 
 I am so very glad to have finally read this book after passing by daily this gigantic wall post featuring this book cover and the students' reflections at my daughter's school since the beginning of the school year in September.

So many wonderful words have been written about this book that it is difficult to say anything new or insightful. August "Auggie" Pullman was born with a rare and debilitating facial deformity. Something of an urban legend in his north Manhattan community, Auggie is going to public school for the first time - middle school. The nebulous world of hormones and awkwardness mixed with social stigma and conformity. 
 Not only is this a story of Auggie's strength and courage, but the journey his classmates and family have to make to not only accept Auggie but to accept themselves. The journey outward always begins within. It is a story that is funny and heart-breaking and moving and makes us all realize that the best way to change the world is to look into the mirror.

First, I should point out that I'm 36 and this book is aimed at children, nevertheless, I really liked this book. It's the story of a ten-year-old boy with a disfigured face as he tries to make his way through his first year at school. 
 The book is in several sections, each from the point of view of a different character. These sections are well written and Palacio writes convincing characters with individual voices. I also like the fact that each section is split into very short chapters - it makes the book seem very quickly paced. 
 At times, it can be a little American and cheesey - especially at the end - but on the whole it avoids that and the central message of the book is one that I really like - that it's important to be kind. I'm going to encourage my son to read it and will possibly purchase a class set for the school in which I work as it's a good story for kids to read.

A very well done story that shows how everyone, no matter how well a front they present to the world, has their own problems. But, if we treat each other as we want to be treated, with kindness and respect, then we can all grow and succeed.
I didn't want it to end. Such a beautiful - and at times painful - story.
A sweet, heartwarming story!

Charming, sad, uplifting. Loved this little gem of a book recommended to me by a good friend. Although it is a book written for middle school aged children, it is great for adults as well. I couldn't put it down! Both of my kids are reading it and hopefully I will get my husband to read it.
I absolutely LOVED this book. I've already read this book 12 times and it never gets old. Once you read this your perspective of the way you look at things will it change!

Wonder is my favourite book, period. It's definitely a must read. Even thought it is appropriate for tween, adults and older kids will absolutely love it. You'll also love it even you aren't exactly a fan of realistic fiction. 
 Have you ever had problems? Lost your phone, sat alone at lunch for one day. Imagine that 100 times worse. No friends and no one to talk to. That's what August Pullman's life is like. Reading the the book you'll feel what it's like to be different through the authors amazing description of what goes through August's head. 
 You will definitely not regret reading it. Wonder will make your heart sing.
One of the most amazing books ever!!! Really unique!! And the perspectives in the book are also really awesome!
A book filled with great characters. You will fall in love with Auggie and his family and friends. A wonderful read for anyone who enjoys a coming of age story.

This book is amazing. I honestly think it should be a mandatory middle school book. August touched my heart. He was funny and charming in spite of his setbacks. This book dealt with bullying in a realistic manor which is refreshing. I loved every second of this sorry, I would follow August's story through college if I had the chance.

This book has so much heart and inspiration that anyone that reads it will look back on their life and regret all the things they have ever done that was mean and hurtful to someone. Don't judge a book by its cover. Looks aren't everything and for the people that are so superficial, they should realise that the most important thing in a person is their personality and soul. 
 This book could seriously change lives and perspectives.
Touching story, easy YA read.

This book was chosen by the Bitch of Month in my reading group. It is a juvenile lit book, but still has a great message for adults. Sadly, it seems that I run into more of the Julian's of the world and less the Summer's. I think that this book may quickly becoming a common part of the upper elementary reading list.

I chose this book because of all the positive feed back. As I began to listen I wasn't sure I was going to like it but boy am I glad I just kept listening! This is definitely a feel good book and one that inspires. By using several different characters view points along the way, the author R.J. Palacio, made this story much more real and interesting. Some may say that in parts it was to sappy or to good but I really do believe people will give their best when a situation calls for it. I am not an emotional person but I have to admit this book made me cry. A good kind of cry!

'Why am I so ugly, mom?' 
 That just breaks my heart. It was so painful to read those words. To hear those words came out of a 10 year old boy mouth. It just pains me. I applaud August's courage and tenacity to go to school and having to hear the whispers of other kids and being isolated. This boy just got my heart. 
 I absolutely love the principal's speech in the end about August.
Powerful and complex, Wonder takes you through so many emotions and the powerful lesson of kindness. I think every middle schooler, high schooler and adult should read this.

What an incredibly moving, heart warming novel. Every page brought you closer to Auggie, the main character. You felt what he felt, understood the reason behind his words and just GOT HIM in general. There's slight humor throughout, but I found myself holding back streams of tears in a few emotional parts. Wow. Get this book; whether you're 10 years old or 20 or even 50. Just read it. I promise you won't regret it.

Everything a novel for young people should be. Probably this is classified as mid-school reading, but I found it real, touching and inspiring, with not the smallest hint of saccharine. Give it to all the 8-year-olds and up.

I won a copy from the publisher off of Goodreads. :oD In just three short words, Wonder is wonderful! I am not certain if the book is categorized as young adult, but it would make a worth-while read for kids. In fact, I have volunteered to work on a bullying project and believe this book is a great one to add to a suggested reading list. 
 Ok, enough of the stuffy, clinical review and more of the nitty-gritty.... 
 I dare you to read this book and not cry. This is the story of a champion. A little 5th grade boy named Auggie who was born with severe facial deformities. He is perfectly functional in every way, minus complications from his cleft palate and other structural problems that interfere with development (for instance, because his ears are malformed, he has hearing problems though these are easily corrected with hearing aids). Auggie understands that when people see him their reactions run the spectrum from outright screams to polite but notable pauses as people take in what they are seeing. Yet, this little boy has the most terrific sense of humor and sensitivity that just steals your heart. I think the author wrote it best: 
 Justin notes regarding the outstanding chances of Auggie's facial predicament, "so doesn't that make the universe a giant lottery then?...my head swirls on this, but softer thoughts soothe...no, no, it's not all random, if it really was all random, the universe would abandon us completely and the universe doesn't. it takes care of its most fragile creations in ways we can't see. like with parents who adore you blindly. and a big sister who feels guilty for being human over you. and a little gravelly-voiced kids whose friends have left him over you. and even a pink-haird girl who carries your picture in her wallet. maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. the universe takes care of all its birds" (Palacio 2012, p. 204, lack of capitals author's choice). 
 Justin is speaking of Auggie's family and friends who look past Auggie's face to find the human worth knowing and worth being friends with, because without Auggie, their lives would be so much less. 
 Read this book. It is not a difficult or challenging read. You can read it on vacation or at the beach. It makes you feel good about people, because there are good people in this world. Auggie's principal gives the following J. M. Barrie quote at 5th grade graduation: "Shall we make a new rule of life...always try to be a littler kinder than is necessary?" (Palacio 2012, p. 299). Isn't that what makes life wonderful? Being a little kinder than needed and enjoying the gift of friendship, love, and enjoyment in return? 
 Auggie has the last word in the book and I think it is going on my wall of favorite quotes. He says, "Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." Well said, Auggie...very well said.

Always try to be a little kinder than is necessary. 
 Amazing words to live by. I didn't expect to love this story as much as I did, but after reading it, I can totally understand why kids love it so much. I hope the movie does it justice, and I hope that both the movie and the book touch kids in such a way that they will be forever changed for the better.
This book made me bawl. Super fast read, wonderfully written characters. and a big (mostly happy) cry fest.

I would recommend this book to everyone, but particularly those of us who work in Special Education, more notably inclusive schools. Sadly, it doesn't paint the American Education system in a very good light at all. Within this book, the reader comes to love most of the characters. The story centres around August Pulman, a young boy who was born with a severely disfigured face. He has been home schooled for most of his life, but his parents then decide to send him to a mainstream school. The rest of the story is how everyone copes with and is affected by this decision. This is an extremely life affirming story, and I shall probably read this one again and again. Of course, I particulary loved the Bowie references, too!

I had read so many positive reviews of Wonder from teachers I respect, that I knew that I had to read this book. Frankly, though, I didn't expect to love it as much as they did. Heartwarming realistic fiction just isn't my thing these days. I was wrong. 
 Nothing could have prepared me for the simple and powerful story in these pages. As a fifth grade teacher, reading about fifth graders, from the first-person perspective of fifth graders, I am simply amazed by how RJ Palacio knows these children. 
 Initially I rated Wonder 5 stars, but on further reflection I reduced it to 4. The ending of Wonder is just a bit too Mighty Ducks for me: "And everyone lived happily ever after." That's nice and feels good, but it's just not very real. 
 I really want to share this book with my class. I love how it illustrates the complexities surrounding motivations and impacts of our actions. I also found her portrayal of social dynamics at this age to be both accuracte and instructive. I only hesitate to read this aloud because of a few references to boobs and kissing.
Excellent book, everyone should read it! za story of love and understanding!

This book could be described in one word: hopeful 
 It gives you this kid with an inescapable problem and shows how he lives with that and learns to love himself, to see beyond what's wrong and enjoy life to the fullest. 
 Still, I think that killing the dog was unnecessary drama and would have liked to be warned about it.

Absolutely loved this book and the message engraved in the pages, I read this on a whim due to being in a reading slump and devoured the story! I loved August so much and his story, if you haven't read this, what are you waiting for? This is a book that everyone should read and take something from and become a little better because of it. Choose kind.
This book is emotional and amazing. It describes how looks don't always matter!

This one kept appearing as a top-rated book, so I picked it up without really paying attention that it is a young, YOUNG adult book, like perhaps middle school-ish. It took a while to get used to the simple sentence structure, but the themes were anything but simplistic. This was a heartfelt read about August, who was born with a severe facial deformity and at age 10 is going to regular school for the first time. August takes us through what it feels like endure the looks, the stares, the sometimes mean comments of his every day life. It is his journey towards acceptance, most importantly of himself. Teaches wonderful lessons about friendship, family, and understanding -- my favorite being: "Be kinder than necessary." I'm going to pass this book to every middle-schooler (and adult) I can.
Fabulous. Simple, realistic, sweet.

I'm going to go ahead and mark this as 'read' for the kids. This was bought in 2012, and languished on my shelf (through no fault of its own) till the 12-year-old was to read it for Lit at school. The nine-year-olds read it along with us and soon said book is hijacked and no longer in my possession! Very readable, surprisingly unintimidating and good fodder for thought even for the young readers.

I try to go into books with as much blindness as possible, especially if it's a recommendation - Just tell me that you liked it, not what you liked about it as I want to learn all of that on my own. Wonder came highly recommended by several people whose opinions I respect, and all I knew about it was that it was about "a boy who sort of looks like Owen Meany", and armed only with that little bit of foreknowledge, I was a go to read. And what a read it was! I am diligent about never giving spoilers when I talk about books, movies, or television, so I won't comment on the plot or any of the incidents that drive it other than to say that, to me at least, everything that happened was totally believable and the book moved naturally and very quickly, and all of the emotional check-boxes that Palacio set out to fill were ticked. I didn't even realize that this was a YA novel until I got it, and honestly, I think classifying it thusly might be a disservice - Yes, this book is good for kids, but it should really be read by everyone. And that includes you.

Wonder is the depute novel by R.J. Palcaio and what a debut it is. This is an AMAZING novel that will tug at your heart strings and make you think twice about how you treat others. 
 August (Auggie) Pullman only wants to be a "normal" kid who is about the start 5th Grade. Auggie has an amazing parents and sister. Unlike his classmates Auggie has been home schooled up until now. This will be his first time attending school. Being the new kid is always hard, but for Auggie, it's twice as hard. August Pullman got the rotten end of the gene pool and was born with a severe facial deformity. When the going gets tough, Auggie sticks it out and ends up surprising both himself and those around him. 
 The majority of the time, we judge people based on their looks. In our society, the better looking you are, the more popular you tend be. August Pullman shows us why that is not always the case. 
 This book is tended for middle schoolers, however, I feel it should be required reading for high school students and adults as well. The theme here, as R.J. Pullman puts it "Don't judge a boy by his face." 
 Society can be cruel, but if you stick it out, amazing things can happen. 
 Everyone can take something away from the amazing novel.

with all the hype, I was expecting so much more. it was good, I enjoyed it and loved the characters. I liked it, but it wasn't amazing, which I was thinking it was going to be. I probably would have given it 4 stars, had I not read all the hype :/
One of the best books I've read! Every middle school student should read it! In fact, any age person should read it!

August Pullman was born with a 'craniofacial anomaly' and has had several corrective surgeries to give him a more normal appearance but he is still exceedingly shocking to behold. He is a bright boy and has been home-schooled over the years, but now it has been decided that it is in his best interest to attend fifth grade at Beecher Prep School--which is like leading a lamb to slaughter. The story Wonder is the story of the great courage and character it took for this fragile boy to face the harsh, often cruel and judgmental world of the schoolyard, one day at a time, and not only survive, but prosper. 
 It is a very moving story and probably a good one for middle-school children to read to learn more about what it feels like to be so different on the outside yet only desiring to be seen as normal and to be accepted. 
 The book and its happy ending struck me as a bit pollyannic though. We all know children who were never accepted by their peers because they were different in some way and came through their school years with scars and wounds. The tragedy of school shootings shows what a bad job our society has been doing in teaching tolerance, acceptance and inclusion.
