 A quote used at the commencement address by the principal expresses an ideal world, "'It was at moments such as these that [he] recognized the face of God in human form. It glimmered in their kindness to him, it glowed in their keenness, it hinted in their caring, indeed it caressed in their gaze.'"
A MUST-READ for all teachers, parents, children, and humans.
Ft. Star Wars.

Have you ever read a book that seemed life-changing to you? 
 I think I just read one. 
 This one. 
 "Wonder" has left a very, very, VERY deep impression on me. I don't think I'd ever forget about this book and the emotions evoked in me when I read it. 
 It's THAT amazing. 
 Yes, I may read more books about zombies, apocalypses, aliens and all that stuff, but I do love my fair share of contemporary fiction. Books that make me FEEL. Books that contain drama and oscar-worthy performances of their characters. Books like "Wonder" here. 
 August is just like any other 10-year-old kid, except for how he looks. Due to genetic makeups and mutations, plus numerous surgeries done on his face, August doesn't look normal. But inside, he is. And he wants to be treated like he is. 
 "Wonder" tells the story of August and his relationship with other people, including society as a whole, in the context of dealing with his facial deformity (I think deformity is a harsh word but I can't think of any other word to substitute it right now). We get to follow August through his first-time journey at a regular school, and although the book is narrated from his perspective, the book includes viewpoints from the people around August, which just makes the story much more wholesome and complete. I'm not going to reveal whose perspectives are in the book -- because for me, I loved the surprise when I find out who's the next character I'd be immersed in. That's the joy of reading, isn't it? :) 
 Palacio has done a brilliant and incredible job creating the characters in "Wonder". To me, they were very realistic, and throughout the book I was constantly reminded via Palacio's smooth and amazing writing that they are just being human, and their vulnerability shows. I mean, face it, if I were August and I'm used to stares, mean words, insults and bullying, there's still a limit to how much I can take. There are going to be days when life just sucks and I'd break down. Because I'm only human. Yet in the book, August could actually poke fun at himself too, which totally makes him one awesome person. Seriously, what's there in life if you couldn't even poke fun of yourself from time to time? 
 The feelings that overcame me while reading "Wonder" were indescribable. I laughed, I teared up, I smiled; sometimes I felt cold and bleak at certain stuff, and others were heartwarming. It was such a wonderful mix of emotions! 
 One really great thing about this book is that I really learnt a whole lot of life lessons from it. One of which is that life is fair. I know almost all of us (including me) complain and whine about life being unfair as it is, but this book right here made me take a step back and look at the big picture, to really SEE that even if God (or the Universe if you're an atheist) didn't give you something in life that you want, He made it up to you in different ways. You'd understand better if you read the book, trust me. 
 In short, "Wonder" is a book about love, life, friendship, family, courage, kindness, acceptance and being human. If there's a soundtrack to "Wonder", it would most suitably be Christina Aguilera's "Beautiful". Palacio even included an except of the song lyrics in the book! 
 I don't want to only recommend, but I NEED everyone out there to read "Wonder". And I mean everyone. I'd bet it will change your life perspectives, even if it's just a bit. 
 I'll just leave a quote that was used in the book, which I thought was an excellent one: "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." - Dr. Wayne W. Dyer. 
 Rating: 10/5 (Because it deserves all 5 and more!)
It was AWESOME!! I fall in love with it! It was so creative so heartbroken and so magical! I had a great time while i was reading!!
A very moving poignant look at the life of a boy and the people around him. I cried at multiple points, but that could be just cause I'm a softy.
Beautiful, touching read. And it was especially special that I got to "book club" it with my 10-year old niece.

This book is so wonderful and touching, however sometimes a little hard to read. 
 Its concept seeing August also through different eyes of people who are touching and changing his life works just great. 
 August wins you right over with his funny and smart personality and makes you want to hug him all the time. His story touches your heart with humor and intelligence as well as so much love as someone has to give. 
 Wonder is written with the such a great sensitivity, human emotions and insight that it became a really uplifting story about courage, determination, fear and real friendship. 
 I can highly recommend this book, specially to all younger readers!

I thought it was an ok read but there were some things that bothered me (probably also because I have passed a bit the target age group for this book). I didn't like the fact that you couldn't really tell the perspectives apart. All kids tended to think in the same way, even though three of them are 5 years older than the rest. I also thought that some characters (such as Summer and August's parents) were behaving unrealistically positive all the time. But this can too be justified by the targeted audience. 
 I think it makes an interesting read for a child or young adult even, and quite possibly it raises some issues they might not be aware of. For an adult though, the book doesn't bring that much.

5 stars [?][?][?][?][?] and 5 hearts [?][?][?][?][?] 
 that's how much i love this book.

I think this book should be mandatory reading for all middle school students. Not only does it promote kindness but it teaches forgiveness. Friends sometimes make mistakes and do or say hurtful things. Leadership,doing the right thing, loving yourself no matter what. Love all the messages in this book.

A sweet, fast read. Perfect for teaching children/tweens/teens and reminding adults about the importance of compassion, kindness and empathy. It told a story through various perspectives and would have liked to have heard the parents' perspective.
Absolutely beautiful book for teens and adults alike.

Wow!! This novel is so heart-melting, I think everyone needs to read this book in their lives. I was glad when the books was based around a middle grade, and actually turned out good, not too overly-dramatic either. The books written in multiple narratives which I love so much! Truly well done to R.J

Este libro me ha durado lo mismo que un trozo de chocolate: nada. 
 He de decir que este libro constaba como alternativa si no encontraba mis otros libros en la tienda. No encontre uno, asi que acabe comprandome este. Todo un error, tuvo que ser mi plan A desde el principio 
 Lo que hace especial a este libro es el dilema moral que se nos plantea entre sus hojas. Responderme a una cosa: Cuando vais por la calle, y veis por ejemplo a, no se, una chica con pelo verde chillon. ?No la mirais aunque sea 1 segundo porque no es algo que veais todos los dias? Y ahora os pregunto, ?Y si fuera un nino con un sindrome de deformidad facial? 
 Aqui encontramos el Quid de la cuestion. Yo doy el primer paso y confieso que lo miraria. Ahora viene lo mas importante: ?Le miro porque quiero hacerle dano? ?Tirarle una piedra? ?Pegarle? No. Simplemente lo he observado un momento, no tengo la finalidad de incomodarle, de hacerle dano, pero lo hago. Y es que, muchas veces hacemos dano sin querer hacerlo. 
 Esa es la frase que mas me ha marcado del libro. Me ha ayudado a darle el valor que se merece. No puedo odiar absolutamente a ningun personaje de esta obra, a ninguno. Me he puesto en el punto de vista de Jack, de Via, de Justin, y de todos los que pueblan la novela. Todos queremos que el mundo sea de luz y color, pero no lo es, la vida es dura, buena y mala a partes iguales, y tenemos que convivir con ello. 
 He llegado a comprender el agobio de Jack, la soledad en cierta parte de Via, el rechazo de las personas, y por supuesto el dolor de August. Y es que, no culpo a ninguno. 
 Es una novela que pondria en cada aula de cada centro de ensenanza. Una novela de sabor agridulce, ni feliz, ni triste. Y eso es algo que se debe aprender de la vida, que es agridulce 
 Os lo recomiendo a todos y cada uno de vosotros.

Amazing Read! I absolutely LOVED this book, It is seriously right up there with my favorite reads. 
 August is a 15 year old boy with major birth defects that affect how his face looks drastically,. He has dealt with the stares and gasps from strangers thru out his life, and mostly him Mother has kept his "safe" at home while she homeschooled him. It isnt until August agrees to try out 5th grade in a real school that things get rocking. 
 I fell in love with August,His parents, his sister, his Dog,almost every character 
 This was one of those books, I did not want to end, I'll admit, as the pages dwindled down I got a little anxious knowing the story would end soon- LOVE books like these 5 STARS and, I will be on the look out for more books by this author
I absolutely loved this book.

"We carry with us, as human beings, not just the capacity to be kind but the very choice of kindness." 
 This book is remarkable. I think all of America (including some elected officials) should read this. It's beyond necessary. Speaking of necessary: "If every single person in this room made it a rule that, wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary- the world really would be a better place."
It only took us forever but what a GREAT book. Everyone needs to read it. Thanks Kristine for sharing it with us!

Oh the feels. This book is simply amazing. The writing is beautiful. The characters are deep and well developed. I listened to this book on audio and was so surprised when the book changed to different characters' perspectives. The ability to step outside of August's world and hear how things were through the eyes of those around him pulled me so much further into the story. I cried so many times while listening. His mother is the mother I strive to be, and his principal and teachers reminded me how I should be when working with kids. There was not a single thing I didn't love about this book and it's overwhelming message to be kind is something I wish I could share with everyone I meet. Everyone should read this book. Loved it 100%.
This is the best book I have read this year. I hope it wins the Newbery. I am encouraging both my sons to read it.

This was an incredible book that people of all ages should read with its themes of perseverance, acceptance, friendship, family relationships, and biases against people who are different. The character of August/ Auggie is resilient as he attempts going to school for the first time in Grade 5 after having a series of surgeries related to his facial deformities. The descriptions of his relationships with his sister Via and his parents are loving and devoted. Each section of the book is devoted to a different character's perspective, and it is interesting to read their views and personalities. Not too sure if I will see the movie, since Julia Roberts plays the mother even though in the book her ethnic background is important to her character. And Owen Wilson as the father? Not too sure about that one.

I ended up really liking this young-adult book. It's a quick, easy read, with short chapters and a straightforward writing style. 
 It's the story of a grade 5 boy who has a severely mis-shaped face and head. He has to deal with being seen as different all the time, and is excluded and bullied. The story focuses on relationships, and some is told from the boy's own point of view, some from his sister's, and some from friends'. 
 It actually reminded me a lot of a film I saw recently that didn't seem to get a lot of attention, but deals with similar issues, called "That's What I Am". 
 It's a very emotional book, and definitely worth reading.
For a book aimed at a younger audience this is fantastic! Is it a masterpiece? No, but it is a touching story and gets the point across beautifully.
WONDER-FUL ;)

I've been stuck in the YA blackhole for sometime now, but picking this book, I knew I went overboard. This is a children's book, yes, a book for 10-year olds alongside The Wonderful Wizard of Oz and The Lion, the Witch, & the Wardrobe. Nevertheless, it has so much heart and soul that adults will sob and laugh. It's bold and engaging and simultaneously sad and funny, while tackling a sensitive yet realistic topic that we're all constantly faced with. 
 While I was reading this book, I was thinking how nice it would be if this would be a required reading to grade school students. Everyone - adults and children alike - will learn so much from this book.
I totally understand why this is so popular for school reading! This book reminded me that kindness isn't always natural and easy. And sometimes we don't even realize we're being unkind.

"Piu gentili del necessario. Perche non e sufficiente essere gentili. Bisogna essere piu gentili di quanto ci viene richiesto." 
 Questo libro e davvero bellissimo, mi ha commossa molto. 
 Una storia dolcissima dalla trama semplice ma che contiene temi meravigliosi che possono insegnare e far riflettere molto sia ai ragazzi che agli adulti: la gentilezza, l'accettazione del diverso, il coraggio... 
 Consigliatissimo.
A wonderful , thought provoking book.

No one can argue with the message of this book, but the execution is definitely hit-or miss, depending on how much tolerance you have for "warm and fuzzy". I definitely think that kindness and empathy are the two most important human qualities, but when it gets rubbed in my face the idea loses its emotional appeal.

Everyone should read this book at least once in their lifetime. Yes, it's a book about a boy born with a "deformity" but it's not because it's about all the things Auggie teaches us and his classmates like the meaning of being a friend.
Loved the many voices within this novel.

My Take to follow Amazon description: "August Pullman was born with a facial difference that, up until now, has prevented him from going to a mainstream school. Starting 5th grade at Beecher Prep, he wants nothing more than to be treated as an ordinary kid--but his new classmates can't get past Auggie's extraordinary face. WONDER, now a #1 New York Times bestseller and included on the Texas Bluebonnet Award master list, begins from Auggie's point of view, but soon switches to include his classmates, his sister, her boyfriend, and others. These perspectives converge in a portrait of one community's struggle with empathy, compassion, and acceptance. " 
 My take: I've had this book on my kindle shelf for about 2 years and I am kicking myself that I did not read it when my kids had to read it for middle school. Everything about this book is perfect , from the heart wrenching concept to the heartwarming characters. The messages in this book are truly inspirational. Must read for kids and grownups alike.
i think that this book was really good but that Julian was pretty mean to Auggie.
Fabulous. Absolutely amazing read!

This was a book club read and I didn't like it much. Perhaps it was just too juvenile, or maybe I just didn't find the plot very interesting - I'm not sure. 
 It was well written and the different pint of view chapters worked well to form the whole which is why Im' giving it the 2 stars, but this wasn't one for me.
This was very cute. I thought it would be more heart breaking, but I still really enjoyed it. A full review is to come.
Read this in third grade XD im in high school now so i remember most of it
Everyone, children and adults should read this book.
this is such a beautiful coming of age story!! this got me out of of a reading slump... beautiful
LOVED it. A very special book.
Such a beautiful and lovely story.I don't know why but the ending reminded me of Harry Potter lol. You know, the friendship was just goals.

A tragic, heartwarming debut novel from R.J. Palacio. She masterfully captures the awkward, middle school aged student, struggling to fit in at school. For August Pullman this is exceptionally more difficult, due to his severe facial deformity. I found myself rooting for August the whole time and wondering myself how he would meld into the school community. While August develops and learns a lot along the way, his classmates and the reader, are changed for the better, as well. This book would make an ideal class or family read aloud and many discussions are sure to occur, given the opportunity.
It shed me to tears! Wonderful wonderful book!
This book made me cry a few times. I enjoyed it, it's a quick read. I highly recommend parents to read it and share the book with their kids. Empathy. Kindness. Courage. Perspective.
My 11-year-old daughter has an uncanny way of knowing which books I'll love and which books will make me cry. Wonder was definitely one of those books!

I wasn't ever the new kid at school, because I went to school from Kindergarten to Graduation with over 75% of my graduating class so I don't know how it is to be the new kid. I can only hope that when Michael was the new kid in 1st grade that it went okay with him. He never talked about having any issues, but that doesn't mean that things didn't happen that he really didn't want his dad or I to know about. Connor wasn't the new kid because he started Kindergarten with the other kids. 
 I originally bought this book so Michael and I could read it together, and then when I told him about it, he said that his 5th grade class is currently reading it and once they're finished with it, they will get to go watch the movie together. I purchased it Sunday, started it Monday morning [had to finish previous books I was reading] and I finished it this morning. Definitely not one of my fastest reads, and that is okay. I really wanted to savor the story so I tried to read it as slowly as I possibly could! 
 Everytime Isabel spoke in the book, knowing that Julia Roberts is going to be playing her in the movie, I could imagine her speaking. Same with the dad, I read his parts as Owen Wilson's voice! 
 I think the book brings a good message with it. Be kind. Not everyone is going to look like everyone else expects to be normal. And I think people shouldn't pick on those who they don't think are normal looking. I did enjoy getting to read other people's views on Auggie and what they had to endure as well. Summer, Jack, Via and Justin told their stories and I did enjoy that. 
 I think this should be a book that is required to be read in 5th grade, because face it, that's when popularity primarily becomes a thing and kids get mean. They start picking on other kids around that time frame (I'm not saying 5th grade specifically).

This is the book I am recommending for book club next year. We've read YA books before and have loved them. This one is extra special because of the wonderful lesson surrounding the protagonist, Auggie Pullman. if this generation of young folk learns to "act a little kinder than is necessary", I hope to live long enough to see them put it in action in the adult world.

I think this book should be assigned reading for all elementary students. Its message is really valuable. I enjoyed how it was told from several different perspectives. It felt a little long sometimes, especially in the descriptions that didn't seem to matter much. It was heartbreaking at times, but I wouldn't say it's a tear jerker or anything. The conclusion is wonderful and helps you believe that kids will choose kindness in the end.
I borrowed this from the library and then immediately bought a copy to loan to everyone I knew. It's a must read.
Absolutely phenomenal book. Completwly lived up to the hype and all the glowing critical reviews. A treasure that I will definitely read again.

A friend of mine read this book and said that every kid and parent should read it - and she was right! My 8 year old daughter is reading it for a book club at school and so I snuck away with it when she wasn't using it and read it myself. What a wonderful story with so many good lessons and 'precepts' to live by! The author does a great job of creating the characters and telling Auggie's story from each perspective. This book truly is a Wonder!
A book for youngest but still really enjoyed it

Felt all the feels. I laughed, I cried. I was outraged one moment and then whooping in triumph the next. The characters in this book just completely stole my heart. I wish I could scoop them all up in a huge hug!

Superb book. One that should be on the curriculum, dealing with intolerance and acceptance, bullying and disfigurement. 
 Wonderful narrator in Auggie, and good chapters and views from other characters and family members filling in the picture. 
 Makes you question your own views on disfigurement. 
 Very well-written, well paced and a beautiful ending. Tissues will be needed.
I truly engaged every single emotion reading this. I believe all students, regardless of age should read this...and parents too, because adults can be the meanest critics of them all. I loved this!

I finally finished this book. I started to read it back when it was released but never finished it. So this week in preparation for the movie I decided to start over and took out the audio book from library. It's an amazing book about friendship and how we all should be kind. There was one part in the book that I cried. Everyone should read this book. Can't wait for the movie to come out.
beautiful

I selected this book to read because it was one of the highest rated books in my "to-read" list - and I agree: "Wonder" was wonderful. Even though it was written from the perspectives of children and teens, this book is very appropriate and engaging for adults. I was saddened and delighted to tears several times during the book. Having known a few children (and even adults) in my life with severe disabilities, I certainly could relate to the feelings of many of the characters, both "good" and "bad". But even the main character - August, with all his facial imperfections, which I could not fathom dealing with myself - has much to teach me about dealing with my own deficiencies and lacking. If you have ever excluded someone or been excluded; or taken up for someone, or have had someone take up for you, you will relate to this story. "Wonder" tells the story of what love and kindness are, and how such virtues can change and empower both the givers and the receivers... and the readers.

It is a story about a ten years old boy named August, he is known for his difference. He was born with facial deformity that made him look different, eat different. But, he is just a normal boy being judged by his appearance. 
 The story is told by him and how he survived the 5th grade.

I think this is a solid story. Relatable and thought provoking for all ages. I think it will stand the test of time. I liked the format of the story being told from all the character's differing points of view. I really liked Mr. Browne's precepts. I like stories with good teachers in them. Well told. Well done.
This book was beautiful, inspiring, and uplifting. Everyone needs to read this one.
This one-day read should be a requirement for every human being. LOVED IT!

Wonder-is an engrossing story of a sheltered severely disfigured boy who becomes transformed and transforms those around him when he starts attending a private school in fifth grade. I liked that the story is presented in sections chapters written by each character so the reader gains insight into the motives of each person.

I loved every page! Quick, delightful read. I loved all the characters; such a well told story of kindness. There truly is so much goodness in the world, and I enjoy books like this that highlight all the joy that can still be found amidst the toils in life.

Told from multiple points of view, in very distinct voices, which leads to a nicely rounded story, though Auggie, the "wonder." Tells the bulk of the story. 
 It's tough starting a new school, and the move to middle school, and then high school is a source of stress and change for most children. But Auggie Pullman has an added bonus--facial abnormalities, that, despite multiple surgeries, are quite obvious. People stare at him all the time. And kids can be cruel. But they also can be kind... wonderfully so.

This was a great YA book. My 10 year old read it and recommended that I read it after him. I'm so happy I did! The characters were realistic and the story was heartwarming. I loved seeing the story through so many different perspectives. If you have a child 10-14, they should read this book!

Nicely written and very moving at many times. I give Palacio props for capturing interesting, seemingly authentic little details that make her protagonist and his world really come alive. 
 Palacio tells the story from the POV of several characters and although they all express themselves differently and offer different perspectives, they still kind of sound alike. 
 Now I will sound like an absolute grinch: this is SUCH a feel-good story that it felt really forced and artifical by the end. Trying to avoid spoilers, but EVERYONE IS REDEEMED? OR ELSE THEY GO AWAY? Life just isn't like this, and this book is realistic in most other ways. 
 Plus, I'd like to declare a moratorium on books and movies ending with an adult giving a long and profound speech. (I'm looking at you, Crazy, Stupid, Love. and your wacky punctuation.) Especially books that are about young people--who apparently need a Lecture About How Special They Are.

This book is supposed to be a "quick read" but not to me... anyways I finished it and I love it! It's such an aspiring story about friendship, courage and kindness told from different characters point of views, but all I have to say it's amazing! I really recommend!
This is a book that will change your life for the better! I really loved it!

a powerful story of an ordinary boy born with a severe facial deformity and his first year in a public school (a middle school) Auggie Pullman's wisdom and tolerance and sense of humor will captivate you and crack your heart open.

Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful book. 
 I listened to it on audiobook, which was an amazing idea.

Wonder is one of those books that just begs to be on the shelf for "the librarian recommends..." It's about a young boy, with extreme facial deformities, entering school for the first time and meeting people outside his otherwise insulated world. 
 Imagining that the author does not go for the tear jerker depressing but life affirming ending, and you could probably figure the rest out. Really. Wonder only offered a few surprises. (Note, I don't think these are spoilers, but if you like even minor surprises to be surprises, don't read any further.) 
 -About forty pages in, the novel changes narrative but tells some overlapping stories in time. This saved so much about this book for me. The narration style of August alone was very accurately juvenile, and though that is an accomplishment, does not always make for the most engaging reading. Besides, because of the circumstances his character faces, he has no choice but to be an unreliable narrator. It was nice to compare perspectives on collective experiences. In addition, when the focus of the novel relies so heavily on the impact of one character's situation, it is almost a relief to be reminded that even something so personal as August's syndrome can have a huge impact on the lives of others. It also serves to remind the reader that everyone on varying degrees struggles with identity and acceptance, and thus could benefit tremendously from a kindness that is "more than is necessary." 
 -The book brings about a variety of unique elements to its otherwise commonplace tropes and motifs. Little things like the dad and Auggie listening to the Magnetic Fields made me smile. The teacher's treatment of the "precepts" for the month were neat. 
 But otherwise...well nothing was wrong, it just was not too memorable in the end. I recommend it, but I can't bring myself to rave about it. Give it a whirl if you just feel like a feel good sort of story that is quickly paced.

Simple story. Simple truths. With a hell of a lot of heart. That's what Wonder is. 
 Read full review at: 
 http://theinsomniacbibliophile.blogsp...

Auggie starts 5th grade - the first time going to school due to his facial deformity and several surgeries to correct it. This heartfelt but not corny story of "fitting in" and how to be kind is told in a unique way. There are eight sections, each told from a different character's point of view (Auggie tells three sections). Readers will relate to the bullying incidents in the plot, but the telling is what makes this stand out. I really appreciated that the adults were not just stereotypes but well-rounds characters - both parents and teachers. And a lot of the students act inappropriately, especially at first, but many but not all come around to the fact that the way one acts toward another is more about you than that other person.
This book is amazing.

I just re-read this book for book club. the copy I bought contained the Julian chapter, which was not in the original book. This chapter adds so much more to the narrative that I urge readers to look for this! This little book is a gem that I hope will be taught in middle schools for years to come. an instant classic.
The book was a heart touching story and eye opening one that everybody at all ages should read
Not bad at all, but didn't pay attention to the fact this isn't for adults. A great book for the YA population, however.

A heart-warming story. Some people are saying that it isn't believable for kids this age to be kind in a situation like this one. I disagree. Kids can be even more kind than adults. They can be champions for injustice. They can be blind to differences. I've seen it first hand. Does it always happen? No, and especially not right away as this book implies. Read this book if you are losing hope in humanity.
What a great book! I think every student entering middle school should read this book, and every middle school teacher as well.

Check out my quick review at http://tinyurl.com/cdz9lnu 
 Palacio R J
Turned out to be one heck of a great book!!!!
What a truly great book. I'm really loving all the new YA books I've been introduced to working at a Middle School.
An unforgettable novel of pure delight cannot recommend highly enough
Wow, such an amazing book. Shows both the cruelty and kindness that kids can have. 10/10 recommend!!

For some reason, even though this book was recommended highly to me, I just didn't feel like reading it. So when my hold was up I decided to dive in. It took me a little over 24 hours to finish. I didn't want to read another heartbreaking tale of a disadvantaged (in this case "deformed") child trying to make their way in the world because I just came off a really sad tale about a child. I was ready for a "feel good" book. This was that. It reminds you of the good in the world. Just when you are waiting for the bad part, you want to stand up in cheer because it isn't so bad. This is a great book and I really enjoyed reading it.

Wonder introduces us to August ("Auggie"), a 10 year-old boy who is born with a horribly disfigured face. Homeschooled his whole life, his parents finally make the decision to send Auggie to 5th grade in the local public school. What follows is an incredible story of family, friendship, and the triumph of humanity and kindness. 
 Every now and then, a book moves me. Wonder is that kind of book - the kind where you run into other parents in the school yard, you chat with your children's teachers, you call up your friends and family with kids and say: YOU HAVE TO READ THIS BOOK. Everyone should read this book. No, wait... every middle grade school should read this book. It should be part of middle grade curriculum. No, everyone should read this book. There's a lesson here for everyone. 
 Auggie is one of the most endearing main characters I have run across in a very long time. As he is introduced, we do not know exactly what is wrong with Auggie or why. This is what the author does so well, in revealing his disfigurement, providing only small glimpses so that we get to know the real Auggie before we can only see him as horribly disfigured. Of course, we have that luxury as readers, but those who would encounter Auggie in person would see his disfigurement right away; thus, as readers, we have a very different experience in getting to know Auggie. 
 Based on what we know about bullying in schools, we would anticipate that a child like Auggie would be a magnet to being abused, mocked, or excluded. This DOES happen, but what is so beautiful is that there are many other children who look past Auggie's "face" and see what a "wonder"-ful person he is on the inside - something we see as readers all along. Additionally, these children go a step further to stand up to the bully and choose their own path. This is so well done! 
 And then there is Mr. Browne, the English teacher, and his precepts. Each month the children are giving a precept (i.e., "motto", "quote", etc.) to ponder and write an essay about. While there are many noteworthy ones I can highlight, it is the first that is the most poignant: 
 "WHEN GIVEN THE CHOICE BETWEEN BEING RIGHT OR BEING KIND, CHOOSE KIND" 
 I just about had a heart attack when I read that! I have been living by those EXACT words for 20 years after I first encountered a similar quote in the 1950's movie Harvey starring Jimmy Stewart (by the way, there are many, many fabulous quotes in that movie). This is the quote from the movie: 
 "Years ago my mother used to say to me, she'd say, 'In this world, Elwood, you must be' - she always called me Elwood - 'In this world, Elwood, you must be oh so smart or oh so pleasant.' Well, for years I was smart. I recommend pleasant. You may quote me. 
 Same idea right?! So, although there are other equally relevant precepts, this is the one that will stay with the reader because it is so simple: We can choose kind. As I was reading through the book, I was thinking to myself, "This is not going to end well." I was oh-so-wrong and I can say that at the end, tears streaming down my face I felt HOPE that if just given the words, given the options, children CAN choose kind. 
 I honestly can't rave enough about this book. 
 One note however ... my 10 year-old daughter read this book as well. She did enjoy it, but I really sensed that it underwhelmed her. I think that at her age, there is an expectation that a book is purely entertaining. That is, books should be filled with fantasy, magic, adventure, alternate realities, and so on. This is not THAT kind of book. This is REAL. This is a book that elicits 101 great discussions and that is why I think it she wasn't over-the-moon about it the same way I was. I still think it should be required reading in school.

Wow, a great read. Due to his many medical needs Auggie has been homeschooled through the fourth grade. Now, he's about to begin 'real' school for the first time and meet new kids who don't know about his 'condition'. Auggie's face is so deformed he won't even describe it to you. All his life he's had to deal with people staring - now it will be a whole schoolfull. 
 Told from Auggie's own voice, his sister and new friends, Wonder takes the reader on a rollercoaster ride of discovery and growth. 
 I would recommend for ages 10 and up, a great read for parents to read in conjuction with their kids. Lots of opportunities to discuss with this one.

I had to read this book for my Children's literature class, and I'm so glad that my professor chose this book. I fell in love with Auggie and the world that he lives in. Each of the characters are relatable in some aspect, and I would definitely recommend Wonder to anyone who loves to read and even those who don't enjoy reading.

"AUGUST PULLMAN'S PRECEPT 
 Everyone deserves a standing ovation because we all overcometh the world. --Auggie" 
 -------------------------------------------------------- 
 "If every person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 I JUST LOVE THIS BOOK!

I absolutely adored this book. If you could only read one book in your life, I definitely feel that it should be this one. It truly teaches the value of one's self worth, the unimportance of appearance, and the value of friends who are supportive. This book made me appreciate the life I have, the friends I have, and the opportunities that I am given. A must read.

Beautiful story! Can't wait to see the movie. Perfect for reading in 5th grade. I didn't know you got various perspectives/narrators. It really adds to the book and it's perfect for the classroom. So glad I finally read it!

This should be a mandatory book every kid should read at the end of primary school. Goodbye Lord of the Flies and say hello to Wonder. This book speaks so well about empathy, kindness and the effects of bulling. I was drawn into the story and struggled putting the book down. What a great read highly recommend. Love the Auggies of the world!
This is a very powerful book that should be read in Fifth grade classrooms across the globe.

Wonder-ful. Well crafted writing dealing with some rather difficult parts of growing up, for anyone, much less someone with the kinds of obstacles Auggie and his family face. The characters feel well rounded and real. . .even the ones we don't get to spend as much time with.
An incredible story about the power of kindness!
I like Wonder.

I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives. 
 Wow...this book was amazing! I usually prefer books with action or a dark theme, but I decided to try something new with this one. 
 My name is August, by the way. I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse. 
 August (Auggie) Pullman was born with many craniofacial anomalies. This causes him to be anxious to start 5th grade at Beecher Prep. A month before school, the principal invites Auggie to take a special tour of the school and meet a few of the kids who will be his class. What will ensue, is a journey through 5th, of determining who is truly kind, or uses it as a facade to make them look better. Normally, books do not get to me emotionally, but this one did. I hope you will read this!

This is a book that's gonna stay with me for a long, long time. 
 August Pullman was born looking...different from everybody else. His eyes are about an inch below where they should be, he has "cauliflower ears," and people often ask him if he was burned in a fire. Aside from outer appearance, Auggie is just like everybody else, but not many people look past his face to realize that. This becomes apparent when, after being homeschooled his entire life, he decides to go to a regular school in the fifth grade. This story goes through Auggie's school year and the trials and transformations that come with it. 
 Not only is August a lovable, memorable character, but every single character also has a well-developed backstory that takes you into their lives. I felt like I knew everyone in August's class, and because of that I was attached to them all and I hoped so strongly for a happy ending for each of them. 
 This story also taught valuable lessons that resonate to audiences of all ages. The messages of kindness and acceptance were present throughout the book, even being included in the Dean's graduation speech. This book made me want to go out and do something nice for someone else, and I closed this book with a genuine smile on my face. 
 Also, real quick, I just want to say that there was a reference in this book to almost everything I love. There was Green Day, Beauty and the Beast, Star Wars, the Beatles...there's something for everyone. There is not one person out there that I think could hate this book, and it is worth all the hype it has received. I'm scared for the movie now because this book was written so perfectly.
Good read. I can see why schools pick it for summer reading. It helps to get out of your own head about what others think.

I struggled with this review. If I could give this book 3.5 stars I would have. On one hand the message is beautiful - "Be Kind," however, I found that the believability of the characters to be lacking. I have a hard time believing that Via and Auggie would be as understanding and perceptive as the story portrays. There were some very teary eyed moments, but considering everything, Auggie's ending was justified. In terms of the writing, it was easy and clear to jump from each POV, but I will say that the chapter introductions and some of the awkward spelling detracted from the story in places but was forgivable. For these reasons, I give Wonder 3 stars.

It was a nice read, indeed. It's just that it didn't move me. And I didn't really believe it. I think I enjoyed the parts from the other characters' POV (especially Via's - that might have been the best part, and I felt for her) much more than those from the POV of Auggie, at least the first part narrated by Auggie - I didn't buy it; it just didn't sound like something that would come from a 10-year-old. It got better and more interesting as it progressed, the novel does lay down the rules of relationships and human interaction very well, it shows that people are egocentric (sorry, August), they can be mean (hi, Julian), but they can also be incredibly kind and sweet (yes, Summer and Jack, I'm talking about you), so it had its moments. 
 I would definitely encourage my kid to read it if I had one because it has a strong moral in it, two, even - don't be mean to those who are different from you and have the courage to do your thing. Me, I think I'll have forgotten about this book by tomorrow. 
 And, yeah, that Daisy bit was totally uncalled for, in my opinion; let's milk some tears, shall we?
Loved this story; it should be required reading for all middle school students.

"I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 So begins the tale of August, a boy with a facial deformity about leave the safety of homeschooling to start fifth grade at an actual school. We get some insights to his appearance anyway and quasimodo comes to mind. It's the focus of the entire book. 
 The book is about August and his challenges, but it changes narrators to the people around him, and still it's mostly about him. And because it's a children's book, it works. Had it been a grown up book, I would have had many issues about this. 
 August talks about feeling completely normal, but we never get to see that. I didn't once let go of the "problem" with August and see him as a normal boy, because I was constantly reminded that he was different. 
 It would have been nice to read some stories of August and everyone around him completely forgetting about his deformity. For isn't it so that if you live with something long enough you stop noticing it? 
 I felt like August wasn't allowed to be "normal" even by his own family, he was always treated differently. And while I don't have too much experience on the matter, I would hope that people with challenges aren't constantly reminded of their limitations. 
 But again, it's a children's book. And children have different focal points than adults so maybe this works better for the younger audience. Maybe it teaches them something, and I really hope it does. For around the core of the struggle in a nice circle are the people that care for and take care of August. I hope they learn to have compassion for others. For in the changing of the narrative, we see that everybody has their own struggle, no matter who they are. And that is something we should all keep in mind. 
 But of course it holds the fairytale happy ending where the "good" people get their reward and the "bad" people get their punishment. It's written for the young ones after all.

www.bookworm221.tumblr.com 
 Wonder is a story about family, friendship, love, growing up and many other wonderful things. And we discover all this feelings through August, a 10 year old boy who was born with a very rare birth defect that affects the way his face looks, in the book and through different narratives we start to make a mental image of what August face looks like but let me be clear, this is not the most important thing about the book. 
 We first enter August life when he's about to start going to school for the first time (he was homeschooled by his mother). It's really interesting reading about August's first wxperiences at school, while reading I was reminded of my first days at school, and it's true what it says in the book, everyone is nervous/excited on their first day but for August it wasn't only his first day in 5th grade, it was his first day surrounded by other kids, who talk, stare and sadly avoid him. 
 As I said before Wonder is narrated by different characters all of them young, in the second part of the book we hear from Via, August sister where I think R.J. did an amazing job capturing the dichotomy of her feeling towards August, one part wants to protect him, to be there for him, to be quite about her own problems because she thinks that they aren't important compare to August's, to pretend she doesn't care that her parents don't pay the same amount of attention to her as they pay August. But another part wants his parents to pay attention to her, to ask about her day, her worries, how she feels. She wants to talk about her bad day but she doesn't because how can her bad days ever compare to one of August's bad days? 
 My favorite parts of the book are the ones that are narrated by August's friends, for instance his friend Summer says: 
 "He's just a kid. The weirdest - looking kid I've ever seen, yes. But just a kid." 
 Or his friend Jack: 
 "I think the bravest thing I ever did was become friends with August" 
 As someone who has worked with kids with different educational needs (not August's case) I can relate a lot to this book especially with this quote: 
 "What's cool about really little kids is that they don't say stuff to try to hurt your feelings, even though sometimes they do say stuff that hurts your feelings. But they don't actually know what they're saying. Big kids, though: they know what they're saying." 
 Because that's something that I've always said, kids can be cruel, very cruel to other kids and even adults but I do not think that kids are born that way, there comes an age in which what a kid does or says reflects on who his parents are and on how he lives his life at home. 
 Wonder is an amazing book and R.J. Palacio an amazing writer, she was able to capture so many important things in a book that ones you are reading it seems so short. The book is full of life lessons that I think we can all benefit from and I strongly believe this book should be and must be read by everyone. 
 Keep Calm and Read On 
 Instagram and Twitter @bookquotes221

I read this with my 8 year old daughter (we took turns). She and I laughed, cried, and frequently got mad while reading this story of a boy born with facial abnormalities struggling to navigate the shark-infested waters of middle school..

Everyone should read this charming, brilliant novel about growing up, fitting in, standing out, and the love that makes life worthwhile. It's a tale of empathy and kindness that cuts through the space between people, and I loved it wholeheartedly. 
 "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 August is 10 years old, and due to a combination of rare conditions was born with a facial deformity. He's never been to school before, and the novel begins with the prospect of him starting the 5th grade at a local school. He experiences all the usual struggles of a 10 year old, like making friends, dealing with bullying, and navigating relationships with his sister and parents, but they are all magnified through the lens of looking different. 
 "She said soft words that I know were meant to help me, but words can't change my face" 
 My favourite thing about Wonder is that it doesn't diminish the challenges of looking different, it doesn't sugar-coat the direct and indirect cruelty people like August experience every day. And yet it is not a sad book, it is ultimately uplifting. It draws together so many themes of friendship and love with gentle care, making it an important read for all ages. 
 "August is the Sun. Me and Mom and Dad are planets orbiting the Sun." 
 Wonder also includes some terrific adult characters. Though they don't get their own chapters, August's parents are very much present within this novel, something that so many YA novels lack. They are real people, with their own lives and history, their own pain and flaws, and they exist beyond the orbit of August's perspective. I think this is so important for young readers, to see examples of positive relationships with parents. They are not a perfect happy family with no struggles, but they do try and communicate, which I think gives this book much of its warmth. 
 "so I gave her my wing to hide under" 
 When the perspective first shifted away from August to his sister Via I was a bit thrown. I didn't expect it to be a multiple perspective novel. Once I got over that, and back into the rhythm of the story I was glad for it. August is, as Via said, the Sun around which this book orbits, but all the other perspectives add layers to his story rather than taking away from it. The end result is a story with surprisingly rich characters for just over 300 pages. 
 "You don't need your eyes to love... You just feel it inside you." 
 Wonder is a story about love, and I loved it right back. It reminds me of the sensitivity and heartbreaking hope of The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time has, but Wonder infuses that with a gentle kindness that will warm even the coldest heart. The novel is considered 'middle-grade' and would be suitable for readers aged 10 and up. But it is one of those rare novels with enough depth that it should not be restricted to young readers alone.

What do you do when you see someone with a deformity, a missing limb, a physical disorder, or really, anything that's considered "not normal"? Do you stare? Do you look away? Do you glance away and then look back, pretending that everything is "normal" and you're not bothered? Do you tease and mock? Do you cringe? Do you feel badly that you're looking at that person differently? We all do it. When we're confronted with a person's appearance that is less-than-average, we panic. We don't know what to do. We don't know how to approach that person because we can only assume that their less-than-average appearance makes them a less-than-average kind of person that needs to be treated differently. It's a twisted part of our human nature. 
 August (Auggie) Pullman was born with a facial deformity, though that's an understatement of grand proportions. He's looked at differently every day. People treat him like a porcelain doll. People even scream, when startled by his appearance. He says he's used to it, but can anyone ever really be used to that sort of treatment? 
 Up until the fifth grade he's been kept out of school. His mother has homeschooled him because of the multitude of surgeries that he goes through to make his face more functional, firstly, and slightly more average, secondly. For the fifth grade, he gets sent to Beecher Prep, a private school in the city. 
 Remember what it's like being the new kid in a new school? Remember how you looked at the new kid in your school? Remember how they were treated? Now imagine going through that every single day for a year, because every time you meet someone new, you are always considered the freak: always. 
 Wonder is a remarkable story of growth. The perspective switches between Auggie, his sister, and various other friends of the kids. The growth can be seen in all the perspectives, by all the kids. This is not only the story of how one deformed kid is grown to be accepted by his peers, but the story of how a group of kids grows to accept the strange and different in their worlds. 
 This review was originally posted on RATS.

This is one of those books that you just love. It's hard for me to go into detail without either giving the entire plot away or making it sound stupid, but it was just a great story that I didn't want to end. It says a so much about RJ Palacio's skills as an author that he was able to write a book that would not only captivate young readers but adults as well.

I love that it starts with Auggies story, his voice and perspective. I think it would have been a totally different story (and a much harder read) if it had been written about him and not from him...at least to begin with. I loved hearing the different voices that told the story. The reader had nearly a 360 degree view of what was really taking place. 
 It made me reflect on parenting and particularly not judging parents.
Every middle schooler should read this book. Really...
Just ... amazing.

Okay, so as a man I am not meant to admit this. So this is just between you and me. Wonder made me cry. Actually cry, not just a lump in the throat, but actual tears. It is only the second book to make me do so. (Time traveller's wife being the first). There, I said it. 
 The story starts off being told from the point of view from August himself, the facially disfigured boy that the book is about. It moves on to the view point of the other characters (all beautifully illustrated at the start of their section). Second up to August is his sister. I was worried at the start of this, wondering what she could have to offer the development of the story, but it isn't long until you see what hardships she equally has been through as a result of her situation. Every character to voice thereafter is equally well voiced and wonderfully well developed. 
 As much as the book made me cry, it also made me laugh. It is the perfect balance, and as close to perfect a book can be. I would recommend this to anyone, whatever age.
I read this book after seeing the previews for the movie - good story that displays resilience, empathy and kids true nature (they can be mean).

The voices that narrate the book Wonder are so strong that it's a bit life changing to read this book about August, Auggie, Pullman, a fifth grader who embarks upon his own life changing year. Born with mandibulofacial mysostosis and having gone through multiple surgeries, Auggie has been homeschooled up till now, but during the summer before fifth grade, his parents start floating the idea of starting school. Middle school seems to start in fifth grade in New York State, so the idea is , what better time to start? A meeting is arranged with the head of the middle school, Mr. Tuchman, and in joking with his dad over the guy's name, August warms up to the idea. At the interview, it turns out that Mr. Tushman has recruited some kids to show him around. One of these, Julian, will become his nemesis, and one, Jack Will, a close friend. The fact that they were recruited does lead to some hurt feelings and surprises. 
 What saves this from becoming another us against them book, is the nuance that Polacco brings to the characters in allowing them to speak for themselves. Everyone makes a journey that year. This is a real look at what friends and family can mean, even when you want to step away from it all for a minute. 
 My only fault with the book is the cinematic ending, which I will NOT outline. I really want to give this a 5 becauseI loved it, but the ending just didn't do it for me. 4 1/2 stars.

Wonder by R.J. Palacio was a really great read. I went into the book with no expectations. The book involves with being different, friends, school, and other things. The story starts with a boy named August and he is born with facial difference. All he wants is to let everyone know he is just like them. I think the story was really cute and heart warming. No one should be judged for the way they look. I loved how unique this story is and how it effected me. Overall, I gave this book a 5/5.
B E A U T I F U L AF!!! One of my favorites this year 2017! #MustRead

I do not know how ANY human being could read this wonderful book and not be moved and awed by this story of an exceptional little boy and his family. 
 Another 10 on my list in less than two weeks! 
 I confess that when I picked up this book at the book store, I had no idea what the story was about. I purchased it to give as a gift, along with a gift card with the same picture on it. 
 I did not make it out of the parking lot for over two hours after I opened it to scan over what it was about. I cried several times and when I got to page 64 I could not stop laughing AND crying for a long time. 
 This book will be on my gift list for many years to come.

As much as I have heard about this book, I was expecting so much more. It was a cute story, but I wasn't overexcited about it. On the other hand, if I read it to my kids, it could be a great teaching opportunity.

Wow. Habe das Buch eben ausgelesen und bin immer noch am Weinen, weil es so schon war! 
 Das Buch handelt von August (Auggie), dessen Gesicht deformiert ist, und davon, dass er zum ersten Mal in seinem Leben eine richtige Schule besucht. Erzahlt wird nicht nur aus Auggies Perspektive, sondern auch aus der von Freunden und seiner Schwester. Anfangs hielt ich das fur merkwurdig, aber selbst die Perspektive vom Freund der Schwester tragt zu der Handlung bei! 
 Alles in allem ein superklasse Buch, das jeder mal gelesen haben sollte!

Everyone (especially kids in elementary, middle, or high school) should read this book. Such a good reminder about the importance of being kind and loving those around us, even if they are different than us. Life is hard and everyone needs to try harder to make life a little easier and a little better for everyone else.

Auggie has a severe facial deformity, and is going to attend the fifth grade in public school for the first time. This is the heartwarming,and at times, heart-wrenching story interwoven with themes of friendship, bullying, belonging, family, and coming of age. 
 This story is very well written and told from a variety of character's perspectives, characters that will stay with you long after reading this wonderful story. The very short chapters make the read very accessible for a variety of readers, and make this book a good read aloud.
5 for concept and theme, but had to downgrade for the weak character development in the other narrators (with the exception of Via). Definitely a book for all Tweens to read and discuss.
"I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives."

Review first published on my blog: http://memoriesfrombooks.blogspot.com... 
 August "Auggie" Pullman is an little boy in the fifth grade. He loves video games and Star Wars just like so many other boys. However, he has been home schooled until this point because he was born with facial deformities and has required extensive medical intervention. His physical appearance has caused him to be excluded and shunned in so many situations that he spent part of his childhood wearing an astronaut helmet. His favorite holiday is Halloween because he can hide behind a mask and for a short while feel like any other child - a short while when appearance does not affect how people look at him and react to him. 
 In fifth grade, Auggie joins a mainstream school. This is the story of what happens in that fifth grade year. It is Auggie's story, but what pleasantly surprised me, it is so much more than that. The first section of the book is Auggie's story. Then come sections from the perspective of those surrounding Auggie. His sister Via who loves her brother but has her owns struggles and challenges as she starts a new high school. Summer who becomes Auggie's first friend at school. Jack, another fifth grader who friends Auggie. Miranda who is Via's best friend and who has been a big part of Auggie's life. Justin who is Via's new friend. Throughout, the reader comes back to August and his story. 
 Each of the characters introduced are part of Auggie's life and are changed by their relationship with him. Each of them also faces their own struggles with growing up, feeling different, and feeling left out. As such, this story becomes so much broader because we all have experienced those feelings at times. While a reader (especially the target audience of children) may not directly relate to Auggie's situation, they may see themselves in one of the other characters. 
 I love discovering books that I enjoy as an adult and that I can share with my children. Even more, I love discovering books that can spark a conversation about life and life lessons with my children. A wonderful book!
This book lives up to the hype. It does make you feel good, but it also doesn't gloss over reality. The author seems to have a really good understanding of how kids interact at school.
The first part of this book was really hard for me to read, it just hurt my heart reading about the people that were mean to him. But I kept reading and the end was great.

There are so many wonderful books in the world that sometimes it seems like all of the stories have already been told. But Wonder is a new story. An incredible portrait of family, change, and friendship. A story that I will read again. I heard a lot of buzz about Wonder in #mglichat and from my MG writer buddies, and the book didn't just live up to my expectations--it took me to a whole new place. And that is special. 
 R.J. Palacio brings New York to life in this simple and touching story about August--Auggie to his family and friends. Auggie is different. I won't tell you how. And in fact, Auggie doesn't tell you how, either. Instead, other characters fill in the blanks for him, offering their own unique perspectives in different acts throughout the novel. Some authors mangle this format. But not Palacio--she nails it. 
 Each act in Wonder tells us only what we need to know, and moves swiftly forward with the action. We follow Auggie on his journey into fifth grade, as he adjusts to new friendships and his family adjusts to his new role. He's a normal kid, witty and charming despite his differences. Because even though Auggie is different, the challenges he faces are so much the same as everyone growing up. The great joy of Wonder is that we get to experience Auggie's challenges right along with him, and experience that sameness for ourselves.
Oh, gosh. Beautiful, beautifully written, and so, so important.

I read this for book club, otherwise I never would've picked it up as middle grade isn't really my thing. That said, my initial impression was that this book was a well-executed morality lesson for children, with a story that was sure to keep young people engaged (even if it was entirely predictable and insubstantial for older audiences). But then I met with my book club and some of that exalted membership pointed out that a message of "just be nice to people and the world will be a better place" is unlikely to convert any of the bullies of the world, and furthermore might be subtly counterproductive. Spoiler alert (although not for any adult who pays attention at all to the narrative): everything works out fine for our special needs protagonist in this book, and the implication is that the goodness of people will eventually win out and help those who are different to live their lives as normally as possible. But what if that's not how it works in the real world? Wouldn't that be really discouraging to a young kid who's being ostracized, who is trying ot be as nice as possible, and who finds that it doesn't help at all? So in retrospect, I don't think the Polyanna optimism of this book is good for children at all, and thus I docked it a star.
Good but a little precious. I understand why it has been recommended so many times and I enjoyed it but it was a little "Hollywood."

"You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder." 
 What a WONDERful book! This book honestly did not disappoint. I am so happy that I finally got to read it. While this story is sad, (and I did shed a few tears while reading), it is also funny, and awe-inspiring. For me, these feelings outweighed the sad. 
 "Shall we make a new rule of life...always try to be a little kinder than is necessary." 
 This book has many inspiring quotes but this is one that especially stood out to me. I completely agree with it as well. If we all tried a bit harder to be kinder everyday, imagine what a brighter place the world would be. 
 On another note, I absolutely loved how Ms. Palacio told the story from many different perspectives, not just August's. Especially for Auggie's friend, Jack, I could truly see how much he grew through out the story. I love seeing character growth. It makes me feel like I am joining them on their life-changing journey. This is definitely a new favorite book for me and I highly recommend it to anyone! You should especially read it before the movie comes out.

In the words of my eight year old son, " it's about a boy born with a terrible facial deformity that caused him to be friendless. He is kind, friendly, funny and courageous. He teaches others that you just have to be yourself and people will like you."
Auggie's so cute and never lets anything get him down for long! Such an inspiration!

"If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 One of the best reads. A must, must, must read for everyone.

Wonder is a great story about friendship, and looking passed the differences on the outside of someone. This book has good characters, and you hear from all of the characters' points of view, which is special in a story. This is a great read aloud book to educate students on how to treat people, and what a good friendship looks like.

Cheese and crackers this book is amazing! 
 I can't even put the way it makes me feel into words. Such a genuinely touching story that leaves you floating on a cloud afterwards. I loved all of the characters and how the author stresses the point (without over doing it) that we should empathize with others. 
 This is one of those books that you just want to squeeze and cuddle with once it's over. Definitely a good addition to anyone's favorite's shelf.
A truly touching story...made my heart feel good (even if things are tied up a little too happily-ever-after in the end.) Hope this gets into the hands of YA readers.

A BOOK FOR ALL AGES 
 I think it's like the Cheese Touch in Diary of a Wimpy Kid. The kids in that story were afraid they'd catch the cooties if they touched the old moldy cheese on the basketball court. At Beecher Prep, I'm the old moldy cheese. (page 72) 
 For me, Halloween is the best holiday in the world. It even beats Christmas. I get to dress up in a costume. I get to wear a mask. I get to go around like every other kid with a mask and nobody thinks I look weird. Nobody takes a second look. Nobody notices me. Nobody knows me. 
 I wish every day could be Halloween. We could all wear masks all the time. Then we could walk around and get to know each other before we got to see what we looked like under the masks. (page 73) 
 This was a very quick, easy read but don't let the fact that it is targeting a younger reading audience detract you from picking this up for yourself. This book is a good opportunity for us to stop and think about how we react, respond, and treat people who are "different" from ourselves. 
 It's so sad that we live in a society where beauty reigns supreme and youth a close second. I really wish that when we looked at people we didn't just register their outward appearance but really could see the inner beauty and heart of a person. I'd love it if we didn't even consider how someone looks or how they're different than us and instead just viewed every person coming in contact with as a human needing love, compassion, understanding, kindness, generosity, etc. almost like each person was just a blackened silhouette that you just respond to the exact same way. 
 I really hate myself when I glance away from someone with a facial disfigurement, scar, patch, birthmark, etc. because I'm trying to not be rude--but then it's a different kind of rude to not be able to withstand looking into the face of a person as you communicate with them. I also don't want to risk staring and talking to the "defect". For example: I really struggle with someone who has a lazy eye--do I look at the good eye or the "bad" eye? I try to talk to the bridge of the nose and then I'm standing there asking myself "why is it so much easier when someone appears 'normal'?" And then I hate myself for even trying to classify what is "normal" or not! 
 So, I myself have been trying to practice not even registering what a person looks like and just acknowledging everyone with a genuine smile and greeting--and not the phony pity ones that Auggie talks about in the book. It's true we're almost trying to make up for the fact that we're pitying them for being "different" that we plaster on our biggest, "fakest" smile and are just trying to make someone feel comfortable but when they see a big, unrealistic Cheshire grin that's only gonna make them more uncomfortable and feeling like they're differences are standing out more. 
 I like that this book is thought provoking and talks about various, different character's responses--whether it be someone regrets having fled the scene as they saw him coming to avoid the awkwardness or someone bluntly asking if he was in a fire. This book covers just about every kind of person and reaction and it makes you more sensitive to hearing it from the side of the one actually enduring the "challenge". This book made me want to downright cry when you think of the cruelty that someone can inflict on a person. 
 I dealt with my own form of bullying in grade school through junior high for my looks. I was teased for my white hair, white eyelashes, pale skin, pug nose, horse teeth, chicken legs, my clothes, wearing the same backpack two years in a row, growing up in a trailer park, the way my bangs were cut, for still playing with Barbies in 3rd grade (haha but joke's on them...I secretly played until 14). Anyway, kids will find all kinds of reasons to be a bully to someone they feel is beneath them and sometimes it is because their home life is not so good...or they're being bullied. I did survive and it made me a defender of the under dogs when I got to high school and I had my "glow-up" (as my niece told me it's called) and I used my positive attention from people for good. I remember one day I was walking with a girl, my senior year, and a couple of other girls approached just as I branched off from my friend and they said something along the lines of "You're new here and all...so we feel obligated to tell you that hanging out with that "scrubby" girl will ruin your reputation" and I said, "What reputation?" and just walked off and she and I are still connected to this day. She's such a sweet soul and I don't understand how people select friends just based on shallow standards. She was one of the first people to befriend me when I was new there. I only wanted a reputation of befriending everyone equally and I was fine if my reputation was that I was not like the likes of those "mean girls". 
 I enjoy reading books that put me in someone else's shoes...or someone else's space helmet. ;)

This book should be mandatory reading for late-elementary or early-middle school kids. Great messages about differences and bullying, and yet the story was never fake or preachy. It's a great book for every age.

3.5 
 It made me cry, which not a lot of books do, so there's that. The narrative is interesting and I finished it quickly. At first I wasn't so sure about it because I didn't like Auggie as a narrator in the beginning (the immature language etc.). But as the narrators continued tochange, I got more into it and felt it was an interesting way to let the plot unfold(and Auggie's voice grew on me as he grew up as well). 
 I'd recommend it to YA librarians and middle school teachers for sure. It's also a good, quick read for those of us who enjoy YA. There's definitely some powerful messages of empathy and kindness in there, but without being preachy. Overall, glad I read it.
Wonder by R.J. Palacio was a wonderful character driven story.
amazing. one of the best books i've ever read

One of my favourite books EVER. Once I had read the last word, I just lay in my bed for about an hour thinking about it! It made me WONDER so much about everything- about how unfair life is, but also how beautiful it is. This wonderful story made me realise how powerful being true to oneself is. I am just babbling on now as I am very tired. It was just so amazing. READ IT !! 
 Most importantly, it is not the outside that counts, but the inside. I wish that I could spend one day as August just to discover who my true friends are. I got really attached to him and I really enjoyed seeing his evolution.
This is a good book. Better yet, this is an IMPORTANT book.

A story with a functioning traditional family about a boy trying to be normal, but enjoying some of the perks of being different. I particularly liked the section told from Olivia's point of view. Being the older sibling is difficult, even though mostly you accept it as the way your family is and continue on.

"Always try to be a little kinder than is necessary." 
 I can't believe I waited so long to finish this book. The storytelling is so well paced. The characters are developed so well. And over anyone's life time we have all met a Julian. And while we may not have met anyone who looks like Auggie, we have met someone with his soul. If we don't realize it l, we all wish we could be like Auggie. 
 Middle school is hard enough, but to have a major facial deformity makes a tough situation just a bit harder. Oddly enough the main character Auggie doesn't grow like you'd see in your average juvenile fiction. He grows as a person. He overcomes MAJOR obstinate like the Plague game and the war. But everyone else grows so much more. 
 His parents by letting him finally go to school. Summer by throwing caution to the wind and sitting down with him at his first lunch. Jack who started to hang with Auggie, but then fell to peer pressure to bad mouth him only to come around and be a true friend. Via who wants to hide be brother for some freedom and her former best friend who claims Auggie as a status symbol. 
 Even the teachers who don't act overly protective when the war kicks up, but shows great restraint in not kicking Jack Will out after a fight. 
 This book could take the Newbery this year. I would support that 100%. 
 I won't lie it often not an easy book. It's not an easy story. Life isn't easy. 
 The multi-viewed story gives everyone's perspective on the same parts of the story. Only the reader truly gets the whole story. The message, subtle through most of the book, is clearly beaten into the readers's mind during the last pages. It's a message that shouldn't have to be beaten into anyone's head, but many people need to have it beaten in their thick skulls. 
 Be kinder than necessary. 
 Get this book and I hope you love it as much as I did.

I liked the multiple narrators in this book--it kept the story moving along nicely. Because of the way a lot of books about people who are different tend to exploit a reader emotionally, I was really worried something terrible was going to happen at the end that would make me cry. While I did cry at one point, it wasn't the end that did me in, and that was a huge relief. I would recommend this book to people who like heartwarming stories even when they don't involve someone dying of cancer or similar.

Wonder is an amazing and inspiring book. It makes you feel like you are in the story. I love the author's technique of re-writing the same story from different character's points of view. It makes the story a lot more interesting. I think that it is very good!
What a beautiful storydY'-
Great idea for a book. Everyone should read this.

I understand the premise, but I feel like the story was poorly executed and the characters flat. As well as this, some of the values preached in the book are not those that I share, which is fine, of course, but made it less enjoyable for me. It is important to "be kind, don't bully, don't judge people for their looks," etc. but these themes are nevertheless very cliche. I feel like Palacio could have gone deeper with this message. I also think that August was a very unique protagonist, and there was so much potential in his character that she did not expand upon. Like I said, the characters are flat. I understand that this book was written for younger audiences, however, and I believe that without looking at it too deeply and simply taking the message at face value, it is a fairly enjoyable read. There were parts that made me angry or happy in spite of myself, and while I wouldn't recommend this book to anyone, I do not think it is altogether a terrible story.

A wonderful book for adolescents to learn about formal literary characteristics like point of view, style, and tone, and also about bullying and accepting difference. I will definitely encourage my kids to read it in the years between fifth and seventh grades!
This was an excellent book and I highly recommend it.
This book deserves all the great hype it's receiving. Truly a wonderful book.

One of the rules of a YA book is that it has to remove the parents in order to have the protagonist(s) tackle issues on their own. The objective of such stories is to explore how kids face issues. Generally books do this by killling off the parents or having them absent for some reason. The protagonist can't tell the parents some things. What I love about this book is that it shows supportive parents instead. It still accomplishes what a YA book must, which is to challenge a child into independence by facing up to challenge on their own. In this case the challenge was going to school for the first time in Augie's life. He'd always been homeschooled previously due to medical issues but now, he was on his own and in middle school. The author did a brilliant job of building story from multiple perspectives and creating organic problems without saving the MC through deux ex machina. Instead, the entire story is believable, real and also KIND. The problems are real and hard to face and there is a pervasive answer of kindness and relation to our fellow human throughout.
