I couldn't recommend a story more. And I recommend it to any age and any type person. Beautiful and perfectly crafted story. Read it.

I loved the main character, Auggie, in this brilliant young adult book. He doesn't look like the other fifth graders, but he's a smart, funny, and kind young man with a supportive family. I loved the journey of seeing children grow to accept Auggie for who he is and look past his physical features. 
 "Wonder" actually brought tears to my eyes on more than one occasion and could, without a doubt, become a required read for young readers in middle school one day!!

Amazing!!! This is (and i totally mean it) one of the rarest books that actually made me cry. Heart warming, with such beautiful and inspirational messages. 5/5 and i highly recommand this book to everyone
Pulls the heart in a dozen directions, but never feels forced. A warm, funny, real book.

"Her smile hugged me" - August Pullman 
 After reading this book, I curled into a ball, wiped my tears and made some hot chocolate. After I finish a good book, I always get a surreal feeling. My heart goes all like, "wow it's actually over" , and Wonder definitely gave me that feeling. This is one of those books that makes you feel warm, angry and fuzzy all at once! So many feels, be ready to transport back to your childhood. 
 I was skeptical about reading this book because it's geared towards children. However, after reading it, I can honestly say I would recommend this book to readers of all ages. At the time I read this book, I was in a complicated relationship with reading. My hectic life as a college student gave me no time to read for pleasure (although this could also be due to my poor time management); however, the simplicity, funny and witty nature of this book helped rekindle my love for reading again. 
 Like many others have stated, what makes this book special is the characters. The book is split into different points of views, which enables us to understand how the main character's facial deformity impacts the people around him. The story also touches on a lot of issues that kids around Auggie's age experience. The author talks about bullying, self-esteem, pet death, isolation and relationships. But it does so in a way that's relatable and sensitive. 
 I think the main message of this book is obviously subject to interpretation. But to me, the story aims to teach readers about being more compassionate and understanding. I know this might seem cliche, but you have to remember this book is aimed towards a younger audience. It's not trying to be an adult book, even though it can be enjoyed by older readers. 
 August (aka Auggie) is an innocent, witty and kind-hearted boy who is just about to start middle school. He loves Star Wars, Halloween and chocolate milk with extra foam. He is, in every way, an ordinary kid. However, what makes him unique is his face. The way he talks about his condition made my heart melt: 
 "My name is August, by the way. I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." - August Pullman 
 There were moments in this book where I cried and laughed. But ultimately, this book left me feeling grateful. I loved how intelligent all the characters were. I loved the style of writing too. If you enjoy contemporary and witty novels, then this is definitely a must-read!

Such a touching piece that makes tears from my eyes keep on falling. A really good read indeed. 
 "Olivia reminds me of a bird sometimes, how her feathers get all ruffled when she's mad. And when she's fragile like this, she's a little lost bird looking for its nest. So i give her my wing to hide under." 
 "Now that I look back, I dont know why I was so stressed about it all this time. Funny how sometimes you worry a lot about something and it turns out to be nothing"
Told from various points of view, this is a satisfying and successful story, which many will enjoy.

Reading this book makes me feel wonderful, feel happy and just so damn touch and grateful for everything I had and have. 
 This is recommended to ALL 
 I can gush about how much I love LOVE LOVE this book ,but it's too unrealistic. 
 Average looking people with minor defects such as a face full of pimples are laughed at, mocked at etc, now imagine a facial deformed person ... sure he'll be teased, bullied, look down, isolated BUT this is a weird society we are now living in. 
 People feel more sympathetic towards people with obvious defects--eg loss of limbs but NOT normal defects like acne, little hair, bad skin,weight or those unseen defects such as people who has low IQ but not so low till it's so obvious . 
 It's something like because she/he has cleft lip and pallet you must give her more attention, logically it sounds fair to that poor boy/girl because she/he's born without this or that,but what about the others like Via? 
 My favourite in this book isn't August (no offense), but it's Via, next is Jack. 
 Via reflects how I felt personally because I have a sister who was born cleft palette, it's tiring to always be sidelined yet knowing you are doing the right understanding actions . She's resilient and brave and loving,she isn't mean to be feeling human... wanting a normal life for a moment and have the attention to herself! 
 As for Jack, he has just shown us we submit to the fear of peer pressure and fear of being out of the norm,everyone wants to fit in and we will hurt people we never want or thought or even intended to hurt, yet we are good kind hearted ,we just need the courage. Honestly I felt Jack should have gotten an honor roll too,so does Summer! 
 Summer is the rare kind of friend and person you can ever find,but someone as brave as she.... that's nearly nil in our current evil pervert society. 
 Basically the book is just too good to be true, you can't have perfect loving parents,siblings, relatives,friends and teachers . Yes there are mean jerks out there,but in truth, reality is much more cruel than the mean characters Ms R.J. Palacio has portrayed which just makes me feel deflated.... sorry I'm pessimistic but I'm a realist at heart.
I read this book with my daughter and mother...we all LOVED it!!

Such a WONDERful book!!! 
 Though it is marked as a middle age novel, I think anyone would enjoy this book and everyone should read it at some point in their lives. It's one of those books that make you realize what's really important in life and how our actions could have a huge impact on someone's life. 
 I loved Auggie from the very first page and as a special needs mom, this novel pulled so many sensitive strings. I laughed, cried, got angry, I wanted to jump into this book and hug Auggie and yell at some of those kids! So many emotions in just two days!!! 
 The story is told in different characters' perspectives, which was good because I got dissapointed in one of his friends, but then you read his side of the story and I was like... "Ok, I forgive you." 
 However I would've loved to read from his mom's and his teachers' POV. And I didn't like the fact that Justin's perspective (his sister's boyfriend), is told in a very infromal format; no capital letters, no punctuation marks at all. He is a high school student after all. 
 "...what you've done with your time, how you've chosen to spend your days, and whom you have touched this year. That to me, is the greatest measure of success."
Rated 3.5 stars

"Have you read Wonder?" the girl asked excitedly. 
 "No, I haven't." I was taken aback. Shouldn't I be giving her recommendations? 
 "You HAVE to read it." 
 It was one of the first enthusiastic recommendations I've gotten at my job as a bookseller, so I took it to heart. I bought it almost immediately after this interaction, and then sat on it for a while. I needed a palate cleanser after Kangaroo Notebook, and this was the perfect prescription. 
 I was expecting this book to be maudlin and cheesy and make me uncomfortable. But really, it does a brilliant job showing that August Pullman is just a kid, and keeps the other characters grounded. One of my favorite parts was the very end. August gets an award during his fifth grade graduation. He's happy, but admits that he knows that he's getting that award because of his face, and the fact that no one wants to be him. It was so raw and honest and was such a unique example of how a well-loved kid would handle being looked at that way. 
 Let's talk about his parents, though, because weren't they a bit too perfect? They were a bit too idealized for me. I get why we couldn't get their perspective in a kids' book, but they could have seemed a tiny bit less saintly.

Wonder is not only a cute but moving novel. As it is written in the different perspectives of characters in the book, it gives a new light to a topic that is not often touched by children's authors. Personally, I thoroughly enjoyed this book and it recommend it to enthusiastic readers,anywhere, anytime, any age. Wonder depicts that children with similar disabilities as Auggie have an extremely hard life and the environment around them should be welcoming. Not only does this book entertain the reader but it also conveys an important message that everyone should learn to accept. 
 Happy reading :)!
heart warming,great.tears would swell up.never forget him.

August is the Sun. Me and Mom and Dad are planets orbiting the Sun. The rest of our family and friends are asteroids and comets floating around the planets orbiting the Sun. The only celestial body that doesn't orbit August the Sun is Daisy the dog, and that's only because to her little doggy eyes, August's face doesn't look very different from any other human's face. To Daisy, all our faces look alike, as flat and pale as the moon. 
 --Olivia Pullman [August's sister], A Tour Of The Galaxy 
 I am in love with this book. Originally got it for my little sister, a shy fourth grader who's been home-schooled since forever (and we want to send her to a real school once she gets to the fifth grade, kind of like August's sitch in the book), but I couldn't help but read it first. Lately, the books I've been reading have followed this trend of disappointing me, and I'm glad to say this one didn't. It wasn't the sobfest, pity-me novel I expected, though I shed a tear or two in between chapters. It was actually pretty funny. I got a few stares from my sister when she saw me laughing by myself, book in hand. You'd think this would be a serious novel all about morality and judgment and stuff, but its not just that. It's a humorous, sincere, heartwarming, beautiful story about a kid who's just trying to get by. Remember your first day of middle school? Remember having to claw your way out of it as your mom tried to drag you out of the car and almost literally threw you inside the building? Okay, maybe that was just my experience. But I bet you were nervous too, right? Just think of how this kid felt. The book says he looks like his face had been melted, but "whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse". 
 The thing is, he's just like everyone else, but everyone else doesn't know that. 
 I loved August's humor and personality. I loved his Star Wars obsession and how the author used a ton of Star Wars references throughout the whole thing. I love how sobby chapters could send you falling off your seat laughing in the end. I loved how every part of it was so sincere. It almost felt like this was non-fiction. And plus points to Palacio for including other characters' first-person narratives, I mean, I love August, but getting into someone else's head that long kinda bores you. So then you'll need some other head to invade. I love how its not all about the main character. I love how, sometimes, August is not the main character at all. Other people have lives too, yknow. And having someone-- different --as a relative or a friend isn't exactly easy, either. 
 I think the author could write full books about the other characters, too. I'd love to get inside their heads a bit more. Like Justin, Miranda, Jack... They're interesting characters. 
 I'd recommend it to anyone between the ages of 8 and 80. Or anyone who's ever felt mistreated. Or anyone who knows what it's like to feel. It's beautiful. Read it. NOW.

It took me a while to get into this book, but I'm so glad I did. I think what held me up was Auggie's "voice" at the beginning, but he definitely matured as the story went along. I didn't really like how the fifth graders were portrayed as having boyfriend/girlfriend relationships, but who knows what fifth graders these days think about that stuff. I recommend this book as a family read-together (does anyone do this?)

I highly recommend this story to teachers, parents of middle grade students, and (of course) middle schoolers. Wonder reminds me of the adage that everyone is fighting (some kind of) a battle. This tale of friendship, courage, and acceptance reminds us to be kind and to be ourselves.
I think that every middle school student should read this book. I loved how it was told from the perspective of different people.
beautiful
One of the most moving affecting and truthful books I've read...ever. Everyone age 10 and older should read it. Finished it on a plane and think I spooked my seatmates by crying so much.

This was such a lovely book. Being a middle school teacher in an environment where the teachers try to be very active in knowing how the social dynamics of a grade affect students, this really hit home. I loved the varying perspectives throughout the book and got such a sense for each character that I couldn't put it down. I wanted to know how things were going to get resolved and understand why certain characters did certain things. Definitely an emotional read but absolutely wonderful.

"What's cool about really little kids is that they don't say stuff to try to hurt your feelings, even though sometimes they do say stuff that hurts your feelings. But they don't actually know what they're saying. Big kids, though: they know what they're saying" (21). - August 
 "I wish every day could be Halloween. We could all wear masks all the time. Then we could walk around and get to know each other before we got to see what we looked like under the masks" (73). - August 
 "...sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone" (137). - Jack 
 Mr. Browne's Precepts: 
 September - When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind. Dr. Wayne W. Dyer 
 October - Your deeds are your monuments. inscription on an Egyptian tomb 
 November - Have no friends equal to yourself. Confucius 
 December - Fortune favors the bold. Virgil 
 January - No man is an island, entire of itself. John Donne 
 February - It is better to know some of the questions than all of the answers. James Thurber 
 March - Kind words do not cost much. Yet they accomplish much. Blaise Pascal 
 April - What is beautiful is good, and who is good will soon be beautiful. Sappho 
 May - Do all the good you can, By all the means you can, In all the ways you can, In all the places you can, At all the times you can, To all the people you can, As long as you ever can. John Wesley's Rule 
 June - Just follow the day and reach for the sun! The Polyphonic Spree

I liked this. (Although, I tend to like books as told from the perspectives of young and naive voices, a la "The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Nighttime" and "Room", so it was not shocking that I enjoyed this as well.) 
 I appreciated that the author incorporated several perspectives, as opposed to just August's, because August's voice tended to grate on my nerves after a bit. It was nice to break the monotony, and the voices were all unique and different. On that note, however, I did have one main problem with this book. Time and time again, we are reminded that August is brilliant and much smarter than many people his own age. It didn't read this way when he spoke. He often speaks in an extremely immature voice, saying things that do not come across as "gifted". Instead, he occasionally tends to come across as "special needs", which is the opposite of what I (and I assume the author) wanted. This is exemplified by the fact that the other 5th grade classmate's narratives just sound so much more mature and well-spoken. I do love all the characters, including August. Via was my favorite character. She was so multi-dimensional, and I feel like her perspective on life was much needed and approachable. The family dynamics, relationships, and friendships depicted in the book were all believable. Some were sweet, some were strained, some were complex, and all were believable. 
 I recommend this.
Truly inspiring.

Not willing to give up on the search for the next Newbery winner, I continue to read books for young readers -- and this one exudes courage and heart. My favorite quote, even before Auggie uses it as his precept: I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives.

Once in a blue moon! That is how often a book such as Wonder comes along! Wonder is released in March and I thoroughly recommend EVERYONE to read it. 
 The book's main story features Auggie. A boy born with severe disfigurement. He has been home schooled for the majority of his life but he is starting school and the book is told through the course of the school year. 
 The book is split into different sections giving the reader a chance to see how Auggie's story is through another character's eyes. I love this idea and am really impressed how quickly the pace and feel changes in the story. 
 Towards the end as there is a major development with one of the main characters I really started to get a sinister feeling. Was Auggie's life at danger? I was so scared that after growing to love a character as much as I loved Auggie we were going to loose him. The ending will definitely have you reaching for the tissues but for a sad reason or a happy one you will have to read and find out! 
 As I say above this book is amazing! So touching, full of soul and one that will stay with you for a long time.
My 8 year old son and I read this novel together and both loved it. It opened up many conversations about true friendship, courage, and honesty.
This book was good. So good, it made me cry while reading it on the train.

I'm afraid to write this review, based on so many friends' reviews. I think I might need to duck! 
 I wasn't in love - I cried at one super poignant scene, but aside from that, I had a really hard time connecting. I just don't think the author made fifth graders sound like fifth graders - even if some are smarty pants homeschooled kids overcoming incredible odds. If they were 7th graders, maybe, but most of the time, the conversations between the main character and his friend Summer were more like what I'd expect from 10th graders. And the attempts to make it sound younger by using a few key vocab words or Things Boys Like like Star Wars, it just felt off. 
 Now, the parts with teenagers SOUNDED like teenagers, and I liked those much better, but since they were ancillary characters in this Very Important Book that will probably become a required reading book, it didn't do enough to warrant a higher rating. 
 I do think it's a good story to tell, of course. I'm not heartless. I must admit that I wanted to SEE August, which makes me feel like some sort of weirdo, but I was too distracted wondering what he looked like to enjoy the book. I did give a copy to my SIL who works in Special Education (though it's not about Special Ed, ok?) because I think it's a good book for educators to read. 
 (don't get me started on the "precepts" bit. 5th graders, people. why not "inspirational thoughts" or just "things to think about" or something else cheesy?)

This book made me sad, anxious, and happy. This was a wonderful book, I'm almost upset that I can't stay in August's world a little longer. But that ending left me so happy I almost don't mind. Everyone should read this book. 5 stars

I read this in September of 2011 and realized that I had never posted a review. Wow. . . 
 I did, however, post a look at WONDER with THE TIPPING POINT at THE NERDY BOOK CLUB on June 10th, 2012 (you can find "Tipping Point of Wonder" in the archives). 
 Finished Wonder for the third time over the weekend.

Wow. This book was exceptional. Moving. Beautifully written. Despite having several narrators, each felt true and heartfelt. I cried on public transportation while reading this and I'm not even ashamed. This is a must-read.

I felt bad all these years of postponing to read this awesome awesome book after seeing this read by my roomie years ago, and now I finally did, it was totally worth it. (Read it twice!) Super amazing! 
 First time schooling was definitely experienced by everyone, we all had to go through it. We all got stared at (probably) for being the new kid in school. But in Auggie's case, it was a lot worse. He was an ordinary kid, being born with severe craniofacial anomalies, causing him to experience the "stare" a lot. And he had to undergo this in his new school, aside from all the other things he needed to learn and experience the first time (rules, quizes, projects, school events, friendship by choice, bullies, boy wars.. the list goes on). 
 Wonder was simply wonderfully written in a way that readers of all ages would definitely enjoyed it, and leave them in a rollercoaster of emotions (cried, laughed, angered... - repeat nth times). I personally loved the way it was told in 6 different perspectives, all in first person point of view, which includes Auggie's and the people who were deeply involved with him and whose lives were greatly affected by Auggie's presence. It gives the story more depth and insights on the character's background. 
 The book has also a lot of valuable lessons to teach and share to everyone, more like a self-reflection. Definitely recommending to all, such an easy read. Not boring at all!

I have read many many books that have made me cry, not always generally out of sadness but out of one thing or the other. This book, I think, was the first book that made me cry from happiness. 
 I loved everything about this book. It's at a very easy reading level but the story is one that can resonate with people of all ages. I kept finding myself talking out loud while reading, dreading all the sad parts and getting angry for August and it was such an emotional read. 
 I also loved how the book was split into different points of view, so that way we could see not only the story told from a perspective other than August's, but we could also read about other people's stories. I especially liked reading about Via and Justin (who were super cute) and also loved finding out more about Jack's life. 
 The ending was ridiculously good. Really, really, ridiculously good. From the nature retreat to graduation I was so enthralled in the story and was wide awake despite it being about 2:30 am when I finished. 
 SO YEAH I HIGHLY RECOMMEND

I finished Wonder over a month ago, but I still can't stop thinking about how much I loved this book. Auggie's character is just so enduring. I never reread books but I honestly think I may have to soon. 
 Here is my blurb about the book from a recent book talk I did. 
 Auggie Pullman was born with an extreme facial deformity. Because of this he has had to be home-schooled so he could recover from numerous surgeries he has had. But this year, he is starting middle school at Beecher Prep. He worries if the other kids will accept him, if they will stare, and if he will make any friends. Auggie says, "I wish every day could be Halloween. We could all wear masks all the time. Then we could walk around and get to know each other before we got to see what we looked like under the masks." This is a story of courage and also of kindness." 
 Seriously, everyone should read this book.
The story overall was good but recently I've read other YA fiction that was truly amazing. It's worth a read.

The book everyone should read, no matter your age, favorite genre or anything else. You just go there and read it. I'm sure this book gives something to everyone. I cried, I laughed and enjoyed every bit of it.

This simply told story of Auggie who has severe craniofacial syndrome and who is entering the fifth must be read by everyone. Palacios not only explores how Auggie sees the world, but also provides perspectives from his family and friends to show how life is not only challenging for Auggie, but for everyone else. It reaffirms why we should all be "a little kinder than is necessary."

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." - Auggie 
 *This book deserves a standing ovation* 
 There are times when a book changes you--maybe in little ways you don't even seem to notice--but changes you one way or another. But there are also times when a book makes impact to your very core and shifts a whole new dynamic in you. It sounds dramatic when you put it that way, but it is the closest thing that can describe how I feel about this Wonder (pun intended). 
 I have never read a book so humane, so honest, and so heartbreaking as this gem. I laughed, sobbed, shed silent tears and cried happy tears while reading Auggie's life through his eyes and the eyes of people who has seen him and loved him. 
 Auggie's story is not something that is supposed to make you feel good; it's real hard-knock stuff that would make you evaluate yourself and how you see the world. 
 R.J. Palacio was able to sensitively tackle the issue that is seemed to be dealt with with curious gazes and judging eyes in reality. My heart is filled with joy as human kindness, friendship, love and bravery were clearly pivotal in the development of the story. 
 August's story is more than his own as numerous others suffer the same thing he goes through day by day. I planned to read this ages ago but now that I picked it out, I realized it doesn't matter that I read it a little late and I have not recommended this to others yet. I'm just happy it changed me in a profound way I can't fully describe. 
 And my hope is that this book changes you too, and in the end, we all choose to be a little kinder than necessary.

My daughter read this book in school and wanted me to read it. Wow. My son has a medical issue that required surgery and 6 weeks in the hospital...and she was put on the back burner. He does not have the facial deformity, but he has some physical impairments so it was somewhat personal. I loved it.

I could fill this entire page with words and not be able to fully express how charming and powerful this story is. I loved every page, and I cannot wait to share it with my 5th graders next year! 
 Such a simple concept...kindness, kindness, kindness! It changes lives.
This book was soooo good!!! There were some really sad parts though, and to be honest, I cried. This was beautifully written!!
Borrowed my granddaughter's copy to read as I'd heard so much about this book. Very glad that I did.

Wonder has made it to my list of all time favorites. 
 August was just so sweet and I was laughing at one page and crying at the next. 
 Such a good book

If I could give this book more stars, I would. It was amazing. Funny. Sad. Bittersweet. Unique. There were so many passages that would be underlined if it wasn't a library book. Beautifully written. Standing ovation. Everyone should read it starting with 5th graders.

Que livro incrivel! Como nao li isso antes?! 
 Melhor audiobook que ouvi ate agora tambem! Adorei

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." 
 I haven't read a middle grader in a really long time, but I am so glad I picked this one up. Auggie's story as told through multiple POVs is so heart-warming and beautiful. The only reason I'm not giving Wonder 5 stars is because I think things tied up a little too nicely in the end to be believable (but that could also just be my cynical college student side rearing its head).

my 10 year old finished this book and loved it. Asked me at least 3 times a day when I was going to read it, as I finished up another book. Read it last night and it is truly wonderful. I think I liked it more because it touched my child in a way few books have.

Una historia sobre como la perfeccion muchas veces radica en nuestros defectos y en lo que nos hace diferentes de los demas. August es uno de esos personajes que logra entrar al corazon de los lectores sin siquiera proponerselo, y el modo en que la autora nos presenta no una sino multiples perspectivas de cada uno de los personajes y situaciones es un aporte narrativo bellisimo que no solo enriquece la historia, sino que construye todo un mundo, el mundo de Auggie <3. 
 Un consejillo final: no lo lean esperando grandes misterios o aventuras, leanlo con la mente abierta y con ganas de un buen rato con algo de humor y reflexiones sencillas pero que llegan directo al alma.

What an incredible story. I just want to hug it and never let it go. I love how the author grants her readers different perspectives. You're not only getting Auggie's thoughts but those of his sister and friends. The emotions are so real. I just never wanted to put the book down. At the last page, I was balling like a baby from the story and the fact that I had to say goodbye to one of the best characters in children's literature. Definitely a bittersweet moment.

What a sweet and heartwarming read. I even teared up a little at the end. This is a lovely story for all ages with a message that I think everyone could use a little dose of. All I am saying plotwise is a kid with facial deformities goes to school for the first time (5th grade). I don't do spoilers. I just loved the story and I recommend this book to pretty much everyone.

3.5 I'm on the edge for this book. It was very strong overall, especially for a contemporary. The story was very meaningful. It was not middle grade, not YA, but somewhere in between with characters from both age groups. There are enough perspectives for anyone to find someone to relate to. 
 With all the points of view giving their side of events in the story, it was sometimes repetitive, especially in the beginning. Also, some perspectives bugged me. One had no capitalization nor quotations.
August, the main character, is wonder-ful in this. I also like the different perspectives that surround him. A must-read for a few reasons.

"Wonder" is by far one of the best books I have ever read. While this book is a young adult novel about a 5th grade boy, it transcends all age limits. August is going into the 5th grade, but he has been home schooled his whole life. This is due to a severe facial deformity he has had since birth. Going to a real school for the first time is a traumatic experience for him, but he faces it with courage and bravery. As the story progresses, I felt myself connect with so many of the characters and sympathizing with the complexities of their experiences. This book with make you think about human nature and the kindness we need to show to each other every day. This is a MUST read!

"When given the choice between being right and being kind, by all means - choose kindness." - Wayne Dyer 
 This quotation is woven throughout the story of Augie Pullman's first year at Beecher Prep. The story is fairly simple and straightforward, written for a fifth grade reading level. But this book should be required reading for all kids, and adults too. 
 Augie, who was born with facial and cranial anomalies, has been sheltered by being home-schooled. But his parents decide that it is time for Augie to go to a real school. How Augie faces the day-to-day dramas and traumas of middle school that any normal kid would face, on top of being an outcast for his appearance, is a great story. Read this book and share it with others.
A stunning book that really left me in tears. I read this to my class and we all went through a gambit of emotions.

I thought this book was an excellent take on a topic rarely discussed. Auggie's experiences as a child with facial deformity were insightful and at times heart breaking. I was glad for the multiple perspectives and felt they really enriched the story. I'd recommend for both kids and adults.

I loved this book! It was an easy read, yet also an important read. I feel like all 5th/6th graders should read this book as it teaches valuable lessons in empathy and kindness. Palacio does a great job showing the importance of kindness without being trite. I also really loved the characters, even the minor ones.

IF YOU LIKED THIS TRY... 
 Yes this book deals with a boys facial deformity in an original, informative, inspiring way. But it also nails the moment of being in 5th grade, a sort of middle-elementary age that can be lost in our obsession with teen/adolescence and (these days especially), those "pre-teen" years. Auggie and his pals are PRE-pre-teen and the dialogue and narration actually reflects this in a very real way. As a result, we get a fully realized depiction of Auggie's challenge just before it's complicated with the issues of personal identity and love-life that are still a couple years away, so the book is one of the few that is fascinating and relevant to 10-100 year olds. Really well done.
Closer to a 4.5- wonderful book!
I've made a mistake. I started reading this book at night and it is morning now. could not close the book.

I read this with my 8 year old and we really enjoyed the story. The book is well written and we enjoyed the dialogue and the humor with which Auggie presents his story. Personally, I don't typically like books with numerous narrators, and I got tired of switching voices throughout the story. I would've enjoyed this more if it was told only from Auggie's POV.
This is such a sweet story about the importance of kindness. I want to read it to my kids when they are a little bigger.

August is such an amazing boy! With everything he's been through he always tries to keep his head held high! 
 Amazing story!!
I hope my kids to read this one, too.
I loved this book. What a fantastic read. Brilliant.

I just finished this book and it was SO good! It really makes you think what it would be like to have a child with a deformity or to have one yourself. I love the characters and reading from all the different perspectives. This is a really wonderful book!

I give this 4.75 out of 5 stars [?] 
 This book is WONDER-ful !!! 
 It's really really good for kids and even elders. I'm so glad that we has to see POVs of other characters, it makes us know and understand more about how they feels about Auggie. This book has a very good story, it showing us how to live life, giving love and acceptance. I highly recommend this you should read it to your youngers.

Uno dei libri piu belli che abbia letto, sul serio. 
 Sara che mi rivedo in molti aspetti della vita di August, il protagonista, tra operazioni in ospedale (stesso reparto) e inconvenienti quotidiani, anche relazionali. Sara che la scrittrice riesce a farti immedesimare a prescindere nei personaggi, anche se certe dinamiche non le hai mai vissute (ogni capitolo e narrato da una persona diversa, mostrando il loro diverso punto di vista sugli stessi fatti). Sara che scorre tutto a meraviglia e si legge in un soffio, tra risate e riflessioni amare. 
 "Wonder" lo consiglio spassionatamente. E uno scorcio per nulla pietistico e triste sulla disabilita, ma non solo. E anche la storia di una famiglia come tante, o come tutte, che affronta le difficolta in modo vero e vicino ad ognuno di noi. Pieno di affetto e maturita, ma anche tanta consapevolezza. 
 Quel che resta e un grande insegnamento: accertarsi per come si e, fregandosene dei giudizi altrui perche tanto, alla fine, chi ci ama restera sempre accanto a noi. Nonostante tutto.

This is a kind of book you need to read when you've watched the news for too long and your faith in humanity has dropped below freezing point. The kind of book every parent should read and then read it to his children and then teach his children how to read it. The kind of book that could actually change the world a little bit. The kind of book that makes you smile and gives you hope. The book I will gift to all my friends' children and recommend to anyone that has a bad day. Seriously, find it, get it, read it. 
 It is not the greatest piece of literature of all time, but that should not be its purpose.

Actually, somewhere between a 3 and a 4 star. It resonated with me because I have a son who was born with a cleft palate. Though his was definitely nothing like August's. 
 The book is told from differing viewpoints which initially caught me by surprise because the first 80 pages is strictly from the viewpoint of August (or Auggie) and then suddenly we switch to - his sister, Via, I think. And then to someone else. Which was good - just unexpected. I have read reviews that did not like some of the voices that were chosen - but I thought they all had good questions, observations, and viewpoints. If they had not been there, then some things that Ms. Palacio wanted to say would have gone unsaid, I think. 
 August is entering 5th grade. He has a severe (emphasis on the word severe) facial abnormality and he has been homeschooled up to this point but his parents think it would be a good idea for him to try school. Not public school but a smaller private school. He is understandably against this idea. At first. But after he meets a couple of the kids, he decides to give it a try. And so the book covers Auggie's first year of school. 
 The book is all about kindness and putting others before you. Also about not judging a book (or a boy, in this case) by its cover. Actually, all the kids have hangups. It's just that Auggie's is very visible and so it takes a while to uncover what is going on with his sister and the kids that befriend (or don't befriend) Auggie. 
 I would really like to hear from kids that read the book and then reviewed it or talked about it. I think it would make a great read-aloud in middle school classroom. There are so many areas that could be opened up for class discussion and class projects. 
 I would recommend it - just keep a box of Kleenex close by because a few tears may flow.

Wow! I am so glad that I read this book. It is warm, inspiring and a positive demonstration of the way that people can work to overcome differences, pulling together to make a real difference. Lessons for all in this book. Definitely inspired by Mr Browne's precepts.

I feel like it possibly would've been a higher rating had I read it vs listened to the audio. 
 Sweet story though overall. I'm glad a movie is being made :)

I was going to say I really liked the POV parts of the book, and how they switched and the way they were written. Then it was August's turn again and I just forgot everything else. It was just so good. I really liked Justin and Miranda. Okay, I just really liked the whole book. All the characters were so well developed, and it was amazing, all the little nuances. It was so REAL! I could imagine real kids I know saying the things the characters said, or acting the way they did. It was super cool. Maybe the book was a bit idealistic, but it's so good and teaches such an incredible lesson that every kid - and adult - should learn.
Lovely YA novel about the importance of never judging a book by its cover.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I loved this book because it made me fell sorry for August because of his facial deformity but he was still determined to go to school and to make friends. Even though Auggie wanted yo drop out a number of times he still managed to go to school and deal with bullying, wars and also tricky school work! I loved this book and I recommend it to anybody over 10 years old. dY~S

Honestly I was surprised by how much I loved this book, mainly because I don't normally read middle grade books, but it was fantastic and I felt myself rooting for these characters. I like the growth from each of them as the year went on, and how they all learned new things about themselves, because like the author wrote middle school is the worse.

One of the best books I have read recently, I read it in less than 24 hours. 
 A rare book that had me smiling, laughing and crying. 
 People can be so cruel and I can't say that I was shocked by some of the behaviour of certain characters in the book. However, it gave me such strong hope that there are kind people in this world who will always do the right thing. This book honestly touched me in ways no other books have; I feel I can truly say this book has changed my life in a simple, but extraordinary way. It has made me view everyone I know and everyone I meet in a different light. It has made me stop and think, "be kinder than is necessary. Because it is not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 I hope everyone takes the time to read Wonder, and I hope it touches your heart like it touched mine. :)

Pretty good. Much more juvenile than the YA books I'm accustomed to, so perhaps it was a little lost on an old lady like me. It's very cute, and I enjoyed the different characters' perspectives, but it felt like a pretty run-of-the-mill kindness conquers all kid's book. 
 Bottom line: Have your kids read this book. It will teach them to be "kinder than is necessary," which is a wonderful lesson to learn.

This book was really geared to a young audience. Some adolescent fiction can be enjoyed by adults, but this would be best enjoyed by 3rd to 6th graders. It is a good story, teaches kindness and acceptance, with a predictable ending. The reason that I read it was because I am often in need of stories for emerging adult readers that can manage 6th to 8th grade reading material.
Cried hard, twice, while reading this. The dialogue is excellent. The characters are real. (Oh middle schoolers, why so cruel?) it's really, really a worthwhile read. Go, Auggie, go!

Liz showed us the book trailer for Wonder in class and I immediately moved it way up on my reading list. Then I went to the Scholastic Warehouse Sale the second time and bought it for myself. One quote from the book trailer burned itself into my consciousness: "You can't blend in when you were born to stand out." Wonder is the story of August (or Auggie). He is a 10 year old boy who has been born with severe facial deformities. Because of extensive surgeries, he has been homeschooled all his life but now he will be starting 5th grade in a regular school. The book is the story of how he, his family and new friends cope with life in this new situation. How do others treat him? Will people see beyond his weird, scary face and instead see him as he really is, inside? 
 I just LOVED this book for lots of reasons. I loved how the author wrote from various points of view. You have the opportunity to get into the head of August, friends Miranda, Jack, Summer, and sister Via. Each person has a unique relationship with August and a new insight into his life. I also really loved how the author deals with the themes of acceptance, especially of people that are different than you; the value of each and every human being, regardless of ability. August is a young man of great ability but his facial deformity makes people think he is stupid, incapable of learning, of being human. The book this reminds me of Out of My Mind by Sharon Draper. From Amazon's description: "Melody is not like most people. She cannot walk or talk, but she has a photographic memory; she can remember every detail of everything she has ever experienced. She is smarter than most of the adults who try to diagnose her and smarter than her classmates in her integrated classroom--the very same classmates who dismiss her as mentally challenged, because she cannot tell them otherwise. But Melody refuses to be defined by cerebral palsy." This is another powerful book about the courage of those with disabilities and how we need to look beyond the outer layer of people and instead, focus on the inner person.

It's been a few years since I originally read this but wanted my kids to read it. Listened to the amazing audio with them and had some great conversations. If you still haven't read this one, you should! 
 (Original review) 
 4.5 The simple message of this book is kindness. 
 As I sit here in my school library and listen to the stories of students whose lives are so different from my mostly picturesque childhood, I can't help but remember this story. I need to remember that I might be someone's only smile that day or only kind words. Remember that I don't know what goes on at home or what is like to be them, even if I think I do. Remember that I might be the only one who looks them in the eye or talks to them one on one. Remember that I might be the one they think of when they need to remember what kindness is. 
 If you need some examples of kindness, read Wonder. Told from various points of view, this story of a a boy who doesn't fit in and the people who surround him with kindness. These characters are not perfect but it is easy to see why they keep trying.

Wow. That was one of the best books I have read in a long time. The message told throughout is one that every person, child and adult, can benefit from. I honestly believe this book has the ability to change somebody's life. It may be the little nudge to get you to go the extra step. "Always try to be kinder than necessary."

The premise of this book is 5 stars for sure. The overall 3 rating is because parts were difficult to read like the book not all being from Auggie's point of view (think Justin's section). Part of me really gets why it was so necessary and I am really glad to better understand the individual motivations of the characters but it was hard to have so many parts and I really disliked reading Justin's part. 
 I liked the character development a lot, you felt that they were really individuals. Auggie wanted to be normal, Via wanted a taste of anonymity, Miranda wanted a family who noticed her, Jack wanted to be good and to have a genuine friend, Julian wanted popularity, etc. 
 I really liked Mr. Tushman, you can see through what he is trying to do the whole book but it is subtle and so heartfelt. I loved the message he brought through about transition points in our lives and how you shouldn't just let middle school age kids off the hook or expect them not to develop character-if not then when? I also liked the subtle message to parents throughout the book about being involved in your kids lives-you could tell the difference in the book between characters whose parents were involved (think Jack, Auggie, Summer) and those who weren't or who taught the wrong things by example (Julian). 
 Choosing kind is so important-everyone has a heart and feelings no matter what they look like, act like, etc. Since we never know what is truly going on with another person we should all do our best to be kinder and genuine about it.

I was recommend this book by a friend who devoured it one sitting. I read it over two evenings and did become totally engrossed by it. I loved the sensitivity of the book and the way it was both heartbreaking & funny. Auggie was lovely and you fall instantly in love with him, but for me I found myself feeling for his sister Via just as much. A daughter that has to grow up fast, gets sidelined ( not through bad parenting, just the facts of their lives) and she understands. All the voices ring true and I loved them all. 
 I docked 1 star for the chapter narrated by Via's boyfriend Justin. I know it was done for a reason I just don't understand what the reason is... Why on earth are there no capital letters! It totally irritated the hell out of me! Urgh! I won't go on but please don't do it again it distracted from the flow of the story. 
 To conclude I am going to give this book to my 8 yr old to read when she's 10. I think all 10 yr olds should read it at school. It makes you think. I am going to try to be kinder from now on.
I finally finished this book! It felt like it took forever. Overall, I enjoyed it, but I didn't enjoy it as much as I thought I would.

This is one of the best books I have read this year, really, really amazing. A must read for parents, teachers, principals, high school, and middle school students. It is a challenge for many new 4th graders, but would probably be o.k. for spring 4th graders. I have my friend, Mrs. Landrigan, to thank for recommending this book to me. I laughed, I cried, I couldn't stop reading, and finished it in one day!!!! The book begins with a quote from one of my favorite Natalie Merchant songs and held my interest until the last word. I kept wanting more, and these characters will stay with me for a while. I thoroughly enjoyed the way the author told the story from the point of view of the different characters, it helped me get a unique perspective on the story. Don't miss out on one of the best books of the year, put it on your summer reading list, if you can wait that long!!
"Wonder" ful! Very touching story, and humorous too. Auggie is a gem!

This was a heart-warming story. A quick read, an interesting read, and with many perspectives that contribute to a work that creates empathy in the reader for those who are different, both on the outside and on the inside. Perhaps it is just a touch too idealistic at particular moments, but that is easily forgiven when considering the intended age of a reader of this story.
At times maudlin, but also devastatingly realistic of the cruelty & kindness of children.

Ten year old, August Pullman is a medical "wonder". August was named after his Brazilian grandpa Augusto. Everyone just calls him Auggie. He has inherited a rare genetic sequence of DNA that altered the way his face formed. After many surgeries, Auggie, as his family calls him, can finally breathe easier and live without special feeding tubes. 
 After being home schooled by mom, his parents decide it is time for Auggie to start 5th grade at the nearby Middle School Prep. Auggie is used to people staring, but doesn't think he can handle 5th grade. He's afraid of staring school and afraid of how the other kids will react to him and how hard it will be to pretend he doesn't notice their unkind actions and words. Middle School is tough. Auggie thinks he won't fit in. What he does know is that his doctors have called his condition a wonder of science. To family and friends Auggie is "wonderful".

This is a must for parents, educators, children, and basically anyone that ventures into public. Auggie, the most loveable ten-year-old boy on the face of the earth, was cursed with a facial anomaly that terrifies others. This is broader than the story of one boy's struggle; the major theme is the importance of kindness. People effect others whether they want to or not. 
 Told from the perspective of Auggie, his older sister Via, his new friends Jack and Summer, and Via's friends Justin and Miranda, my heart was captured from the first page. I stayed up until 3:00 am finishing this book because I had to know happened next. I laughed, I cried. I fell in love with Auggie and his friends and I wanted to rip the bullies apart limb for limb. R.J. Palacio told this incredibly important story beautifully. I hope it gives our world some perspective that it very much needs.

A really wonderful story. I admit, I teared up a few times, but it wasn't too heavy handed or preachy. I'm not sure how much the multiple narrators added to the story, but it was an interesting choice. Auggie is a pretty special character. And the art is just perfect.

This is one of the most profound and timely books I've read. I read it aloud to fourth and fifth grade classes and they identified with Auggie and the rest of the characters. I hope it may have inspired some empathy in them. Thanks R.J. Palacio for a wonderful thought provoking book!

** spoiler alert ** 
 Such a wonderful book! Highly recommend to all students in grades 4-6. This book teaches about kindness towards others despite whatever flaws they may have! 
 SPOILER ALERT dYs" 
 DO NOT read this book if you love a dog named Daisy! You've been warned!

August (Auggie) Pullman is a 10 year old boy who is much the same as other kids his age--he loves Star Wars, playing with his dog, and his XBox. But he has one very important thing that makes him different: his face. Auggie was born with a severe craniofacial deformity that even several surgeries have not been able to fix. 
 But life has been mostly OK for Auggie, because he's lived with his loving sister and parents, who homeschooled him. But then they tell Auggie something he is not prepared for: He will be going to regular school as a fifth grader. 
 I can't even tell you how much I enjoyed this book. It's so rare that a book has you feeling a gamut of so many emotions. I laughed, smiled, cried, and felt tinges in my heart for some of the things Auggie was going through. I am a mother, and I cannot imagine having to be in that situation to have a son so different. 
 The best thing about August is that he has such a great sense of humor through it all. He laughs at himself more than anyone else does. In fact, he is the one who makes others feel comfortable around him. In spite of the lot he's been given in life, once you get to know him he makes friends easily. 
 I really enjoyed the use of the different narrators throughout the book as well. It was great to get each person's different perspective on life with Auggie and see where they were coming from. The only thing I wish I could have seen was maybe a chapter from each of Auggie's parents. 
 It would have been easy to make a book about a "deformed" boy and overcoming adversity very sappy and eye-roll-inducing. But RJ Palacio has done a great job with making lovable characters and plot lines that a reader can really get into. I can't wait to read more from her.

I expected to be blown away by this book - so many rave reviews and a contender for the Newbery. Very enjoyable, but not a 5-star. The ending was a tad predictable. The first half was certainly a 5, but the latter half dropped off a bit on the amazement-scale. Still, a great read for anyone. Truly, anyone.

(From www.pingwings.ca) 
 This was the most recent pick for the Sisterhood of the Travelling Book Club, and this is a book that had been on my TBR for years. I'm so glad I finally got around to reading it! 
 Wonder was a great book, and a very quick read. I read the whole thing in one day, and was immediately pulled into Auggie's world. I also really enjoyed that the story changed perspectives so that I got to know other characters better. I wasn't expecting that and I really enjoyed it. 
 This was a really great book, one that I think I would have loved when I was younger. There is a movie adaptation coming out later this year, and I am definitely going to have to see it.

Sweet Auggie....what a fanstastic little boy, and what a great story. I really enjoyed this one. :) 
 "Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness." 
 --Wonder

Every kid should read this book and I hope every adult and teacher. R. J. Palacio hits the tone of this book perfectly (maybe she still feels like a grade five student inside?) and it has the ringing endorsement of the kids at our house. 
 Her main character, August Pullman, has been home-schooled by his mother for years and his family decides he should start attending a normal school in grade five as it is the time that many kids transition to a new school and so many of them will feel awkward and 'new'. August - "Auggie" - isn't exactly sure that this is the way to go but agrees to give it a try. Tricky part in his life though, is that he was born with severe facial deformities and has undergone something like 27 surgeries in his short life to try and improve some of the difficulties he was born with, like problems with his palate or eyelids. 
 August goes through all of the difficulties of being an unusual new kid but it is multiplied hundreds of times over. The changes he goes through and the changes of his classmates are what make this book fascinating and R. J. Palacio's gift for looking into that 10-year old brain and emotions make it real. 
 At the end of the book August thinks "I didn't destroy a Death Star (he is a fan of Star Wars) or anything like that, but I did just get through the fifth grade." It's a great book and one I'll be passing on over and over.
"Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed". Words to remember.
This is the book to beat for this year's Newbery Award. If it doesn't take the gold, I predict it will at least snag an honor award. We'll see if I'm right...

'Wonder'is one of those books that fills me with an evangelical zeal and I just want to give everyone a hug. I want to tell everyone I see that no matter what others say about them they are a wonder and they deserve a standing ovation atleast once in their life. I was tedious when I first read this book because, lets face it, it is set for a Middle School Audience, but it appeals to everyone. This book made me cry, laugh, and want to punch people in the face all at the same time. There isn't really a 'main character' because some of the book is split into section's and it is in a different character's point of view- Via, Auggie, Jack, etc. If you like books that make you happy or think about life. Read this book. If you like Star Wars or Harry Potter. Read this Book. If you like making the world a better place (because after you read this you will be giving everybody hugs.) READ THIS BOOK. You will not regret. If you do that's okay. You might be soul-less, heartless, and brainless, but none-the-less, it's okay. Please, read this book.
Something about the ending left me uneasy. Also, the dog seemed a little much.
This was, quite simply, amazing <3
A great book with a beautiful message.
3.5 stars for this cute, sweet, yet totally unrealistic book. A quick and satisfying read and I'd definitely recommend it.

I have had my eye on this one for a good while, especially with all the hype around it. This book is about a boy named Auggie who is completely normal. Oh! Except for that one thing about having a deformed face. I will not reveal too much about plot except that it's about Auggie's struggles while attending school for the first time as a 5th grader. But that's not all folks, this book also centers around other side characters by switching pov's, something I want to mention because I'm listing it as a reason you should read this book. 
 Without further ado, here's what I thought about Wonder. 
 1. Deformities: I loved how Auggie's deformities were revealed to us. It is clarified right off the bat that there's something not right with the way Auggie looks, but as you read, the picture starts to come together, and I loved that! Not just as a reader but as a writer. When you study writing in first person, you always have the conversation about how to best relate to your reader what your MC looks like, and this book was an exemplary example of that rule. But as a reader, it allowed me to delve deep into the core of Auggie's character and approach his deformities with just the right mind-sight. Well done, Palacio, well done. 
 2. About Auggie: My favorite thing about Auggie was how down-to-earth he was. There was no pretentiousness in his character. I feel that's a common approach when it comes to books like these, but Auggie was such a normal, flawed, quirky, nerdy, kind little boy, endearing and so realistic. 
 3. About Those POV's: I have to admit, I wasn't hooked on this one until a bit into the book where we started getting more pov's. I really like Auggie and his story to begin with, but what it was was that the book switched to Auggie's sister, Olivia's, perspective and I found myself relating to her so strongly it hurt. And I think that's what Palacio was trying to do overall, put something in this book for everyone. Of course, I like all the other's, and Auggie's story was the one to make me cry tears of joy in the end. I'll just go on a tangent and say it now, what a wonderful ending!!! 
 4. Bullying: The theme of bullying is a heavy one in this book, and it relates to ALL of the characters' stories. Seeing it in such a diversified and complex light was critical to this book's theme, and a big reason why I loved it so much. 
 5. Transcends the Ages: This is definitely a book that transcends the ages: Here's why. 1) Kids of this age group will have so many things they can directly relate to. 2) Teens and older teens will remember all of the emotions captured in this book with painful remembrance. Yet somehow, at the same time, it feels so good to know you are done with that time of your life and survived it. Plus it makes you analyze all the past bull-shit you went through, which can be an empowering thing, truly. 3) Adults are portrayed well in this book and I think it would be interesting for adults/parents to see the characters Palacio has chosen and how he has portrayed them. Plus it's a good reminder of how complex and difficult young adult life is at all levels. 
 6. Makes Me Think: I love it when books make me think and then subsequently catch me by surprise at my own thoughts. In this book I realized I saw Auggie's skin as being burned (likely because Auggie tells us that he has been commonly thought of as being deformed due to getting stuck in a fire). But the thing was, I knew that wasn't true from the start, so why did I see him that way? He is intensely deformed in every feature of his face, but that doesn't mean his actual skin is grotesque. I don't exactly know what this realization said of me, but I think it's something to do with seeing an unfamiliar thing or hearing an unfamiliar concept and automatically associating it with something undesirable or inferior or even gross or pitiable. When it's actually just different. 
 Hmm, what do you think?

Shall we make a new rule of life...always try to be a little kinder than is necessary? 
 In that one sentence is wrapped the premise of Wonder: to be kinder than is necessary. That it's not enough to be kind but that one should be kinder than needed. That the decision to be kind is a choice each and every single one of us faces, but that not every one chooses to do so, because, let's face it, it's hard. 
 I don't really want to say too much about this book, only that it is simultaneously beautiful and ugly and all too real. I think each person has to discover it for themselves and take whatever meaning they want to from it, because each person is different. Each person is flawed, and those flaws -- whether real or perceived, regardless of whether they are physical, emotional or psychological -- almost always affects how we behave and are perceived by others. 
 This is an adult book that I think children should read. Many will say this was written for young adults (and I think that's probably true as well) but I believe adults would benefit from reading this anyway. It's very easy to lose sight of things when people, regardless of age, are caught up in the drudgery of their own quotidian existence. It's easy to lose sight of how lonely life can be even when you're surrounded by so many people, or how uplifting it can be when someone notices you. 
 There's much to be learned by everyone from this novel, least of which is this: we all have a choice about how we are with others -- and everyone, to a degree, is imperfect, flawed, damaged -- and that being kind or nice is not easy, even if you love someone very much. Sometimes it's easier to be cruel or mean or even neutral. That sometimes, in the need to want to belong to a group, in the desire to be accepted, it's easier to do something atrocious and demeaning just so you're not alone or ostracized. And sometimes, part of growing up is making the hard choices and not conforming, that we all need to accept and love our flaws. 
 Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world. -- Auggie 
 I could've finished this book in one sitting, but I didn't. I wanted it to last. I re-read a few chapters again and again, because it touched me so much.
Wow. This might be listed as a book for kids, but it is a book for everyone. Everyone should read this book.
I loved this book. it made me happy, sad, angry, joyful. it was everything I love in a book. I recommend it to everyone.
An awesome read........

I had heard a lot about this gem of a book and now I know why. I think I had heard it was sad which made me think someone dies (they do but now who u might think) so had to be in the right mood. Instead it made glad to be alive and reminded me the most important legacy we can leave on this earth is how we treat others. I loved that this book can be read by children and adults alike. I hope schools adopt for their reading curriculum. Good life lessons to be learned through the story of Auggie -- a little boy with a huge heart and unique but wonderful face. Please do yourself a favor and read this book. It's a quick read and well worth it!

Loved it. 
 It's fantastic getting to experience the perspectives of the different characters. 
 A very uplifting read.

One of the better young adult novels I have read in a very long time. The characters are genuinely believable. The experiences are realistic. The first book in a while I have devoured in large chunks. Will definitely read more by this author when she releases new books.

One of my favorite middle grade books ever! Wonder has heart, humor, and even "precepts"- mottos for living. I listened to the audio book, and the readers did an excellent job. 
 Wonder is divided into several parts, each with a different character point of view. Auggie opens and closes the novel, getting the most "page time". He uses kid-friendly terms to explain how it feels to live with his deformity. For example, he says that the school secretary gives him a "shiny smile" when she first meets him. Shiny smile = a fake, too big, smile people use when they feel uncomfortable. 
 I especially enjoyed the POV of Auggie's older sister Via. She describes the universe of her family: Auggie is the sun, and she and her parents are the planets spinning around him. Her words aren't resentful, just terribly honest, and compelling. 
 The other voices include a few of Auggie's and Via's friends I like how Palacio portrays how Auggie's situation affects the people around him. The peripheral characters earn my empathy and attention just as much as Auggie does. 
 One of my favorite adult characters is Auggie's English teacher. (Of course, right?) Every month Mr. Browne gives his students a precept, or motto, to think about, and he opens the year with this one: 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." - Dr. Wayne Dyer. 
 Some of the BIG IDEAS Wonder addresses are straightforward: friendship, loyalty, and judging appearances. But some are more tricky. Like, is it ok to break a rule if you are protecting a friend? And, what's the difference between protecting someone and babying someone? 
 Overall, a thoughtful novel that's great for middle grade readers through adults! 
 Taken from my full review at Diary of a Word Nerd: http://wp.me/p2SvHJ-h5
ok for the littles
This would be a great read-aloud for 5th grade teachers at the beginning of the school year...or anytime. Wonderful story!

I loved this book, but I must admit to you right off that I am a sucker for happy endings and a bit of a sap. Some people will not love this book like I do. This is the story of 10-year-old Auggie Pullman, a boy with severe facial abnormalities even after numerous surgeries. Auggie's face strikes fear in little kids, meanness from kids his own age, and strange looks from adults. Auggie has been home-schooled his entire life, but his parents have decided that it is time for him to go to public middle school. The story is told from multiple perspectives, and it is funny, heartwarming, sad in places, and wonderful...to me. The problem that some readers will have is that the book presents the world as it should be rather than how it really is. For example, Auggie's new principal is wonderful. He draws Auggie out of his shell, doesn't have the normal horrified reaction most adults have to seeing Auggie's face, and helps Auggie warm to the idea of attending public school. While there are many principals just like this, there are also some who would not give Auggie this kind of time and attention. For some readers, too many characters are perfect and wonderful. I think this book will be one that you either love or hate. I loved it!
Sensitive story about a boy who has a facial deformity and the challenges his faces as a middle school student.

What I love about today's snowy weather is that I was able to get off work early and it's too cold outside that even the heater was always on, I still dont want to 
 leave my blanket and I have enough time to finish this 
 book. I love each unique characters and their way of narrating, love the way the story is told through different perspectives. Defo a really worth reading book.
A must-read for every child and adult!!
Fantastic, heart-wrenching and heart-warming. Everyone should read this book at least once.

Just finished reading this with my son. Powerful message presented in an engaging story. Auggie Pullman is a compelling main character. I also loved that the story was told by several characters. The different perpectives made the story flow well.

If you read the Goodreads description, then you know Auggie isn't "normal". (And yes...I tried to imagine what he looked like: kind of like Sloth from Goonies but smaller.) He has a "previously unknown type of mandibulofacial dysostosis caused by an autosomal recessive mutation in the TCOF1 gene complicated by a hemifacial microsomia" (Google it). Because of his need to have MANY surgeries to fix some of the problems associated with his rare problem, Auggie has never gone to a real school. 
 If you've ever gone to a new school (even transitioning from elementary to middle), then you know it isn't easy even if you are "normal". Auggie's story of his fifth grade year is told from a variety of perspectives: his sister's, his new friends, his sister's new boyfriend, and his own. Not only do we get to see how Auggie sees people's reactions to him, but we also get to see how those people handle themselves around Auggie. (And how they change as they get to know him on the inside instead of just judging the outside.)
just...wonderful
Wonderful story that makes want to hug everyone and cry.

This is one of those books you want, no, wish everyone would read! Read it to your kids, classes, grand-kids, everyone you can think of. Help kids discover the empathy they have within, that others you don't even think could, have, or those you know DON'T have, will after this read. 
 Awesome in my opinion! Love the first person, voices, action, drama, friendship, love, devotion, the peep into others lives you think are just great, but are far from it for one reason or another. "Everyone deserves a standing ovation at least once in their lives!" August Pullman 
 This book deserves on big standing O! 5+ stars!

Love, love, love this book! I laughed so many times, and then...yes...there were times tears sprung to my eyes. A fun and touching read. 
 I think all kids should read this one. But, it's a really good one to remind adults about what's what.

Whenever too many people start recommending a book, I get nervous. If I don't like it, I'll be disappointing a lot of people. Also, there's this thing of... like... who recommended it to me first, you know? 
 The biggest people encouraging me to bump this up on my are as follows: 
 My wife Liz, who got my daughter Eleanor to read it as well. 
 My daughter Eleanor, who asked me after I was 5 pages in, "what's your favorite part?" 
 Tim, a friend I teach with, who is also a goodreader. 
 *Sidenote* 
 So Tim, who I teach with, put this really cool "book review wall" outside his room. It was great. 
 Check it out, sorry it's a little blurry: 
 The best part was, instead of giving books stars, or thumbs up, or whatever, he rated them in Isenbargers. (Mrs. Isenbarger is our school Librarian/Media Specialist.) I thought it was really clever, and much better than the boring old stars that goodreads uses. (No offense, goodreads.) 
 At any rate, Wonder earned a high 5! ISENBARGERS!! 
 *End Sidenote* 
 The book was also recommended by our science teacher - Mrs. Shelton, several goodreaders, and praised by a cousin-in-law Seulky - and by extension her daughter - during the reading. 
 All that to say: the book didn't disappoint. To live up to all that hype is a feat in and of itself. 
 Eleanor had read it, but asked me if - since I was reading it myself - would I read it out loud to her. I told her I would when she was around, but I wouldn't read the whole thing. Man, did she love this book. Every couple pages, she'd ask me what my favorite part was up until that point. She had to cover her mouth so she wouldn't give anything away. 
 She asked if she could help me review this one, but I told her no. I wanted to review this one on my own. It was really interesting reading sections with her. She doesn't quite realize what a Wonder she is herself. 
 It was tough for me to read the part out loud to Eleanor where the mom is describing Auggie's birth to August himself. She didn't catch the nuance. She only caught the comedy and love: the farting nurse, the doctor passing out, and the love that the mother had for August. She heard the story as August himself heard it. I, on the other hand, heard the story that wasn't told. The perspective of a mom telling about a time in her life when she was very scared, and very alone - knowing that she can't tell this version to her son, which is still as much the truth as the other version. 
 The version she told Auggie was not a lie of omission. There are many ways to tell a story. That was one of the strengths of the book: the way it pulled in the different perspectives so well. 
 Yeah, it was tough reading that part out loud. But it was brilliant to hear Eleanor laughing as I read it. 
 Here is the video for the song Wonder, if you're interested. Which begs the question: was Auggie the only wonder in this book?

I actually really enjoyed this, and I like books that showcase different characters' perspectives on a situation. What I actually liked best was that the author seemed to have a very keen understanding of exactly how bullying and general unkindness works at that age, and showcased it happening to everyone, not just August. 
 I'd gladly give this to kids who liked "Origami Yoda," "The Last Invisible Boy," "Out of My Mind," and similar reads.

This is an amazing book. Rarely do I read a book and think that EVERYONE should read it, but that was my reaction after reading Wonder. Many of my students have already read it for a book club and their reactions have been powerful - I hear them refer to it frequently, so I know it has stayed on their minds. It has stayed on my mind too; Auggie (and the many people whose lives he touches) is absolutely unforgettable.
Great book. :)
Read it -- no questions asked.
Loved this book.

I feel harsh giving this 3*- I enjoyed the book, a lot but found it a bit shallow at times. Extremely short chapters, 6 (some brief) perspectives- it was a beautiful story but I could have done with delving deeper. I didn't find it emotional, but instead poignant- I just think it was aimed at a younger audience and so I missed the level of fiction I most enjoy. Good- verging on 4*.

The fact it isn't for my age range did not hinder the impact this book had. It was thoughtful and thought provoking, plus wonderfully written with enough humour and liveliness to make it perfect for younger readers. 
 It deals with complicated issues in such a way that it emphasises the idea that they shouldn't be 'taboo'. It encourages the reader to embrace difference and understand that difference is normal. 
 The focus was on August, who is astoundingly mature for his age - though we still understand that he is a child verging young adult. He's remarkably good-natured though his situation is tough. He overcomes it gloriously, though not without its down bits, and it's wonderful to see the glorious way he brings out the best in those around him. 
 It's told from multiple perspectives, and I felt like I got to know every character. From August's friends Jack and Summer to his sister, Olivia, and her boyfriend. I kind of adored Mr. Tushman. 
 His family is caring if not overbearing and I loved Olivia's input in the novel. She has had to deal with a lot whilst understanding her life isn't as necessarily difficult as Augusts. But she still has her own problems to deal with, from friends to thinking her mum doesn't care for her as much as August. 
 This story isn't just about August's face, it's also about children and young adults having to deal with growing up and all it contains: school, friends, and family. It's a wonderful book written by someone who put a lot of care in to representing the under-represented in novels and life. I enjoyed it very much.

I can honestly say, I think this was the best book I read in 2013. It's about a boy with a facial deformity who goes to his first year of middle school and has to cope with all kinds of things a kid that age would go through. It sounds like one of those tear-jerker sappy books where you are supposed to cry through half the book and then feel like you are a better person for having read it. Happily it is not that at all. There are sad moments and funny moments just like in life but I never felt like the author was trying to manipulate the reader into an emotional reaction. Also, there were Star Wars references which is a big plus in anything really. The story is told from several viewpoints and they have interesting or intriguing moments. August, the main character has his own sections but the ones told by Via his older sister are just as, if not more, compelling. The only complaint I had about the whole thing was the part with the dog. I don't want to spoil anything but I'm not sure that whole business was necessary. Yet even with that thrown in, this book was a seriously good read.

This is a story about a boy who was born with profound facial differences, and his adventure starting fifth grade at a mainstream school for the first time. The story is told from the perspective of several different characters, and I loved the way each of them added something important to the story and painted a complete picture. Engaging, moving, real and ultimately uplifting, Wonder is one of those books that make you want to recommend it to strangers on the street. I plan to share it with my students this year.

The BEST children's book I read in 2012. 
 Wonder is told in chapters that alternate between characters, giving us multiple perspectives. Auggie, or August, was born with a facial deformity that has put him through a huge number of surgeries, and, as a result, has been home-schooled. He is about to start the fifth grade at a school with other kids. Not only is he a new kid, an awkward situation for any kid, but the way he looks makes the other kids squeamish and mean. However, Auggie's perseverance and who he is on the inside garners him friendships. This is a wonderful story about friendship and what it truly means to be a friend.
