It's funny, sad, and uplifting---a book for all ages.

Such a fast, enjoyable read. Somewhat problematic at times; not sure why Via's boyfriend's chapter had to have no capitalization for example. If they were going to print it like that they may as well have add grammatical and spelling errors for the fifth graders. But I really liked this story.

Great book, well told exploration of being "different" but finding your place. Only complaint is that the family buried the sister's needs. Siblings of special needs kids should be allowed to be their own person outside of the affected sibling.

This is a very simple book about being different and trying to fit into a milieu. It's about celebrating all that that difference - that thing that sets us apart and makes us special - can bring to the homogeneity of a group. In this case, August Pullman, who has been homeschooled all these years owing to multiple surgeries in his decade-long existence, starts 5th grade in a regular school. 
 What I liked most of all was how many of the characters, especially Auggie, his sister Via, and their parents, are comfortable in their skin, and unfazed about letting their vulnerability show.

Such a warming tale. I love how easy it is to get familiar with the characters like as if we're engaged in a real conversation. I love Auggie the most. Everyone should read it, it is such a happy book.

What a beautifully crafted book! I loved the way that the book was written, with each part spoken by a different character. The voice of each character was different, yet reflective of that character's age. 
 I can see this book being well-received and appreciated by middle and high schoolers. What a wonderful volume to promote the values of empathy, teamwork, and friendship! I thoroughly enjoyed the book from beginning to end and look forward to future books by this author.

I posted a full review on my blog: http://britwillwrite.wordpress.com. 
 To put it plainly, though, it just wasn't very well-written to me. The characters were unrealistic and one-dimensional, and there was little overall conflict. It has a good message to it, but the writing left a lot to be desired.
LOVED this book. Everyone should read it.

I team my did enjoy this book:) it's a touching story about a kid and I loved reading the other perspectives. August affected everyone and that's why it was interesting to see the other characters thoughts and point of view. I highly recommend this book:)

I can't remember the last time I cried so hard over a book. From the very beginning I was completely entranced by the characters and I loved how as a reader, we got to see the story from many different perspectives. Wonder is a beautiful story of the trials and tribulations of growing up and it really is WONDERful!!!!

This was such a good book! It just moves you and you get so attached to the characters. I also really liked the structure and how it allows you to see Auggie in other character's perspective. Really, really good, definitely recommend it!

I've already purchased three additional copies of this wonderful book to share with my daughter's school and friends. Adults and kids alike should read this book. An amazing view of how we see/treat others who are different than we are. A great debut story for Palacio.

Wonderful book recommended by my 10 year old daughter. She basically insisted I read it after her 5th grade teacher read it to the class. My daughter even read to me to get me hooked, and we finished it in two nights. This is a must-read for every 5th grader. It is a beautifully written story of a young boy born with extreme facial deformities, home schooled until 5th grade, who enters school for the first time and must face the biases and rejection of his peers. Written for young adults, it contains life lessons and reminders of basic truths that people of all ages can benefit from.

I'm usually not a middle-grade reader, but the cover caught my attention since the beginning of the year. I've seen a couple glowing reviews for it, but I didn't think much about it until I saw it in the library last week, and I was like "why not?" I read the first few pages to test the book out, and I somehow ended reading thirty pages...and I still wasn't sure what's up with the main character, Auggie: from the first few pages, I knew he had something that set in apart, but I didn't know what exactly--so I borrowed the book to sate my curiosity. And boy am I glad I did. 
 Wonder is the fascinating, inspiring story of Auggie who is born with a severe Treacher-Collin's syndrome, making his face almost hideous to strangers. He attends school for the first time in fifth grade, and he struggles to fit into the school environment. But he is not the only one with problems as his friends and family also struggle to adapt to him. The story, theme may be predictable, but it's the execution that makes Wonder special. Each character has their own engaging, heartfelt story to tell. Wonder is definitely one of my favorite, thought-provoking reads this year. It opens itself to many discussions, and I wish I read it when I was in fifth grade. 
 So What Does August Look Like? 
 Admittedly I had a hard time picturing August (Auggie) since the descriptions made him sound like everything that could possibly go wrong--went wrong on his face. What in the world are cauliflower ears? And no jaw? bulging eyes? 
 So I Googled. And it was just heartbreaking. Though maybe I've seen my share of not-so-normal things, it didn't surprise me. I can see why kids would be horrified though. 
 Fifth Graders Can Be Mean: 
 What stood out for me was Palacio's uncanny ability to capture the feeling of being ostracized in school. I had a nostalgic feeling of being back in fifth grade (even if it has been nine years ago) and I had my share of unwelcome peers--and I wasn't even suffering from Treacher-Collins syndrome. Like Auggie, I've dealt with "The Plague," friends who didn't stand up for me, and knowing telling the teacher is pretty useless (even if you can live down being a tattleteller.) Fifth-grade was serious business, and I was glad I missed the last week of school for a trip--I was eager to get away from my peers. 
 The thing that hurt most was the realization that the 10-year old me would probably not stand up for Auggie. Instead I would be grateful that it wasn't me that they were picking on. Not having a partner for field trips or group projects was not on my list of priorities. Hey! I was ten, stuff like that matters. 
 Characters: 
 I was pleasantly surprised with Palacio's wide spectrum of characters and how the voices still remained distinguishable. Wonder is composed with several points of view from Auggie, Jack, Summer, Via, Miranda, and even Justin. They may be all kids, but they speak volumes. I was delighted with their complexity, and I ended up loving each character for being themselves. I was disappointed I didn't get Julian (the head bully)'s viewpoint though, I was convinced he had more depth--beyond the influence of his stuck-up, rich parents. What I really wanted to see was Julian's parents being taught a lesson. 
 August (Auggie) 
 I have mixed feelings about him. Throughout the novel I see him grow-up, and not use his appearance as an excuse: when he goes to sleep by himself without being told and when he leaves his stuffed animal behind. But even at the end of the novel, I can't help feeling like he hasn't changed that much. There's a scene where he hopes that he will be handsome man in his next life, and his dependency on the astronaut helmet--both of these scenes make me feel Auggie is still the kid in the beginning of the novel. Rather, I think it's the people around him that deserve more credit. 
 However, I still admire this kid. Never did he feel sorry for himself, or wonder out of the probabilities--why was he chosen like the people around him do.) 
 Olivia (Via) 
 My favorite character, and arguably the most realistic one. August's older sister who is starting high school. She's my favorite character for she embodies so many conflicts, but yet still remain in control of her emotions. She is a wonderful older sister. Via is also a heart-wrenching character because she loves Auggie, but she hates herself for the less-than-nice thoughts she has of her brother. At times Via shows signs of sibling jealousy--but yet she restrains herself. She constantly debates what's best for her brother: if they should make him feel normal (and if that would be lying to him), or teach him how to deal with being abnormal. 
 Justin: 
 Via's boyfriend. He is the passive observer who at first doesn't know how to react to Auggie. I had my reservations since his lack of capitalization irked me, reminding me of Omegle conversations with illiterate people (I imagine him talking in slurs.) He also seemed like a very reserved character. But even he does some surprising things that made me like him instantly. 
 Summer: 
 One of Auggie's friends. Honestly, I find her the most unrealistic character. Not being she's super nice (which she is), but because her actions are idealized. Why would you sit down and immediately start making a list of names with a kid you just met? I am not sure how good of a conversation started that is in real life. 
 Ending: 
 I was bracing myself for a happy, cheesy ending--and I got the unrealistic, happy, cheesy ending I secretly didn't want. Oh well, at least it tied well to Auggie's belief that "everyone deserves a standing ovation." 
 Despite the cheesy ending, I fell in love with Wonder. There are points in the book I wasn't a big fan of such as the whole precept idea. I just thought that was unnecessary and even slightly lame. But I loved the multiple perspectives, and the astronaut helmet. A brilliant novel, and an inspiring story.
This book was everything I wanted it to be and more. I love it when a book exceeds my expectations. This is a fantastic book.
What a touching and moving book. A definite must read!! I'm sad it took me so long to pick it up!!!

I stayed up late several nights so I could keep reading this. It's a page turner about empathy, character and inner strength. My sixth grader enjoyed it also. At times I felt like the kids acted older that the fifth graders they were supposed to be. Perhaps that's because they're from NYC. My sixth grader thought it was a pretty authentic portrayal. Favorite quote, err, precept, "it's not enough to be friendly, you have to be a friend. "

I normally do not read MG books but I am so glad I read this one! All of the characters were real and interesting and I loved the message. This is a book I plan to read with my son when he is a little bit older.

Parts of this book deserved five stars, but a few sections fell a little short, so I could only give it four. 
 Augie himself was wonderful as a character, and I really liked the way his family was portrayed. Even when they did things I didn't like, they were believable and interesting. I had more trouble with his sister's friend Miranda, whose section was less convincing. The kids who were Augie's own age were very realistic, but some of the slightly older kids and teens seemed a little too cardboardy. 
 Augie's ability to get past the pain of his own life was inspiring. As a reader, I both felt sorry for him and attracted to him, because his personality came across as friendly and charismatic, which is amazing in the face of what he had to go through. I thought that his fascination with Star Wars was really cool, and found it sad that he thought he had to "outgrow" that aspect of his life. I mean, he made it through 5th grade in a brand new environment with all of his other challenges, but somehow having a Star Wars poster in his bedroom was going to distance people from him? That didn't quite make sense, and if it was to indicate that he was maturing in some way, it didn't work for me. 
 Augie's other interactions with people, even the negative ones, were brilliantly crafted and convincing. While Palacio gradually describes the details and deformities of Augie's face, over the course of many pages, the mind's eye has a hard time putting them together in a way that makes the reader flinch. So, by the time you realize just how different his appearance is, you've come to accept Augie. That was extremely well done.

This is one of those books that once you begin it- you can't stop until you finish it. I just finished reading this book and relished every word. Beautifully interweaved perspectives of a special boy who just yearns for normalcy. A definite must read when you are in the mood for something that touches the soul and warms the heart. 
 Three words to describe this book-Inspiring. Captivating. Empowering.
What a special book. It should be required reading for all. The story may be predictable but the writing was unexpected and incredibly powerful. I am so, so grateful that Auggie is a part of my life.
Beautiful book that made me cry on the subway.

After recently finishing Netflix's series '13 Reasons Why' and coincidentally reading this at the same time, I've really been learning the importance of kindness. Always be kind. 
 This book was a quick, light read. But one which has had quite an impact on me. Auggie and his family have bought so much light in my life, I just want to hug them all! Such a beautiful book with great messages. Recommend to ALL!
Read so many disappointing books lately. This just caught me unawares. Started reading it to see if it was suitable for my 9 year old and couldn't put it down.
All kids should be required to read this book in school.

My first YA book in a while. I read it because my daughter had it assigned for summer reading for school. 
 I was very impressed with this book! Well written, interesting, put together wonderfully, good story and characters - everything you need for a good book. It did get a bit preachy at times - the points were well made with the story and didn't really need to be summarized for the reader. All in all, a very enjoyable read.
Finally read WONDER and it did not disappoint! Full of heart and hope and a reminder to choose kindness even when it's hard!
The book is a great 4-star book. With the addition of Julian's chapter, it became a 5-star book. Great story with an amazing lesson.

Definitely written for a younger audience with some predictability, but the message is great. 
 First what I didn't like - I found the author mentioning way too many pop culture references from a variety of generations. I kind of felt like saying to her, "I get it, you are still young, hip, and 'with it'." 
 Also, I did like the different points of view from the different characters, but sometimes I felt like she was trying too hard to stylize her writing, like when she wrote from an older kid's perspective but for some reason HE was the one who didn't have capital letters to begin the sentences, etc. 
 That said, I would recommend this book, and I would read it again. It had a good message, it was engaging, it was an easy read, and I liked the characters.
Hmm, not what I expected. Thought-provoking and enjoyable, but nothing groundbreaking.

Kisah tentang anak yang menederita kelainan Mandibulofacial Dysostosis atau Treacher Collins Syndrome. Kalian bisa langsung masukkan kalimat itu dan carilah di gambar bagaimana gambaran wajah si tokoh utama kita. 
 Sebenarnya sudah lama penasaran dengan buku ini karena sampulnya yang menarik, walaupun belum pernah baca reviewnya. Bahkan saya tidak punya banyangan apa isi buku ini. 
 Di awal bab buku ini bercerita dari sisi August 'Auggie' Pullman, bagaimana Auggie menilai orang tuanya, kakaknya, dan teman-temannya. Auggie juga bercerita mengenai penyakitnya, bagaimana dari sedikit kemungkinan yang ada, dia bisa terkena kelainan wajah seperti itu. Jujur kalau ngebanyangin bayi yang harus di operasi berkali-kali pasti rasanya tidak tega dan lagi hasil operasi juga tidak menjadikannya sama seperti anak-anak lainnya. 
 http://thelittlepresent.blogspot.com/...

This is one of the best books I have read all year. I would not be surprised if it is a Newbery contender. It is so timely with all the recent news and talk about bullying in schools. All 5th,6th, and 7th graders should be required to read this. This story will make kids think twice before they say something mean to a classmate. It is about a 5th grader with facial deformities, and is an amazing chronicle of Auggie's first year in school after being homeschooled for his earlier grades. Told from multiple perspectives it is a book you will not be able to put down.
This book is amazing. I laughed. I cried. It gave me a new point of view. My students loved it.

Love this book. I know some think that the ending is a little too perfect, but I think it's a natural ending for the story and it worked for me. The first chapters left me feeling like it was going to be a bit after-school-special, but the changing of the voices, and getting to hear from so many different characters really worked for me. Palacio captured the complexities of the relationships surrounding Auggie, and gave each character a depth. This one will stick with me for a long time, and will probably be reread.
Stupendous! One of the most moving books I've read in a long time.
Loved, loved, loved this book. Everyone should read it and take the message from it.

August "Auggie" Pullman has a severe facial deformity. His ears are two tiny cauliflowers. His eyes are low on his face. His mouth has been operated on multiple times due to a cleft palate and other problems. But Auggie's biggest problem can be summed up in two words: middle school. He's about to be entered into his first mainstream school as a 5th grader, and the reaction he gets will surprise even him. 
 This parable on looks and America is surprisingly mundane in its approach. Take away the deformity and you would be lulled with all of the typical school scenes and equally humdrum upper-middle class NY domestic scenes. But the angle of Auggie's face helps to throw the book off a fatal flaw just enough. Instead, you actually start to feel for the kid. Cynics need not apply, of course, but if you like feel-good stories, you will find yourself cheering the boy's battle against stereotypes, ignorance, and especially cruelty. 
 The book's point of view shifts from Auggie to his beautiful sister Via (Grade 9), his allies and his enemies. You might think an older sister would be blessed, dodging the "bad genes" as she did and being beautiful on top of it. But Via must live in the shadow of a sibling who needs constant attention and THAT becomes a cross to bear as well. Stress on the parents? Yes, that too. 
 Mostly, though, the book gets into the small-time, mud politics of the school. Dirty tricks. Shifting alliances. Expected cruelties and unexpected acts of kindness. Defeats, victories, hesitations -- all with the reader knowing full well where it's heading. In fact, if you read past page 100 it's because you've signed a virtual contract that you want to cry with joy at the end. Well, if you're the teary sort. The eye-roll sort will have bailed long ago. 
 For middle school readers, this wholesome book is a parable worth listening to. Given its message, I can only hope that the book -- set for release on Valentine's Day -- takes flight and that many fall in love with it. For me, that's the important part. Less important is the fact that I thought it told too much and went on too long. Less important still is the fact that multiple characters used the same expressions, like, "I know, right?" 
 So yeah. Recommend. Teens may feel too old and sophisticated, but gifted elementary and middle school readers are perfect. Wonder what they'll think, in fact.

4.5 stars. I don't easily give out 5's, although normally I do round up. Wonder is a great middle school book about finding friends and confronting bullies. It is also a story about family and love. The main character, Auggie, is a medical wonder because of his facial "disfigurement" which adds an entirely new perspective to the standard middle school blues story. It's more than just about fitting in, it's about overcoming fear and embracing the good things in life. I also learned a lot because the book compelled me to do some basic research into Auggie's case and those of other kids like him. In that way, it promotes open-mindedness, sympathy, and awareness.

Define "normal"! What is normal? 
 While some people are dying to be seen as "normal", others hate the sound of the word "normal" following their names. I don't know a clear definition myself! What I know for sure is, NOthing is normal until you believe it is. 
 Wonder; a book recommended by dearest Dana. 
 August or Auggie Doggie (as his father calls him) is a fifth grader who is not normal. He is not a child with a special need although he has some kind of syndrome that he doesn't even know how to pronounce. Something is wrong with Auggie's face. Don't bother to imagine how bad it is because "whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse". Because of "this", he's been homeschooled by his mother who's never been a real teacher. 
 The story begins when Auggie overhears his parents discussing the possibilities of transforming him to a traditional school. The idea terrifies him at first but he finally decides to give it a try. The rest of the story tells us about his experience and all the challenges and issues he and his family face after this important decision. 
 Characters take turns telling the story from their own prospectives. Palacio does a great job moving us between them. I very much enjoyed that technique. The only annoying thing was when "Justin" takes his turn, all the punctuation marks suddenly disappear. To me, reading that chapter was rather challenging. 
 Issues that might come-up when homeschool students transfer to traditional schools, 
 challenges of being parents or siblings of children with special needs, 
 spreading awareness among children and adults, 
 and what is considered a special need and what is not, are all topics that were brought up in the book. 
 Easy read, 
 deep and inspiring.

I listened to the audio of this one, and I'd recommend it! Breakdown: 
 Plot: August was born with a chromosomal abnormality that affects how his face looks. This book is about him and his family as he starts in a private school after being homeschooled, and follows him throughout the year as he deals with the reactions of the kids and adults in a school situation. 
 Language: This is a middle-grade novel, so obviously not much to worry about with language. There were various uses of God's name in vain, no cuss words. 
 Sexual Content: August's older sister "long" kisses a boy. That's it. 
 Spiritual: There was some spiritual/philosophical stuff in this book that is probably good for parents to be aware of if their kids read it - most notably some talk about Heaven and one of August's friends theory of reincarnation (August says he likes her theory). Worth a discussion for those of us who are Christian parents. Some misapplication of quotes from the Bible (like August's "precept" at the end of the book). 
 Other: Some mean comments from different bullies, including one comment from a kid who said he'd "kill himself" if he looked like August. Later August and this boy are reconciled and laughing about how they'd "kill themselves" if they were so-and-so. I didn't like that. 
 Overall: I really enjoyed this book overall! The story was sweet and full of those bittersweet moments that make you choke up a bit. I liked how it gave the perspectives of different characters besides just August's too. I would just say to know your kid before you hand them this book, in case some of the bullying comments would affect them negatively (especially the comments about suicide, which were cringe-worthy to me as a parent).

I loved this book about a boy with a facial disfigurement. So much of it rings true for people with a physical disability too, in fact, any child who happens to be a little bit different. 
 It is a story of courage, of friendship and most of all of hope.

Happy tears! Happy tears! What a remarkable story, told from multiple perspectives. Though I favored August's perspective, I thought each character had a great take on what was happening in their lives, and on their connection to August. 
 I highly recommend this one.

This book was... good. 
 I mean, obviously, I gave it four stars, and the main problem I had with it is that it didn't really 'click' with me - and the reason it gained 'liferuiner' status for me is because of a part in the Julian chapter. But I did really enjoy reading it. It was a lot of fun, and I liked most of the characters, and the ones I didn't I felt kind of weird about wanting to punch in the face, because they're fifth graders and that's kind of bad. Thankfully, Jack takes care of that. Good job, Jack. 
 This book follows August Pullman, a boy with a severe facial deformity that's going to school for the first time. Of course, there are problems. But there's a lot of happiness, too. It was a pretty happy book, and I enjoyed reading it. 
 The book is told from several different perspectives - there's August, of course, as well as a few of his friends or people that are observing the story and can put their point of view on it. I really did like how the story was told, and while I think that Jack's POV was possibly my favorite (I also liked Justin's, just because of how interestingly it was written, but I didn't actually care about Justin, so that kind of made it not my favorite), I did enjoy all of them. 
 This book was definitely good. And maybe I'll re-read it someday and it will click with me and then I'll decide that younger me was stupid and give it five stars instead of four stars. But for now, four it stays, because it is a good book.
A must read!
Started reading this with my 7 year old but he finished it with his dad and I finally got to pick it up again a couple months later. We all thought it was a really good story.

2017 Reading Challenge 
 A book with a child narrator 
 Wonderful book about fitting in, friendship and love.

I will go so far as to call this book life-changing. I'm no fan of books that try too hard to teach lessons, but this one feels genuine to me--the author truly seems to get how middle-schoolers think and act and feel. This is one of the few children's books I'm going to have to buy, because I want to make sure my kids read it. Everyone should read it. If this doesn't win the Newbery, I'll eat my hat.

I read this story in one sitting at the airport, and I really enjoyed it. I was not expecting the multiple narratives, but I found it useful to see the various character perspectives. The story was heartfelt and sad (I cried multiple times in public), and it was uplifting to read how this young boy with such severe facial deformities, and his kind friends, was able to navigate middle school.

I am often amazed at the ability o young children to be kind and loving with no second thought, but I worry about what happens when this innate ability disappears as they grow older. This book gives me hope, and reminds me that kind children come from kind parents. Every parent could benefit from reading this with their child.

When Mr. Tushman got choked up, I lost it! 
 "You really are a wonder, Auggie. You are a wonder."
Amazing!Love it!

Love, Love, Love, Love this book! An amazingly written story about a boy born with a genetic defect and the struggles he has gone through. After finally being able to go to a real school starting in 5th grade, he has many up and downs to deal with, but he overcomes them and grows, while helping everyone around him grow too! 
 Read This Book!!!

I really enjoyed this book - would i read it again? I'm not sure. 
 It was interesting but its not like one of those books that suck you in and that you just can't stop thinking about or anything like that.
so beautiful ... so full of wisdom ... the family was portrayed as such a good and important part of life ... the lessons were priceless

Review: wow, I literally could not stop reading this book, unputdownable is a complete understatement. I actually started reading this with a group of children at school and then I made sure we all had a copy so we could all finish it over the holidays. The short chapters, the mystery behind what August really looks like, the situation with him and his school had us all completely mesmerised and desperate to carry on reading it. 
 Firstly, I loved the character development in this book. It's not just August who grows and learns over the course of the novel. This book is written from several points of view and all the other characters grow and change and I love that about the story. The point of view who we don't hear from is the one belonging to any adult. There are no teacher chapters or parent chapters, this is told entirely from the children's perspective, which I think is brave but brilliant! I particularly enjoyed seeing august's sister Via change over the course of the novel, the kids I was reading with agreed that intiallly she seems passive aggressive but that we do feel sorry for her having to deal with all she deals with, she really blossoms in this novel and the way she deals with her own problems in truly admirable! 
 I loved the idea that whatever August has is an entirely new thing, it means that no one has the exact condition he has and so there's no risk of offending people with one of the conditions he has because he is completely unique, and indeed the novel teaches that it is completely ok to be unique, this is strong message throughout the whole book. I loved August sense of humour as well, we know that he sees himself as normal and why should no one else, but we see that he copes with the way he looks and the way he is different from everyone else with humour and courage and yet he can completely empathise with others, despite his being so completely unique! 
 There are some very funny bits in this novel, it's not all moral lessons, there is a storyline and humour, action which will leave you breathless, and real life. Anyone starting a new school or a new situation will be able to identify with August and his fears, Via too! This also teaches a powerful lesson about friendship and bullying which is why I decided to read it at school, it is beautifully written too which also comes in handy at school but which adds to the fact that this book is completely addictive. Having just finished this book. I know that this is something I will want to reread again and again!

I cried twice in this book. I have never cried twice in a book before. Ever. Once is my limit. 
 I wish I could be eloquent and write the wonderful review for this book that is in my heart, but I'm emotionally spent. I feel filled up with happiness, and I don't want to use this happiness trying to explain it. I just want to enjoy it for now before I go into another book that might make that happiness dwindle. 
 Excellent, wonderful book. I love Auggie.

Wow! I have a feeling this is a book that will stay with me a long time. I had high expectations, based on friends' recommendations, and they were actually surpassed. Auggie is an amazing character, as are Via, Jack,and Summer. The story moves along quickly as it's told through multiple characters' voices, but every so often a line or two appear that stopped me cold! I'm looking forward to talking about it at our book group--and passing it on to a granddaughter!

This is a book that everyone of every age could enjoy and everyone should read. I went into this expecting to feel sorry for Auggie but I didn't. You can't because he won't allow it. It pulled on my heart strings a little the few times he expressed his desire to be "normal". Being that we get to hear the story from Auggies point of view makes it more personal than just reading a story about a boy with a facial deformity. We actually get to LIVE the deformity. It's amazing!! It also helped to understand more by hearing the points of view from other characters. This story seeps into your heart and you wish you could know a child as full of life as August Pullman. This book actually deserves 10 stars!!!

This book would work well for kids 5th grade through middle school. It has a message and with all we hear and read about bullying this book would make a good schoolwide read. How do we learn to be kind? Read Wonder and maybe you will find out.

Sweet story about a boy who was born with a face that made little kids runaway, screaming in horror. After being home schooled in his early years, he begins middle school- always a challenge for anyone, let alone a boy like him. The author did a great job writing several chapters from the viewpoints of other characters. Interestingly, the she chooses not to tell any part of the story from the antagonist's point of view. Great story to read to older elementary students to help teach about tolerance and kindness.

The story of August( Augie Pullman) who was born with a severe facial deformity, as he begins 5th grade having been previously home schooled. At times this book is heartbreaking and at times triumphant. An awesome book where kindness wins out and about a young boy who is truly a Wonder. A story of how one person can make a difference. 5 stars.
Very painful, but uplifting story! Auggie is an amazing character with an amazing battle yo share.
one of greatest books ever people of all ages should read it
Very good for teaching the lesson of loving all.
Apparently I only cry in books 1. When family pets are involved or 2. Cheesy speeches and awards ceremonies when Grandmas cry. Call me Granny Momo. I enjoyed this little story.

Good book and good lessons/reminders for all of us. I'm going to give it to my daughter to read this summer before starting middle school. I think it'd be a good book for our mother-daughter book club as well. But for the cynic in me, (and I feel like a schmuck for even typing this) I just can't give it 5 stars...a little too sappy and contrived. Would all of Mr. Browne's precepts have been the same if Auggie hadn't been at Beecher? That's only one example. But I'm not entirely the target audience so I can't complain too much. I did appreciate Julian's version, and especially loved his grandmother and her lessons. All in all still a book I liked and would recommend. I just didn't LOVE it.

It took a while for the penny to drop: This book is for young adults, and you're not that young anymore, David (whatever you might choose to think). Anyway, by the end, the peculiar magic of Auggie and pals had done its trick. Yup, that graduation ceremony is a three-tissue affair. A little gem, bursting with heart and goodness.

A very, very warm book. By the moment you finish this book you'll feel warm and cozy. 5 stars because it's well written, all the characters were interesting and the message was delivered, wonderfully. I loved Auggie. 
 Reading this book is like eating a tasty meal and feeling the love that was put in while it cook. This book was written with love, you can't help but feel it, and love it.

Aimed at younger readers, this story uses a series of narrators to describe the 5th grade year of a student with significant cranio-facial deformities. The prose is engaging and the themes of friendship, love, and difference are ultimately uplifting.

so glad I finally got to reading this, had been on my list for a bit. heart warming and inspiring story. i liked the how the author used the characters narrations throughout the book to tell the story. I would recommend this to my friends and family.

This book is incredible. Beautifully written in brief, conversational chapters, the story follows Auggie, a ten-year old born with facial deformities, from his perspective as well as that of his older sister and classmates. Both witty and sob-inducing, this story will not leave you untouched: a resonant testament to just how mean people can be and the true power and grace of kindness. Spinelli-esque.

I was genuinely surprised by how much I didn't like this. I didn't find it moving or touching or anything like that - the 'honesty' of the voice grated horribly on me, and it all felt truly contrived and grim. A lot of people (going, at least, by mentions I've seen online since reading it) seem to feel rather precious about this book, and state they've found it incredibly useful or enlightening or similar, and I sort of don't want to bang out about my dislike because it's basically inconsequential if others out there are getting so much out of it. I just...had a lot of issues and discomfort in the reading. (And also had a considerable issue with the cover, but that really isn't the fault of the author, or indeed the book, this I appreciate.)

What a wonderful book about a little boy and the trials and tribulations he faces because of his physical deformities. I really liked the way the main characters were narrating different sections. It really allowed you to get to know the characters and their points of view. I wish that there had been a section from the mothers point of view though. This is a book that every middle school student should read (as a class though because I think it should be discussed together). The discussions of kindness and empathy are very pertinent for this age group.
Excellent. Everyone should read this. Then hug.
Any book with a lesson in kindness that warms your heart is fine by me.

I really don't get what the hype was with this book. It did not seem at all realistic to me. Everybody was so *perfect*, perfect parents who somehow never argue, a sister who is so incredibly understanding and never really thinks of herself, friends who were a little mean at first but then at the end everyone is just one big happy family. Teachers who genuinely care and are not over-worked at all and have no trouble adjusting to a new student with physical deformities. It's just a super nice world. I felt like the book lacked depth. The kid gets bullied (and not nearly as bullied as he likely would be in real life) and at the end miraculously his being bullied teaches everyone about their common humanity and being kind to each other. What an all-around easy life these people must lead that a fifth-grader getting bullied somehow changes the hearts and lives of an entire school. If only.
Engaging and heartfelt. The short chapters make it very episodic, but the overall structure is pleasing.
Really good.

This book is about a boy named Auggie, who was born with a genetic birth defect that has made his face misshapen, even after many surgeries. He is going into fifth grade, and up until this point he has been home-schooled. This is the story of his fifth grade year. 
 It's a moving story, and I think it does a good job of showing what it might be like to live with some sort of severe cosmetic issue, especially when you are young. It is definitely trying to teach a message about kindness and empathy, but this is a message that children do need. 
 My main issue with this book was that at the very end the author became a bit heavy-handed with the lesson. The ending is just a little too pat and a little too happy. But, given the intended audience, I am okay with that. 
 A solid 4.5 stars. Recommended for everyone to read at least once.
Loved this book! On-target for the middle school audience, touching for all of us.
This book came highly recommended, from a variety of sources and they weren't wrong. Every child, parent, and family should read this book!

As the synopsis suggests, Wonder is a novel about kindness, empathy, and compassion. And Bullying. But mostly, Wonder is a book about courage. The courage August needs to put a smile on his disfigured face everyday. The courage his friends show in loving and protecting August despite their own ambitions. 
 Wonder is a middle grade novel, written specifically with middle school children in mind, but the lessons learned are valuable for all ages. Written from the alternating points of view of six adolescent children, Palacio takes her readers through August's first year of real school. Until the fifth grade, because of the number of surgeries necessary to repair his cleft palette and facial disfigurements, August had been homeschooled by his mother. These alternating points of view add depth and insight into the plot. While none of the secondary points of view are well developed, these voices are effective in validating Auggie's character. 
 At the beginning of every month, Auggie's English teacher writes a precept on the blackboard, a rule to live by, for the children to contemplate before writing their response. The precepts I appreciated the most were the ones the students sent in to their teacher during the following summer. 
 If your mother is anything like mine, she harped on you constantly about the proper use of pronouns. Never put yourself first! I beat on my children about their poor grammar all the time, to no avail. My hope is, one day they will finally hear it like I hear it when someone uses a pronoun incorrectly. It grates my nerves like someone running their fingernails down a chalkboard. 
 My one beef with this novel is the improper use of pronouns. To make matters worse, the majority of the errors were made when the pronoun was the subject of the sentence. Fourteen instances, in fact, but who's counting. 
 I understand Palacio was hoping to authenticate the voices of her characters by adopting the language they speak. But as writers, we have a responsibility to set an example. To do otherwise is putting our stamp of approval on incorrect grammar.

Such a beautiful book about acceptance, love, kindness, and goodness. This book is a MUST read for children, but also educators and future educators- I wish that my teachers for exceptional education had us all read this. I regret not reading this book sooner.

I thought this was a gem of a book. The author captures the voice of tweeners pretty well. I liked the multiple perspectives as well as the subtle (ans not so subtle) kinds of bullying that go on. I one piece that was disappointing, was the cute and tidy ending. I think that was the one part that was difficult to believe.

This book was chosen for me by Rebekah for the A Million More Pages POFM - August 2017. 
 5 stars 
 RIP Daisy. Enjoyed reading everyone's stories. Hope Julian will be able to tell August he is sorry.

This is one of the best books I have ever read. I am writing this review many days after I read the book. This books keeps coming back to me. The messages, the thoughtfulness, the emotions, the story - highly memorable. 
 Everybody should read this book.

I really struggled between 3 and 4 stars, so I think it would be a solid 3.5. 
 I finished the novel within one sitting with a smile and desire to give the whole world a hug. It's a sweet story, but it could have definitely been more complex and full.
Absolutely amazing. My only regret is that no one around me reads YA novels so I can't spread this gem.

This is a intriguing book with a powerful message. It really makes me think of what it must be like to go through life with a severe deformity. As a parent myself I could really sympathisize with Auggie's parents. I couldn't help wishing a short section had been devoted to their viewpoint since the story is told in the viewpoint of several different characters. I think this would be a wondeful book for all kids to read as it might give them pause the next time they have the inclination to poke fun at, or even just stare at, someone with a disability.

Review can also be found on my blog: http://melissa-reads-books.blogspot.b... 
 "The universe was not kind to Auggie Pullman." 
 And still he was so brave! I really liked this book. While I was reading this I just couldn't imagine a good ending. But oh boy, I was wrong. It was so beautiful and I ended up crying the last few chapters! And I really didn't expected the last sentence: It was perfect 
 I really recommend this book! It's a perfect read in between a series or whatever. Plus the chapters are short, which is so good (I could say 'one more chapter' without ending up reading an hour to finish it like in other books :D). All the characters are so well described and real. I really loved the change in POV's. 
 & This book will seriously make you think more about judging, appearances, friendship and family. 
 "Greatness lies not in being strong, but in the right of using strength. He is the greatest whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own."

Most of us have felt a bit out of place, and some more than others. The beauty of this book is the author creates a space in which she can discuss how society can treat disability and difference. 
 It would be a difficult topic to cover by a lesser author...and I would argue this author just pulls it off. There is humor, Augie is a well-drawn character and the subtlety makes this community feel alive. 
 There are some choices the author made which probably made her task a bit easier, all of which can fall under the category of conflict avoidance. We get various perspectives, but not the one I really wanted...this was a choice not to have too much sympathy for a bully, which I get...but if writing is a project of explaining social variables (and I think it very much it is), ignoring the bully is dodging the project the author set out to do. This may be simply due to the audience; hence the very (almost too) happy ending. It gives us little to chew on or mull over. I hope another has or will take up this task and give us the words and thoughts to alter our perceptions. This is a great effort. 
 B-

"Wonder" (Knopf 2012) by R.J. Palacio is the story of August who has a radically deformed face--no ears, his eyes at cheek level, a cleft palate which has required numerous surgeries. He's smart and funny, but you can almost imagine the torture he endures from children and adults both, especially when he starts school for the first time in the fifth grade. 
 Early in the book August resists having to go to school. He says, "I miss being a baby, not knowing stuff." Innocence is blissful--particularly for August. 
 August tells his story, but so do others, deepening and widening the reader's understanding of August's life and the many lives he affects. Some voices are of fellow fifth graders. 
 Summer befriends August. She doesn't think he looks so scary. 
 Jack, on the request of the principal, befriends August. Jack forgets about August's odd appearance and they seem to be friends. But his painful betrayal feels true to life. 
 August's older sister, Via, 14, just starting high school, adores August. But how complicated it is to always have to make sacrifices for him. His problems are always bigger than hers and he always gets more attention from their parents. She understands this, of course, but sometimes she needs attention, too. 
 Via's ex-friend, Miranda, cherished August when they were younger, but now she's moved on to have friends other than Via, which is hard for both Via and August. 
 Via's new boyfriend sheds light on August's loving family and makes the reader see that, yes, things are rough for August, but people adore him in a way most people aren't adored. He says, "The universe takes care of all its birds." It's hard not to love these characters. 
 Both family and school scenes feel authentic. There's no cuteness. The author understands feelings, their subtleties, and when our behaviors surprise us, especially in adolescence. We don't always know why we act as we do, but we can feel the consequent emotion immediately--for instance, shame. 
 Mr. Browne, the English teacher, asks his students to observe monthly precepts. September's precept: Given the choice between being right or kind, choose kind. This story, without being pedantic, is the perfect anti-bullying book. Every class should read it. 
 The book shows people behaving both badly and wonderfully. I guess that's why the name is so apt. "Wonder." I loved this book. 
 Patricia Hruby Powell is a nationally touring speaker, dancer, storyteller, occasional librarian, and children's book author. Her book "Josephine: The Dazzling Life of Josephine Baker" will be released by Chronicle Books in October 2013.

Everyone is giving this 5 star reviews on here, and while I think it's amazing and wonderful and very very well-written, I have to bump it down to 4 or 4.5 based on the ending. It's a story about how much kids suck, and at the same time, how awesome kids can be. Written from the perspective of a 5th grader, it really captures the feelings and typical interactions that happen at that time. While it is the story of someone going through and succeeding in an amazingly difficult situation, the ending seemed almost too happy-ending. I really felt August's joy and self-confidence as it increased and he learned to navigate in a new world, but it really just felt like a little too much. 
 That sad, I highly recommend this story for all ages. The realness of the characters, the honest writing style, and yes, the happy ending make it a touching and worthwhile read.

I think the subtlety and not-so-subtlety of how hard middle school can be and the importance of sympathy and empathy are really well done. However, I wanted something more or different - some more real turmoil, something grittier, some bigger moment I think. There are so many uplifting and happy moments that it seems almost inauthentic. What this book I think really showed me is that I don't really like books with happy endings or well-wrapped resolutions.

I liked the range of views on Auggie's situation (Auggie, Jack, Via, Justin, and Summer) and the mash-up of early middle school and high school perspectives. However, I sometimes felt a twinge of doubt when hearing some of the voices. August seemed really young for a ten year old and the parents' dialogue too often sounded like an after school special. That is minor, though, relative to the amazing conversations this book will inspire.

The story is also told from his sister's perspective. She loves him but is embarrassed of him as she enters high school. This is a lovely coming of age book.

An amazing first novel by R.J. Palacio. Yet, not a book I would have read had it not been a book club selection. It is the story of August Pullman a 10 year old boy born with a severe genetic disfigurement of his face. His medical case is so much more complicated than that simple statement and has been the center of his family's life. This is not just August's story, but also the story of his family, friends and even "enemies." It is a beautiful reminder that "Courage. Kindness. Friendship. Character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness." Highly recommended.

I really loved this book. I was seriously tempted to turn back to page one and read it again. It is just so dang heartwarming. I well up a little just thinking about it. The characters are so real. They're not perfect, but they're good people. I loved the overall message on the importance of kindness. (Although, just so you know, the book did not feel preachy.) 
 A wonderful story that I know I will want to read again and again.

what a wonderful book.

This review contains spoilers. I read this book because I saw it was highly rated and I also wanted to see if it was something my kids should read. I really liked it and I do want my kids to read when they get closer to middle school age. I think it carries great lessons on kindness and encourages tolerance and acceptance and it really is a great book for the intended audience. As an adult reader, I did feel that it felt a little too wrapped up in niceness. I wonder if a boy so different would find friends so soon. Like other reviews I've read, I agree that the most convincing and compelling voice was that of Via. One of my favorite things she said was how the family has spent Austin's childhood convincing him that he is just a normal kid, when the truth was, he was not. Via's emotions were sometimes raw but so honest and real, and this really added to the story. My favorite part was (spoiler alert) during the field trip when his classmates took up for him to protect him from the bullies, and how this became a turning point for his experience at school. As for the award ceremony, did anyone else think it should have been Summer and Jack that should have gotten the final award? All in all a great fast read that I would definitely recommend.

"I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives," says August Pullman, the main character in Wonder, and RJ Palacio certainly deserves hers for this bittersweet but ultimately uplifting novel about a severely disfigured boy. Wonder appears to be aimed at kids of perhaps ten upwards, but it's an equally engaging and moving read for an adult and I thoroughly enjoyed it. 
 We all know that starting a new school at all is hard enough as it is, but things are doubly difficult for Auggie, whose facial disfigurement is so significant that he is fully accustomed to people visibly recoiling when they meet him for the first time, even if they think they're hiding their reaction. 
 As we follow him through his first year, Auggie is self-deprecating, quietly determined and, like most children of his age, an amusing and sometimes poignant mix of naive and astute. It's impossible not to root for him. However, a major strength of wonder is the introduction of perspectives other than Auggie's in the narrative. Wonder is among other things a book about how we perceive others, so it's only fitting that we hear not just from Auggie himself but from those around him. The sections narrated by Auggie's teenage sister Olivia, who is fiercely protective of her younger brother and yet at the same time acutely aware that his unique needs mean she will always play second fiddle, are particularly enlightening, but every voice struck me as vivid and authentic. 
 The toughest challenges Auggie has to overcome are related to his appearance, of course - but anyone who can remember being eleven will be familiar with typical anxieties like their first overnight school trip, mysteriously shifting social cliques and peer pressure to grow up too soon, and there is much in Wonder that any reader can identify with. 
 If I have a criticism of Wonder it's that there are times when Auggie's parents seem a little too understanding, a little too indulgent, even, to be true, and I would have liked to see a little more complexity in their characters. It's also fair to say that Wonder isn't particularly plot-driven. But it's a lovely, oddly life-affirming read that reminds us of some simple but vital truths, good and bad, about human nature, and although there a couple of heartbreaking chapters, I'd defy anyone not to finish this book smiling.
This book made me laugh and cry and REALLY evaluate my past, present and future actions. All I can hope is that I do everything I can to be kind- that is ultimately what matters in life.
This is the rare book that makes you want to listen to the words to 70s Beatles' songs and try to be a kinder person.

Such a heartwarming and real book. My daughter is the one that recommended it to me as she read it for school. So glad she did! I think I'll now recommend it to our book club, as it has a great message for all ages.

This book is a beautifully and simply written story of a boy and a family facing an unfair fate with dignity and persistent decency. It's just so good. The book is a meditation on kindness and simple goodness. So refreshingly real and good.

Beautiful

Written as an uplifting, and inspirational tale for children: Auggie's face is horrendously disfigured from birth, and his mother decides it is finally time for him to stop home schooling and to face other children as a 5th grader. The novel is written mainly from Auggie's persepective though half way through the novel we are treated to a rerun of events through the eyes of different characters, his sister Via, her boyfriend Julian, Auggies' school friend Summer, and so on. This is great if you don't really engage with Auggie though I must say I got a little tired of this conceit in the end. 
 Suitable for any children from age 8 onwards depending on their maturity and reading levels but probably aimed at 10-12 year olds. The opening chapters' fart jokes mercifully disappear very quickly and much of novel is fairly serious though the children are depicted as having fun; it's not all doom and gloom all the time. 
 I suppose that was my problem with it. It was a bit too American- cheerful and worthy. I kept comparing it with another of this year's Carnegie books: The Weight of Water, which, while optimistic in the end, went through a lot of pain in the mid section. Part of that is because it is aimed more at the 12-14 market, but I can't help thinking that part of it reflects a British outlook rather than an American one! 
 So if you are generally of a cheerful disposition and like uplifting tales of personal struggles and bravery, then settle down with a box of tissues for the final 30 pages and enjoy! 
 Moved it down to a 2*. As a novel for this genre and age group it is a 3* but for. But for me personally a 2*. OK but I would hope I never have to read it again.

Wow! This was recommended to me by a fifth grade student. I am so glad I read it. Make sure you have the tissues ready! The different issues brought up, the different points of view...I will certainly be recommending this book.

Every so often a book comes along that hits a deeper chord, that makes you think about the individual human experience. Auggie was born completely disfigured, to the point where the nurses didn't even want his mother to hold him. His whole life he's been in and out of surgeries and homeschooled...until his fifth grade year. Now his parents want him to go to school for the first time...and he goes. Told from different first person accounts (his, his sister's, his sister's boyfriend, and several of his friends), the story makes readers see that everyone has their own story, and their own problems. Funny, sad, and full of Star Wars references that warm the heart, Wonder is a pleasure to read. Give to kids who like realistic fiction or who want to read about how someone else might live. Look for it on Newbery short-lists.

Definitely very sweet and heartwarming, but that is also my critique...a little too sweet and heartwarming. I enjoyed the various points of view which added a lot of depth to the story. I also had the benefit of reading the e-book which included the Julian chapter. I highly recommend that chapter as well, although (spoilers) he learns the valuable lessons of kindness and empathy as well. I am left with questions about Auggie's future since real life does not end up tied up with a pretty ribbon. I certainly valued the themes and lessons in the story, but i found trouble connecting with Auggie's perfect family or the incredibly perfect school response. This is a great story to use as a middle school discussion of human relationships and a well written mentor text about using multiple points of view to tell a story, but I do not recommend it as a true "antibullying" message.
Beautiful story! Couldn't keep it down once I started! Can't wait for the movie, hope it does justice to this amazing book!

I listened to this book. The reader was great and I enjoyed the whole story line. It made me think about how I treat anyone that is obviously different. It has prepared me more to treat everyone with kindness and joy

EVERY MIDDLE SCHOOL CHILD SHOULD READ THIS for a lot of reasons, I'm studying psychology and I think psycHologically, this is an important book. Those young teen years are so tough, and this book realy makes kids think about kids that are "different". I like how the author uses everyones point of views because kids that age should be learning to look at things through other peoples eyes, and so that is really great how she did that, really great for that age group. It won't be a book you make them suffer through, its really good and easy to read. It has a good ending and I think kids will like it. 
 Lastly, it talks about kindness and you just love Auggie, the kid that goes to school for the first time in middle school with a severe face deformation and it is so touching. 
 Anyways, Moms and Dads, have your middle schoolers read this, it is on my required list for when my kids turn that age. I think this is really an important book for them socially. Read it yourself, I did in 3 days and that rarely happens. I really liked it.
Fantastic book about a boy with a facial deformity going to school for the first time. The author did a great job with the voices of the kids.

Young adult reads have never been my cup of tea, but they can be my kind of Thai tea (which I like but doesn't drink often). And probably Wonder is the sweetest Thai tea I've ever tasted. 
 Literally couldn't put this book down once I started reading it. August Pullman, the protagnist, hooked me up since the introdution. Born with facial deformities, none can imagine what kind of life Auggie must go through. Being given 'that' look; getting mocked; called names; and worse, bullied. Lucky he still has supportive family and friend. 
 But I can't thonk how real life Auggies live their life. I once knew a girl whose face was slightly deformed -uneven eyes and sideloped nose. I hid her whole Facebook post because she regularly posted selfies, which made me felt uncomfortable. But let's just get back to the book rather than listening to my misanthropic banter. 
 This book has many narrators: Auggie himself, his friends Jack, Summer and Miranda, his sister Via, her boyfriend Justin. Palacio succeed in giving different perspectives through these narrators. But honestly, though, she can skip Justin's part because it's not that necessary. Maybe she wanted to give more perspective about Via's character, but STILL THO' 
 I said that this book tasted like Thai tea which is too sweet for my taste but I still enjoyed it somehow. Kinda unrealistic but hey, this is a story, fiction. There's no way a real life Auggie could get a medal by just being himself: smart ass kid who basically did nothing while his friends protecting and encouraging him. If anybody deserves the medal, it was Jack Will. Not Auggie. 
 Despite the heart-warming story, I still feel a little annoyed with some details like how doting Auggie's parents are towards him even though they said their son need no special treatment and stuff. This book still hold tight to the paradigm of how delicate and 'special' handicapped people are. Stop giving them special treatment and just interact with them the way you are with everyone else. 
 But good point is, don't judge a book by its cover (which I refuse to do and I consider as an excuse ugly people spout when they just lack everything). Auggie might look different but he still has a kind heart, smart brain, and good sense of joke if you just give him a chance.
Read this one out loud with Zane. There was lots to talk about with him

Because I was able to put this book on so many of my social justice shelves, it gets a 5. It bumps down to a 4.8 when I remember that the ending wraps things up just a little too nicely. Kind of like the saccharine tone of the Boxcar Children or Anne of Green Gables, Wonder provides a neatly wrapped little package of an ending, satisfying and shiny. As superficial as that sounds, the rest of the book was phenomenal. 
 I can see why it perhaps didn't quite get onto the Newbery list, but then again, I don't know that I would put The One and Only Ivan above it. Perhaps it's one of those under-appreciated books that then begins to shine as soon as kids start to read it. 
 Told from multiple perspectives, but always focused on this one boy, Wonder tells a coming of age story via August's first year of middle school. The year we experience is his first foray into formal schooling: he was homeschooled for most of his life because of his multiple medical conditions. His time in the 5th grade is full of ups and downs as he grows into himself. His face differs from other children's to an extent that makes people stare and comment, sometimes even feel fear. Learning to deal with peers in a mature manner is only one of the obstacles he has to work with in his new life. The social fabric of middle school is complicated, and he finds that his family and friends are his biggest supports when he needs them most.

Such a beautiful story, with an even more beautiful message to go with it. I admit I cried several times in this book. Whenever I feel sad about my problems in my life, I'm going to think of this book and remember how lucky I am to be me. I had several favorite quotes in this book, but my favorite was this: 
 August's mom, "There are always going to be jerks in the world, Auggie. But I really believe and Daddy really believes, that there are more good people on this earth than bad people, and the good people watch out for each other and take care of each other." 
 Content: Uses God's name as profanity probably about 10 times.

I assigned this book to my 6th grade students as their winter reading. However, I did this without actually reading the book first. This was a HUGE move on my part (and not the smartest), but all the reviews were excellent and the last book they read was a total flop, so I figured I couldn't wrong. And, I didn't. 
 I read this book in one day--I couldn't put it down. I also have had several students email me, saying that they have already finished it, too (and they are not "readers"). 
 This book is golden. It deals with many issues that young children are faced with. Some of my favorite topics that I look forward to discussing with my students are bullying, self-acceptance, peer influence, and friendship. Obviously, if you've heard anything about this book, you know that bullying presents itself many times and in many ways. I like that RJ presented bullying on different levels, because sometimes students don't see the "smaller" acts as being bullying. Nor do students see the snowball affect their actions may have. So quickly, someone can go from name calling to physically hurting someone. This is something that needs to be brought to students' attention. 
 This book is written from many viewpoints. Of course, Auggie's POV is seen the most throughout the novel, but his sister, Via, had my favorite "part." I liked the real and mature emotions that Via brought to the book. Auggie's emotions were real, no doubt, but since he is only 10 years old, there were a lot of serious things that went above his head. Via, being in high school, saw and understood more things that Auggie. She also, tactfully, talked about the negative side of having Auggie as a brother. By seeing Via feel overlooked and not always happy with her family's situation was so authentic AND was written beautifully. 
 I could go on and on about this book, but, since I should be grading semester finals, read it yourself over Winter vacation. It's a quick read that will stick with you long after you finish.

Book # 24 Read in 2013 
 Wonder by R.J. Palacio (YA) 
 August (Auggie) was born with a facial deformity. Up until now (the 5th grade) he has been home schooled. He decides to try 5th grade in a regular school. He expects to be treated oddly by some but while that is true, Auggie is also pleasantly surprised by others. Auggie strives to come into his own during this first year of school. 
 I loved this book. Auggie was a wonderful character. He was brave, funny and genuine. There was a wonderful cast of characters in this book--Auggie's parents and sister, Jack Will, Summer and the middle school principal. I recommend this book. 
 http://melissasbookpicks.blogspot.com

I loved this book. It was about a boy who was born with severe deformities and his transition to going to real school with other 5th graders. It is a book about empathy and compassion and looking past outside appearance. It shows realistic reactions from people who want to do the right thing and aren't always sure how. It is about making mistakes and atoning for them. It is about learning to forgive and learning to be yourself. 
 I think all kids should read this book. Most adults, too.
I thought this book was beautiful and inspiring. Once I started I couldn't stop. August is an amazing character in a brilliant book. Only flaw is the chapters are slightly short.

https://ayearofbooksblog.com/2016/12/... 
 At the recommendation of my niece, Wonder has been on my TBR list for a while. She enjoyed it this past summer and with this glowing recommendation, my son and I picked it out earlier this month. He no longer likes to be read to, choosing to read independently, so the initial plan was to keep up with each other. Today when started I was pondering what book that I might be able to finish by midnight, he suggested that I go ahead and finish reading Wonder. 
 Wonder is a great book for the grade 4-6 crowd and tells the story of August (Auggie), a boy born with a severe facial abnormality. He had so many surgeries that he had been homeschooled up to that point. His parents felt that it was time to start attending a regular school with his peers. Although he was used to stares, quiet comments and shock expressed by others related to his appearance, starting grade 5 was not easy for Auggie. Kids can be mean! Being different is not easy! 
 In the end, Auggie makes friends. He wins them over with his great personality and they learn to accept the differences which make him Auggie. His family is there supporting him all the way! 
 This is a great book that would be fantastic to read to a grade 4 or 5 class. It would prompt frank discussion about others who may have challenges and the fact that EVERYONE is struggling for acceptance and kind words and actions can make ALL the difference! I liked how the book was broken down into chapters which were narrated by different characters, sharing their individual perspectives. 
 I enjoyed Wonder and am looking forward to chatting about it with my niece and son.

** spoiler alert ** 
 A coming of age tale that works through the regular and ups and downs of adolescence with the bittersweet difference of, well, being really, unavoidably different. 
 While the story of Auggie, told from multiple points of view, runs the gamut of emotions and ends on a true feel-good note, its one and only downfall is the clear-cut, all's well that ends well resolution and the amount of time spent getting there and within the actual "moment" of conclusion. Had things been left a little less perfect, or perhaps if Palacio had left a lingering question about Auggie's future -both within the walls of his middle school and beyond- with the feel-good resolution to the story at hand, I could have given five stars. 
 Regardless of my qualms with the ending, this book is fabulous and I recommend it to all.
"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world"

From the book, "Ten-year-old Auggie Pullman, who was born with extreme facial abnormalities and was not expected to survive, goes from being home-schooled to entering fifth grade at a private middle school in Manhattan, which entails enduring the taunting and fear of his classmates as he struggles to be seen as just another student."

Auggie's story is a story that makes your heart hurt and yet burst with good feelings. It's a tale about a young boy called August, who was born with an extremely rare genetic mutation that has caused his face to look a little bit different. He's been homeschooled all his life until his parents decided to let him enter middleschool. Auggie has to deal with many stares and awkward glances, but he's okay with it, and understand why people react this way. However, Auggie stars to have some trouble at school, some of the kid's aren't so nice and as a result he starts to regret his decision. 
 I absolutely adored this book, I managed to finish it in one night because once I really got into the story, I couldn't get out again. The writing is entirely captivating, and yet reminiscence of a young boy, and feels like an accurate reflection on how a boy this age would behave and react to situations. It's told though multiple perspectives, a technique that worked surprisingly well and allowed a lot of insight into the motives and reasons behind why particular characters behaved certain ways. It showed how easy it is to be mislead about a person's character. And how we shouldn't make rash judgements about people based merely on what we see. There's a lot going on behind closed doors, you could say. 
 August's sister Via is an incredibly strong and selfless character, accepting that auggie would always come first and yet never holding it against him. She is very admirable. 
 The tone suited the theme perfectly, and I thought Auggie was a brilliant protoganist. He has a knack for making everyone laugh and I just want to hug him. 
 I highly recommend this book!
Loved this book!
Well-told story, makes bullying seem real without being too preachy.
Tears and laughter! Awesome read!
One of the best books I've read in a long time. It made me cry, it made laugh and it made me think, a lot. A book that everyone should read.

This book was truly great. I loved it. The only thing that bothered me about it is that I wished it were about sixth graders. The characters seemed far older than the fifth graders I work with on a daily basis. To me, it is more how they are at the end of the year. Everything about the characters screamed sixth grade to me. 
 I was considering using this as a read aloud, and I think it could be really powerful. I am just not sure it is right for the very young group of fifth graders I have this year!
Simple and tender with valuable lessons for audiences of all ages, it's no wonder that Wonder has become so ubiquitous among schools around the world, making it modern classic.

I read this as a read aloud to my 12 year old daughter. We laughed, cried, and cheered Auggie on the entire book. This is a great story about kindness and to be mindful of how we treat others.

August (or Auggie) is a fifth grade boy who was born with a facial deformity. Because of this, he has been homeschooled his whole life due to the multiple surgeries he has had. At the start of the book, Auggie is about to go to public school for the first time. Through the book, we encounter his parents' fear of how he may be treated, the reactions of classmates, reactions of adults, and the bullying that occurs toward Auggie. 
 This story is a remarkable tale and written in a special way that allows the reader to see through the eyes of not just Auggie but, also, his friends and sister. It is a tale of courage, love and going beyond differences. Auggie and his classmates go on a journey together, and it is a beautiful story. 
 I loved how real the story was and how the simple reactions and dialogue the characters had were realistic and the actions felt as if this were something that really occurred and not just a work of fiction. You feel for Auggie when the bullying occurs, and you feel the courage of his friends and Auggie. It is a book that I plan to read again and again. I plan to share it with my class because it shows how courage can come in many forms.
An excellent YA read. The characters really felt like 10 year-olds and my heart broke and sang for every one of them.

Everyone needs to read this book! Normally books like this are depressing, but this was so uplifting!I couldn't put it down and I loved the story, the characters are true and heartwarming. Choose kind. Loved it.

3.5 Stars 
 Auggie was born with severe facial deformities, and even with many surgeries his appearance still causes stares and uncomfortable interactions. 
 Auggie has been home schooled, but as the summer before 5th grade approaches, Auggie's parents want to put him in school. Auggie's parents and the school administration work to make school a positive experience for him. 
 Life is not perfect, private school is a big challenge for Auggie and some of his classmates. 
 There are good lessons to learn for readers, especially 5th-8th graders.
Fantastically written book. Plenty of points of view, honest thoughts, and true reactions. This book teaches us that even though we might look different, we are still human. Kindness goes a long way.
This is a wonderful book. (Pun intended.). I thoroughly enjoyed it and would recommend it to the young and old. Great story. Makes you ponder life a bit and that's a good thing.
