Great story. I can't wait to see the movie.
Absolutely adored this book. It's a little mushy and a you can tell what's going to happen at times, but this book has a great message.

There are so many lessons to be learned from this book and even though it is YA, you can always be reminded at an age. August is a normal kid who happens to have drawn the short straw when it comes to genetics. With serious facial deformities he goes up against challenges that no child should. This book is well written, moving, and a must read for all ages.

I really wanted to adore this book. I wanted it to get inside me, tug at my heartstrings and make me feel "all the things." But it just didn't deliver. It all just felt a bit...meh. 
 Don't get me wrong. I enjoyed the novel, I just wasn't blown away by it. 
 I liked August a lot. I wanted to hug him the entire way through the novel. I feel that August's character was the strongest element of this novel. 
 However, the novel, for me, was let down by the use of multiple narratives. The different perspectives added very little to the overall plot and having finished the novel, I find that I've already forgotten what the other narratives actually revolved around. None of the voices really stood apart from each other. Justin's narrative seemed particularly unnecessary and the lack of punctuation was something that grated on me quite a lot (but that might simply be a personal gripe.) I feel that the story could have easily just been told from August's perspective and would've worked just as well. 
 The story as a whole, whilst a nice read, was also a little too cutesy for me. The ending simply didn't have that much of an impact on me. The book had some nice sentiments but I didn't feel particularly affected by it upon finishing. I'd recommend this novel if you're looking for something light and heartwarming but if you're looking for a novel to really cut deep or to give you something to think about, then this isn't the book for you.
I've moved from reading dystopian young adult books to ones that punch you in the gut and squeeze your heart - whatever that genre is called.

A heartwarming story about a boy who is bullied his whole life because of his deformed face. He attends school for the first time in fifth grade and makes a few friends. The school year changes his life and the lives of his classmates. This book should be read in all middle schools.

this is probably going to be the 'feel good' book of the year. auggie's journey from a sheltered, unsocialized, homeschooler to the hero of the school is bound to make you cry. seriously, i dare you to read this and not:) alternate chapters from different povs allow you to feel what it really is like to have a brother/friend/etc. who is the butt of everyone's joke and the source of actual horror to strangers. a great class room read.
I loved this book. Simple & beautiful.
Wow...this book would be a great read for all ages. I loved it from the first page to the last!
Sweet story about the harsh realities of Middle School for ALL kids.

With the help and encouragement of parents, family, school faculty and friends, an incredible transformation is met with humor and courage. While this story is a unique example, there are challenges for many others around us who see themselves as less than perfect. Lessons can be learned from Auggie's story. When we see past the outward facade of an individual, they really can be quite WONDER..ful.
Reviewed this for LMC - loved it!
So, so, so good. Totally lived up to the hype. Standing ovation!

I read Wonder in two sittings (it could've been one) and I've hesitated in writing this review because I know that I just won't be able to do this book justice. This is easily the best book I've read this year and one that will linger with me for a long time. 
 Wonder comfortably fits in the YA category - the underlying premise is deceptively simple and the chapters are 2-3 pages long, but the characters are incredibly rich and poignant (I admit that they sometimes seem to fit a mold too cleanly, but I'm willing to give on that angle - I don't always mind having clear good guys and obvious bad guys). I love being immersed in a book, but this was the type of book that I had to physically put down a few times in order to compose myself. Even in the parts of the book where I felt the pain and heartbreak of the characters, i always found myself uplifted by the human spirit.
A nice story, but perhaps a bit too cheesy in the last 25 pages.
Well written in the voice of a 10 year old with severe facial deformity. He goes to school for the first time and experiences good and bad behavior of his classmates.

this is a must read for the middle grades

There is no doubt about it, this book is a tear jerker. I have to say that I really am struggling with rating it. My initial reaction is that it was a four star book - I really liked it. Then, when I come to write down what I liked and what I struggled with, I realise that there was a lot that I struggled with in this book, but there was a lot I liked too. So, I am going to be kind and stick with my initial four stars, and I'll explain why it could have been three stars. 
 August is 10 years old. He has a terrible facial abnormality, which has meant serial surgical procedures for most of his short life. Because of this, he has been homeschooled up until now. August lives with his Mom, his Dad, his sister Via and his family dog, Daisy. At the beginning of the book Auggie finds out that his Mom and Dad have been going through the process of enrolling him at a school, because Auggie needs to learn more than his Mom can teach him, and she's not just talking about fractions: 
 '"We can't keep protecting him," Mom whispered to Dad, who was driving. "We can't just pretend that he's going to wake up tomorrow and this isn't going to be his reality, because it is, Nate, and we have to help him learn to deal with it. We can't just keep avoiding situations that..." 
 "So sending him off to middle school, like a lamb to the slaughter..." Dad answered angrily, but he didn't even finish his sentence because he saw me in the mirror looking up.' 
 EVERY parent who reads that is going to be thinking about their own 'letting go' challenges. All of us have had those moments where we are sending our children into the unpredictable and not necessarily kind world. We know the instinct to protect, for just a little while longer, even as we know that we should let go. How much harder is that choice in this case? 
 Readers in their early teens will know how hard it is to start a new school, wanting to get things just right, wanting to make the right impression. How many books have been written about just that?! 
 Doesn't it make us all feel a little bit ashamed of the days we haven't wanted to go out in public because it's a fat day/a big zit day/a bad hair day/an I said a stupid thing yesterday day...We all know that moment when we have to brace ourselves, be a bit more courageous than we want to be, and get on with it. Most of us are dealing with something much less significant than Auggie, and yet we recognise an element of it. 
 That's where this book has it over us. Because, 'whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse.' We are, like Via, on the moral back foot. Via is four years older than Auggie, and she can only remember glimpses of time without him being around. Her story is equally as compelling as Auggie's. Via tells the story of what it is like to be Auggie's sister. It is hard for her to admit that she has needs, when - always - Auggie's needs are greater. But moments of self-pity, and let me say that self-pity is normal for a teenager, when she sees Mom standing outside Auggie's door late at night just looking in and wonders if Mom has ever done that at her door, paint a realistic picture of feeling a little bit less loved than her brother, of getting less time and attention. However, when she gets to go to a new school, where the kids don't know about her little brother, she revels in her anonymity. She becomes Olivia, and makes some new friends, including a boyfriend. None of this is without some fairly normal teenage challenges like learning to cope with not being in the popular group, and how friendships change. All of which have been the MAIN storyline of many a book, but are peripheral in this one. As Via says, 'August is the Sun. Me and Mom and Dad are planets orbiting the Sun. The rest of our family and friends are asteroids and comets floating around the planets orbiting the Sun...But this year there seems to be a shift in the cosmos. The galaxy is changing. Planets are falling out of alignment.' Hmmmm...a useful, but well-worn, metaphor. 
 The story of Auggie's settling in to school has its highs and lows, as might be expected. Some fairly predictable plot devices are used, like the quirky girl who could be in the popular group, but chooses to sit at Auggie's lunch table, the boy who struggles between peer pressure and conscience, and the boy who fakes nice in front of the adults. I felt that the age of these kids was really indeterminate...they wandered from sounding between 8 - 10years (for example, Auggie often calls Mom and Dad Mommy and Daddy) and 12 - 14years. 
 I'm not sure, either, about some of Mr Browne's 'precepts'. They felt contrived, and I'm not sure they entirely worked as a plot device. Subtlety would have been better than smacking us in the face with the morals of the story. And I didn't even know how many of them I really agreed with, or felt like they were worth a month's scrutiny. For example, 'When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind.' Ummm...since when could you be unkind and be right??? So then, are we supposed to be 'kind' (read patronising) to Auggie. Since when is that kind? Doesn't he deserve true kindness, which would always be right. For that matter, don't we all? I'm still struggling with that one. So, maybe it is worth a month's scrutiny! 
 Another plot device that seems to be popular at the moment, is the multiple perspectives device. This works when all the voices are unique. Books like 'Bluefish', by Pat Schmantz and 'Because of Mr Terupt', by Rob Buyea, do this really well. In 'Wonder' the voices just don't feel significantly well characterised, although it does allow the reader the chance to review scenes in the book to learn a little more. 
 But a good book provokes, doesn't it? And this book did provoke thought. And I am sure it would be a great book to use in class, although it is somewhat clumsy with its morals. Great discussion could be had over so many elements of the story. So long as it doesn't slip into being patronising, or over simplified. This book had some heroic attempts at reminding us that we are all human, and we struggle to make the best decisions we can with the resources we have, and that we won't get it right all the time. And that's a great message to remember. I wish that had been a Mr Browne precept. 
 So, all in all, I liked the book. Maybe I even really liked the book, but it wasn't without its challenges. Ultimately, though, I am still inclined to err towards a four star rating.

Wow. Wonder is such a wonderful book. I wasn't sure how the story will go but R. J. Palacio did a great job in this one. I love how the story is told through Auggie and many other character's point of view. Auggie's such a beautiful person if only one looks beyond his physical appearances. He's such a trooper with a big heart. Via, his older sister, is also a great character. She cares about Auggie a lot and was willing to sacrifice many important part of her life to him. I also like Auggies's friends, Jack and Summer too. In addition, I really enjoy reading about Auggie's first time experience in school, his life experiences, and the ways people interact him. This book brings out various emotions and many heartwarming moments. I really enjoy reading it.
Worth the hype. Great book. Excellent in audiobook.

Wonderful story telling, uniquely from the perspective of the children. 
 A touching story that will stay with you for a long time. 
 This could be one of those tales that stays in our lives for a very long time.
Wonderful
A beautiful story. The kids and I enjoyed listening to this on audio. Great themes!!
Such a wonderful story, for any age. Loved it. You should read it. Yes, you.

DNF, so no rating.

 This was such a beautiful book and by the end of it I was crying. 
 I wasn't crying tears of sadness, but tears of joy. 
 I can't stress this enough, how beautiful and life-changing this book is. 
 This might be a middle-grade book, but this book is for ALL ages. Everyone needs to read this book. It will change how you look at people and make you a better person.

This is a book that reminds you of the good in people. It makes you laugh, cry, and cheer for Auggie, the main character who was born with a genetic disorder and is starting school for the first time in 5th grade. This book reminded me of the power of kindness and I can't recommend it enough!

This story is told in eight parts, each from a different point of view. My favorite part is told from the POV of Via (Olivia), August's older sister. She, the often overlooked and neglected child in the family, is my favorite character and the one I relate to. (She deserves her own book.) It wasn't until Via explained her brother's physical abnormalities that I understood and could visualize August. I think the story would've been better served if that had happened earlier. Overall, it's a cute story although sometimes episodic and disjointed. Read it for the emotional impact, but don't expect a page-turning plot.

books is proofs that words can touches you in places that most of the time are out of reach and this book is one of it. it teaches you to be kind and to love and to have courage because as Christopher Nolan would say, "it was at moments such as these Joseph recognized the face of God in human form. It glimmered in their kindness to him, it glowed in their keenness, it hinted in their caring, indeed it caressed in their gaze." and because greatness lies not in being strong, but in the right using of strength. He is the greatest whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own.

"Shall we make a new rule of life...always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" 
 This story is about a young boy, Auggie, who has severe facial deformities. It's about his family and his friends and his first time going to school. The author writes the tale from other characters perspectives as well which was nice because it really gave you a well rounded point of view! A nice sweet tale about what it means to have courage and to show kindness! Also a great read to help teach empathy to kids!

Wonderful story about a 10 year old boy with facial deformities that begins public school for the first time. I laughed, I cried, and I stayed up way to late to finish. Made me want think about how I treat people.

This book is on many a top 100 books list and so when I saw it on my sons bookshelf I thought I would give it a go. This a simple story a boy (August) with a condition which caused him to have a severe facial deformity and about his first year at school which is grade 5 after being home-schooled for the previous years. The book is written from a number of first person perspectives - August himself, his friends at school, his sister, his sister's boyfriend and his sisters friend. 
 The ups and downs of life at school and family life make this a beautiful read. It is written simply yet powerfully and I really liked it.

I ordered this book on a whim because I needed something to fill my Amazon shopping cart to get free shipping. I am so glad I did. I finished this book in a day. The story follows young August with a severe facial deformity starting 5th grade in a new school after being homeschooled. The story is told from different points of view about Auggie's life. The multiple points of view are actually done very well as I felt all the characters were multidimensional. I can't wait to use it as a read aloud for my fifth grade class. The book is filled with teaching moments and I know my students will love Auggie as much as I do.

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation atleast once in their life because we all overcometh the world." 
 Charming? Uplifting? Endearing? These words are not strong enough to describe this book. I must say I haven't read such a cute book for a long time. This book succeeded beautifully.
I know this book has been an inspiration to many, but honestly I didn't feel anything. Writing is insipid and the book is average at best.

Loved this book so much! 
 I loved Auggie. 
 Cant wait to see the film
A GREAT read aloud for my middle schoolers. Such a great way to teach perspective and point of view! Auggie is such a DEAR character.
The Book Smugglers said it better than I could.

OMG! This is such an amazingly, heart warming, fun book. Palacio did such an amazing job. If I could think of a better word than amazing I would use that. This is a story of a boy named August Pullman who has a "deformed" face but his heart is anything but. I laughed and cried throughout this whole book and would of read the whole thing in one night if I did not have to work. 
 This is a definite must read and will be going on my " all time favorite" shelf.

I really, really liked this book. I think it is fantastic for 4th-6th graders. Does it delve deeply into some of the issues at hand? No. Does it end up a bit rosier than normal life usually pans out? Yes. But, that is what makes it perfect for the age group it is aimed for. It walks that thin line of telling an awesome, heartfelt story that does not talk down to this age group. Plus, it does not go too far and keeps fairly upbeat despite August and his family being dealt more than their fair share of challenges. I always appreciate a book that makes me laugh, cry, and feel connected to something bigger than myself. Wonderfully written!!

Amazing book! This book deals with a young boy who is born with facial anomolies. Because of this he is entering school as a 5th grader for the 1st time in his life. We get to see how people react to seeing his face, getting to know him as a PERSON and see how this affects his family and his new friends. With bullying being such a "hot topic" in schools I really recommend this book for teachers/students but also for all who enjoy reading as we all have encountered bullying as children and even in adult life. Great book - R. J. Palacio is a 1st time author!

This was an easy read for my book club. So glad we chose it as it made me think about how I react when I see someone with different features. I grew up with a sister who had a hand that was smaller than her other one. It happened to be her right hand, the one you use to shake hands, so it was something that was noticed often. It never changed who she was, but peoples reactions can be harmful without realizing it. 
 As I read about Auggie's condition at the beginning, I liked how they didn't go into detail right away, but made you come up with your own image based on what they did give us. It helped to give Auggie his own voice without the immediate reaction of his looks to change what you thought of him. When the narration changed to his sister Via, I was bummed at first as I wanted to keep reading about AUggie. But then it changed again and was a friend of his and then another. I realized that it helped to hear what those close to Auggie saw in him and how they all had different reactions to what he went through and how they fit into his life. 
 Everyone has a right to there own opinions, but it makes you realize that you can't judge a book by it's cover. This is a very thought provoking book and I am looking forward to our discussion about it a club night!
it is a very good story, that lifts the heart.
Fantastic!!!! I want everyone I know to read this book! So well written.

The author is coming to our school tomorrow and we are talking about Choosing Kind. I kinda feel like the author read "Schooled" (by Gordon Korman) and said "I can do that!" TBF, there is a lot more to it than that, but switching perspectives, showing other people's interactions...very Schooled. 
 In the end, a good book about being yourself and trying to fit in. I like the tone of Schooled and John Howe (Totally Joe, the Misfits, Abby in the Middle) better, but I am not everyone of course :) 
 I thought the ending a bit saccrine- you can survive as an outcast without being given an award- I know, I and ALL my friends have done it. Sometimes the school rallies around you...more likely you just keep going until the people who give you a hard time are in your rear view. It may be nicer that everyone accepts you, but stamina and continuing are more important than acceptance by the masses. Be you, its the only person you can be :)
Outstanding ? I read this with my 9 and 10 year old children who loved it as well.

WONDER 
 R.J. Palacio 
 [*****] 5 Stars. 
 If I act like the objective grown-up I'm supposed to be, I should give this book 4 stars. Problem with that would be that I love my "Queen of Biased Feels" title a little bit to much so yeah... there goes being mature. 5 SHINY RED STARS FOR YOU, BUDDY! *smiley face* 
 ----- 
 Okay, I should try to redeem myself or something here. I'm physically disabled, or handicapped, or whatever normal people think people with medical issues are, and have been using crutches to walk ever since I can remember. 
 Side Note: I've always had problems with the word "normal". That's a word used in Physics for a kind of force. It's also used to casually describe the weather. That's about it. People misuse it for "common" when they're trying to mean "average". No living thing can be normal! 
 This may seem like a random invite to my personal life but it's not; it's my reason for why I'm specifically and extremely biased when it comes to "Wonder" and the emotions it evokes in me. All those things Auggie (the protagonist) has gone through, I've experienced at one or another point in my life. It's baffling and extremelly tiring to have to pretend not to notice strangers on the street throwing furtive looks your way when you're just innocently strolling down the street and had never comitted any type of crime to justify their behavior. Now, how am I supposed to NOT give this book the whole 5 stars? 
 Protagonist was too naive and forgave too easily for my liking. There's a few situations in where I would have reacted in a different way than him, even at his age (10 years old), but then again I'm a different person myself, more detached towards people (darn defense mechanisms!). Still, for the most part it felt a lot like reading my autobiography. 
 Aside from Auggie, I disliked every single character in the book with only three exceptions. Either they annoyed me, bored me or made me feel betrayed on his part. Every one of them, except for the one exception, got on his good side by the end of the story. I don't quite get how he can be so understanding to the point of Oh-My-God-what-are-you-doing? but whatever, apparently I'm a cold-hearted hater of humanity or something along those lines. 
 This spoiler/rant over here is what irked me the most: Again, what the heck is this bullsh*t? Your "best friend" rips your heart off right out of your chest but oh, he sent you a "Hope u friend me agen cuz im really sorry" text message and all of a sudden everything's alright? Really?! 
 Moving on, moving on... Since it's targeted to young kids, I guess the author wanted to deliver us a lesson or two about kindness, courage and hope. She did a good job but by the end of it all it was a little bit too hopeful. I love the feeling, I swear I do, but it's so not how reality works. If this were real life, poor Auggie would have had it a heck of a lot worse than this. 
 A few necessary mentions: The parents are all kinds of kick-ass and I'm adopting them as my own, I don't care that they're fictional characters. Summer is an extremelly good friend and everyone should be just like her, kinda-weird-and-awkward people are always the best sort of people. 
 Favorite Character: Mr. Tushman. What is this man anyway? I'm not even sure there's someone infinitesimally similar to him in existence. Award for most awesomesauce awesomeness in a human being ever in forever and ever, ever goes to him. Cheers! *clapclapclap* 
 Favorite Quotes: "'Shall we make a new rule of life... always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary.'" -- Mr. Tushman (extracted from The Little White Bird by J. M. Barrie), page 299. 
 Favorite Chapters: A Simple Thing; Awards; Floating. 
 ----- 
 Song: Warrior by Demi Lovato.

My friend, who is an 8th grade English teacher, recommended this book to me, since I am an in class support teachers assistant for special needs children on the elementary school level. As an avid reader/member of Goodreads, I enjoy my contemporary fiction and women's literature as well as memoirs and historical fiction, but I also like to read the books that my students (and years ago, my own kids), are reading. Lately I find that the genres geared towards kids are more science fiction, fantasy, and dystopian, none of which inteterst me. But my friend advised me to read this realistic fiction book geared towards 5th and 6th grade, and a couple of days later, someone on the Today Show panel also gave it a thumbs up for this age group. 
 August is a ten year old boy who was born with severe facial deformities and has gone through many surgeries throughout his life. Until now, he has been home schooled, but his parents feel that he should try to navigate the real world and want him to start middle school as a 5th grader. This novel follows his experiences in middle school where he encounters all of the challenges that "normal" kids do...cliques, bullying, trying to fit in....the usual challenges which are made that much more difficult due to his unique situation. Although there are times that August feels like he cannot stand it anymore, he is basically a secure child because of his close knit family who loves him unconditionally and have given him a sense of self esteem that he didn't even know he had. The interesting thing about this book is that the author tells the story through different points of view. The story is August's story, yet we hear from his older sister, who has had her own issues to deal with and speaks with the wisdom of a sibling of a special needs child, the two students who become friendly with August, one by request and one by choice, the sister's boyfriend, and the sister's former best friend (the two girls had drifted apart during this year of high school). The author demonstrates through this literary technique how August has pulled all these people together, and the strength of his personality has taught them all important lessons about character, kindness, and compassion. The characters are realistic and sympathetic, the events real, and the description of school so vivid that I could visualize this in any school today. The situations are life events; at times I laughed, and other times I needed a pack of tissues.I read this in one day, and I feel it is an important book that parents shoulc read with their children. It would be a teachable moment; bullying is rampant in school, and children are targets for any reason, not just a disability. This book could provide a springboard for discussions about the challenges of middle school, for students, parents, and teachers.
My oldest said this was SO good and really made her think.
Best book I've read all summer.
What a beautiful, beautiful book. My kids will definitely read this before middle school.

Loved this book! Sweet, touching, funny--it's a great look at how we all treat those who are "different," and how we can each do a little bit better. Easy to read--I read it in less than a day. I'm recommending it to my husband, kids (ages 10-17), and friends. A read the whole family can enjoy and then discuss.
Amazing. This book was so wonderfully written. It brought me to tears multiple times. What a great book that teaches us empathy and kindness. Loved it.

IF YOU ONLY READ ONE BOOK THIS SUMMER...READ WONDER BY R.J. PALACIO!!! 
 Wonder is the story of August Pullman, a boy about to go into fifth grade at Beecher Prep. August has never attended an actual school before-he's always been too sick. But he's stronger now...physically. August was born with a facial deformity which has required him to have 27 surgeries in his first eleven years. 
 August considers himself an ordinary boy: inside. He knows others don't see him that way when they look at his face. According to August: 
 "I think the only person in the world who realizes how ordinary I am is me." 
 The story of August's fifth grade year is told from a variety of viewpoints: August, his sister Via, Via's childhood friend, a fellow Fifth Grade student, and Via's new boyfriend. Each narrator brings insights into his or her own behavior and feelings which enhance the complete story. Each voice is unique and genuine. 
 This book is by turns joyful, heart-rending, hopeful, hilarious and inspiring. The story is about more than one boy's journey to continue accepting himself and sharing himself with others. It is about love and friendship and family. It is about growing in compassion and kindness and opportunities to exist with each other in this world together as triumphant spirits of everything that makes life exquisite. 
 It speaks to us of the choices we make for ourselves and in our attitudes and behaviors toward others. It speaks to the difficulty of making those choices. We all know that the 'right' choices are rarely the easy ones. So how do you find the courage to make them anyway? The various narrators give us examples from their perspectives. Then it's up to us. 
 August reflects 
 "It's like people you see sometimes, and you can't imagine what it would be like to be that person, whether it's somebody in a wheelchair or somebody who can't talk. Only, I know I'm that person to other people, maybe to every single person in that whole auditorium. 
 To me, though, I'm just me. An ordinary kid." 
 Although I know we won't be able to finish it before the school year is up, I began reading it to my two Fourth Grade classes this past week. I found it to be such a magnificent, soaring read for me that I am hoping some of the students will be motivated to get the book from the library and finish it on their own this summer. Although we were only able to get 11 pages into it in one class and 15 with the other, neither class wanted me to stop when we ran out of time! I am soooo looking forward to reading with them again our last two weeks! 
 Wonder is a first novel by R.J. Palacio and it is a book that will add to your life in an extraordinary way when you read it!

Wonder is a very special book! I was immediately drawn into the characters' lives...especially the protagonist, Auggie. Each character is very well developed and the book is very well put together. The overall theme is that if embracing differences and finding courage. As a middle school reading teacher, I strongly recommend this book to all upper elementary/middle school students.

a touching story with themes of bullying, acceptance, friendship, family, and courage. The story is told in different parts by several characters, and the audio was well done, featuring different narrators for each perspective.
This book changed the way I look at everything. There is beauty in the world. It made me grateful for my life. It is a fee good book

3.5 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." 
 "Shall we make a new rule in life ... always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" 
 "we carry with us, as human beings, not just the capacity to be kind, but the very choice of kindness."

I did a review of Wonder over on my channel which you can check out here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SAKdf3... 
 spoiler: it's amazing

Wonder, by R. J. Palacio has become a 'publishing sensation' dealing sensitively with the rare issue of cranio-facial anomalies but also tackling more widely stuff around being a kid, who's in, who's out, friends, enemies and frenemies. It does so beautifully in the main with the story told from August 'Augie' Pullman's view of his first ever foray into the public world of 'middle school' after being home-schooled. Augie is a sweet, engaging character who has grown accustomed to the double-take his appearance causes in others. He loves Star Wars and his dog, Daisy, his favourite day of the year is Halloween when he can hide behind a mask like everyone else in New York. Chapters told from other points of view (sister, sister's boyfriend, friends etc) didn't work for me, detracting from Augie's viewpoint and adding little. The ending was upbeat; Augie becomes accepted and popular even, albeit in a class mascot type of way. Are kids ever this nice? Not in my experience. Sadly, in school as in life ( perhaps not in the world of children's books) bullies win out.

Auggie Pullman is born with Treacher Collins, a chromosome disorder that results in severe facial deformities. He is homeschooled for many years because of his ongoing need for extensive surgery and his parents' fear about how Auggie will be treated. 
 When Auggie begins fifth grade, his parents decide to send him to school. How Auggie, his family, and his classmates deal with Auggie's transition to school during one school year forms the basis of the storyline. I appreciated the honesty of his situation and how other children respond to Auggie at school. Many kids tease Auggie and the author also shows how Auggie is excluded without being openly bullied. 
 Wonder is a remarkable book about courage, love, and the difference one person can make in the lives of others. Auggie is an inspiring person because he is just an ordinary kid. It isn't just Auggie who inspires you, though, his parents, older sister, his teachers, and his friends and their families show their strength and love for Auggie in their daily interactions with him. 
 While the ending was a little bit like a Hallmark movie, I thought it was appropriate to the mood of the story and the characters' actions. 
 You will cry and smile and think of the special people in your life. Wonder is the sort of book that stays with you.
Lexile: 790
About as good as a YA novel can be. Four stars due to the never ending conclusion and because it wasn't the best written novel I have come across.

August Pullman is a ten-year-old boy with serious facial abnormalities. He's been home-schooled up to now, his parent's attempt to protect him from the meanness of other kids. But now he's going to start fifth grade at a real school. 
 The book follows Auggie's experiences of the fifth grade as he tries to make friends and deal with the reactions of the other kids and tries to find a way to fit in. That's hard for any kid, but for Auggie, it's even tougher. As well as Auggie's experiences, we also follow the experiences of those whose lives he particularly touches - his older sister, Via and her boyfriend, Justin, and friend Miranda, and two kids from his grade - Jack and Summer. 
 My favourite character in the book was Summer. She's a very smart girl with her head screwed on right who makes a point of befriending Auggie on the first day of fifth grade, and one of the few kids who is able to see past his disfigurement right from the start. 
 All the characters were great, and while Auggie had the most obvious problems to deal with, the other characters all had things in their lives or problems they had to deal with too, never mind just trying to survive fifth grade (in Auggie, Jack, and Summer's case) or high school (in Via, Miranda, and Jack's case). 
 A really great book, with moments that made me want to cry, and moments that made me laugh out loud, and moments that made me want to hug some characters (especially Auggie) and strangle others (especially this kid in Auggie's class named Julian, and Julian's awful mother). It's a book written for kids, but it deals with issues people of any age will be familiar with, and can definitely be read and enjoyed by anyone aged 9 - 100!

Many middle schoolers have the experience of feeling that everyone's staring at them for some reason; for the protagonist in Wonder, this is literally true. Auggie has a severe craniofacial difference that causes people he encounters to, at best, look quickly away or, at worst, behave abominably. Wonder tells the story of Auggie's first foray into 'real school' after years of homeschooling by his understandably protective parents. Told from multiple points of view (Auggie, his sister, a new friend, his sister's boyfriend), the story is not so much about Auggie's particular challenges but about how hard it is for most young people to find their way in the world and how we can all make it easier (or harder) for one another.

A YA novel, describing the fifth grade year of a boy with a craniofacial deformity, from his perspective as well as the perspectives of some of his classmates, as well as his sister and some of her classmates. Very nicely done. I came to this via its mention in Will Schwalbe's Books for Living.

Middle-class, middle-aged authors should not attempt to write 'txt spk' as done by ten-year-olds. Otherwise it was pretty good, though I preferred A Curious Incident, for those who insist on comparing the two.
I loved this one! I hope I can read it aloud to a class this year!
An incredibly moving advocation for the simple act of being kind, and an unforgettable story.

I loved this story. It would have been a favorite of mine when I was 10/9-11. 
 I finally got to it because of a recommendation from Izzy; I'm so glad that it didn't languish forever on my to read list, as do most of my "to read" books. 
 I loved August's voice so much that at first I was disappointed when another voice/several characters' voices started narrating the story. However, I ended up really appreciating the multiple perspectives. All of the kids' points of view are done perfectly, both the fifth graders and the ninth graders. 
 I had heard that there was one, and I could tell ahead of time what the sad animal moment would be, but at 10 I might not have seen it coming. 
 The story is very touching, and very funny, and very sweet. The ending was not my favorite, but that's okay; it worked well enough, and I appreciated why it ended the way it did. 
 I have some theories about one of the characters who wasn't given a voice, and I see that there is a published short story told from his point of view, but this book was so perfectly put together that I don't know that I have much interest in reading it. 
 I enjoyed seeing all the precepts included at the end of the book. 
 This is a great book about bullying, being kind, doing the right thing, being courageous, good teaching, friendship and family, and I respected how it didn't talk down to kids. I remember having these same kinds of deep conversations and thoughts when I was the age of Auggie and his classmates, and I think most readers around age 10 will identify with this group of kids. I also think that this could be a life-altering book for some young readers. And, it was simply a fun read and hard to put down. Very engaging.
Amazing. Beautiful. Meaningful. That's how i describe this book.
Amazing story to read with my 10 year old.

This book was really great but I wonder if - in today's world where social media sites can destroy a child's self esteem in the real world -- is it a bit too idealistic? One of the things I love about it is that it is unflinching about adolescent cruelty as well as hopeful about people's capacity for acceptance. But the main character has an exceptionally strong character and family in my opinion. I wonder that they weren't going to counseling to help them deal with the world?

Wonderful late elementary book about a boy with a cranio-facial anomaly and his transition to his fifth grade year... his first in a school environment. The story is told not only from his perspective, but from the perspective of his older sister, his sister's boyfriend, his 'best friend', and others in his world. Wonderful book about the importance of kindness and what true courage looks like.
Amazing book, very affecting without beig sappy. the multiple perspectives grounded it.

i read this aloud with ava and she and i absolutely loved it. it is well written from various points of view. highly recommended for adults and children alike. 
 originally read june 2012
This was such a great book! I truly loved it and think it should be read in all middle schools. Kids can be cruel and this is a great teaching book for just that!

Read 22/06/2013 - 24/06/2013 
 A beautiful little book. Yes, at times it was sort of schmaltzy, and a little predictable at times. But it was also beautiful. At first, I was unsure of the narrator switches, but actually I found them quite endearing and enlightening - it felt like each character had a slightly different perspective, and gave a little something different to think about. 
 It may not be anything particularly groundbreaking, and may not be a literary 5-star piece of work. But the way it made me feel warrants the 5 star rating.

After years of home school, August's parents decide it is time for him to enter mainstream school. He's been in home school due to the fact that he was born with an extremely rare and severe facial deformity, and much of his life up to that point had been spent in and out of hospitals undergoing numerous surgeries. In fifth grade, as middle school begins, he starts attending a small private school. The story is both jarring and inspirational. I liked the way the author tells the tale through various characters eyes: August, his sister, his friends. It gives a unique perspective to how everyone is feeling as they undergo this huge change in life. I'd recommend this to teachers who might be looking for books on diversity or anti-bullying.
amazing

This is one of those "Everybody ought to read" books. I started listening to it about lunch time and finished it by the end of the day. It's about a boy named August that has a severe facial deformity and is starting school for the first time. I really liked how it gave the point of view of all of the major characters. I think it's important to know their thoughts to be able to understand their actions and points of view. Of course Auggie faces struggles as he starts Jr. High and faces the stares and ridicule of the different kids. He is lucky enough to meet some truly great kids that befriend him and stand up with him. It's a story of strength and knowing who you are and being able to stand up for your friends. Great book.

I just finished reading WONDER by R J Palacio and was absolutely stunned by the intelligence, honesty, hope, courage and "wonder" in its pages. This MG/YA book should be on every middle school reading list. At a time when there is so much negative press about bullying and peer pressure to conform, a story like this comes along and makes us all examine our selves to see what we stand for. This is a story I will be thinking about for a long time.
Inspiring

"Wonder" really works well in touching the human heart. Here we have a child with an unfortunate condition but he is surrounded by loving family and gains new loving friends. 
 Written in a narrative style, the author brings in different characters and we learn of them as they write from their viewpoints, including that of August, the main character. 
 This book targets younger readers and the author does a nice job of making the characters believable and relatable, although not all of them are "good" or "kind". However, the book works well for adults as well, serving a nonjudgmental reminder of how we as human should treat one another. 
 I recommend this book to readers of all ages.

I loved Wonder, it was sweet and heartwarming to read. I loved reading from the different perspectives, but I did have a few minor issues. I don't believe Justin's tics were explained or why his chapter didn't have capital letters or quotation marks, if anyone knows please tell me! Also I feel like the story could have benefitted from having an adult's perspective. Possibly Isabel, Nate, Mr Browne, or Mr Tushman. Overall these were very minor and did not take away from my enjoyment. I can't wait to read Julian's Chapter because I feel like that will really round out the story. I'd love to get some insight into his mind!

The author RJ Palaico has the reader in her palm immediately with her intro. "..I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you are thinking, it's probably worse." For a debut novel she has cleverly crafted honest feelings of the boy August, his sister Via and friends so that we the reader fully understand how extremely difficult this young boys life is everyday because of his facial deformity. And of course the adverse effects of bullies has us empathizing and hoping for a good resolution. We read this youth book in an adult book club and I am glad that we did; it was refreshing and very positive. Simply put- be nice to everyone is not a syrupy thing to be reminded of and maybe this book should be a required read for all ages.
I hope all my students read this!

Such an amazing story! With themes of perseverance, being true to self and to friends, and dealing with changes and with bullies. Beautifully written, both realistic and inspiring, this book chronicles the story of Auggie's fifth grade year, his first in regular school due to a series of craniofacial related health issues and surgeries. It is told from the point of view of Auggie and those whose lives his touches. One intriguing aspect that is secondary to the story is Mr. Browne's precepts, a classroom practice that I'm wondering about duplicating -- maybe in Mommy school.
Was thoroughly amazed at this story and how the author told it through many different viewpoints. Definitely a must read for any young adult or adult!!
Absolutely amazing! One that should be read by everyone regardless of their age. One that I will recommend and pass on!
This could be one of the sweetest, most heartwarming novels I've ever read. Left me sobbing, feeling so uplifted and so emosh. Couldn't recommend it highly enough. An absolute delight.
A must read.
Love this book! This time I listened to the audio format. It was as good as the book! Great quotes and lessons in this quick read!
Amazing book! kindness!!!!!!!
This provided so many great discussions with my children (10 and 13).
I read this aloud to my whole family. We all loved it, from the oldest to the youngest.

loved it. 
 Very moving, engaging & entertaining.

The story is told from the viewpoint of various children involved, and I believe the author did a great job of expressing their tangled emotions. Had I had the time, I'd have read the entire book in one sitting.
I loved this book.
Actual rating: 4.5/5

I loved this. It was so sweet and the kids all seemed like realistic ten year olds with their tendency to get caught up in the moment and move from one topic/feeling to another very easily. I found it interesting that August was aware of people who were being fake friendly/kind to him, because I feel like sometimes stories with unusual characters tend to make everyone overly nice or the main character is very gullible. I also enjoyed hearing from his friend Jack and his sister, those two perspectives really added to the story and made me think about how everyone has their issues and complexities, not just the main character. The depth of this story surprised me considering that it's narrated by a group of young kids- I loved it.
Auggie is my hero amazing how one person can change so many lives! Great read!
A very touching story. I am going to have my son read it, too.
This book should be a mandatory read for all middle school students and teachers. It was exquisite.
Wonder was full of the kind of small redemptive moments I cherish in a good book.

I read an article one time that said reading fiction books can give you more empathy. I'm not sure if that's universally true, but reading this book definitely will. It makes you appreciate the life you have, and reminds you of how all of your actions can impact others. My daughter is a little too young to understand this now, but as soon as she's old enough it's required reading!
WONDER = WONDERFUL! This is a fabulous book!

Richly-layered characters, a story that will crack the toughest of exteriors, and laughs and tears (holy balls, the tears -- Minne was giving me extra kitty cuddles and antics because of the excessive heaving, choking sobs). For anyone who has ever survived the fifth grade!

I bought this book many months ago. I've so many new books waiting in line to be read and then e-books came along and occupied most of my time. 
 Having this book in hand; made me remember the feeling of curling up in a sofa and flipping an actual book. Not flipping "pages" on Kindle app on my iPad. 
 This is such a beautiful book. Of course, the storyline is pretty much predictable but the way of execution, the story being told, it's amazing. Different parts of the books are told by different characters. We get to learn and understand how each characters felt. Their thought process, their feelings, their regrets. 
 I guess I always have a soft spot for kids who are bullied. And August Pullman was one of them. 
 I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse. 
 August Pullman was born with a facial deformity that, up until now, has prevented him from going to a mainstream school. Starting 5th grade at Beecher Prep, he wants nothing more than to be treated as an ordinary kid--but his new classmates can't get past Auggie's extraordinary face. WONDER, now a New York Times bestseller, begins from Auggie's point of view, but soon switches to include his classmates, his sister, her boyfriend, and others. These perspectives converge in a portrait of one community's struggle with empathy, compassion, and acceptance. 
 In a world where bullying among young people is an epidemic, this is a refreshing new narrative full of heart and hope. R.J. Palacio has called her debut novel "a meditation on kindness" --indeed, every reader will come away with a greater appreciation for the simple courage of friendship. Auggie is a hero to root for, a diamond in the rough who proves that you can't blend in when you were born to stand out. 
 Such a delightful read and I managed to finish in 3 days. 
 You are always beautiful, in your own way. Don't let someone else tell you otherwise.

Wonder is a touching story of a boy born with physical deformities making his way to school for the first time. Challenged by perceptions, judgments, and middle school hormones, August has to face his fears and put his unique face forward.

I had seen this book advertised without really knowing what it was about, so when I spotted it in the library I thought I'd give it a try. When I read the blurb I sort of doubted whether I wanted to read it, thinking that it'd be aimed at children. 
 The book deals with Auggie Pullman starting mainstream school with a severe facial deformity, focusing on Auggie and his friends and family who narrate their sides of his story. 
 In retrospect I can't say that anything incredible or exciting happens and yet every time I put it down I wanted to pick it up again, there was definitely something compelling about it. 
 The only negative thing that I can say - and this is really what kept it at a three star rating - is that there were characters who could have been used as narrators who would have been harder hitting than some that were actually used. Justin and Miranda added absolutely nothing to the story plotwise or with their emotions/opinions. Yet there was absolutely no input from Auggie's parents. 
 How did Auggie's Dad react to his wife putting Auggie in school? Did Auggie's mum purposely choose Auggie over Via? How did Nate react to this? How did Isobel really deal with Auggie's school trip? 
 There was a lot of emotion that wasn't tapped into, which could have made this book a bit more stand out for me.

From a parental perspective, as this book started out, I was thinking it would be a great book to recommend to my boys. It was quite easy to read, with short chapters, fun chapter titles, and quite a bit of humor (added by mostly by Dad). After finishing the book however, I'm not SURE it's for my boys (maybe when they are a bit older?), although I did really enjoy the book myself. 
 One of my boys is a bit of a hypochondriac and prone to panic/anxiety attacks (sometimes more than a bit, we were having a BAD day today, as I was trying to read this book) ... at first I thought this might be a good book for him to read (just to realize his problems are very mild and he is very lucky and healthy) but then, I don't know. I can see this book bringing up some stress points for him. The grandmother dying (having a stomach ache and going to the hospital, and not coming back out), the dog dying, the talk of heaven (also talk of reincarnation as an alternate possibility), and just the trials of any kid entering middle school (which he will be doing in a few months). I don't want him to worry about not having someone to eat with, or kids being mean and spreading rumors, fighting. Maybe after a successful transition to middle school I'd feel more comfortable with him and that aspect of the story. Maybe not something every parent needs to worry about, but those with kids sensitive to any of these topics may have some cause for concern. 
 Where we are at, elementary school goes through sixth grade. Middle school is 7-9. It is just a little odd to be reading about 5th graders being in Middle School (although I've seen it in the Big Nate books too). I was a little put off by the talk of "relationships" in this 5th grade class. That there were "couples" and they were "going out" and "dating" ... in 5th grade??? (or am I being naive?) MY boys (6th and 8th grade) aren't interested in girls ... or am I being naive again? Also the fact that the kids could wear masks at school for Halloween (not allowed here), and I don't think any of our schools would allow pink hair or tube tops (although Olivia does think that it is inappropriate for school). 
 There was a LOT of pop media references. A TON of StarWars stuff (but my boy does love StarWars too), Diary of a Wimpy Kid, ET, Miley Cyrus, Doogie Howser ... others I can't remember right off. Classic stuff too (Wizard of Oz, War and Peace), but things that if a child does NOT have a reference for, they might not "get" parts of the book. 
 The section outlining the genetics MAY go over the heads of some kids. It was a little technical, but interesting to me. I have a cousin whose child has a fatal disease, and it seemed like the same basic odds came into factor for it (with both parents being a recessive carrier). At the end of that discussion, Via thinks "countless babies who'll never be born, like mine." I read that as Via giving up the thought of having childen at all, so as not to risk having a child like Auggie, or even passing on the gene. 
 The story was heartbreaking and uplifting ... the attitude and treatment of August by different individuals was really interesting and you have to ask yourself, where would I stand, what would I have done? We come to understand Auggie, Via, Summer, Jack (even a glimpse at Jack's nanny from a memory he has). It would have been interesting perhaps to get more of an idea of Julian's thoughts, although the emails exchanged with the school and his mother do shed light on that. 
 The story here has a "happy" ending ... a standing ovation. A title tie in at the very last sentence. But I can't help but wonder what the future holds, imaginary though it is ...

This book was a great book! It is about a kid named August who is born with severe facial disfigurement. Through his entire life, he was mocked and teased, and for the first time, he has to face his biggest fear: public school. This book was told in various perspectives, which I thought added a lot, including some from very minor side characters. I'd definitely recommend this book to a young kid.

This was a beautiful story of strength, kindness, compassion and inner beauty. It is a story that kids can relate to and every young adult should read. I know that I would like for my children to read this book when they are a little older. Just beautiful.

Orismena biblia, ekhoun kathara ten prothese na se psukhagogesoun kai na se diaskedasoun. Alla pali, na se problematisoun kai na se baloun sten diadikasia na skephteis. Na skephteis poios pragmatika eisai, poios mporeis na gineis, pos blepeis ton kosmo kai tous anthropous guro sou. Ena tetoio biblio einai kai to "Thauma", to opoio kuklophorei edo kai liges meres, apo tis ekdoseis Papadopoulos. Ena biblio pou an kai theoretika katatassetai sten paidike logotekhnia, ekhei na dosei kai na prospherei, polla perissotera ap' osa, isos, se prodiathetei, pairnontas to sta kheria sou. Ena biblio pou se sugkinei kai kata kapoion tropo, se sokarei, giati emmesa, se anagkazei na antikriseis to eidolo sou ston kathrepte kai na anarotetheis, "ti tha ekana an emoun ste these tous;" e to semantikotero olon, "eimai telika, kalos anthropos;" 
 O Augoustos, einai ena dekakhrono agori to opoio kai gennetheke me ena idiaitero eidos dusmorphias, me ena stomatoprosopiko sundromo pou ton ekhei anagkasei na upoblethei se dekades epipones egkheireseis pou par' ola tauta, den tha mporesoun pote na apokatastesoun ten emphanise tou, kathistontas ten phusiologike. Ola auta ta khronia, e metera tou, etan ekeine pou phrontize gia ten ekpaideuse tou kai etsi, emene oso to dunaton makria apo alla paidia ki anthropous me tous opoious, den megalose mazi kai pou den mporousan na diakheiristoun ten emphanise tou e opoia kai prokalei apostrophe. Erthe omos e ora pou o Augoustos, prepei na paei skholeio, na antimetopisei ton kosmo, enan kosmo pou einai skleros kai pou polles phores, den katalabainei e den thelei na katalabei, alla kai tous idious tou tous phobous pou khoris na to thelei, leitourgoun katastaltika os pros ten tonose tes autopepoitheses tou. 
 Prota ap' ola, to "Thauma", einai ena exairetika kalogrammeno biblio, me logo aplo kai katanoeto pou skopo den ekhei na demiourgesei entuposeis, oute na phluaresei pano se mia sugkekrimene katastase, katapheugontas se phtenous melodramatismous. Okhi giati den tha mporouse, alla pragmatika, giati den to ekhei anagke. E istoria tes Palacio, einai mia istoria toso paraxene, toso xene stous perissoterous apo emas kai omos, mia istoria pou tha mporouse na sumbei ston kathena mas. Kai e skepse aute kai mono, einai tromaktike. Okhi giati den tha antekhame na antikrizoume kathe mera to paramorphomeno prosopo enos paidiou, alla giati kathos diabazoume kai ginomaste meros tes istorias, suneidetopoioume pos isos na men diathetame tis psukhikes antokhes kai to sthenos pou apaiteitai gia na uposterixeis enan tetoion anthropo kai ten zoe pou tou epiphulassei e katastase tou. Kai pistepste me, khreiazetai megala kotsia, okhi gia na to apodekhtheis esu o idios, alla gia na mporeseis na kaneis tous allous na doun, auto pou mporeis na deis esu, auto pou brisketai kato apo ten epiphaneia. 
 E aphegese, einai moirasmene. Kai nai, mporei o idios o Augoustos na pherei sten plate tou to megalutero phortio, omos den einai o monos pou upopherei kapoies stigmes, pou den einai kai liges giati polu apla, den mporoun na einai. Giati akoma ki an xerei pos kapoioi ton agapoun giauto pou einai, par' olo pou prospathei na einai gennaios kai aisiodoxos, den ta kataphernei panta. Giati einai ena paidi kai malista, ena paidi me katanoese ki euaisthesies. Paromoio phortio sekonoun oi goneis pou prepei na megalosoun kai na prostatepsoun ena paidi me idiaiterotetes. E megalutere tou aderphe pou an kai katalabainei ten katastase, niothei kapoies phores na pnigetai apo ten anagke na einai phusiologike, opos toulakhiston to ennoei o upoloipos kosmos. Oi philoi pou blepoun se ekeinon kati peran tes emphanises kai pou omos, apomononontai kai lambanoun meros se enan polemo pou oi idioi, pote den tha epelegan na emplakoun giati einai elithio. 
 Ksekinontas to keimeno mou, anephera pos ena apo ta erotemata pou se anagkazei to sugkekrimeno biblio na theseis ston eauto sou, einai to an eisai kalos anthropos. Prosopika, den xero an eimai, mporo omos na po me sigouria pos diabazontas to "Thauma", aisthanomai kaluteros anthropos. Mpeka ste these, okhi mono tou Augoustou, alla ton gonion, tes aderphes tou, ton philon tou, olon ekeinon pou ton sterizan e ton apaxionan. Exetasa to nomisma apo kathe pleura kai auto pou katalaba einai pos, telika, den ekhei tipota allo semasia, para auto pou aisthanomaste mesa mas, auto pou monakha ta matia tes psukhes mporoun na doun. Oi praxeis mas, einai autes pou kathorizoun to poioi eimaste kai to poioi tha ginoume, einai kathara dikia mas epiloge. Mporoume na kleisoume ta matia kai t' autia mas, e na ginoume oi eroes ekeinoi tes kathemerinotetas pou aisiodoxoun, autosarkazontai, den noiazontai gia ta skholia ton allon, pou mporoun na dinoun khoris na perimenoun antallagmata giati tha ekhoun ten megalutere ikanopoiese olon. Tha mporoun na agapane kai pano ap' ola, na zoun te zoe tous opos theloun kai na niothoun eugnomones gi' auto. Kai nai, auto, einai ena mikro "megalo" thauma.

Wonder is a hard book for me to review, as it wasn't written for me. So I will star it and try to review it as my 10 year old daughter would want me to. Did I enjoy Wonder? Yes. It was a heart warming story that makes you think about how kind you are to those around you. I think other 10 year old kids will read and love it as she did. 
 As an adult, I had some issues with the book. Yes it was a little too much bubble-gum-rainbows-and-unicorns for such a heavy topic. But I think as a 10 year old, you need that to temper the issues at hand. My biggest complaint was the change in narrators. I tend to dislike books that change narrators, simply because it is so hard to do that really well. I appreciate what it brings to a story, but if the tone of each narrator isn't distinct, well, that bothers me. With the exception of Justin's stream of conscious style with his aversion to capital letters, the other narrators kind of blend together. Again, that is an adult complaint, and one I doubt my daughter really noticed or cared about. 
 I thought this was a good book for tweens and teens to read, and one their parents should read along with them. There were some points along the way where I had to explain some things (genetics, cleft palate, etc). A great way to spark a conversation between the generations.
We are reading this book for our book club. I am happy to say this is the second book I have finished before discussion day. It is worth reading... It might even change your life.

The story of August Pullman, a ten-year-old with severe craniofacial abnormalities, is a brave, thought-provoking, heart-warming tale. I am so impressed that R.J. Palacio chose to write a story with the main character being a kid like Auggie. This is a new title on the Battle of the Books list, a moving story told by Auggie as well as through the point-of-view of some of the kids around him. It feels like a book that should be required reading for everyone. I am so glad that some of the fourth grade teachers at school are reading it aloud to their classes this year. I wasn't sure how it would do as a read aloud, but the teachers say their classes are loving it! It certainly is unlike anything I've ever read before.

Reader thoughts: This was so good I had to add a new shelf. "Made me cry." Now, the reason I cried was because the pet died, and I'm a sucker for the pet dying in the middle of all the other character struggles. (I bawled my eyes out during the Ramona and Beezus movie.) 
 Anyway, most of the book wasn't even about that. It was about a funny fifth grader who is mostly ordinary, except that his face isn't ordinary. 
 Auggie was so unstoppable. He didn't give up. In situations I would be terrified of, he kept going. He talked to people, made jokes, sat with others at lunch, invited friends over for a birthday party at the bowling alley, etc. He made himself approach other kids. I was shy enough to struggle with that, and I know how hard it is to go to perfect strangers and try to introduce yourself or ask to sit at their table or hang out with them. And I look fairly normal. I cannot imagine what strength it toook for Auggie to continually put up with rejection after rejection and still be so light-hearted and good-natured. He laughed at so many things! I loved it. 
 Plus, he had a lot of different interests, especially Star Wars. 
 I love that the book explored different povs, and you can see how different characters view Auggie. His sister cares for him, but she is definitely tired of the world revolving around him. She has her own struggles. She just started high school, lost some friends, got a boyfriend, tried out for the school play, etc. Most of her worries aren't even about her brother! 
 So, Auggie has to put up with a lot. He has friends who are mean behind his back. He has students who don't want to touch his skin. He has a sister who doesn't want to hang out with him. His hearing is getting worse. He's extra small for his age. He has to eat funny. He thinks he looks like a duck. Sometimes people stare. Sometimes little kids scream. 
 Writer thoughts: I'm a bit surprised this book is set in 5th grade as opposed to 6th grade. Most middle schools (that I've heard of) are 6th through 8th or even just 7th and 8th. Sometimes they'll include 9th grade. I guess there must be middle schools that start at 5th grade. 
 Why did RJP pick 5th grade, then? My guess is that 10-year-olds are old enough to make decisions but young enough to still want to have fun. They're not (usually) old enough for puberty, and Auggie and his classmates had enough going on to not have that complication thrown in. 10- and 11-year-olds are young enough to make up dumb games like Cheese Touch, but they're old enough to know that they're being rude. 
 Writers have to pick ages carefully, and I don't think this book would have had the same impact had Auggie been in 6th grade. He would have sounded too whiny, and it would have been weirder for him to keep crawling into his mother's lap.

You know what I think about Wonder? I THINK EVERYONE ON THE PLANET SHOULD READ IT. Yep, it was worth the all caps. Not only does R.J. Palacio do an absolutely wonderful job writing this story, it's a heart-warming, tear-jerking and all around awesome read. 
 Need more reason to read this? My friend, who isn't a big reader, was the one who highly recommended this one. That's right people. A non-book reader suggested this book. She's a teacher and reads it to her students as well. It's that kind of story. One that impacts you at any age. 
 "Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the word." - Auggie's Precept 
 It's mostly told through little Auggie (who I just want to hug), but there's a few chapters that are told from other people's perspectives. I wasn't prepared for it at first, but it works perfectly. Plus the book is full of gems to hold on to. 
 "...but what I want you, my students, to take away from your middle-school experience," he continued, "is the sure knowledge that, in the future you make for yourselves, anything is possible. If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 It's amazing that this is a debut novel. I can't wait to see what R.J. Palacio comes out with next! I'll probably cry in that one too. Really, read this one people! 
 Have any of you read this one? What did you think? I think I need to go read it again. 
 "He is the greatest," he finally continued, "whose strength carries up the most hearts by the attraction of his own."

Despite the slightly unreal "happily ever after, some people are just amazingly kind" thing Wonder has going on, it is sweet, well-written, important and most importantly to me - a true Middle Reader. J Fic to the core. I can hand it out to my 4th and 5th graders happily and hopefully, knowing they will cry and love it and maybe be changed by it. This is rare.
One of those books that makes you wish it didn't end, I am at a loss for words as to how WONDERful this book will make you feel! A must read for eveyone. Just remember, always choose to be kind!

Am just speechless!......it's no exaggerating when i admit it really got me into tears... This is just one of the books that the moral of it gets to be stuck with every time u pump into a situation as similar to what the main character's have... And Auggie i wish to be one of his besties if i were in the book indeed not out of sympathy but thats for real. I think that this is just a brilliant book and everyone should really consider adding to their list....

I didn't expect this one to be a stay-up-until-the-early-hours-of-the-morning-reading type book. But it is. The main character has facial deformities and is headed into public school for 5th grade, for the first time. The author uses his point of view as well as 5 other teens/pre-teens. I think that may be one my favorite aspects- no matter who you are, you're bound to relate to at least one of them. 
 This should be required reading for every person on the planet.

This is the first book I read last year. It is a middle grade book. It was cute and had a good message. I don't remember it being as "omgz" fabulous as everyone thought. A book about being different. Honestly, I'd have to read it again to remember if I'd recommend it or not. Sorry! I do remember thinking that although it was one kids could relate to, it was a little too "easy" in terms of how things became better for the character.
Heartwarming - reminds me of "Firegirl".

Wonder is an extraordinary story and it must be read by everyone. 
 There were so many scenes that moved me to tears. 
 This book is like a punch to a gut,a reality check.. 
 IT made me realize how the world treats someone even if they are a slightest bit different. 
 How people don't respect the feelings of other people.How people can be judgmental.. 
 It also showed me that there are decent people out there.People who respect the less fortunate and treat them with kindness and care. 
 I wanted to hug August.He is such a sweet kid.I loved his family and his friends. 
 These are my fav quotes: 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 "WHEN GIVEN THE CHOICE BETWEEN BEING RIGHT OR BEING KIND, CHOOSE KIND."
Liked all the characters, so many very good people in one book. YA all the way. Cute.
A quick and easy read, but left me with a reminder of the power of kindness.
Magic.
Ho bisogno di qualche giorno per elaborare tutte le emozioni che questo piccolo grande libro mi ha regalato. A breve la mia recensione.
Absolutely brilliant. I would recommend this book 100 times over until there were no words left to read, and still. It was perfect and realistic.

Not a perfect book, but one that has great value for the intended audience (main characters are 5th graders) and adults alike. 
 August is a likable, but imperfect character. This is basically true of all the characters, including the various narrators and August's parents. They're all extremely believable, with the one exception of the 15-year-old boy who writes in all lower case and has insight beyond his years. One of the things I like about the variety of voices is that we see how everyone struggles with something (divorce, death of a parent, having less money than peers, etc.). No one has an easy road. We see not only how August is affected by his disability/difference, but also how his family and friends are affected. And I love, love, love how non-one-dimensional his sister and parents are. They're all good people, desperately trying to do their best. Slight spoiler: (The one exception to these round characters is Julian, the bully, who obviously gets his cruelty from his mother, but I think his p.o.v. would have been interesting. Instead, he's just there as a randomly mean kid who seems to have most adults fooled, and who conveniently disappears at the end.) 
 I also love, love, love the structure of this novel. Each narrator retells some of the previous events from his/her own perspective and then moves forward in the chain of events. I am a huge sucker for books with interesting structure. 
 As for the plot: Yes, things end a little too conveniently. It's all a little "After School Special." Yes, August's role as a sort of mascot ("little dude") for his classmates feels condescending . August is a character I'd like to see revisited as a high school student, to see how his life and role in his school have changed. But this is a book that I want my kids to read when they're in 5th grade. It has so much to say about being different, standing up for what you think is right, and, above all, kindness.

Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world. -August Pullman 
 No words can describe how happy I am upon finishing this book. One of the best books I've read this year and I just want to hug Auggie so tight! 
 Auggie was born with a facial abnormality and for that, he often get bullied. I'm sure some of us might have been in his shoes, but I applaud him for being strong and kind despite all the hostile actions that was thrown at him. 
 This book is written not only in Auggie's own perspective, but also five other perspectives and each of them was a gem. Overall, this was such an excellent read and I got a little bit teary towards the ending. Auggie is a wonder. Truly.
Loved it! Highly recommend for 5th grade and up.
This book is wonderful. Wonder is the kind of book that you can read no matter your age. Honestly with all the bullying in school, if it's not already, it should be part of the curriculum.
storia molto carina, peccato che si concluda con un happy ending poco credibile =(
definitely cried sever all times with this book.
Wonder is a beautiful story of friendship and courage. This book should be required reading for all middle school children and their parents. Truly a wonderful story!

Lo compre por impulso el pasado Sant Jordi y lo acabe en tres dias. Asi que lo primero que debo decir, claramente, es que esta escrito de forma que te enganchas y quieres saber que mas pasa, o mas bien, quien mas cuenta su version de las cosas. La trama es sencilla y sin embargo te lleva de 0 a 10 en pocas paginas. Si, tiene cierto tonito un poco dramaticon y lloroso, pero en general no busca el efecto en el lector, y eso es de agradecer. 
 Un personaje menor si se le compara con otros pequenos como Owen Meany, pero interesante. Acompanado por otros mas que tambien hacen la lectura interesante. Creo que deberia ser de lectura obligatoria para ninos de 10+

A wonderful book! 
 I believe everyone must read it in the hopes of making this world a kinder place. Reading August's perspective helps to realise how blessed we are and how we take most things for granted. 
 Don't consider this a book for kids, it's for everyone!

Captivating, raw, thought-provoking, uplifting, and insightful. This kiddo Auggie brought me into a whole heart-wrenching, tear-jerking/tear-drowning, touching lot of package of read. You know that feeling when you just want to hug the protagonist as well as the book not because of how fascinating he is or it is but just how good you felt about them both. Entirely an upbeat life story that'll make the readers cry and can change them as well. Very inspiring!!! 
 Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world.-Auggie 
 Like everyone in the world experienced being stabbed, criticized and bullied in the face or at the back. But Auggie's precept made him the most invincible above everyone else around him. He doesn't mind what people are saying behind his back, but instead that gave him the courage to push in life and pursue what he dreamed of in spite of his disability. You know, 'coz he believe in himself and he's not a lame quitter. And at the end, everyone around him gave him a whole heartedly standing ovation. And he truly deserve it! That inspired everyone in the world (even me) because of this brave kiddo named Auggie. 
 Two thumbs up for this book! Really, a good book!
Oh my goodness me. I'm stunned.

Brilliant first novel about the importance of kindness. You don't have to read much about this book to know what it's about, but I was surprised at how laugh-out-loud funny it is. Sure, there are sad parts and scary parts, and my heart goes out to Auggie and Via and their parents, but I laughed out loud dozens of times. I think one of the great strengths of Wonder is that it is told from several points of view. I loved getting inside the heads of all these terrific kids and hearing what they learn over the course of the school year. 
 Not that I pay much attention, but this would be my pick for the Newbery.

I been meaning to read this book for so long but can't get around it and now I finally has time to read it. This is one of those books that I read that I can't seem to put down. It was really captivating and heartwarming. It was beautiful written considering it was a perspective of different age, Ague and his new friends, his sister and her friends too. 
 No matter how old are you, be a kid or an adult, people can be just cruel with or without meaning to.
When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind. -R.J Palacio, Wonder
A lovely feel-good book that redeems your faith in the goodness of mankind. Made me tear up a few times too.

I heard about this on NPR sometime back, but my son was given it to read as part of an anti-bullying group he is involved with at school. I picked it up out of curiosity and so glad I did. The importance of kindness is a big theme throughout this book and the courage that it takes to be kind sometimes. Auggie's story is told through several different voices and I would have liked to hear more from his sister. Jack Will's voice seemed very true to life as a 5th grade boy struggling between being cool and doing what he feels is right in his heart. Very touching and tender story, highly recommended.
Like a friend of mine said, this is a book to put away and share with your kids when they're old enough. A real joy to read. Be kinder than is necessary.
So moving and wonderful - recommended to anyone that wants a feel good story. It might be YA, but anyone can appreciate its message. So great!

This book was wonder... ful. It was beautifully written. I don't have any complaints. As a teacher I can see how invaluable this would be in the classroom. 
 I especially liked the principal's speech at the end about kindness. <3
Fabulous story!
