An excellent book. Not your typical new kid to the school book either. Auggie has had multiple surgeries to correct a facial abnormality that he was born with, but he still does not look normal. Going to the school for the first time in fifth grade is not easy for anyone let alone Auggie. R. J. Palacio crafts an exceptionally written novel that stands out for the quality of the writing and the emotions the kids struggle with as they go through their fifth grade year.

I had student come to me this year and state that this was a book I had to read. Seeing that passion in a young reader makes it worth trying. 
 This is a book every student ready to transition to a new building should be read or read. I love seeing many different views of the same events. This is a good story for teachers to read to see that everything in life is not black and white and you can change your views of life over time. 
 I would recommend this book over and over again.

Such a powerful and beautiful story that kept taking me to unexpected places. I loved the alternating POVs and the fully realized characters that populated this book. WONDER is a true joy to read and behold.

I admit that I was a little slow to pick this book up despite all the good things I heard about it, but once I did, I had a hard time putting it down. A friend of mind told me this book changed her fourth grade students and now I understand. I look forward to reading it to my kids. It's the sort of book that changes you for the better, but doesn't pour on the guilt or the suffering. It's definitely one of my favorites this year. 
 Content: completely clean
Precious and wonderful. Lots of good quotes and material for discussion.
If I could give this book 10 stars I would!! I loved it! My new favorite. I recommend it to everyone!

I loved everything about this book. The story drew me in immediately, I was held captive the whole time I was reading it, and even after I read the last page, it stayed with me for several days, in the back of my mind, mulling over all my feelings about it. 
 The story of Auggie surviving and thriving his first year of Public School in 5th Grade is told through the narration of different characters in the book. 
 Two of my favorite things about this book is the friendships Auggie is a part of at the school, and Mr. Brown's precepts. 
 And I love that the author wrote this story after having a bad experience with one of her children encountering a child who looked different. She wished she had handled it differently, and thus this story was born. 
 I also really love this quote - WHEN GIVEN THE CHOICE BETWEEN BEING 
 RIGHT OR BEING KIND, CHOOSE KIND. 
 That just about sums up one of the great secrets of life, doesn't it? 
 I recommend this book to everyone I know who loves to read. Old, young, male, female. I think there is something for everyone in this book.

K, So I like read this in one day. I love multiple characters, and the way Palacio didn't shy away from the complexities of family life. It was a nice balanced read. Not to heavy handed with horrible circumstances, and not chock full of formulaic elements. I really liked the whole cast of characters.

I really enjoyed this book. August is a ten year old child who has facial abnormalities, and is beginning his first year at school. 
 I liked the style that this book was written, and I liked the POV format. I liked August's humour, and his Star Wars obsession. 
 But it has been only 3 days since I turned the last page, and for me, Wonder wasn't particularly memorable. Still, I really enjoyed this novel.

This book may be written with a middle schooler in mind but it's a beautiful read for anyone; any age. In the busyness of growing up - we need books like this to remind us of what truly matters. We speak often of how kids can be cruel, well this book reminds us so can most adults. And yet, it's the sense of goodness and kindness that's inherent in most people that this book reminds you. Always be more kind than you need to be. That's one of the lines that I'll remember from this book. 
 This book ranks right up there with Sherman Alexie's 'The absolutely true diary of a part time Indian' for me.

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world." --Auggie 
 Wonder is a book where you cry in the corner and question yourself why the world is so cruel and why life has to be so unfair. I never cried so hard - literally sobbing in a book, that I actually put down it in a minute to grab my emotions because I can't read when my tears just keep on flowing - I thought my tear ducts has been severely damaged by this book. 
 If I could give 10 more stars for how amazing this book is. Hands down! 
 I wanted to kick myself for not knowing about this book for so long that I just read it today. I wanna thank my sister-friend for sharing this to me because my life has been not the same after reading this. I know that I have tons of favorite books, but I can say this is my second to the list. I love the writing style, how I got to connect with every characters in the book, how this is the first time I've read a 10 year old boy's point of view, and how every chapter in the book is like a "life changing" feeling for me. It was really written beautifully. 
 "She's very pretty," Mom said. 
 "Yeah, I know," I answered. "We're kind of like Beauty and the Beast." 
 (This really made me cry harder. I dunno why but I'm just hurt of what he said in this part.) 
 ******************* 
 The best part of why I love this book so much is because I didn't read the plot and just go in my gut that maybe this will be good, but I was so wrong. It's not just good or fine because once I started it, I CANT PUT IT DOWN. That's how amazing this story is. Beyond amazing! 
 A wonderful boy "Auggie Pullman" - who had change so many lives because of his compassion, loyalty, unconditional love and kindness. His pure heart and witty mouth. His sense of humor and his ability to be extraordinary, when all he wants is to be ordinary. He is not just extraordinary, but I think he's blessed. Blessed with bravery and courage. I'm in awe for him. 
 "That's why your deeds are like your monuments. Built with memories instead of with stone." 
 A book about Kindness. Friendship. Courage. Character. 
 ******************* 
 I also can't help but relate August Pullman to Bailey Sheen from Amy Harmon's "Making Faces". They are so alike in many many ways. I wish ya'll could read that book because it's truly inspiring too. "Making Faces", is actually my number one in my favorites of all time so you know how special this book is because this is my second favorite. ;-) 
 Anyway, I can't help but cry again while doing this review. I know I'm very emotional but this book just really punched me in the gut so many times because I have a loving nephew who has Down Syndrome. 
 It's pure perfection.
My young students love this book. A bit of a tearjerker, but not heavy handed. And the writing is good.

Great book! Carries this theme I've been thinking alot aobut lately, the power of kindness. Agree with Owen's teacher that he should wait until he's in 5th grade to read it. Will have more power and understanding for the book. Henry loved it and recommend it to all pre-teens and adults.

Couldn't love this book more! Love the way the book is set up to give different view point from the main characters. Favorite quote was "shall we make a new rule of life......always to try to be a little kinder than necessary?" My other favorite one was "Courage, kindness, friendship, character. These are the qualities that define us as human beings, and propel us, on occasion, to greatness."'
My niece just finished reading this in school, and recommended it to me. Great book. Millions of opportunities for teachers to get a classroom discussion going.
Amazing <3

I can hardly wait to recommend this title to my students. I loved the way that the alternating points of view helped me to understand and appreciate each character more deeply. With each new section, I found that I had a new favorite character!
Still love it!
This book is for everyone for everyone "overcometh the world."
A lovely, funny, honest, smart book about a 5th-grade boy who suffers from severe facial deformities going to school for the first time.

One of the best YA books I've read in ages. Brilliant for a debut novel - I hope she writes more! I loved the mix of contemporary culture with snippets of classic wisdom whether from books Auggie reads or Mr. Browne's precepts, etc. This book made me think of (and alludes directly to) Elephant Man, but has a victorious joyful ending where you are almost jealous of Auggie. The device of having the story told from multiple characters' point-of-view is powerful and made me realize more deeply that every one has their own struggles and very real feelings. The theme of kindness shines brightly throughout the novel but especially at the climax and end. My precept for Mr. Browne: "It's nice to be important but it's more important to be nice."

Actual Rating: 4.5 
 Lovely book, giving us insight into the life and struggles of not only the innocent people in this world that don't look "normal" but also their families, and their friends. 
 I was honestly expecting it to have a horrible ending, with something happening to Auggie to stop him from going to school or something that was a terrible act on the part of another human being, but all this book really showed me was the strength of human nature. Bravery, kindness, courage, friendship. 
 It occurs to the reader that even though Auggie didn't look like everyone else, he was probably the most well rounded child because he hasn't allowed his looks to influence his personality, like many of us do. All of the time he was just him an by being himself he was the most relatable and touching person. 
 It was really a beautiful read, highly recommended.
This is one of those books that everyone should read, a feel good story. What is your precept?

This is one of the best children's books that I have read in awhile (Thanks Betsy Farquhar) August is a child with severe facial deformities attending school for the first time in the fifth grade. 
 I love how the author tells the story through August and the other children who come to care about him. 
 I would also recommend Out of Mind by Sharon Draper for a story told from the perpective of a severly handicapped but spirited and intelligent child.
An amazing read.

THIS IS A MUST HAVE AND MUST READ BOOK. 
 I could read this over and over again. This isn't an ordinary middle schooler story but its an extraordinary one. I thought this would be a one perspective book but woah! <3 <3 <3 Really love this one. Auggie is such a wonderful person.
A good book to read with my daughter and to discuss many issues with her

I believe "Wonder" should be mandatory reading for 5th, 6th, and 7th graders. It is a wonderful book that has certainly changed my life by reading it, and I will recommend it to everyone I know. (And it is the author's first novel? Wow.)
Wow. Wow wow wow.

This was an unbelievably touching story. You will love Auggie and his friends and family! They are totally human on every level. The only criticism I would give this is that I think Auggie and his friends are written a little too maturely for their fifth grade ages, no matter what they have been through. At the end of the day, a fifth grader is still a kid and not an almost-adult in a kid's body. But that is a minor difference. I enjoyed every moment and was rooting for Auggie's success in the world all the way! Don't miss this gem...
Wonderful

What a wonderful, special, perfect book to start my year off (and to finally, finally have read!). 
 Always choose to be kind and make the effort to understand yourself and others, in any experience.
made me smile

What a story! I read the whole thing in one sitting, turning the final page in the wee hours of the morning. The journey of August Pullman has earned its place as one of my all time favorite books. Although this is technically a children's book, I highly recommend Wonder for anyone with a heart.
Wow, well that was an emotional roller coaster! Seriously, such an amazing story! I really think its one that everyone should try!

I have a favorite quote from Plato... "Be kind, for everyone is fighting a hard battle." That is at the heart of this book. I think this is a very special book. This is wonderful Young Adult book - but a person of any age would find this book inspiring. I enjoyed that the book showed the perspectives of many people not just of the main character, August. I would have liked to hear the perspective of Julian. I, like other reviewers, found some things too perfect. August's parents and the principal are big examples. I struggled between 3 and 4 stars - I gave it 4, not because it is such great literature - but because it is just that good a story.

Really heartwarming. After I finished it I had the urge to hug everyone around me (especially my dog ;( ). Also the end was a little bit too much, but hey, it's a children's book, so I forgave. 
 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cYMCL...

This was so sweet and sad and beautiful and I just loved it so much. 
 (I'm so excited for the movie, too -- even if I have to look at Owen Wilson's nose to get through it.)
Wow! This is my new all time favorite book! So powerful! It makes me proud to be a teacher.

this book is amazing. it left a smile on my face, it gave tears in my eyes. it has lots of messages, but the one that stuck with me most is kindness. 
 when given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind - Dr. Wayne W.Dyer 
 this story is about the struggling of a fifth grader, with an extraordinary appearance. now, i said it is extraordinary because i cannot even picture actually how August looks like. and i'm afraid that if i see a person like him somewhere, i'm afraid that i will give him the stare that everyone gave. because that would make me a bad person. 
 i love August's family. they are so supportive to each other. they fight, of course, but they know that all would be well the next day. 
 and August, i think, although he's only in a fifth grader, but i think he has a very sincere heart, a traits that we rarely seen on such a young age. (judging by how most of his friends been treating him, i'm gonna hold to this opinion). 
 and i love how the author wrote a character like Summer and Jack, quoting his mom; 
 'there are more good people on this earth than bad people, and the good people watch out for each other and take care of each other.' 
 i totally recommend this book to all. i wish there's a sequel for this. i am curious about August's life. his college life, his work, his married life. and i hope that Jack will end up with Summer. and Via will marry his boyfriend Justin and Miranda will find someone better for her.

This book was so amazing! It has so many lessons junior high students should learn before they go to junior high. August Pullman was born with a disfigured face. It was so disfigured that people would jump back if they unexpectedly saw him, or even if they had been prepared ahead of time. He hated his face, but he had such a supportive family that he learned how to deal with the hardships in his life. After having multiple surgeries over the years his parents finally decided to send him to 5th grade after being home schooled all those years. I loved the character development throughout the book. I loved all the people he met; the nice ones and the mean ones. The story was told through each character throughout the book, so it was interesting to hear what each of them were thinking. It taught love, patience, understanding, compassion, being kind, and many more ideals. A must read for young adults and is an inspiring read for adults.

Since I am someone with a sizable facial birthmark I could totally relate to Auggie. I wish this book was around when I was a child because it may have helped me process through the struggle of having kids pick on me because I looked different. This book is very well written and definitely is inspiring. A great read! I have already loaned it to a student who told me it would be a while before I got it back because he had a friend that wanted to read it as well.
Overall, it was really great! Although, some of the writing used was a little mature for the ages of some of the characters. I think I would've enjoyed this more if I was younger.

A very worthwhile read. This story about a boy with a facial deformity was somewhat predictable, but it still warmed my heart and brought tears to my eyes. Seeing the various perspectives made this a particularly compelling story. My only complaint was that the students were in 5th grade, but it seemed like they were in 7th, maybe 6th grade--would have been much more believable. But regardless, a thoughtful story that would be good for any child or teen to read.

This book really exceeded my expectations. Like all of my other 5-star reviews, it was well-written, had a good story, and made me Love it so much I want to buy copies to put in the hands of like-minded readers. 
 After reading the description I very much expected a somewhat saccharine tale of a boy with a facial deformity experiencing all the cruelty of middle grade life plus some with an ultimately uplifting climax in which he finds one special friend of something wonderful happens to show he is indeed extra special, deep down. Instead, Palacio begins with the premise that August Pullman is, in fact, a normal boy with an extraordinary face and maintains this throughout. He has many of the weaknesses one might expect from a child that has experienced others' reactions to his features and a lifetime of being the center of his family's attentions-he is sometimes expects the worst from people and is occasionally a bit self-centered-but he also has a lot of strength and maturity befitting a 10-year old boy who has had to deal with a lot, and is still learning how to do so. 
 The story is told from a number of different viewpoints-not all characters central to the storyline, such as August's sister's boyfriend. Middle School Drama is portrayed in all of its superficial and childish glory, and adults-instead of serving as 2-dimensional heroes and villains-are as varied as the kids. Throughout this very eventful year in Auggie's life, all of the drama and uplift is realistic and well-motivated, characters are developed throughout the story, and by the end Auggie has grown up just as much as you'd expect-and no more. He is still a normal boy with an extraordinary face.

I'm not a huge book crier. But I cried twice while reading WONDER. It's the kind of book every kid and parent and human-being-in-general needs to read. The language is simple and beautiful, and the story is, simply put, a wonder.

What a wonderful book about a boy with a deformed face. The writing is perfect and I actually reminds me of A Visit From the Goon Squad for junior high school students in its alternating perspectives and text message chapters. Highly recommended for anyone of any age. Although there is a Hallmark-style ending. This would usually bother me, because the endings seal a certain impression on the reader, but I didn't mind. The rest of the book more than made up for the ending.
Cried on every other page for the first half of this book. A sweet, simple and insightful book.
A must read for everyone! Seriously! Read this book!! Have your children, grandchildren read this book! It's fantastic in every sense of the word! LOVE
I loved this book, I couldn't put it down, it was wonderful. I definitely recommend it.

"If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary--the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God." 
 This is the book I needed to read right now. 
 Be kinder.

I loved this book! While I don't necessarily think it is a literature classic, it will have a valued place on my bookshelves. The characters are lovely, real people, struggling with human issues and the desire to live on a higher plane and choose kindness. I can't wait until my children are old enough to read and discuss this together.

I started to love this book at the end of the first chapter when Auggie says, "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." 
 And then I got to the first POV change, where we start to see things from Auggie's sister Via's perspective. Wow! I didn't see another narrator coming and it kind of blew me away that this book wasn't going to be just Auggie's story. 
 Though our hero is in a very dramatic situation, nothing felt overblown or exaggerated. In fact, the quietness, the everday-ness of the story is really what makes it stand out. I was, at some middle point in the book, describing it to the people as "The Elephant Man for kids" but it's really more of an everyday life story about a community that is given the opportunity to grow.

I'm seriously a very insecure person. Looking at the mirror and can't stop talking about how ugly and fat I am, babbling about all these gibberish things girls talk about all the time: wrong hair color, pants always 2 sizes too small. This read made me realize what a hypocrite I've become. I intend to change that. This book made me realize the things I've taken for granted. The smiles I've held, the small talks, the pat in the back to people who deserves it, the kind acts, the little wonders I can do that may or may not change someone else's life. All things considered, I can say, this is one of the best books I've ever read and that R.J. Palacio is now part of my favored authors. 
 This novel is very well-written. It's poignant and just perfect. It's like listening to the characters talk about something and you don't feel like reading, you feel like you're infront of them, listening to them and talking to them. The characters are so alive I actually hear them breath and see them smile. 
 "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 -- R.J. Palacio, Wonder
What a meaningful, well-written book. It's filled with themes appropriate for all ages.
An amazing wonderfully descriptive emotional book with a happy ending too!
Heartwarming story
Of course I cried a few times. Not sure I found it completely believable, but I'm glad it ended the way it did. And when a certain jerk got punched in the nose, I cheered!!
"Shall we make a new rule of life...always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?"

** slight spoilers, ye be warned. ** 
 I'll preface my review with the thought that Wonder is not a YA book. YA readers and adults alike can read and enjoy it, but it's target group is for younger audiences. The main character is in 5th grader and is starting 'Middle School'. Middle school when I was that age was 7th-8th grade, so I wasn't aware that in other parts of the country that middle school starts in 5th grade. 
 Wonder started off easy enough, but it was just a little too perfect. The parents and sister of Auggie, who was born with a facial deformity, behave almost too good. Auggie is too well adjusted for having a deformity and numerous surgeries that have left him scarred and frightening looking. I'm not saying it was unbelievable, but it was just a little too Pollyanna for me. 
 But about 1/3 of the way in, the ball drops. Not really drops...it's more like a jump ball, and everyone is fighting and jumping to grab a hold of it again. The sweetness is gone and now it's just a fight to stay above surface. Friends and family are scrambling to make sense of it all. It's a masterful reversal leading into the second act. 
 I'm finding it hard to put into words how much I liked this story. 
 It's a sweet but at times brutally honest depiction of how classmates, adults, siblings, teachers and the physically deformed themselves deal with someone who is by all accounts grotesque. 
 Grotesque, yet not so in his spirit,behavior character or personality. I think the author purposefully had Auggie act and react to difficult situations in a positive way. He never lashed out or flipped tables over or reacted negatively toward the bullies. Yet, the bully problem took care of itself. 
 I'm not saying this ever happens in real life. But we honestly don't need another book dealing with bullies in a reactionary way, with vengeance and punishment meted out. But inwardly and theoretically, this is a perfect way for bullying to stop, with everyone coming to the conclusion that the kid is a jerk, the victim is a hero, and we all have a big party at the end. 
 I KNOW it's not realistic. But dammit, I like a happy ending. Who says books need to ALWAYS BE BRUTALLY HONEST in every single detail? 
 "Kinder than is necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed." 
 -- R.J. Palacio, Wonder
Its like an episode of WOnder Years in book form. Such a sweet funny story. This made me want to get up and cheer at the end of the book.

August, the hero of our book is a boy who has a genetic disorder that made his face come out wrong. There's no way to say this pc, so we're just going go skip saying it. 
 This book takes the POV of several characters that relate to August and talk about their relationships with August. 
 I think the story that stands out the most, is Via, August's older sister, who has always been pushed to the side because August has always needed to come first. Via, who has just entered high school, has to deal with her own problems, loss of friends, a new boyfriend, shame of her brother, etc. 
 August is a boy who is easily bullied. I think this book shows a lot at how August could have gone the other way, to hit back and let the hatred of others rule him. But he rose above that. He's still insecure with who he is, but August is fundamentally a boy who tries to do the right thing. 
 Jack Will. I think honestly, even though August was the one that had to deal with all these problems, Justin, Via's boyfriend was right. August has the perfect family, the best friends anyone could ask for, and a wonderful home. Jack is a kid who knows he doesn't always do things right, but tries anyway. And it's much easier to like him because he failed yet got up anyway. 
 This is such a feel good book, I got so caught up reading it and I am aware that this is a poor review and I would love write more, but I honestly can't say anything else. 
 Indication of a good book. when you can't be bothered to write quotes down. 
 What it means to be a honest, good person. And Happy Halloween.

A strong first novel told in distinct voices. The unusual topic and intricate look at middle school politics forces middle grade readers to hold a mirror up to their character and see if they are part of the problem or part of the solution. A few parts are a bit treacly for this adult reader, especially the heart-warming speech by the school director at the end, but it will leave kids with something to chew on. As soon as I finished it, I promptly started reading it aloud to my 5th graders. And even if we don't finish, the short episodic chapters allow me to pick a good place to stop, and will ensure that this will probably be their first choice for summer reading!

This was a great book! I have to admit I knew about the book for the past year or so but wasn't all that interested in it. But as many books I have read for the past two years, I gave it go since the entire 3rd and 4th Grades were going crazy about it. So I took it home and and read it in about 2 days and wow was it good. 
 It's an easy read about a though subject and it is a great way to show kids what you can do about bullying and how you can be more inclusive with other kids. 
 *SPOILER ALERT!* 
 I gave it 4 stars cause I have to admit I was hoping Jack with get the prize at the end. I think Auggie was a bit full of himself at times and Jack, even though he had said some nasty things in the past, handle situations better afterwards. Jack also continue been friends with Auggie even when he was been bullied.
How did it take me so long to read this book? It is poignant and startling and so very sweet.

Another MUST read book for students, teachers, and pretty much every other human being on the planet. What a great reminder of the importance of kindness and compassion in our every day interactions. This book has given me a better understanding of the type of teacher and person that I want to be. Although it is profound, it is also profoundly funny and extremely entertaining. I can't think of anyone who wouldn't enjoy it. I listened to a lot of this book on audiobook and the voice actors did an amazing job bringing all of these characters to life. 
 Auggie Pullman has never gone to school. Although his mother is convinced that he should attend Beecher Prep for the fifth grade, Auggie... not so much. He doesn't look like most of the other kids, his genetic conditions and countless surgeries have left him with a unique face, and August knows that middle school kids aren't always the nicest. Even though going to school terrifies August, he enters the fifth grade excited to learn and unaware that throughout the year, he will be teaching the students at Beecher Prep some of the most important lessons they will ever learn.

I was in tears from the first paragraph on. Luckily at least half of those tears were shed in joy. This book is absolutely beautiful. 
 The author masters the different perspectives with incredible honesty. 
 A must-read. 
 Choose kind.

This book would have to be one of my favourite reads for 2012. The author developed such a loveable main character that your heart went out to him and you admired his pluckiness. The story line gave you an opportunity to see what it felt like to be young person with such a hideous deformity. He has the unenviable task of fitting into a school system and being judged by what he looks like not by who he is. However by the end of the story, like the characters in the story, you forgot about the young boy's facial deformity too.
This book should be required reading for all middle grade teachers. I love it and it will become a signature read aloud!

This is such a beautifully written story. I was crying and laughing the whole time, Auggie is such a beautiful character and Palacio did a great job telling his story. I love how realistic this book was, Palacio did not cringe from anything she told a story that will touch people's hearts forever.
I really enjoyed this book and think it is a good one to use when trying to teach about tolerance and bullying :)
DON'T MISS THIS ONE!! --In depth review coming--

Wonder by R.J Palacio 
 This book was wonderful. I loved the characters. I felt like August was amazing! 
 I loved the writing style and how the story was often told from different points of view. To keep this review short and sweet, I give it give stars!

This is one of the best stories I have read. It's a story filled with alllllll of the feels. I laughed, I cried, I didn't want to put it down and when I finished it I wanted to stand on the street corner and hand it out to everyone passing by. I would recommend this book to anyone and everyone. 
 Auggie is one of the sweetest characters I have ever had the pleasure of reading about. What an incredibly strong, real and inspiring guy. I spent the whole book wanting to reach in and hug the kid. I also enjoyed each of the other characters - they all had flaws and it made the story that much more real to me. 
 I loved what Palacio did with giving multiple perspectives of the story. I feel like it made the characters that much more dynamic and real. There was a friendliness to this story that envelops you in. A story that teaches and loves you at the same time. 
 This novel was incredibly realistic. From the characters to the story, this is easily a story that I could see being played out in various different schools with different, but very similar situations. This is a book that I would love to see read and discussed in schools. 
 I hope you guys pick up and read this one - and most of all I hope you love it. I hope you laugh, shed a tear, and hug someone after you finish the book.
Heart-gripping. Heart-twisting. Heart-breaking, but healing also. Definitely check this book out.

Read my review of 
 Wonder

This was such a joy to read. It tugged at my heart strings as a parent but it also demonstrated a strength I hope my own children will have one day. I loved the different POV as it added depth to the main character August. It should be a must on all 12+ list to read!

Such a heartwarming story - and fantastic on audio! Auggie Pullman is an awesome kid who has dealt with severe facial abnormalities all his life. The book opens with him beginning the fifth grade and attending public school for the first time, which is quite an adjustment for both Auggie and his classmates. 
 This was totally a five star until it got kind of all "let's sum this up in the corniest, preachiest way possible" at the end.

This was recommended to me by Steed - my close friend's 5th grader (he and I are book nerds:-) - and I absolutely loved it! I think this should be on every elementary school list as a required read. Pick it up and read it...then make sure your kids read it too!

I loved this book!!it taught me a lot about ow you might have tough times in life. Also about you should always think about what you do before you do it! This book was an awesome book! I think everybody should read it! It teaches you a lot!!

I really enjoyed this book. Loved the triumph over trial message and the goodness of most of the people in the book. I listened to it and really enjoyed listening to all the kindness quotes at the end of the book. I hope that I can teach my children to be kind to those who need a friend!

Auggie has never been to school, instead he's been homeschooled his entire life. It made it easier to work his schedule around his many surgeries for his facial anomaly. Auggie was born looking differently than the rest of the world due to several genetic abnormalities coming together in one moment, something that only has a one in 4 million chance to happen. But it happened to Auggie, and now he is getting ready to start 5th grade in a private school. Auggie knows that he is just a regular kid hidden behind an uncommon face, but the question is whether his classmates will ever figure that out. 
 Read the rest of my review on my blog, Waking Brain Cells.

This is a good "teaching" book. If I were a middle-school teacher, I would definitely teach this book in class. It offers an excellent opportunity for discussion of such topics as disability and difference and bullying. This book is a more effective way of teaching children about these topics than having a guest speaker or lecture, since through this book children can really get in the head of the main character (who is bullied because of his different-looking face), and thus feel empathy towards him. They can see how bullying effects someone and also what it is like to live as "different". The multiple points of view offered in this book also offered perspectives of people who are family members of or friends with a "different" person (the main character) and how they are affected as well. This book was below my reading level (and naturally so; I'm sure the intended audience is probably middle-schoolers), but I can still appreciate it because it involves such an important topic, and it is executed in a way that children will be receptive to.
Wonder-ful!

Oh, you guys. This book was fine, but it was like, Everything A Children's Books Should Be According to Sensitive, Well-Meaning Grown-ups. 
 There were the Life Lessons and the Other Sides of the Story and the Progressive Liberal Parents and the English Teacher Who Teaches You To Be Human... maybe I am a cold-hearted reader, spoiled on grad school and cynical to everything of emotional resonance, but I just really can't take that kind of story seriously. 
 It all just seemed too predictable, too stacked up, all leading up to the ENDING - an overblown graduation ceremony... from the fifth grade. I just can't jump on the bandwagon.
Fantastic book!!

This book has so much heart! I had heard nothing but across-the-board praise for it, and the story was familiar to me, so I decided to pick it up. 
 Auggie doesn't just look different from most kids, but he looks different enough to expect the double-take that kids and adults have done since he was born. Other than his severe facial deformities, he is a pretty normal, happy kid with a loving family and a few good friends. 
 Life changes dramatically when his family decides to stop home schooling him and send him to a middle school for the first time. He deals with bullies and friends and tries to navigate his first year in school. 
 This book is told from multiple points of view - from Auggie, his sister, her friends, his friends and a variety of people. Each voice is unique and honest. I would recommend this to anyone, but especially to kids in middle school, as it is an excellent way to help teach empathy.

I loved Wonder. I lost track of the number of times I was in tears reading Wonder, both sad and happy tears. I'm actually tearing up while writing this review. The different narrators provided a look at all of the perspectives on difference. I was particularly touched by the Via chapters, it was refreshing to see the sibling of a child with extraordinary medical needs portrayed as mostly selfless but a little bit selfish and sad. Mostly, I just loved Auggie, and his complete...averageness. Wonder is a book I will come back to for another read, and it will definitely stick with me.

I'll be darned if I wasn't wiping away tears when I reached the last page. This book didn't shy away from the brutality that is the middle schooler. When Auggie goes to Beecher Prep "like a lamb to the slaughter," you cringe along with his parents, because you know the worst is going to happen to him--and it does. But there are angels looking out for Auggie, too, "the universe taking care of its own." I was especially moved by the tender, frustrating, exhausting, overwhelming, beautiful nature of the relationships between Auggie and his family members. August Pullman is a character who will stay with me for a long, long time.

Oh my goodness, how I loved this novel, as did my nine year old daughter. Inspired by a girl the author saw, Wonder tells the story of Auggie Pullman who was born with severe facial defects and is attending school for the first time in fifth grade. I loved everything about this: Auggie, his sister, his parents, the fact we get multiple peoples' viewpoints, the other kids, the realism of schoolyard dynamics. Needless to say I was sobbing like a baby at the end. I wish my own daughter could attend fifth grade next year with Auggie and his classmates. Also, it's so, so, so nice to read a book where the parents are so wonderful - and have such a great relationship with the kids and each other while still being flawed. Must-read book (and read in one sitting).

If it wasn't for my book club, I would have never picked up this book. Good book that I gobbled up in one, delicious gulp. Couldn't put it down at bed time!! I enjoyed seeing the story from different points of view and was amazed at how resilient August was in the story with all his challenges. I also appreciated seeing the story of the Halloween costume from August's point of view and from Jack's too - what a common misunderstanding among kids this age!! One kid saying something to fit in and then another hearing and misunderstanding! I hated Julian and his mother for being so narrow-minded and prejudiced against August - I was so glad when August won over the other kids and Julian was the one without friends!! It was also interesting to read August being worried about getting hearing aids and then realizing it was not a big deal after all - another lesson typical in real life too! Giving this book to my fifth grader to read now to hopefully get her thinking about compassion and learning that there are many different sides to a story!!
4.5 stars. A really beautiful and uplifting book. Great middle school stories. Definitely something I want my children to read, but a great book for adults too!

wonderful book for all ages. I especially think anyone in middle school should read it. It has changed my perception and how I may judge others. great book brought me to tears at the end unfortunately I was on a airplane when i finished it and the people around me probably wondered why I was sobbing.
Loved this so much!

Auggie is born with a deformed face. He has been home schooled his whole life but now he is going to attend 5th grade at Beecher school. Mr. Tushman has invited Auggie to tour the school with three students during the summer. Jack, Charlotte and Julian are surprised by Auggie's face but show him the school, only Julian asks an inappropriate question. The book continues with Auggie's school year told from the different points on view of the book's characters.

Can't wait to watch the movie. 
 mn 'jml qrt lsn@ bl shk.

I really enjoyed this book. I had heard so many people say that they cried through this book that after I picked it up from the library, it sat in my bag for a week before I felt emotionally prepared to cry through a book. 
 Surprisingly, I didn't cry. I can see why some people do, but for me this book had so much hope and triumph in it that I didn't find it sad at all. Sure hard lessons are learned, and the kids can be mean in the book but still most every character in the book grows and triumphs over the obstacles. 
 I actually think this book has moved to the top of my newbury contenders list. The reason is not because I feel it is a better story than the other two that I have at the top of my list but because it is such a new and different topic. 
 So many books that have won the award are about either the civil rights era or coming of age stories. Although this is sort of a coming of age story it is about someone with a face deformity. I haven't seen a book like this win so I think it would be great if it did. 
 One other thing I really liked about this book is how many different perspectives the author put in the book. It was great that we were able to see how the different characters grew. I would have loved to have a perspective written from the point of view of the mom, but since this is written for a tweener audience, I understand why that perspective is not included. 
 All in all this was a great book and I highly recommend it!
The world would be a better place if everyone read this book.
A great book. My son had to read it for 7th grade--a good choice for required reading. I think he liked it also--he laughed at the funny parts-that is a good sign for him.
Loved it! Everyone needs to read a book like this.

Ohhhhh you guys! I don't think I can fully express how much I enjoyed this novel. The story centers on August Pullman, a young boy with a face so deformed it's prevented him from going to mainstream school. But Auggie relents to his parents' pleas to attend middle school and what follows is a year-long journey through the school year--one full of trials and tribulations--as told by a cast of characters that includes Auggie along with his sister and classmates. The story will tug at your heart strings as it teaches you a powerful lesson about compassion and friendship. 
 Passages I Want to Remember: "I think there should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." // "Do people look the same when they go to heaven, mommy?" "I don't know. I don't think so." "Then how do people recognize each other?" "I don't know, sweetie. They just feel it. You don't need your eyes to love, right?" 
 Would I Recommend? It's the first book I'll tell people to read when they ask, "What should I read next?" As I was reading Wonder, I found myself thinking back to a Pulitzer Prize-winning feature story I read years ago about a REAL little boy with a facial deformity named Sam. If and when you read Wonder, do yourself a favor and read this article about this kid -- he truly is a real-life Auggie: http://www.pulitzer.org/archives/6449
This was a really heart-warming story about acceptance and how the kindness and courage of those around us can so positively impact our lives. I really enjoyed it.

Emotional manipulation. I don't usually read them. This one, however is going to be Atwood Family Required Reading. My main mantra in our family is to 'be kind'. If I can raise kind boys, I've got it made. I think everyone that has read this book has been inspired to try a little harder to be a little more kind.

Loved the story line. Great book. Only problem that I had with it the characters all act like they are older than the age they claim in the book. It would be more believable if August was a 7th grader and Olivia an 11th grader.
Beautiful. Loved it in the same way I loved Perks of Being a Wallflower. Loved all the voices, all believable and lovable. Loved Auggie the most.

August Pullman is special. He is one in four million; at least that's the odds of someone having the same syndromes that made his face look so different. But Auggie is special in so many other important ways. Surviving numerous facial surgeries and homeschooled until fourth grade, Auggie's courageous adjustment to fifth grade in his first real school is not like other students. Auggie's story is realistically told through his voice and shifts narrators throughout to include his sister Via, friend Miranda, and new school friends: Summer, Jack and Justin. Auggie's story is guaranteed to capture your heart. It might even change your life in a small way; perhaps you may find yourself choosing kindness more often. This amazing children's book should be read by everyone. Sharyn H. / Marathon County Public Library 
 Find this book in our library catalog.

Great book, great main character but my only problem was the end seemed too perfect. But I loved the style of writing, loved the overall message and as a teacher think that a lot of what is described throughout the story could very easily happen in a middle school.
Wonder is one of those books that I'll be rereading again and again for the rest of my life, as it brings me endless amounts of joy, sadness, and well -- wonder.

The second I finished this book, I knew that I HAD TO write a review for it. This book is about a boy named Auggie who has a very rare condtion. He has a deformed face and it hasn't been easy for him to live. Just imagine having a condition like that: everyone stares at you, gets scared of you, makes fun of you, and all those horrible stuff. (Now that I'm thinking about this, this is like my childhood since I had lazy eyes growing up, probably anopther reason why i like this book) For the first time in his life, he's going to a real school, and try to become an "ordinary" 5th grader. We all know how hard it is to start in a new school, but it's harder for him because of his condition. 
 Toward the end, I was crying tears of joy. And when I finished reading it, I was literally hugging this book. It's such a beautiful book, but it also made my heart hurt in some parts (Which makes it even more amazing). It makes you want to reach out and hug the whole world and to tell people how much you love them. It's uplifting and warm. Some of the things I like about this book: people of all ages will equally enjoy this novel. I can give this to my 9-year-old niece and she would love it! I'm a 20 year old and I was crying. The second thing I like about this book is the technique that the author used. This book had 6 POVs. I would normally say that it's too many because sometimes, I don't even enjoy books that are written in two perspectives. BUT, each perspective offered an insight into the main character's beautiful personality in a way that would be impossible to otherwise know. This is also another message I got: a person is more than just a person; in this book, we were given a chance to see what's going on with the six of the character's thoughts and why things ended up that way. Everybody needs to read this so you'll understand what I'm talking about. And to the people who have read it: that last line destroyed all my feels.

Cerita tentang anak yang memiliki keistimewaan sejak dari kandungan yang membuatnya berbeda dari anak-anak lain. Menjadi seseorang yang berbeda itu tidak mudah apalagi di sekolah para abg, anak SMP. Ceritanya ok sih tapi aku agak berkeberatan dengan terlalu banyaknya point of view. Menurutku beberapa terasa tidak perlu dan mengulang sehingga banyak bagian yang aku skip skip saja. Dan mungkin karena si pembaca ini emak-emak, sebenarnya aku penasaran dengan point of view ibu Auggie. Sayang, penulis tidak menyertakannya dan malah menambahkan point of view Justin yang menurutku paling tidak relevan (dan mengapa pula di bagian Justin ini tidak ada huruf kapital? segitunyakah si Justin :D). Ada satu point of view yang lebih relevan tapi tidak disertakan yaitu dari si Daisy, anjing keluarga Auggie, hehe. 
 Setelah membaca Wonder ini, aku membaca Me Before You. Aku lebih sreg dengan permainan point of view dari Jojo Moyes. Tidak berlebihan. Lebih pas. Tidak ada pengulangan yang tidak perlu.

The was a rough book for me. The same day that my son's teacher's letter came home saying it was her favorite book was the day a friend shared a post from the Cleft Palate Association. She was hoping to win a copy. I figured that the universe was telling me to read the book so I ordered it. 
 For anyone reading this who doesn't know me, my son was born with a cleft lip. Craniofacial conditions are sort of near and dear to my heart. I spent years worrying that my son would have problems in school. As of right now he's 8 and has had a couple kids ask him about it but that's it. 
 I read part of this book in the waiting room at his craniofacial appointment - just a coincidence since we only go every other year but it was right after the book arrived. I had to keep stopping. No one wants to cry from a book in a doctor's waiting room :-) There was actually another mom there reading this book too. I almost went over to tell her how pleasant our experience with school has been but decided to just stay with my family. 
 I cried fairly frequently in this book but plenty of the cries were happy cries - relief that so many people are kind. I hope my son continues to have friends who roll with his cleft scar and don't worry about it. I hope my kids are always nice to kids who have more struggles than they have. 
 And now I'm off to drop the book in the lap of my 11-year-old daughter, who could probably use a reminder not only to be kind, but to be thankful that her start of middle school is less scary than August's.

I thought to myself, "I will just read the first couple of chapters of the book and go to bed." That was four hours ago and I am sitting here with tears running down my face and a huge smile. Growing up with a brother with multiple disabilities brought a lot of meaning to me when reading his sister Via's perspective. Being able to read the perspectives of the other characters was amazing. I will definitely be buying this book and recommending it to everyone. What a powerful story about kindness, family, friendship, and how we must overcome those trials in front of us and be the best person we can be.

This is one of those books that I will probably remember for a very long while. I loved how each person was able to help move Auggie's story forward, but in a way that also honoured their own experiences with him. I also really liked how we got to see Auggie grow from a timid young man into a young man who knew his own worth, and how the people around him saw beyond his unusual face to his soul. I loved the themes of being kind and seeing beyond what someone looks like to who they really are. 
 4.5 stars

Maybe the front-runner for the Newbery, this is a fantastic book and I would be happy to see it win. It's not perfect, and I felt like the ending was a bit too perfect and feel-good (unbelievable even), but I still loved it and won't soon forget it.
Every child in 4th or 5th grade should read this. It teaches great character.

Wow. 
 What a WONDER-ful book. Such beautiful writing. R.J. is such an amazing writer: she can change her style so greatly so that the perspective-changing isn't the slightest bit confusing, as is the case with most books. 
 This book make me laugh out loud, and cry, practically at the same time. August is just such a loveable character, and when he's hurt, you hurt with him. 
 I loved Summer and Jack and all of his friends in this book--I also loved the Principal, Mr. Tushman. 
 The ONE PROBLEM I had with this book was Via. 
 Her character seemed to completely change between chapters. In one, she's defending August and standing up for him, and then she's screaming at him to "grow up" and that "things aren't always about you, for once!" and how she was neglected and such, when just a few chapters before she was stating that she understands why August needs more attention and that it never got to her. 
 ...... 
 no. 
 I can deal with mean characters, and stupid characters, and characters where you just KNOW everything is going to go wrong with, but unrealistically written characters? 
 nononononono. 
 no. 
 I'm sorry, but the only thing I liked about her was her boyfriend, Justin. 
 But EVERYTHING other than Via, I adored. This book was so moving and perfect. A must read! I recommend it to those who've read "Out of My Mind."
I finished this book in one sitting, impossible to put down. Warning though - if you are the type who cries when reading a touching story - do not read this in public.

This is a great book, juvenile fiction really, but touches the hearts of everyone. It deals with bullying and kindness and bravery and strength and all beautiful themes that create an exceptional character if instilled in us. My only take on the book is how simplistic is the approach towards dealing with bullying and how everything worked itself out in the end, and that all characters as first person are somehow alike, sharing the same voice. 
 One of my favorite quotes was by Mr. Tushman, "If every single person in this room made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary--the world really would be a better place. And if you do this, if you act just a little kinder than is necessary, someone else, somewhere, someday, may recognize in you, in every single one of you, the face of God."

It made me laugh and cry and want to applaud with the rest. It is a book that reinforces your faith in the basic decency of human beings that we come across sometimes, so surprising and so welcome. Thank you for writing this book R.J Palacio.
Would make a great daily read-aloud for grades 5-8.

This was an incredible read. One chapter could be heart-wrenching, the next chapter laugh out loud funny. Learning that some people can be extremely cruel and others love unconditionally. This is a book everyone can learn from. Every child (and adult) should read this. 
 Above all, we need to be kind to one another.
Simply wonderful. I have no words. EVERYONE should read this book.

Yes, I cried at the end. This book reminds us the importance of kindness and friendship. A valuable lesson to learn and I think the age that this book targets is spot on. Highly recommend for preteen kids.
Loved it! :) A wonderful read for all ages. Can't wait for the movie to come out next year esp when Julia Roberts will be playing Auggie's mum.

I LOVED this book and think that is should be required reading for every middle school aged child. We read this book for a fast and easy read during the summer months. I read the book in one sit down and cried several times. There are so many sad parts of the book and at the same time so many victories in the book. I will make sure that all of my children read this book because I believe it will make them all feel more for others.

I read this book at the recommendation of my media specialist and finished it within 24 hours because once I started, I couldn't put it down. The theme of practicing kindness in conjunction with a touching story and inspiring characters results in a book that makes you want to be a better, kinder person. A must read for any current middle schooler, parent of a middle schooler, teacher of a middle schooler,or former middle schooler.

This is a kind of story which deserves more than a 5-star rating. A story that everyone must encounter reading. If I become a parent, I'll make sure that my kid/s will read this. 
 5 REASONS 
 1) A book that will bring transition in your life. 
 2) Cruelty of the world and the people : vice versa, their WONDER. 
 3) So much with life lessons - Family. Friendship. Love thy mankind. Growing-Up. Kindness. Sympathy & Empathy. 
 4)Style of writing: Narrated on different characters which would make you understand about why people do this and do that, feel this and feel that. It's like, let me quote Atticus of >To kill a mockingbird, his statement clearly explains, "You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view. Until you climb into his skin and walk around it." 
 5) TRULY A BRILLIANT PAGE-TURNER BOOK.
This book reminded me why I love YA. It is a complex story within a simple read. A great reminder to be grateful for what you've got and to be nice to everyone you encounter.
A wonderfully likable main character who triumphs over bullying and insensitivity in a touching though formulaic tale.
Absolutely incredible.

2015: so many good things about this book, friendship, compassion, empathy, fortitude. Worth a re-read every so often. 
 2012:A wonderful book that I could not put it down. Hopeful and inspiring; a must-read!
This story made my heart happy.

Wonder by R.J. Palacio was a tremendously awesome read! This debut novel from start to finish was a success, and deserves all the praise and recognition it receives. I read this novel as a recommendation from a friend and read it in a little over a day. Palacio's writing style is geared towards younger readers. However the message that the novels tells is one that will stick with both young and old. The characters that we meet in the story take us on a journey and transform the reader as the characters themselves discover things about themselves. The main character August (Auggie) Pullman is truly the hero of this novel. He is a character full of heart, patience, love, strength, and courage. Auggie's family and friends undergo transformations and are also heavily effected by Auggie. Palacio uses humor and heart to mold this story and melt your heart. I laughed and cried at the emotional ending. With so many characters to root for in this novel, and all the humanistic levels and lessons that are taught and learned this novel stands out and is again worthy of all the accolades and awards that it will receive. I highly recommend this novel to both readers young and old. It will be one that stays with you forever. TWO THUMBS UP!!
This is my favorite book of the year so far. I wanted to start reading it all over again after I finished the last page. All middle school kids should read this book. It is fabulous!

Picked up the book as a easy, relaxing read on the beach. What I didn't knew is that this story could easily be a lesson of how life truly is. I think these days is difficult being a kid, especially a kid who has problems and has to adapt to a life and a group of childrens that doesn't understand how difficult life can be. 
 This story with August was truly impressive. Made me smile and cry as I went through the pages. Showed me how cruel people can be towards a small child and how they can interpret it and we don't see it. It showed me how he can move past all the hatred and just be truly kind. 
 The friendship betweeb August, Jack and Summer was simply beautiful! 
 It was an amazing and powerful read that made my emotions go on a roller-coaster. I absolutely loved this book! I highly recommend it!

I believe there is a conspiracy between this author and tissue manufacturers. This book is amazing. It's going to be one that sticks with me for a long time. It should be required middle school reading. So many layers. In the span of 300ish pages, I was reading from all of the perspectives of my inner-former middle schooler, former teacher, parent, and sibling selves. While recognizing that there will always be people who suck, it's still beautifully optimistic about human nature. It also serves as a good reminder that everyone is carrying their own loads, and while it doesn't excuse the uglier aspects of human nature, it can explain it and be used to change it.

Wonder, told from the perspective of five different characters, is about August, a boy who enters middle school after being home schooled for his whole life because of medical issues and a severe facial deformity. The thought processes of the characters, and the different ways they deal with August's disability (or don't deal with it) is very real and heartbreaking at times. As a middle-school teacher who sees peer pressure and the cost of non-conformity (for whatever reason) up close every day, the book felt very real to me. Wonder will definitely be a must-read for the middle school population. It's also a contender for the Nevada Young Reader award this year.
" The universe takes care of all its birds. "

My children wanted to rate this book with me and insisted we give it 5 stars. My two sons (ages 10 & 15) both enjoyed the novel. It also held my 8 year old daughter's attention. Rarely do we find a book that pleases both genders and appeals to their various ages. They liked the story because it focuses on every day life at school and home, which all three could relate to. 
 August Pullman, the main character, was born with a severe facial deformity. He needed to be homeschooled until he was 10 years old to accommodate all of his surgeries. The novel begins when his parents make the decision to send him to middle school. The story is told from several different perspectives, including August's sister and other children. Readers will empathize with him as he struggles to be accepted and find a sense of belonging. Any child who has ever been bullied or felt excluded will relate to August's experiences. His determination, courage, and sense of humor ultimately help him to succeed. This is a story which stresses the importance of kindness, compassion, and tolerance. It will uplift anyone who reads it.

My 10-year-old and I have been reading this back-and-forth since she started fifth-grade in September. She enjoyed it tremendously, and I thought it was phenomenal. Every adult should real it because many of us missed the important lessons that it teaches when we were in the 5th grade. I want to become a better person because this book reminded me that kindness is the most important trait you can master. Sad, funny, witty and cleaver. Just read it.

"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world "-Auggie 
 My favourite quote from the book dY~SdY~S

This is a fantastic book to read no matter your age. Loved it. I hear it will soon be a movie. 
 I'm looking forward to that. I hope the do the movie right.
"Everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their life because we all overcometh the world. --Auggie's precept."
This book truly touched my heart. A brilliant read.

It's unpopular opinion time. 
 I wanted to love this book, I really did. And honestly, I expected to love this book. Maybe that was the problem, maybe I let this get too hyped in my head and expected more than it was. Maybe it's just that I'm in a weird reading mood. Maybe the audio made me like it less than I would have otherwise, I don't know. All I know is that I didn't love this book like so many others do. 
 This book follows a boy named August who, due to genetics that cannot be controlled, doesn't look like other kids. He's had many surgeries to improve the function of certain portions of his face and head, but he still doesn't look like everyone else. And that makes him odd. To some it even makes him scary. So we follow, through the eyes of six different characters, August's first year in a school with other kids. It's fifth grade (which I guess is middle school in New York) and not everyone is kind. 
 I liked the premise, but I was not a fan of how the story was laid out. It's told in first person from six different perspectives, as I mentioned. Of the six, we probably get the most page time in August's head. Then we have his sister Via, his friends Summer and Jack, and Via's friends Justin and Miranda. And honestly, August was my least favorite perspective of the six. It makes sense to show his insecurities, because everyone is insecure at some point, and looking different and being noticed would obviously be hard for a ten-year-old, but August felt too sorry for himself. And that never seemed to change as the story progressed. There was too much self pity for me to connect with him. From the eyes of the others this wasn't that noticeable and I actually did enjoy his character. Jack was my favorite perspective, I had a lot of fun in his head. 
 Everything in the story is focused on August. And I know that's the point of the book, to show his adjustment to school, the way that people react to him, and to highlight the good and the bad sides of humanity, but it felt too focused on him. This is a personal thing, but for me the story would have been more powerful had it not focused so much on August and instead told a story around him. Obviously the way it's written works for most people, which is great, but for me it lessened the message when it made it seem like everyone was always talking about, thinking about, and worrying about August. 
 And maybe the environment that I grew up in was just very different, but I had a hard time believing that everyone would react the way that people reacted to August. Yes, bullying exists, and yes, I have seen it in action, but it was still hard to picture all of these people, adults and children alike, having to do a double take, unable to hold eye contact with him, refusing to talk to him, and calling him names. Yes, all of those things happen, but the scale seemed very heavily weighted toward that mindset in this story. 
 One of my goodreads friends, I can't recall who at the moment, mentioned in their review that this was too sweet, and I have to say that I agree. It's a good message to teach--not everyone is the same and we shouldn't hate because of those differences. At the same time though, this was a little over-the-top for me. Sometimes things don't go well, sometimes people don't like you, sometimes people are jerks and there is nothing you can do to change that, but you have to learn take it all, the good and the bad. 
 This isn't a horrible book or a bad book, it just didn't work for me. It has a powerful message and I think that it's important to remember to be kind, no matter what. There are some things about us that we can't control, but we can decide how to act. 
 I know this was made into a movie and is being released later this year, and I'm actually interested to see how they adapt it. It seems like some of my personal issues with the style of story telling might be negated in translation to film, so I'm interested to see how the two compare for me.

Eh. I didn't super love this one. And I really really expected too. I do suspect listening to it on audio didn't help. Most of the narrators were great, but I did not care for the voice of August (main character). I'm not sure if it was an adult, reading it in some breathy childlike voice, but I found it grating. Every single sentence was read in this amazed sort of like whisper, which just got tiring after a while. 
 I found the story a bit heavy handed. It's been a long time since I've been a fifth-grader, so it's entirely possible this would be right up their alley, but I don't adore stories that are so terribly obvious as to the message. I LOVE the message (Be kinder than necessary.). But I don't love any story that Tells you what it's about.
Such a great read! Very heartwarming story. I think that this is a must read for anyone especially middle schoolers.

August Pullman is a 10-year old boy that loves Star Wars and playing his X-Box. However he does not love being home schooled. His parents have always home schooled him because they were afraid of the ridicule he would receive from other children due to the facial anomalies he was born with. August was use to people starring and being fearful of being around him, but it did not mean that he had to like their responses. August works very hard to try and fit in to his new school as he enters fifth grade. The principal even assigned him some friends to try and make the transition easier. August soon discovers that things are not always as it seems, and people that seem like your friends can be your worst enemy. It is a very heart touching story of friendship, courage, and determination.

It was cute and heart warming. Got teary eyed at some parts but didn't really blew me away. A very light read, just what i needed. I especially loved the different perspective thingy the author did. I think it was pretty effective. I feel so much for Via and Miranda. If I was able to read this a lot sooner though, I would have given this book 5 stars. This would be a great read for its target audience. It gives lessons about things that are actually important and that kids these days should read about.

"La leccion de August" es un libro que no cuenta una historia extraordinaria, si no que cuenta una historia normal, habla de una vida normal, de un nino que es normal, pero que nacio con una cara completamente distinta a todas las demas. Y eso es lo que lo hace tan especial, que tras leerlo, te das cuenta que no hay nada de raro en sus vidas. 
 Lo que mas he disfrutado de este libro, es, sin duda alguna, la forma que tiene el autor de narrar desde los distintos puntos de vista de la gente que rodea al pequeno August y del suyo propio. Porque todas las pequenas cosas que ocurren no solo le afectan a el, si no que tambien son parte de las vidas de la gente cercana a el, que hacen propios sus problemas y dolor. 
 Este libro es una oda a la amabilidad del ser humano con todas sus posibilidades, y a la fuerza del caracter, sin dejar de recordarnos que todos somos humanos.
Loved how the story was told through several characters...all very real. Find the message of kindness to be SO important for middle schoolers!
The book was wonderful in all the sense. I loved the simplicity but also the profound message it gave away.. A must read for children and adults who are still children at heart.
It was such a sweet book and a great book to teach everyone even adults about kindness. You can only hope as a parent you raise your children to be as kind as august and his friends. Wonderful story!

Is it wrong of me to have a love hate relationship with this book. To be honest even though the story centers around Auggie what I loved most were the multiple POVs. Which were amazing! To be specific the POVs which I most enjoyed were those of both Via and Will which really showed character development and were in my opinion instrumental to the story. It would have been far too easy for Palacio to write the novel from Auggie's POV but she realized that for it to be an honest and authentic portrayal she would have to incorporate the experience of all those who Auggie touched. But with the good often comes the bad, I must say the first third of the book which was primarily if not completely Auggie's POV were to be quite honest unbearable. But alas I do think they were true to the character, they just weren't my favorite part of the story. All in all the novel deals with ordinary people dealing with extraordinary circumstances and the kindness that lies within us all. I think this would be a great read for all ages but particularity kids. Definitely recommend.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I loved this book. The characters were so well written and I'm always a sucker for books with multiple narrators. 
 I found the way Via talked about her grandmother's death and her mother's response versus August's perspective of their mother's response to Daisie's death (and the fact that he seemed fairly unaware of his grandmother's death and the impact it had on his mother and sister) especially interesting. I loved August, but I think I especially loved him because he wasn't a pity case - he was complex and at times bratty and self centered, which made him so much more realistic. 
 I also loved the precepts and Mr. Tushman's speech about kindness. They were both profound without being too saccharine. This book was touching as well as interesting and engaging.
This was pretty decent but I do feel it has been really over-hyped. I think because I was expecting it to be so insanely heart-wrenching my expectations were unrealistically high. Still good though!
Junior fiction to make you weep.
I loved this book!!! It was really good and it kept me entertained. I liked how it was seperated and how it was told from different perspectives
Fantastic book! Beautiful, honest, insightful and uplifting. I'm better for reading it! Loved it!!
Great easy-reading book. Both my kids loved if too. Suggestion for 10+ years

This book is so special and wonderful. I cried wet happy tears through much of the last third. I would give it 6 stars if I could. 
 "Kinder than necessary. Because it's not enough to be kind. One should be kinder than needed."

I feel bad giving this book only 3 stars. It's certainly not because of the topic. When I sub at the elementary school, I work with special needs kids much of the time so I have some understanding of what these kids have to deal with. Fortunately, not the cruelty because the kids are very kind to the special needs students in school. But I can see the challenges. I enjoyed reading about Auggie's first year in public school as a 5th grader. The book is told from Auggie's perspective at first but also from his sister's and a few other friends and wraps up with Auggie again. A little simple in the way of writing but it worked. I guess I felt it was too forced. Too perfect. Maybe it was just meant to be a feel good story which is fine, but I had heard so many fantastic things about it that I guess I expected more. 
 Would I recommend it? Sure. It's a quick read, but for me lacked something.
A beautiful book...

Get yourself in line at your local library to read this book. Seriously. 
 And yes, some people might call it unrealistic because of the uplifting ending, but there are plenty of passages in there that make you feel like you've been kicked in the gut. Also, contrary to one reviewer's opinion, I actually like different points of view, because we see Auggie and the world around him not only from his point of view, but the point of view of other kids, like his sister or his friends. We see how he changed them. And you might see yourself in one of the characters, or you might not, but I'm pretty sure (and at the least I hope) you will stop to think about your own behavior toward "others" who are different either physically or behaviorally, and behaviors toward "others" you have seen. Ultimately, I agree with the principal - "If every single person [...] made it a rule that wherever you are, whenever you can, you will try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place."
Terrific middle grade novel. Compassionate storytelling with a compelling arc in a super-current setting. Good, quick read w/ a 4-hanky warning.
Just amazing. Should be required reading in middle schools.

Wonder is the best book I have read in a long, long time. I love this book. RJ Palacio hit the top with this novel. This is one of the best books I have ever read! I recommend Wonder to all my friends, to all 5th, 6th, 7th, 8th, 9th, 10th, 11th, and 12th graders. This books is amazing. What an incredible, wonderful message.

I loved this story. It is a sweet story of an amazing little boy as he starts 5th grade and his first year in a public school. His face is severely deformed but his heart and spirit is undaunted. He has many challenges but never gives in or gives up!

4.5 stars 
 I liked this story a lot. In fact I think the additional POVs enriched the story. I thought it was curious that none of the additional POVs belonged to any adults. I thought maybe the parents would get a chance? But I can see why the author wouldn't include their POv.
This was a wonderful book with a lot of heart. It made me want to be kinder to everyone I meet.
Great story about kindness told from multiple perspectives.

"When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." 
 This book definitely belongs in the "cute little story" category, rather like the fairy tales of our childhoods; child has tough time/child overcomes by learning important lesson. It is targetted at a younger audience, and is all about acceptance, tolerance,and yes: kindness. 
 The star of the story is a boy with a severe facial deformity, and he is the narrator for much of the book. His friends and family also have a chapter or two each, and more is revealed by seeing their points of view. 
 A quick read with the feel-good factor.
Absolutely love this book! Great first read aloud in a grade 5 classroom. Awesome for read aloud a because it has short chapters.

I loved this book and bought extra copies for our elementary library quickly. Even with several copies there was always a line for the book (mostly 5th graders; a few 4th graders). It sends a strong message to readers, particularly student readers, that we need to have compassion for others. In our 5th grade book club, I heard some of the greatest discussions from multiple groups of students. I thought the multiple characters narrating the story really gave us the chance to try to understand the same situation from different points of view. It is a wonderful book for many intermediate (and probably several middle grade) students.
How do you define kindness? That is the main premise for much of this book. Auggie is a sweet, sensitive character that helps all readers try to define kindness in their own way.

Everybody everywhere needs to read this book. No matter how old you are, what gender, race, or religion, you have to read this book. Auggie's story is one that everyone can learn from, and at the end of the day, we could all do with a reminder to be a little more compassionate, a little more understanding, to be kinder than is necessary.

Kids, school, families, differences - so many layers to this story and so many great characters. I recommend this book to students, teachers, and parents as a good story and as a way to generate discussions about kindness, friendship, loyalty, and life in general.
I want my girls to read this book. This novel could be an entertaining and essential tool in teaching sympathy.
