This books is amazing! The magic about Wonder is not the lesson it teaches, but how it is taught. It's one story told from multiple perspectives, giving direct insight onto all sides of a cube. Palacio came out with a second version that includes an additional perspective. That is the one you should grab. The additional perspective is what tied it all together for me. It offered some hope and introduced the reality that we all make mistakes, that just because people do hurtful, ugly things, it does not make them a bad person. 
 Wonder is original, and heart warming. It would make a great gift to anyone, and especially I recommend it if you want to teach your children about making mistakes, and especially being kind.
This YA novel is for absolutely everyone. Sympathetic, funny, bittersweet and page-turning.

I really enjoyed this book. My hope is that there really are kind people like this out there, especially kids. The only thing that bothered me just a little is that the kids seemed older than they were, more like 6th or 7th graders. But that didn't interfere with my loving this book.

Thank you, R.J. Palacio, for making me realize that my problems can't be compared to what a lot of people go through every day. I read this book thinking that I'd like it, but the truth is that I love it and it will always have a special place in my heart. August Pullman is the strongest person I've ever read about. His courage and bravery left me speechless, and I can't thank the author enough. 
 We will all have shitty moments in life, we will all be judged, we will all be excluded, but the truth is that our kindness and strength are the only and most important thing that will lead us to victory. 
 August Pullman did that in this book. He reached victory. He is a wonder.
This was a very good book for kids. I am going to read it to both of my girls.

Predictably uplifting, but I suppose my desire for a more challenging story should have been adjusted when approaching a book for children. Still, it successfully walks the line between simplistic tropes and universal truths by avoiding the heavy-handedness of many saccharine tales about "difference." The most valuable stories are always about the same things: struggle, perseverance, and love. For kids, this is recommended.
Everyone should read this book!
Cute book, well written and entertaining. Very well captures the struggles of junior high and high school kids.
I cannot express how much I loved this book. My 10 year old asked me to read it and I'm so glad that he did! This is one of those books that will be with me forever.

It was a tear jerker but I enjoyed it. I agree with my friend Andrea, the 10 year old dating scene was not cool but I thought the overall message was very important. 
 10/11/17- Reread this aloud to my kids. One thing that tends to really stand out to me more when I read aloud is the use of language. -mostly because I do a lot of skipping, rewording and editing on the fly and it interrupts the flow of the story. I didn't notice it before, but there was A LOT of taking the name of the Lord in vain. (I think that they use this as a fall back in these middle grade books where other swearing might not be viewed as appropriate but for some reason these ones are okay). :(
This was such a great read! I highly recommend it & actually think it should be required reading in school.

Thanks Sarah, for encouraging me to read what I might have thought was exclusively a "middle-grade" read. Such a lovely story! 
 "Shall we make a new rule of life...always to try to be a little kinder than is necessary?"

I wanted to read this book due to all the great reviews it received. This is the second YA book I have read this year, with "The Fault In Our Stars" being the first, which in my opinion is an extraordinary read! "Wonder" is well written, with a nice flow. But I am still trying to figure out why it received so many 5 star reviews. I will recommend this read to my 13 year old granddaughter and be interested to hear her review.

This was a great book. I couldn't put it down, and there were several times I was near tears. I enjoyed the different points of view that the author wrote from, and the lessons taught in this book are worth repeating. Nicely done.

What an wonderful book! Auggie was born with a rare facial physical deformity that makes people react negatively when they first meet him. Other than that, Auggie is a normal kid who just want to do what kids do. When his mom decides that maybe it is a good idea to send him to school after sheltering him from people, Auggie agrees to take the difficult step and face a world who judges people by their appearance. I think this was a very enjoyable read and that has many lessons for middle grade kids can relate to.

This is a very unique and inspirational book. 
 Deformity is something none of us wants to live with. We all want to lead normal and perfect lives. August is born with a genetic disorder which leads to his face being disfigured. Shy and wary of the stares and jokes thrown his way, he is used to shying away from people. 
 But with the help of his sister and friends, he joins a school and embarks son a journey full of delight, struggles, and triumphs. There were so many instances where I had tears in my eyes feeling the pain that Auggie felt and I had to take a moment to catch my breath. 
 It's a beautiful book that makes you realize how words, actions and thoughts could impact a person in their lives. 
 The best book ever.

Without realizing this was a middle school book, we selected it for our book group's January discussion. The determining factors were that it was highly rated, had an important theme which would make for a good discussion and was short so it would be better to read during the busy Christmas holiday season. This book kept me, an adult in my late 30s, interested and even brought me to tears. It is heartbreaking while being uplifting and will be an exceptional weapon against bullying in school-age readers. Bullying and teasing are the main themes of the book since the main character is severely deformed and attending public school for the first time. The book begins with August Pullman's narration and we get a good feel for how his life has been, how he perceives himself and his family and his nervousness about attending public school. Once we have listened to Auggie's voice for a while, we are given different narrative perspectives from his family, friends, and even the bully. The book does a great job of allowing us to empathize with each of the characters from Auggie's sister Olivia Pullman to his best friends Summer Dawson and Jackalope Will. There is even a perspective from Auggie's main bully, Julian Albans. The book does a decent job of not turning anyone into a perfect altruistic good guy (except maybe Auggie) or evil bad guy (except Julian until the end when we hear his side.) If I had one complaint, it would be the bully's grandmother's story (it felt too contrived) and the way it immediately turned the bully around in the end. It felt like Julian did a 180 as soon as his grandmother finished the story and that didn't seem realistic. I don't think that is too much of a spoiler for those who haven't read it. 
 Worth Quoting: 
 3.9% "What did you tell [the principal] about me?" "How funny you are, and how kind and smart..." "Did you tell him anything else?" I said. Mom smiled at me. Her smile kind of hugged me. "I told him about all your surgeries, and how brave you are," she said. 
 16.7% "Jack whispered: "Do you ever want to beat those kids up?" I shrugged, "I guess. I don't know." "I'd want to. I think you should get a secret squirt gun or something and attach it to your eyes somehow. An every time someone stares at you, you would squirt them in the face." "With some green slime or something," I answered. "No, no: with slug juice mixed with dog pee." 
 20.2% "I've though about this a lot," said the second mummy, sounding serious, "and I really think...if I looked like him, seriously, I think that I'd kill myself." "You would not," answered Darth Sidious. "Yeah, for real." insisted the same mummy. "I can't imagine looking in that mirror everyday and seeing myself like that. It would be too awful. And getting stared at all the time." "Then why do you hang out with him so much?" asked Darth Sidious. "I don't know," answered the mummy...The mummy shrugged. I knew the shrug, of course. I knew the voice. I knew I wanted to run out of the class right then and there. 
 22.5% Coming home after four weeks felt very strange at first. I remember very vividly stepping through the door and seeing August running over to welcome me home, and for this tiny fraction of a moment I saw him not the way I've always seen him, but the way other people see him. It was only a flash, an instant while he was hugging me, so happy that I was home, but it surprised me because I'd never seen him like that before. And I'd never felt what he was feeling before, either; a feeling I hated myself for having the moment I had it. But as he was kissing me with all his heart, all I could see was the drool coming down his chin. And suddenly there I was, like all those people who would stare or look away. Horrified. Sickened. Scared. Thankfully, that only lasted for a second: the moment I heard August laugh his raspy little laugh it was over. Everything was back the way it had been before. But it had opened a door for me. A little peephole. And on the other side of the peephole there were two Augusts; the one I saw blindly, and the one other people saw. 
 22.8% "I love Auggie very, very much," [my grandmother] said softly..."But he has many angels looking out for him already, Via. And I want you to know that you have me looking out for you."...She looked out at the ocean and spread her hands out like she was trying to smooth out the waves. "You are my everything. You understand me, Via?"...I understood her. And I knew why she said it was a secret. Grandmothers aren't supposed to have favorites. Everyone knows that. But after she died, I held onto that secret and let it cover me like a blanket. 
 28.8% [T]he phone rang. It was the nurse from August's school calling...So much for the old movies and mother-daughter bonding. Mom picked August up, and the moment he came home, he went straight to the bathroom and threw up. Then he went to his bed and pulled the covers over his head. Mom took his temperature, brought him some hot tea, and assumed the "August's mom" role again. "Via's mom," who had come out for a little while, was put away. I understood, though: August was in bad shape. 
 31.3% It was actually because I was playing Four Square with August that I found out about the Plague. Apparently this is a "game" that's been going on since the beginning of the year. Anyone who accidently touches August has only thirty seconds to wash their hands or find hand sanitizer before they catch the Plague. I'm not sure what happens to you if you actually catch the Plague because nobody's touched August yet - not directly...I told Maya that was really dumb and she agreed, but she still wouldn't touch a ball that August just touched, not if she could help it. 
 33.6% "You want to know what's wrong with my face?...The main thing I have is this thing called man-di-bu-lo-facial dys-os-tosis - which took me forever to learn how to pronounce, by the way. But I also have this other syndrome thing that I can't even pronounce. And these things kind of just morphed together into one big superthing, which is so rare they don't even have a name for it. I mean, I don't want to brag or anything, but I'm actually considered something of a medical wonder, you know." He smiled. "That was a joke," he said. "You can laugh." 
 40.2% "While you're at home, you take the time to think about what's happened. And if you want to write me a letter explaining what happened, and a letter to Julian apologizing, then we won't even put any of this in your permanent record, okay?" [Ah, the old Permanent Record we all feared having negative marks on when we were in school.] 
 50.4% olivia reminds me of a bird sometimes, how her feathers get all ruffled when she's mad. and when she's fragile like this, she's a little lost bird looking for it's nest. so i give her my wing to hide under. 
 53.1% How can I describe what I heard when the doctor turned on my hearing aids? Or what I didn't hear? It's too hard to think of words. The ocean just wasn't living inside my head anymore. It was gone. I could hear sounds like shiny lights in my brain. It was like when you're in a room where one of the lightbulbs on the ceiling isn't working, but you don't realize how dark it is until someone changes the lightbulb and then you're like, whoa, it's so bright in here! I don't know if there's a word that means the same as "bright" in terms of hearing, but I wish I knew one, because my ears were hearing brightly now. 
 56% "Mommy, is Daisy with Grans now?" "I think so." "Are they in heaven?" "Yes." "Do people look the same when they get to heaven?" "I don't know. I don't think so." "Then how do people recognize each other?" "I don't know, sweetie." She sounded tired. "They just feel it. You don't need your eyes to love, right? You just feel it inside you. That's how it is in heaven. It's just love, and no on forgets who they love." 
 67.7% Mr. Tushman and Ms. Rubin and Summer and all the rest of the kids were just watching the movie. They had no clue how something bad had almost happened to me and Jack. It's so weird how that can be, how you could have a night that's the worst in your life, but to everybody else it's just an ordinary night. Like, on my calendar at home, I would mark this as being one of the most horrific days of my life. This and the day Daisy died. But for the rest of the world, this was just an ordinary day. Or maybe it was even a good day. Maybe somebody won the lottery today. [This is how I felt after the Joplin tornado. Mom and I were trying to recover and other people were posting about ordinary days and flippant nuisances on Facebook. It felt like life should be in shambles for everyone and not just us because for us it was our whole world.] 
 85.9% "I don't think it's for anyone else to judge the semantics of a note," said Mom. "It doesn't matter whether you think one note is worse than the other - it's how the person reading the note reads it." [This is why the law says reasonable person because some aren't reasonable.]

I enjoyed the book. Although it was obviously not written for my demographic of adults. I agree with other reviewers that I felt that the alternate POVs could have used some differing voice but overall the story kept my attention and I did shed a few tears (for Daisy). I did struggle with the idea that a ten year old "normal" child could have had this much deep introspective views in to their own feelings.

This is such a bittersweet, heart-warming book. I wish it had been written when I was in middle school. As an adult, though, it provides insight to many teachable moments that might arise with my own children in the future. I'll be eager to read it to them in a few years, although I'm not sure how I'll keep my composure. It's a tear jerker (in a good way).

This book is a modern day classic. My son and I read it together and we feel in love with August (or Auggie to his family and friends). The book let us explore and discuss so many topics (bullying, death of a family member and a pet, surgery, accepting people, empathy). I think this book would be a great classroom read as it covers so many important issues. It is funny, heartwarming and most of all makes you think about what other people might be feeling or struggling with. I highly recommend this to not only children but adults too as we can all learn something from little Auggie and his friends.
Wonderful!

It seemed that I was one of the only people in America who had not yet read this book. When I learned that a movie adaptation was coming out soon, I decided to bump it to the top of my list before the movie ruined it for me. 
 I found this book to be compulsively readable and I enjoyed every moment of it. I thought the message was important and timely and I am glad that this book has experienced the popularity that it has. I am going to add this to the list of books to read or listen to with my kids. 
 Having said that, I felt that the book was wrapped up SLIGHTLY too sweetly. The characters all had believable, clear voices, but I felt that some of the negative emotions that would exist in this reality were downplayed just a tad. I understand why that author took this approach, as this is a book aimed for children. I guess I wanted just a little more emotional oomph (although there was enough to bring a tear to my eye a time or two). 
 Overall - I think this book was very effective at providing a glimpse into August's world and is a good edition to the current childhood canon.

August is the type of character you automatically fall in love with. Although an extreme introvert, August managed to show everyone how brave and kind he is. He managed to let go of fear and accept people for what they are. The more I read, the more I wish I could be like him. For he is a stormtrooper, a wonder, a miracle, and above all- he is Major Tom.

Have you ever felt that a huge crowd has been watching you and staring straight right at your face? Have you caught your best friend trash-talking you just to be on the popular side? Have you ever thought how those people WONDER? WONDER why they badly care? WONDER why don't they get the deal obviously? WONDER why they don't accept people as who they are?WONDER why should they waste time mumbling in and out of the business of others? WONDER why they lack the sense of sensitivity? If I would have the time to jot down the WONDERS I had during and after I have read this...it would take forever. 
 This WONDERful story started with August Pullman -- the child that was born with unusual sickness, the mandibulofacial dysostosis caused by an autosomal recessive mutation in the TCOF1 gene, which is located on chromosome 5, complicated by a hemifacial microsomia characteristic of OAV spectrum, in simpler words, his face's sickly deformed. Auggie's parents, Isabel and...I forgot his dad's name were forced to homeschool him for years. One time, they decided to enroll Auggie to school but only if Auggie says he's ready. And unexpectedly, Auggie agreed for he know what sort of trouble and pain he will get into. But what surprised Auggie was the pain brought by the one he trusts. 
 Auggie has better senses than any normal human being. I wouldn't call it a supernatural power or chemically created power brought by the surgeries he had but, he has the unique ability to see things and keep it really quietly because he exclusively understands (It kind of reminds me of being a wallflower actually). Moreover, as a child, he knows his place, he knows what's happening and he never argues with it (well, maybe sometimes...you know every child has tantrums and a blasted curious minds). 
 Going beyond the story, I really have this urge to comment about being RUDE. If you see a man with an unusual face, would you actually tell your friend or the person beside you "hey, the man looks weird, he has long mustache and a big nose and all" barefacedly? I mean, what are you trying to get?! What could you possibly get from destroying a person's ego? If you can't help it, DON'T YOU THINK IT'S TIME TO ACT AMBIGUOUSLY? I mean come on! Haven't you heard the thing called "SELF-RESPECT"? 
 Lastly, a unique boy like Auggie sees what we see and feels what we feel (if you know what I mean) that's why we better not judge that boy by his face. Heck, we better NOT JUDGE ANYONE without knowing who he/she is and regardless of his/her status in life.

Sweet story, good message, and I enjoyed the writing style. I especially liked that it kept switching narrators so you really got inside many of the characters heads instead of just one. This allowed supporting characters and their stories to become much more meaningful, and it was just fun to see how the author really felt about each of his characters. Overall, I would recommend this as a fun, quick, very clean and uplifting book.

This juvenile fiction book is about a boy who enters regular school for the first time in fifth grade. Some complications, it's middle school, he's smart, and he has a terrible craniofacial deformity that makes him look like a monster. This first year odyssey is told from a variety of views--his, his sister's, schoolmates, and parents. It is well-told and helps the reader understand what it is like to be different--really different.

R.J. Palacio does a wonderful job with this book Wonder. I cried at the end, and it was very telling. I loved how the author tells it from each person and their feelings. It flows smoothly. Auggie is wonderfully written and the author expresses his thoughts and feelings wonderful. Via being the sister of Auggie dealing with being put on the back burner.

What a beautiful book to use to teach young secondary school children about empathy, compassion and choosing the kind of person you want to be. 
 While the language is simple and I would even say plain (though I don't mean this critically), the subject matter is deeply moving and powerful. Read this book with your children and teach them some valuable life lessons.
There's so much EMOTION!!! It's like your laughing hysterically one second then your crying into your shirt the next. 5 stars.

My kids and I read this book, and it was a beautiful and extraordinary portrait of middle school life. The themes that run through this young adult book struck such a chord with my 6th, 5th, and 1st grader. The story of August Pullman, the wonderful boy that is disfigured at birth, and how he courageously enters public school had us laughing and crying throughout the entire book.
Would middle school kids really be this kind?
Good book. Very light read.
Brilliant, entertaining, perfect.....SPECIAL.

I read this book to my 8 year old son and we both thoroughly enjoyed it. A heartwarming story of a boy's first year at school after being home-schooled due to extensive surgical procedures and facial abnormalities. This is a must read with wonderful insight to understand the art of friendship and kindness. I LOVED it.
i love this book!
Extraordinary...
Wonder is a must read. Loved the story. Loved the characters. I should write such a wonderful first book.
Beautiful book! This book should be included in all intermediate classroom libraries!
Love this book. It's about friendship and kindness. Palacio really taps into the mind of a middle-schooler. I think most kids could relate to the emotions of the characters in thes book.
Cool beans!!! :-)

This book is so amazing. It should be required reading for all middle school kids and their parents. The author does such a wonderful job of speaking in the voice of each of the characters. Middle school is such a challenging time and Palacio really gets to the heart of the feelings and challenges. Loved it!
This book has messages for everyone! It is very human, and a good tool for discussing feelings, perspective and humanity.
Great book!
very good book
Great little book. Well written and very moving. Loved it.

One of the few novels worthy of nose-burying. Couldn't put it down once I'd started till I'd read the last word. Very relatable, beautifully written, rich with opinions and multiple viewpoints on a single key event. Although, it was quite predictable, with Julian and his mom being too cruel and the ending being too perfect. Cliche, I'd say. Would've been interesting with an antagonist's viewpoint. All in all, it was interesting and fun to read.

I loved it :) so many emotional moments that made me wipe my eyes with sadness and happiness throughout the book. 
 I love when a book is full of upstanding characters and this had it. the characters had depth and I really enjoyed the multiple POVs. there was realism in their emotions and their struggles working through their own thoughts and situations. 
 The narrations were perfect and the scenes painted perfectly. 
 The precepts hit us on the heart right away - to choose to be kind more than is necessary...!!! and the summertime precepts sent by the students were a fun addition and definitely got me curious about Julian's story. 
 I loved the scene near the end where the dad talked about the astronaut helmet with Auggie. <3 
 cheers to the little dude.

it was okay.. i mean nothing too interesting happened in it. I didn't really see a climax or anything and some parts were too long like when they went on a camping trip the author literally wrote down all the instructions the person was giving like it was uneeded. but it did teach me to treat everyone with respect and that deformed kids are just like us and we shouldn't make a face when we meet them.

I have to say, I loved this book! The back cover blurb says 'Don't judge a boy by his face', but we all do this every day. Perhaps it just strikes a chord with me, because my own daughter was born with a facial disfigurement. I can still remember how people used to look at her. 
 This story is told by the boy himself, Auggie, a wonderful, feisty little character you can't help but fall in love with, and those people closest to him. Aged 10, and home-schooled, Auggie begins prep school, and this story follows him through the trials and tribulations of that first year. 
 Be warned, there are moments when you will be reduced to a weeping wreck, but others where you will be smiling with joy. There is nothing depressing about this story, it is warm-hearted and uplifting. 
 'I feel ordinary. Inside. But I know ordinary kids don't make other ordinary kids run away screaming in playgrounds.' That's how Auggie begins his story. 'I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse.' 
 He goes on to tell how the other children at school recoiled when they first saw him, how they stared and whispered behind his back; wouldn't sit beside him, or touch him, for fear of catching 'the plague'; how the kids he thought were his friends were only looking out for him because they were told to by teachers; how he was physically attacked and bullied by older kids, who should have known better. 
 The story is told simply, directly, and you can't help rooting for him. His family are loving and supportive, but even they struggle at times to cope with the impact his syndrome is having upon them, and it's interesting to read their experiences of having Auggie in their lives, both good and bad. 
 But with a group of parents campaigning to have him removed from the school, and his friends being bullied simply for being his pals, it's hard to keep going, no matter how bright, resourceful and resilient Auggie is. 
 Sometimes funny, sometimes shocking, this is a story which will stay with you long after you've finished reading it.

This is a wonderful story about a boy who has facial deformities and how he, his family and those around him are affected by it. While the reader may think she already understands what people are going through, this book really presents a window deep into the minds of all of these people, and helps us see that this is a layered situation. Every intermediate student should read this book. It's about being a person of character and kindness. I'm not a fast reader, but this is a fast read.
Beautiful! Very interesting the combination of different points of view. A really interesting book for children and adults!

Absolutely WONDERful and WONDERfilled!! 
 This is one of the best books I've ever read! Very inspiring! definitely a tear jerker! I never thought I'd shed tears on this book. If you want a fiction book about KINDNESS AND CHARITY and all the virtues you would wish you have, this is it! It definitely teaches you principles to live by throughout your whole life. 
 I encourage teachers, students, friends, children and everyone who can read to READ this book! It will teach you how to have God's image in your countenance! :)
A beautiful, moving book.
I read my children the first five "chapters" and they laughed and laughed and laughed. And begged me not to stop

a wonder definetely a wonder, a marvelous, beautiful and uplifting strory... Not always you can find a book that touches you as much as this did to me, but when it happens (like what happened to me when I first starting reading this book), I reassure you won't want to stop reading, you will get obsessed, or at least that happens to me (now I can't help thinking about it) jajaj, I'm just kidding but yes, you will also learn a real important lesson of life, this book will mean a big change in your point of view, and you won't forget it never, ever, ever...

Recommended to me by Jill Mansell, and not something I'd read ordinarily. Very glad I did though - reminded me how lucky I am, but in a good way, not a guilt-inducing there-but-for-the-grace-of-God way. 
 My daughters are reading it next.
My 10 yr. old daughter read it & I think I enjoyed it just as much as she did!

I read this book in less than 24 hours. I just couldn't put it down. I loved the characters. I loved how Palacio shifted the POV so many times. I loved the transformation of so many characters. I literally sobbed through parts and laughed at other parts. Palacio captured 5th grade boys and girls, but especially boys, remarkably well. I will be recommending this book to everyone I know and may even read it again in the near future. Well done Palacio. Well done.

This was a recommended read from a Friend I greatly respect. She said we should get this into the hands of kids and maybe there would be a little more kindness in the world. Such a true statement! This, just as Out of My Mind, should be read by the masses.

Wonder is an amazing book about a kid who is starting middle school and his first time in an actual school. Auggie is scared that people will make fun of him, but not many people do. His sister, Via helps him through his bad beginning of school. One of my favorite quotes is this: When given the choice between being right and being kind, choose kind.- Mr. Browne's September precept. 
 There are 8 parts in this book: 1: August, 2: Via, 3: Summer, 4: Jack Will, 5: Justin, 6: August, 7: Miranda, and 8: August. You will learn more in the book!

I enjoyed this book. Loved the characters, the changing perspectives, and how they breathed new life into the plotting and pacing. It felt real to me, not sentimental. 
 But mostly, what made this a five star review, was how it impacted my nine year-old, Lucy. Her 3rd grade teacher read it to the class and for weeks after, she would bring August into our conversations, sharing what he might think, how he would be impacted if he were experiencing what we were experiencing. 
 In so many ways, August doesn't seem like "every kid" because his challenges are so huge, but he is. Kids can relate to his struggles. 
 August has stayed with her, long after the reading, and it really can't get better than that.
All the feeeels dY~dY~ This book was beautiful, meaningful and a lovely read dY'-
This is a book every adult and child (over 8) should read. So absolutely amazing.

I can't put the book down. A rare topic that's new to me. I never read something like this so far. Hats off to R.J Palacio for making the story hilarious. 
 I know, sometimes people like me judge special person like August Pullman. And now that I read such a great story, I eventually know how they felt and how they avoid feeling that way. How brave they are for facing the cruel world with such an optimistic side. Unlike other stories, Auggie is not the pity-me-person which is why I love him. I also love the switching view point. Their issues and several ways to show love to little Auggie is heart-warming. It is well written but easy to read. It is fun but I got teary eye. 
 It's a mixture of every emotion I have. It's not a waste of time. Choose kind. Argh. Gonna read it again. :))

Wonder has left me full of wonder for the courage of individuals who face incredible challenges. August, the wonder around whom this story revolves is a grade 5 boy with a face that causes even the most tolerant to turn away. Imagine starting middle school with a face like this - yes bullies emerge but so do some angels. I so value this story because of its faith in the human race. Inspiring is the word I would use to describe this novel. I am so glad I spent time with Auggie, his family, fellow students and teachers.

Every 5th grader should read this book. I am glad that my daughter read it but I'm even more glad that August got his standing ovation. He's right, everyone does deserve at least one in a lifetime. This is an awesome book about friendship, loyalty and perseverance.
One of the best books I've read :]

Really wonderful book, it is telling the truth of what is happening in life. I think it's targeting all people to face their real feelings and how they should treat all people regardless how they looks like. 
 Auggie is a kid who's been chosen by god to be special human being, though, will be seen as a handicapped with deforms. 
 From my view of point, I don't see him as handicapped kid, where he is smart with normal body and only having some face deforms and all other things can be overcome. 
 I've loved the way his mother handled the situation, how she pretend to be strong for him, of course she suffered a lot, thought she could manage to give him the life he deserves as she believes. 
 His sister in the novel teaches us all how she sacrificed for her brother, where Auggie needs her parents more than her. Though, she needs them and misses them. 
 In the school, too many lessons learnt, it's been highlighted how people feels towards someone like Auggie, and nobody should be judged of how they looked like, because under the appearance there is heart and feelings. 
 There are more to comment on this great novel, but let it be easy, simple and short :) 
 In the end, one quote I love from many is: 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." --Dr. Wayne Dyer

 Una linda historia que te incita a actuar y a firmar el compromiso: #EligeSerAmable

I especially love the audio version. Excellent conversation starter with kids, ages 9 and up I'd say. Here's my interview with the author http://www.slate.com/articles/double_...

One of them maybe because it shows a kind of family (esp. parents) that I have been dreaming to have. Salute to Palacio!! One of best I've ever read!!!
Awesome quick-read. It's a page turner! You laugh, you cry, you remember and you are grateful not to be in middle school anymore.

Location: Children's Department

This book is the kind of story you want to carry around in your back pack and hand out to strangers. It feels as if could change a person, a school or a town. I also love how authentic the voices feel.
This is a fab book and a great read. Well done RJ Palacio!!! Although I can't say I'm too keen on your photo on the back cover - but that's just me, being picky as usual.

This book made me wanna cry at the same time it made me wanna cheer. This should be read by everyone. A must read.

This book revolves around August Pullman, who is having various facial deformity and is being Homeschooled untill his mother decides him to send to a normal school from 5th Grade. And there starts the story the ways his schoolmates and friends react by seeing him...which he was ascertained of.

 This book kept a hold on me. There were moments where I cried and the other where I laughed. Must read for all ages.
"Todos deberiamos recibir una ovacion al menos una vez en nuestra vida, porque todos vencemos al mundo."

I enjoyed this book and found it very moving. It is not just a book for children and can certainly be appreciated by adults. It is about perceptions and reactions to children who are physically different. It is about courage and kindness Wonderful!

This book, left me with a happy cry! This book was amazing and tought me the same old saying "Don't judge a book by its cover" My favorite part of this book was when he was about to take a nap after camp and the dad brought home the new puppy, Bear!
Great Book!!!

Every kid needs to read this book. I fell in love with Auggie on the first page. Wonder is a great lesson in compassion and empathy. I also loved that we got to see this story from the point of view of the other kids. Definitely a must read.

I love it when the school librarians give me a book and say, "It's just come in. We wanted to give it to you first to read; you'll love it." Good call, oh keepers of the books, good call. 
 There's so much to recommend this: a powerful and moving story, courage, redemption and transformation. A lovely modern-day Bildungsroman. 
 Check out 'Mr Browne's Precepts', woven beautifully throughout and listed at the end. 
 I'm going to start reading this to my 5/6 class on Monday.

Lovely, uplifting book. 
 No idea how realistic it is, but you can't argue with the sentiment and guidance "when given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind".
Great:) fun and personable

Such a great read, the book signifies the plight of every child being new and having to experience school s the odd one out, not just the disabled, but even the socially introverted. I could really relate to this book back to when I was about ten.

I could not put this book down...the story of this boy and the world spinning around him is so captivating and painful at the same time. My daughter's teacher read this aloud to her class two years ago--so glad she did, the message of being kinder than necessary is applicable at all stages of life. Echoes of the central message in "To Kill a Mockingbird" definitely resonate through this book.
This book is great! I couldn't put it down until I finished it! I highly recommend this book.
simple act of kindness could change someone's day, or even someone's life.

I only wish that there were more than 5 stars to highlight. This book should be required reading not only in middle school, but in every school. In every college. In every sector of life and education. Palacio is a master of voices, of subtleties, of knowing when to stop before things get corny or unrealistic. I have to admit that I read this book because my 11 year old niece told me she was reading it and I can't wait to sit down and discuss every wonderful, painful, enlightening detail with her. Thank you R.J. Palacio -- I believe that you are the true wonder for writing this book.
I didn't know tears could come out of this book

I think this book should be read by middle schoolers everywhere, so they may take a moment to think about kindness and perhaps be kinder adults. This story was so well told and so emotional; I wish more books made my heart swell as this one did!

I read this book after seeing a full page ad for it in The New York Times Book Review and looking at the corresponding book trailer on YouTube. The main character, 10 year old August Pullman, is born with a facial deformity that makes people look away in horror and keeps him out of public schools until the beginning of 5th grade, when the book begins. He opens the narration of the book and says, "I won't describe what I look like. Whatever you're thinking, it's probably worse." His parents decide he is ready to face the stresses of Beecher Prep School. His entrance into the mainstream is supposed to be softened by his introduction to Jack, Julian and Charlotte, young "leaders" chosen by the principal to show Auggie around the school before the year begins. Of course, children don't become friends simply because adults want them to, and kids are cruel - a lesson Auggie must learn time and time again. Wonder has won many "best book" accolades and been described as one that will make children and adults treat others better. I loved Auggie and wanted to cheer him on in the truthful, sad sections of the book that he narrates. I thought the narrative structure was weakened by the alternative voices used by the author - various friends, and Auggie's sister, Olivia. I felt these other narrators did little more than re-narrate the same events rather than advancing the plot. But there are so many other positives about the book, one of which is the Choose Kind pledge on a Tumblr site advocating the book's anti-bullying mission. Also, I really loved the Precepts used by one of the teachers to frame his instruction for the year - 
 "When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind." --Dr. Wayne Dyer 
 "Your deeds are your monuments." --Inscription on ancient Egyptian tomb 
 "Have no friends not equal to yourself." --Confucius 
 "Fortune favors the bold." --Virgil 
 "No man is an island, entire of itself." --John Donne 
 "It is better to know some of the questions than all of the answers." --James Thurber 
 "Kind words do not cost much. Yet they accomplish much." --Blaise Pascal 
 "What is beautiful is good, and who is good will soon be beautiful." --Sappho 
 "Do all the good you can, by all the means you can, in all the ways you can, in all the places you can, at all the times you can, to all the people you can, as long as you ever can." --John Wesley 
 "Just follow the day and reach for the sun." --The Polyphonic Spree 
 "Everyone deserves a standing ovation because we all overcometh the world." --Auggie Pullman
One of the very best books I have ever read. Every teacher, student, HUMAN should read this book. It is life-changing. Period.

Hermoso libro, asi como Auggie (protagonista) cree que todos deberiamos recibir una ovacion de pie al menos una vez en la vida, yo creo que todo mundo deberia leer este libro al menos una vez en su vida.
SO good for both genders and all ages.
Loved this one! Quick read and passed it on to my teen to read
I heartily recommend that you read this book. It is one of the best books I have read for a long time. Uplifting and life affirming. Just wonderful!
Wonder was easy to read - engaging, hard to put down. The story was realistic and uplifting. Categorized as a children's book, but I think it's a good read for all ages.
Precioso. Simplemente eso, precioso.

The message that the author is sending in this novel is one that students can relate to. As a teacher, I notice the struggle students have when a peer of theirs has a disability or is not "normal". Overall, students want to do the right thing but struggle with peer pressure and often make poor choices. This book shows students' choices when dealing with the main character, a 5th grade student with a hearing impairment and severe facial deformities.

This book will stay like forever though i finished it. It makes me look at this world in the different way, like everything has two sides so we shouldn't look once and judge it. There's always good in bad, silver linings. This book is like an encouragement that gives you a feeling that you want to be kinder to everyone. Like it is said in the book that people should be kinder than necessary, quote or unquote. Great great written. My all time favorite book so far :)
Cool beans! *thumbs up*

A wonderful book. There are so many things I'm thinking about this book. I love reading books that change my perspective of life. This is one of those books. The way that Auggie was feeling because of his face, made me think in all the people that is struggling with self-esteem, we never know how much words can hurt someone or just a simple sight. 
 I learned about friendship. A friend can make the difference, sometimes we just need someone who can support and help us to feel important and that we really matter. 
 Family- maybe my favorite part of this book. Every time I read about Auggie's mom or Dad I couldn't stop thinking in my mom and dad. He had wonderful parents, they loved him more than anything and they were always willing to help him to feel happy. He was an a fortunate kid. He was born in a special family. 
 Kindness. This book ended with the words I needed to read. "Try to be a little kinder than necessary". A lesson I would take forever. I loved so much this book [?][?]

This book was incredible. Kindness is something that as a society, we lack. It is heart-breaking that we are so quick to be cruel and judgmental. This book will remind you WHY we need to change our ways. I loved this book and so will you. This is the kind of book that once you read, you pass along. This is not a book that belongs on a bookshelf, it is to be shared.

Really endearing. Told from a half dozen perspectives centering around the protagonist, August (who has almost the same name as Augustus from The Fault in Our Stars! Coincidence?), who has a severe facial abnormality which makes his first year of middle school pretty rough. You also hear from his sister, his sister's boyfriend, and some of his friends.
I really loved this books
This book was so amazing. It's so sad but absolutely brilliant!
Nice story about how a disfigured boy is treated by people around him in a school in New York. Also captures his feelings about himself. Easy to read
Touching, simple and inspiring; this novel tugged on my heart strings. 'Wherever you are, whenever you can... try to act a little kinder than is necessary - the world really would be a better place.'
A must read for children and adults alike.
Muy bello. Realmente te pone a pensar.
Awesome book!

Fantastic Middle Grade novel. A true gem. It's been a while since I've read a book that really captures kids while being able to suck adults into the story as well. So heart warming and heart wrenching at the same time. I shed some tears, though not necessarily over what one would think. In the interest of avoiding any spoilers, I'll just say the writing drew such empathy from me that I actually cried tears while reading. First book to do that to me since Sharon Creech's Love That Dog. I highly recommend picking this book up for a read.
Great, easy read on being KIND to everyone. Even those who are different. I hope my children learn this lesson.

I would recommend all teachers and parents to read this with their children, as well as many adults. 
 Its a beautiful book that teaches us all about kindness and compassion. 
 I read a lot of reviews before buying the book, and although there are heartbreaking parts, those parts weren't actually as bad as I thought that they would have been. 
 Though Auggie does not look like the rest of us, what he goes through is something many kids in school go through. For that reason, I think that this book is a MUST in schools, because it teaches the readers about strength, kindness, compassion, friendship and how to learn whats right and wrong.
This book was just plain amazing. I loved it. The words really pulled me in. I was up all night reading this novel and you will be too.

This book is absolutely amazing. Auggie pullman has a facial deformity.In this book, you can read about how this young, ordinary boy's extraordinary face effects his friends, family, and enemies. 
 If you like this book try Out of My Mind By: Sharon M. Draper.

At first I thought it was going to be boring and when I realised it was told from other people's point of view, I really enjoyed it. 
 Great story! Truly reflects human nature and how we treat others.
I can't remember the last time that I cried reading a book....pretty impressive!
Well, not really my kind of book, i was not really interested about the story.
A quick read and a very good book that everyone should read.
Outstanding! Five+ stars!!

This was such a heart warming book, it made me think about the rest of the world from a different perspective. I think everyone should read this book. I think after reading Wonder i will never look at anyone with something wrong with them with a weird look.
I loved this book so much! All middle school kids should read it.

(Don't judge the book by its cover .. don't judge the boy by his face) 
 The fact that this story talks about a 10 years old boy ,who is facing the harsh world because he was born with a deformed face, makes me drown in tears. 
 It was a really happy journey reading this story, just like watching a really good movie, you live and feel the words as you are one of the characters. 
 I loved how the writer made us see the incidents from different angles, loved the unconditional family love, loved the kid Auggi and everything. 
 I think this story makes us all sympathize with disabled people and look at the world through their eyes. 
 And at the end i would like to say , like principal Tushman said, Always be kinder than necessary and the world will be just fine. 
 This book is a must read , 5 star.

A feel-good book that left me feeling really warm on the inside. Language was simple and light, reminiscent of the things I'd read as a kid (though perhaps no longer as appealing to my teenage self). Didn't really like the way the fonts, grammar and punctuation changed when switching from one perspective to another. But overall, it was a meaningful read which will teach loads of kids (and adults of course) the value of empathy and the often forgotten importance of kindness.
My daughter gifted this book to me after I bought it for her and I have enjoyed our discussions about the story of August as much, if not more than the story itself. That alone makes it brilliant.

Wow! I loved this book. It reminded me of the movie Mask in many ways. Auggie, the main character, is loved and valued by his family who have learned to see past his unique face. But this is a unique family and story. The family strives for normalcy--more for Auggie than for themselves, but this is often interrupted by Auggie's needs. The story, told from various perspectives, creates a multi-faceted view of Auggie's life and also shows how others adapt to Auggie and, from him, learn compassion. As a teacher, I related to this student, taunted by peers who do not yet understand how to embrace and value differences. I'm so happy to see this book will be a movie soon! I highly recommend it. Great writing, great story!
Wonder was one of my favorite books, I recommend reading it if you want to read a cute book that will make you want to scream or laugh at some parts.
By far... The best book ever! I don't care what age you are.. This is a must read. Loved the very last line of the book!
Very very touching and it is so well done it makes you want to go and hug August .

Have you ever thought how tough it would be if you looked so hideous that people just stay away from you like a disease? Well this is the journey of August who, due to a genetic defect, has a deformed face. He is home schooled until he goes to school first time. This is his story, his one year journey and it will definitely touch your heart.

I wanted to read this book because I instantly thought of my mother-in-law. She was born with a craniofacial abnormalities and had numerous surgeries and was picked on plenty in school. I really liked this book and thought a lot about what it must have been like for my mother-in-law. 
 This is a middle grade book and I did buy it hoping to give it my 11 year old daughter. It brought tears to my eyes more than once and think maybe it might hit a little close to home for her because of her grandma. But I feel this is a wonderful book for kids and want to recommend it to my friend that is a librarian at an elementary school. I worked at an elementary school for years this is pretty spot on to what kind of mean things kids can do and how much they struggle trying to find their niche.

This is one of the best books I've read for such a Long time. I absolutely loved it. I'm not surprised it's had more than a thousand reviews on Amazon - it's everthing the other reviewers have said, uplifting, life-affirming - just a tremendously positive book. Loved it, didn't want it to finish - completely identified with the central character, loved the rotating viewpoint (always a favourite of mine). Fascinating, involving and a rattling good read.
Incredible, touching book! A MUST read!
Un libro de lectura rapida que uno deberia leer al menos una vez en la vida.

The simplicity is what bewitches me, everything about this book is just raw and true. 
 When I first started to read Wonder, I had no expectations what so ever. A 10 year old boy with a deformed face wasn't someone I imagined becoming so compassionate about. 
 But the futher I came into the book, the more intrigued I became. It became nearly impossible to stop reading. It definitely touches a sensitive subject; our obsession of beauty. Something that is so important in our world, which makes us often forget not to judge a boy by his face. Wonder teaches us the importance of family and friendship, but most of all kindness.

I read this book in about 3 hours. I couldn't put it down until I found out how Auggie's story was resolved. As I read this story I felt heartbroken, sympathetic, angry, and hopeful. I liked all of the characters (except for Julian and his family!!) and the way the author made readers consider their perspectives and the different ways Auggie's condition affected them. I especially got a lot out of the chapters narrated by Via. Although Auggie was the one who had to live with his condition, Via's life was affected in tremendous ways and I saw her as an extremely strong and admirable character. 
 I recommend this book to young and old readers alike, especially if you're uncomfortable with someone who looks a little different. It'll give you some insight and hopefully some empathy as well. After I read the book I went to the author's website: 
 http://rjpalacio.com/index.html 
 There's a cool trailer for the book, discussion questions, and an interview with the author. She explains how she got the idea for the book, which surprised me as it directly relates to a scene in the story. Enjoy!!

This book is about a boy named August or Auggie who was born with not so normal face. Auggie has always been homeschooled until now. His mom want him to start going to a normal school in 5th grade. This is a perceptive account of the effects of deformity, both on the one with the condition and those around him or her. The story is told through the eyes of Auggie, the boy with a strange face, and other children who come into contact with him.

Author: R.J. Palacio 
 Grade Level: 5-7 
 Lexile: 790 
 Meet August Pullman. He was given the short straw and has had to live with the consequences. Auggie is your ordinary, humorous, kind hearted, smart fifth grader...except he was born with a facial abnormality. A severe facial abnormality that has been the cause of unwanted attention since he could remember. 
 Up until the start of the book Auggie's parents have homeschooled him; however, now they decide he's ready for a real, formal education. When the first day of fifth grade arrives, Auggie not so confidently passes through the doors of Beecher Prep, not sure what he'll find on the other side. Luckily, Beecher Prep is a great school with an approachable principal, creative teachers, and some out of this world students! But, like all schools, Auggie must struggle through making true friends, dealing with bullies, and learning all the new rules of school. Imagine how hard it'd be for you to start a new school in fifth grade; now think about having to start a new school with a mismatched face. 
 What I Liked: I couldn't put this book down! It took me two days to read it cover to cover. First, this book is "raw". All of the scenarios could and do really happen, many to students without facial abnormalities. The author doesn't sugar coat...there were times (many times) I gasped to myself while reading! Second, the friendships that were built throughout the book were heart warming. It was great to see/read that students weren't just being nice because Auggie was "different" but because of his true personality. Third, having other narrations throughout the book deepened the entire plot. I loved hearing what Auggie's sister thought about the entire situation, and Jack's feelings too. 
 What Could Have Been Better: No comment. I thought this book was exceptional. I felt like I was part of the family from the beginning and only hope that there will be a sequel! 
 Who Should Read This Book: I believe all ages will thoroughly enjoy this book. Another great book to read with a parent. If you've ever felt left out, bullied, or just plain ugly, you'll be able to relate to Auggie. Auggie will become you're new best bud and I can predict you'll be just as bummed as I was when it's over as I was.

Or when his photo was photoshopped from the yearbook (I mean WHAT?? No parent would be that stupid and shallow, seriously-.-). Also on how it is difficult to be Via with a brother like that..especially the part when Miranda asked if Justin was 'okay' with it...I mean why wouldn't he? It's not like August would affect their relationship in any kind of way? Unless August was a brat who kept bothering Justin, but he's not. So I think things like that are too exaggerated which kind of kills the plausibility. This could've been a great book. In the end though, I would still recommend it to my friends and family :)

Wonder is about 10 year old August Pullman, who suffers from a severe facial deformity. Coddled by his parents for years, he is thrown from homeschooling to fifth grade, middle school. During his first year he meets an assortment of people, friends like Summer and Jack, and crueler students like Julian and Henry. August's appearance at first scares students, but by the end he shows them that people are more than skin deep. 
 Overall, I really liked this book. It was an easy read and the change in point of view was very refreshing. I think the book perfectly captured the essence of ten year old boys and girls, and the hardships of being different. While a huge part of the book focused on the adage "don't judge a book by its cover" I saw the overall theme as the importance of kindness. Everyone in the book is happier when they are kinder, which translates into real life. Being kind isn't hard, and it is always rewarding. I don't think there's any content too strong for a middle school school or older, and I think someone reading it that is the same age as August could connect to him in a way I couldn't.

When given the choice between being right and being kind, choose kind. - Dr Wayne Dyer

I got this book on the same day I attended a youth summit on bullying at which the amazing Alex Libby (from the film Bully) spoke and now his story and this book are woven together in an article on our web site at: 
 http://www.reachandteach.com/s/wonder 
 Here's an excerpt of the review: 
 Masterfully crafted and impossible to put down, this book should be required reading for anyone over the age of ten. Augie, like Alex Libby, is an amazing person with fascinating interests, incredible courage, a wickede sense of humor, loving compassion for others, a willingness to forgive other people's weaknesses and bad behavior, and he can be a lot of fun to be around if you take the time to get past the surface. Augie, though, unlike Alex, has such severe deformities that it takes a lot more work to get past his surface. The story takes you all the way through his first full year at school. One minute you'll be laughing out loud about something that happens and the next minute you'll be crying. A minute later you'll be incredibly angry. The author takes you on a roller coaster of emotions without being heavy handed. 
 Fans of The Neverending Story know that a good book can make you feel like you are the main character. As Augie, you fearfully wonder if anyone will let you sit near them in the lunchroom. You feel betrayed when your best friend says something terrible about you behind your back. You fret that your own sister doesn't want you to come to her school play because she's tired of the spotlight always being on you. Within just a few paragraphs you ARE Augie. 
 Then, R.J. Palacio shakes things up. Suddenly you start to experience being other people in Augie's life: his best friend, his sister, her friend, six other characters in all. This is critically important. Told differently this story could have made you feel very sorry for Augie and furious at the other characters, but you might not see yourself in the circle of people around him. Without getting into the other characters' skin and seeing things through THEIR eyes you might unwittingly continue be part of the problem of bullying instead of being part of the solution. With Wonder, you get to see how one little thing that you do can cause unbelievable pain, or how another tiny simple thing can bring great joy. 
 That was also a message clearly learned by the people who had seen Bully. Every single person in the room had either been bullied or had witnessed another person being bullied. Some admitted to having engaged in bullying against others. Over half, though, despite being witnesses to bullying, had never taken action to stop someone from bullying. Virtually everyone in the room pledged to become "upstanders instead of bystanders." 
 Wonder brings that message home more clearly than any other novel I have read about bullying. One criticism I've seen about the book (spoiler alert) is that it has a happy ending. We know that many bullying stories end in tragedy. One of my greatest coming out gripes was that just about every book about growing up gay ended with the gay person getting beaten up, murdered, or committing suicide. Yes, that can and does happen, but it doesn't have to. My hope is that someone who reads this book will realize that one simple act of kindness, one moment of being a little extra mindful, simply looking at someone long enough to catch their eye and then smiling (which prevented one contemplated suicide that I know of) or giving someone an awkward little wave, or letting an adult know that a child is in terrible pain, could mean the difference between life and death. 
 Augie's fictional story has a happy ending. Alex Libby is really happy with his life now that he has moved to a new home and new school and has been warmly accepted by the people in his new town. Any child can make the difference between happy endings and heartbreaks. Wonder empowers children to make that difference. Simply taking a seat in the lunchroom next to another kid who looks all alone can be a huge gift (and you may find that your next year of lunches are much more fun than they would have been at some other table). We each have the power to transform someone else's world, and at the same time, our own. Sometimes that transformation starts when someone hands you a book and says "you've got to read this." 
 Wonder is among the best books I've ever read and I hope that it becomes even more widely read by children than the Harry Potter series. Real children can't ride a broomstick and win the Tri-Wizard Cup, but they can do amazing magic to keep other children safe and happy. 
 Now..... to read more about how this book and Alex Libby (from the film Bully) merge together, visit our web site at: 
 http://www.reachandteach.com/s/wonder

Everyone lives a normal life with everything ordinary. Well, everyone except for August Pullman, You see, the thing is, August wants to be normal like everyone else, but he can't. He just can't. Every single day of his life is filled with embarrassment. It's not the inside or who he is that matters, it's the outside and what's inside of him that matters to everyone else. But little does August know that his life will only get worse when he starts school at Beecher Prep. There, he will learn to face all the ultimate challenges of life. And at the end, it all comes down to whether or not August's face is a giant gash down his life, or a little scratch on his finger.

Wonder by R. J. Palacio is a book about a ten year old who has many different birth defects. The birth defects affects what his face looks like. He's had many different surgeries to try and help his face deformities. Now his parents want him to go to school for 5th grade. He's been home schooled his whole life. He has to get ready to face the 6th grade bullies and nice kids. He goes to Beecher Prep and makes some friends in Summer and Jack Will. But he also finds some mean kids in Julian. August ends up fighting through it with friends and at the end of the year, wins the Henry Ward Beecher award for courage and bravery. In the end he finds more nice people than mean people. 
 Some things I liked about this book are that it was really interesting to see what August, and other kids who have to deal with this kind of stuff, has to deal with throughout the school year. Some things I didn't really like were that some of the things kid said and did don't really correspond to their age. I don't think at 5th grade some kids would say what they said in the book. What I'm saying is that it is kind of unrealistic what the kids were saying. 
 I would recommend this book to boys and girls. I think I was a little bit too old to read this book. It was a really easy read for me so I would recommend this book to some younger audiences.

I loved this story and consider it a must-read for all parents, and especially parents of children of special needs. It's also a great book to read and discuss in class for grades 4 and up. Palacio does a great job talking from her protagonists point of view, and I did love hearing directly from this sister as well as some of the other characters, but there were perhaps a few too many POVs. August is an exceptional human being in every sense of the word. The juxtaposition of his own vision of himself and his life compared to that of his older sisters presents a wonderful view into the complicated life of a family with a special child. Every note of these intertwined stories rang true. 
 I admit to being disappointed that the parents played such a relatively small role in the story. Though we hear directly from almost every other character (major and minor), but we are curiously never allowed into the parent's inner world. Likewise, I felt that parents who had been so involved in every minute detail of this child's traumatic life, but pretty much left him to fend for himself in his first year of school. Those minor criticisms do not take away from the wonder of reading this book and sharing it with my children. It opened a lot of interesting, intense discussions, as we also have a special needs child in our family.

August (Auggie) Pullman is about to start his very first real school (fifth grade). He has been homeschooled by his mom due to the huge number of surgeries he had to endure since he was a baby. Auggie was born with a severe birth defect enforcing him to deal with more than 20 surgeries in just under ten years. He knows how people look at him whenever they go out, and he's scared of what will happen when he enter the normal school - he won't know anyone there. What if the kids are afraid of him? What if they hate him? Will he have any friends? 
 Anyways, when Auggie's parents take him to Beecher Prep, just a few blocks away from his place to meet the principal, Mr. Tushman, he decides to give it a try. Besides, if it's too bad, he always has the choice to give up and go back to being home-schooled. In the school, he actually has plenty of problems, yet, he also has some of true friends that interact with him no matter how he look like to them. I love Auggie's family, it taught me that no matter how hard your life seems to be, family is the number one people that always stay with you when the world against you. 
 This story also told from multiple viewpoints, and not once does it feel disconnected. In fact, the multiple points of view help plot out the novel very well. I've read some of books about bullying, unfortunate people, and stuffs like that but I don't think I've ever wanted to jump in and save someone as badly as I did with Auggie. This little guy has a very beautiful heart the readers can't help but like and love him. While this is a middle-grade novel, it think it's perfectly suited for any age. In fact, I would suggest kids, teens and adults to read it. It's well-written, powerful and has an important insights for all of us. El final lo senti un poco flojo y a decir verdad dudaria en leer las otras mini novelas que complementan a esta libro pues hubiese sido mejor incluir todo en este libro que dejar por separado las perspectivas de los amigos de Auggie y siendo algunos de los mas importantes como Julian.

This review was hard for me to write because I have some conflicting feelings about Wonder. First of all, it's pretty great. One of my new favorites even. There's tons of ups and downs, much like real life and the changing character viewpoints make you see August from different perspectives, and because the story revolves around August's appearance and how others perceive him I thought it was pretty clever. Here comes the confusing part. While I was reading (especially towards the end) I was a little irked at how perfect everything was falling into place. Don't get me wrong, I love a happy ending but it was a little too perfect- a sunshine, rainbows, and lollipops type of ending. Normally, this would be enough to change my view on the book almost entirely because after all, what's more upsetting than a disappointing ending? However, after rethinking the message of Wonder which is essentially kindness and self-acceptance, I realized the ending is pretty... well, perfect. What's better than sending out a positive message to readers, especially young readers, who the book is aimed at. This books is the definition of teaching that courage, love, and optimism will always be rewarded. 
 Favorite quote: 
 "So doesn't that make the universe a giant lottery then? You purchase a ticket when you're born. And it's all just random whether you get a good ticket or a bad ticket. It's all just luck...maybe it is a lottery, but the universe makes it all even out in the end. The universe takes care of all its birds." 
 -Justin

Is it wrong to feel bad for not giving this entirely well-meaning book about being nice to others a solid five stars? Because for some reason, I feel like a curmudgeon for taking away a star and that I have to over-explain my reasoning. So, let's just start with the positive: 
 This is a great Young Readers novel that expertly exhibits what it's like to look or be different from what is considered "normal" and how we need to not only be nice to other people who are "different" from us but also appreciate them for who they are beyond what makes them "different." This is an important lesson for anyone at any age, but I think it's especially important for children who often lack a filter when they first encounter something or someone that is different from what they have seen or experienced before. I would recommend that this book be required (or at the least highly recommended) reading for kids just because it has such a positive message. 
 Also, it's very well-written on top of the positive message. The writing flows well and it's easy to read this book in a day. The characters are all engaging and well-written. I appreciate that the book reached beyond just Auggie's difficulties trying to live a "normal" life and showcased characters like Summer, Auggie's sweet-natured friend who is being raised in a single parent home after her dad's tragic death, and Jack, another of Auggie's school friends who is a poor kid at a rich kid's school. Auggie is obviously the main character and these side characters revolve around him, but I love that there is a deeper level to explore. Even though Auggie has the most obstacles to overcome in order to feel like he fits in, all of the other characters are dealing with something negative in their life that they struggle to turn into something positive. 
 The reason why I can't give this book the solid five stars is because I wish we could have gotten more about Summer, Jack, Miranda (Auggie's sister's friend), and Justin (Auggie's sister's new boyfriend). They all have their own POV chapters...and then that's it. There's no resolution to the things they are dealing with. I get that this isn't their story, but I kind of hated that the author introduces these emotional dimensions to them and then just relegates them to be another way of someone viewing Auggie. 
 I also thought the main antagonist (Julian) was too one-dimensional. I get that kids can be horrible, but after reading these other side stories, I kept expecting that we would see why Julian is so terrible to Auggie. Instead, the only explanation we get is that his parents are also stuck up and awful. I didn't expect a heel-face turn, but I at least wanted to see a little bit more depth to his character. 
 Overall, despite my criticisms, I do believe that this is an important book that children need to read. It's heart is continually in the right place, and the characters seem so real and grounded. If I was a teacher, I would definitely teach this in my classroom. Since I'm not, I will have to be content with passing it off on my nieces and nephews instead.

"Wonder" racconta la storia di August (Auggie), un ragazzino affetto dalla sindrome di Treacher Collins a causa della quale, come dice il protagonista, "la mia faccia sembra tutta schiacciata". Fin da piccolo Auggie e stato sottoposto a svariate operazioni e ricoveri in ospedale e non ha mai frequentato la scuola, fino a quando la madre decide che e giunto il tempo per lui di frequentarla e lo iscrive per cominciare la prima media. Ovviamente per Auggie la cosa e fonte di grandissima ansia e tantissime preoccupazioni ma tra alti e bassi (tra i quali, l'essere costantemente fissato e indicato da tutti) il primo anno scorre e Auggie, i suoi genitori, la sorella Via e gli amici (vecchi e nuovi) impareranno qualcosa di nuovo. Il punto forte del libro e il fatto che le vicende siano raccontate da vari punti di vista: quello di Auggie, ma anche quello di Via e di altri personaggi. 
 Un libro per ragazzi ma adattissimo agli adulti.

eri ho visto una bambina che leggeva su una panchina e mi sono seduta vicino a lei. Nell'istante stesso in cui mi sono appoggiata, la bambina si e alzata di scatto e prima che fuggisse le ho chiesto cosa stesse leggendo (I diari di Nikki. ndr). Probabilmente era un soggetto particolarmente timido, in caso contrario dovrei considerare l'idea che forse la mia faccia sembra quella di un pedofilo. Fatto sta che mi e venuto in mente August Pullman, il protagonista di "Wonder" affetto dalla sindrome di Treacher Collins, che proprio a causa della faccia ha difficolta a essere accettato. A dieci anni finge di non accorgersi di come la gente abbassa gli occhi quando incrocia il suo sguardo o degli urli involontari di stupore, ma se prima poteva nascondersi al sicuro nella propria casa, adesso che iniziera la prima media dovra imparare a farsi valere. 
 A fine lettura il mio cuore ha detto "crack" e sono d'accordo con lui. C'e qualcosa, in questo romanzo, che lo rende speciale. Non tanto la tematica della malattia e dell'accettazione o lo stile semplice, quanto piuttosto la presenza di piu punti di vista. Il libro si divide infatti in piu parti ciascuna narrata da un personaggio in particolare, col risultato che "Wonder" non e solo la storia di August ma anche la storia della sorella Olivia, dell'amico Jack, di Miranda, Summer e via dicendo. Il miscuglio di vite che ne deriva si converte in un miscuglio di emozioni (mi ha toccata particolarmente l'introspezione di Olivia, costretta ad affrontare l'adolescenza all'ombra del fratello minore). Immedesimarsi diventa ancora piu semplice ed immedesimarsi in una storia cosi difficile puo aiutarci a considerare la realta con occhi diversi. Da leggere assolutamente.

 From what i read, Palacio has a sort of touch and go style of writing where she would talk about an issue and then just dabble about it without offering a resolution. She also failed to use the multiple pov format to her advantage and just made the book really boring. There were also a lot of unnecessary information in this book. 
 Overall, this book was a complete bust for me and wouldn't recommend it at all/

Wonder by R.J. Palacio is absolutely breathtaking in its simplicity. Perfect for middle grade readers, it will pull in anyone who picks it up, and won't let go until the last page is turned... and long after. 
 Wonder himself is a wonderfully (heh) normal kid, who just happens to have a face that makes people pause. The story starts with his own point of view, explaining in a matter-of-fact way how he looks "probably worse than you imagine", and his nervousness about entering school for the first time after being homeschooled his whole life. (He'll be in 5th grade, incidentally.) 
 Wonder takes the reader through many of the basic storyline arcs of great middle grade books before it, such as Beverly Cleary's "Ramona" books, and Judy Blume's Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing, but with a twist. Wonder goes to school, makes friends makes enemies, dresses up for Halloween, goes on a field trip, etc. But because of his unique look, the everyday takes on a stark realism for anyone who has ever felt like an outcast... and then it changes, and takes the reader even beyond that. 
 Points of view shift, and suddenly the reader is in the minds of those "normal" people who are effected by Wonder's place in their own lives: his sister, his friends, even his sister's boyfriend. With each point of view, the reader gains more of a deep, abiding worldview beyond Wonder himself, and thus, beyond their own selves as well. 
 I can't say enough how amazing this book is. Read it. Everyone should read it. I don't care if it's hyped... it deserves it. It deserves everything it can get, and R.J. Palacio is a genius.

Wonder wasn't the greatest book I ever read, but it was pretty good. And, frankly, I think that all kids should read it as it really does teach a lot about communication. 
 The most interesting thing to me was the constant switching of points of view. You get to read everyone's side to the story, and it shows how kids can be bullies sometimes without even realizing it. Auggie acts just like you would expect an under-sized, bullied kid with a disease that deforms his face to act. Jack acts exactly like you would expect a semi-popular 10-year-old to act. Basically, everyone is a pretty accurate portrayal of who they would be in real life. 
 My only beef was that we never really read from the points of view of the parents. I understand that this is a "middle-grade" book, but it still would have been nice to get some insights into the minds of Mr. and Mrs. Pullman.
