 Wonder e un libro molto dolce, uno di quei libri che e giusto leggere, perche insegna ad essere gentili e la gentilezza, al giorno d'oggi, non e mai troppa. 
 Ci sono tante cose che mi sono piaciute in questo libro, in primo luogo il protagonista: August e davvero speciale, e simpatico e divertente e coglie spesso l'occasione per scherzare su tutto, persino sul suo aspetto. Questo rende la lettura piacevole e scorrevole e fa si che Auggie non appaia mai come una vittima. 
 Credo che questa sia una cosa fondamentale: August e un bambino esattamente come tutti gli altri, pensa e agisce come tutti gli altri, solo che ha una faccia un po' diversa. 
 Inoltre e estremamente intelligente e buono, ama incondizionatamente la sua famiglia e i suoi amici, e ben presto, attraverso questa storia, ci insegna che l'aspetto esteriore non conta affatto, quando si e belli dentro. 
 Un concetto scontato? Non credo. 
 Voi come reagireste di fronte a un bimbo come August?

"My mom smiled at me. Her smile kind of hugged me." 
 This is one of the books you want to (and most likely will) read in one-sitting. 
 When I first read the synopsis of this book, I was intrigued. Let me begin by saying this was the first book I read in a long time. I wanted something different to reignite my love for reading again. After finishing this book, I can say this book definitely did that. Like others have mentioned, the characters in this book made me feel nostalgic. 
 August is an innocent, kind-hearted and ordinary boy with an extraordinary boy. He's just seeking to fit in and be like everybody else. However, his outwardly appearance makes it difficult for other kids to genuinely get to know him. The book addresses a lot of important issues about self-esteem, bullying, depression, pet death and coming of age. 
 I think this is the type of book I wish I read in middle school. It inspires us to be more compassionate. 
 Reading this book made me cry, laugh and think. It was witty without trying to hard to be. It maintained its innocent charm while talking about serious topics. As a reader, I felt so much compassion for August. Here he was, in a situation he had no control over. Yet, his resilience and optimism is inspiring to even the oldest reader.

I read this book for my school's book club, and I must say that it is quite a well written book. I mean, there is finally other people's points of views, making the story less boring and one sided (and I really hate one sided books, which don't give a chance for the other characters to make their points clear, because there is always more to an antagonist than just being 'bad' in a well written book). 
 But to be really honest, there are some times that I really don't like August, because sometimes he just gives up and wants attention and extra care from his parents, and times that he is so stubborn that it kind of annoys me. I mean I understand WHY he feels these ways, and it's because he is hurt, but sometimes you just have to stand up a little more for yourself. PLEASE don't scream at me, I'm just being honest. 
 Now, I have to say, my favourite character has to be Julian (you would know if you had the Julian chapter). Because I think in the end, he had such a better character improvement than anyone else, I mean ANYONE. I would have hated the book if he was just the 'common school bully who's rich and snooty to others' cliche, so I am really glad the author did this. 
 Overall I loved this book still.

 I heard the movie is coming out. Some books are better left as books and live off imagination alone...

The verdict: A memorable portrait of human dignity--children's literature that knows kids are smart enough to understand the world they live in. 
 So why add another review to the internet of this already smash-hit, critically-acclaimed novel? Wonder the movie is hitting theaters next month, in case people haven't heard of it. I wanted to read it, but I wasn't sure if I'd take the time to review it. That changed once I started. As a middle school teacher--as a human being--I must champion R.J. Palacio's timeless message. Some books deserve the hype, and Wonder lives up to its name. Parents, your kids must read this book. Read this book with your kids even, then discuss it as a family. It's rare to find literature that distills the complicated themes of life into such simple truths, and a novel that does so makes a powerful treasure. 
 Born with a facial deformity, 5th grader August Pullman enrolls in a private school to attend classes outside his home for the first time. While adults do their best to not notice and students make no secret of their curiosity and horror, Auggie wants nothing more than to just be ordinary. Soon Julian, a teacher's pet when instructors are looking and a horrible bully when they're not, leads a charge to ostracize the new student, and even the friends Auggie thinks he can count on wear masks of their own. Meanwhile, Auggie's sister Via struggles to adjust to a new high school and the pains of growing up. The point of view changes as the narrative unfolds, allowing the voices of Auggie's classmates to intersect and craft a heart-wrenching tour of empathy and human dignity. Written at the middle-grade level, this beautiful coming-of-age story speaks to kids and adults alike. 
 Told in short vignettes with a relatable middle school voice, Palacio's novel captures the rapid change-of-subject and constant ups and downs of life from a kid's point of view. Readers hear first from Auggie, then from his sister Via--whose section beautifully depicts the mess of compassion and resentment that comes with having a sibling who needs special care--and then from the perspectives of two of Auggie's schoolmates, Via's boyfriend, and her ex-best friend. Some expanded editions even include the ebook known as The Julian Chapter, giving voice to Auggie's main tormentor. 
 Nothing about the story feels forced or contrived. Palacio builds her narrative on ordinary conflicts: shifting friend groups, arguments with parents, a sick family dog. Put together, the chapters touch on all aspects of identity from race and class to which lunch table a student belongs. At times I wanted a bit more pep in the plot; nothing terrifying or particularly unusual happens, especially when compared to other classic novels of its type. Yet the pedestrian tour of Auggie's universe works to extend its humanity. While one might think Wonder is just a metaphor for how we all feel like the outcast sometimes, it bravely goes beyond that expectation by featuring themes about kindness and courage. The other narrators see just as much transformation as August does, and at times they're even more likeable. Creative in form and content, Wonder is a twenty-first-century tale that bridges gaps across generations, fighting for every kid to take a turn in the spotlight. Recommended for middle school and high elementary school readers, especially for class or book reports.

Thank you @R. J. Palacio for this wonderful novel. It's not merely about the incidents of the novel itself, but for making us in the shoe of those kind of people who face problems in this world for a 'defect' they are not responsible for. 
 It was nice to be in the mind of a deformed child, to know how he perceives the world around him, the challenges he face when people- both adults and children- give him the face of astonishment and detest. 
 I always wondered of how children with Down syndrome think of people around them. I had that cousin who passed away at his teenage. Because his face always seemed smiling, I keep thinking how he think or wether he understand when some people look at him with disgrace, does he feel it, is he aware of what some might say! Of course he wasn't like August, the kid in the novel, but for a second I recalled his face and the common faces all kids with their deficiency have. 
 My prayers for all kids (and people) with such defects. Our societies became so ugly that a 'normal' person can hardly survives from others' looks, so how about them!

A few weeks back, I ranted a bit (okay, a lot), about the absence of aspirational heroes in Middle-Grade fiction these days. For the most part, I'm still feeling tantram-y about the general state of things in this regard. 
 HOWEVER-- 
 WONDER, by R.J. Palacio, goes a long way to correct this. 
 Let's face it: there are books and then, there are BOOKS! And, by the latter category, I mean those rare gems that not only captivate us but also change us---for the better---by us having had the good fortune to have read them. 
 WONDER is such a wonder. It tilted my orbit, just a touch, and here's why: 
 The story is about Auggie, a normal kid with a horrifying facial deformity. Yes, I said *deformity* although, like everyone else in the story, the impact of that word diminishes for the reader as we, too, get to know this remarkable little man. 
 The story unfolds through the eyes of first, Auggie, then in sections devoted to the people who know and love him. It's a study in perspective---how each character views and copes with the daunting challenges of everyday life when you're always the center of unwanted, and sometimes hostile, attention. 
 The writing is sublime perfection. Simple, and yet, so, so powerful. Palacio's voice carries the sophisticated eloquence needed to lift such a melancholy story into the realm of inspiration. 
 One of my favorite passages: 
 "Why do I have to be so ugly, Mommy?" I whispered. 
 "No, baby, you're not..." 
 "I know I am." 
 She kissed me all over my face. She kissed my eyes that came down too far. She kissed my cheeks that looked punched in. She kissed my tortoise mouth. She said soft words that I know were meant to help me, but words can't change my face." 
 My heart aches, just typing that. 
 There is so much wisdom in this book. I'm in no way surprised that so many have plucked pearls from its text. I am particularly fond of this one: 
 "I think that there should be rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." 
 Wouldn't we all be better people if we gave more of those and received at least one? 
 Read this book. You'll be grateful you did.

I read this book for school, and can i just say that this book is great. It's written for upper elementary school/lower middle schoolers but it's a good story. Something that everyone should read. 
 Characters: Auggie is so cute and he breaks my heart. His accounts on his life in school and home. Geez...Auggie is also extremely funny and isn't afraid to laugh at his own condition. Though sometimes I just want to shelter him from the world, but I know that he needs the life experience in such a school setting and such. My favorite character in the book was I would have to say Summer. She was just so sweet that I got a tooth ache from her. I don't know what it was about her, but she's just one of those people who are good and that's it. They're made out of goodness. 
 Plot: This book is all about bullying and making friends and 5th grade and all the stuff that comes with it. Now we've all been there right? 5th grade was one of those years where you started to find yourself and such. But for Auggie as you can imagine it's 10x worse. It's the slow shift of kid's feelings, attitudes, and learning how to be kind to one another. It has good lessons that anyone of any age can learn from. I surely learned from this, and I've been through all the grade school learning and such. 
 Setting: This is set in New York City, modern times....not much I can say about it really...pretty average setting...eh... 
 Overall I give this book 5/5 stars because it tugged on my heartstrings and just...Auggie...

I was "assigned" this to read for my work and I wasn't looking forward to what I thought would be a sappy brave-kid story. But I have to admit, the author won me over.The narrators (the point of view changes) are natural and engaging. I would recommend this to young adults/teenagers.
it's good so far and kinda sad at the same time!!!

My sixth- and fourth-grade children loved this book. My wife said I would too. And so I did. 
 Feeling sorry for yourself? Thought that middle school was thought on you? Then put yourself in the place of young Augie as he entered 5th grade with a disfigured face that disgusts and stuns his classmates. It is a struggle for both Augie and his classmates as their worlds are turned upside down, testing their character. This book will at times will make you fume or cry, and question the ability of humans to transform themselves. 
 We don't find out until well into the book what Augie's face looks like, fittingly delivering the message that it's what's inside that counts. Is it a message that his classmates will come to understand? 
 We can see what's going on inside the heads of Augie, his classmates, his family and others who enter his life as the book is written from all their points of view. That's not something I usually appreciate, but Palacio handles it so deftly that it succeeded beyond my expectations.

This is a really special book, beautifully written, insightful and sensitive. The only slight disapointment was that the end wavered into dangerous territory of being a bit too sickly-sweet. Fortunately it was saved by Auggie's wonderful sense of humour. 
 Not many books are getting 5 stars from me these days, but Wonder made me both laugh and cry, so that last star is well earned.
This is such a wonderful read! The plot, the writing and the precepts are all fantastic! I highly recommend for everyone!

Just finished reading Wonder and think everyone should read this book. This is a real love story - a story of parental love, sibling love, and deep platonic love. I read this because it was on my daughter's assignment list last year (6th grade). I feel in love with all the characters, the main character, Auggie, his family, his friends and his teachers. For those who have had these kinds of experiences, you will love being reminded of those moments in your own life. And for those who have never had those moments, this book describes them so well, you will feel like you are in the middle of it all and will wish you had these moments. 
 Give yourself a gift, read Wonder. And then give it to someone else. That is my precept for January.

Wow. This book is a must-read for any older elementary school kid through elderly adult. It hits all the right emotional notes, yet isn't overly sentimental. The characters are rich and believable, and the story is compelling--at times gut-wrenching, at times very funny--and beautifully written. My 9-year-old recommended this book to me, saying it was the best thing she'd ever read. My mother read it in a day and immediately had to talk it out with her. I was next, and I am so happy to be part of our growing family "club" of "Wonder" readers. This book is a classic in the making.

Wonder is an excellent book about compassion and kindness told from multiple perspectives. It's also a really really funny book in certain sections. It was amazing. 
 P.s. this should be mandatory reading for all middle schoolers.

I loved this book and recommend it to all of my tutorial students, ages 10 and up, without reservation. I've even used it as a writing prompt because this story of an outcast-turned-hero, and the remarkable way he changes those who encounter and initially fear or avoid him, is so thought-provoking and stylistically beautiful. The characters are thoroughly realized--so real that I actually miss them, and want to revisit them even though I finished this book very recently! Thematically rich (prejudice, bullying, disabilities, bystanders, friendship, family, adaptation and personal growth...), this story is perfect for teachers to assign, knowing that kids will undoubtedly love and be enriched by this praiseworthy book. In fact, two of my own writing students recommended Wonder to me! This book gets five stars for me without any contemplation because it is MEMORABLE and REREADABLE, offering depth and an uplifting, honest look at how people learn to accept differences and look past appearances, despite initial fear, revulsion, disdain, or shyness. A book to touch readers of all ages, with no content for anyone to object to, in my opinion. I finished this book and wished I had written it.
I really love this book. It's about how to see the world from the point of view of the kids. Very recommended.

Is it a trip down memory lane to the horrors and pressures of middle school or is it a daily reminder of how we live? Wonder is considered a young adult book, but transcends all ages. From the heart-wrenching tail of a facially deformed 10 year old to the glory of a tale of human triumph and lessons on kindness for us all, Wonder is one of those books you will read and carry with you for a long time. 
 You'll embrace the characters. You'll recognize their pain. You'll cry and laugh with them. Invite them into your house and see for yourself! 
 Two of my favorite quotes from the book: 
 "Shall we make a new rule of life....always try to be a little kinder than is necessary?" Mr. Tushman 
 "I think it should be a rule that everyone in the world should get a standing ovation at least once in their lives." Auggie

WOW, this is a "Wonder"ful book! 
 I love YA and especially good YA. 
 This story is about a 10 year old boy named August (Augie) Pullman. 
 He is a sweet young boy with a loving sister, mom, dad, dog and a rare autosomal congenital disorder. 
 So rare that it occurs in 1 out of 50,000 births. 
 Treacher Collins-Franceschetti Syndrome or mandibulofacial dysostosis. 
 Augie is home schooled until he is 10 when his mom thinks he should attend a "real" school. 
 The story of his 5th grade year is full of sorrow, tears, resentment, and finally friendship which knows no deformity. 
 Augie is a real hero. 
 He continuously puts one foot in front of the other and walks through his life. 
 Everyone should read this book to learn a little more about themselves and how they treat others. 
 A Must Read!!!!

Now, the only thought that aches my heart is the fact that I'm going ahead with four stars instead of five. This is undoubtedly right there on top of my all time favorites; and my honest answer for this is because I felt that the author could have done a lot more justice to such a strong central character as "August Pullman". Else I would have gladly without further a doubt gone ahead with a five starer. 
 I did go over the reviews by readers prior to picking up this book, and like one of the reviews said "Wonder is one of those rare books that makes you want to hug everyone in it so tightly that they'll have no doubt about how much you love them...and beyond that, it also makes you want to reach out and hug the whole world." quote unquote. And this seriously is true with R.J. Palacio's "Wonder". 
 Definitely a read that is worth the praise.
